justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:78 for suggestions.
Parallel loans from Persian خراب / xarāb (< Arabic 'destruction')
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ({ref EWAia} II:370-371, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:593 no. 10265).
Iranic lexemes, ultimately derivatives from PIE *temH- 'to be dark' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:82, {ref EWAia} I:627). Cf. Avestan tąθra- ᾽darkness᾽.
Lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit haḍḍa- 'bone', only attested in lexicographical works. Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:807 no. 13952; {ref KEWA} III:573).

Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn' (Proto-Iranic *sauč- 'to burn, emit flames'). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:338-340, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:208-210).

notes: This seems to be a compound with the first part "or" being the actual word for "cloud" (given variously as orǝ́, owrǝ́, warǝ́, which derives from common *nebʰ- (cf. NP abr).

justificationDiscussion: Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to be cold, freeze' ({ref NIL} 416-417, cf. {ref EWAia} II:641, {ref Cheung 2007}:336-337, {ref ALEW} 1008-1009, {ref Derksen 2015}:439-440, {ref LIV²} 323).

notes: The Pashto form ra-tlal literally means "to go hither" (cf. rā in Morgenstierne 2003: 69).
justificationDiscussion: A derivative of Proto-Iranic *tač- 'to flow, run, walk' + preverb rā- 'hither' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:81-82, {ref Cheung 2007}:372-374), further to PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, to flow' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:610-611, {ref LIV²} 610-611).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'run' in /cognate/5199/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/3259/, 'river' in /cognate/5249/ 'swell' in /cognate/1881/, 'turn' in /cognate/3066/.

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ({ref LIV²} 439-440). Note that the semantic extension 'to disappear' as a euphemism 'to die' appears to be a post-Anatolian innovation, where the Hittite cognate mer-/mar- retains the original meaning 'to disappear' (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:8).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥-, the inherited Indo-European word for 'dog' ({ref NIL} 436-440, {ref EIEC} 168, cf. {ref Melchert 1989}, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:505-506, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:187, {ref Adams 2013}:190, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:520-522, Beekes 2010}:811, {ref EWAia} II:674-675, {ref ALEW} 1054-1055, {ref Derksen 2015}:455, {ref Kroonen 2013}:256, {ref de Vaan 2008}:87, {ref Matasović 2009}:181).

notes: Klingenschmitt (2000: 216 fn. 86) sets these words together with Pashto caṣǝl in relation to Old Ind. *cakṣ.
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *čaš- 'to drip; to drink, eat'? ({ref Cheung 2007}:35-36).

notes: Horn (1893: 201) suggests a derivation from the verbal root 'wart' "to turn". If so, all those languages that would preserve *#w would have to have loaned this word from languages like Persian.

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯š- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Vedic √ghoṣ- 'to sound'), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ({ref Cheung 2007}:115-116, {ref EWAia} I:518-519; {ref LIV²} 200 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s-).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'to consume, eat', further connections uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:147-150, cf. {ref LIV²} 609).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Iranic, Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂ōu̯ió- 'egg', which may be a vr̥ddhi-derivative to the Indo-European word for 'bird' *h₂eu̯-i- ({ref EIEC} 176, cf. /cognate/856/); alternatively {ref Schindler 1969} reconstructs an adpositional construction *ō-h₂uiom 'towards the bird'. For individual branches, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1681, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:439, {ref Orel 1998}:497, {ref Holm 2011}:60, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:41, {ref Bailey 1979}:30, {ref ESSJa} 1:61-64, {ref Derksen 2008}:27, {ref Kroonen 2013}:17, {ref de Vaan 2008}:438, {ref Matasović 2009}:50.

According to {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:77, as though from an Iranic diminutive *str̥-kā, and in view of the meaning 'planet' (cf. Avestan star- 'star', Vedic stár- 'id.) probably to be further connected to the Indo-European word for 'star', *h₂stér- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:755-756). The same semantic development is also attested in Modern Indic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:330 no. 5798).

notes: Bailey (1979: 56) suggests a relation to *kap- "grey" in O.Ind. kapila- and to the blue/grey word *kapauta-, weiter dazu EWAia I: 303
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kapā̆- 'fish', generally found in Eastern Iranic as a replacement for inherited Proto-Indo-Iranic *matsi̯a- 'fish' ({ref ESIJa} 4:241-242, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:56, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:458). Perhaps further to an Indo-Iranic root *kap- 'grey', maybe in Vedic kapila- 'tawny, brown, reddish', but cf. {ref EWAia} I:300-303.

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *pénkʷe 'five', generally considered to be the Indo-European inherited numeral for 'five' (not attested in phonetic spellings in Anatolian languages). See {ref Eichner 1982}:383-569 for extensive discussion, cf. also {ref Adams 2013}:415-416, {ref Beekes 2010}:1172-1173, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:409, {ref Demiraj 1997}:315-316, {ref Orel 1998}:316, {ref EWAia} II:65-66, {ref ALEW} 756-767, {ref Derksen 2015}:351, {ref Derksen 2008}:400, {ref Kroonen 2013}:140, {ref de Vaan 2008}:509, {ref Matasović 2009}:176-177.

notes: The Avestan word varǝδa- refers to a plant "v[ie]ll[eicht] Rose" (Bartholomae 1904: 1369). The Sogdian word "ward" means "rose", which is a common meaning of 'flower' in most modern Iranic languages. Also attested in Parthian as wār.
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes reflecting Proto-Iranic *u̯arda-, traditionally further connected to Vedic √vardh- 'to increase, grow' and further to an IE root *u̯erdʰ- (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:399-400, {ref IEW} 1167), but cf. {ref EWAia} II:520-521, {ref LIV²} 228 against connections of this proposed root outside of Indo-Iranic.

notes: Wakhi: There is no reason to assume an Indic loanword, as the phonology is completely regular and the lexeme is robustly attested in Iranic.
justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃mei̯gʰ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1077, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:466, {ref EWAia} II:374-375, {ref ALEW} 649, {ref Derksen 2015}:317, {ref ESSJa} 21:93-94, {ref Derksen 2008}:338-339, {ref EWNl} 3:140, {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

The reflexes found in the individual languages reflect different generalised accent/ablaut classes of PIE *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur- 'four'. For extensive discussion cf. {ref Eichner 1982}:298-382, cf. also {ref Adams 2013}:703, {ref Beekes 2010}:1471-1472, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:546-547, {ref Orel 1998}:173-174, {ref EWAia} I:526-527, {ref ALEW} 483-485, {ref Derksen 2015}:241, {ref ESSJa} 4:97-98, {ref Derksen 2008}:87, {ref Kroonen 2013}:133, {ref de Vaan 2008}:505-506, {ref Matasović 2009}:179.

The Iranic lexemes in this class represent light verb constructions with Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ({ref ESIJa} I:140-143) constituting the semantic head. Cf. 'ice' in /cognate/5932/ for further etymological discussion.

notes: Morgenstierne (2003: 53) quotes Henning (BSOAS 12/1: 56) for *migda-, cf. Sogdian mγδˀk. The COBL comment on Sogdian "fruit" considers it possible for this word to be a Semitic loanword. The reason that Sogdian in COBL does not show mγδˀk is that the source that was used to fill the Sogdian list uses another word instead.
justificationDiscussion: As though continuing a Iranic stem *migda(ka)- 'fruit'; a probable loanword from West Semitic, cf. Biblical Hebrew מֶגֶד 'choice produce', Syriac maγδā 'fruit', etc. (cf. {ref Henning 1947}:56).
loan_notes: Cf. Biblical Hebrew מֶגֶד 'choice produce', Syriac maγδā 'fruit'

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯āstra- 'pasture, grass' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:93 {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:403, cf. {ref Bartholomae 1904}:1414, 1416).

Hellenic, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from a basic PIE root *k̑er- (cf. {ref Nussbaum 1986} for extensive discussion of formations in the meaning 'head' and 'horn' derived from this root), cf. also {ref Beekes 2010}:641, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:237, {ref EWAia} II:638-639.

notes: Original meaning "to observe".
justificationDiscussion: Ultimately a derivative of PIE 1. *ser- to look after, protect' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:10, {ref Cheung 2007}:129, cf. {ref LIV²} 534).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:23 for a conjectural loanword hypothesis from Persian.

notes: cf. Parthian iškar- and Zoroastrian Middle Persian wiškar "hunting ground, wilderness"; Cheung (2007: 345) puts this verb to an Iranic root *skar- "pursue, drive, look for (the cattle)".
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives and light-verb constructions continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *skar- 'to pursue, drive'; no known etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:346).

notes: Not in Morgenstierne (2003)

justificationDiscussion: Nuristani and Iranic lexemes fom Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰand- 'to laugh' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:200 no. 3815, {ref Cheung 2007}:442-443).
Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg' (North and West Germanic, but no attestation from Gothic), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:48, {ref Kluge 2011}:105-106).

Tocharian, Greek, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ({ref LIV²} 215-216, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:683-684, {ref Beekes 2010}:505, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:356-357, {ref EWAia} I:594, {ref Cheung 2007}:222-223, {ref ALEW} 338-340, {ref Derksen 2008}:652, {ref de Vaan 2008}:685-686, {ref Matasović 2009}:67).

Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from a PIE root *men- ({ref KEWA} II:575-576, {ref ESSJa} 20:158-161, {ref Derksen 2008}:330). Quite possibly (but not certainly) also cognate with Proto-Germanic *mannan- in /cognate/8248/, cf. further discussion in that cognate set.
Derived from IE *gʷou̯- 'cow' ({ref Bailey 1979}:89, cf. {ref EWAia} I:478-480).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: PIE *méh₂ter- or *mā́ter, which is *mā́ + suffix *-ter-; ultimately related to /cognate/1421/, cf. also /lexeme/10415/ and /cognate/1156/, for Indian words, see Turner 1931: 499; see also comment on 'woods' in /lexeme/26112/

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷerH- ({ref EWAia} I:487, {ref ESSJa} 7:29-31, {ref Derksen 2008}:177-178, cf. {ref ALEW} 332-333).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes reflecting the Indo-European inherited word for 'name' (cf. {ref EIEC} 390-391). Certain details of the reconstruction of the PIE word are disputed (cf. {ref Stüber 1998}:53-59), but a general shape *Hneh₃-mn̥ with different ablaut variants of the root and suffix tend to be agreed upon. Debate on the identity of the initial laryngeal as *h₁ or *h₃ hinge on interpretation of the Doric Greek forms in ἐνυμα- versus the ὄνομα forms more commonly found elsewhere (cf. esp. discussions of {ref EWAia} II:35-37, {ref Beekes 2010}:1084-1085). Cf. also {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:517-519, {ref Adams 2013}:288, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:96-97, {ref Demiraj 1997}:165, {ref Orel 1998}:87, {ref Derksen 2015}:556-557, {ref Derksen 2008}:212, {ref Kroonen 2013}:382-383, {ref de Vaan 2008}:412-413, {ref Matasović 2009}:38).

Iranic words for 'narrow' are better derived from *temk-, cf. already Horn 1893: 89 and Cheung 2007: 377f. Derivation from *tanu-ka- (thus e.g. Korn 2005: 168) might be formally possible but does not really explain the semantic difference found in Persian tang 'narrow' vs. tanuk 'thin'. None of the Iranic forms meaning 'narrow' require *tanu- or *tana-, while there is good evidence for a root *tank-/tanč- 'tp strain, press'.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *neu̯- 'new' ({ref NIL} 524-526, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:605, {ref Adams 2013}:287-288, {ref Beekes 2010}:1009, {ref Hübschmann 1897}:479, {ref EWAia} II:25, {ref ALEW} 690-691, {ref Derksen 2015}:330-331, {ref ESSJa} 26:9-13, {ref Derksen 2008}:357, {ref Kroonen 2013}:389, {ref de Vaan 2008}:416, {ref Matasović 2009:293). Not the same root as PIE *neu̯- 'to nod, tilt (the head)' (cf. {ref LIV²} 455-456)

Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- ({ref HED A+E/I}:431-435, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:404, {ref {EWAia} I:424, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:230-231, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:276).
Parallel loans from Persian پوزه / pōz(e) 'muzzle, snout' (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:68).

The lexemes in this set continue a basic root *Hoi̯- 'single, alone' with different adjectival suffixes ({ref LIPP 2}:587-591): (1) *Hoi̯-ko- (Indic, cf. {ref EWAia} I:262-263, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:119 no. 2462); (2) *Hoi̯-u̯o- (Iranic, cf. {ref ESIJa} I:134-136, {ref EWAia} I:262-263); (3) *Hoi̯-no- (Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, Celtic, cf. {ref ALEW} 1233-1236, {ref Derksen 2015}:501, {ref ESSJa} 6:11-13, {ref Derksen 2008}:138-139 212-213, {ref Kroonen 2013}:11, {ref de Vaan 2008}:642, {ref Matasović 2009}:304-305),

Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from a PIE root *men- ({ref KEWA} II:575-576). Quite possibly (but not certainly) also cognate with Proto-Germanic *mannan- in /cognate/8249/, cf. further discussion in that cognate set.

notes: loaned into Armenian as քարշ kʿarš, cf. /cognate/627/
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷels- 'to draw a furrow' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:319-320, {ref LIV²} 388-389).

Lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:208-210).
Parallel loans from Persian دريا / daryā; cf. 'lake' in /cognate/2771/ and 'sea' in /cognate/2011/.

notes: Bailey (1979: 111a) assumes a -xa- suffix for this word. Klingenschmitt (2000: 203) calles this "Suffixtausch" of *-xa- and *-ka-
comp. /lexeme/1883/
cf. Vedic síkatā-, later sigatā- unlike Old Persian θikā- 'pebbles', cf. also cognate/7858/
justificationDiscussion: The correspondence of Indic initial *s- with Iranic *θ-, *s- is irregular, suggesting a possible parallel loan from a third-source or lexical contamination within Indic or Iranic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:772, no. 13386); {ref EWAia} II:728, however, considers the Indic and Iranic forms not to be separated.

notes: if cogn. with Pasht. gəraw- 'to scratch', then fr. IE *kreu- and cognate with 'hit' in /lexeme/18777/

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Arabic بحر / baḥr 'sea' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:110).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *derb- 'to join, tie, sew (together)', and further to PIE ?*derbʰ- 'to bind together, braid' (cf. {ref LIV²} 121).

Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *√tej- 'to sharpen' from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'prick, be sharp' ({ref EWAia} I: 645, 668-669, cf. {ref LIV²} 592-593). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes attached to this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:332-333, no. 5839.

Modern Hellenic lexemes, ultimately from an Ancient Greek diminutive formation πέσκος 'skin, rind'. Further etymology uncertain cf. {ref Andriotis 1999}:1168, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:890, {ref Beekes 2010}:1180.
Continuing a derivative of PIE *kemb- 'small', assuming a connection with Proto-Iranic *kamb- 'lesser' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:439, cf. {ref Schmitt 2014}:198-199 s.v. OPers. *kamna-).

Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'to make smoke' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:895, {ref EWAia} I:795, {ref ALEW} 243, {ref Derksen 2015}:145, {ref ESSJa} 5:203, {ref Derksen 2008}:132, {ref de Vaan 2008}:249, {ref Matasović 2009}:111, {ref Irslinger 2002}:61; cf. {ref LIV²} 158).
Loanword from Arabic صاف / ṣāf

Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯afra- 'snow', derivatives of an Indo-Iranic root *u̯ap- 'to disperse, scatter' to which there are no certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:418-419,{ref Bailey 1979}:305-306, {ref EWAia} II:503-505, {ref KEWA} III:145).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: element NE- (neg. prefix), for the compound strategy see also comment on 'few' in Slavic lexemes of /cognate/1940/

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂stḗr-, *h₂ster- ́ 'star' ({ref NIL} 348-354, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:326, {ref Adams 2013}:701, {ref Beekes 2010}:156-157, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:120-122, {ref Clackson 2017}:110, {ref EWAia} II:755-756, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:330 no. 5798, {ref Lehmann 1986}:322, {ref Kroonen 2013}:478, {ref de Vaan 2008}:585, {ref Matasović 2009}:355). For a proposed deep etymological connection with PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry up/wither by heat' cf. {ref Pinault 2007}.

notes: Not listed in Morgenstierne 2003.

justificationDiscussion: Light verb constructions with loanwords from Arabic فكر / fikr 'thought' as the semantic head.

Lexemes from PIE *trei̯- 'three' ({ref Eichner 1982}:142-297, {ref LIPP 2}:803-805, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:872-873, {ref Adams 2013}:339-340, {ref Beekes 2010}:1502, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:261-262, {ref Demiraj 1997}:387-388, {ref Orel 1998}:463, {ref EWAia} I:675-678, {ref ALEW} 1125-1126, {ref Derksen 2015}:471, {ref Derksen 2008}:449, {ref Kroonen 2013}:546-547, {ref de Vaan 2008}:628-629, {ref Matasović 2009}:390).

Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref LIV²} 373, {ref EWAia} I:437, {ref KEWA} I:289 for discussion of potential Slavic comparanda). {ref LIV²} reconstructs as though from ?*k⁽ʷ⁾su̯ei̯bʰ- 'to swing (oneself)'.

notes: The alleged similarity with cognate 503 is probably accidental. Korn (2005: 189) seems to follow Horn (1893: 121) who derives these words from the PP of the Old Iranic verb *drang- "make strong/firm". Cf. Cheung (2007: 76) *dregʰ-.

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing PIE *du̯o-, *du̯i- 'two' ({ref Eichner 1982}:1-141, {ref LIPP 2}:168-174, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:826-827, {ref Adams 2013}:651, {ref Beekes 2010}:359, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:268-269, {ref Demiraj 1997}:151-152, {ref Orel 1998}:79, {ref EWAia} I:761-763, {ref ESIJa} II:481-490, {ref ALEW} 235-237, {ref Derksen 2015}:143, {ref ESSJa} 5:185-186, {ref Derksen 2008}:130, {ref Kroonen 2013}:529, {ref de Vaan 2008}:183, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:6, {ref Matasović 2009}:110)
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE root noun *h₂ep- 'water, river' ({ref NIL} 311-317, {ref EWAia} I:81-82, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:19 no.407).
Probably a loanword from Turkic, but not fully certain (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:259-260).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: PIE *kʷi-, kʷé-, *kʷó-, kʷéh₂-; cf. /cognate/339/, /cognate/1107/, /cognate/242/, /lexeme/6637/; PIE n. sg. interrogative pron. *kʷí-d 'what?', pronominal adj.*kʷó-d 'which (n.)?'

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *peth₂- 'to spread out' ({ref Bailey 1979}:507, cf. {ref LIV²} 478-479).

notes: Cognate class A should be reserved for borrowings from Persian, not for Persian itself.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} I:427).

Two variants *kʷr̥mi- and *u̯r̥mi- in the same meaning 'worm' are generally reconstructed for PIE. The variant *u̯r̥mi- attested in Germanic and Italic might have been secondary from *kʷr̥mi- (cf. {de Vaan 2008}:665), but it may also be possible that the two lexemes were a rhyming pair already in Indo-European poetic language (cf. {ref Watkins 1987}:288). Cf. also {ref Demiraj 1997}:225-226, {ref Orel 1998}:197, {ref EWAia} I:394-395, {ref ALEW} 493-494, {ref Derksen 2015}:246, {ref ESSJa} 4:171-172 {ref Derksen 2008}93-94, {ref Matasović 2009}:181-182.

notes: origin obscure
related to /lexeme/24821/

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry out (by means of heat)'. The Germanic forms in this class are generally connected to this group although the morphological derivation remains obscure, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:54, {ref EWA 1}:365-366, {ref Kluge 2011}:64, 260, {ref Kroonen 2013}:38. Cf. also {ref Lubotsky 1985}:6. For the IE root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 257-258, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:318-319; see also {ref EWAia} I:182-183). For Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes connected to this class cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:67 no.1476.

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *baka-, possibly to a root *bʰeg- 'to bend, arch', but there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic ({ref EWA 1}:418, {ref Kroonen 2013}:48, {ref Kluge 2011}:80-81).

Derivatives from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (to pieces)' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:144-145, {ref de Vaan 2008}:138, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560), often considered to be a dental-enlarged form of PIE 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' (cf. {ref LIV²} 556-7).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: elements TO/TOMU, DAT, DI AND þE = dem. pronoun 'that' as in /cognate/318/

notes: from PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'to pound, to mash' (Kroonen 2013:187, Kluge 2002:375, ALEW 374; not in LIV²).
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *grauta- 'strong, thick, big', further from PIE *gʰrou̯d-o-, cf. the Germanic strong verb *greutan- 'to grind, crush' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:187, 189, {ref Kluge 2011}:376-377, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:256, {ref Seebold 1970}:242, cf. {ref ALEW} 374).

Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fly_N' in /cognate/5414/, 'wing' in /cognate/343/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/224/, 'swim' in /cognate/8317/, 'hair' in /cognate/1902/, 'feather' in /cognate/2263/.

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *bītan- 'to bite, be sharp', further derived from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' ({ref LIV²} 70-71, {ref Kroonen 2013}:65, {ref Lehmann 1986}:68).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'bitter' in /cognate/5262/, 'sharp' in /cognate/2894/ and 'split' in /cognate/935/; poss. also connected to 'worm' in /cognate/3146/.

justificationDiscussion: Germanic lexemes generally connected to Latin sordēs 'dirt' and derivatives (cf. {ref IEW} 1052, {ref Lehmann 1986}:333, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:574-575, {ref Orel 2003}:392; tentatively {ref Kluge 2011}:833; cf. also {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:637, {ref de Vaan 2008}:576 cited in /cognate/4865/) as though from a PIE o-stem adjective *su̯ordo-. If these lexemes go back to the same source, then they may be a post-PIE innovation in Germanic and Italic. [Not {ref Kroonen 2013}].

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *blōda- 'blood'. The further root etymology remains uncertain, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:76-77, {ref Kluge 2011}:135-136, {ref Kroonen 2013}:68-70 for various proposals.
Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg' (unattested in Gothic), further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:105-106, {ref Kroonen 2013}:48).
Germanic lexemes reflecting PIE *h₁eh₁t-mon- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:119-120, {ref EWA 1}:393-394, {ref Kluge 2011}:67, cf. {ref EWAia} I:164).

Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *brinnan- 'to burn'. The Indo-European root etymology remains unclear: either to (1) PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ({ref LIV²} 92-93, {ref IEW} 166-7) or (2) *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ({ref LIV²} 219-220, {ref IEW} 493-5); cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:77-78; {ref Seebold 1970}:137-138, {ref EWA 2}:342-345.

Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 676, {ref ALEW} 1242-1243. Cf. {ref ALEW} 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and {ref Matasović 2009}:427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic cognates. Cf. also {ref Kluge 2011}:994-995.

The IE root underlying the Germanic forms in this class is generally reconstructed as *⁽g̑⁾el- on the basis of Germanic and Italic correspondences (cf. {ref LIV²} 185). The reconstruction of a palatovelar or plain velar depends on whether one additionally accepts cognacy with Balto-Slavic forms (cf. Lith. gelumà 'frost', Ru. gólotь 'Glatteis'), cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:288-289, {ref Ringe 2017}:109. The Germanic forms are considered by some scholars (cf. {ref Orel 2003}:209) to be related to Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xoldъ 'cold', but the correspondences of Slavic initial *x and medial *d to Germanic *k and *d is irregular. Consequently the connection of Slavic *xoldъ to the Germanic and Italic lexemes from IE *⁽g̑⁾el- must remain at least uncertain, if not outright rejected.

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:1001 s.v. Zahl; {ref Kroonen 2013} postulates *dolH- following {ref Kloekhorst 2008} who compares the Germanic forms via ON telja, OE taljan 'to tell' with Hitt. tallii̯e/azi 'to pray, evoke (a deity)'. The connection between the Germanic words and the Hittite verb as well as Greek δόλος 'bait, trick' is accepted by {ref Kroonen 2013}. However, the situation may be more complex with several similar roots side by side, cf. the new entry of *del(H)- ‘ziehen, anziehen’ in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} where it supposes the Hittite and Greek forms to belong together but not the other words mentioned here.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *snīþan- 'to cut'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:443-444, {ref Kluge 2011}:820, {ref Kroonen 2013}:462).

Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. {ref EWAia} I:154 and {ref Kroonen 2013}:97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion.

The IE root etymology of Proto-Germanic *daujan- given here follows {ref LIV²} to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:90-91 (but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. {ref LIV²} 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of {ref Kluge 2011}:919 s.v. Tod).

The root etymology in this set follows {ref LIV²} 549 and the latter of the two possible etymologies suggested by {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1011 to a PIE root *skabʰ- 'to scratch, shave'. Cf. however {ref Beekes 2010}:1342-1343 favouring a substrate origin.
From Early Modern Dutch vijs; further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref EWNl} for discussion.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *drinkan- 'to drink'. Further etymology uncertain; a proposal to connect it with Lithuanian drė́gti 'to become moist, to thaw' to a basic root *dʰreg- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:103) has not been widely accepted ({ref Seebold 1970}:165-166, {ref Lehmann 1986}:94-95, {ref ALEW} 226-227).

The reconstruction of the Proto-Germanic form of this adjective is problematic, therefore connections outside of Germanic are difficult to ascertain (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:157-158, 162-163; {ref Kroonen 2013}:100).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *stauba- 'dust', a derivative of the strong verb steuban- 'to scatter, drift', further etymology generally considered uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:474, {ref Lehmann 1986}:328, {ref Kluge 2011}:878, 884, {ref Kroonen 2013}:475). Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:478 s.v. *steuban- ~ *stūban- proposing a connection to Lithuanian siaũbti 'to dash about' via *tséubʰ-ié- (with metathesis of initial *ts- > *st-).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂au̯s-os-, *h₂us-es- 'ear' ({ref NIL} 339-343, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1130-1131, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:637-638, {ref Demiraj 1997}:415, {ref Orel 1998}:501, {ref ALEW} 74, {ref Derksen 2015}:71, {ref Derksen 2008}:507, {ref de Vaan 2008}:63, {ref Matasović 2009}:48-49).

Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *erþō-, generally considered a dental-stem to a PIE root *h₁er- seen elsewhere in Ancient Greek ἔρα 'earth', Welsh erw 'field', cf. also the Old High German hapax ero 'earth' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:18, {ref Kluge 2011}:253-254, {ref Kroonen 2013}:118-119, cf. also {ref Beekes 2010}:449).

Anatolian, Greek, Armenian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat' ({ref LIV²} 230-231, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:261-263, {ref Beekes 2010}:375, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:644, {ref EWAia} I:61-62, {ref ALEW} 269-270, {ref Derksen 2015}:157-158, {ref Smoczyński 2005}:183-184, {ref ESSJa} 6:53-54, {ref Derksen 2008}:154, {ref Kroonen 2013}:119, {ref de Vaan 2008}:185-186, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:196, {ref Matasović 2009}:113).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes continuing or derived from PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' ({ref NIL}, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:78-79, {ref Beekes 2010}:1077-1078, {ref Babinotis 2010}:826, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:22-23, {ref Orel 1998}:405, {ref Holm 2011}:60-61, {ref EWAia} I:42-43, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:2 no. 43, {ref ALEW} 25-27, {ref Derksen 2015}:47, {ref ESSJa} 32:41-42, {ref Derksen 2008}:365, {ref de Vaan 2008}:425)

Germanic lexemes continuing preverb *pe-/po- + PIE *h₃elh₁- 'to decay, perish' ({ref Neri 2007}, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:125-126, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}; formerly reconstructed as *peh₃lH- 'to fall' in {ref LIV²} 463-464).

Passive form of English 'to scare', continuing Middle English skerren, and ultimately a loanword from Old Norse skirra 'to frighten; to shrink from', cf. also Old Norse skjarr 'timid, shy, afraid of' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}, {ref de Vries 1977}:494).
loan_notes: Loaned into Middle English from Old Norse skirra "to frighten; to shrink from, shun; to prevent, avert"

justificationDiscussion: Germanic lexemes, generally considered derivatives of PIE *pek̑- 'to pull hair, fight' ({ref LIV²} 467, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:190-191, {ref EWA 3}:108-112, {ref Kroonen 2013}:134).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Baltic, Germanic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *péh₂-u̯r̥, *ph₂-u̯én-, an inherited r/n-heteroclitic nominal stem (cf. {ref NIL} 540-545, {ref EIEC} 202, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:613-614, {ref Adams 2013}:421-422, {ref Beekes 2010}:1260-1261, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:426-427, {ref Kroonen 2013}:151, {ref de Vaan 2008}:500).
Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pisk- 'fish', cf. {ref IEW} 796, {ref Kroonen 2013}:142, {ref de Vaan 2008}:467-468, {ref Matasović 2009}:142.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cognate with 'fly' in /cognate/2504/ and 'float' in /cognate/1226/, also related to 'swim' /cognate/1181/.

justificationDiscussion: Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing different derivatives from PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:70, {ref de Vaan 2008}:227-228, {ref Matasović 2009}:67-68, cf. {ref LIV²} 88).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fleugan- 'to fly', continuing a derivative from a root *pleu̯k- that is generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:146, {ref EWA 3}:385-388).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fly_N' in /cognate/5414/, 'wing' in /cognate/343/, 'bird' in /cognate/186/, 'swim' in /cognate/8317/, 'hair' in /cognate/1902/, 'feather' in /cognate/2263/.

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ({ref NIL} 526-540), cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:653-654, {ref Adams 2013}:432, {ref Beekes 2010}:1227-1228, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:534-535, {ref EWAia} II:77-78 {ref Kroonen 2013}:152, {ref de Vaan 2008}:462, {ref LIV²} 458).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'leg' in /cognate/2783/, 'stand' in /cognate/6813/, 'fall' in /cognate/1126/, 'lie' in /cognate/8225/, 'sleep' in /cognate/9252/.

justificationDiscussion: Germanic and Celtic lexemes from PIE *preu̯s- ({ref LIV²} 493-494). The connection of the Celtic lexemes to this class follows {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:137, {ref Matasović 2009}:140, but cf. doubts in {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:24-25, {ref EIEC} 287. For Germanic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:154-155.

Italic and Romance lexemes continuing nominal derivatives of PIE ?*bʰreu̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'to enjoy, use' ({ref Untermann 2000}:297-298, {ref de Vaan 2008}:244-245, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:303). The attestation of this lexical root is restricted to Italic and Germanic (cf. {ref LIV²} 96).

Precise connections outside of Germanic are disputed. For the purposes of cognacy, this class follows the reconstruction of {ref LIV²} with possible but uncertain connections to ?*g̑ʰeHb- (cf. OIr. gaibid), but cf. the hypothesis of {ref Kortlandt 1992}:104-5, followed by {ref Kroonen 2013}:172-173, who suggests a remodelling of earlier *ga-ef- from *k̑o(m)-h₂ep-.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Possibly related to 'take' in /cognate/5345/ (cf. notes in LIV²). Alternatively possibly connected with *h₁ep- 'seize' according to Kortlandt (1992:104-105).

justificationDiscussion: Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *gōda- 'suitable, good', a derivative of PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:162-163, 184, {ref EWA 4}:694-697, cf. {ref LIV²} 195).
Possibly (but not certainly) cognate with Latin grāmen 'grass' in /cognate/8369/. Cf. discussion in citations below.

A verbal adjective from the strong verb *grōan- 'grow', cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:260-261, {ref Kluge 2011}:378, {ref Kroonen 2013}:191-192. Extra-Germanic connections unclear, but perhaps further connected to Lat. grāmen 'grass', but the latter may also be connected with IE *gras- 'fressen' (cf. discussion in /cognate/8369/, and in {ref Seebold 1970}:242-243, {ref Kroonen 2013}:191-192.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Kroonen 2013}:535; cf. for a suggestion to Greek τράμις 'space between the anus and genitals, perineum' and also {ref Kluge 2011}:181, suggesting to Greek τόρμος 'hole, socket').

notes: Derivation within (and therefore further connections outside of) Germanic uncertain.
justificationDiscussion: Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Frequently considered a derivative of the strong verb *hinϸan- 'grasp, seize' with the original sense of the word being *'grabber', but there are no clear morphological parallels for the stem formation, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:255-256, {ref Lehmann 1986}:176-177, {ref Kluge 2011}, {ref Kroonen 2013}:207-208, 227 for further discussion.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: from the same root as 'this' and 'that', see in /cognate/2435/. see also comment on 'other' in /lexeme/19763/

justificationDiscussion: The cognacy of the Greek and Germanic forms is generally agreed, but the derivation of the forms from a common IE proto-form is disputed. An explanation from a compound stem *h₂k-h₂ou̯s-i̯e- 'is sharp-eared' is commonly considered (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:71), but this analysis remains uncertain (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:55). For references to older literature, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:50-51; {ref Lehmann 1986}:180-181.

The only extra-Germanic correspondences are found in Baltic (cf. Lith. sver̃ti 'to weigh') which could go back to an original IE root *su̯er(H)- (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:578-579, {ref Kroonen 2013}:499, {ref ALEW}:998-999).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *ko-, ke-; the same root as in 'he', 'this' and 'that', cf. e.g. /cognate/2435/

notes: Cf. Skt. kaláyati , Gr. kéllō 'drive', Lat. celer 'fast'. This root apparently meant 'drive'; the connection of the Gmc. word is based on a semantic shift 'drive cattle' > 'graze cattle (pasture)' > 'guard', etc. The Gmc. formation is unique among the representatives of this root. Apart from the formal problems, we have to assume a dental extension in Gmc. *hal-d-.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: PIE *kʷi-, kʷé-, *kʷó-, kʷéh₂-; same root as in 'who', 'what, 'if', cf. /cognate/2748/, /cognate/160/

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. {ref EWA 5} s.v. OHG jagôn with extensive discussion of previous proposals.
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:271, {ref EWA 5}:195-199 for further discussion).

IE root etymology unclear. {ref LIV²} s.v. ?*dʰreb-, considers the forms to be possibly connected with OCS drobiti 'to splinter, pulverise' but regards this connection as uncertain. {ref Seebold 1970} and {ref Kluge 2011} see no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. {ref Kroonen 2013} derives from via a backformation to iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip' and accepts a root etymology with OCS drobiti, but reconstructs from *dʰrebʰ- to avoid reconstructing PIE *b.

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑neh₃- 'to perceive, recognise' ({ref LIV²} 168-170, cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:160-161, {ref Malzahn 2010}:609-611, {ref EWAia} I:599-601, {ref Cheung 2007}:466-467, {ref ALEW} 1311-1313, {ref Derksen 2015}:519-520, {ref Derksen 2008}:546, {ref Kroonen 2013}:311-312)

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *mari- 'lake, sea', further from PIE *mor-i- 'id.'. Generally considered a western Indo-European isogloss, but cf. a possible further attestation in Iranic via Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:354-355, cf. {ref EIEC} 503-504, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:68-69).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed; likely to be of onomatopoeic origin. Cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:257-258, {ref Lehmann 1986}:185, and {ref Kroonen 2013}:228 for various proposals and references to further literature.

The Tocharian, Hellenic, and Germanic lexemes in this class are generally considered derivations from PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom', although certain derivational details remain disputed. Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 88, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:415, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1232-1233, {ref Beekes 2010}:1596-1597, {ref Kroonen 2013}:66). It is possible, but uncertain that Latin folium and the Romance lexemes continuing it belong here, cf. further discussion in /cognate/8247/.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. discussion in {ref EWA 5}:1172-1175.
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯p- 'to stick' ({ref LIV²} 408-409, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:326-327, {ref Kroonen 2013}:335-336).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Perhaps to the PIE word for 'liver' *(H)i̯ekʷ-r/n-, if certain irregular sound changes took place (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:565, {ref Kroonen 2013}:336). An alternative possibility is an original meaning 'fat', if compared to the root of Gk. λιπαρός 'oily, fatty, greasy' if in Germanic an adjective was substantivised as similarly in Romance from Lat. (iēcur) fīcātum (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:565; {ref EWA 5}:1082-1084).

The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated (cf. esp. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:819-821, {ref EWAia} I:728-729), the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is, however, generally agreed (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:819-821, {ref Demiraj 1997}:184-185, {ref Orel 1998}:130, {ref EWAia} I:728-729, {ref ALEW} 392-393, {ref Derksen 2015}:199-200, {ref Derksen 2008}:133, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:360-361, {ref Kroonen 2013}:327, {ref de Vaan 2008}:348). The reconstructed root form for this class follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *flaiska-, without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref EWA 3}:370-371, {ref Orel 2003}:104, not in {ref Kroonen 2013}).
Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'to be(come) high, to rise up' ({ref NIL} 30, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:60, {ref Delamarre 2003}:87, {ref Matasović 2009}:77, {ref LIV²} 78-79).

Generally considered to be of IE origin, but the precise IE etymology is disputed. From PIE *ment-, if {ref Kroonen 2013}:376-377's reconciliation of the two earlier possible etymologies from {ref IEW} (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:261) is correct. Etymology outside of Germanic otherwise uncertain; cf. {ref Boutkan & Siebinga 2005} for extensive discussion of alternative hypotheses.

Armenian, Indic, Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'to hinder, restrict' ({ref NIL} 301-303, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:94-95, {ref EWAia} I:39, {ref Derksen 2008}:388, {ref Kroonen 2013}:28-29, {ref de Vaan 2008}:42, {ref Matasović 2009}:36, 214)

Connections outside of Germanic disputed: the principal hypotheses are (1) an adjectival formation based on a local particle *nē- (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:647) or (2) a lengthened-grade formation to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, obtain; accomplish' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:387). See {ref Faltings 2010}:409-412 for further discussion (not in {ref Heidermanns 1993}). The Scandinavian and Modern English forms in this class are originally the comparative degree of the adjective which had taken over the meaning of the positive degree, i.e. *'nearer' > 'near' (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Germanic and Italic lexemes as though from PIE *kólso- 'neck' (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:95, {ref Kroonen 2013}:205, {ref EWA 4} 777-780, {ref de Vaan 2008}:125). Root etymology disputed. Root reference form for this set follows the reconstruction of {ref Ringe 2006}:95. If ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ({ref LIV² } 386-388), then these lexemes may be root-cognate with the Baltic lexemes in /cognate/1868/, but the etymology of the Baltic lexemes is less than certain; cf. further discussion in that cognate class. Alternatively a root etymology has been proposed to PIE *kelH- 'to tower, soar' (cf. {ref EWA 4} 477-480).

Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *nógʷt-/*négʷt- 'evening, night', a dental-stem derivative of PIE *negʷ- 'to become dark, dawn' ({ref NIL} 504-513, {ref LIV²} 449, cf. {ref {Beekes 2010}:1027, {ref Demiraj 1997}:283-284, {ref Orel 1998}:282-283, {ref EWAia} II:2-3, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:242, {ref ALEW} 683-684, {ref Derksen 2015}:327-328, {ref ESSJa} 25:175-177, {ref Derksen 2008}:355, {ref Kroonen 2013}:381, {ref de Vaan 2008}:416-417, {ref Matasović 2009}:293-294). The Brythonic lexemes in this class are sometimes considered to be (parallel?) loanwords from Latin (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:293-294, {ref Deshayes 2003}:539-540), but by others to be inherited (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:121, {ref NIL} 509n10). The assumption that these lexemes are inherited has been followed here.

notes: Vedic -:nas(-a)- as a second member in compounds confirms *H in root onset, ergo PIE *Hnas-
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes continuing an Indo-European word for 'nose' traditionally reconstructed as *(H)nā̆s- ({ref EIEC} 395, cf. {ref IEW} 755), although Leiden school of Indo-European reconstructs an ablauting s-stem *neh₂-s- (cf. {ref Kortlandt 1985b}:119). The traditional reconstruction has been followed here for the purpose of a root reference form. For individual branches cf. {ref EWAia} II:30-31, {ref ALEW} 711, {ref Derksen 2015}:336-337, {ref ESSJa} 25:212-216, {ref Derksen 2008}:357, {ref Kroonen 2013}:383, {ref de Vaan 2008}:400)

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *alda- '(grown) old', further from PIE *h₂el-tó-, a verbal adjective to PIE *h₂el- 'to nourish, rear' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:29-30, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:97-98, {ref Kroonen 2013}:20, cf. {ref LIV²} 262).
Germanic lexemes continuing denominal verbal formations from Proto-Germanic Proto-Germanic *spila- 'play, game', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:867, {ref Kroonen 2013}:467).

Etymology uncertain ({ref EWNl}). Often assumed to be connected in some way with Proto-Germanic *dragan- 'to draw, pull, carry' (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:506-507, {ref Kroonen 2013}:522) but the sound changes necessary to make this connection are irregular.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *regna- 'rain', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:284, {ref Kluge 2011}:753, {ref Kroonen 2013}:408).

Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:350-352, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:441-442, {ref Kroonen 2013}:408-409, {ref de Vaan 2008}:517-518, {ref Matasović 2009}:310-311, cf. {ref LIV²} 304-305).

Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ({ref EWAia} I:252-253, II:425, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:459, {ref Lehmann 1986}:231, {ref Kroonen 2013}:408, {ref de Vaan 2008}:517-518, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:241 no. 2648, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 3:87-91, cf. {ref LIV²} 304-305).
No certain cognates outside of Germanic, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:381; {ref Orel 2003}:303. No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

notes: *ureip-, urīp- < IE *uer- 'turn, twist, bend' (Walde 1930: 2.280)

justificationDiscussion: Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sal- 'salt' ({ref NIL} 586-590, {ref EIEC} 498, {ref IEW} 878-879, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:742, {ref Beekes 2010}:177, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:24, 40-41, {ref ALEW} 887-888, {ref Derksen 2015}:548-549, {ref Derksen 2008}:461, {ref Kroonen 2013}:425, {ref de Vaan 2008}:535, {ref Matasović 2009}:319). The root is difficult to reconstruct; the traditional reconstruction as *sal- has been followed here after {ref NIL}, but note in order to avoid reconstructing PIE *a the Leiden school reconstructs a hysterokinetic l-stem: nom.sg. *séh₂‑l‑s, acc.sg. *sh₂‑el‑m, gen.sg. *sh₂‑l‑ós ({ref Kortlandt 1985b}:119, {ref Beekes 1995}:177, cf. also {ref Rieken 1999}:424n2103). The Germanic forms in this set show an extension in *d which may be on analogy to *su̯eh₂d- 'sweet' /cognate/5109/, alternatively the *-d- might be explained as a compound with the root *deh₃- 'give' (cf. {ref ALEW} 886-887 s.v. Old Lithuanian saldùs 'sweet' and further discussion in /cognate/5157/).

Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Baltic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE 2. *sekʷ- 'to say' ({ref LIV²} 526-527, cf. {ref ALEW} 884-886, {ref Derksen 2015}:387, {ref Kroonen 2013}:420, {ref Schumacher 2004}:565-568, {ref Matasović 2009}:328).
According to {ref Kroonen 2013}:302 from Proto-Germanic *krapp/bōn- ({ref EWNl} *krabbōn-), as though from PIE *grobʰ-neh₂- (cf. {ref LIV²} 187).

Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *mor-i- 'lake, sea' (ESSJa} 19:227-229, {ref Derksen 2008}:325, {ref Kroonen 2013}:354-355, {ref de Vaan 2008}:365, {ref Matasović 2009}:277; cf. also {ref Derksen 2015}:305-306 for Lithuanian mãrios 'isthmus; (dial.) sea'). Generally considered a western Indo-European isogloss, but cf. a possible further attestation in Iranic via Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' (cf. {ref EIEC} 503-504, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:68-69).

Often connected to PIE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' under the assumption of a semantic development 'follow with the eyes'; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:431-432; {ref LIV²} 525-526; {ref Seebold 1970}:387-388. Probably to be connected with Hitt. šākuu̯a- 'eye' in /cognate/3305/.

Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *seh₁- 'to press in' → 'to sow' ({ref ALEW} 906-907, {ref Derksen 2015}:392, {ref Derksen 2008}:446, {ref Kroonen 2013}:428-430, {ref de Vaan 2008}:557, {ref Matasović 2009}:336, cf. {ref LIV²} 517).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *nēan- 'to sew', a strong verb continuing PIE *sneh₁- 'to spin (wool, etc.)' ({ref Kluge 2011}:647, {ref Kroonen 2013}:385, {ref LIV²} 571-572, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:447).
Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 557-558, {ref Kroonen 2013}:440-441. Possibly an extended form of the root *(s)ker- 'to cut', cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:487.
An early loanword into West Germanic from Latin curtus 'short' (cf. {ref EWA 5}:927-929, {ref Kluge 2011}:551).
Proto-Germanic *singwan- 'to sing', probably from PIE *sengʷʰ- 'to sing, proclaim' ({ref IEW} 906-7, {ref LIV²} 532, {ref Kroonen 2013}:437, {ref Seebold 1970}:392-393).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sed- 'to sit (down), seat onself' ({ref LIV²} 513-515, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:926-927, {ref Beekes 2010}:376, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:506, {ref EWAia} II:692-693, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:422 no. 7467, {ref Cheung 2007}:125-126, {ref ALEW} 895-896, {ref Derksen 2015}:391, {ref Derksen 2008}:445, {ref Kroonen 2013}:434, {ref de Vaan 2008}:551-552, {ref Matasović 2009}:325-326).

Germanic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *pel-. The Germanic forms in this class reflect *pel-no- ({ref EWA 3}:122-126, {ref Kroonen 2013}:135), while the Italic/Romance forms reflect an i-stem *pel-ni- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:455, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:525 no. 6377).

Etymology disputed ({ref Kluge 2011}:498; {ref EWA 5}:581-584). According to {ref Heidermanns 1993}:322-323, followed by {ref Kroonen 2013}:290, to the root underlying OIr. glenaid 'adhere, stick' and also in Gk. γλίνη 'sticky substance', OCS glьna 'mud, clay', to PIE *g̑lei̯- / *glei̯- 'smear, stick' (cf. {ref LIV²} 190 s.v. *gleiH- 'bestreichen, kleben bleiben').
Without clear etymology outside of Germanic; proposed Baltic cognates could well be loans from Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:410; {ref ALEW} 878-879; cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:379-380).

Lexemes derived from the Proto-Germanic. strong verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke' ({ref Seebold 1970}379-380, {ref Kluge 2011}:748, {ref Kroonen 2013}:406, 410). No further accepted etymology outside of Germanic, cf. further discussion in /cognate/299/.

Balto-Slavic and Germanic lexemes generally connected to a common IE root *gleh₂dʰ- ({ref ALEW} 345, {ref Derksen 2008}:162-163, {ref Derksen 2015}:183, {ref Kluge 2011}:361, {ref EWA 4}:478-480, {ref Orel 2003}:135), but cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:179 who prefers an alternative etymology.
Originally an agent noun to the same root as OHG slingan ({ref Kluge 2011:808}, {ref Kroonen 2013}:453). The Germanic forms must continue a Verner variant *-gʷ- (cf. {ref LIV²} s.v. *slenkʷ-, n1).

Tocharian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *snei̯gʷʰ- 'to stick, adhere to' ({ref NIL} 622-625 {ref EIEC} 530, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:689-690, {ref ALEW} 951, {ref Derksen 2015}:416, {ref Derksen 2008}:457, {ref Kroonen 2013}460, {ref de Vaan 2008}:409-410, {ref Matasović 2009}:349, {ref LIV²} 573).

notes: maybe also related to Romance forms in /cognate/2083/?
justificationDiscussion: Reconstructing a common IE root for these forms is extremely difficult as the forms in various branches likely underwent deformations or reformations among individual daughter languages due to onomatopoeia or phonotactic reasons. The root reference form for this class tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 583-584, which reconstructs PIE *spti̯eu̯H-.

notes: IE *prem- besides *pres- (Buck 1949: 575)

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ({ref LIV²} 590-592, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:879-880, {ref Beekes 2010}:601, {ref EWAia} II:764-766, {ref ALEW} 981-982, {ref Derksen 2015}:430, {ref Derksen 2008}:465-466, 468, {ref Seebold 1970}:464-465, {ref Kroonen 2013}:473, 477, {ref de Vaan 2008}:589-590, {ref Matasović 2009}:338).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:562-563, {ref Orel 2003}:383, {ref Kluge 2011}:887, {ref Kroonen 2013}:476, 487 for various proposals and references to further literature.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *staina- 'stone', reflecting PIE *stoiH-no- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:472, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:546, {ref Lehmann 1986}:321-322). Further derived from PIE *sti̯eH- 'to become stiff' (following the reconstruction of {ref LIV²} 603).

Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ({ref EWAia} I:252-253, II:425, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:350-352, {ref Kroonen 2013}:408-409, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:566, {ref de Vaan 2008}:517-518, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:241 no. 2648, {ref Thurneysen 1946}:119, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:96, {ref Matasović 2009}:308).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- 'sun' ({ref NIL} 606-611, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:516, {ref EWAia} II:742, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:782 no. 13574, {ref  Abaev 1959–1995} IV:246-248, {ref ALEW} 892, {ref Derksen 2015}:390, {ref Derksen 2008}:479-480, {ref Kroonen 2013}:463-464, {ref de Vaan 2008}:570, {ref Matasović 2009}:324). For an influential analysis of the nominal formation cf. {ref Beekes 1984}.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'to swell', without certain connections outside of Germanic ({ref Seebold 1970}:489-490, {ref Kroonen 2013}:499).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *swimman- 'to swim, float', further etymology uncertain ({ref Seebold 1970}:491-492, {ref Kroonen 2013}:501).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sterta- 'tail', possibly a dental-enlarged root *sterd- to PIE *ster- 'stiff' but uncertain, cf. {ref EWNl}, {ref Kluge 2011:877, 883, {ref de Vries 1977}:547, {ref Orel 2003}:376).

notes: Sinhalese etana from éta- < *(h₁)ei- + *só- ~ *tó-

justificationDiscussion: A Germanic-Celtic isogloss with further connections uncertain (cf. {ref IEW} 1057, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:76, {ref Matasović 2009}:377, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:617-618, {ref Kroonen 2013}:537).
Germanic forms identical to Old Latin tongēre 'to know' < *ton⁽g̑⁾-éi̯e- (cf. {ref LIV²} 629, {ref IEW} 1088, {ref Kroonen 2013}:533-534, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:353).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: originally a 2pl YOU_PL form, used for YOU_SG due to a politeness effect, ultimately identical to /cognate/5822/

justificationDiscussion: Germanic and Slavic lexemes generally derived from PIE *u̯ergʷ- 'to throw' (cf. {ref LIV² 689, {ref Derksen 2008}:515, {ref Kroonen 2013}:581).
Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *bʰendʰ- 'to bind' ({ref LIV²} 75, {ref EWAia} II:208, {ref Cheung 2007}:4-6, {ref Kroonen 2013}:64).

Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- 'tongue'. The forms as attested appear to have undergone multiple contaminations in several daughter languages: (1) The Tocharian forms reflect *ĝn̥dʰu̯éh₂- ← PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- by metathesis of place of articulation (cf. {ref Ringe 1996}:45-6, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:79, {ref Adams 2013}:147). (2) Balto-Slavic lexemes appear to have lost initial *d- already at a common Balto-Slavic stage ({ref Derksen 2008:159}, {ref Derksen 2015}:285, cf. {ref ESSJa} 6:74-75). (3) Armenian, Italic, and Lithuanian lexemes appear to have independently contaminated with initial l-, probably under influence of their respective regular reflexes of PIE *lei̯g̑ʰ- 'to lick' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:307-308, {ref de Vaan 2008}:343, {ref Derksen 2015:285). (4) Celtic forms appear to have undergone a distance assimilation *dengʷāt- > *tengʷāt-  ({ref Matasović 2009}:368). (5) Indo-Iranic forms have a similar preform *ºg̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*ºg̑ʰuh₂- to the form *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂- found in other branches, but instead appears to i-reduplicate the initial syllable (cf. notes to Ved. jihvā́- in {ref EWAia} I:591-593). Additionally, the Iranian forms appear to show a different Anlaut from the Indic ones (Indic *j-, Iranian *s-). This small deviation aside, the Indo-Iranic forms appear to go back to basic form *ji-ju̯aH-/*ji-juH- (vel sim.) in Proto-Indo-Iranic. This apparent reduplication could be secondary reanalysis of an original *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰuh₂- > *daju̯aH-/dajuH- as a reduplicated form *ji-ju̯aH-, (cf. forms such as *kʷe-kʷl-o- > cakra- 'wheel'), cf. {ref Mallory & Adams 2006}:175. For the purposes of root-cognacy, The Indo-Iranic forms are treated in this class as cognate with the other forms which are more clearly from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-u̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂-. The least disturbed forms appear to be found in Germanic, for which see {ref Lehmann 1986}:349, {ref Kroonen 2013}:526-527.

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing an inherited word for 'tooth', widely considered to continue a participle *h₁d-ónt- to the verbal root *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', lexicalised as 'tooth' already in PIE ({ref NIL} 208-220, {ref LIV²} 230-231, {ref EIEC} 594). Under this explanation the original Ancient Greek form would be continued by Aeolic ἔδοντ-, which underwent vowel assimilation in other dialects. The Leiden School of Indo-European reconstruction alternatively reconstructs a distinct root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' following {ref Kortlandt 2003}:77, who argues that it would better account for ὀδών much more straightforwardly, and it would also much better account for the Ancient Greek privative adjective νωδός 'toothless' < *n̥-h₃d-ó-, (expected †νηδός < *n̥-h₃d-ó-); as for Aeolic ἔδοντ-, it only occurs in late grammatical texts and could have itself been created on the basis of an analogy to Greek ἔδ- 'eat'. For individual branches, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:776, {ref Beekes 2010}:1049, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:1049, {ref EWAia} I:693-694, {ref ALEW} 174-175, {ref Derksen 2015}:115, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:169, {ref de Vaan 2008}:166-167, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:62-63 {ref Matasović 2009}:90).

Etymology outside Germanic disputed; either (1) to PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- ({ref Lehmann 1986}:55-56, {ref Orel 2003}:32, 39; for the root cf. {ref LIV²} 98-100); or (2) to PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ- and related to the IE word for 'upper-arm' *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ-u- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:47).
Possibly a variant to the more widely attested root *terh₁- 'bore, rub' ({ref LIV²} 632), cf. {ref LIV²} 647 s.v. ?*treh₁-, {ref Kroonen 2013}:546, {ref Seebold 1970}:519.
Lit. 'to break (open)'.

Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Generally compared with Baltic material via Lith. klaũpti 'kneel down', etc. (cf. {ref LIV²} 364, {ref Kroonen 2013}:229, 232), but the connection is uncertain on semantic grounds (cf. {ref ALEW} 502-503}).  For older hypotheses, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:259-260, {ref Lehmann 1986}:382-383.

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Iranic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ({ref NIL} 196-199, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:541-542, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:556-557, {ref Demiraj 1997}:298, {ref Orel 1998}:303, 525, {ref EWAia} I:513, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575). Most lexemes in this class (Greek, Armenian, Iranic, Germanic) reflect a PIE adjectival stem *gʷʰer-mó-. Albanian is only root-cognate with the rest of the forms and has a distinct stem formation (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:298 for further discussion).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'bitter' in /cognate/6086/, 'burn' in /cognate/2243/, 'day' in /cognate/3850/, 'fire' in /cognate/396/, 'sun' in /cognate/2299/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain; occasionally attempted to be derived from the root *u̯ed- underlying the IE word for 'water' (cf. /cognate/335/, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575), but such a secondary formation does not easily explain the strong stem formation in Germanic ({ref Seebold 1970}:539, {ref Kluge 2011}:972).

notes: a PIE variant is cognate/2394/
justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Albanian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ód-r̥-, *u̯ed-en- 'water', a heteroclite r/n-stem derived to PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref NIL} 706-715, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:987-988, {ref Adams 2013}:627-628, {ref Beekes 2010}:5126-1527, {ref Demiraj 1997}:401-402, {ref Orel 1998}:482-483, {ref EWAia} I:215-216, {ref ALEW} 1185-1186, {ref Derksen 2015}:488, {ref Derksen 2008}:523, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575-576, {ref Untermann 2000}:815-816, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:21, {ref Matasović 2009}:394).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:264, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:422, {ref Kroonen 2013}:384 for various proposals.

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯eit- 'to shine brightly' {ref EWAia} II:679-680, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:316-317, {ref Kroonen 2013}:267, cf. {ref LIV²} 340). The Germanic forms irregularly reflect final *-t-, but this is generally explained by a secondary gemination *-tn- > -tt- or secondary influence from Gmc. *swart- (< IE *su̯ord-o-, cf. /cognate/188/), cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:980.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:678-679 and {ref Kluge 2011}:980 for several possibilities of formal correspondences with Vedic forms vītá-  (from different etymological sources); the etymology to a compound *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- 'set apart' favoured by {ref Lubotsky 1994}:203-204, {ref Kroonen 2013}:584-585 requires the assumption of a glottalic model of interpretation for the PIE voiceless stops within the framework of the Leiden School, where traditional *d is assumed to have been pre-glottalized *[ˀd], and susceptible to dissimilation to *h₁, which is interpreted as glottal stop *[ʔ].

notes: comp. fr. ECHT 'marriage' and GENOT 'companion'

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:368, {ref Adams 2013}:546, {ref EWAia} II:542, {ref ALEW} 1226-1227, {ref Derksen 2015}:496, {ref Derksen 2008}:519-520, {ref Kroonen 2013}:587, {ref de Vaan 2008}:662-663, {ref Matasović 2009}:47, cf. {ref LIV²} 287).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/1662/, 'sun' in /cognate/5156/, 'swell' in /cognate/3436/, perhaps also 'wind' in /cognate/9440/.

justificationDiscussion: Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fly_N' in /cognate/5414/, 'bird' in /cognate/186/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/224/, 'swim' in /cognate/8317/, 'hair' in /cognate/1902/, 'feather' in /cognate/2263/.

notes: cf. NHG FEGEN 'brush, sweep', maybe ON FAGA 'adorn, clean' (Kluge)

justificationDiscussion: Traditionally derived from PIE *pro-u̯o-, remodelled in PGmc. as *frau̯i̯a- 'the one in front, lord' (cf. {ref NIL} 645, {ref Kluge 2011}:314). Doubted by {ref Kroonen 2013}:153) on account of phonological difficulties.
Usually considered a loanword into Romance from West Germanic *bosk- 'forest' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:131, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:192-210).

Two variants *kʷr̥mi- and *u̯r̥mi- in the same meaning 'worm' are generally reconstructed for PIE. The variant *u̯r̥mi- attested in Germanic and Italic might have been secondary from *kʷr̥mi- (cf. {de Vaan 2008}:665), but it may also be possible that the two lexemes were a rhyming pair already in Indo-European poetic language (cf. {ref Watkins 1987}:288). Cf. also {ref Lehmann 1986}:397, {ref Kroonen 2013}:600).
Iranic and Germanic lexemes from a PIE heteroclite stem *i̯eh₁-r/n- ({ref EWAia} II:98-99, {ref ESIJa} 4:130-131, {ref Kroonen 2013}:273).
Usually derived to PIE *bʰer- 'carry' {ref Meyer 1891}:27, {ref Huld 1984}:40-41, {ref Orel 1998}:18 (but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:92, {ref Holm 2011}:51-52 with some skepticism).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *meg̑- 'big' ({ref NIL} 468-478, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:917-918, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:458-460, {ref Demiraj 1997}:250-251, {ref Orel 1998}:240, {ref EWAia} II:337-338, {ref Kroonen 2013}:361-362, {ref de Vaan 2008}:358-359, {ref Matasović 2009}:253). For Tocharian lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this class, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:479-480.

Since {ref Meyer 1892}:18 compared with Armenian jag 'small bird' with various proposed reconstructions to reconcile the comparison (for further discussion cf. {ref IEW} 409 s.v. *g̑ʰāgʷʰ-, {ref Demiraj 1997}:429-430, {ref Holm 2011}:52-53, and {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:239 most recently proposing a pre-form *g̑ʰu̯eh₂gʰV-). Alternatively {ref Huld 1984}:135-136, {ref Orel 1998}:525 assume that the forms are an Oriental Wanderwort comparing also Persian zāq 'chough', but cf. {ref Holm 2011}:52 rejecting this hypothesis on the grounds that it is not a typical case of a Wanderwort. {ref Demiraj 1997}:430 remains unconvinced and instead suggests an onomatopoeic origin.
Probably a loanword from Latin capessere 'to seize, snatch at' ({ref Meyer 1891}:176, {ref Orel 1998}:164, {ref Holm 2011}:53), but other Latin loan sources are theoretically possible.
loan_notes: Borrowed < Lat capessere ~ capissere (inf.) 'to seize, snatch at', or < Rom. *capsare based on Lat capere 'to take'.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:427-428, {ref Orel 1998}:524, {ref Holm 2011}:53 for discussion of various proposals.
Generally connected to PIE *sokʷo- 'juice of plants and fruit' ({ref Meyer 1891}:196, cf. {ref IEW} 1042, {ref Huld 1984}:67, {ref Demiraj 1997}:181-182, {ref Orel 1998}:129, {ref Holm 2011}:53).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:65, {ref Orel 1998}:103 for various proposals and further discussion.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:65, {ref Orel 1998}:103 for various proposals and further discussion.

Tocharian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'to incinerate, consume by fire' ({ref LIV²} 133-134, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:802, {ref Demiraj 1997}:138-139, {ref Orel 1998}:68, {ref Holm 2011}:55, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:970, {ref EWAia} I:712-713, {ref ALEW} 187-189).

Etymology in this class follows {ref Orel 1998}:105 and {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974 to PIE *teh₂- 'melt, thaw', but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:173-174, {ref Holm 2011}:56-57 for proposals to PIE *tep- 'be warm, hot'. Cf. also {ref LIV²} 616, 630.
Loanword from Latin venīre 'to come' ({ref Orel 1998}:508).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:332-333, {ref Orel 1998}:343 for various suggestions.

Anatolian, Armenian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dei̯-, di- 'be bright; shine' ({ref NIL} 69-81, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:766-767, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:616, {ref EWAia} I:750-752, II:304, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:362 no. 6328, {ref ALEW} 205, {ref Derksen 2015}:127, {ref ESSJa} 5:213-214 {ref Derksen 2008}:134-135, {ref de Vaan 2008}:170, 315-316, {ref Untermann 2000}:352, 868, {ref Matasović 2009}:101).

Etymology unclear. The proposal of {ref Orel 1998}:115) is rather implausible from a semantic point of view. The etymology is otherwise uncertain (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:177-178 for further discussion).

notes: privative pa-

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ({ref LIV²} 262, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1194-1195, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:277-279, {ref Orel 1998}:324-325, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:990, {ref EWAia} II:113-114, {ref Derksen 2015}:563, {ref Derksen 2008}:401, {ref de Vaan 2008}:71-72, {ref Matasović 2009}:130).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Albanian, Iranic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, etc. 'earth' ({ref NIL} 86-99, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:858-863, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:128, {ref Adams 2013}:205, {ref Demiraj 1997}:155-156, {ref Orel 1998}:80-81, {ref EWAia} I:424-425, {ref ALEW} 1296-1298, {ref Derksen 2015}:516, {ref Derksen 2008}:542).

Modern Indic cognates to be connected with Vedic khād- 'chew, bite; eat' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:203, no. 3865). No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:451-452, cf. {ref LIV²} 359-360).
Generally derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:43-44, {ref Orel 1998}:24-25, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:966).
Loanword from Latin largus 'big, large, great (of distances)' ({ref Huld 1984}:85, {ref Orel 1998}:214).

notes: Etymology unclear.

justificationDiscussion: The Slavic lexeme along with similar words in other Indoeuropean languages can be interpreted as a derivation of a PIE root *ot- (*ott-). However, it is a ideophonic, nursery word and any deep etymology would be rather doubtful. In any case, reconstructions of baby babbling like *h₂et-o- {ref de Vaan 2008} seem over the top.

Root etymology in this class follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:970-971 to *dʰreh₂s-, a parallel root to dʰreh₂gʰ- 'aufgewühlt werden, in Aufruhr geraten' (LIV² 154f.). For older proposals, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:76.

Albanian lexemes generally derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ({ref NIL} 196-199, {ref LIV²} 219-220), although the stem formation of Albanian zjarr is uncertain (cf. {ref Holm 2011}:62, {ref Orel 1998}:525 and especially the detailed discussion of {ref Demiraj 1997}:428-429).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'bitter' in /cognate/6086/, 'burn' in /cognate/2243/, 'day' in /cognate/3850/, 'hot' in /cognate/333/, 'sun' in /cognate/2299/.

justificationDiscussion: In all likelihood a loanword but of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:87-88, {ref Orel 1998}:234).
Loanword from Romance *fluctulāre < Latin fluctuāre ({ref Orel 1998}:101, cf. {ref Holm 2011}:63, {ref Demiraj 1997}:172-173, {ref Meyer 1891}:109).
Loan from Latin *camba ~ gamba 'leg' ({ref Huld 1984}:80, {ref Orel 1998}:177, {ref Holm 2011}:63).

notes: There might be another root *merk⁽ʷ⁾- with a meaning pertaining to the same semantic field, cf. e.g. Ukrainian dialectal morokvá 'quagmire, swamp', Lith. mer̃kti 'to wet, to moisten (flax, linen)' and maybe as a cognate Latin marceō 'to be withered, droop', cf. also Derksen, EtymDictSlav 325f. s.v. *morky, ALEW 637 and de Vaan, EtymDictLat 364f. (Freiberg).
justificationDiscussion: Albanian and Slavic lexemes from PIE *merg̑⁽ʰ⁾- ({ref Demiraj 1997}:256, {ref Orel 1998}:245, {ref ESSJa} 20:10-14; 21:163-165, {ref Derksen 2008}:326, 342-343).
Loan from Latin pōmum 'fruit tree; fruit' ({ref Meyer 1891}:326, {ref Orel 1998}:314, {ref Holm 2011}:85-86).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ({ref LIV²} 105-106, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:331-332, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:595, {ref Demiraj 1997}:154-155, {ref Orel 1998}:157, {ref Rohr 2000}:42-43, {ref EWAia} I:713-715, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:489 no. 8655, {ref Cheung 2007}:45-47, {ref ALEW} 246-248, {ref Derksen 2015}:146-147, {ref ESSJa} 4:194-195, {ref Derksen 2008}:96, {ref de Vaan 2008}:174-175). The connection of Gaulish dede to this class is tentatively accepted (so {ref Matasović 2009}:86), but cf. the discussion of {ref Delamarre 2003}:138-139 regarding the possibility alternatively deriving the Gaulish form from PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place'.
Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:268, {ref Orel 1998}:267, {ref Holm 2011}:64) for various proposals).
Etymology here tentatively follows {ref Orel 1998}:16-17, {ref de Vaan 2008}:201-202, but cf. the objections and further discussion of {ref Demiraj 1997}:89-90).
Loan from Turkish yeşil 'green' ({ref Holm 2011}:64).

notes: Although Common Iranic would continue *g̑ʰ as /z/ (as with Avestan), Klingenschmitt (2000: 200, fn. 30) emphasises that /d/-forms are not a sign of loans from Persian, but the result of an early dissimilation of *d͜zasta- > *dasta-: "Die Bedeutung des Wortes und die weite Verbreitung der Lautform *dasta- schließen aus, daß es sich um eine Entlehnung aus dem Persischen (ap. dasta-, mp. dast) handelt. Die Lautform *dasta- muß vielmehr durch Dissimilation entstanden sein (vgl. Morgenstierne, EVP, S. 39)."
justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *g̑ʰes- *'grasp'(?), 'hand', 'grip' ({ref NIL} 170-173). Indo-Iranic cognates reflect *g̑ʰes-to- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:812), other languages reflect an r-stem g̑ʰes-r- or thematised r-stem *g̑ʰes-r-o- ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:471-472, {ref Adams 2013}:711-712, {ref Beekes 2010}:1620-1621, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:431-432, {ref Demiraj 1997}:140, {ref Orel 1998}:70).
A loanword from Latin intelligere 'to perceive' ({ref Orel 1998}:62, cf. {ref Holm 2011}:66).

notes: Uncertain etymology.
justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology ({ref Demiraj 1997}:426-427, {ref Orel 1998}:520-521, {ref Holm 2011}:66-67).

Etymology uncertain. {ref Meyer 1891}:365 proposed a loan from Latin grandis 'large', rejected by {ref Jokl 1911}:74 considering Alb. rëndë a participle of a now lost verb cognate with Lith. rė́ju 'put together' (followed by {ref Huld 1984}:108. {ref Orel 1998}:370 supposes a connection with a stem *raunta- derived from rashë, the aorist stem of bie 'fall', although his proposed further IE connections for this verb are uncertain (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:343 "Eine sichere etymologische Deutung für dieses ohne Zweifel uralte suppletive Verb ist nicht in Sicht.").

Etymology disputed. Traditionally derived to PIE *u̯reh₁g̑- 'break, tear' ({ref Orel 1998}:377, {ref LIV²} 698), but {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:994 consider this unconvincing semantically and suggest alternatively a possible connection to rā-, the suppletive aorist to Albanian bie 'hit; fall'. In either case the verb must be a *-sk̑e/o- derived present stem.

Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain. {ref Orel 1998}:137-138 prefers a connection to Old High German jagōn (cf. /cognate/243/), which has no certain etymology outside of Germanic itself; {ref Demiraj 1997}:191-192 who rejects the connection with the Germanic lexemes and suggests instead a connection with Lat. sāgiō 'spüren, ahnen, wittern', OIr. 'nachgehen einer Sache, suchen' to PIE *seh₂g- '(witternd) nachspüren'. If so, perhaps to be connected within Albanian to 'hear' in /cognate/8546/. Undiscussed, however, in connection to Albanian gjegj in {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974-975.

Etymology uncertain. Possibly a loan from Germanic *jakulaz 'icicle, glacier' (so {ref Orel 1998}:3-4), but cf. objections from {ref Demiraj 1997}:74-75); cf. {ref Huld 1984}:37-38 for various unconvincing alternative hypotheses.
Etymology in this class follows {ref Orel 1998}:515, {ref Matzinger 2005}:99, but cf. {ref Holm 2011}:68 for further discussion.
Generally derived from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, consider' ({ref LIV²} 141-142, {ref Demiraj 1997}:132-133, {ref Orel 1998}:64-65, {ref Holm 2011}:68-69, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:969).
Pace {ref Orel 1998}:359, because of the onomatopoeic nature of the lexemes in this meaning it is difficult to establish an etymology outside of Albanian with certainty.
Loanword from Romance *manctus ({ref Orel 1998}:242). On the semantic development within Romance from Latin mancus 'maimed, crippled' > 'left', cf. discussion in /cognate/2071/.
To be derived from PIE *i̯et- 'to place oneself (firmly)' ({ref Orel 1998}:158, 343-344, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:979).
Probably a loanword from Italian milza 'spleen' ({ref Orel 1998}:259), but possibly even earlier from Gothic *milti-, cf. Catalan melsa 'spleen' ({ref Holm 2011}:69-70).
Etymology outside of Albanian unclear, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:274, {ref Jokl 1911}:58, {ref Demiraj 1997}:277, {ref Orel 1998}:274, {ref Holm 2011}:70} for various proposals.

Tocharian, Armenian, Albanian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat' ({ref NIL} 486-488, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:498, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:469-470, Demiraj 1997}:269-270, {ref Orel 1998}:267, {ref EWAia} II:343-344, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:574 no. 9982, {ref ALEW} 638-639, {ref Derksen 2015}:312-313, {ref ESSJa} 19:7-11, {ref Derksen 2008}:315, {ref Kroonen 2013}:369).
Connections outside of Albanian uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:89, {ref Demiraj 1997}:254-256, {ref Orel 1998}:243, {ref Holm 2011}:72 for various proposals and further discussion.
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:36, {ref Demiraj 1997}:70-71, {ref Orel 1998}:1-2 for discussion of various proposals.

notes: Loan from Turkish
justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Turkish kafa 'back of the head' ({ref Huld 1984}:106, {ref Orel 1998}:353, {ref Holm 2011}:72-73).

Probably a derivative of PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ({ref Orel 1998}:371, {ref Holm 2011}:73; cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:251, 344 without attempting to assign a root etymology). For the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 299-301.
Etymology difficult, {ref Meyer 1891}:153-154, {ref Orel 1998}:152, {ref Holm 2011}:73, {ref Hyllested 2012}:73-81 for various proposals and further discussion.

notes: Formally unclear whether the etymology goes back to *Hoi̯-no- or *sem-.
justificationDiscussion: The etymological handbooks differ on whether Alb. një 'one' should be assigned to PIE *sem- (Gk. εἷς, Arm. mi, etc.) /cognate/6066/ or *Hoi̯-no- (Lat. ūnus, Goth. ains, etc.) /cognate/91/ (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:101, {ref Demiraj 1997}:207, {ref Orel 1998}:304-305, {ref Holm 2011}:74 for various assessments).  Consequently the Albanian numeral '1' has therefore been placed in its own cognate set reflecting this etymological uncertainty.
Albanian lexemes generally agreed to continue a derivative of PIE *h₂ner- 'man, male person' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:304-305, {ref Orel 1998}:304, cf. {ref NIL} 332-335).
Hellenic and Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *selk- 'to pull' ({ref LIV²} 530-531, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:753, {ref Beekes 2010}:412).
