Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Kroonen 2013}:445, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:417-418 for older proposals).

notes: Loan from Romance.
justificationDiscussion: Loan from Late Latin cocceus 'red, scarlet' ({ref Meyer 1891}:210, {ref Huld 1984}:84, {ref Orel 1998}:205, {ref Holm 2011}:75).

notes: loan from latin vēritās and used as noun and ajdective.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:246-247, {ref Orel 1998}:219, 234 for various proposals and further discussion.

notes: Uncertain etymology.
justificationDiscussion: Albanian forms derived from verbal kalb 'to let rot', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Orel 1998}:165, 355 for various proposals).
Etymology uncertain. Considered a loanword from Slavic according to {ref Meyer 1891}:206 and others, alternatively an inherited lexeme (cf. {ref Huld 1984}82-83}, {ref Orel 1998}:197).
For the root ref. form as *(s)k̑eNs- with s-mobile, cf. discussion in /cognate/5451/.

notes: Loaned into in Romance in /cognate/1269/.
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes apparently continuing a West Germanic stem *krat- 'to scratch', although further connections are obscure and it may be an onomatopoeic formation in origin ({ref EWA 5}:762-764). On the tentative connection of English 'scratch' to this set, cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}.

Since {ref Jokl 1911}:14-15 generally derived from PIE *dʰeu̯b- and compared with Germanic 'deep' words, cf. Goth. diupiϸa, ON dýpt, although there is some uncertainty over the stem formation in Albanian (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:50, {ref Orel 1998}:61-62, {ref NIL} 124n16).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:357 for a summary of various proposals.

Tocharian, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ({ref NIL} 287-300, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:5, {ref Orel 1998}:86, {ref ALEW} 62, {ref Derksen 2015}:64, {ref ESSJa} 36:63-66, {ref Derksen 2008}:379, {ref de Vaan 2008}:22, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:11 no. 134, 135).
Root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:109, {ref Orel 1998}:386, {ref Holm 2011}:81, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:994-995 for various proposals and further discussion.
Etymology uncertain. For various proposals and further discussion, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:86, {ref Demiraj 1997}:240-241, {ref Orel 1998}:211-212, 222, {ref Holm 2011}:79).
No consensus on an IE root etymology outside of Albanian, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:99, {ref Holm 2011}:80, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:973-974 for various proposals.

notes: Etymology disputed.
justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:131-132, {ref Orel 1998}:513, {ref Holm 2011}:80 for various proposals and further discussion.
Etymology uncertain. Loan from Greek θυμός?, Bulgarian dymъ?, Turkish duman? (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:117, {ref Orel 1998}:470-471, {ref Holm 2011}:81 for various proposals and further discussion).

Within Albanian borë 'snow' is generally linked to bie 'fall' following {ref Jokl 1916}:93, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:45-46, {ref Demiraj 1997}:106-107, {ref Orel 1998}:32. For etymology of Alb. bie < PIE *bʰerH-, cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:966 and further references in /cognate/388/.
Root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:109, {ref Orel 1998}:386, {ref Holm 2011}:81, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:994-995 for various proposals and further discussion.

notes: Uncertain etymology.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed; the best etymology would tentatively appear to be some sort of derivative to PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, glow' (so {ref Huld 1984}:132, {ref Demiraj 1997}:206, but cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:460, {ref Orel 1998}:518 for alternative proposals).

IE inherited status uncertain. Certainly there is enough comparative material between Italic, Germanic, Greek, and Albanian to posit a (European) IE word *skeh₂p-, but due to the geographical proximity of the branches the possibility of (independent?) early loanwords cannot be entirely excluded (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:408, {ref Huld 1984}:114, {ref Orel 1998}:421, {ref de Vaan 2008}:546, {ref Beekes 2010}:1350 for further discussion).

Albanian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷerH- ({ref Huld 1984}:66-67, {ref Demiraj 1997}:181, {ref Orel 1998}:127, {ref Holm 2011}:82, {ref EWAia} I:487, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:223 no. 4161, {ref ESIJa} 3:191-193 {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:187). Note Sinhalese gala appears to be a contamination of the inherited lexeme with Tamil kal 'stone'.
Loan from Latin directum 'straight, not curved' ({ref Huld 1984}:55, {ref Orel 1998}:73).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: comp. 'breast' in /lexeme/20162/, see also Romance terms in /cognate/2991/

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:69, {ref Huld 1984}:50-51, {ref Demiraj 1997}:82, {ref Orel 1998}:65, {ref Holm 2011}:82 for various proposals and further discussion.
No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:45, {ref Demiraj 1997}:103, {ref Orel 1998}:27, {ref Holm 2011}:83 for various proposals and further discussion.

notes: etymology unknown.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:462 for various proposals.

Albanian and Italic derivatives from PIE *lei̯g̑- 'to bind'. In this set only Albanian lidh may be a primary verbal derivative, while the Italic and Romance forms probably denominal in origin ({ref LIV²} 403, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:86-87, {ref Demiraj 1997}:242-243, {ref Orel 1998}:226-227, {ref de Vaan 2008}:341, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:407-408).

Connections outside of Albanian unclear. The two main hypotheses connect the word either (1) to Germanic and Balto-Slavic words for 'sound' < *g(o)l-so- (so {ref Orel 1998}:138, cf. {ref IEW} 350), or (2) with the IE inherited word for 'tongue' *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- (so {ref Huld 1984}:71, {ref Holm 2011}:85).

Tocharian, Albanian, and Balto-Slavic lexemes from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- 'peg; tooth' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:126-127, {ref Adams 2013}:208, {ref Demiraj 1997}:158, {ref Orel 1998}:82, {ref ALEW} 1289, {ref Derksen 2008}:549, {ref Derksen 2015}:512).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, Iranic, Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dru- 'wood, tree' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:849-850, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:262-263, {ref Beekes 2010}:315-316, {ref Demiraj 1997}:146-148, {ref Orel 1998}:76, {ref EWAia} I:721, {ref ESIJa} 2:357-365, {ref ESSJa} 4:211-213, {ref Derksen 2008}:99, {ref Kroonen 2013}:522-523, cf. {ref IEW} 214-217).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stick' in /lexeme/739/, comp. Ir. /cognate/151/ and 'woods' in /cognate/672/ and /cognate/3138/

justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed. Possibly to PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- ({ref IEW} 541-2) if one follows {ref Orel 1998}:200, 482 to Alb. thyej 'break' (cf. {ref LIV²} 319-320, without Albanian lexemes listed); older etymologies (e.g. {ref Meyer 1891}:185, {ref Jokl 1911}:94) suggest a borrowing from Lat. convertere. The verb is not discussed in {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:229-230, {ref Orel 1998}:210, 221 for various suggestions and further discussion.

Albanian lexemes generally connected with PIE *bʰerh₁g̑- 'shine, gleam' ({ref LIV²} 92), but the precise stem derivation is uncertain (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:27, {ref Huld 1984}:40, {ref Demiraj 1997}:90-91, {ref Orel 1998}:17, {ref Holm 2011}:88-89).

The most promising etymology derives from a zero-grade form of PIE *seh₁- comparable to full-grade forms found in Celtic, Italic, and Germanic, cf. Old Irish sír 'long', Latin sērus 'belated, slow', Proto-Germanic *sīϸu- (so {ref Jokl 1911}:28, {ref Orel 1998}:133, but cf. the reservations of {ref Huld 1984}:68-69).
Loan from Romance *era < Latin āēr ({ref Meyer 1891}:96, {ref Huld 1984}:62, {ref Orel 1998}:89).

Etymology uncertain. {ref Orel 1998}:100 connects to PIE *lek- (of uncertain reconstruction in {ref LIV²} 411 s.v. ?*lek- 'die Gliedmaßen bewegen'(?)). {ref Meyer 1891}:108 assumed a loan from Italian foglietta 'leaf'; cf. {ref Orel 1998}:100 for a summary of various other proposals.

Etymology in this class follows {ref Hamp 1960}:276, {ref Demiraj 1997}:180-181, {ref Orel 1998}:125 to PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to become old'; but cf. also discussion of {ref Huld 1984}:66, {ref Holm 2011}:89-90.
Loan from Balkan Romance *padulem (< Latin paludem 'swamp'), cf. Romanian pădure 'forest' ({ref Meyer 1891:360, {ref Orel 1998}:353).

notes: Nuristani lexemes from *u̯et-so-
justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *u̯et- 'year' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:1014-1015, {ref Beekes 2010}:476-477, {ref Huld 1984}:129-130, {ref Demiraj 1997}:419-420, {ref Orel 1998}:509, {ref EWAia} II:495).
Loanword from Latin viridis 'green' ({ref Meyer 1891}:466, {ref Orel 1998}:499).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂ost-, the inherited Indo-European word for 'bone' ({ref EIEC} 77, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:325-326, {ref Adams 2013}:48-50, {ref Beekes 2010}:1119, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:533, {ref Demiraj 1997}:82-83, {ref Orel 1998}:11, {ref EWAia} I:150-151, {ref ESIJa} 1:232-234, {ref de Vaan 2008}:436-437, {ref Matasović 2009}:44-45). Perhaps cognate with the lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kost- with /cognate/1114/ but the explanation of the initial k- is unclear (cf. further discussion in that cognate set). The PIE stem is usually reconstructed with initial *h₂- on the basis of Greek ἀστραγαλός 'knucklebone' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:129), but the etymological connection of this word to the lexemes in this class is rejected by {ref Beekes 2010}:157-158 who prefers to see Greek ἀστραγαλός as a substratum loanword.

Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ters- 'to dry out, become thirsty' ({ref NIL} 701-704, {ref Lehmann 1986}:358, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:632-633, {ref Kroonen 2013}:554, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:74-75, {ref Matasović 2009}:379-380, {ref LIV²} 637-638).

notes: Uncertain if all of these belong together. Iberian lexemes are of uncertain origin, von Wartburg FEW suggests Lat. lixare for Fr. lexemes. Initial g- for Franco-Provençal seems unexpected for the suggested etymologies for other branches (isolated blend?). We may also be dealing with contamination/blending/expressive distortions. Class needs careful reviewing language by language (-MJCS 31.10.2017).

justificationDiscussion: Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ({ref LIV²} 572-573; cf. {ref Adams 2013}:354-355, {ref Beekes 2010}:1012-1013, {ref EWAia} II:769-770, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:39, {ref Cheung 2007}:348-349, {ref de Vaan 2008}:411, {ref Matasović 2009}:348).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn (around)' ({ref Boryś 2005}:694-695, 710; cf. {ref LIV²} 691-692).

notes: Uncertain, loan? (cf. Holm)
justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed. Considered a loan from Latin/Romance *iti̯ō by {ref Meyer 1891}:97, alternatively assumed to be inherited from IE *h₁ei̯- by {ref Orel 1998}:85; both of these hypotheses are rejected as implausible by {ref Holm 2011}:86-87 instead favouring a loan from South Slavic ići 'to go', influenced by Turkish yetiş- 'to reach, catch up with'.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:81-82, {ref Demiraj 1997}:224, {ref Orel 1998}:193-194 for various proposals and further discussion.

loan_notes: relatively late, not directly from Latin

justificationDiscussion: Connections outside of Albanian disputed (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:306-307, {ref Jokl 1911}:63-64, {ref Orel 1998}:296 for various proposals).
Loanword from Slavic *goditi ({ref Meyer 1891}:126, {ref Orel 1998}:119).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *⁽k̑⁾an- 'to sing, sound' ({ref LIV²} 342-343, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:87-88, {ref Schumacher 2004}:387-390, {ref Matasović 2009}:187-188).

notes: Martirosyan translates 'whole, entire, round, circle' , < IE *b(h)el- 'to blow, grow, swell', related to Gr. PHALLOS 'penis', E. BULL

justificationDiscussion: Origin uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} III:341). Perhaps related to Classical Armenian mowx 'smoke' of uncertain etymology (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:33 and further discussion in /cognate/8305/). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *moxir-o-].

A probable loanword from Syriac qəlāfāʼ 'folium libri', qəlāfəθā 'cortex, squama, putamen mali granata' ({ref Olsen 1999}:932), but cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:398 who less plausibly argue for an Indo-European origin. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kełeu̯-o-].
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑i̯eh₁- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:661).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cf. 'smoke in' /lexeme/11718/, cognate with terms for 'dust' in /cognate/2610/. LJ: It's highly dubious to put the Czech and Slovak word as cognates of a word from a different IE branch, first of all because of their phonetics (f-) and onomatopoetic character. Putting them together with Slavic *pyl- is impossible due to the same reasons.

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic derivatives from PIE *nebʰ- 'become damp, cloudy, misty' ({ref NIL} 499-504). Cf. also {ref ALEW} 186-187, {ref Derksen 2015}:118, {ref Beekes 2010}:1012, {ref EWAia} I:94, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:49-51).

Possibly an unextended form of the root *u̯eh₂dʰ- found in Latin vādo, -ere 'to go, walk, rush' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:196; cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:86). The alternative proposed etymology to *⁽g̑⁾ʰeh₁- 'to come, arrive' depends on whether the Indo-Iranic lexemes (Av. za-zā-mi 'to leave' Skt. já-hā-ti 'to leave, abandon') are to be connected with the Germanic and Armenian ones (cf. {ref EWAia} II:813-814, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:196 for further discussion). The root etymology here follows {ref Martirosyan 2010}, but cf. {ref LIV²} 196 s.v. *gʰeh₁- and 644 s.v. *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'durchschreiten'.

Etymology uncertain. Apparently a modern (dialectal) development of Classical Armenian kot(-)or 'fragment, morsel, piece; broken'; cf. Middle Armenian kt-or 'piece, shard, sliver'; kot(-)or-ac 'slaughter, massacre'. Alternatively, a different ablaut-grade of the same; cf. Classical Armenian kt(-)owr (adj.) 'cut (out)'; kt-ir-kʿ 'portion; dowry', etc. Cf. {ref HAB} II:641-643. [MM: Proto-Armenian ?*k(o)t(o)r-].
Denominal to Classical Armenian pʿor 'hole, cavity; belly'. Further origin unknown ({ref Olsen 1999}:942, cf. {ref HAB} IV:519). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰor-].

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian xmem 'to drink, to imbibe'. Further origins uncertain, probably a more recent loanword on the basis of dialectal variation but the exact source is difficult to establish ({ref HAB} III:122-123, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:467) Not in {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}, {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xi/um-].
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} IV:516-517, for further discussion cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:442-443). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰoʃ-i-/-o-].
Hellenic, Armenian, and Baltic lexemes from PIE *dʰg̑ʰuH- 'fish' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:474, {ref Beekes 2010}:1331-1332, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:439-440, {ref ALEW} 1331-1332).

Derived from Armenian saṙn 'ice' and generally connected to Germanic and Balto-Slavic lexemes for 'frozen snow' or 'hoarfrost', although the precise nominal stem formation in Armenian is not fully understood ({ref Olsen 1999}:137, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:567-568; cf. {ref HAB} IV:176-177 for older proposals). Note, however, {ref ALEW} 1019, {ref Kroonen 2013}:223 not do not explicitly connect the Armenian lexemes.

Origin uncertain. Of unknown origin according to {ref Olsen 1999}:936. Some Caucasian parallels exist (Archi гьоти 'grass', Udi xod 'tree') although {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:342-343 rather consider it more likely that these are loans from Armenian. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xot-o-].
Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:963, cf. {ref HAB} II:510-511). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kanatʃʰ-].
No certain etymology (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:36-37, {ref HAB} I:128-129 for various proposals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *ał-ii̯a-].
A loanword from Syriac mezzē 'crines parvi' ({ref Olsen 1999}:932). [MM: Proto-Armenian *maz-o-].

Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ({ref LIV²} 334-335, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:313-315, {ref EWAia} II:666-667 {ref Turner 1962–1966}:730 no.12598, {ref Cheung 2007}:356-357, {ref Matasović 2009}:208). The parallel verbal root *k̑leu̯s- 'listen to' is a secondary verbal root abstracted from a desiderative formation from *k̑leu̯- 'hear' already in the protolanguage (cf. {ref LIV²} 336).
Of obscure etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:168-169; cf. {ref HAB} II:445). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsan-u-(r)]

Arguably from the original aorist stem to the Classical Armenian suppletive present : aorist pair harkane- : har(e)-. The aorist stem may be derived from 3. *per-, cf. Lithuanian per̃ti 'hit with a bath brush', Latv. pḕrt 'hit', OCS pьrati 'hit; wash' ({ref LIV² 473, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:215-216 for further discussion). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

notes: From Middle Iranian *pēs (cf. Av. paēsa- 'ornament, embellishment'; Ved. péṡa- 'ornament, decoration').

justificationDiscussion: Armenian denominal verbs from Classical Armenian ors 'hunt, catch; hunted animal, game'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with Greek πόρκος 'a kind of fish trap' (cf. {HAB} III:588, {ref Olsen 1999}:13), but disputed by others (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:164 and {ref Martirosyan 2010}:544 for further discussion and alternative propsals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *ors-].

Armenian lexemes generally connected to Germanic and Balto-Slavic lexemes for 'frozen snow' or 'hoarfrost', although the precise nominal stem formation in Armenian is not fully understood ({ref Olsen 1999}:137, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:567-568; cf. {ref HAB} IV:176-177 for older proposals). Note, however, {ref ALEW} 1019, {ref Kroonen 2013}:223 not do not explicitly connect the Armenian lexemes.

Uncertain origin. Suggested to be a blend of the roots found in Greek σφάζω 'kill' and κτείνω 'kill' {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:227, or the root of Greek σφάζω 'kill' and the PIE root *gʷʰen- {ref Watkins 1995}:521 (cf. {ref Clackson 2017}:104-105, 112-113). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *span-].

Generally derived from a (collective?) formation *lēg-i̯a- to PIE *le⁽g̑⁾- 'to drip, trickle' ({ref Olsen 1999}:70, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:297, cf. {ref HAB} II:282-283, {ref IEW} 657, {ref LIV²} 397). Possibly cognate with Modern English 'lake' if not a loanword from Old French (cf. further discussion in /cognate/5612/). Alternatively, derived from the analogous formation *plēh₂g-i̯o/a- to root *pleh₂g- 'flat, wide', which is better supported by semantic parallels, cf. {ref Kölligan 2019}: 248.
Loanword from Syriac ṭarpā 'leaf' ({ref Olsen 1999}:933, {ref HAB} IV:398, {ref Hübschmann 1897}:317). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tereu̯-o-].
Unknown etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:964, {ref HAB} III:142-143). [MM: Proto-Armenian *dzax-o-/-u-].

Denominal formation based on Classical Armenian apowr 'salvation, deliverance; life'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:70, cf. {ref HAB} I:239-240). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010} or {ref Olsen 1999}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *apur-].
Generally derived from *du̯eh₂ró- or *duh₂ró- to √*du̯eh₂- ({ref Olsen 1999}:198-199, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:266-267).

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected with PIE *Horgʰi-, cf. Alb. ergjëz 'nit'; Lith. érkė 'tick, mite' ({ref IEW} 335, cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:603). This is remotely plausible, but the development of the Armenian form is irregular or phonetically unexpected, presumably due to taboo deformation. Cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:81 and {ref ALEW} 265 respectively for the proposed Albanian and Lithuanian cognates. [MM: Proto-Armenian *odʒil-o-/-a-].

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally derived from *k̑l(e)i̯-tr- (cf. Gk. κλιτύς,  Lat. clīvus 'slope, rise; hill'; Goth. hleiþra 'booth, tent' (PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean') (rejected by {ref HAB} II:270). Alternatively, from *lḗh₂-sr̥ ‎(cf. Alb. lerë '(heap of) stone(s)', Gk. λᾶας, OIr. líe 'stone' ({ref Hamp 1967}:16-17, accepted by {ref Olsen 1999}:122). Both etymologies rejected by {ref Martirosyan 2010}:306. [MM: Proto-Armenian *liar-in-].

Generally connected to Germanic words for 'approach, meet', cf. Goth. ga-motjan 'to meet', but a more precise root reconstruction is remains uncertain (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:49-50, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:451-452, {ref Lehmann 1986}:145, {ref Kroonen 2013}:372).

While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of providing a root reference form for this cognate set, we have followed the analysis of {ref Beekes 2004}, cf. also {ref Beekes 2010}:470-471) s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. {ref LIPP 2} s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-. Cf. also {ref Derksen 2008}:513, {ref ALEW} 1174-1175, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:215-216. If *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- is the lexical root underlying this formation, then these lexemes may ultimately be cognate with Hittite išpant-, Vedic kṣáp- 'night', etc. in /cognate/87/.

A probable North Caucasian loanword, cf. Khinalug k’ɨtʰ-ɨr 'nose' ({ref Asatrian 2014}:147-148). No etymology in {ref HAB} IV:577-578, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:783, {ref Olsen 1999}:942. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰitʰ-a-].
Armenian, Indic, Baltic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sen- 'old' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:, {ref EWAia} II:695, {ref ALEW} 901-902, {ref Derksen 2015}:393, {ref Matasović 2009}:330).

Generally accepted to be cognate with Old Icelandic angi 'smell, scent', Danish ange 'steam' ({ref Olsen 1999}:120, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:93-94, cf. {ref HAB} I:202-204, {ref IEW} 43). The root might well be identical with PIE  *h₂enh₁- 'breathe' plus an extension *-g̑- and arguably underwent the semantic development from 'breath' to 'soul; person' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:93-94; cf. a similar semantic shift in Latin animus 'soul, heart' in /cognate/6700/).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Probably the same as 'breathe' in /cognate/860/, 'heart' in /cognate/6700/, 'wind' in /cognate/1566/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected since {ref Meillet 1936}:36 to Greek χαλάω 'to slacken', but this etymology requires postulating an initial voiceless aspirate *kʰ-, and given that voiceless aspirates are no longer reconstructed for PIE this etymology should be abandoned ({ref Clackson 1994}:144-145, {ref Beekes 2010}:1608-1609). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xał-].
Loan from Iranic, cf. Av. karš- 'drag, plough' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:257, {ref HAB} IV:562-563). [MM: Proto-Armenian *karʃ-].

From the original aorist stem to the Classical Armenian suppletive present : aorist pair harkane- : har(e)- (cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:471). The aorist stem may be derived from 3. *per-, cf. Lithuanian per̃ti 'hit with a bath brush', Latv. pḕrt 'hit', OCS pьrati 'hit; wash' ({ref LIV² 473, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:215-216 for further discussion). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:424 for various proposals. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *an(-)dzreu̯-o-/-a-].
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Sogdian krm’yr 'red' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:167, {ref HAB} II:558-559, {ref Olsen 1999}:887). [MM: Proto-Armenian *karmir-a-].
Armenian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref NIL} 706-715, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:205, {ref Derksen 2008}:523).
Etymology uncertain, possibly to be connected Gk. ὄρμενος 'shoot, sprout, stem, stalk' (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:337). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

notes: comp. /lexeme/11703/

justificationDiscussion: Armenian forms generally derived from PIE 2. *h₂eg̑- 'to say' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:117-118, {ref LIV²} 256).

Denominal verbs derived from Classical Armenian kar 'rope, string'. Further origins uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:955); perhaps originally a loanword from Caucasian, cf. Georgian ḳerva 'to sew' ({ref HAB} II:541-542). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kar-].
Armenian and Nuristani lexemes derived from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' ({ref Olsen 1999}:55, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:720 no. 12438, {ref EWAia} II:627, cf. {ref LIV²} 319-320).

Romance lexemes from Latin curtus 'short' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:225, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:1585-1588); further root etymology uncertain, either to 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' ({ref LIV²} 556-557, {ref IEW} 938-940) or to *kʷer- 'cut (off), incise' ({ref LIV² 391-392, {ref IEW} 641-642). The former etymology is preferred by {ref de Vaan 2008}:158, whereas the latter by {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:160-161).
Armenian and Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₁erkʷ- 'to shine, to sing' ({ref LIV²} 240-241, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:259, {ref EWAia} I:114-115, {ref Bailey 1979}:25).
Of unknown etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:941, cf. {ref HAB} III:348-349). [MM: Proto-Armenian *mortʰ-o-].

Hellenic, Armenian, Baltic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃ed- 'to catch scent of (intr.), begin to smell' ({ref LIV²} 296, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1121, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:420, {ref ALEW} 1154, {ref Derksen 2015}:482, {ref de Vaan 2008}:425-426.  For this Hellenic lexemes in this cognate set, this class encodes the compound element *ὀσ-.

Possibly related to Celtic /cognate/8304/ and Armenian /cognate/8305/ lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. Possibly related Germanic /cognate/647/ and Celtic /cognate/8304/ lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. {ref ALEW} 947 (Baltic material), {ref Beekes 2010}:1371 (Greek material), {ref Seebold 1970}:440-441, {ref Kroonen 2013}:458-459 (Germanic material), {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:69-70, {ref Matasović 2009}:281 (Celtic material), {ref Martirosyan 2010}:484 (Armenian material).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes generally considered to be cognate, although the precise reconstruction debated; some taboo distortion is likely to have occurred in some branches ({ref Sihler 1995}:163, {ref Katz 1998}; cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1134-1135, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1535, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:153, {ref EWAia} I:157, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:44 no. 994, {ref ALEW} 40-41, {ref Derksen 2015}:55, {ref Derksen 2008}:388, {ref de Vaan 2008}:42).

Greek, Armenian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from an original m-stem noun *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´-; based on the ablaut patterns attested among the daughter languages a basic root *g̑ʰei̯- can be abstracted ({ref NIL} 162-169, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1619-1620, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1599, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:434-435, {ref EWAia} II:815-816, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:815 no. 14096).

Origin uncertain. Since {ref Pedersen 1905}:220 connected with OIr. carrac 'rock', further compared to Classical Sanskrit karkara- 'hard, firm', Greek κάρκαρος 'prison' by {ref HAB} IV:558-560, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:778. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:685-686 considers a substratum loanword which is also shared with Germanic via pre-Proto-Germanic *karko/u- *'stony rise (where cultic rites were practiced)" (> OE hearg, OHG harug, OIc. harg), comparable to Armenian Kʻarkʻē the name of a mountain of religious importance. Cf. also {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:42-43 who rather assumes a Western Mediterranean substratum origin for the proposed Celtic cognates. If this is the same substratum word as in Celtic and/or Germanic, it is difficult to determine whether this was a single loan event or parallel loan events.

Armenian forms reflect a derived i-stem *h₂reu̯-i-, and are directly cognate with Vedic ravi- 'sun, sun-god' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:135-138, cf. {ref EWAia} II:440). NB: Classical Armenian aregakn is a nominal compound of arew 'sun' with akn 'eye' (cf. /cognate/211/).

notes: Perhaps an Iranian loan. Denominative of ուռ owṙ 'swelling, tumor', cf. CA ուռնում owṙ-nu-m (intr.) 'I am swollen, bloated; (fig.) grow proud"; ուռուցանեմ owṙ-owcʿ-an-e-m (tr.) 'I swell; stuff'; ուռոյց owṙ-oycʿ 'swelling; blister', etc.
justificationDiscussion: Modern Armenian lexemes derived from Classical Armenian owṙnowm. Further etymology obscure. Probably to be connected with Armenian owrowk 'leprosy' according to {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:257, which in turn may plausibly be considered an loan from Iranian. cf. Sogdian βrʾwkʾ 'leprous' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:188; cf. also {ref HAB} III:606-607 for older hypotheses). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(u̯)uṙ-].

Etymology uncertain. According to {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:300 to an Indo-European root *lel- 'to move, to shake' (not in {ref LIV²}) comparing Vedic lelāyati 'to move to and from; shake' (but cf. {ref EWAia} II:480 assigning to PIE *rei̯H-, also not in {ref LIV²}); Lithuanian leliúoti ‎'to swing', etc. (cf. {ref HAB} II:292).

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian počʿ 'tail'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} IV:98, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:641 for various proposals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *potʃʰ-o-]

Denominal to Armenian kap 'bond, fetter'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly an Iranian loanword ({ref Olsen 1999}:16, 887, cf. {ref HAB} II:519-521). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kap-].

Armenian lexemes reflecting a root *derg̑ʰ- 'turn (oneself)' together with Albanian dreth ({ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:110-111, {ref LIV²} 146, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:193, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:234). Possibly a Schwebeablaut variant of *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'pull, drag' in which case to be further connected with 'walk' in /cognate/5824/, 'run' in /cognate/5027/ 'pull' in /cognate/2839/, 'carry' in /cognate/5330/.
Hellenic and Armenian lexemes from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ({ref LIV²} 487-488, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1212, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1115, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:316).

Generally connected with Baltic words for 'sea', cf. OLith. jū́ra 'sea', etc. ({ref Olsen 1999}:50, {ref ALEW} 423), although this etymology is disputed by {ref Kortlandt 1998}:15 (= {ref Kortlandt 2003}:122) on the grounds that the proposed Baltic cognates cannot be separated from Sanskrit vā́r 'water'. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, cf. {ref HAB} IV:134-136.

notes: element -PRE in Toch
Arguably from PIE *kʷu-dʰe (cf. Ved. kúha; OCS kъde; Lat. -cubi, etc.).

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Middle Iranian, cf. Pahlavi spētak, Parthian spytk' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:240, {ref HAB} IV:264-265, {ref Olsen 1999}:907). [MM: Proto-Armenian *spei̯t-aka-].

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleth₂- 'become wide, spread oneself out' ({ref NIL} 564, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1205, {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451, {ref Olsen 1999}:767, {ref EWAia} II:162-163, 179, {ref ALEW} 787-789, {ref Derksen 2015}:362, {ref Matasović 2009}:135, {ref LIV²} 486-487).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *gʷen- 'woman' ({ref NIL} 177-185, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:501-505, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:157-159, {ref Adams 2013}:242, {ref Beekes 2010}:291-292, {ref Martirosyan 2010}363-364, {ref EWAia} I:568-569, {ref Derksen 2015}:558, {ref Derksen 2008}:558, {ref Kroonen 2013}:317, {ref Matasović 2009}:61).

Origin uncertain. Traditionally thought to reflect PIE *sm̥-doru- lit. "together-tree/wood", which is, however, both formally and semantically quite speculative ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:95-96, {ref Olsen 1999}:939, cf. {ref HAB} I:211). [MM: Proto-Armenian *antaṙ-i-].
Etymology uncertain ({ref HAB} III:577). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ord-].

No generally accepted etymology (cf. {ref HAB} IV:385-386, {ref Olsen 1999}:442, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:724 for various proposals; not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tar-i̯a-].

Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. {ref ALEW} s.v. Lith. lãbas, {ref LIV²} 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 speculatively considered a connection with Armenian law (cf. discussion in /cognate/8081/), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW}. A lemma for Lithuanian lãbas is lacking in {ref Derksen 2015}. Apart from the as yet uncertain proposal to Vedic rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

A unique Greco-Armenian isogloss ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:214, {ref Beekes 2010}:264-265, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:336-337, 340-341, {ref LIV²} 162; cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:126-131 for extensive discussion of the various reflexes and derivatives from this root).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Iranian and Middle Indic forms in /cognate/6354/ may belong to this class, pace Mayrhofer EWAia II:165-166, cf. Turner (1962-1966:474).

notes: denominal derivative, cf. Vedic gaṇá- m. 'row, crowd, entourage, a number of fellows' (RV+); see also 'think' in /lexeme/25989/; cf. JB+ gaṇáyati, Sanskrit gaṇayati ʻcountsʼ (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3993
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit gaṇáyati 'counts' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:213 no.3993), a denominal formation to Sanskrit gaṇá- 'multitude, number, series', without further certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:458-459).
Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *rau̯k/č-, from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:316, {ref EWAia} II:463-464, {ref LIV²} 418-419).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'eye' in /cognate/994/, 'good' in /cognate/1783/, 'moon' in /cognate/2336/, 'salt' in /cognate/3845/, 'star' in /cognate/6295/, 'sun' in /cognate/739/, 'white' in /cognate/2401/.

notes: cf. Vedic mála- n. 'dirt'; cf. *mel- 'black', presumably originally *mel- 'earthy' (RP); cf. also *mel- 'soft'
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes generally connected with Greek and Baltic lexemes designating dark colours ({ref EWAia} II:332-333; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:680-681, {ref Beekes 2010}:923-924, {ref Derksen 2015}:544). For the Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:569, no. 9905.
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:594 no. 10286, further to PIE *meld- 'to become soft' ({ref KEWA} II:675-677, {ref EWAia} II:386-387, cf. {ref LIV²} 431).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ({ref EWAia} I:523-524, {ref ESIJa} II:238-242, cf. {ref LIV²} 383-385).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike down' and further to PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, chop' ({ref Cheung 2007}:234-235, cf. {ref LIV²} 555).

Indic and Balto-Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *bʰei̯h₂- to get scared' ({ref LIV²} 72-73, cf. {ref EWAia} II:245-246, {ref ALEW} 112-113, {ref Derksen 2015}:89, {ref ESSJa} 2:163-164, {ref Derksen 2008}:50).
Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)per- 'to fly' ({ref Adams 2013}:383, {ref EWAia} II:97, {ref Derksen 2008}:396, {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} II:343, cf. {ref LIV²} 579-580).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: see note in 'short' /lexeme/21761/, cogn. with 'small' in /cognate/121/

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:297-298, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:560, no. 9758).

notes: from Sanskrit (Mbh.) phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers),Pali phulla- 'blossoming', Prakrit phulla- 'opened, blossoming', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 511, no. 9092
justificationDiscussion: As though continuing Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:511 no. 9092), perhaps continuing a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit phálati 'to burst' ({ref KEWA} II:398).
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Henning 1947}:47, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:73, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:242.

Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *xšnau- 'to hear', further from PIE *ksneu̯- 'to whet, sharpen', presumably via an intermediary sense *'to sharpen (the ears)' ({ref Cheung 2007}:456-457, cf. {ref LIV²} 373).

Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:578-579 no. 10066 Vedic māráyati (1) 'kills', the causative stem formation to Vedic √mar- 'to die', further to PIE *mer- 'to disappear, to die' ({ref EWAia} II:318-319, {ref LIV²} 439-440).

notes: fr. Lat. MARITUS (Buck)
cf. Bailey (1979: 420) who connects NP čap with Sogdian sʾpt deriving both from *k̑am- "to bend over" (cf. *kamp- in LIV 342). However, while Sogdian requires the input *k̑e, NP requires *ke.

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *i̯e/okʷ-r/n-, generally presumed to be the PIE inherited word for 'liver' ({ref NIL} 392-395, {ref EIEC} 356, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:522, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:306-307, {ref EWAia} II:391, {ref ALEW} 413-414, {ref de Vaan 2008}:296).

Pāli pabbata 'mountain' from Vedic párvata- (adj.) 'stony', (n.) 'mountain, mountains, stone', as though from PIE *péru̯n̥to-, cf. Hitt. peru- 'stone' ({ref EWAia} II:99, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:668-669).

notes: cf. Ossetic kom and NP kām „gums, palate“
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kāhman- 'mouth, opening', further connected in Indo-Iranic to the Vedic root √kas- 'to burst, split, break' according to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:598-599, {ref ESIJa} 4:169-170, although cf. the scepticism of further connections to Vedic √kas- in {ref EWAia} I:332-333.
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:497, {ref ESIJa} III:49-51 for various proposals.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar-⁴ 'to have a sore, scratch, itch', from PIE 2. *su̯er- 'to have a sore' ({ref Cheung 2007}:150, {ref LIV²} 613).

Originally in the sense 'delta, confluence of (river) waters' with preverb sam- 'together with, along with' + *udra- 'water' ({ref EWAia} II:705, I:215-216, {ref NIL} 706-715; cf. the Skt. n-stem udan- abstracted from the original heteroclite -r/n-stem derived from PIE *u̯ed-). For the Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:764, no. 13236.
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:227). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:523, no. 9250.
Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Iranic *dau̯č- 'to sew', a root restricted to West Iranic and possibly substratum loanword ({ref Cheung 2007}:67).
Parallel loans from Turkic *küčik
Connected with Avestan raočah- 'light', Old Persian raučah- 'day' ({ref Korn 2005}), further from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:463-464).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'day' in /cognate/691/, 'eye' in /cognate/994/, 'good' in /cognate/1783/, 'moon' in /cognate/2336/, 'salt' in /cognate/3845/, 'star' in /cognate/6295/, 'white' in /cognate/2401/.

notes: Horn (1893: 85) suggests a relation to Avestan tauruna- "young", Old Indic táruṇa- "jung, zart" (probably via "fresh"). Kurdish and Kumzari suggest a simplification of *rn > r.

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes reflecting Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćar(a)d-, cf. Vedic śarád- 'autumn; year'; no further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:616, cf. also {ref NIL} 415n7).
Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit or Prakrit challī- 'bark' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:274, no. 5005). Of non-IE origin, possibly Dravidian or Munda (cf. {ref KEWA} I:405-406).
loan_notes: Probable loanword, but of uncertain origin (cf. KEWA I:405-406 for further discussion).

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from *pēṭṭa- (with variant *pōṭṭa-) (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:475, no. 8376). No further etymology.
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:654 no. 11225, {ref KEWA} III:130 for further discussion.

Originally a possessive adjective formation to Vedic pakṣá- 'wing' > pakṣín- 'winged'; no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:62). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:430, no. 7636.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4711 s.v. Sanskrit carvati, carvayati ʻchewsʼ (Dhātup.); further etymology unclear (< *kerH-?), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 379, EWAia I, p. 547

justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes from Sanskrit kāla- 'dark-blue, black' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:157, no. 3083). Etymology uncertain, but probably a loanword from Dravidian ({ref KEWA} I:203, {ref EWAia} I:343, cf. {ref Burrow & Emeneau 1984}:139 for Dravidian parallels).
loan_notes: Probable loanword from Dravidian, cf. Burrow & Emeneau 1984:139 for parallels.

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit jválati 'burns brightly' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:292,  no. 5306). Indo-European root assignment in this class follows {ref LIV²} 170-171, but cf. the reservations of {ref EWAia} I:607.

notes: 'young of an animal' > affect. for children, Hindi term supp. to be Persian loan (Turner 1931: 415)

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes generally derived from PIE *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- ({ref EWAia} II:374-375, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:117).

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit stabdha- ʻfirmly fixedʼ, originally the past passive participle to Ved. √stambh- 'to affix, secure' and ultimately from PIE *stembʰH- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:788, no. 13676; cf. {ref EWAia} II:754, {ref LIV²} 595-596).

notes: Khotanese patälttä and Yaghnobi pakk- contain a prefix pa(ti)-, cf. {ref Emmerick 1968}: 68.
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ({ref LIV²} 559-560, {ref EWAia} I:315-316, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:144-145 no. 2852, {ref Cheung 2007}:243-244, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:584). Generally considered to be a dental-extended form of *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' in /cognate/6093/, cf. {ref LIV²} 556-557, 559-560.
Indic lexemes possibly to be connected with Vedic √khod- 'thrusts (penis) into' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:209, no. 3934; no certain etymology outside of Indic for Ved. √khod- cf. {ref EWAia} I:456).
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic kurkurá- 'dog', probably imitative after the sound of a dog barking 'kur-kur' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:172, no. 3329; {ref EWAia} I:372).
No secure etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:314-315). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:143-144, no. 2830.

Etymology outside of Indic uncertain. Possibly to be connected with Proto-Slavic *ę̄drò 'kernel, core' ({ref EWAia} I:162), but cf. the scepticism of {ref Derksen 2008}:157-158. For Middle and Modern Indic, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:50, no. 1111.
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *du̯eh₂- ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:904-905, {ref EWAia} I:739, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:370 no. 6497).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing a stem *laḍ(h)- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:633 no. 10920). Further etymology uncertain.

Indic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes, generally accepted as cognates, but a precise reconstruction of the original Indo-European proto-form remains difficult and controversial, cf. {ref EWAia} I:44-45 {ref Turner 1962–1966}:3 no. 55, {ref ALEW} 1145-1146, {ref Derksen 2015}:478, {ref ESSJa} 32:30-33, {ref Derksen 2008}:364, {ref de Vaan 2008}:297 for further discussion. Possibly further connected to *Hengl- in /cognate/6119/, but the details remain uncertain.

Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *uḍḍīyate ~ *uḍḍayate 'flies up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:77, no.1697), further derived from Vedic √day-ⁱ (1) 'fly'; no further etymology ({ref EWAia} I:700, {ref KEWA} I:460).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √yam- 'to sustain, hold, hold up, support', further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:603 no. 10428, {ref EWAia} II:399-400, cf. {ref LIV²} 312).
No certain etymology outside of Indic ({ref EWAia} II:201-202), for Middle and Modern Indic cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:508, no. 9051).

notes: < Vedic vā́ra- ~ vā́la- m. 'tail hair', 'hair of animal, wool', cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 545, Turner 1962-66, no. 11549, 11572
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic vā́ra- (~ Sanskrit vā́la-) 'hair of tail, tail, hair' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:673-674 no. 11549). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} II:545 for further discussion.
Romance lexemes derived from Latin pēnsāre 'to weigh' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:526, {ref DCECH} IV:503-504), further to be connected to PIE 2. *spend- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:457, cf. {ref LIV²} 578).

notes: *dregʰ- (LIV² 126) must be separated from simple *dʰer- (class W, LIV² 145-6) )
composition?

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ({ref LIV²} 439, cf. {ref EWAia} II:318-319, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:578-579 no. 10066, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:19, {ref Matasović 2009}:259). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this class, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:378-379.
No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. {ref EWAia} II:811-812). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:811, no. 14021.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic pátra- 'wing, feather' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:436, no. 7733). Further to PIE *pet- 'to fall, fly' ({ref EWAia} II:71-72, 75-76; cf. {ref LIV²} 476, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fall' in /cognate/7561/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/1486/, 'feather' in /cognate/7563/, 'narrow' in /cognate/4064/, 'river' in /cognate/1525/, 'run' in /cognate/5968/, 'sleep' in /cognate/8796/, 'wing' in /cognate/1567/

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10951 lamba- ʻpendentʼ MBh. (ʻlongʼ in lamba-karṇa-); PIE *lemb(H)- 'hang loosely, droop, sag, cf. LIV, p. 411
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √ramb- ~ √lamb- 'hang down, dangle', cf. Sanskrit lamba- 'pendent', 'long' in lamba-karṇa- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:636 no. 10951), further to PIE *lembH- 'to hang slack' ({ref EWAia} II:436-437, {ref LIV²} 411).
Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₃óh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'mouth' ({ref NIL} 387-390, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:166-167, {ref EWAia} I:181-182, {ref de Vaan 2008}:436).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit saṁkula- 'crowded together, dense, disordered' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:744 no. 12828). further etymology unclear, cf. {ref KEWA} I:211, III:416 for further discussion.

Indic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁reh₁- 'be calm' ({ref EWAia} II:443-444, 447; cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:619, no. 10702). The reconstruction of the root-initial laryngeal as *h₁ rests on comparison to Greek ἐρωή 'rest' ({ref Beekes 2010}:469, not in {ref LIV²}). A distinct root from PIE 1. *h₁reh₁- 'to question' and 2. *h₁reh₁- 'to row' in {ref LIV²}.
Initial b- in all languages seems to preclude direct derivation from vr̥ddhá- 'grown, increased, large', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:524 no. 9271.

notes: cf. Sanskrit kṣvelati 'leaps, jumps, plays' and keli- f. 'play, sport, fun', -d- may stem from blend with Sanskrit krīḍa-, cf. Maryhofer EWAia I, p. 413, Turner 1962-66, no. 3918 s.v. *kheḍ- vel sim: "if krī́ḍati is IE., it has crossed with these"
Turner 1931: 128
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:205 no. 3881 *khiñc- 'to drag, pull'. No further etymology.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a root √dhakk- (cf. Sanskrit dhakkayati 'destroys, annihilates', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:383 no. 6701, {ref KEWA} II:88).

notes: Parallel loans from Arabic 'carnelian, cornelian, garnet' لَعْل via Persian 'ruby'; also Indo-Iranian surname and given name ('darling'), cf. Persian لعل‎‎, Hindi लाल, Urdu لال‎, Pashto lāl‎, but cf. also ep. Sanskrit lálati , Sanskrit root lal- 'cajole, play, dally, caress' ~ laḍ- cf. Mayrhofer KEWA III, p. 91, Turner 1962-66, p. 633, no. 10922, p. 640, no. 11030; epithet of Agni 'fire' is lālela-, lālilá- (Up+) - Krishna is also called "lalla" लल्ला - some conflation?
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Persian لال‎ / lāl 'red'.

notes: presumably cogn. with Skrt. stithi- f. 'standing upright', Vedic sthitá- 'standing, settled', cogn. with 'stand' in  /cognate/309/; cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5503, 13769, 13770
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic; proposed etymologies outside of Indo-Iranic rely on comparisons with hydronyms which are not wholly reliable comparanda (cf. {ref EWAia} II:8-9, {ref LIV²} 448). For Middle and Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:399, no. 6943.

notes: prob. through ḌORO 'thread, streak' (Turner 1931: 262)

justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes, probably originally *lavaná- 'cutting' derived to Vedic √lav- 'cut' < PIE *leu̯H- 'cut off, release' ({ref EWAia} II:475-476, cf. {ref LIV²} 417). For the Middle and Modern Indic forms attached to this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:637, no. 10978.

notes: retra- n. 'perfumed powder', presumably of non-Indic origin (according to Kuiper apud Turner 1962-66, p. 626, no. 10816 "Sanskritization" of a Munda loan)
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit retra- 'perfumed or aromatic powder' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:626 no. 10816). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} III:73 for further discussion.

notes: cf. Vedic bálbalī́ti (ŚB 2.3.2.11), malmalāyati  (ŚBK), balbalā kar- (Br), Sanskrit barbara- 'stammering' (cf. Greek bárbaros) - thus among the ideophonic roots *bal- ~ *bar- ~ *blV- ~ *mal- ~ *mlV-  vel sim. for 'babble, stammer, say blabla', cf. Vedic brav(i)- 'speak'; remodelled independently due to ideophonic needs, but in one or some forms inherited from PIE, cf. Mayrhofer  EWAia II, p. 217

justificationDiscussion: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes backformed from the Old Indic suppletive aorist √dr̥ś- and replacing the inherited present stem paśya- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:371, no. 6507). Ultimately to be derived from PIE *derk̑- 'to see' ({ref EWAia} I:704-706, {ref LIV²} 122-123).

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'to sew' ({ref LIV²} 545, cf. {ref EWAia} II:734, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:766 no. 13444, {ref Cheung 2007}:136-137, {ref ALEW}  917-918, {ref Derksen 2015}:400, {ref Derksen 2008}:487, {ref Kroonen 2013}:437-438, {ref de Vaan 2008}:600, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:203 no. 2174).

notes: cf. Proto-Indo-Iranian *dʱā́rā- f. 'blade, cutting edge' > Vedic dhā́rā- f. 'id.'; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 789; parallel Indic noun to adjective derivations
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic dhā́ra- 'blade (of a sword, knife)' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:389 no. 6793), further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰā́rā- 'id.', but without certain comparisons outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:789).

Indo-Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eH(i̯)- 'to sing' ({ref EWAia} I:482-483, {ref Cheung 2007}:94, {ref ALEW} 320-321, {ref Derksen 2015}:174, {ref LIV²} 183). The Baltic forms show an extra *-d- added to the basic root, sometimes considered a root enlargement, but may be also accounted for via various other explanations (cf. {ref ALEW} 320-321 for further discussion).

notes: A general shape of the root as *(s)keu̯H- seems probable. Only Beekes assumes *(s)keHu-. However, alternative explanations of the Greek forms are presented by ALEW and EWA.The root might be identified with  *(s)keu̯h₂- 'stochern, ritzen' (LIV² p. 561) or for the time being accepted as *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover' without laryngeal identification (cf. IEW 951ff.).

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √drā- 'to sleep, slumber' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:411 no. 7200, 7201). Further root etymology uncertain, perhaps to ?*dreh₁- 'to sleep' ({ref LIV²} 126-127) if OCS -drěmljǫ is a contamination of this root with PIE 2. *drem- ({ref LIV²} 128), but this remains uncertain (cf. {ref LIV²} 126-128, {ref EWAia} I:757-758 for further discussion).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from *choṭṭa- 'small', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:279 no. 5071).

Albanian, Indic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *serp- 'to creep' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:183-184, {ref Orel 1998}:130, {ref EWAia} II:710, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:766 no. 13271, {ref de Vaan 2008}:558, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:648, cf. {ref LIV²} 536).

notes: the same as 'cut' in /lexeme/25251/
Turner 1931: 160

cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 497, no. 8857 s.v. prastará- m. 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' (RV), later 'flat surface' Mn., 'plain', 'rock, stone' Hit.; Pali Prakrit patthara- m. 'stone', from PIE 'strew' cf. LIV, p. 599
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic prastará- 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' (RV.), later 'flat surface', 'stone', a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew' and ultimately to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:497 no. 8857, {ref EWAia} II:187, II:756-757, {ref LIV²} 599-600).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12632 s.v. śodhya- 'be clean(sed)'; cf. LIV, p. 330
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit śodhya- 'to be cleaned' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:733 no. 12632), further derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root *ćau̯dʰ- 'to clean, make clean', but further cognates outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:657). {ref LIV²} 330 mechanically reconstructs ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'to become clean'.

notes: = Skt. CŪṢATI (Turner 1931: 182), "imitative" (Buck 1949: 334)
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9106; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Indic, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:512 no. 9106.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3949, Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 314
justificationDiscussion: Only attested in Sanskrit lexicographical works as gaccha- 'tree' (cf. Pāli gaccha- 'tree') but comparative phonology of Modern Indic forms point back to an original unattested form *gakṣa- 'tree'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} I:314, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:211 no. 3949).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic Lexemes from PIE *u̯emh₁- 'to vomit' ({ref LIV²} 680, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:416-417, {ref Andriotis 1974}:245, {ref EWAia} II:534-535, {ref Cheung 2007}:417, {ref ALEW} 1216, {ref Derksen 2015}:497, {ref de Vaan 2008}:690).

notes: cf. Skt. dhávati 'cleans' (Turner 1931: 329)
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √dhav-ⁱ 'to run, flow, stream, glide, swim', further to PIE *dʰeu̯H- 'to move quickly back and forth' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:389 no. 6803, {ref EWAia} I:782-783, cf. {ref LIV²} 149-150).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit pānīya- 'water' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:456 no. 8082), a derivative of Vedic √pā- 'to drink' and further to PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ({ref EWAia} II:113-114, {ref LIV²} 262).

notes: extracted from compounds in catur- via 'square', thus 'squared', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4534 and 4595ff.
= Skt. PRONCHATI 'wipe, clean' (Turner 1931: 384)

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cognate with 'breathe' in /cognate/860/, an-group cogn. with 'heart' in /cognate/2045/

justificationDiscussion: Italic and Albanian lexemes from PIE *(s)ken(H)- ({ref Meyer 1891}:152, {ref Huld 1984}:74, {ref Orel 1998}:147, {ref de Vaan 2008}:115). Pace {ref de Vaan 2008} lexemes from Tocharian B kentse 'rust' are not to be connected (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:207). For Romance lexemes from Latin cinis, cineris, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:182 no. 1929. Cf. Ancient Greek κόνις 'dust' in /cognate/6166/.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin dorsum 'back' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:247). The etymology as though from Latin *dē-uorsum is based on a popular etymology from Festus, but there are no better suggestions. If so, then the lexemes continue a derivative of PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:184, {ref de Vaan 2008}:180, 667).

Etymology outside of Italic uncertain, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:380, {ref de Vaan 2008}:360 for a survey of proposed extra-Italic cognates. For the Romance lexemes cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:429.

Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes generally considered cognate, but the specific root reconstruction is difficult. Cf. {ref EWAia} I:216, {ref ALEW} 1204, {ref Derksen 2015}:494, {ref de Vaan 2008}:647, 662 for further discussion.
Romance lexemes continuing Latin grandis 'full-grown, large, great', further etymology obscure ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:327 no. 3842, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:281, {ref de Vaan 2008}:270).

Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₂eu̯-i- 'bird' ({ref EWAia} II:507-508, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:659 no. 11304, {ref de Vaan 2008}:65-66, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:65-66, nos. 827, 828, and 831). For Hellenic and Armenian lexemes attached to this class not in the target meaning, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:35, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:398-399).
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:441, {ref de Vaan 2008}:409).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₁ésh₂-r̥, *h₁sh₂-én-, a heteroclitic r/n-stem, generally assumed to be the inherited Proto-Indo-European word for 'blood' ({ref EIEC} 71, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:256-260, {ref Adams 2013}:525, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:138, {ref EWAia} I:149, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:42 no. 971, {ref Derksen 2015}:526, {ref de Vaan 2008}:527-528, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:627, no. 7574)

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe' ({ref LIV²} 267, {ref NIL} 307-311, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:12-13, {ref EWAia} I:72, {ref Seebold 1970}:78-79, {ref Kroonen 2013}:26-27, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:38 no. 473, {ref de Vaan 2008}:43, {ref Matasović 2009}:35).

notes: fr. Lat. CREATURA

justificationDiscussion: Italic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)neu̯dʰ- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:448-449, {ref de Vaan 2008}:417, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:491).

Italic lexemes from Latin frīgidus 'cold' (adj.), a derivative of Latin frīgus 'cold, frost' (n.) < PIE *sriHg̑-e/os- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:254, {ref de Vaan 2008}:243, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:301 no. 3512; cf. {ref LIV²} 587)
Romance forms from Latin computāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:199), further to PIE *pi̯eh₂- ({ref LIV²} 481-482), cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:451-452, 502 for an account of the stem formation within Italic.

Modern Romance forms from Latin (ex-)cavāre 'to dig (out)' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:172, 262), originally a deadjectival verb to Latin cavus 'hollow, excavated' < PIE *k̑ou̯H-ó- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:101-102).
Romance forms from Latin spurcus 'dirty' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:676), further connections uncertain, perhaps to Latin spurius 'bastard'? (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:645).

Iranic and Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *sek- 'to run dry, dry out' ({ref Bailey 1979}:414, {ref EWAia} II:687-688, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:623, {ref de Vaan 2008}:562, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:651 no. 7897, cf. {ref LIV²} 523-524). For the Goidelic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:96, {ref Matasović 2009}:337.

notes: loan fr. French PIED-BOT 'club-foot' < Grmnic BUT 'dull' (Buck 1949: 1071), related to /lexeme/8289/?

justificationDiscussion: Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ters- 'to dry out; become thirsty' ({ref NIL} 701-704, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:687-688, {ref Untermann 2000}:736, 745, {ref de Vaan 2008}:616, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:74-75, {ref Matasović 2009}:379-380).
Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑ad- 'to fall' ({ref LIV²} 318, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:78-79, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:134 no. 1451).
Etymology outside of Italic unclear ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:691-692, {ref de Vaan 2008}:620, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:724 no. 8737).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cognate with 'child' in /cognate/1462/ < 'small', cogn. with 'small' in /lexeme/20504/

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin focus 'hearth, fireplace' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:292-293). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:243, {ref de Vaan 2008}:228-229 for further discussion).

notes: the same as ABOYER 'to bark'? < 'to bark', = NE BAY (Diez 1864: 2)
'flow' < 'drip' < Lat. CŌLĀRE 'filter, strain' (Buck 1949: 678)

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Italic disputed; most recently {ref de Vaan 2008}:687-688 favours a return to an etymology to PIE *gʷelh₁- 'hit, throw' (cf. {ref LIV²} 208, without Italic lexemes connected) as proposed by {ref Müller 1926}:213, but rejected by {ref Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954} II:828. Cf. also {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:570-571. For the Romance lexemes, see {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:788.
Romance lexemes from Latin gelāre 'to freeze', derived from Latin gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:317), further to PIE *⁽g̑⁾el- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:256).

First attested via Very Old Latin duenos (CIL 1.4) prior to the Latin sound change *du̯- > b- (cf. also Faliscan duenas [gen.sg.f.]) permitting the reconstruction of Proto-Italic *du̯eno-; further connections uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:73, {ref de Vaan 2008}:73-74 for further discussion). For Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:106 no. 1208.

Romance lexemes from Latin herba 'a small plant or herb' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:344), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:291-292, {ref de Vaan 2008}:269-270, 282 for further discussion).

Originally a derived adjective from Latin uireō 'to be green', no further etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:739, {ref de Vaan 2008}:681-682). For the Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:782.
No certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:95, {ref de Vaan 2008}:89, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:153 no. 1628).

Certainly to an IE root *men-, but it is not certain whether this is yet another independent root *men- or etymologically related to existing formations (cf. 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' ({ref LIV²} 435-436, {ref IEW} 726-8), 2. *men- 'bleiben, warten' ({ref LIV²} 437, {ref IEW} 729), or 3. ?*men- 'emporragen' ({ref LIV²} 437-438, {ref IEW} 726)).

Italic lexemes generally compared to Ancient Greek ἀΐω 'to perceive, hear', possibly from a root ?*h₂u̯ei̯s- 'to hear', but the details of the Latin stem-formation remain obscure, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:55, {ref de Vaan 2008}:61, {ref LIV²} 288 for further discussion. For Romance cognates, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:61 no. 779.

Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:131).

notes: = Skt. TAN- 'stretch' (Buck 1949: 746)

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes as though from Latin *captiāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:157), a secondary derivative from Latin capiō 'to take', ultimately from PIE *keh₂p- 'grasp, snatch' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:89-90, cf. {ref LIV²} 344-345).

Latin glaciēs 'ice' and Romance descendants superficially appear to be related to *⁽g̑⁾el- but it is difficult to establish a clear etymological relationship (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:275, {ref de Vaan 2008}:263 for further discussion). For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:322.
Etymology uncertain (for various proposals cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:442-443, {ref DCECH} III:878-881).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin sapere 'to have a good taste, taste of' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:628 no. 7586, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 11:193-201, further to PIE *seh₁p- 'to perceive (by taste)' ({ref LIV²} 519, {ref de Vaan 2008}:538-539).
No certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:573, {ref de Vaan 2008}:522). For the Romance lexemes attached to this set cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:603-604.
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:628, {ref Sihler 1995}:40, {ref de Vaan 2008}:566). For Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:655 no. 7947.

Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin perna 'haunch, ham together with the leg' ({ref DCECH} IV:538-539). For the IE reconstruction given, cf. {ref EWAia} II:123-124; for a proposed derivation to a verbal root *TsperH- 'to kick with the foot', cf. {ref Lubotsky 2006} and the discussion of {ref de Vaan 2008}:460-461.

A transferred adjective from the noun phrase iēcur fīcātum 'fig-stuffed liver' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 3:490-493), further etymology uncertain; Latin fīcus 'fig' appears to be a Mediterranean Wanderwort, cf. Attic Greek. σῦκον, (Boeotian τῦκον )'fig', Armenian. tʻowz 'dried fig' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:232, {ref de Vaan 2008}:218). A similar lexical replacement also occurred in the history of Greek (cf. /cognate/1505/).

Italic and Romance lexemes typically compared to Proto-Indo-Iranic *pazdu- 'beetle, maggot'. If so we may consider a root *pesd-, perhaps identical with PIE *pesd- 'to fart quietly', although it may well be we are dealing with an independent onomatopoeic formation within PIE as *pesdu- 'annoying insect' vel sim. (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:493, {ref de Vaan 2008}:454, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:523-524).
Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om- 'earth' ({ref NIL} 86-99, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:195, {ref de Vaan 2008}:287-288, {ref Matasović 2009}:156, {ref ALEW} 1323).

Italic lexemes continuing an n-stem to PIE *(s)kerH- 'to split, separate' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:94, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:101, {ref LIV²} 558). For Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:162 no. 1706.
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *men- 'to rise, stick up' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:388, {ref Deshayes 2003}:502, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref LIV²} 437).

Romance lexemes from Latin bucca ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:122). Possibly a loanword from Celtic (cf. Proto-Celtic *bek(k)o- in /cognate/6204/), but ultimately unclear ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:77, {ref de Vaan 2008}:76).
First element seems related to Lat. post ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:555 no. 6684).

Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯et- 'year'. For the connection of Iranic lexemes, cf. {ref Szemerényi 1951} and further {ref EWAia} II:495. For Baltic, cf. {ref ALEW} 1228, {ref Karulis 1992} II:497-498. For Italic, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:672-673, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:775 no. 9291 & 9292.
Loanword from Etruscan φersu 'theatre mask', in turn borrowed from Ancient Greek πρόσωπον 'face', cf. also προσωπεῖον 'mask' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:500).

Romance lexemes from Latin iocāri 'to joke, jest' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:374, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 5:36-41), a denominal verb to Latin iocus 'joke, jest' and further to PIE *i̯ek- 'speak' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:308, cf. {ref LIV²} 311).

From Latin pulsāre 'to strike, beat' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:566-567), secondary from Latin pellere 'beat against, push, strike', further to PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:455-456, {ref LIV²} 470-471).
Loan from Spanish empujar 'to push'.

Italic lexemes continuing Latin pluvia 'rain', a derived noun to Latin pluō, -ere 'to rain' and further to PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ({ref LIV²} 487-488, {ref de Vaan 2008}:474-475, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:550).

notes: < Lat. CHORDA 'string on a musical instrument' < Gr. XORDEE 'gut' (Buck 1949: 549)

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Romance < Lat. FRICARE besides *FRICTARE, prob. ultimtely cogn. with 'hit' in /cognate/2709/

justificationDiscussion: Latin dīcere, from PIE 1. *dei̯k̑- 'to indicate, show' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:169-170, {ref LIV²} 108-109). For the Romance lexemes attached to this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:240.

As though from Latin *coctiāre 'to cook, burn' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:191), a secondary derivative of Latin coquō 'cook, bake' and derived to PIE *pekʷ- 'become ripe, make cooked' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:134, {ref LIV²} 468).

Hellenic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see' ({ref LIV²} 665-667, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:379-380, {ref Smoczyński 2005}:403-404, {ref Derksen 2008}:521, {ref de Vaan 2008}:676).
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:83-84, {ref de Vaan 2008}:80-81 for various hypotheses.
Italic and Romance lexemes continuing Latin dormīre 'to sleep', further derived from PIE 2. *drem- 'to sleep' ({ref LIV²} 128, {ref de Vaan 2008}:179-180, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:247).
Probably of expressive or onomatopoeic origin ({ref DCECH} IV:484-486, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:544).

Romance lexemes continuing Late Latin flagrāre, Classical Latin fragrāre 'to smell strongly' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:298). Further etymology uncertain, possibly to be connected with OHG braccho 'hound', Middle Irish brén 'putrid, foul' from a root *bʰreh₁g-, in which case the Latin verb would have been deadjectival from an unattested *frag-ro- 'smelling', although this proposal remains quite uncertain (cf. {ref Schrijver 1991}:185-186, {ref Schrijver 1995}:170-171, {ref de Vaan 2008}:238; further to the proposed Celtic comparanda cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:232-233, {ref Zair 2012}:70-71). Alternatively a connection with Sanskrit ghrā́ti, jíghrati 'smells' has been considered but this proposal is formally problematic (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:251, {ref Schrijver 1991}:185-186).

notes: Buck gives Grk. KYLLOS 'crooked' as a cognate (1949: 194)

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *bheid- 'to split', cogn. with 'bite' in /cognate/187/, may be related to 'stab' in /lexeme/22532/

notes: < Lat. APPECTORARE < PECTUS 'chest'

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin petra ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:531), an old loanword from Ancient Greek πέτρα 'rock; cliffside' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:504)
Continuing a derivative of PIE *tu̯em- 'to swell up' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:663, {ref LIV²} 654).
Root etymology in this class follows {ref de Vaan 2008}:99, but cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:106. For Romance lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:170-171.
From Latin grossus 'fat, thick' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:330-331), further etymology unclear (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:273), formerly connected by {ref IEW} 485 with Celtic *brasso- in /cognate/4355/.
Romance lexemes derived from Latin pēnsāre 'to weigh' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:526), further to be connected to PIE 2. *spend- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:457, cf. {ref LIV²} 578).

Etymology uncertain. For Latin arbor {ref Schrijver 1991}:69 cautiously suggested a possible preform *h₃r̥dʰ-ōs to a root *h₃erdʰ- 'be upright, high' which is further tentatively considered a possibility by {ref de Vaan 2008}:50; cf. also {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:43. For Romance forms in this set, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:49 no. 606.

notes: fr. CeltLat. *VIRARE, cf. Gael. gwyro 'turn away, make a detour, remove' (Spanish dictionary online)

justificationDiscussion: Pace {ref Kroonen 2013}, the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by {ref Beekes 1998}), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. {ref EWA 1} 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in /cognate/1735/). Regarding the Oscan form in this class, an alternative root etymology to PIE *h₂ep- is sometimes considered on the basis of the apparent lengthened root vowel as in the Indo-Iranian forms (e.g. Skt. āp-) cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:42-43, {ref de Vaan 2008}:19), however it is possible that the lengthening of the vowel could be secondary. While it is possible that the Oscan form could preserve an isolated reflex of the root *h₂ep- as found in Indo-Iranian, Baltic, and Tocharian, given that there are no other potential reflexes of the root *h₂ep- in Italic connections with Latin aqua cannot be ruled out, and it seems preferable, on the balance of probability, to connect Oscan aapam with Latin aqua < *h₂ekʷ-(e)h₂ (acknowledged by both Untermann & de Vaan). (NB: In Oscan PIE *kʷ > p).

Romance lexemes from or derived from Latin mollis 'soft' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:463); the Iberian Romance lexemes are secondarily derived to a de-adjectival verb *molliāre 'make soft' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:463, {ref DCECH} IV:181-182). Further to PIE *meld- 'be/make soft' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:386, cf. {ref LIV²} 431).

In all likelihood the lexemes can be accounted for via PIE *h₂elbʰ-o- 'white', however the reflexes of this form are restricted to Italic, Greek, and potentially also Albanian (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:20, {ref de Vaan 2008}:32). For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:26.
Romance lexemes from Latin lārgus 'generous, bountiful' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:399), further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:342, {ref de Vaan 2008}:327).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: prob. = Lat. MOLLIS 'soft' (Buck 1949: 83), the same in 'woman' /cognate/961/

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:418-419, {ref de Vaan 2008}:393 for further discussion, rejecting formerly proposed connections to Latin mollis 'soft'); for the Romance forms cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:472.

Iberian Romance lexemes derived from Latin amārus 'bitter' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:31-32, {ref DCECH} I:233-235). Further traditionally compared to Sanskrit amlá- 'sour, acid', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, cold', but many formal details remain unclear (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:25, {ref de Vaan 2008}:37; cf. {ref EIEC} 69).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: derived from IE *sol-no, sol-wo have been reassigned to /cognate/748/.
= Lat. AD, Goth. OIce. AT 'with' and terms meaning 'at' as in /cognate/2542/, see also 'near' in /cognate/2158/.

justificationDiscussion: For root ref. form *leh₃u̯-, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} and {ref Melchert 2011}:127-132.
Probable loan from Old French (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:226).

Cognacy in this class follows {ref Matasović 2009}:317 in treating the lexemes as inherited, but note that the possibility of some borrowing or loan-adaptation between Brythonic and Goidelic and/or early Romance may still be possible (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:54).
Loanword from Old French ({ref Deshayes 2003}:405).
loan_notes: variant of coffre (1175) from Vulgar Latin *cophinum of Greek origin

justificationDiscussion: Etymology in this class follows {ref NIL} 122-124; traditionally (but dubiously) connected to Greek τυφλός 'blind' ({ref IEW} 264, followed by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:210-211, {ref Matasović 2009}:107-108, against which cf. {ref NIL} 123n4).
Brythonic lexemes as though from Proto-Celtic *u̯ait-o- 'blood', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:130, {ref Deshayes 2003}:295, {ref Lucht 2007}:67n7).
Celtic lexemes traditionally derived to PIE *leu̯k- (cf. {ref IEW} 687), but better to *leh₂p- after the analysis of {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:194fn40, cf. {ref LIV²} 402, {ref Lucht 2007}:76.

notes: From Proto-Celtic *bow-koli- 'cowsman, herdsman' < PIE *gʷow-kʷol-o- 'cowherd' (IEW 639), with similar development in Irish, cf buachaill 'boy'.'herd, cowherd' (Matasović 72).

justificationDiscussion: Brythonic lexemes, probably continuing a loanword from Latin cumulus 'heap' although the conservation of medial *-m- in phonetically difficult (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:422, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ({ref IEW} 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:601; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:234-235, {ref HED A+E/I}:257-259, {ref Matasović 2009}:435).

notes: dy-bod (GPC)

justificationDiscussion: Loanwords, either borrowed directly from Old French conter, or a denominal formation within Breton based on a loanword from Old French conte ({ref Deshayes 2003}:413)
loan_notes: Some uncertainty exists whether the Breton verb was borrowed directly from Old French conter, or a denominal formation within Breton based on a loanword from Old French conte (Deshayes 2003:413)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'to dig, bury', probably via a periphrastic formation *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o- 'to make a stroke/stab' to PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:410-413, {ref Matasović 2009}:206, Britta Irslinger, p.c., cf. {ref LIV²} 350, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:111-112)
Brythonic lexemes of obscure origin (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:476).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *dheu(a)- 'to whirl smoke'; cogn. with 'dirty' in /lexeme/18696/ and 'smoke' in /cognate/123/.

notes: Buck 1949:226 from IE *skeu/*keu 'perceive, hear'
justificationDiscussion: Root reference form tentatively follows the proposed reconstruction of {ref Deshayes 2003}:669. No certain etymology outside of Brythonic. Older treatments have various tentative suggestions, e.g. {ref Buck 1949}:226 suggests perhaps to PIE *skeu̯- 'perceive, hear' (cf. {ref LIV²} 561 *skeu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen'), {ref Pedersen 1913}:53 tentatively suggests to Greek κυβερνάω 'to steer'.

notes: etym. dub. CHECK VGK I, 66
justificationDiscussion: A Brythonic word of uncertain origin ({ref Deshayes 2003}:197).

Following {ref Delamarre 2003}:139 connecting Gaulish onomastic depro- to this group, I tentatively reconstruct Proto-Celtic *dēkʷro- underlying these forms (not in {ref Matasović 2009}). Enrico Campanile, Profilo Etimologico del Cornico Antico (Pisa 1974, non vidi) tentatively proposed a possible connection to Ancient Greek δεῖπνον 'dinner, supper' which is formally possible and reconcilable to a root *dei̯kʷ- (not in {ref LIV²}). {ref Beekes 2010}:310 considers Ancient Greek δεῖπνον without certain etymology.

Brythonic lexemes derived from Proto-Celtic *luk-ati- 'seer', a derivative of Proto-Celtic *luk-e/o- 'to look at', ultimately a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:460, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:248, {ref Falileyev 2000}:103, {ref Deshayes 2003}:447, {ref LIV²} 418-419).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'day' in /cognate/691/, 'good' in /cognate/1783/, 'moon' in /cognate/2336/, 'salt' in /cognate/3845/, 'star' in /cognate/6295/, 'sun' in /cognate/739/, 'white' in /cognate/2401/.

justificationDiscussion: Brythonic lexemes based on a denominal formation (cf. Breton kouez m. 'a fall'), from Proto-Celtic *kei̯d- according to {ref Deshayes 2003}:420) but with no correspondences given from Goidelic. Further etymology uncertain.
From Proto-Celtic *kʷello-,; perhaps further to PIE *kʷel(h₁)- 'turn' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:176, {ref LIPP 2} 490).
