Italic lexemes, generally considered derivatives from PIE *pleu̯-mo-, a derivative of PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float'. An alternative possible reconstruction is *pleu̯k-smo- and connected with the extended variant *pleu̯k- which is only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic, cf. /cognate/2263/ ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:516, {ref de Vaan 2008}:474, cf. {ref LIV²} 487-488).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' ({ref NIL} 698-700, {ref Matasović 2009}:375, cf. {ref LIV²} 629-630).

notes: IE *bher-, = Skr. BHUR- 'quiver' (Buck 1949: 678)

justificationDiscussion: Brythonic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:537-538, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:145-146, cf. {ref LIV²} 572-573).

An Indo-European root etymology outside of Celtic for Proto-Celtic *treget- 'foot' is controversial, cf. esp. {ref Irslinger 2002}:60 for further discussion. Older hypotheses suppose a root *tregʰ- 'to walk' and a connection to Latin trahere 'to drag' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:387, 389 following {ref IEW} 1089, {ref Schumacher 2004}:635-636)

notes: Welsh rhoddi < *ro-dī-, cf. PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to place, to put', does not belong to the same cognate class as Middle Welsh roaf, roi, Middle Breton reiff and Middle Cornish ry. These verbs have lost an intervocalic -g- and belong to Old Irish rogaid*, ·rogai* (*rugaid, *·rugai 'to stretch out' DIL 510/R89, LEIA R-39). Etymology first mentioned by Thurneysen, Review of VGK II, IF (Anzeiger) 33 (1914), 33.
justificationDiscussion: The Brythonic lexemes in this class are generally considered to be cognate but the ultimate PIE root etymology remains a matter of considerable debate. The two main hypotheses are to PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:278-282) or to PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ({ref Pedersen 1913}:473, {ref LIV²} 105-106), in either case combined with the preverb *pro- 'forth'. Cf. also {ref Falileyev 2000}:138-139, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. W rhoddaf, and {ref Deshayes 2003}:629). The root reference form Proto-Insular-Celtic *-dī- follows ({ref Schumacher 2004}:678.

Celtic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *mati- 'good', a derivative of PIE *meh₂- 'good; at the right time' ({ref Lucht 2007}:181-182, {ref Matasović 2009}:259-260, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:12-13).
Borrowing from early Romance *bodel < Lat. botellus 'small sausage' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:130).
loan_notes: Early Romance *bodel, from Lat. botellus 'small sausage'

justificationDiscussion: Brythonic lexemes as though from Proto-Celtic *blou̯i- 'hair, wool'. Further etymology uncertain: {ref Lane 1931}:279 attempted to derive from a preform *ml̥-eu̯-s comparable to Ancient Greek μαλλός 'flock of wool' (< *ml̥-nó-), but this conjecture has not been widely accepted (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:115, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:16, {ref Fleuriot 1964a}:85, {ref IEW} 721 [without Brythonic forms given as cognates]). The proposed comparandum in Ancient Greek μαλλός, moreover, is generally considered without satisfactory etymology ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:663, {ref Beekes 2010}:899; cf. /cognate/1492/). [Not in {ref Matasović 2009}].
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:177-178, {ref Matasović 2009}:108-109).
No known etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:65-66, {ref Matasović 2009}:177).

Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ({ref Deshayes 2003}:361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in {ref Matasović 2009}; no etymology given in {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref Henry 1900}:50-51 for various older proposals.
Loan from Lat. ponderis 'of weight' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:596).

notes: element -MA, connections?

justificationDiscussion: Denominal formation from Old Breton sco 'strike, blow', further etymology obscure ({ref Deshayes 2003}:666).
Breton lexemes, first attested in Middle Breton, but further origins obscure ({ref Deshayes 2003}:669).

Lexemes from Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯o- 'to hit; to slay'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Matasović 2009}:345), cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:583-587 setting up either PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ- following {ref Schrijver 1995}:178. [Not in {ref LIV²}].

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯ar-i̯e/o- 'to laugh', a derivative of PIE 1. *su̯er- 'to sound' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:608-609, {ref Matasović 2009}:361, cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:64, {ref Deshayes 2003}:162, {ref LIV²} 613).

Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *dʰalh₁- 'to spring up, sprout' ({ref NIL} 83-85, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:216-217, {ref Matasović 2009}:102-103, cf. {ref LIV²} 132). It is possible, but uncertain that Latin folium and the Romance lexemes continuing it belong here, cf. further discussion in /cognate/8247/.
Lexemes from Proto-Celtic *klēyo- 'left', further derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:114-115, {ref Matasović 2009}:207, cf. {ref LIV²} 332-333).
No clear etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Matasović 2009}:152, cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:266).
Proto-Celtic reconstruction uncertain; no etymology outside of Celtic (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:2, {ref Matasović 2009}:49).
Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *sīro- 'long' < PIE *seh₁-ro- 'long lasting (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:115-116, {ref Matasović 2009}:337).

Possibly otherwise to be reconstructed as an s-stem neuter *kīkos-; further etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:95-96). {ref Matasović 2009}:204 considers the words of expressive origin with an original semantic development from '(female) breast' > 'meat', although {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} considers the semantics to have developed in the opposite direction on the basis of compounds in Middle Irish.

Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑enu- 'jaw' ({ref Lucht 2007}:280, {ref Matasović 2009}:158). NB: traditionally considered a separate lexical root from PIE *g̑enu-, *g̑neu- 'knee', cf. {ref IEW} 380-382.
A loanword into Brythonic from Latin tostus 'grilled, burned', cf. Welsh tost 'severe, harsh, hard' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:732).
loan_notes: or younger and < Old French tost?

justificationDiscussion: A Brythonic word without certain external correspondences (cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:52n1 against an earlier proposal of {ref Pedersen 1909}:63 to connect to Gothic gatwo 'street'). The reconstruction of a common proto-form is difficult, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} and {ref Deshayes 2003}:288 for attempts at a Proto-Celtic reconstruction.

Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:187-188, {ref Lucht 2007}:295-296 for a survey of various proposals. The Proto-Celtic root reference form given for this cognate set provisionally follows {ref Matasović 2009}:352-353.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *kotto- 'old', possibly an old substratum borrowing from a non-IE language (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:425, {ref Delamarre 2003}:127, {ref Sims-Williams 2006}:67-69, {ref Matasović 2009}:218-219).
Baltic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om- 'earth' ({ref NIL} 86-99, cf. {ref ALEW} 1323, {ref de Vaan 2008}:287-288, {ref Matasović 2009}:156).

From PIE *rei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'bind' via Proto-Celtic *rig-e/o- ({ref Schumacher 2004}:546-548, {ref Matasović 2009}:311-312, {ref Schumacher 2004}:546-548, cf. {ref LIV²} 503), but cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:161, {ref Falileyev 2000}:64.

notes: Controversial, explained either as loanwords from Latin tendere or as inherited verbs, based on PIE *ten- 'to span, to stretch' (LIV 626). Perhaps related to /cognate/2837/, see citations in class for further references.
loan_notes: uncertain whether loan or inherited (or a mix?)

justificationDiscussion: Loan into Romance from Old Low Franconian ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:210-229, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:109).

Brythonic lexemes generally agreed to be cognate, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}. {ref Deshayes 2003}:274 reconstructs Proto-Celtic *u̯olau̯o- which has been tentatively followed here as a root reference form for this cognate set.
Loanword from Old/Middle French riviere 'river' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:629, {ref Favereau 1997a}:641).

The IE etymology for the lexemes in this class follows {ref Schrijver 1995}:170-171, also followed by {ref Matasović 2009}:73, and {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, occasionally connected by others to Lat. marcēre, cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:170 for further discussion.
No clear etymology outside of Celtic, cf. {ref Delamarre 2003}:453, {ref Matasović 2009}:231 for various suggestions.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *u̯el-e/o- 'to see', a derivative of PIE 3. *u̯el- 'to see, perceive' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:669-675, {ref Matasović 2009}:412, {ref LIV²} 675).

Brythonic lexemes without satisfactory etymology. Proposed to be connected with PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to bear, beget; create' by {ref Pedersen 1913}:544 via the sense 'make, do', although there are formal difficulties with this etymological identification (cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:346). {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} suggests a root *u̯er- 'to turn, spin (wool)' via an nasal-infix stem with an enlargement in *-b⁽ʰ⁾ (after {ref IEW} 1153), but this remains highly speculative. [Not in {ref LIV²}.]
The precise semantics of the Hittite lexeme are not entirely clear, and therefore the etymology is also uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:170-171).

No clear etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:42, {ref Matasović 2009}:66; cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:103-104). For various suggestions, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:42. Root ref. form for this class follows {ref Matasović 2009}:66.

Two variants within Celtic: W croen points to Proto-Celtic *krokno-, while the Goidelic and Breton forms point to a variant *krokkeno- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:243-244; {ref Matasović 2009}:226). Further etymology less certain; traditionally from an extended variant of *(s)ker- 'cut' (cf. {ref IEW 938-940), but the derivation is formally difficult (cf. the entries in Vendryes et al. and Matasović).
Loan into Brythonic Celtic of Latin quiēscere 'to rest' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:423-424, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

notes: There is a second lexeme for small, PCL. *leg-o, lag-o 'small', from PIE  *h₁le(n)gʷʰ-'small, light' (IEW: 661) Matasović (2009, 236). Does not seem to be the Swadesh term in Brittonic, because of its pejorative connotations, cf. MW 'law 'small, sad', OBr. lau gl. petusculum 'small, bad', MoBret. law 'miserable, bad'.
justificationDiscussion: No clear etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:24, {ref Lucht 2007}:355), cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:60-61 for a derivation from *bʰeg-ko-, although Matasović admits that this proposal is formally difficult and speculative.
Derivatives of PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:413-417, cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:397-398, {ref LIV² 334-335).

The cognacy of the Germanic, Celtic, and Italic (cf. Lat. natrīx) lexemes is generally agreed, but the IE root etymology is debated. More commonly ascribed to PIE *(s)neh₁- 'twist, spin' ({ref LIV²} 571-572, {ref IEW} 973). Also possible, but less likely to *(s)neh₂- 'bathe, swim' ({ref LIV²} 572-573, {ref IEW} 971-972). Cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:403, {ref Lehmann 1986}:262, {ref Kroonen 2013}:381, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:4-5, {ref Matasović 2009}:284, {ref de Vaan 2008}:402).

The Brythonic words in the meaning 'snow' in this set are sometimes compared to Old Irish arg 'drop' and connected to a root *sperg- or *spreg-, but this lexeme is only marginally attested. A better etymology for the Brythonic words would be a connection with the IE root *h₂erg̑̑- 'white, bright, shining' via Proto-Celtic *argi̯o- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:88, {ref Matasović 2009}:41-42). Because of the uncertainties over the proposed Old Irish cognates, this latter etymology has been followed in this class, but note that it is not mentioned s.v. *h₂erg̑- in {ref NIL}.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: of imit. origin (Buck 1949: 265), comp. Iran. words in /cognate/1970/
SK-group cognate with 'pull' in /cognate/2840/, also cogn. with 'thin' in /cognate/497/

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *magino- 'stone, place'. Further connections not fully certain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:9, {ref Matasović 2009}:252-253 for further discussion.

The Celtic forms in this class are often considered to be connected with Germanic in OHG eben, Goth. ibns, etc. (cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:92), but there are many formal difficulties with this identification (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:222, {ref Matasović 2009}:113, {ref Lehmann 1986}:202)

Brythonic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯ei̯d-e/o- 'to swell up', generally connected with PIE 1. *su̯ei̯d- 'to break out in sweat' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:610-611, {ref Matasović 2009}:362, cf. {ref LIV²} 607).

notes: outside connections?

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'wood' in /cognate/3129/, 'hunt' in /cognate/5123/, 'guts' in /cognate/5537/. For the reconstruction given, cf. ALEW s.v. Lith. vidùs.

justificationDiscussion: For the root ref. form, cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:578 assuming an unextended root form, probably to be connected with IE *(s)k̑ʰei̯d- ({ref LIV²} 547-548); cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:37-38, {ref Schumacher 2004}:578-579, {ref Matasović 2009}:343 for further discussion.
Root ref. form in this class follows {ref LIV²} 353-355, {ref Schumacher 2004}:401-403, but cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:72, {ref Matasović 2009}:202-203 for older proposals.

Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 676, {ref ALEW} 1242-1243; cf. {ref ALEW} 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and {ref Matasović 2009}:427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.
Etymology in this class follows {ref NIL} 122-124; cf. also the discussion of {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:123, {ref Matasović 2009}:107.

Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 676, {ref ALEW} 1242-1243; cf. {ref ALEW} 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and {ref Matasović 2009}:427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.
No clear etymology outside of Celtic, cf. {ref Delamarre 2003}:320-321, {ref Lucht 2007}:430 for various proposals. See also ({ref Matasović 2009}:423.

Derived from Old Breton mauu 'young man, servant' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:498), further connected to Old Irish mug 'boy, servant' and generally compared to lexemes from Proto-Germanic *magu- 'boy, relative' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:70-71, {ref Matasović 2009}:274). Further etymology uncertain; the lexemes may well have been substratum borrowings in the Western Indo-European languages (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:240, {ref Kroonen 2013}:347 for discussion of the Germanic comparanda).

Perhaps from IE *kai̯to- ({ref IEW} 521) if inherited and comparable to Germanic terms found in Goth. haiϸi 'field', Engl. heath, etc. These forms are, however, restricted to Celtic and Germanic and we may be dealing with borrowing or (independent) borrowings from a prehistoric NW European substratum language (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:198).

notes: etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 1012)
justificationDiscussion: The forms seem to point back to a root *blei̯d- / *blid- to which different stems were formed within Celtic; further connections outside of Celtic uncertain (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:59, {ref Matasović 2009}:69). See {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1999}:79 for a discussion of the stem formation.
Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *melino- 'yellow', a derivative based on PIE *melit- 'honey' ({ref Matasović 2009}:263, cf. {ref EIEC} 271).

Lexemes denominal from Proto-Celtic *kando- 'white', with the sense of 'to bleach laundry (by beating)' > 'to beat; to fight' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:336), further derived from PIE *skend- 'to shine' (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. Welsh cann 'white', {ref de Vaan 2008}:87, {ref LIV²} 554; not in {ref Matasović 2009}).
Etymology outside of Celtic disputed; cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:66, {ref Matasović 2009}:144-145 for various proposals. Root ref. form follows {ref Matasović 2009}.

notes: fr. the notion of 'servant' (Buck 1949: 82)

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *u̯iH-ró- 'young, powerful man' ({ref NIL} 726-729, cf. {ref EWAia} II:569-570, {ref ALEW} 1252-1253, {ref Kroonen 2013}:588, {ref de Vaan 2008}:681, {ref Matasović 2009}:423).

Loan from Latin aēr 'air, atmosphere, sky' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:20-21, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:4, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:24, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).  The same Latin form was also loaned in parallel into Goidelic, see /cognate/9978

Brythonic Celtic lexemes continuing denominal verbs from Proto-Celtic *trogo-, further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Deshayes 2003}:745, Schrijver 1995}:133; not in {ref Matasović 2009}).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cogn. with 'he' in /cognate/2678/ and many other pronominal forms

notes: IE *gʰu̯er- 'wild animal' (Buck), see 'hunt' in /lexeme/18783/
Cognate with Gothic 'lasiws'.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: element čto, ku, quod, que = pron. 'what', see  in /cognate/160/

justificationDiscussion: Adjectives continuing Proto-Slavic Proto-Slavic *golěmŭ 'big', whose root etymology is generally agreed to be related to Baltic lexemes such as Lithuanian galė́ti 'to be able' ({ref Derksen 2008}:174, {ref ESSJa} VI:202-204). Further to PIE *gelH- or *galH- 'to have power over' ({ref LIV²} 185-186, cf. {ref ALEW} 287-289).

Balto-Slavic lexemes, perhaps to be further connected with PIE *putlo- 'son', but this proposed connection is generally considered to be uncertain ({ref ALEW} 745-746, {ref Derksen 2008}:424-425, {ref Derksen 2015}:375).
Of onomatopoeic origin. No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref ESSJa} 8:18-19, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:202).

An Indic and Balto-Slavic isogloss ({ref EWAia} I:397-398, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:179 no. 3451, {ref ESSJa} 4:155-157, {ref Derksen 2008}:92, {ref Derksen 2015}:247). Because cognates are only found in languages that have undergone the satəm merger, the original identity of the velar as a plain velar *k or labiovelar *kʷ cannot be more precisely determined.

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body' ({ref NIL} 444-448, {ref ALEW} 520-521, {ref Derksen 2015:255}, {ref ESSJa} 13:67-70, {ref Derksen 2008}:254).

Sometimes considered with cognate with PIE *h₂ost- in /cognate/519/ but the details  remain unclear (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:239, {ref ESSJa} 11:167-173 for further discussion). This cognate set is otherwise restricted to Slavic.
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯es- 'to breathe (in, out)' ({ref LIV²} 160, {ref ALEW} 252-253, {ref Derksen 2008}:124, 131-132, {ref ESSJa} 5:151, 153).

notes: PS *ob-volk- with PS *volk < PS *velkti 'pull'. The etymological meaning of the compound is 'something that covers (the sky). The similarity to ?*u̯elg-/*u̯elk- is superficial.

justificationDiscussion: No convincing etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:57-58, 10:124, {ref Derksen 2008}:203-204, and further discussion by Lechosław Jocz in the further citations to this class).

Originally referring to counting by making scores on a piece of wood with a knife. A description of this method of counting is attested in one of the oldest Slavic texts ("On the Letters" by Chernorizets Hrabar). The meaning 'cut' is attested in Old/Middle Polish. Cf. Proto-Slavic *briti 'to shave', ultimately derivatives to PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ({ref Derksen 2008}:63, {ref ESSJa} III:31-32, {ref Boryś 2005}:40, {ref Skok 1971-1974} 1:209-210, cf. {ref LIV²} 92-93).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯reh₁g̑- 'to break, tear' ({ref LIV²} 698, {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} II:505-506, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:461).

Leaving the most unconvincing hypotheses (like the one linking to a hardly if ever attested interjection ps) aside, it still remains obscure which PIE root the Slavic lexeme belongs to. It applies also to a part of (potential) IE cognates, the differentiation between the reconstructed PIE roots relevant here is generally far from clear, cf. {ref NIL}. Therefore, it is most reasonable not to go beyond the Slavic in the reconstruction.

notes: IE *(s)temp/b- (Buck 1949: 1071)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *porxъ 'dust' and Proto-Slavic *pьrxъ 'dust' from PIE *pr̥s-o- (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:413, 428).
Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ({ref LIV²} 458, {ref EWAia} II:76-77, {ref Derksen 2008}:392, cf. {ref Rix 1976}:278-279).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'foot' in /cognate/225/, 'leg' in /cognate/2783/, 'stand' in /cognate/6813/, 'lie' in /cognate/8225/, 'sleep' in /cognate/9252/.

justificationDiscussion: Traditionally derived to PIE *mag̑- 'to spread, smear' ({ref ESSJa} 18:23-25, {ref LIV²} 421). Cf., however, {ref Derksen 2008}:304 s.v. Proto-Slavic mazati 'smear, anoint' with an alternative proposed etymology to Lithuanian mė́žti 'manure, muck out', etc.

The further IE cognacy and the PIE root are not entirely clear (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:323, {ref Boryś 2005}:579, {ref Rejzek 2001}:604-605, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1362-1363. The Kashubian and Sorbian phrases are calques of German 'Angst haben'.  Probable late parallel replacement/shift found in other Slavic languages.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:41, {ref ESSJa} 2:99-100, {ref LIV²} 72).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *ryba 'fish', further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:525-526, {ref Rejzek 2001}:552, {ref Boryś 2005}:528-529, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:177).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯ei̯t- 'to shine brightly' ({ref ESSJa} 13:162-163, {ref Derksen 2008}:258-259, cf. {ref LIV²} 340).

The widely accepted etymology linking the Slavic lexeme to uncertain PIE ?*lek- 'move the limbs' (cf. {ref ESSJa} 14:145-148) is not entirely convincing. There is no internal Slavic evidence for *k and the hypothesis needs to assume an intensive morphological levelling. Cf. also {ref ALEW} 567-568, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:343, {ref Derksen 2008}:271, {ref Kroonen 2013}:323.

The Bulgarian form goes back to the *korkŭ variant. The etymology of the Slavic lexeme and its further IE cognates are not entirely clear. Lithuanian kárka is rather a cognate but the other words linked to PS *korkŭ not.
West Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *uba-eta- 'side dish', the lexical root of *eta- corresponds to PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:2, 665; {ref EWNl} 3:463).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰeHbʰ- 'to be fitting, suitable' ({ref Derksen 2008}:109-110, {ref LIV²} 135-136, cf. {ref ESSJa} 5:45-46).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *treu̯H- 'to rub; to use' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:496-497, 499; {ref Boryś 2005}:640-641, 644).
Germanic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off' ({ref Derksen 2008}:85-86, {ref ESSJa} 4:82-83, {ref Lehmann 1986}:171, cf. {ref EWA 4}:968-969).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived to a Proto-Balto-Slavic verbal root *renk- 'to gather'; no certain further etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:439-440, {ref Derksen 2015}:376, {ref ALEW} 842-843, 867-868, cf. {ref LIV²} 506). For proposed connections in the older literature, cf. {ref IEW} 1155.

Balto-Slavic lexemes, generally considered to be cognate with Armenian glowx 'head' ({ref ALEW} 289-290, {ref Derksen 2015}:162-163, {ref Derksen 2008}:176). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. further discussion and references in /cognate/8243/).

Slavic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *tengʰ- 'to pull' ({ref Derksen 2008}:494, {ref Kroonen 2013}:551, {ref ALEW} 1110-1111) For the root reconstruction, cf. discussion in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' ({ref Derksen 2008}:99, 507; {ref LIV²} 119-121).

The vast majority of Slavic etymology dictionaries assume or accept the etymology presented in {ref ESSJa}: 112, cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 2: 508; {ref Rejzek 2001}: 351; {ref Boryś 2005}: 302-303; {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 2: 152; {ref Snoj 1997-2016}; {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012}: 277-278; {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-}: 3: 449; {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-}: 6: 25; {Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}: 772-773. The hypothesis of {Machek 1968}: 328, assuming a relatedness to Polish polować 'hunt' does not stand up scrutiny (it is impossible phonetically, morphologically and philologically).
According to the mainstream hypothesis, PS *loviti is related to Lithuanian lavùs 'dexterous', Greek Attic λεία (*λᾱϝιᾱ), Doric λᾱία 'gain', Latin lucrum 'gain', Gothic laun, Old High German lôn 'reward' and Old Irelandic folad 'richness', lúag 'praise' and derived from PIE *leh₂u 'aquire by fighting' (for the root reference form see {ref de Vaan 2008}: 349-350 or {ref Kroonen 2013}: 329).
However, {ref Derksen 2008}: 286 does not mention this etymology at all, claiming "To my knowledge, there are no cognates outside Balto-Slavic". The Slavic lexeme is not listed among cognates of the relevant words by {ref Kroonen 2013}: 329, {ref de Vaan 2008}: 349-350 and {ref Matasović 2009}: 397-398. According to {ref Beekes 2010}: 188, who compares Greek ἀπολαύω with Latin lucrum and Gothic laun, "the appurtenance of OCS lovъ 'catch, chase', loviti 'to catch, chase' would require *lh₂eu-, which is an improbable formation".
The etymology is accepted by {ref de Vries 1961}: 347-348 and {ref Lehmann 1986}: 228-229. The mainstream hypothesis is accepted here, although the case needs further investigation.
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. {ref ALEW} 565, {ref Derksen 2015}:277, {ref ESSJa} 14:91-92, {ref Derksen 2008}:270).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:41, {ref ESSJa} 2:99-100, {ref LIV²} 72).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰ-(e)r-o-, cf. Arm. ezr ‘edge, border, bank’ (cf. {ref ALEW} 271, {ref ESSJa} 6:33-34, {ref Derksen 2008}:148, {ref Derksen 2015}:158-159, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:247-248).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *smei̯- 'to smile, laugh' ({ref LIV²} 568-569, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:456-457, {ref Derksen 2015}:550-551).
Further etymology outside of Balto-Slavic uncertain, cf. {ref ESSJa} 15:143-144, 147-148, {ref Derksen 2008}:279-280 for further discussion.

Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *lh₂eiuo- or *leh₂i-uo- 'left' ({ref ESSJa} 15:29-31, {ref Derksen 2008}:275), cf. Ancient Greek λαιός 'left', Latin laevus 'left' ({ref Beekes 2010}:824-825, {ref de Vaan 2008}:323).

The Bulgarian form goes back to the *korkŭ variant. The etymology of the Slavic lexeme and its further IE cognates are not entirely clear. Lithuanian kárka is rather a cognate but the other words linked to PS *korkŭ not.
It's disputable if the Slavic word belongs to PIE ?*dʰreb- or *dʰrebʰ-. The majority view is adopted here.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰlei̯g̑- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:45-46, {ref ESSJa} 2:121-123, cf. {ref LIV²} 88-89).
Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *steh₂-ro-, derived from PIE *steh₂- 'to stand' ({ref Derksen 2008}:476, cf. {ref NIL} 637-659).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:209-210, {ref ESSJa} 8:208-211, and {ref LIV²} 223 for further discussion).

notes: *bʰeu̯t- violates IE root structure constraints. This etymology is impossible. (–MJCS, 11.07.2018).
justificationDiscussion:
The etymology and further IE cognacy is not entirely clear.
The most Slavic etymology dictionaries point to a relationship to Latin re(-)futo and Old Norse bauta etc. However, there were a formal issue with the final consonant of the PIE root then, cf. {ref LIV²}: 82 and {ref de Vaan 2008}: 253-254. A root *bʰuH- 'hit' wit different extentions could be assumed here {ref de Vaan 2008}: 253, cf. also {ref Snoj 1997-2016} and {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} cited below. However, Kroonen points that "the original root-final consonant cannot be identified as *d, but only as *t or *dʰ" {ref Kroonen 2013}: 56. If the final consonant were *t, Slavic forms could be formally related without any additional assumptions (as root extentions). This view is addopted here.

Lexemes in the meaning 'red' derived from IE *kʷr̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye. There are some formal difficulties in reconciling Proto-Slavic *čьrvь 'worm, maggot' to PIE *kʷr̥mi-, but the cognacy is generally agreed (cf. {ref ESSJa} 4:149-150, 169-170; {ref Derksen 2008}:91-93 for further discussion). Probable late parallel replacement/shift with Sogdian /cognate/9774/.  See 'worm' in /cognate/172/ for further etymological discussion.

Slavic forms from Proto-Slavic *koren- 'root' and generally connected within Balto-Slavic to Lith. kẽras 'tree-stump, stub, bush, shrub', etc. Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic are uncertain (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:237, {ref ESSJa} 11:62-65, {ref Derksen 2015}:238, {ref ALEW} 478 for discussion of various proposals).

The sources are, in general, consistent as to further IE cognates of PS *gniti 'rot'. A minor formal issue is, however, the reconstruction of the underlying PIE root. In {ref Derksen 2008} a form with initial *g̑ʰ- is given, the other sources give a form with *gʰ-, e.g. {ref ESSJa}: 177, {ref Rejzek 2001}: 205, {ref Boryś 2005}: 168, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 1: 153, cf. also {ref Kroonen 2013}: 183. A question is, if PS *znojĭ 'heat, sweat' is related. If so, a variation *g̑ʰ- / *gʰ- should be assumed, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}: 546, {ref Rejzek 2001}: 740, {ref Boryś 2005}: 744.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *ter- > *trī, treu-, cogn. with 'push' in /lexeme/24214/, 'turn' in /cognate/330/ (Buck 1949: 568) and 'short' in /cognate/1915/

justificationDiscussion: Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *pē(n)s-u-ko-, for further discussion cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:398, {ref EIEC} 499.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *rekti 'to speak, say', further derived from PIE *rek- 'to order, determine' ({ref Derksen 2008}:433, {ref LIV²} 506).

Tocharian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE ?*pei̯H- 'to sing'. The cross-branch cognacy in this class tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 465, {ref Adams 1982}:133, {ref Adams 2013}:409-410, {ref Derksen 2008}:398, but cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:723-724 with some reservations over the proposed Tocharian-Slavic connection.

notes: For the discussion on the further etymology of PS *koza and its relationship to PIE *ag̑- (cf. Old Indic ajā́) see {ref ESSJa}: 12: 19-21 and 1: 103-104.
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *koža 'skin, leather', further derived from Proto-Slavic *koza 'goat' originally in the sense 'goat leather'; further etymology uncertain but probably a Turkic loanword ({ref Derksen 2008}:242, {ref ESSJa} 12:35-36).

Anatolian, Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *nebʰ- 'become damp, cloudy, misty' ({ref NIL} 499-504; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:603-604, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:71-72, {ref ALEW} 186-187, {ref Derksen 2015}:118, {ref ESSJa} 24:101-104, {ref Derksen 2008}:347-348, {ref Matasović 2009}:288-289).

Slavic lexemes considered cognate with Ancient Greek µῆλον 'small cattle, goat, sheep' < *meh₁lo- ({ref Derksen 2008}:300 arguing for the Slavic forms reflecting an o-grade root form *moh₁-lo-, cf. also {ref ESSJa} 17:173-177). Further connections with Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small' might be possible, but remain uncertain (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:517-518, {ref Kroonen 2013}:456 and further discussion in /cognate/8298/).
Slavic lexemes derived from the zero-grade stem of PIE 'earth' *dʰg̑ʰ-m- (cf. {ref NIL} 86-99, {ref Derksen 2008}:545, {ref Boryś 2005}:755).

Generally agreed that the Baltic and Slavic forms are cognate, but there is debate as to how the Proto-Balto-Slavic word is to be reconstructed. Cf. discussion in {ref Derksen 2008}:523, {ref ESSJa} 7:181-189, {ref Derksen 2015}:195-196, {ref ALEW} 1332-1333.
There is no certain etymology. The relationship to PS *prętati and Russian prygat' is dubious. Cf. /cognate/5208/.

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'stone' (gen.sg. *h₂k-n-és-), an *mn̥-stem nominal derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ({ref EWAia} I:137-138, {ref ALEW} 28-29, {ref ESSJa} 9:137-140, {ref Derksen 2008}:220, {ref Derksen 2015}:47-48, {ref Delamarre 2003}:30-31).
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'do' in /cognate/5215/, 'right' in /cognate/1238/, 'say' in /cognate/4832/, and 'true' in /cognate/1207/.

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Indic, and Slavic lexemes from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ({ref LIV²} 487-488, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1208-1209, {ref EWAia} II:194-196). Assignment of the Slavic lexemes to this class follows {ref LIV²} 487-488 and other sources, but cf. reservations of {ref Derksen 1996}:116-117, {ref Derksen 2008}:403.

The original meaning was 'a part of the body an animal can chase away (literally 'sweep away') insects with', cf. direct attestations of this motivation in {ref ESSJa} 28:141-142. There is no commonly accepted etymology outside of Slavic; all further proposals have formal issues ({ref Derksen 2008}:389, {ref Rejzek 2001}:440, cf. also {ref Boryś 2005}:406-407, {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 4:897-898, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).

Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ({ref IEW} 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:97-98, {ref Derksen 2015}:530-531, {ref Kroonen 2013}:89, {ref Kluge 2011}:907 for further discussion.

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *mysliti, a denominal formation to Proto-Slavic *myslь 'thought, idea'. Within Slavic literature, *myslь is generally further compared to Ancient Greek μῦθος 'word, discourse, story' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:337, {ref ESSJa} 21:47-50, {ref Boryś 2005}:344), although within Hellenist literature Greek μῦθος is generally considered without certain etymology (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:718-719, {ref Beekes 2010}:976 for further discussion). The etymology of Proto-Slavic *myslь is remains therefore uncertain.
Cf. OCS vrъzǫ 'tie' from PIE *u̯erg̑ʰ- (cf. {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:188-189, {ref LIV²} 688).

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around, roll' ({ref LIV²} 691-692, {ref EWAia} II:518-519, {ref ALEW} 1197-1198, {ref Derksen 2008}:529, 539, {ref Derksen 2015}:492, {ref de Vaan 2008}:666-667).

It is often assumed that Proto-Slavic *bľĭvati is derived from *bʰleu̯H- and related to Latin fluō, fluere etc. ({ref LIV²} 90, {ref Derksen 2008}:46). This etymology is adopted here, however cf. {ref ESSJa} 2:140-141, {ref Rejzek 2001}:82, {ref Snoj 1997-2016} with skepticism.

Some sources assume a derivation from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- and a relationship to Latin moveō, movere, cf. the citations below.
However, this etymology is virtually not present in Slavic etymology dictionaries, cf. the citations below and {ref Rejzek 2001}: 398, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 185-186, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 3: 26 where a different set of IE comparanda is given. Although the proposed Greek comparanda rather do not belong here {ref Beekes 2010}: 950-951, 991, 974, 975-976, other IE comparisons as with Old Indic mū́tram 'urine', Proto-Celtic mūno- 'urine' and Lithuanian máudyti with a PIE reconstruction *meu̯H- (and without giving Latin moveō, movere etc. as a cognate) is accepted in branch-specific dictionaries, see {ref KEWA}: 663-554, {ref Matasović 2009}: 281, {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 378.
PS *myti could not derive directly from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁-. An irregular phonetic change or another special change would have to be assumed here.
Thus, the connection to PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- is not accepted here.
There are no certain cognates beyond Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:322, {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 369-370), cf. also {ref ESSJa} 19:144-147, {ref Beekes 2010}: 893.

The connection of the Baltic and Slavic lexemes to each other is generally agreed upon, but extra Balto-Slavic connections, and subsequently any precise IE root reconstruction, remain debated. {ref ALEW} (90-91 s.v. OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden') suggests that a connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' is not inconceivable; {ref Derksen 2008}:40 and {ref Derksen 2015}:80 postulate a root *bʰelH-. The reconstructed PIE root ref. form for this class follows that of Derksen, but it should be borne in mind that this form remains provisional as the morphological analysis of the Balto-Slavic forms and their proposed further IE connections have yet to be satisfactorily explained. Cf. also {ref ESSJa} 2:79-81.

There is no certain etymology. The widespread hypothesis ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:46,  {ref Rejzek 2001}:629, {ref Boryś 2005}:602) assumes an irregular phonetic change, cf. also {ref LIV²} 546. [Not in {ref Derksen 2008}].
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *krīdlo- 'wing', further derived from PIE *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'to describe a circle' ({ref Derksen 2008}:247, {ref ESSJa} 12:152-154, cf. {ref LIV²} 562).
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *médʰ-i̯o- 'middle, located in the middle' ({ref ALEW} 625-627, {ref Derksen 2015}:309).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *gȏdъ 'right time' < PIE *gʰodʰ-o- ({ref Derksen 2008}:172-173, {ref ESSJa} 6:189-192, cf. {ref LIV²} 195).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kʷei̯t- 'to perceive, to recognise' ({ref LIV²} 382-383, {ref ALEW} 919-920, {ref Derksen 2015}:401, {ref ESSJa} 4:119, {ref Derksen 2008}:89-90).
It is impossible to reconstruct one single root form for PS with regular sound correspondences within Slavic. It is an apparent nursery word. Any deeper etymology can not be convincingly proven.
Slavic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80, cf. {ref ESSJa} 2:203-204, 2:213-214, {ref Derksen 2008}:57-58, {ref Kroonen 2013}:53).
Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯olk̑-o- ({ref Derksen 2008}:526-527, {ref EWAia} II:526-627; for Pashto cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:94).

The etymology pointing to PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'sew' is not commonly accepted, cf. also {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 41-42 and {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 4:434-435. It is, however, convincing formally and semantically (and has parallels).
See also {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 668-669.

The ingenous and popular etymology as *dus-di̯u- 'bad sky, bad day' is kept here. However, is should be born in mind that this etymology is considered to be doubtful or at least not the only thinkable by many scholars, cf. the citations below and {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 1: 521-522, {ref Rejzek 2001}: 129, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 1: 100.
One of the most widespread alternative etymologies assumes a relationship to PG *duska- 'drizzle(?)', see {ref Kroonen 2013}: 111.
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *wer-, = OCS ĄŽE 'chain', perhaps ultimately related to 'turn' in Lat. VERTERE > 'twisted string' (Buck 1949: 550) and to /cognate/2868/

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:390; cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:191-193, {ref Rejzek 2001}:441-443, {ref Boryś 2005}:408-409, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:5 for various proposals and further discussion).

Lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *met-. Further IE root etymology disputed: either to PIE ?1. *met- 'mähen' ({ref LIV²} 422) or ?2. *met- 'abmessen' ({ref LIV²} 422) ({ref Derksen 2015}:313-314, {ref ESSJa} 18:105-108, 112-115, {ref Derksen 2008}:308-309); {ref ALEW} 639-641 doubts connections outside of Balto-Slavic.
Slavic lexemes generally derived from a causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to seat (oneself)' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:202-203, {ref ESSJa} 8:49-52, {ref LIV²} 513-515).
Slavic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰreu̯s- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:99-100, {ref Matasović 2009}:81, {ref ESSJa} 3:33-34, {ref Derksen 2008}:63).
Slavic lexemes generally connected to PIE 1. *u̯elH- 'to be strong, have power' ({ref Derksen 2008}:514).

notes: fr. ie. ken- 'scratch, scrape', ultimately cognate with Gr.: κὀνισ 'ashes' (Pokorny) and maybe also with 'scratch' in /lexeme/18887/

Further Indo-European cognates uncertain. The root is probably dialectal (North Slavic). Variants with a/u s/x can coexist in one single language or its dialects, normally with slightly different meaning (probably the variant with -a- is a result of a contamination with another root).

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside Slavic uncertain, cf. {ref ESSJa} 3:44-45, {ref Boryś 2005}:40-41, {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 1:381-382, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 1:265 for various proposals.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *pleu(g/k)-; cognate with 'fly' in /cognate/2504/, 'flow' in /cognate/222/, 'swim' in /cognate/1181/, 'rain' in /cognate/919/, 'wash' in /cognate/662/, Romance terms from OFrank. form of 'wave' related to NE FLOOD (Buck 1949: 680), therefore also cognate to 'river' in /cognate/2652/

notes: etym. dub.

justificationDiscussion: Related to the common words for '(finger)nail' widely found elsewhere in Indo-European via a derived feminine stem *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:354-355, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164).
Modern Indic and Slavic lexemes from PIE *h₁enter- 'inner part' ({ref Derksen 2008}:158, {ref ESSJa} 6:72-73, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:16-17 no. 357, {ref EWAia} I:76-77, I:166-167).

Taking into account lexemes like Polish ryj 'snout' and Russian rylo 'snout' (that can be expressively used also for human mouth), both derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'dig' (the original meanig was probably 'pig snout'), there is no reason to doubt on the relationship of PS *rŭtŭ to PIE *reu̯H-. The alternative etymology is much worse from the semantic point of view.

PS *guľati does not have a commonly accepted etymology. From the semantic perspective the hypothesis of {ref Boryś 2005}: 196 (*geu̯h₂-, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016} and {ref LIV²}: 189) looks most convincinɡ, the -l-/-ľ-, however, needs a formal explanaition.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *pьxati 'push, shove', a derivative of PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, crush' ({ref Derksen 2008}:420, {ref Boryś 2005}:420, {ref LIV²} 466-467).
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'do' in /cognate/5215/, 'say' in /cognate/4832/, 'straight' in /cognate/1180/, and 'true' in /cognate/1207/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed. Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *obačiti, traditionally explained as a compound verb *ob-ačiti where *-ačiti is interpreted as a derivative of PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' (cf. Slavic lexemes for 'eye' in /cognate/211/), although there are some formal issues with this identification (cf. {ref ESSJa} 26:91-92, 32:41-42). Less plausibly it has been suggested that the lexemes were borrowed through East Slavic from Polish (cf. {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 1:337, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 1:154-155, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 1:138), however, the presence of cognates in many Russian dialects (Smolensk, Kostroma, Pskov, Tver' Novgorod, cf. {ref ESSJa}: 26: 91} makes the hypothesis about an ordinary borrowing from Polish somehow questionable.
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:548, {ref ALEW} 1290-1291, 1301-1302; {ref LIV²} 177 mechanically reconstructs a root ?3. *g̑⁽ʰ⁾er- 'to shine, radiate').

Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *kyjь 'stick, club', a jo-derivative to *ky- < PIE *kuh₂- with regular laryngeal metathesis from zero-grade *kh₂u̯- (full-grade PIE *keh₂u̯- 'hit, split', cf. {ref ESSJa} 13:257-258, 12:10-11; {ref Derksen 2008}:265, {ref LIV²} 345-346).

Slavic lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *prostъ 'simple, straight' as though from PIE *pro-sth₂o-, a derivative to *steh₂- 'to stand, place' + *pro- 'forwards'. ({ref Derksen 2008}:421-422, {ref Boryś 2005}:484-485, cf. {ref NIL} 637-659).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:133-134, {ref Rejzek 2001}:220, 231-232, 305; {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:398 for further discussion).

There are enormous difficulties in reconciling this group of related Balto-Slavic lexemes to a PIE proto-form. Cf. {ref ALEW} 1081, {ref Derksen 2008}:499-500, {ref Derksen 2015}:459-460 for further discussion. A contamination or blend of between two roots *teu̯h₂- ({ref LIV²} 639-640) and *teu̯k- ({ref LIV²} 641) is a possibility. Cf. also Proto-Germanic *ϸeuha- 'thigh' in /cognate/6956/. The PIE root reference form *teu̯(h₂)k- is provisional only.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *vę̄zati 'tie', a derivative of PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'make narrow' ({ref Derksen 2008}:521, {ref Boryś 2005}:688; cf. {ref LIV²} 264-265, {ref NIL} 301-303).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic, cf. {ref ESSJa} 14:249-252, {ref Derksen 2008}:274, {ref Boryś 2005}:280 for further discussion of various hypotheses.

Balto-Slavic lexemes, related to the common words for '(finger)nail' widely found elsewhere in Indo-European via a derived feminine stem *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:354-355, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164, {ref ALEW} 681-682, {ref Derksen 2015}:327).

notes: < 'cooked'.
justificationDiscussion: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *pekʷ- 'to make ripe; to cook' ({ref ALEW} 477-478, {ref Derksen 2015}:237-238, {ref Derksen 2008}:393, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:255-256, cf. {ref LIV²} 468).
From Proto-Slavic *rъvati 'to tear' and further derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'to tear (up)' ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:452, {ref Derksen 2008}:441-442, {ref Boryś 2005}:528, {ref LIV²} 510).

Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:131).

notes: VLat. *MUTIOS and MUTILOS 'cut off, shortened' (Buck 1949: 1071), maybe finally related to /lexeme/14959/ and /lexeme/6724/

justificationDiscussion: Italic lexemes continuing Latin mandūcāre 'to chew, bite' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:431 no. 5292, cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 6/1:160-161). Latin mandūcāre is a secondary derivative to a primary verbal formation attested in Latin mandere 'to chew, bite' (cf. mandūcō 'glutton'). Traditionally attributed to a root *meth₂- 'to tear off' via a semantic development to *'tear (prey)' → 'to lacerate' → 'to devour' → 'to chew' ({ref LIV²} 442-443), alternatively {ref de Vaan 2008}:361-362 sees a development from *menth₂- 'to stir, whirl' ({ref LIV²} 438-439) via a nasal-infix stem *mt-n(é)-h₂-. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:382 consider a word of expressive origin.

Romance lexemes from Latin crassus 'thick, fat', forms; some from *grassus via a contamination with Latin grossus 'thick, fat' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:212). Further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:147, {ref de Vaan 2008}:141).
Romance forms from Latin botellus 'small sausage; intestine' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:109, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} I:464-465), further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:74-75).

Romance lexemes from Latin camba, gamba 'horse's ankle' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:143, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:111-120), most likely to be a loanword from Ancient Greek καμπή 'a bending, winding' in the technical language of horse veterinarians and breeders ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:267).
loan_notes: Borrowed into Latin from Ancient Greek as a terminus technicus; acquired specialised meaning 'leg' only later in Romance.

justificationDiscussion: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin lārgus 'generous, bountiful' ({ref DCECH} III:586-587, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:399), further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:342, {ref de Vaan 2008}:327).
The Latin and Romance forms are based on a reduplicated formation *pró-pro with dissimilation of the second *-r- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:492-493, {ref LIPP 2}:641).
Romance lexemes as though from Latin *tīrāre, of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:725, {ref DCECH} V:505-508 for further discussion).

Romance lexemes from Latin impingere 'to push, strike, drive at' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:358), further to PIE *pei̯g- 'to paint', probably a variant of the better attested root *pei̯k̑- 'carve out, cut out' ({ref LIV²} 464, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:465-466).

notes: Loan from Germanic, cf. /cognate/465/.
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Germanic *kratten- 'scratch' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:386-387).
Catalan lexemes from Latin labor 'work, labour' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:391), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:320).

Cf. Latin *tāliare 'to cut' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:704-705), a derivative to Latin tālea 'a cutting, piece of wood'. No further etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:673-674, {ref de Vaan 2008}:605).
Romance lexemes apparently going back to a stem *pe/itt- 'small', probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:543 no. 6544a, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 8:342-347).

Romance lexemes from Latin tornāre 'to turn (in a lathe)' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:46-80, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:729-730). A denominal verb from Latin tornus 'turner's wheel, lathe', in turn an old loanword from Ancient Greek τόρνος 'turning lathe' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:695-696).

Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE 2. *k̑el- 'warm' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:83), cf. {ref Nussbaum 1999} for a detailed discussion of the Latin stem formation; for Romance lexemes cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:139 no. 1506 (Lat. caldus 'warm'). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:294, {ref Kroonen 2013}:231.
No certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:30); possibly to *h₃emh₃- 'to grab' according to {ref de Vaan 2008}:40.

notes: Fr. AVEC = Lat. APUD + HOC (Diez 1864: 46)

justificationDiscussion: Iranic and Italic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'to suckle' ({ref MacKenzie 1990}:110, {ref EWAia} I:797, {ref de Vaan 2008}:210, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:281, cf. {ref LIV²} 138-139).

notes: Lat. crocus (ultimately a LW from Gk. κρόκος).
justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin crocum 'saffron flower' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:216), a loanword from Ancient Greek κρόκος 'saffron flower, Crocus sativus' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:152).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}:638, {ref Králik 2015}:589 for discussion of various hypotheses.
Slavic lexemes generally considered to continue a derivative from a PIE root *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'disgusting, gross' ({ref Derksen 2008}:160-161, {ref ALEW} 303-304, cf. {ref ESSJa} 6:81-82).
It is related to PS *golŭ ['naked']. The original meaning was thus 'stick without twigs, naked stick' {ref Rejzek 2001}: 218.
Slavic forms continuing a nominal derivative *per-mo- to PIE local adverb *per- 'through, beyond, over; very' ({ref LIPP 2}:611).

There is no certain etymology outside of Slavic. All the existing hypotheses (linking it to PIE *kes-, PIE *i̯eh₃s- and PIE *h₂ek̑-, cf. {ref LIV²}: 261, 311, 357) are unconvincing formally and/or semantically (cf. {ref ESSJa} 32:9-10, {ref Rejzek 2001}:421-422, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:178).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *goditi 'please', further derived from PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ({ref ESSJa} 6:188-190, {ref Derksen 2008}:172, {ref Rejzek 2001}:206, cf. {ref LIV²} 195).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *rokъ, derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *rekti 'speak, say' < PIE *rek- 'to order, determine' ({ref Derksen 2008}:433, 438; {ref Boryś 2005}:517, 532; cf. {ref LIV²} 506).

Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' ({ref Cheung 2007}:224-225); Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *goniti ‘chase, persecute’ and further to PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:177, {ref ESSJa} 7:23, 196-197, cf. {ref LIV²} 218-219).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'cut' in /cognate/6606/, 'hit' in /cognate/1998/, 'kill' in /cognate/3551/, 'throw' in /cognate/8806/, 'tail' in /cognate/1935/, 'run' in /cognate/5193/.

justificationDiscussion: Slavic lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *orvĭnŭ, a derivative of PIE *reu̯h₁- 'to open' ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:155-156, {ref Rejzek 2001}:546, cf. {ref LIV²} 510).

notes: = Lat. CRATIS 'wickerwork, hurdle', Gr. KARTALOS 'basket', SKT> KṚT- 'twist thread together, spin' (Buck 1949: 668)
element(s) -NIEWAZ, etym.?

justificationDiscussion: Derived from Proto-Germanic *minwizan- 'smaller', a derivative of PIE *mei̯H- 'become small, recede' ({ref Faltings 2010}:393-394, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:412, {ref LIV²} 427).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Kluge 2011}:142, {ref de Vries 1977}:70). Traditionally considered an extended from an extended form of a root *bʰer- 'to cut' according to {ref IEW} 166 (cf. {ref Orel 2003}:37). Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:53 for a proposed comparison to Albanian barmë 'bast'.
North Germanic lexemes continuing Old Norse ský 'cloud', further connections unclear (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:508).

notes: < 'excrement'
justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:446. cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:410-411).

notes: lit. 'not-sharp', VAS = NE 'to whet' (Buck 1949: 1070)

justificationDiscussion: Originally a loanword in Old Norse from Middle Low German spīsen ({ref de Vries 1977}:536).
loan_notes: Loans from Middle Low German in turn from Medieval Latin spesa from Latin expensa (pecunia)

justificationDiscussion: Tocharian and Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *preK- 'to be afraid' ({ref LIV²} 491, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:711-712, {ref Adams 2013}:402, {ref Lehmann 1986}:111, {ref Kroonen 2013}:402). The identity of the root final velar is not certain.
Denominal formation to a loanword from Latin campus 'field' in the sense of 'place for fighting' (cf. {ref EWA 5}:368-370, {ref Kluge 2011}:468).
Etymology uncertain but generally connected to PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'to kindle' ({ref LIV²} 259) despite phonological difficulties, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:11; {ref Orel 2003}:7; {ref de Vries 1977}:99-100.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:615, {ref Kroonen 2013}:549).

No accepted etymology outside of Germanic; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:292, for the suggestion that Proto-Germanic *saiwi- is a probable non-IE, pre-Gmc. loanword. {ref Kroonen 2013}:423, 435-436 accepts an etymology from IE *sei̯kʷ- without referring to other hypotheses.

The Germanic forms from PGmc. *wenistra- are in all likelihood derivatives from PGmc. *weni- 'friend' as a taboo replacement as 'the friendly side' (cf. similarly motivated replacements in Gk. ἀρίστερος 'left', Lat. sinister 'left'); cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:623, {ref Orel 2003}:455, {ref Kroonen 2013}:579. For the IE root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 682-683.
Possibly related to English 'cut' in /cognate/2579/, but further etymology uncertain; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:286.

notes: numeral one plus negative suffix -gi

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *gamala- 'old', of uncertain etymology. Cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:154, {ref Orel 2003}:125, {ref Kroonen 2013}:166 for various proposals.

notes: North Germanic only.
justificationDiscussion: Possibly to be connected to the verbal root underlying Ved. √śak- ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:264-265, 301-302), but the etymology is not fully certain; cf. {ref EWAia} II:600-601.

notes: see also Goth. /lexeme/20063/

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Early Low German ({ref de Vries 1977}:368). The inherited lexeme is found in Elfdalian 'smell' /cognate/8301/ and 'sky' in /cognate/2903/.  Since this is present in Old Norse, the case can be made that this is not necessarily a parallel loan, although the inclusion of Faroese in this set suggests the loan must have been particularly early.

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *halan- 'tail, tip', traditionally further compared variously with Sanskrit śalá- 'staff', Middle Irish cail 'spear', Ancient Greek κῆλον 'shaft, arrow' from a proposed IE root *k̑el- 'to prick, sting' ({ref IEW} 552, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:204, {ref Orel 2003}:156, {ref Kroonen 2013}:203; not in {ref LIV²}), but more sceptically regarding the proposed comparanda cf. {ref EWAia} II:615-616, {ref KEWA} III:306, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:10-11, {ref Beekes 2010}:685.

From Old Norse kasta, generally connected to ON kasa 'to bury in a cairn', kǫs 'heap, kǫstr 'hill', without a clear etymology outside of (North-)Germanic ({ref de Vries 1977}:303, 342-343; cf. for various proposals in older literature). No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Old Norse kasta is generally connected to ON kasa 'to bury in a cairn', kǫs 'heap, kǫstr 'hill', without a clear etymology outside of (North-)Germanic ({ref de Vries 1977}:303, 342-343; cf. for various proposals in older literature). No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.
Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ({ref LIV²} 175-176, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:213-216, {ref Kroonen 2013}:166-167).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. cf. 'go' in /cognate/8326/, 'leg' in /cognate/1649/, 'walk'; proposed cognacy with /cognate/8366/ cf. notes in class.

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref NIL} 706-715, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575-576, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:1015-1016).

No certain etymology outside of North Germanic; traditionally considered a derivative of PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow' ({ref de Vries 1977}:671 citing {ref IEW} 81ff. *u̯ē-; not in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}).

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse skógr; no certain etymology outside of Germanic. Traditionally derived from a root *(s)kek- / *skeg- 'springen; lebhafte Bewegung' ({ref IEW} 922-923, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:497). Not in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}.

A Germanic and Balto-Slavic isogloss, therefore postulating a root reconstruction *skeu̯bʰ- to PIE remains uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:6, {ref LIV²} 560. Cf. also {ref Kroonen 2013}:444-445 who additionally compares Sanskrit kṣóbhate 'to shake, tremble' and postulates a root *kseubʰ- with a metathesis occurring in the Balto-Slavic and Germanic forms; more skeptical to extra-Germanic connections cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:416-417).

loan_notes: Loanword status insecure, cf. OED entry.

justificationDiscussion: Further connections uncertain. Perhaps to be connected with the complex of 'white' words from PGmc. *blank- but due to the difference in semantics this connection remains unclear, cf. OED, {ref EWA 2}.
Probably a loan from Old French diguer ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Derivative to Proto-Germanic *drita- 'shit, dirt' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:103-104, {ref Seebold 1970}:164-165).

West Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *habiga- 'weighty, heavy', a derivative from the root as the Germanic strong verb *hafjan- 'to raise, lift', and further derived from PIE *keh₂p- 'to seize, snatch' ({ref Seebold 1970}:244-246, {ref Orel 2003}:147-148, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:198, {ref LIV²} 344-345).

According to {ref Kroonen 2013}:257, Old English huntian continues a Proto-Germanic weak verb *hūnton- as though from PIE *⁽k̑⁾n̥t-néh₂-, an iterative formation to Proto-Germanic *hinϸan- 'to reach for' and connects further to Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand' as though from PIE *⁽k̑⁾ont-ú-, although there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic; cf. also {ref Lehmann 1986}:122 and discussion to Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand' in /cognate/234/.

Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *lagja- 'leg; hollow bone, stalk'. Attestation is restricted to North Germanic and there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:321-322).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:247, {ref Kroonen 2013}:358).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)} for further discussion.
No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:522, {ref Kroonen 2011}:333, {ref Kroonen 2013}:460-461 for further discussion.
Identical with 'hair' in East Germanic. Possible comparisons outside of Germanic, but ultimately uncertain. Cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:338, {ref Kroonen 2013}:504 for further discussion.
Old English tígan is a denominal formation as though from earlier *téag-jan 'to bind', based on OE téag 'rope', to be connected with ON taug 'rope', probably from Germanic *taug-.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref LIV²} 676; {ref Kroonen 2013}:570. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)} suggests a contamination of two different verbal stems (cf. s.v.).

Etymological connections outside of Germanic unclear. A hypothesis going back to Karl Horst Schmidt supposing a putative PIE *gʷʰei̯bʰom to connect the lexeme with Tocharian A kip, B kwīpe 'shame; modesty' presupposing for Germanic a semantic development 'shame' > 'vulva' > 'woman', but this hypothesis remains uncertain and alternative etymologies are also possible for the proposed Tocharian comparandum, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:976, {ref Kroonen 2013}:584, {ref Adams 2013}:257.
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to grind, crush' ({ref de Vries 1977}:392, {ref Lehmann 1986}:260, cf. {ref LIV²} 432-433).

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse hræðast 'to fear' (vb.) or light verb constructions based on Old Norse hræðr 'fear' (n.). No certain connections outside of North Germanic (not in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}; {ref de Vries 1977}:263 reconstructs a Germanic stem *hrēð-).

Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- 'to look, seek after' ({ref LIV²} 668-669, cf. {ref EWAia} II:509-510, {ref Cheung 2007}:411, {ref Bailey 1979}:309, {ref de Vries 1977}:650-651, {ref Orel 2003}:441, {ref Kluge 2011}:978).

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', further from the PIE heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥- ~ *u̯ed-en- 'water', derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref NIL} 706-715, {ref Kroonen 2013}:575-576).
Tocharian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *deu̯k- 'to pull' ({ref LIV²} 124, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:982, {ref Seebold 1970}:503-505, {ref Lehmann 1986}:346, {ref Kroonen 2013}:515, 525).
North Germanic lexemes continuing a denominal verb to Proto-Germanic *klawō- 'claw', further etymology uncertain ({ref de Vries 1977}:313, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:496-497, {ref Kroonen 2013}:292).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fraiwa- 'seed', further etymology disputed (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:123, {ref Kroonen 2013}:152).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hwassa- 'sharp', further connections outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:315-316, {ref Kroonen 2013}:264, 266, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:284-285).

Traditionally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'push' ({ref IEW} 1032-1034, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:564-565), but more recently {ref Kroonen 2013}:487 argues that the Germanic internal evidence cannot support this etymology.

North Germanic lexemes traditionally compared with PIE *tep- 'be warm, hot' ({ref IEW} 1069-1070, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:418, {ref de Vries 1977}:606-607), but not accepted by {ref LIV²} 629-630 s.v. 1. *tep-. Not in {ref Kroonen 2013}.
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'worm' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:397, {ref Kroonen 2013}:600). Perhaps further connected to PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' (cf. /cognate/348/ for further discussion).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *belgan- 'to swell', further derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'to swell' ({ref Seebold 1970}:99-100, {ref Kroonen 2013}:73-74, cf. {ref LIV²} 73-74).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:252, {ref Lehmann 1986}:192-193.
No clear etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:389, {ref Kroonen 2013}:555. For older proposed connections to Baltic material, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:525.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: *urengh- < IE *uer- 'turn, bend', the same root as in 'worm in /cognate/348/

justificationDiscussion: Italic and Romance lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry (through heat)' ({ref LIV²} 257-258, {ref de Vaan 2008}:53, {ref Untermann 2000}:130-131, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:50 no. 620).

From Latin Lat. infāns, infāntis ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:362), a fossilised participle of the verb for, fāri 'speak' with the negative prefix in-, lit. 'un-speaking' > 'infant, baby' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:316, {ref de Vaan 2008}:231).

Probably of onomatopoeic origin; the older proposed loanword hypothesis from Old High German tūmōn (cf. e.g. {ref Buck 1949}:671) is questionable for formal reasons (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:747, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:403-409 for further discussion).

Romance lexemes derived from Old French breu, a loanword on Germanic *brod- 'broth' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002}:297, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:118; elsewhere in Romance cf. It. brodo 'broth', broda 'soup', etc.)

Romance lexemes from Latin tūtāre, tūtārī ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:446-449). Further root etymology disputed: Either to ?*teu̯H- '(freundlich) beachten, betrachten; schützen' ({ref LIV²} 639-640) or to* teu̯h₂- 'to be strong' > 'keeps strong, protects' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:632-633).

Romance lexemes derived from French gauchir 'to warp, deform', originally a loanword from Old Low Franconian *wenkjan 'to waver, falter' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:555-560 for further discussion).

Romance forms from Latin pressē, the adverbial form of Latin pressus, -a, -um 'pressed, straitened' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 9:365-367, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:559), a past passive participle to Latin premō, -ere 'to press'. Further root etymology difficult (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:487-488 for further discussion).

Romance lexemes from Latin pulsāre 'to strike, beat' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:566-567), secondary from Latin pellere 'beat against, push, strike', further to PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:455-456, {ref LIV²} 470-471).
As though from Latin *trīnicāre 'divide into three' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:277-285). Further to PIE *trei̯- 'three' (cf. /cognate/146/).

notes: of imitative *krak, but prob. blended with Grmnic. forms such as /lexeme/21781/ (Buck 1949: 265)

justificationDiscussion: Light verb construction with French debout as the semantic-bearing morpheme, from Old French de + bot, the latter derived from an Old Low Franconian loanword *bōtan 'strike, hit' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:219, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:109).
Romance lexemes from Latin bastum 'stick' as a secondary n-stem *bastō, -ōnis. No further etymology ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 1:279, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:83, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:67).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Romance < Lat. MINUTIA 'particle, trifle' (Buck 1949: 890), see cogn. 'small' in /cognate/1173/

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin iactāre 'to hurl' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:372), an intensive/iterative stem to Latin iaciō 'to throw' and further to PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:292-293, {ref LIV²} 225). The Italic derivatives from this root show an anomalous extension in *-k-.
Loan from West Germanic (Frankish) *markôn 'to designate' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 16:527-533 for further discussion).

Romance lexemes from Latin galbinus 'yellow' {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:312, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:24-27). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Celtic loanword (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:266, 291, 297 for further discussion).

notes: < Lat. PILA 'bundle (of hair)'? (Dietz 1864:342)
justificationDiscussion: Continuing a derivative of Latin pilleum 'felt', cf. Old French peille 'rag, cloth' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 8:494-503, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:537, No. 537). Perhaps to be further connected with pilus 'hair' or a loanword from Greek πῖλος 'wool or hair made into felt' but ultimately obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:507, {ref de Vaan 2008}:465).
Anatolian and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰedʰh₂- 'to pierce; to dig' ({ref LIV²} 66, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:654-655, {ref de Vaan 2008}:229).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: prob. nursury word, not necessarily cogn. with one another, see comment on /cognate/79/

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Germanic (pace {ref Kluge 2011}:768, cf. {ref EWAia} II:434).

notes: 'because of' < 'during the time' < 'while' (n.)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *knuk(k)an- 'knuckle', perhaps a root-extended variant *g̑nu-g- to PIE *g̑enu-, *g̑neu- 'knee' but this is not certain (cf. discussion in {ref Kluge 2011}:507-508, {ref Kroonen 2013}:298).

notes: etym. dub.?
justificationDiscussion: From Early Modern High German smutz, from the verb smutzen 'to spot, speckle, stain', etc. Further connections ultimately uncertain. Seebold ({ref Kluge 2011}:818) tentatively suggests the root of Ancient Greek μυδάω 'to be damp, dripping' (without s-mobile), although the etymology of this Greek form is not without its own difficulties (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:974, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:717-718, {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:263 for further discussion).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:678-679 and {ref Kluge 2011}:980 for several possibilities of formal correspondences with Vedic forms vītá-  (from different etymological sources); the etymology to a compound *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- 'set apart' favoured by {ref Lubotsky 1994}:203-204, {ref Kroonen 2013}:584-585 requires the assumption of a glottalic model of interpretation for the PIE voiceless stops within the framework of the Leiden School, where traditional *d is assumed to have been pre-glottalized *[ˀd], and susceptible to dissimilation to *h₁, which is interpreted as glottal stop *[ʔ].

Lexemes apparently continuing earlier *raska-, further root etymology disputed though often assumed to continue a derivative of PIE *ret- 'to run' ({ref Kluge 2011}:349-746, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:437-438).

From MHG swanz, a backformation to MHG swanzen which is in turn in all likelihood an intensive formation to schwanken 'to waver, oscillate', in turn derived from the adjective schwank 'swaying' < Gmc. *swanka- (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:832, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:573).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *k(o)m(t)-; = Lat. CUM, Skt. KÁM 'with', Hitt. KATTI, Grk. KATA (Kloekhorst: 463), the same stem in 'with' in /cognate/960/

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic lexemes from the collocation σταχτή (κονία) 'distilled (ashes)', from the process of distilling ashes to produce lye (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:1324), further to Ancient Greek στάζω 'drop, let fall' from PIE ?*steh₂⁽g̑⁾- (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1388, {ref LIV²} 592.

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek κοιλία 'cavity of the body; thorax with abdomen', further derived from Ancient Greek κοῖλος 'hollow, hollowed out, spacious, deep' < PIE *k̑eu̯H- 'hollow' (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:690, {ref Beekes 2010}:730-731).
Modern Greek lexemes continuing a diminutive formation of Hellenistic Greek *πούλλο(υ)ς, a loanword from Latin pullus 'young fowl, chicken' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1146).

Greek and Indic lexemes derived from PIE *denk̑- 'to bite' ({ref LIV²} 117-118, {ref EWAia} I:688, {ref Beekes 2010}:299). Sometimes connected to these lexemes are also  Tocharian AB tsāk- 'to bite', but these lexemes are probably better explained via PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'to sting' (cf. {ref LIV²} 142, {ref Ringe 1988-1990}:71).
Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ἀμαυρός 'dim, faint' ({ref Andriotis 1999}:828-829). No further etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:71-72, {ref Beekes 2010}:84).

No clear etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:34, {ref Beekes 2010}:38-39}). It is likely that Ancient Greek αἷμα was a lexical replacement for the inherited word for 'blood', ἔαρ < *h₁esh₂-r̥- (cf. /cognate/859/), which was only retained as a poetic word in the language of Homeric epic and other archaic poetry.
Modern Hellenic lexemes derived from Ancient Greek κόκκος 'kernel', further etymology unknown ({ref Babinotis 2010}:694-695, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:553, {ref Beekes 2010}:733}).

Hellenic lexemes of uncertain etymology, perhaps from a PIE root *pneu̯- if cognate with Germanic lexemes attested by, e.g., Old Norse fnýsa 'sniff, snort' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:920, {ref Beekes 2010}:1213-1214, {ref LIV²} 489).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to kindle; to burn' ({ref LIV²} 345, {ref Beekes 2010}:618, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:480-481). For the root reconstruction with initial palatovelar *k̑- (rather than plain velar *k-) cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'day' in /cognate/2234/, 'dry' in /cognate/8281/, 'hard' in /cognate/8428/, 'sun' in /cognate/5455/, 'fog' in /cognate/6235/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Greek unclear; possibly with 'ice' in /cognate/4901/ (cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:28-29, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:588-589, {ref Beekes 2010}:786). {ref Adams 2013}:236 attempts to connect Tocharian B krośce to the Greek forms, but this is formally problematic (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:786).

The root etymology in this set tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 238 to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' via a stem formation *h₁r̥-sk̑é-, although formally the Hellenic lexemes may also reflect a secondarily thematised present stem *h₁erg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ- to *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'to climb, ascend' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:377, {ref Beekes 2010}:468).

Hellenic lexemes generally derived from PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, to hew' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:563-564, {ref LIV²} 555), but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:748-749 also considering the possibility of substrate origin.

Hellenic and Armenian lexemes as though from a PIE stem *Heh₂m-, an exclusive Greek-Armenian lexical isogloss ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:412, {ref Beekes 2010}:518, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:156, cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:96-97).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off' ({ref LIV²} 144-145, {ref Beekes 2010}:533-534). Older etymologies (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:287) compare forms related to Skt. dhvān- 'dark', however the internal structure of the Greek derivatives θάνατος, θνῄσκω must be accounted for in terms of preforms *dʰn̥h₂-eto-, *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑e/o- respectively, thus {ref LIV²} reconstructs *dʰenh₂-.  The Modern Greek present πεθαίνω was backformed from Ancient/Medieval Greek aorist (ἀ)πέθανον, with replacement of -ανον with present morph. -αίνω and regular loss of initial unstressed ἀ-.

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek σκύλος 'dog', morphologically transferred into the o-stem declension from Ancient Greek σκύλαξ 'whelp, puppy' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1290). No agreed etymology outside of Greek; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1023, {ref Beekes 2010}:1361 for various proposals.

Connections outside of Greek unclear; occasionally proposed to Arm. čʻor 'dry' (cf. /cognate/5006/), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:182, {ref Beekes 2010}:1035-1036, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:546).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek χῶμα 'earth thrown up, bank, mound' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1619), an abstract noun derived to the same root as Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'to heap up, raise, stuff with rubbish or earth' from PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1654, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1281, {ref LIV²} 179).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek τρώγω 'to gnaw, nibble, munch' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1461). Generally considered to continue a thematic present stem *tréh₃⁽g̑⁾-e- to a root *treh₃⁽g̑⁾- 'to gnaw away' on the basis of comparison with Tocharian B treṣṣäṃ 'to chew (up)' < *tr̥h₃⁽g̑⁾-sk̑é- ({ref LIV²} 647, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1141-1142); alternatively {ref Beekes 2010}:1514-1515 prefers a 'Pre-Greek' origin.

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek μακρός 'long' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:810), ultimately a zero-grade derivative *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:660-661, {ref Beekes 2010}:895, {ref NIL} 478-481).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'to run away, flee' via the causative-iterative stem *bʰogʷ-éi̯e- 'to make run, flee' (cf. {ref LIV²} 67, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1183-1184, {ref Beekes 2010}:1559).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *leig-, leiq- 'miserable, ill', cogn. with 'small' in /cognate/1326/ and 'some' in /cognate/2939/

justificationDiscussion: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing derivatives of Ancient Greek παλαίω 'to wrestle' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1024), and probably further to be derived from PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach, draw near' ({ref LIV²} 470-471, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1145).

Modern Greek lexemes derived from Ancient Greek φῶς, -τός 'light', ultimately a derivative of PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to shine' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1575, {ref Beekes 2010}:1551-1552, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1168-1170, cf. {ref LIV²} 68-69).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *sreu-, comp. 'river' in /cognate/2647/ and possible relation btw. IE *sreu- and *rei-, prob. also cogn' with 'wet' in /lexeme/26050/

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ({ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}; cf. {ref LIV²} 476, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:655-660, {ref Beekes 2010}:1181-1182, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:286-287, 294, {ref EWAia} II:71-72, {ref Matasović 2009}:129)
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fall' in /cognate/7561/, 'feather' in /cognate/7563/, 'leaf' in /cognate/790/, 'narrow' in /cognate/4064/, 'river' in /cognate/1525/, 'run' in /cognate/5968/, 'sleep' in /cognate/8796/, 'wing' in /cognate/1567/

justificationDiscussion: Boeotian καλϝός shows that the Proto-Greek stem for the adjective was *kalu̯o-, but there is no secure etymology beyond of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:486-487, {ref Beekes 2010}:626-627).

Modern Greek lexemes directly continuing or continuing secondary derivatives of Ancient Greek χόρτος 'enclosure, court', from PIE *gʰor-to- 'fence, enclosure' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1606-1607, {ref Beekes 2010}:1644-1645).

Modern Greek πράσινος 'green' was originally a derived adjective 'leek-green' based on Ancient Greek πράσον 'leek'.
