Compared with Lat. porrum, one could assume a common pre-form *pr̥som, but the maintenance of intervocalic *-s- in Greek is unexpected. For this reason it is more likely we are dealing with independent loanwords from a third source ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:934, {ref Beekes 2010}:1129; cf. s.v. Lat. porrum in {ref de Vaan 2008}:481-482).

From Hellenistic Greek μαλλί(ον), the diminutive of Ancient Greek μαλλός 'flock of wool' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:811-812); further etymology outside of Greek unclear ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:663, {ref Beekes 2010}:889).

Hellenic lexemes from a PIE stem *gʰebʰh₂l-. A reconstruction with a laryngeal *-h₂- is required because of the connection with Tocharian AB śpāl 'head'; also connected with OHG gebal 'skull' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:522, {ref Beekes 2010}:682-683, {ref Adams 2013}:703).

notes: root and outside connections? comp. ENDON 'inside, at home'

justificationDiscussion: A denominative verb to Gk. κυνηγός 'hound-leader, huntsman'. The lexical root for the 'leader' element of the verbal governing compound is from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive' (cf. {ref LIV²} 255f.), compounded with *k̑un- 'dog' (cf. {ref NIL} 436-440 s.v. *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥- 'Hund' cf. /cognate/21/).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *h₂ner- 'man', the same stem as in 'man' /cognate/2316/ and 'person' /cognate/449/

justificationDiscussion: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek πάγος 'that which is fixed or firmly set; rock, ice' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1016), further derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm, stiff' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1141, 1184, cf. {ref LIV²} 461).

notes: = Lat. Goth. AN 'interr. part.'

justificationDiscussion: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing a denominal formation from Ancient Greek σκότος 'darkness, dark' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1287). For further discussion and justification of the root ref. form, cf. 'shadow' in /cognate/8269/.

Tocharian and Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯- ({ref Beekes 2010}:843-844, {ref Adams 2013}:614). The Tocharian lexemes are generally considered to be based on an *mn-stem neuter to an IE root *lei̯- ({ref Ringe 1996}:109, {ref Adams 2013}:614), and connected to the complex of words surrounding Gk. λειμών 'wet, grassy place, meadow' λίμην 'harbour', and λίμνη 'lake', but cf. {ref van Windekens 1976}:271-272 for older hypotheses.

Root etymology uncertain. Perhaps to *h₂er- 'to fit (together)' (cf. {ref LIV²} 269-270) in the original sense 'more fitting' > 'better' > 'the better side, left' via popular euphemism ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:106-107, {ref Beekes 2010}:128, 131-132).

From συκώτιον, the diminutive of Ancient Greek σῦκον. The meaning 'liver' was taken on as a transferred epithet from the phrase ἥπαρ συκωτόν 'liver (of an animal) fed on figs' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1354). Further etymology obscure, probably a prehistoric loanword ({ref Beekes 2010}:1421). For a parallel semantic development in Romance cf. /cognate/905/ from Lat. fīcus 'fig'.

Hellenic lexemes from a zero-grade derivative *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:660-661, {ref Beekes 2010}:895, {ref NIL} 478-481, cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:810).

Hellenic lexemes to be derived from the same root as Ancient Greek φθείρω 'to ruin, destroy' < *dʰgʷʰer-i̯e/o- 'flow away, disappear' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1198, {ref Beekes 2010}:1569). The onset cluster ψ- found in some Modern Greek dialects has probably come about via contamination with Modern Greek ψύλλα 'flea' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1626).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body, gore' ({ref NIL} 444-448, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:580, {ref Beekes 2010}:774).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃er- 'to set in motion; rise' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:826, {ref Beekes 2010}:1109-1110; cf. {ref LIV²} 299-300).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Hitt. ištāman- 'ear', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1058-1059, {ref Beekes 2010}:1408, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:411-413).

Variants among the Ancient Greek dialects point to an original u-stem *stenu- that was later thematised as *stenu̯o- (with subsequent loss of medial *-u̯-), but further connections outside of Greek remain unclear ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1051-1052, {ref Beekes 2010}:1399).
Gk. κοντός 'short' appears to derive from the same root as Ancient Greek κεντέω 'to sting, goad', for further discussion cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:563, {ref Beekes 2010}:672-673.

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek λαιμός 'throat, gullet' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:755). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:613-614, {ref Beekes 2010}:824).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kn̥-i̯o-, a derivative of PIE *ken- 'new, fresh' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:609, {ref Beekes 2010}:616). As a verbal root, cf. {ref LIV²} 351.

Modern Hellenic lexemes backformed from Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)μύσσομαι 'to blow one's nose, snort' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:906), further to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, take off' ({ref LIV²} 443-444, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:726, {ref Beekes 2010}:985-986).

Hellenic lexemes derived from the adverb πάλαι, probably a fossilised case form of a root noun *pl̥h₂-ei̯ and to be connected with πέλας 'near', πελάζω 'approach, draw near', πίλναμαι 'draw near, approach', πλησίον 'near' (adv.) from *pelh₂-, in the sense *'in the (near, recent) past' > 'old' ({ref Chadwick 1976}, {ref Beekes 2010}:1144-1145). Older etymologies attempting to connect to the same root as Att. τῆλε 'far away' (cf. Aeol. πήλυι) cannot be correct since Mycenaean pa-ra-jo does not contain a labiovelar as one would expect ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:851, {ref Beekes 2010}:1144-1145).
A denominal verb from Ancient Greek παῖς (gen. παιδός) 'child', cf. /cognate/1462/ for further discussion.

Perhaps to be connected with Balto-Slavic forms (Latv. merguôt 'rain slowly', merga 'soft rain', Ru. morositь) to a root *mergʰ- (with Greek forms reflecting a Schwebeablaut variant *mregʰ-), but this etymology is uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:195, {ref Beekes 2010}:238; not in {ref LIV²}).

Modern Greek lexemes continuing a derived adjective to Ancient Greek κόκκος 'kernel' used in the production of red dye, further etymology unknown ({ref Andriotis 1999}:729, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:553, {ref Beekes 2010}:733}).

From Ancient Greek σωστός, a derivative of AGk. σῶς 'healthy, safe, intact' and further derived from PIE *teu̯h₂- 'swell, be strong' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1084-1085, {ref Beekes 2010}:1440; cf. {ref LIV²} 639-640).

Hellenic lexemes whose root etymology is traditionally disputed between the near-homophonous roots *peth₁- 'to fall', 1. *peth₂- 'to spread out', and 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:931, {ref Beekes 2010}:1225-1226, cf. {ref LIV²} 477-479). See now, however, {ref  LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} merging *peth₁- 'to fall' and 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' into a single, more basic root *pet- 'to fly; to fall'. In view of this, the basic etymology to *pet- has been tentatively accepted here.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fall' in /cognate/7561/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/1486/, 'feather' in /cognate/7563/, 'leaf' in /cognate/790/, 'narrow' in /cognate/4064/, 'run' in /cognate/5968/, 'sleep' in /cognate/8796/, 'wing' in /cognate/1567/

notes: < SXOINOS 'rush, reed' (Buck 1949: 549)

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *leg̑- 'to collect, to pick up' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:625-626, {ref Beekes 2010}:841-842, {ref LIV²} 397).

Probably a substratum loan in view of the Ancient Greek dialectal variants (Dor. γλέπω) and alternation in final aspiration in related vocabulary (cf. βλέφαρον, γλέφαρον 'eyelid'), cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:219-220 for further discussion. In view of these alternations, possibly borrowed as a root ?*gʷlep⁽ʰ⁾- (cf. note by Scarborough in this set).

Hellenic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE *sper- 'to spread, scatter' ({ref LIV²} 580). The connection of Albanian lexemes to this class follows {ref Demiraj 1997}:56, {ref Orel 1998}:93, but more skeptically cf. {ref Holm 2011}:78; for Hellenic, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1035-1036, {ref Beekes 2010}:1379-1380, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1316).

Hellenic lexemes, traditionally connected with Baltic lexemes (Lith. ver̃pti, 'spin', Latv. virpêt 'spin with a spindle' ({ref IEW} 1156), but the evidence of Myc. e-ra-pe-me-na without initial *w- makes this etymology impossible ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:967, {ref Beekes 2010}:1275-1276). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain.
Gk. κοντός 'short' appears to derive from the same root as Ancient Greek κεντέω 'to sting, goad', for further discussion cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:563, {ref Beekes 2010}:672-673.

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek τραγῳδέω 'to take part in a tragic drama; speak in tragic style, declaim' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1442), a denominal verb to Ancient Greek τραγῳδός 'singer and dancer in the tragic choir, tragic actor'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1498 for various suggestions.

Anatolian, Hellenic, and Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original athematic root-present to PIE *h₁eh₁s- 'to sit' ({ref LIV²} 232, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:252-255, {ref Beekes 2010}:518, {ref EWAia} I:181).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *dér-mn̥ '(flayed) skin, leather' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:265-266, {ref Beekes 2010}:318; a derivative of PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' cf. {ref LIV²} 119-121).

The best IE etymology, is a derivation to *h₂u̯ers- 'rain' (so {ref Wackernagel 1888}:129 = Kl.Schr. 1.632, tentatively accepted by {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:838-839, {ref Beekes 2010}:1128). The hypothesis of substrate borrowing is a possibility but, given that there is no concrete extra-Greek comparison for it, gratuitous. For the purposes of cognacy Wackernagel's etymology has been followed here.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek κοιμάομαι 'go to bed' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:690-691), a secondary denominal verbal formation from an unattested noun *κοιμή or *κοιμός to the same root as the Ancient Greek primary verbal derivative κείμαι 'to lie' from PIE *k̑ei̯- 'to lie' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:509-510, {ref Beekes 2010}:633-634, cf. {ref LIV²} 320).
North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *smēha- 'small', further etymology uncertain ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:519, {ref Kroonen 2013}:456, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:519).

notes: IE *(E)PI- 'upon' + *SED- 'sit' (Buck 1939: 575)

justificationDiscussion: Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:767, {ref Beekes 2010}:1037-1038; cf. {ref ALEW} 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.
No convincing etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:522-523, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:892-893, {ref Beekes 2010}:1182).
No satisfactory etymology outside of Greek; for some proposed inner-Greek connections cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:384-385, {ref Beekes 2010}:479.

notes: = Arm. ARBI 'I drank', Lat. SORBEO 'I gulp down'

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *preh₁- 'to blow on; stoke up' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1192, {ref LIV²} 489, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1153).

SMG κολυμπώ, etc. from Ancient Greek κολυμβάω 'dive headlong (like a κόλυμβος-bird)' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:701), a denominal verb to κόλυμβος 'little grebe, podiceps minor'. Further etymology obscure ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:559, {ref Beekes 2010}:741).
Greek and Celtic lexemes as nominal derivatives of PIE *h₁ers- 'rear' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:838, {ref Beekes 2010}:1127-1128, {ref Matasović 2009}:118).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek σκέπτομαι 'I look about carefully, examine' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1279-1280), further derived from PIE *spek̑-, with metathesis *sp…k > sk…p ({ref Beekes 2010}:1347-1348, {ref LIV²} 575-576).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *deh₁- 'to bind' ({ref Beekes 2010}:321-322, {ref LIV²} 102, cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:338).

Within Hellenic the root of the noun, *γλῶχ- / *glōkʰ 'point', is attested via γλωχίς 'end of a yoke strap, barb of an arrow, etc.', but there are no known cognates outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:229-230, {ref Beekes 2010}:278).

No certain etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1063-1064, {ref Beekes 2010}:1413-1414);  {ref LIV²} 603 mechanically reconstructs ?*strebʰ-, but ?*stregʷʰ- also remains theoretically possible.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek ἐξερέω 'I speak out, utter' with semantic shift to 'spew out, vomit' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:948), further to PIE 1. *h₁reh₁- 
to ask, question' ({ref LIV²} 251, but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:391-392).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Medieval Greek περπατῶ, further from Ancient Greek περιπατέω 'walk about' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1093). Probably further to PIE *pent- 'find (a way)', although the precise details of the stem-formation are uncertain (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1157, {ref LIV²} 471-472).

Modern Greek lexemes derived to the root of Ancient Greek ζέω 'boil, seethe' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:530-531), further to PIE *i̯es- 'to boil, foam' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:399-400, {ref Beekes 2010}:499-500, {ref LIV²} 312-313).

Originally 'fresh', a transferred epithet from the phrase νηρόν ὕδωρ 'fresh water' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:915-196), further to PIE *neu̯- 'new, fresh' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1018, cf. {ref NIL} 524-526). Not the same root as PIE *neu̯- 'to nod, tilt (the head)' (cf. {ref LIV²} 455-456).

Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as a transferred adjective in the phrase nummi aspri 'rough coins', the original semantic development to 'white' appears to have been '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white', cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:223-224, {ref Beekes 2010}:154.
Hellenic and Armenian lexemes generally derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe' ({ref NIL} 307-311, {ref Beekes 2010}:101-102, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:416, {ref Olsen 1999}:27, cf. {ref LIV²} 267-268).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Nuristani, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, to fall'. For the root reconstruction cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}. For individual branches cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:658-659, {ref Beekes 2010}:1248, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:286-287, {Turner 1962–1966}:437 no. 7733, {ref Kroonen 2013}:138-139, {ref de Vaan 2008}:458, {ref Matasović 2009}:126).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fall' in /cognate/7561/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/1486/, 'feather' in /cognate/7563/, 'leaf' in /cognate/790/, 'narrow' in /cognate/4064/, 'river' in /cognate/1525/, 'run' in /cognate/5968/, 'sleep' in /cognate/8796/.

justificationDiscussion: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek δασύς 'thick with leaves, thickly wooded' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:333). Often further compared to Lat. dēnsus 'thick, close, compact' but the comparison is formally problematic and therefore there is no clear etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:253, {ref Beekes 2010:305}).
Etymology outside Hellenic uncertain ({ref Chantraine {1968–1980}:1025-1026, {ref Beekes 2010}:1364).

Modern Greek χρονιά 'year' from Ancient Greek χρόνος 'time' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1613-1614), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1277-1278, {ref Beekes 2010}:1613-1614 for discussion of older but unconvincing attempts at an IE etymology).

A derived adjective from Hellenistic Greek κίτρον 'fruit of the citrus tree', a loanword from Late Latin citrium, cf. Classical Latin citrus 'citrus tree' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:667-668, {ref Beekes 2010}:705).

Etymology outside of Hellenic uncertain, possibly to be connected with verbs φλέω 'to teem with abundance, abound' and φλύω 'to boil over, bubble up' as derivatives of PIE *bʰleu̯H- 'to overflow'; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1214, {ref Beekes 2010}:1580, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1546-1547.

Hellenic and Baltic lexemes generally connected with Indic lexemes in the meaning 'dirty' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:680-681, {ref Beekes 2010}:923-924; cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:554, {ref EWAia} II:332-333).

Hellenic and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑elh₃- 'green, yellow' ({ref Derksen 2008}:542, {ref Polański 1962-1994}:1067-1068, {ref ALEW} 1296, 1325-1327, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1263-1264, {ref Beekes 2010}:1638).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'moon' in /cognate/2337/, 'green' in /cognate/6332/, 'red' in /cognate/3832/, 'white' in /cognate/2411/ 'yellow' in /cognate/7535/.

justificationDiscussion: Originally a denominal verb to Ancient Greek κτύπος 'loud noise, crashing sound', probably of onomatopoeic or expressive origin ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:592-593, {ref Beekes 2010}:792, {ref Babinotis 2010}:740).

Etymology for these lexemes follows that of {ref Weiss 1994}:143-145 and {ref de Vaan 2008}:639-640 to *u̯eh₁- over the older proposed etymology to *u̯egʷ- (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:745-746). Romanian ud 'wet' < Lat. ūdus may belong to this class but could also belong to PIE *u̯egʷ- in /cognate/5276/, cf. discussion in /cognate/8427/.
Hellenic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *pleth₂- 'be(come) wide, broad' ({ref NIL} 564-566; cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1205, {ref Derksen 2008}:404).

SMG ξαπλώνω, from Medieval Greek ἐξαπλώνω, remodelled present stem from Ancient Greek ἐξαπλόω 'unfold, roll out' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:943). The verbal form is based on the compound adjective ἁπλόος 'single, simple', whose first element ἁ- is evidently from IE *sm̥-, but the etymology of the compound's semantic bearing head -πλόος is less clear (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:97, {ref Beekes 2010}:117 for further discussion).
Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek κοπτερός ({ref Babinotis 2010}:689). Further root etymology in this class follows {ref LIV²} 555 to PIE *(s)kep- 'to chop', but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:748-749.

Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Lith. kvė̃pti 'breathe' ({ref ALEW} 545-546, {ref Derksen 2015}:268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison (cf. Chantraine 1968–1980}:494-495, {ref Beekes 2010}:638-639).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek ὀμαλός 'equal, level, smooth' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:973), further to be considered a derivative of PIE *sem-, cf. Ancient Greek ὀμός 'common, one and the same, equal, similar, level' < *som-o- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:799-800, {ref Beekes 2010}:1074-1075).
Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰeng̑ʰ- ({ref NIL} 13-15, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1159-1160, {ref EWAia} II:220-221, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:518, {ref ALEW} 115-116).

Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit rakṣā- f. 'preservation, care; guarding'; 2. 'ashes (used as a preservative)', further derived from Ved. √rakṣ- 'to protect' and derived from PIE *h₂leks- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:611, no. 10551-10552; {ref EWAia} II:422, {ref LIV²} 258).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10187 s.v. 11./12. *moṭṭ(h)a- 'big, fat'; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √kart- 'to cut (off), split, break', ultimately from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:145 no. 2854, {ref EWAia} I:315-326, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560).
Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vārdala- vārdala- 'rainy day, bad weather' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:674, no. 11567), further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} III:195 for various proposals.
Derivatives from Vedic √kalp- 'to be well ordered' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:150 no. 2944). Further etymology disputed, cf. {ref EWAia} I:323-324 for further discussion.

Similar to Iranic *kutī̆- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Iranic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also {ref ESIJa} IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.

notes: = Skrt. STOKÁM 'drop, little' (Turner 1931: 300)

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'to make smoke' ({ref EWAia} I:795, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:392 no. 8649, {ref de Vaan 2008}:249, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:305 no. 3572).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5539; non-Indo-Aryan
justificationDiscussion: A loanword from Dravidian, cf. Telugu eḍama 'left, left-hand, left-hand side', Tamil iṭai, iṭam 'left side' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:311 no. 5539, cf. {ref Burrow & Emeneau 1984}:44 no. 449).
loan_notes: Cf. Telugu eḍama 'left, left-hand, left-hand side', Tamil iṭai, iṭam 'left side'

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: from Vedic pārśvá-, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 100f. s.v. parśu- f. 'rib'; cf. /cognate/3966/

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Indic uncertain ({ref KEWA} II:667, {ref EWAia} II:369). For Middle and Modern Indic forms cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:591, no. 10250.

notes: cf. Sanskrit kathayati ʻconverses with, describesʼ (MBh.) (√kath-), derived from kathā- f. 'narration, telling how and why' (MBh.), ultimately derived from kathā 'how, why', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2703f., Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 148f.
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit katháyati 'converses with, describes' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:135 no. 2703), derived from the Vedic interrogative adverb kathā́ 'how?' and further to the interrogative pronoun ká- 'who, which?' < PIE *kʷó-, *kʷí- ({ref EWAia} I:294-295, 284-285, cf. {ref LIPP 2}:452-479).
As though from Sanskrit kharju- 'itching, scratching, scab', probably originally a loanword from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:201 no. 3827, {ref KEWA} I:303).

notes: Khas. = Skt. CYĀVÁYATI 'causes to fall' (Turner 1931: 344)

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *seh₁dʰ- 'to reach the goal, be successful' ({ref EWAia} II:722-723, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:773 no. 13401, cf. {ref LIV²} 517).

No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic, although a connection with Germanic words for 'fox' (cf. OHG fuhs) remains worth considering ({ref EWAia} II:140, {ref KEWA} II:298; cf. also discussion in {ref Kroonen 2013}:157-158). For Middle and Modern Indic cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:467, no. 8249.

notes: cf. Skrt. jaḍa- 'stupid, dumb', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5090
< Skrt. ŚOCYATE 'is purified' (Turner 1931: 622), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12621; LIV, p. 331
justificationDiscussion: Continuing Skt. śocyate 'is made to feel pain', the Sanskrit the passive of Vedic śocáyati 'sets alight, burns' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:732 no. 12621). The verbal root continues Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331).
Continuing Sanskrit jhāṭa- 'forest, arbour' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:296 no. 5362). Further etymology unclear ({ref KEWA} I:454).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5362; related to /cognate/6868/? - cognate with 'forest' /cognate/3954/

justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:111 no. 2368 *ullaṭati 'turns over', 2. *ullaṭyate 'is upset' 3. ullāṭayati 'causes to turn over' from ud- + √laṭ-. Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} III:87, III:95.
Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 386-388.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'round' in /cognate/4906/, 'live' in /cognate/3185/, 'navel' in /cognate/7117/, 'yesterday' in /cognate/6487/, 'turn' in /cognate/5879/.

notes: fem. of ŽMOGUS 'man' (Buck 1949: 83)

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:163 no. 3193, {ref EWAia} I:355-356).

notes: from Vedic varṣám n. 1. ʻrain ʼ (RV+), pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV), 2. ʻyear' (ŚB) (root vr̥ṣ-), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 446, no. 1139: Pali vassa- m. n. ʻrainʼ, pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ, Prakrit vāsa- m. (or < vārṣa-), varisa- m. n. - NB. New Indo-Aryan forms are Sanskritisms - ultimately cognate with 'rain' in /cognate/1612/

justificationDiscussion: Well attested in Pamir languages, origin uncertain.
Modern Indic lexemes as from Vedic pāṁsú- 'soil, dust, sand' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:452 no. 452, further probably to PIE ?*pē(n)s- ({ref EIEC} 499, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:114-115).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *pakšá- 'wing, pinion', further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain unclear ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:429-430 no. 7627, {ref EWAia} II:62).

notes: Gypsy ROM 'a Gypsy man' < Skrt. ḌOMBAḤ 'a particular low caste' (Turner 1931: 261)

justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes from Vedic jáṅghā- 'leg', further derived from PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ({ref EWAia} I:564, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:280 no. 5082, cf. {ref LIV²} 175–176).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11348 s.v. *varta- 'round stone', *'rolled / rolling stone', from PIE *uert- 'roll, rolled; turn, spin', cf. Skrt. vartula- 'round, circular', Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 156
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indo-Iranic *varta- *'turning around, circular object' → 'round stone', further to be derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to revolve' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:661 no. 11348, {ref KEWA} II:154-156, cf. {ref LIV²} 691-692).

Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hu̯aǰ-, from Proto-Indo-Iranic *su̯aǰ-, cf. Ved. √svaj- ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:152-154). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:788, cf. {ref LIV²} 610-611 reconstructing ?*su̯eng- on the basis of the comparison of Old Irish seng 'schlank' < *'biegsam').

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'sun' in /cognate/5156/, 'swell' in /cognate/3436/, 'wind' in /cognate/342/, perhaps also 'wind' in /cognate/9440/.

notes: from *kuha- 'fog, mist' according to Turner 1962-66, p. 175, no. 3386, perhaps related to guh- 'hide, conceil' (?); unclear
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing a stem *kuha-, further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:175 no. 3386).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: = Skt. ASAU, AMUSYA (Turner 1931: 43); comp. also 'that' in /cognate/2683/

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit ṭaṅka- ~ ṭaṅga- 'leg', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:301 no. 5428, {ref KEWA} I:456).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11109 s.v. leṭyáti ʻsleepsʼ Pāṇ.
comp. /lexeme/2069/

< *śāṭa- ~ *śāda- 'falling, rotting', different blends of Vedic -śada- 'falling' with Sanskrit śāta- m. 'fallout' (śātana- n. 'the cutting off') and MIA -saṭá- (Pali); cf. Vedic (AV) parṇa-śadá- m. 'falling of leaves' ~ Pali paṇṇa-saṭá- 'heap of fallen leaves'; Turner 1962-66, no. 12267, 12381, 12386, Mayrhofer KEWA III, p. 323; ultimately from PIE *k̑ad- 'fall', cf. ²LIV, p. 318 (IEW 516) - ATTENTION: Maithili साराब is VERB
related to Nep. RAGAṚANU 'to rub, cause to work overtime'? (Turner 1931: 526)

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from *choṭṭa- 'small', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:279 no. 5071).
No certain etymology outside of Indic ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:729 no. 12579, {ref EWAia} II:652-653).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4782
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit cikkaṇa- 'smooth, slippery' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:259 no. 4782). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Dravidian (cf. {ref KEWA} I:385).
Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick' No certain further etymology ({ref EWAia} I:692, {ref KEWA} II:11-12, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:350 no.6128).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10186
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a Sanskrit root √moṭ- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:586 no. 10186). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} II:692 for further discussion.
Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish druimm 'back'. Further etymology unclear, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:203-204 for various suggestions.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *māro- from PIE *meh₁-ro- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:18, {ref Matasović 2009}:258).

Cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} for {ref LIV²} 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben'. The Celtic lexemes in this set have been tentatively assigned to the new root *u̯elh₂- 'beat, hit' assuming a semantic development 'beat, hit' > 'wound' > 'blood'. See further {ref Lucht 2007}:65, {ref Matasović 2009}:410.

Goidelic lexemes continuing an Indo-European stem *konh₂m-, cf. Ancient Greek κνήμη 'leg', Old English hamm 'ham' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:129-130, {ref Matasović 2009}:211, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:723).
Baltic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃eu̯g̑- 'cold' ({ref ALEW} 76, {ref Karulis 1992} I:22, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:8, {ref Matasović 2009}:301).
Hellenic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₂rei̯- 'to count, reckon' ({ref Beekes 2010}:131, {ref Lehmann 1986}:281-282, {ref Matasović 2009}:313).

Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *latyo- 'day', as though a *-i̯o-stem derived from PIE *leh₁t-. Alternatively, an analysis as a secondary derivative to a primary t-stem from a hypothetical root *leh₁- remains possible; cf. note by Scarborough in the cognate class citations below for more extensive discussion.
Etymology uncertain, perhaps of onomatopoeic origin? (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:6).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).
From PIE *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- 'sun' ({ref NIL} 606-611; for the semantics cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:201-202, {ref Matasović 2009}:324).
Generally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'hit, beat' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:177-180, {ref Schumacher 2004}:642-646, {ref Matasović 2009}:393; cf. {ref LIV² 601).

Etymology uncertain. Perhaps an expressive variant of Old Irish eitte 'feather', or a derivative of the verb cel- 'hide, cover' and subsequently contaminated with OIr. eitte ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:116).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).

Goidelic lexemes probably continuing a compound containing Proto-Celtic *retu- 'course', and ultimately a derivative of PIE *ret- 'to run' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:112, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:310).

Iranic (and Celtic) lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:6-10, {ref Bailey 1979}:499, {ref MacKenzie 1990}:112, {ref Matasović 2009}:62). Late parallel replacement/shift in Celtic, /cognate/1709/.
Of uncertain etymology, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:408-409 for various proposals.
No certain etymology outside of Goidelic, cf. {ref Lucht 2007}:199 for further discussion.
Celtic lexemes derived from a stem *pl̥h₂-mo/eh₂- to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, broad' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:132, {ref NIL} 562-564).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/4527/, 'mountain' in /cognate/2804/, 'thin' in /cognate/1923/, 'wide' in /cognate/5264/, 'smooth' in /cognate/6801/, 'earth' in /cognate/5892/, 'stand' in /cognate/8055/, 'tree' in /cognate/8103/.

justificationDiscussion: Celtic lexemes generally derived from PIE *treu̯d- 'to thrust, push', although the specific stem-formation is disputed ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:149-151, {ref Matasović 2009}:391, cf. {ref LIV²} 651-652).
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:109 for a summary of older attempts at an etymology in {ref IEW}.

Celtic lexemes, denominal verbal formations based on Proto-Celtic *selgā 'hunt', a derivative of PIE *selg̑- 'to let go, release, send away' ({ref Matasović 2009}:329, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:80-81, {ref Falileyev 2000}:82, {ref Deshayes 2003}:325, cf. {ref LIV²} 528-529).

Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *g̑ar- (?*g̑eh₂r-) 'to sound, call' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:331-334, {ref Matasović 2009}:153, {ref LIV²} 161, cf. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:186, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:187).
No certain etymology outside of Goidelic ({ref Lucht 2007}:241).
Celtic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *mīlo- 'animal' continuing PIE *meh₁lo- 'small animal' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:51, {ref Matasović 2009}:271-272).
No known etymology outside of Goidelic ({ref Lucht 2007}:254).

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally considered to be from PIE *(s)lei̯b- 'drag, glide' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:131, cf. {ref LIV² 566 s.v. ?*(s)lei̯b-, {ref IEW} 663) via an original meaning '(slippery) slope', but {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} finds this development semantically dubious.

The Goidelic forms in this class from Old Irish bél 'lip; (pl.) mouth' are doubtlessly connected to Middle Welsh gwefl 'lip', but the reconstruction of a Proto-Celtic preform is difficult ({ref Matasović 2009}:419), cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:29 for a survey of older, unconvincing suggestions.

Perhaps further from PIE *koi̯(H)lo- if connected with Latvian kaîls 'naked, bald', but the comparative semantics are rather remote (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:6, {ref Matasović 2009}:220).

notes: From Old Irish gar 'short; near'

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *3. men- 'to rise, stick up' ({ref EWAia} II:313, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:566 no. 9858, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:72, {ref Matasović 2009}:276, cf. {ref IEW} 726, 747-748, {ref LIV²} 437).
No certain etymology; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:14 for a survey of various hypotheses.

The Goidelic forms in this class are from a compound imm·beir < Proto-Celtic *ambi- (preverb) 'around' (< PIE *h₂(e)mbʰi- or ámbʰi) + *ber- 'carry' (< PIE *bʰer-), cf. {Schumacher 2004}:218-233, {ref Matasović 2009}:62, {ref LIV²} 76-77, {ref LIPP 2} 36.
The Modern Goidelic forms in this class derive from the OId Irish compound do·srenga.
Generally connected with Germanic words for 'dark' < *dʰerg- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:57-58, {ref Matasović 2009}:96; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:153, {ref IEW} 251).

Anatolian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ebʰ-. Since {ref Watkins 1973} the Celtic words have been connected to Hittite and Palaic words for 'river' from a PIE n-stem *h₂ebʰ-n-, more recently followed by {ref Willi 2004} and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:294-295 s.v. Hitt. ḫapa-. A popular alternative analysis reconciles the Celtic words with Indo-Iranic words for 'water' (cf. /cognate/157/) and Baltic and Nuristani lexemes for 'river' (cf. /cognate/7856/) via a derivation using the 'Hoffmann Suffix' *h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:23-24 s.v. Proto-Celtic *abon-; {ref NIL} 311-317 tentatively reconstructs for Celtic ?*h₂ep-h₃on-, cf. {ref NIL} with references to further literature), but this analysis must assume an inner-PIE development *-ph₃- > *-b- (e.g. *pi-ph₃-e-ti > Ved. píbati '(s)he drinks'; cf. Lat. bibō with voicing assimilation to the reduplicated syllable). Since the number of examples of *-ph₃- > *-b- are few in number, this must remain a conjectural proposal.  The cognacy in this class therefore follows the etymology of {ref Watkins 1973} to a root *h₂ebʰ-. Cf. also {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:4-5.
Without secure correspondences elsewhere in Celtic or other Indo-European languages; perhaps a non-Indo-European substratum borrowing ({ref Lucht 2007}:331-332).
Etymology uncertain, an old proposal of {ref Thurneysen 1917}:312 connects with Old Irish fairsing 'broad, spacious'.

notes: < Lat. SPHERA (Buck 1949: 53)

justificationDiscussion: From PIE *telH- 'become quiet' ({ref Matasović 2009}:382-383; {ref LIV²} 621). NB: {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:170 conflated two roots *tel- now reconstructed separately as *telH- ({ref LIV²} 621) and *telh₂- ({ref LIV²} 622); {ref LIV²} 621 s.v. *telH- does not connect the Germanic lexemes connected to OHG stillen as {ref Matasović 2009}.
No known etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:32, {ref Matasović 2009}:309).
No certain connections outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:123-124, {ref Matasović 2009}:210).
No plausible etymology ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:101).

notes: outside connections?

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Goidelic difficult to establish with certainty. Cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:143-144 for previous proposals and further discussion.
Derived from Old Irish cengal 'link, belt, tie', a loanword from Latin cingulum 'belt' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:65).
No known etymology; perhaps a substratum loanword (cf. {ref Lucht 2007}:397).
Etymology outside of Celtic is disputed; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:104, {ref Lucht 2007}:410-411 for a survey of various proposals.

notes: etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 64)

justificationDiscussion: Generally compared with Latin badius 'bay, chestnut brown', but without any further correspondences elsewhere in Indo-European; cf. {ref Lucht 2007} for extensive discussion of alternative proposed etymologies (cf. also {ref Matasović 2009}:70, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:113, {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1999}:358, {ref IEW} 104-105).

notes: < GALLA 'gall-apple, air-bubble, light object' (Buck 1949: 680)

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes based on a stem *pīkk-, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:536)

notes: < Skrt.  TÁT, TADÁ or TÁTHĀ  (Turner: 270)

justificationDiscussion: As through from Sanskrit *rukta- 'bright, liked' to Vedic √roc- 'to shine', further to PIE *leu̯k- 'to be bright' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:621 no. 10755, {ref EWAia} II:463-464, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'day' in /cognate/691/, 'eye' in /cognate/994/, 'moon' in /cognate/2336/, 'salt' in /cognate/3845/, 'star' in /cognate/6295/, 'sun' in /cognate/739/, 'white' in /cognate/2401/.

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Proto-Indo-Iranic kʰaru̯á- 'mutilated, imperfect' (cf. Ved. kharvá- 'mutilated' {ref Turner 1962–1966}:201 no. 3832), possibly further connected within Indo-Iranic to Avestan kauruua- if the term means 'mutilated', further connections outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ({ref EWAia} I:448-449).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic jána- 'race, person' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:281, no. 5098), further derived from PIE *g̑ónh₁-o-, derived from PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to produce; beget' ({ref EWAia} I:566, {ref NIL} 139-153, {ref LIV²} 163-165).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 151, no. 2972, for Kashmiri p. 152, no. 2979
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Vedic √kaṣ- 'to scratch, scrape' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:151 no. 2972, for Kashmiri cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:152 no. 2979). According to {ref EWAia} I:331-332 possibly a colloquial form of Vedic √karṣ- 'to pull, drag, plough', if so then from PIE *kʷels- 'to draw a furrow' (cf. {ref LIV²} 388-389).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 6097 and 6102; see note on Iranian words in /cognate/1970/

notes: Bielmeier (1979: 189 in: Historische Untersuchung zum Erb- und Lehnwortschatzanteil im ossetischen Grundwortschatz, Frankfurt/Bern/Las Vegas: Lang) argues against the assumption that lenk is a loan from Caucasian languages and discusses the possibility of an IE origin by comparing it with Lithuanian leñgvas 'light' and Germanic *lenhw-ta-z (cf. Gothic leihts).

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic śuddhá- 'clean, bright, white', a derivative of Vedic √śodh- 'to clean, to make clean' and further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:725-726 no. 12520, {ref EWAia} II:657). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, {ref LIV²} 330 mechanically reconstructs ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'to become clean'.

Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre' ({ref EWAia} II:525-526, but cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:526). For Modern Indic forms in this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:666, no. 11418.
From Indic *ṭōkk- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:304, no. 5476. No further etymology.

From Vedic sthūlá- 'large, thick', a variant of Vedic sthūrá- 'id.' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:795 no. 13776), ultimately from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-), a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ({ref EWAia} II:768-769, {ref NIL} 639). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'big' in /cognate/7106/.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no 11443 s.v. Vedic vásā- (vasā́- TS, vaśā- AitBr.) f. ʻfat, greaseʼ (VS), ʻbrainʼ Kathās.

justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes from Vedic himá- 'cold, frost' ({ref EWAia} II:815-816). From the ablaut patterns attested among the daughter languages a basic root *g̑ʰei̯- can be abstracted, to which was derived an original m-stem noun *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- ({ref NIL} 162-169).

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Sanskrit khúra- without certain etymology, possibly loans from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:207 no. 3906; {ref KEWA} I:310, {ref EWAia} I:454, cf. {ref Burrow 1948}:376). Perhaps further connected with lexemes as though from Sanskrit *khuṭṭa- 'peg, post' in /cognate/9630/, but these could also be parallel loans.

notes: Nep. ARU = Skt. ÁPARAḤ 'other' (Turner 1931: 23)
cf. Turner 1931: 534, 1962-66, no. 10539 s.v. rakta- ʻcoloured, dyedʼ (ŚB), ʻredʼ (ŚāṅkhGr̥.), n. ʻbloodʼ (Mn.), °aka- ʻredʼ (VarBr̥S) (√rañj-), Pali Prakrit ratta-, Rom. rat m.; cf. /cognate/6611/
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes from *raktá- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, Iranic *ra(n)ǰ- ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:610, no. 10539; {ref EWAia} II:424-425, {ref Cheung 2007}:313-314 {ref Henning 1971}:46, {ref LIV²} 587).

notes: originally name of the river Ganges, cf. Vedic gaṅgā f.
justificationDiscussion: Continuing Vedic gáṅgā- '(river name), Ganges' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:211 no. 3952), further etymology uncertain. Perhaps a reduplicated nominal formation to Vedic √gam- 'to go' (< PIE *gʷem-) or a pre-IE river name.

Modern Indic lexemes as though from derivatives of Vedic kaṇḍū- 'itching, scratching' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:135 no. 2689). Further etymology unclear, possibly a loanword from Austroasiatic ({ref KEWA} I:147, {ref EWAia} I:292).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66 s.v. khalla m., no. 3848: "connexion with challi <-> and of both with skhádate ʻcutsʼ Dhātup. [...] doubtful"?
< Vedic nāgá- m. 'snake' (ŚB); perhaps cognate with /cognate/1358/ - but later also used for 'elephant', perhaps rather < PIE *nogʷó- 'naked', cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 151 for further suggestions
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic nāgá- 'elephant; snake' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:404 no. 7039). Further etymology not certainly explained, possibly a derivative of PIE 2. *negʷ- 'naked' if the original meaning was 'the hairless, naked animal' (cf. {ref KEWA} II:150-151, {ref EWAia} II:33 {ref NIL} 513-515 for further discussion).

notes: cf. Old Vedic káṇa- m. 'grain of corn' (AV), later 'drop of water' via 'particle', Turner 1962-66, no. 2661
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:133 no. 2661 s.v. Vedic káṇa- 'grain of corn', further etymology unclear ({ref EWAia} I:291.

notes: Nep. DULKI 'trotting', DULKI HIRNU 'to trot' (Turner 1931: 316)
Turner holds loanword fr. Skt. SUVĀSINĪ 'a woman who resides in her father's house', a term of courtesy for a married woman' (1931: 627)
Not in Turner 1962–1966
= Skrt. kuṇḍate 'limps' < Turner 1931: 123
Kathās., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4564
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit caṅga- 'of good understanding; handsome' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:247 no. 4564). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Dravidian loanword ({ref KEWA} I:267).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5878, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 684f.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Arabic هواء / hawāʾ 'air'.
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 714, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:429).
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *keh₂u̯l(o)-, further analysis of the word formation within Indo-European is unclear (cf. {ref ALEW} 467-469, {ref Derksen 2015}:233).
Ossetic lexemes, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:14).
Baltic lexemes continuing *gʷerh₃- 'to devour' ({ref LIV²} 211-212, cf. {ref ALEW} 315-316, {ref Derksen 2015}:172).

notes: lit. 'not-sharp', ASS(TRUS) maybe ultimately cognate with /lexeme/6922/; = Lat. ACUTUS, OSC OSTRU (Buck 1949: 1069)
Formerly identical with Lat. tālis 'such', but probably formed independently from the same morphemes.
justificationDiscussion: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *teh₂li- 'as such' ({ref ALEW} 1115-1116).
Baltic lexemes derived to PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to beat, split' (cf. {ref ALEW} 470-471, 517; {ref Derksen 2015}:234, 254, {ref LIV²} 345-346).
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic ({ref ALEW} 512-513, cf. also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:303-304).

Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to be cold, freeze' ({ref LIV²} 323, cf. {ref EWAia} II:641, {ref Cheung 2007}:336-337, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:64, {ref ALEW} 1008-1009, {ref Derksen 2015}:439-440, ref NIL} 416-417).

Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound'; possibly in origin an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ({ref ALEW} 331-332). Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 210-211.

Baltic lexemes continuing denominal verbs based on nominal formations in the meaning 'tree, wood; forest' continuing PIE *medʰi̯o- 'middle' ({ref ALEW} 625-627, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:382, cf. {ref NIL} 465-466).
Perhaps to PIE ?*leu̯p- '(ab)schälen' ({ref LIV²} 420, {ref IEW} 690-1), cf. {ref EWA 5}:1454-1457; otherwise obscure (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:328).
No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 512-513 for further discussion).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *kelH- 'to rise up, to tower' ({ref ALEW} 441-442, 475-476, {ref Derksen 2015}:221, 236, cf. {ref LIV²} 349).

East Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *u̯ordʰo- 'word'. In East Baltic the o-grade of the root was generalised, although Old Prussian wīrds, wirds 'word' reflects a zero-grade < *u̯r̥dʰ-o-, also found in Germanic (Gothic waurd 'word' etc.). The stem is also attested with e-grade vocalism in Latin verbum 'word' ({ref ALEW} 1188-1189, {ref Derksen 2015}:489).

Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either (1) to *kolso- underlying the Germanic and Italic lexemes in /cognate/265/, or (2) to PIE *kʷelh₁- ({ref LIV²} 386-388) as a reduplicated formation (cf. {ref ALEW} 433-434). The latter explanation is favoured by {ref Derksen 2015}:220. Both proposed etymologies are not precise correspondences and require special pleading to explain the deviations so that it is difficult to favour one etymology over the other (cf. {ref ALEW} 434 for further discussion).
East Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE 2. *lei̯H- 'to pour' ({ref ALEW} 581-582, {ref Derksen 2015}:284, cf. {ref LIV²} 405-406).

Traditionally postulated to a root *ser- 'red' ({ref IEW} 910-911, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:763), although this etymology is no longer accepted by {ref ALEW} 891. Cf. also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:534, {ref Karulis 1992} II:155-156.
Baltic lexemes, to judge from cognates such as Ved. śā́kha- 'branch', probably continuing an ablauting h₂-stem, like PIE *k̑ók-eh₂- ~ *k̑ek-h₂- (cf. {ref ALEW} 1003-1005, {ref Derksen 2015}:439).

Lexemes continuing a derivative with PIE *-mo- to Proto-Germanic *malan- 'to grind', further from PIE *melh₂- 'to crush, grind' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:242-243, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:351, {ref LIV²} 432-433).

Cognacy in this class follows {ref ALEW} 423, but cf. {ref Kortlandt 1998}:15 (= {ref Kortlandt 2003}:122) who rejects the etymology with Armenian, assuming that Baltic initial j- is secondarily acquired (similarly cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:215).
Possibly from an IE formation *h₁ēd-so- *'flesh (for eating' > 'skin' according to {ref Adams 2013}:549, but this proposal remains uncertain.
East Baltic lexemes, without certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 623-625, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:422-423 for further discussion).
Cf. Old Lithuanian tiẽsus 'straight, direct', without certain connections outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 1100-1102).
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *tekti, in turn derived from PIE *tekʷ- ({ref Derksen 2008}:489, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:159, cf. {ref LIV²} 620-621).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'come' in /cognate/15/, 'run' in /cognate/5199/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/3259/, 'river' in /cognate/5249/, 'turn' in /cognate/3066/.

notes: = OPrus IR 'and, also', Gr. ARA 'now, thus'
Loan from Belarusian
justificationDiscussion: Loan from Old Belarusian blagij 'shame, miserable, bad' prior to the spirantisation of /g/ > /h/, cf. Modern Belarusian благі / blahi 'bad' ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:65-66, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:45-46).
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic, cf. {ref ALEW} 1307, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:784 for further discussion.

notes: element(s) TODEL

justificationDiscussion: Traditionally derived from Lith. pìlti 'to pour (out); to fill' and further to PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill, become full' ({ref ALEW} 773-775, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:460, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:592-593).

No certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. Latv. dižs 'great'). Commonly conntected with PIE *dei̯h₂- 'to light up' (LIV² 108, IEW 183f.), which is however problematic, as Winter's lengthening is lacking ({ref ALEW} 204-205; not in {ref Derksen 2015}, cf. also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:107-108).
No certain etymology outside of (East) Baltic (cf. Latv. juõds 'demon, evil spirit'). See {ref ALEW} 419-420, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:238 for further discussion.
Baltic lexemes generally considered derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ({ref LIV²} 359, {ref ALEW} 463-464, {ref Derksen 2015}:231).

notes: Cf. Lith. pur̃vas 'dirt', Latv. pùrvs 'swamp'
justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 404, 829).
Baltic lexemes generally derived from PIE *u̯elg- 'to become damp' ({ref ALEW} 1178-1179, 1242-1243; {ref Derksen 2015}:486, cf. {ref LIV²} 676).
Further etymology outside of (East) Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 469-470, 486, {ref Derksen 2015}:234, 243, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:282 for various proposals and further discussion.
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *u̯ei̯s- 'to sprout, thrive' ({ref ALEW} 1170-1171, {ref Derksen 2015}:485, 495; cf. {ref LIV²} 671).
Derived from Lithuanian gìrti 'to praise', further derived from PIE *gʷerH- 'to express agreement' ({ref ALEW} 335-336, {ref Derksen 2015}:171, 178-179, cf. {ref LIV²} 210-211).

Cf. Old Lithuanian plùnksma 'feather' ({ref ALEW} 802). Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fly_N' in /cognate/5414/, 'wing' in /cognate/343/, 'bird' in /cognate/186/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/224/, 'swim' in /cognate/8317/, 'feather' in /cognate/2263/.

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology (cf. {ref ALEW} 990-991).
No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 1328-1330, {ref Derksen 2015}:522).

Lithuanian júoktis 'to laugh' is derived from juõkas 'laugh, laughter'; probably a German loanword (cf. Prussian jōk 'joke') according to {ref Derksen 2015}:214; cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007} who considers there to be no good etymology.
loan_notes: German loanword (cf. Prussian dialect jōk), ultimately from Lat. iocus 'joke'

justificationDiscussion: Possibly to be connected with PIE *s⁽k̑⁾eH- in /cognate/7189/, but the stem-formation in Celtic is difficult to reconcile (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:342-343, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Originally fossilised past passive participle to a primary verbal derivative of the PIE root PIE *h₂er- 'to fit together', now lost in in Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 56-57, {ref Derksen 2015}:61).
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 1118-1119).

Generally attempted to be derived (as though) from IE *dʰrus-ko/eh₂- to a root *dʰreu̯s- 'herabfallen, abbröckeln', and cognate with a primary verb attested in Germanic (cf. Goth. driusan, OE drēosan, OS driosan 'to fall'), cf. {ref ALEW} 234, {ref Derksen 2015}:142, {ref LIV²} 157-158.

notes: Cognate with e.g. Russian смотреть 'look at'
justificationDiscussion: Baltic lexemes generally agreed to be cognate with Proto-Slavic *motriti 'look at, watch' from a Proto-Balto-Slavic stem *mot(r)-, but a further IE root etymology remains disputed (cf. {ref ALEW} 620-621, {ref Derksen 2015}:307, {ref Derksen 2008}:327 for further discussion).
Uncertain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1131-1132, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:691 for further discussion. [Not in {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}].

Possibly, but not certainly, to be connected with Latv. diêt, in turn from PIE *dei̯h₁- 'dahinjagen' ({ref LIV²} 107), cf. {ref ALEW} 169, {ref Derksen 2015}:112), alternatively to Lith. dejà 'Wehklage', without certain etymology (cf. {ref ALEW} 189).

Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives to the same root as Lithuanian deñgti 'to cover', further from PIE *dʰengʰ- 'to cover' ({ref ALEW} 174, 192-193; {ref Derksen 2015}:115, 121-122, cf. {ref IEW} 250 [not in {ref LIV²}]).

Root reference form for this class follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} to PIE *mei̯gʰ- 'to close the eyes, blink', cf. also {ref LIV²} 427, {ref ALEW} 644-645, {ref Derksen 2015}:315-316, {ref Smoczyński 2005}:240, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:395-396 for further discussion.
A derivative of Lithuanian gyvatà 'life', ultimately a derivative of PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' (cf. {ref ALEW} 340, {ref Derksen 2015}:180 for discussion of the nominal derivation).

notes: "imitative" (Buck 1949: 334)

justificationDiscussion: East Baltic adjectives derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ({ref ALEW} 801, {ref Derksen 2015}:367, {ref NIL} 562-564).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/4527/, 'mountain' in /cognate/2804/, 'hand' in /cognate/1712/, 'wide' in /cognate/5264/, 'smooth' in /cognate/6801/, 'earth' in /cognate/5892/, 'stand' in /cognate/8055/, 'tree' in /cognate/8103/.

notes: = OCS KRĚSŬ 'turn, change of weather', ON HREIFI 'wrist' (Buck 1949: 667)

justificationDiscussion: Identical to 'liver' in other Slavic languages ({ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1714, cf. {ref ESSJa} 6:72-73, {ref Derksen 2008}:158).

West Slavic lexemes as though from Proto-Slavic *ogonъ and derived from *o(b)-goniti sę 'keep off, drive off' in the sense of 'a part of the body an animal can swat away insects with' (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:383-384). Further derived from an o-grade form of PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref ESSJa} 7:23, 196-197; {ref Derksen 2008}:177, {ref LIV²} 218-219).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'cut' in /cognate/6606/, 'hit' in /cognate/1998/, 'kill' in /cognate/3551/, 'throw' in /cognate/8806/, 'hunt' in /cognate/1298/, 'run' in /cognate/5193/.

justificationDiscussion: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *lě̀to 'summer', as though an o-stem derived from PIE *leh₁t-. Alternatively, an analysis as a secondary derivative to an original t-stem from a hypothetical root *leh₁- remains possible; cf. note by Scarborough in the cognate class citations for further discussion.

Traditionally derived to PIE *mag̑- 'to spread, smear' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 3:613, {ref ESSJa} 18:23-25, {ref LIV²} 421). Cf., however, {ref Derksen 2008}:304 s.v. Proto-Slavic mazati 'smear, anoint' with an alternative proposed etymology to Lithuanian mė́žti 'manure, muck out', etc.
Onomatopoeic in origin, no further etymology outside of Slavic ({ref ESSJa} 8:135).
As though continuing an Indic stem *ḍoka- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:313 no. 5566). No further etymology.
Loanword ultimately from Persian qiži 'dirty', possibly via an intermediary language ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:635, Oleg Abaev, p.c.).
Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ni-waz- 'to carry/flow downwards', further to PIE *u̯eḡ- 'to float; to drive' ({ref Cheung 2007}:429-432, cf. {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref LIV²} 661-662).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'carry' in /cognate/7547/, 'fall' in /cognate/3661/, 'fly_pst3sg' in /cognate/1993/, 'house' in /cognate/5142/, 'run' in /cognate/6778/, 'swim' in /cognate/7464/.

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *ātr-, *ātar-, a derivative of PIE *h₂eh₁- 'to be hot' ({ref ESIJa} 1:318-324, cf. {ref LIV²} 257).

notes: Sims-Williams (2000: 232f., quoted from Korn 2005: 132) suggests *su̯l̥g̑ʰ-su- in order to explain Bactrian χοζο. Korn (l.c.) assumes *su̯elk̑s for xwaš-forms.

justificationDiscussion: As though from Proto-Iranic *u̯azi̯ā̆-u̯ant- 'possessing weight', cf. Avestan uaziia- 'weight, load' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:105).
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Abkhaz ləgaž 'old man' from *ləg 'person' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:19-21).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kau̯fa-, perhaps originally 'hump', without certain cognates outside of Iranic ({ref Schmitt 2014}:202-203).

notes: for Ossetic *frā-xai̯za-
Iranic forms that derive from MIr. *wind- would belong to cognate set 8643
justificationDiscussion: The Iranian forms in this set are based on a secondary root *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' of denominal origin, already attested in Old Iranian (Avestan vaēnaiti, Old Persian vainatiy; cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:412-413). For the primary verbal root, cf. {ref LIV²} 668-669 s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁-.

notes: cf. Toch. /lexeme/23430/
from 'to gnaw, eat, gorge'?, if so then related to  Skt. KHĀD 'gnaw' (Cheung: 445)
Cheung (2007: 345) suggests a derivation from PIE *skep- ‘to cut, split (with a sharp tool), make a crack’

Schmitt (2014: 278): "Offenbar handelt es sich um eine jüngere Ersatzbildung für ein Erbwort und am wahrscheinlichsten um eine -ka-Ableitung von heteroklitischem *vaz-r̥/*vaz-n- „Kraft, Größe“; es gehört dann letztlich zu der Wurzel idg. *u̯eǵ „kräftig sein/werden“." Schmitt emphasises that connections to vazra- "weapon" are to be discarded.
loan_notes: generally believed to be of Median origin

justificationDiscussion: Light-verb constructions construed with (parallel) loans of Arabic نفس / nafs 'breath'.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *braiH- 'to shave, shear, cut', ultimately from PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ({ref Cheung 2007}:22-23, {ref EWAia} II:282, {ref LIV²} 92-93).
Iranic lexemes derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root noun *tau̯k- 'progeny, children', without certain correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:651, 670).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', further from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' ({ref Cheung 2007}:432, cf. {ref LIV²} 661-662).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'carry' in /cognate/7547/, 'drink' in /cognate/1955/, 'fall' in /cognate/3661/, 'house' in /cognate/5142/, 'run' in /cognate/6778/, 'swim' in /cognate/7464/.

notes: Mayrhofer (EWAia II 658) suggests a PIE extended root *(s)k̑eu̯-bʰ. Klingenschmitt (2000: 205) *huu̯-apah- "gutes Werk verrichtend", cf. Old Ind. sv-ápas- 'gut wirkend' (Mayrhofer EWAia I 84), then identical with 3165.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Arabic علف / ʿalf 'feed, fodder'.

notes: Korn (2005: 142 fn. 348) discusses a derivation of *mū "to bind", Old Ind. mū́ta- "basket", but it is not certain whether MIr. has *mūd or *mōd (Klingenschmitt 2000: 196 argues for MP mūy).

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref LIV²} 218-219, cf. {ref EWAia} II:800-801, {ref Cheung 2007}:244-245).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'cut' in /cognate/6606/, 'kill' in /cognate/3551/, 'throw' in /cognate/8806/, 'hunt' in /cognate/1298/, 'tail' in /cognate/1935/, 'run' in /cognate/5193/.

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes probably to be related to Vedic valká- 'bark' ({ref EWAia} II:525-526, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:275, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:123). Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre', but cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:526.

Korn (2005: 88) assumes a (dialectal?) substitution of f > h; cf. Avestan zafar/n-. She follows Bailey (1979: 351b) in connecting this word with "tooth", cf. Old Ind. jámbʰa-. This evidence suggests an input *g̑m̩bʰ- > *zaβ- > *zaf- and > *δaβ- > (*daf- >) dah- respectively. Avestan shows cases of β > f, e.g. “navel” nāfa- vs. Vedic nā́bʰi- (Hoffmann/Forssman 1996: 98). I [TJ] don't see the need to assume a root without nasal for the Iranic forms (cf. Bailey, l.c.; but see Pokorny 1959: 382).
Loan from Arabic, cf. Standard Arabic دِمَاغ / dimāḡ 'brain'.

notes: The Avestan context is about firewood "which is called nǝmaδka". Bartholomae (1904: 1068) connects this word to nǝmata- in comparison to Old Indic avatká- of avatá-. nǝmata- is interpreted as brushwood ('Reisig') and derived from the verbal root "nam" i.e. 'to bow'. If this is correct, the PIE origin would be the verbal root "nem".
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *namadkā-.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gau̯b- 'to say (positively/negatively)', no certain etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:113-114).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rái̯as-, an s-stem noun formed to Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rai̯-'to stretch, extend', cf. Vedic √jray- 'id.', further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:606-607).

An Indo-Iranic and Albanian lexical isogloss from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, contemplate' ({ref LIV²} 141-142, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:969; however doubted by {ref Cheung 2007}:48-50, cf. {ref EWAia} I:777-778 without Albanian).
Iranic lexemes derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root noun *tau̯k- 'progeny, children', without certain correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:651, 670).

notes: related to 'fire'?

justificationDiscussion: Continuing Proto-Iranic *ham-tač-, cf. PIr. *tač- 'reach for, attain, receive', and further to PIE 1. *tek- 'to stretch the land, receive, reach' ({ref Cheung 2007}:374-375, cf. {ref LIV²} 618-619).

notes: The light verbs correspond either to NP šodan or raftan, the preverbs either to NP piyāde or rāh or pā. Hence this cognate sets combines at least two different roots. Horn (1893: 77) derives piyāde from *padātaka- in comparison to Sanskrit padātí-/padātika-.

justificationDiscussion: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷreu̯Hg̑ʰ- ({ref ALEW} 356, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}. This root is not reconstructed by {ref LIV²}, nor are any comparanda outside Balto-Slavic given by {ref Derksen 2008}, {ref Derksen 2015}, but the comparison with AGk. βρῡ́χω 'grind the teeth' < *gʷruHg̑ʰ- appears reasonable formally and semantically (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:244).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-European *mleu̯h₂- 'to speak' ({ref LIV²} 446-447, {ref EWAia} II:235-236, {ref Cheung 2007}:274-275).
Slavic lexemes from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ({ref Derksen 2008}:115, {ref LIV²} 128-129, cf. {ref ESSJa} 5:101-102 assuming a basic root *der- with a root extension).
Loanword from Polish ({ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-}:53).
loan_notes: Most probably the source was a folk form wonitować. The Polish source form is itself a loan from Latin. Polish wymiotować can not be the source of the Belarusian lexeme from phonetic reasons (it can be supposed that the Polish wymiotować is a folk etymology).

notes: sporadic Slavic ?*kob(-)ě/it-
justificationDiscussion: Polish kobieta is a Polish-only innovation (originally the word was abusive). It has no certain etymology despite of many attempts to explain it ({ref Boryś 2005}:241). It is often linked to kobyla 'mare'. {ref ESSJa} links the lexeme to *kob- 'divination, fate', so the original meaning could be 'witch'. However, all etymologies are highly speculative.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin pālus 'stake, wooden post' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:536-537), continuing an Italic instrument noun *pā̆g-slo- derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm', cf. Latin pangō, -ere 'to insert firmly, fix' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:478-479, {ref de Vaan 2008}:442-443, cf. {ref LIV²} 461).
North Germanic lexemes from ON dáligr 'wicked, harmful, miserable' (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:73-74; no lemma in {ref Heidermanns 1993}, {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}.
No clear etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:20). For older proposals to Lat. albus 'white' in /cognate/955/, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:100.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: = Lat. GLOBUS, NE CLAW, CLING, maybe also 'child' in /cognate/2223/

notes: < Lat. MAS, MARIS 'male = the bigger one' (Buck 1949: 879)
= Fr. SAPER 'undermine' < MLat. SAPPA 'hoe'
< Lat. DE PARTE 'from the side' (Buck 1949: 869)

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian and Italic lexemes from PIE *sekH- 'to divide, separate' ({ref LIV²} 524), cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:695-697, {ref de Vaan 2008}:545).

notes: VLat *STANCUS 'weak', ultim. orig. dub. (Buck)
< Lat. CALLIS 'path' (Buck 1949: 718)
< Lat. EXTORQUERE < TORQUEO 'twist, wind', cogn. with 'turn' in /lexeme/25917/
< Lat. PALUDEM 'swamp' (Buck 1949: 47)

justificationDiscussion: It is uncertain whether this lexeme is a loanword from Latin spīna (via Old Polish?) or a cognate of it (cf. {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} II:708, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:735). [Not in {ref Derksen 2008} and therefore implicitly not considered a part of the Slavic inherited lexicon in that work.]

Russian glaz 'eye' has without any doubt a PS origin (*glazŭ '(small, round,) smooth stone' with a semantic development that has parallels in Slavic, cf. Russian expressive šary 'eyes' < 'ball(s)' or Polish expressive gały 'eyes' < 'ball(s)'). However, the further etymology is uncertain.

There are two widespread hypotheses on the etymology of PS *žirŭ: 1) *ži-r- < PIE *gʷi̯eh₃-r- 'something that is good/necessary to live' 2) *žir- < PIE *gʷerh₃- 'something that is eaten, ravened'. Both of them are semantically and morphologically convincing.
Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:83-84, 123; {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:176, {ref Rejzek 2001}:230).

I find the etymology presented in {ref ESSJa} as to the underlying PIE root *kʷer- and its original meaning 'make, do, create' (probably derived from a more primitive meaning 'cut', see {ref LIV²}) convincing.
However, I think that the proposed order of the semantic development is unconvincing and that the reconstructed connotation of the *kresati with 'life' is unnecessary. Words referring to the look of humans and animals are very often derived from verbs meaning 'make, create, form, give birth', cf. PS *tvoriti 'make, create', Polish tworzyć 'make, create' and Polish twarz 'face' > twarzowy 'about a clothing a person looks pretty in' (cf. also Polish potwór 'monster' > potworny 'horrible, ugly'), PS ličiti 'to form, to shape' (< PIE *lei̯H- 'pour', also originally 'formed by casting', cf. /cognate/1223/) and PS *lico 'face', Polish śliczny 'beautiful', Macedonian ličen 'pretty' or PS *roditi 'give birth', Polish rodzić 'give birth' and Polish uroda 'look, beauty' (cf. also Russian urod 'monster, ugly person' > urodlivyj 'ugly'). We can assume a similar development in PIE *kʷer- > PS *krasa. The meaning 'red' in Russian is a later development from 'beautiful' and not the opposite way. It is limited to Russian, where the meaning 'red' is attested much later (11th century vs. 15th century) than 'beautiful' {ref Černyh 1999}: 1: 440.

Italic lexemes from Latin ruere 'to rush, hurry on; tumble down, collapse' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:613 no. 7423), further to PIE *h₃reu̯- 'to run, hurry', perhaps further derived from PIE *h₃er- 'to set (oneself) in motion'? (cf. {ref Meiser 2003}:613, {ref de Vaan 2008}:530). [Verbal root not in {ref LIV²} or {ref {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}].

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: may be ultimately related to /cognate/2625/ and /cognate/559/

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes continuing Latin concha 'shell, seashell' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:199), an old loanword, already attested in Plautus, from Ancient Greek κόγχη, κόγχᾱ 'mussel' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:136).

Romance lexemes from Latin mancus 'maimed, crippled' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:431), perhaps further derived from Latin manus 'hand' in /cognate/888/ (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:382, {ref de Vaan 2008}:361 for further discussion).
From Proto-Romance *pettia ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:532), generally regarded as a borrowing from Celtic (cf. Welsh peth 'thing, object')
loan_notes: Generally considered from an Celtic borrowing in Latin (cf. Welsh peth).

notes: Lat. FUNIS 'rope', etym. dub. (Buck)
From Lat. narrāre.
justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin narrāre 'to relate, tell' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:481), further to PIE *g̑neh₃- 'know' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:267, {ref LIV²} 168-170).

Romance lexemes from Latin infūsum (Giovanni Abete, p.c.), the past passive participle of Latin infundere 'pour in' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:363). Further to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯d- 'pour', possibly a post-PIE enlargement of *g̑ʰeu̯- 'pour' for phonotactic reasons ({ref LIV²} 179-180n1, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:249-250). Root assignment in this class follows {ref LIV²} in reconstructing a separate root *g̑ʰeu̯d-.

notes: IE *bu 'imitation of a muffled sound' (Buck 1930: 2.113)
related to Slavic 'weak', = MLG SLAP
It is a compound of ot- and rok- with an etymological meaning 'he who can/must not speak'. Cf. the parallel semantic formation in Lat. in-fāns < *n̥-bʰh₂-nt- 'un-speaking'.

justificationDiscussion: An intensive formation to Swedish skrata 'scare, chase away', of onomatopoeic/imitative origin ({ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Traditionally considered a labial-extension to the root *dʰu̯eh₂- 'make smoke' ({ref IEW} 247-248, {ref Orel 2003}:68, {ref Kluge 2011}:180; cf. {ref LIV²} 158). Alternatively {ref Kroonen 2013}:88 sets up a derived noun to PGmc. *dimpan ~ *dempan- 'to fog' < *dʰembʰ- (cf. MHG dimpfen 'to smoke, steam' Elfdalian dimba 'to smoke', Nw. demba 'to smoke'; but cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:180 who considers the MHG form a backformation to MHG dampf, not in {ref LIV²}.).
No certain etymology outside of Iranic, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:117-118 for further discussion.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯an-na- 'to sound, play an instrument', further to PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' ({ref LIV²} 611, {ref Schumacher 2004}:607-609, {ref Matasović 2009}:360-361).
Etymology uncertain: most likely a loan from Iranic *pad- ~ *pat- 'fall' via an Iranic language with *d > l, but details are unclear ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:265).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *druko- 'bad', further connections uncertain (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996 D:198-199, {ref Matasović 2009}:105-106).

notes: < Lat. PLANTA 'sprout, shoot' (Buck 1949: 91)

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Brythonic (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

notes: etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 19)

justificationDiscussion: Derived from Middle Welsh bwyd 'food' (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}), further from Proto-Celtic *bēto- < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-to- ({ref Matasović 2009}:64), cf. PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live' ({ref LIV²} 215-216).

notes: "of imitative origin" (Buck 1949: 671)

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Celtic disputed, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:22, {ref Delamarre 2003}:170, {ref Matasović 2009}:295-296, for various proposals.

Cf. Middle Welsh lladd 'to kill', further derived from Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯o- 'to hit; to slay'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Matasović 2009}:345), cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:583-587 setting up either PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ- following {ref Schrijver 1995}:178. [Not in {ref LIV²}].

Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *nebʰ- '(to become) wet, cloudy, vaporous' ({ref NIL} 499-504, cf. {ref EWAia} II:13, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:400 no. 6955c, {ref Kroonen 2013}:386, {ref de Vaan 2008}:404).
No convincing etymology outside of Celtic. See {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:7-8, {ref Matasović 2009}:86-87 for various suggestions.
Welsh lexemes derived from PIE *terh₁- 'to rub, bore' ({ref Matasović 2009}:370-371, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref LIV²} 632-633).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:140, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:212 no. 2292, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:214, {ref Matasović 2009}:220).
{ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} suggests a possible loanword from Old English céce 'fauces, mouth, cheek' (> Engl. cheek).

The Brythonic forms in this class may be etymologically separate from the Goidelic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:161, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:8, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}.

Welsh lexemes, which along with Old Cornish trein and Gaulish *trugna- (implied through Romance, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:744 no. 8947) appear to reflect Proto-Celtic *trugnV- ({ref Schrijver 1995}:442n2, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Matasović 2009}:353).

notes: etym. dub.
justificationDiscussion: Denominal from Welsh gwth 'a push, shove, thrust', further root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} for various suggestions.
Loan from Late Latin putris (putridus) 'rotten, putrid' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

notes: etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 265)

justificationDiscussion: A probable Mediterranean substratum word ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:42-43, cf. also {ref Falileyev 2000}:22, {ref Deshayes 2003}:373). Perhaps cognate with Armenian kʻar in /cognate/651/, but ultimately uncertain. Cf. notes in that class for further discussion. If this is the same substratum word as in Armenian, it is difficult to determine whether this was a single loan event or parallel loan events.

Welsh lexemes consisting of a compound  cyn- 'before' + ffon 'stick' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}); the 'stick' compound member, for which cognacy is being encoded in this set, continues Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff', further from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' ({ref Matasović 2009}:334).

notes: outside connections?

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: this cognate set is justified by Buck (1949:137-138), IE *g(u)ei(o)- 'to live', cogn. with 'snake' in /cognate/1919/

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic lexemes as nominal derivatives PIE *dʰegʷʰ-r-h₂ from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1475-1476, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1112; cf. {ref LIV²} 133-134).

Modern Indic lexemes derived to Ved. √chad- 'to cover' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:275, nos. 5020-5021); further etymology uncertain, perhaps to PIE ?*(s)k̑ed- ({ref IEW} 919, {ref LIV²} 546) if connected with Old English hætera 'garments' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:554-555 for further discussion). The root reference form for this set tentatively follows this etymology.
Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hrugja- 'ridge; back'. Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:250, {ref Kluge 2011}:775 for further discussion.

Romanian spathe is originally from Latin spatha 'beater, spatula', originally a loanword from Greek σπάθη 'broad blade (of wood or metal)', while the Iberian Romance forms are from Latin spatula, the diminutive of spatha  (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1930–1935}:612, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:638-639, {ref DCECH} II:733-734).

notes: 'loins'
justificationDiscussion: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *lendʰ-u- ({ref Derksen 2008}:276, {ref ESSJa} 15:48-50).

{ref EWAia} II:258-259 supposes two possible (homophonous) root etymologies either to *bʰes- 'to skew, to crunch' (cf. {ref LIV²} 82 s.v. ?*bʰes- '(zer)kauen') or *bʰes- 'to blow, to breathe', however {ref NIL} 34-36 considers these two postulated roots to be one and the same. For developments in Middle and Modern Indic, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:537, no. 9425.

This word is well attested in Iranian languages. Cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:267 on Khotanese bata- "small" deriving it from a root *vā "be deficient", cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:204 *h₁u̯eh₂- "to be empty, absent, lacking".

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *wanda- 'turned, twisted', further derived from PIE u̯endʰ- 'to twist, wind' ({ref Seebold 1970}:554-555, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:654-655, {ref Kroonen 2013}:573, 587, cf. {ref LIV²} 681-682).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *elhja- 'evil'; further etymology uncertain ({ref de Vries 1977}:285). More recently cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:637-638 suggesting a connection to PGmc. *ubila- 'bad' in /cognate/2195/ under the assumption of some irregular sound changes; alternatively cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:117 tentatively suggests a connection with OIr. elc 'mischievous, capricious' via ?*h₁elk-o-. Root ref. form follows the reconstruction of {ref Kroonen 2013}.
Of uncertain origin ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

The further connections of the Germanic adjective *ubila- 'bad' are debated. It is generally agreed that OIr. fel 'bad, evil' may be formally identical with the Germanic lexemes from earlier *upelo-, if the Celtic lexemes are not borrowings from Old French fel 'faithless, unfaithful, disloyal' (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:637-638, {ref Matasović 2009}:396, {ref Kluge 2011}:938, {ref Kroonen 2013}:557). Debated remain the further proposed connections to Hitt. ḫuu̯appa-, connected since {ref Juret 1942}:71 and further advocated by {ref Watkins 1969}:30, {ref Melchert 1988}:233n1, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:369-371, but doubted or rejected by {ref Lehmann 1986}:371, {ref Kluge 2011}:938, {ref Kroonen 2013}:557. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} tentatively reconstructs *h₂u̯óbʰh₁-/h₂u̯(é)bʰh₁- for the proposed Anatolian cognates.
From Latin captīvus 'taken prisoner' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:157), derived from Latin capiō, -ere 'take', further to PIE *keh₂p- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:89-90, {ref LIV²} 344-345).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin vivenda 'foodstuffs' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:786 no. 9410, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 14:575), originally a neuter plural gerundive form derived from Latin vivere 'to live' and ultimately to PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:685-686 and further discussion in /cognate/72/).

No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:346, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:375). Occasionally compared to Balto-Slavic lexemes, e.g. Lith. mãkas 'purse, pouch, scrotum', but the connection remains uncertain (cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:399).
Etymology outside of Tocharian obscure, probably connected within Tocharian to Tocharian A kātse 'near'. Cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:112, {ref Adams 2013}:165-166 for various further discussion.
