Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *červo 'belly, intestine' ({ref ESSJa} 4:82-83, {ref Derksen 2008}:85-86) and further derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off').
Cf. Skt. caṭaka- ~ *caṭikā- 'sparrow', Prakrit caḍaa ~ ciḍiga ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:248 no.4571. Of uncertain origin, possibly onomatopoeic ({ref KEWA} I:368).

notes: Origin unclear.
justificationDiscussion: Commonly assumed to be a borrowing from Latin locusta 'grasshopper', but this is semantically unconvincing; rather, of uncertain origin ({ref Deshayes 2003}:445).

notes: from ie. *dheu-/dhwes- 'shake, agitate, whirl' > 'breathe'  (Buck), Slav. stems *duxЬ  'breath, spirit', *duchati 'breathe, blow', *dyxati 'breathe'
cogn. with 'suck' in /lexeme/25941/, ultimately related to 'eat' /lexeme/19955/ and probably 'breast' /lexeme/18670/

justificationDiscussion: Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰreu̯s- ({ref Lehmann 1986}:82, {ref Kroonen 2013}:76, 80, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:99-100, {ref Matasović 2009}:81).

Slavic lexemes to be further connected with dialectal Lithuanian pìršys 'chest (of a horse)', but further connections outside of Balto-Slavic remain uncertain. Traditionally further compared to Vedic párśu- 'rib' (cf. e.g. {ref Boryś 2005}:431), but this connection remains unclear for formal reasons ({ref Derksen 2008}:429, {ref Derksen 2015}:358, cf. {ref EWAia} II:100-101).

There is no consensus etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 7:146-149, {ref  Rejzek 2001}:216, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:353, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 1:463, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}). Against the older proposed comparisons to Latin grandis 'big', Ancient Greek βρένθος 'pride', cf. respectively {ref de Vaan 2008}:270, {ref Beekes 2010}:237-238.
Baltic lexemes, probably derivatives from PIE *kreu̯H- 'to heap up, cover' ({ref ALEW} 531-532, {ref Derksen 2015}:256, 261, cf. {ref LIV²} 371).

Tocharian, Armenian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pstḗn ({ref IEW} 990, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:386, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:584-585, {ref EWAia} II:752). The potential connection of the Greek forms from Ancient Greek στῆθος (/cognate/8545/) to this class is disputed, and rest on assuming that it is root-cognate with a gloss στήνιον from Hesychius's Lexicon. The word-formation within Greek is, however, unclear ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:795, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1054-1055, {ref Beekes 2010}:1403-1404).
Borrowing from Romance (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:289, {ref Orel 1998}:277).

Tocharian lexemes, possibly to PIE *h₁ergʷ- via a derived stem *h₁r̥gʷ-ont- 'dark' (cf. Skt. rájanī- 'night', Gk. ἔρεβος 'darkness of the underworld', Arm. erek 'evening', Goth. riqis 'darkness'), but ultimately uncertain ({ref Adams 2013}:101).

Generally accepted to be cognate with Goth. kilϸei < PGmc. *kelϸīn-, but with further connections uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:198, {ref Orel 2003}:212). {ref Kroonen 2013}:309-310, suggests a connection to PGmc. *kulda- 'litter (of progeny)' < *gʷl̥H-tó- (cf. Nw. dial. kull, kuld, OSw. koller, kuller, Da. kuld) , but this remains uncertain.

Italic lexemes continuing Latin numerāre 'to count', a denominal verb to Latin numerus 'number' and ultimately a derivative to PIE *nem- 'to apportion, allot' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:450-451, {ref de Vaan 2008}:419, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:492, cf. {ref LIV²} 453).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:241, {ref Kroonen 2013}:349).
Parallel loans from from Arabic اسم / ism 'name'.
Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *spek̑- 'to look (at), see' ({ref LIV²} 575-576, {ref EWAia} II:107-108, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:452 no. 8012).

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *meh₁- 'to measure' ({ref Adams 2013}:503, {ref EWAia} II:352-353, {ref ALEW} 634-635, {ref ESSJa} 18:191-194, {ref Derksen 2008}:312-313, {ref Kroonen 2013}:365, {ref de Vaan 2008}:373).

Generally connected to PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to ignite, burn' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:118-119, {ref Adams 2013}:225-226). For the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} (formerly {ref LIV²} 345 1. *keh₂u̯-).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'burn' in /cognate/1461/, 'dry' in /cognate/8281/, 'hard' in /cognate/8428/, 'sun' in /cognate/5455/, 'fog' in /cognate/6235/.

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill, be(come) full' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1191-1192, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:309-310, {ref Demiraj 1997}:327, {ref Orel 1998}:335, {ref EWAia} II:156-157, {ref ALEW} 772-773, {ref Derksen 2015}:356, {ref Derksen 2008}:426, {ref Kroonen 2013}159, {ref de Vaan 2008}:472-273, {ref Matasović 2009}:132).

Tocharian, Hellenic, and Albanian lexemes from PIE *sh₂eu̯- 'to rain' ({ref LIV²} 545, {ref Adams 2013}:796, {ref Beekes 2010}:1541, {ref Demiraj 1997}:380-381, {ref Orel 1998}:413-414); note the zero-grade of the root was *suh₂- by laryngeal metathesis ({ref Jasanoff 1978a}:89n7, 90n11).
Slavic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ({ref NIL} 185-189, {ref Derksen 2008}:563, {ref Lehmann 1986}:278).

Indo-Iranic lexemes from Sanskrit lóhita- 'red' (Ved. róhita- 'red') with semantics generalised from 'red' > 'any red substance' > 'blood' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:650, no. 11165), further derived to PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'red' ({ref EWAia} II:471).

notes: Also Welsh 'cig', Breten 'kik', both meaning 'flesh' Buck (p249)

justificationDiscussion: Slavic lexemes as though from PIE ?*pel- 'to flame up, blaze up' ({ref LIV²} 469, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:390, {ref Boryś 2005}:409).

Etymology outside Italic uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:148-149, {ref de Vaan 2008}:142 for various speculative proposals). {ref LIV²} mechanically reconstructs ?*⁽k̑⁾remH-, but without any certain cognates outside of Italic.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm, hot' ({ref LIV²} 219-220, {ref Derksen 2008}:178-179, {ref ESSJa} 7:42-43).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'bitter' in /cognate/6086/, 'day' in /cognate/3850/, 'fire' in /cognate/396/, 'hot' in /cognate/333/, 'sun' in /cognate/2299/.

justificationDiscussion: Albanian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- (cf. {ref NIL} 162-169, {ref Derksen 2008}:544-545, {ref Demiraj 1997}:133, {ref Rohr 2000}:124-125).

notes: prob. nursery word (Buck 1949: 91)
fr. NE PAGE in earlier sense 'boy' (Buck 1949: 91), Anglo Norman loan but common to all surviving Goidelic languages

justificationDiscussion: Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *sekH- 'to cut off' ({ref LIV²} 524, {ref Derksen 2008}:446, {ref de Vaan 2008}:550-551).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sterban- 'to become stiff, die', further to PIE *(s)dʰerbʰ- 'to become stiff, firm' ({ref LIV²} 512; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:477 reconstructing *(s)terbʰ- with the same basic comparanda). For older comparisons cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:472-473.

notes: blend of *gadda- 'sediment, mud, dirt' with gandhá- 'smell' or Middle Persian and Persian gand 'bad smell' (?); cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4011 and 4014
< DRECK 'dirt'

justificationDiscussion: Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑leu̯s- 'to listen to' ({ref Matasović 2009}:209, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:126-127). This root is very likely to have been abstracted from a desiderative verb form of *k̑leu̯- ({ref LIV²} 334-335) already in the protolanguage, cf. {ref LIV²} 336n1.
No certain etymology outside of Goidelic ({ref Lucht 2007}:241).

notes: Fr. Lat. laxius, comparative to laxus.
justificationDiscussion: Ibero-Romance lexemes derived from Latin laxius 'more widely, more freely', the comparative adverb to Latin laxus 'spacious, wide' ({ref DCECH} III:626-627, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:403 no. 4956), further derived from PIE *sle⁽g̑⁾- 'to slacken, go limp' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:331, cf. {ref LIV²} 565).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit √dar-¹ 'to tear, split' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966} 353-354, no. 6186, 6190), ultimately from PIE *der- 'tear (intr.), split' ({ref EWAia} I:701-703, {ref LIV²} 119-120).

Possibly from a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic. Lat. plūma might be based on the *pleu̯k- root, but alternative derivations from unextended *pleu̯- are also possible, cf. /cognate/999/.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fly_N' in /cognate/5414/, 'wing' in /cognate/343/, 'bird' in /cognate/186/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/224/, 'swim' in /cognate/8317/, 'hair' in /cognate/1902/.
the same word in 'small' /cognate/1877/, etym. dub. (Buck)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', usually compared to Middle Irish slacc 'sword' and slahta 'struck' to a root *slak- as a Celtic-Germanic isogloss. Whether such a root may be postulated for Proto-Indo-European remains uncertain ({ref Seebold 1970}:425-427, {ref Lehmann 1986}:314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:452, cf. {ref LIV²} 564).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- '(finger)nail' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:723-725, {ref Beekes 2010}:1086-1087, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:254-255, {ref EWAia} II:4-5, {ref ALEW} 681-682, {ref Derksen 2015}:327, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164, 170-173, {ref Derksen 2008}:355, {ref de Vaan 2008}:641, {ref Matasović 2009}:36). Indo-Iranic forms go back to an aberrant *(H)nákha-; Indo-Aryan forms go back to nakhá- ~ *nakkha-; some show early nasalization due to blend with aṅgúri- ~  aṅgúli- 'finger, toe' (°-aṅgulá-) or aṅguṣṭhá- 'thumb'; aṅká- 'hook' (RV) and later aṅkurá- 'hooked' may also have played a role, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}, no. 6914 + 134f. 137f., 100, 109; Addenda 6914
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'claw' in /cognate/5097/, 'foot' in /cognate/1252/, 'leg' in /cognate/1231/, 'scratch' in /cognate/3194/, 'thigh' in /cognate/7424/.

notes: 'sink, float, slip', see Turner 1931: 476

justificationDiscussion: Certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking ({ref ALEW} 933, cf. {ref LIV²} 562). Identical to 'run' in /cognate/6359/. On the possibility of the connection of Lithuanian skrìsti 'fly_V' to this class, cf. discussion in /cognate/9622/.

notes: The Avestan form *(š)mar- is attested with the meaning "remember".
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall; recount', further to PIE *(s)mer- 'to think about, remember' ({ref Cheung 2007}:137-138, {ref EWAia} II:78-79, {ref LIV²} 569-570).
Parallel loans from Turkic (cf. {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} III:152, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 4:119).
North Germanic lexemes continuing a basic stem *dim-, comparisons outside of Germanic are uncertain ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:151-152, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:77, {ref Kroonen 2013}:96, 108).
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:794).

Cf. Lithuanian gul̃ti 'to lie down', which with the Latvian and Latgalian lexemes in this set may go back to an East Baltic root *gul-, but a further IE root etymology remains uncertain (cf. {ref ALEW} 377-379, {ref Derksen 2015}:193-194, 196).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit accha- 'clear transparent'; further etymology uncertain, perhaps to Vedic acchāyá- 'shadowless' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:8 no. 142).

Root ref. form tentatively follows the reconstruction of {ref Adams 2013}:241 to a putative PIE *klemH- (not in {ref LIV²} or {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}), rejecting alternative proposals to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean' as formally improbable; cf. {ref Adams 2013} s.v. TochB klänts- and {ref Malzahn 2010}:624-625 for further discussion.

Generally derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean' ({ref LIV²} 332-333, {ref Malzahn 2010}:592-593, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:69-70, also Ron Kim p.c.), less likely {ref Adams 2013}:184-186 derives to *kel(h₁)- 'raise up', cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:593 for further discussion.

Traditionally connected to PIE *meh₁- 'to measure (out)' in the sense 'measure' > 'body part used as measure unit' > 'length of hair used as a measure unit' > 'hair' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:572-573; cf. for the root reconstruction cf. {ref LIV²} 424-425).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 180, no. 3471; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 401: "schwerlich zu trennen von jav. (°)gaēsa-", perhaps a blend with *káisra- > Vedic (YV+) késara- n., but phonologically unclear; Indic forms constitue a cognacy subclass *gáića- (*káisra-?)
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes from Vedic kéśa- 'hair of the head', difficult to separate from Young Avestan gaēsa- although there is disagreement over the voicing of the initial velar; {ref EWAia} I:401 suggests a contamination of an original *géśa- the Indic lexemes with Vedic késara- 'hair, mane'. For Middle and Modern Indic, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:180 no. 3471.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Turner 1931}:241, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:330 no. 5803.

notes: cf. Sanskrit mastaka- m. n. (Up+) 'skull, head', related to Vedic mastr̥han- m. 'brain' < Proto-Indo-Iranian *mastr̥gʱan- (cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 326).
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit masta-, more commonly Sanskrit mastaka- 'skull, head' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:571 no. 9926. The stem appears to continue an r/n-stem with the Sanskrit stem masta- continuing earlier *mastn̥-, while the r-stem is preserved in Vedic mastr̥han- 'brain', YAv. mastərəγan- 'brain'. Further connections uncertain, perhaps a derivative of PIE *mosgʰ- 'marrow'(?), cf. {ref EWAia} II:336 for further discussion.

notes: The Iranic forms show a prefix *ka-.
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing PIE *ml̥h₃dʰ-, cf. Vedic mūrdhán- 'forehead, head, top part', Ancient Greek βλωθρός 'grown high', Old English molda 'top of head' ({ref EWAia} II:368, {ref Bailey 1979}:52, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:591 no. 10247).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin in-tendere 'to stretch out, stretch forth, extend' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:366 no. 4483, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:740-746). The IE root is either *ten- 'to stretch, extend' or *tend- 'to wear down', cf. {ref LIV²} 626-628, {ref de Vaan 2008}:612 for further discussion.
As though from an Indic stem *muṭṭa- 'heart', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:587 no. 10188).

Etymology outside Tocharian uncertain. {ref Adams 2013}:23 proposes a connection to Hittite ḫaḫ(a)ri- 'lung(s), midriff' (but this Hittite form remains of obscure etymology according to {ref HED H}:7).
Derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'be warm, hot' ({ref Lucht 2007}:376, {ref Matasović 2009}:147, {ref NIL} 196-199).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'bitter' in /cognate/6086/, 'burn' in /cognate/2243/, 'day' in /cognate/3850/, 'fire' in /cognate/396/, 'hot' in /cognate/333/.

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin occīdere 'strike down, knock down' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:495), possibly further to PIE *kh₂ei̯d- 'hit, beat' (cf. {ref LIV²} 360, {ref de Vaan 2008}:79-80) for further discussion).
Romance denominal verbs as though from Latin *mattea 'club' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:445), further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:366-367 for various proposals.
Baltic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷelH- 'to suffer; to prick' ({ref LIV²} 207, cf. {ref ALEW} 286, 309, {ref Derksen 2015}:170, {ref Seebold 1970}:313-314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:315).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', possibly from a root ?*slak- 'to hit, beat' only otherwise attested Celtic, cf. Middle Irish slacc 'sword' ({ref Seebold 1970}:425-427, {ref Lehmann 1986}:314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:452, {ref LIV²} 564).

The IE root etymology of Proto-Germanicc *daujan- given here follows {ref LIV²} to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:90-91 (but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. {ref LIV²} 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of {ref Kluge 2011}:919 s.v. Tod).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from the perfect stem *u̯oi̯d- 'to know' (< *'to have seen') from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to catch sight of' ({ref LIV²} 665-667, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1053, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:211, {ref EWAia} II:579-581, {ref Cheung 2007}:408-409, {ref Derksen 2015}:566, {ref Derksen 2008}:518), Matasović 2009}:422-423).
Etymology outside of Anatolian debated, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:645-646, {ref HED PA} 168-170, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar Vol. 2, 446-447 for various proposals.
Romance lexemes from Latin collocāre 'sit, set, place' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:194, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} II:905-910), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:347).
Etymologically isolated, the proposed connection with Lithuanian girià 'forest, wilderness' remains doubtful ({ref ALEW} 332). For older proposals cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:291-292.

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂nér- 'man' ({ref NIL} 332-335, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:103-104, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:61-62, {ref Huld 1984}:100-101, {ref Orel 1998}:304, {ref EWAia} II:19-20, {ref de Vaan 2008}:406-407, {ref Untermann 2000}:495-497).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *kerla- ~ *karla- 'man, freeman', a derivative of PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to wear down, make old' ({ref de Vries 1977}:301, {ref Orel 2003}:210, {ref Kroonen 2013}:285, cf. {ref LIV²} 165-166).

Despite some morphological difficulties, the formal and semantic relationships make a common origin of PS *xolkŭ, *xolstŭ, *pa-xolŭ and *xoliti ver plausible.
According to {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 554-555 the etymology of Lithuanian skaláuti 'wash, flush' is not entirely clear; it can belong to skeliù, skélti 'chop, split', derived from PIE *skelh₁- (cf. *skelH- {ref LIV²}: 553). Smoczyński gives here only PS *ščelĭ 'aperture' as a Slavic cognate. The etymology is mentioned but not accepted by {ref KEWA}: 288.
Thus, even if we accept an underlying *xol-, its further etymology is obscure.

Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:452-453, {ref EWAia} II:318-319, 327-328, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:596 no. 9888, cf. {ref LIV²} 439-440).

notes: Parallel loans from Arabic
loan_notes: ultimately from Arabic آدَم‎ / ʾādam 'human being, man'

notes: Parallel loans from Sanskrit
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Sanskrit puruṣa- 'man, person'.

Generally connected to words for male sexual organs in other IE languages, cf. Vedic pásas- 'penis', Gk. πέος 'penis', Lat. pēnis 'penis', OHG fasal 'seed, descendant' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:670, {ref HED PE, PI, PU}:37-45).

Cognate with Lithuanian peldė́ti 'to swim'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally assigned to PIE *pelǝ-, *plē- 'to fill' (now reconstructed as *pleh₁-, cf. {ref LIV²} 482-483) with a root extension in *-d- ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:565, {ref IEW} 800-801, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:34-35). Not in {ref LIV²}, {ref Derksen 2015}, or {ref ALEW}.
Tocharian lexemes as though from *n̥k̑-u̯-o- 'mortal', derived from PIE *nek̑- 'to disappear, go missing' ({ref Adams 2013}:82-83, cf. {ref LIV²} 451-452).

PS *rępŭ does not have any certain further IE etymology and cognates. In any case, I do not see any serious reason to treat PS the lexemes with the meaning 'tail' and lexemes referring to various creaky or crackling sounds as two separate etymona. Note that reflexes of *rępiti refer often to playing string instruments (and especially bowed string instruments) and there are also some attestations referring to whiping. That makes, in my opinion, a very good link to 'tail'. We have doubltess an ideophonic root here.

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain. Appears to be a derivative from Lithuanian úodas 'mosquito', which is in turn traditionally derived from the same root of Lithuanian ė́sti 'to eat' < PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat', but many uncertainties remain regarding this etymological connection. Cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:704, {ref ALEW} 1150-1151, {ref Derksen 2015}:480 for further discussion.
Of uncertain etymology, perhaps a derivative to the same root as Latvian galēt 'to kill' (cf. /cognate/2302/) with an original meaning 'killed animal' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:285).
For the interpretation of the Hittite and Luvian forms underlying the Sumerogram ᵈEN.ZU and Akkadogram ᵈSÎN, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:206-207.

Armenian, Slavic, and Italic lexemes reflecting PIE *lou̯k-s-neh₂, a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine, be(come) bright' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:320, {ref ESSJa} 16:173, {ref de Vaan 2008}:352, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'day' in /cognate/691/, 'eye' in /cognate/994/, 'good' in /cognate/1783/, 'salt' in /cognate/3845/, 'star' in /cognate/6295/, 'sun' in /cognate/739/, 'white' in /cognate/2401/.

justificationDiscussion: From Old Irish gelach 'moon', derived to the Old Irish adj. gel 'fair, white, bright, shining' ({ref Lucht 2007}:259-260), further to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ({ref Matasović 2009}:156, {ref EIEC} 654).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'grass' in /cognate/1576/, 'green' in /cognate/6332/, 'red' in /cognate/3832/, 'white' in /cognate/2411/ 'yellow' in /cognate/7535/.

justificationDiscussion: Indic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *(s)kend- 'to shine' ({ref EWAia} I:528-529, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:252 no. 4661, {ref Demiraj 1997}:199-200, {ref Orel 1998}:146-147, {ref Holm 2011}:70-71; cf. {ref LIV²} 554).

Possibly cognate with Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'mouth' and Proto-Germanic *munϸa- 'mouth' according to {ref Karulis 1992} I:611-612, although cf. discussion in /cognate/6017/, /cognate/262/ regarding uncertainties to the etymologies of the Germanic forms.
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Late Vedic lāṅgūla- 'tail' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:639 no. 11009), further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:477-478, {ref KEWA} III:98).

IE root etymology disputed: either (1) to PIE h₂ek̑- 'sharp' and connected with OCS ostьnъ 'sharp point', or (2) to PIE *Host- 'bone' and cognate with Hitt. ḫāstai-, Skt. asthi-, Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc. ({ref Karulis 1992} I:80-81).

notes: Is there any reason to suspect that the Elfdalian is a more recent loanword from Swedish rumpa 'tail' instead of being inherited?

justificationDiscussion: Traditionally connected to the root *g̑ʰeh₁i̯- 'to gape, open up (the mouth)', although aspects of the stem-formation remain disputed (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:171-172, {ref Adams 2013}:216-217, {ref LIV²} 173-174).
Etymology uncertain. Traditionally derived to PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' (cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:580, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:403). [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}; not in {ref IEW}].

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- ~ *hnakka(n)- 'neck', perhaps further comparable with Tocharian A kñuk 'neck' although there is some uncertainty the formal aspects of this proposed etymology. For further discussion cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:646, {ref Kroonen 2011}:167-169, {ref Kroonen 2013}:234, {ref van Windekens 1976}:225-226, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:162-163.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:571 for references to older (now uncertain) proposed etymologies, {ref Orel 2003}:395 for a proposed Albanian cognate and references to older literature. No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

Proto-Slavic *kŭrkŭ is occasionally compared to Vedic kŕ̥kāṭa- 'joint of the neck' (so {ref ESSJa} 13: 209-211, 218-219, {ref Rejzek 2001}:313, cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:223), although the etymology of the Indic comparandum is generally considered without certain etymology (cf. {ref KEWA} I:256-257 and {ref EWAia} I:388-389). Consequently the further connections of Proto-Slavic *kŭrkŭ must remain uncertain.

Baltic lexemes, generally analysed as containing a PIE noun for 'life, lifetime, life expectancy' *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- combined with the derivational suffix *-h₃en-, i.e. transponat *h₂i̯-eu̯-h₃n-ó- > Old Lithuanian jáunas 'young, new' ({ref NIL} 277-287, {ref ALEW} 408-409, {ref Derksen 2015}:209). The nominal stem *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- which serves the basis of this formation appears to have inflected as an ablauting u-stem but a corresponding verbal root *h₂ei̯- has not yet been identified (cf. {ref NIL} 279n1 for further discussion).
Cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:390.
Etymology not yet satisfactorily ascertained, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:206-207 for various hypotheses.

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *nabja- 'beak', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref de Vries 1977}:406, {ref Kroonen 2013}:380). Cf. however {ref Orel 2003}:279 and others attempting to connect to Proto-Germanic *nabō- 'nave' via a meaning 'protuberance, knob'.
No clear etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:975-976, {ref Beekes 2010}:1288).

Latvian lexemes generally connected with Lithuanian kúokas 'club, stick'; further etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected with PIE *keu̯- 'to bend' with a velar extension -k- ({ref Karulis 1992} I:413-414, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:306, {ref IEW} 589), but more recently cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:324 regarding the etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}, {ref ALEW}].
Generally considered to be an *-mn̥-stem noun derived to *steh₂- 'stand' ({ref Adams 2013}:776-777, {ref NIL} 639).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:500). For Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:657, no. 11258.
Cf. Old Irish uisce 'water' derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well, to spring' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:21, {ref Matasović 2009}:394, {ref NIL} 706-715).
Originally 'mountain' ({ref ESSJa} 7:29-31, {ref Derksen 2008}:177-178; cf. /cognate/80/ for further etymological details).

Perhaps from IE *kai̯to- ({ref IEW} 521) if inherited and comparable to Germanic terms found in Goth. haiϸi 'field', Engl. heath, etc. These forms are, however, restricted to Celtic and Germanic and we may be dealing with borrowing or (independent) borrowings from a prehistoric NW European substratum language (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:198).
Generally derived as though from PIE *h₁n̥-dʰuh₂-s- 'having breath within' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:188-189; for the root cf. {ref LIV²} 158 s.v. *dʰu̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen').

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes continuing Indic *rukṣa- 'tree', a metathesised variant of Vedic vr̥kṣá- 'tree', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *u̯r̥ćšá-. Further connections uncertain, perhaps to be connected with Vedic valśa- 'shoot, branch, twig' ({ref EWAia} II:572, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:622 no. 10757).
Lexemes derived from PIE *gʷem- 'to come' ({ref Beekes 2010}:192, {ref LIV²} 209-210).
Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear, to die' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:452-453, {ref EWAia} I:318-319, 327-328, cf. {ref LIV²} 439-440).

notes: parallel Sanskritisms, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 647, no. 11119 s.v. lōká- m. ʻfree space, worldʼ (RV), ʻspace, territoryʼ (ŚB), ʻpeopleʼ Mn.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Greek unclear, possibly a prehistoric loanword (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:90-91, {ref Beekes 2010}:106).
Parallel loans from Arabic insān (via Persian).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-Slavic Lexemes derived from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ({ref LIV²} 232-233, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:380-381, {ref Adams 2013}:64-66, {ref Malzahn 2010}:535-537, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1002-1006, {ref ALEW} 259-261, {ref Derksen 2015}:151, {ref Derksen 2008}:216).
Romance lexemes as denominal verbs from Latin cammīnus 'way, path', an old loanword of Celtic origin, cf. Old Irish céim 'step, pace, stride' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:144, {ref DCECH} I:787).
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:583 for a critical discussion of previous proposals). For the IE-CoR reference form, cf. {ref CHD L-N} 301.

notes: Loan from Old English ford (Buck)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *haita- 'hot', no certain etymology outside of Germanic ({Heidermanns 1993}:271-272, {ref Kroonen 2013}:202, cf. {ref EWA 4}:887-888, 915-916).

notes: cogante with Latin 'iter' way (Weeks 1985:159)
cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 280, no. 5086 s.v. jáṭā f. ʻhair twisted togetherʼ, PārGr̥. ʻfibrous root, rootʼ Bhpr., Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 564 - further source unclear
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic jaṭā- 'hair twisted together', further etymology unclear ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:280 no. 5086, {ref EWAia} I:564).
Anatolian and Indic lexemes from PIE *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'water' ({ref NIL} 715-717, {ref EWAia} II:544-545).

Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂erg̑- 'brilliant, white' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:307, {ref Adams 2013}:52-53). For non-target Hellenic and Indic lexemes in this class cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:125, {ref EWAia} I:116.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vālukā- 'sand' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:675, no. 11580). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} III:196, {ref EWAia} II:547 for discussion of various conjectures.
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:632-633, {ref Beekes 2010}:851, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'day' in /cognate/691/, 'eye' in /cognate/994/, 'good' in /cognate/1783/, 'moon' in /cognate/2336/, 'salt' in /cognate/3845/, 'star' in /cognate/6295/, 'sun' in /cognate/739/.

notes: Cf. eDIL s.v. as-beir (www.dil.ie/4383)
justificationDiscussion: A compound of Old Irish -beir 'bear, carry' (< PIE *bʰer- 'carry', cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77) with the preverb ess-, es-, e-, as- 'out of' (< PIE *(h₁}eg̑ʰ-s 'out of' adv., cf. {ref LIPP 2} 205).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *kweϸan- 'to say'. Further etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, possibly from PIE *gʷet- if comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite', but the comparison is not entirely clear; cf. {ref LIV²} 212, {ref Kroonen 2013}:319, {ref Lehmann 1986}:277-278, {ref Seebold 1970}:318-320, {ref Olsen 1999}:811.

Etymology uncertain, perhaps a secondary full grade teik- to tik-, which could be the zero-grade form of PIE *tek- 'to stretch out the hand' (cf. {ref ALEW} 1084-1085). If so, perhaps further connected to 'right' in /cognate/7113/.
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *věděti 'know', a derivative of PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see, catch sight of' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:518, {ref LIV²} 665-667).
Goidelic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *gelo-, most likely to continue a derivative of PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ({ref Lucht 2007}:431-432, {ref Matasović 2009}:156).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'moon' in /cognate/2337/, 'grass' in /cognate/1576/, 'green' in /cognate/6332/, 'white' in /cognate/2411/ 'yellow' in /cognate/7535/.

justificationDiscussion: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:667 and {ref Adams 2013}:333-334 for previous proposals.
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ekʷ- 'to say' ({ref LIV²} 673-674, {ref EWAia} II:489-491, {ref Cheung 2007}:402-404).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *u̯et-e/o- 'to say, speak', further derived from PIE *u̯eth₂- 'to say' ({ref LIV²} 694-695, {ref Schumacher 2004}:679-680, {ref Matasović 2009}:418, cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:67).

Cf. Old Lithuanian regė́ti 'to see', further etymology uncertain. {ref LIV²} 498 considers a possible derivation on the basis of an essive formation ?*r̥gʰ-h₁é-, but this is not fully certain (cf. {ref ALEW} 855-856 for further discussion).

Romance lexemes from Latin domina 'mistress, lady', the feminine equivalent to Latin dominus 'master of a household' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:245-246), further derived from Latin domus 'house' < *dom-u-, cf. PIE *demh₂- 'build' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:177-179, cf. {ref LIV²} 114-116).
Root etymology uncertain; probably either PIE *leg̑- 'gather' or PIE *leu̯k- 'shine' (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:836-839, {ref Adams 2013}:596-597).

No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:763). For Modern Indic forms cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:792 no. 13734. Cf. parallel loans from Sanskrit into Modern Indic in /cognate/5789/.
Parallel loans from Persian عورت‎ / ʿawrat 'nudity, genitals', ultimately via Arabic عَوْرَات‎ / ʿawrāt 'blemishes; nudity; genitals, pudendum'.
loan_notes: via Arabic عَوْرَات‎ / ʿawrāt (pl.; sg. عَوْرَة‎ / ʿawra 'genitals; nudity')

justificationDiscussion: North Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *skenþan- ({ref Orel 2003}:338, cf. {ref de Vries 1961}:493). Further etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref Kroonen 2013}].

notes: jugded Sanskrit loan (NARI) by Turner (1931: 341), Buck gives "fem. der. fr. NAR- 'man'" (Buck 1949: 83)
root conn. obsc. (Buck).

justificationDiscussion: Latvian and Latgalian forms derived from Latvian siẽva 'wife' and further connected to PIE *k̑ei̯-u̯o- 'socially close' (cf. {ref ALEW} 1016-1017, {ref Villaneuva Svensson 2011}:32). It is not certain whether or not the underlying lexical root is identical with *k̑ei̯- 'to lie' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:116 s.v. Lat. cīvis).

notes: this class needs further cognate subclasses

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cognate with 'he' in /cognate/2680/ - may be ultimately the same as /cognate/7471/

justificationDiscussion: Latin rotundus 'round' and its Romance continuants, derived from Latin rota 'wheel' and ultimately further to PIE *ret- 'run' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:611, {ref de Vaan 2008}:527, {ref NIL} 575-580).

Etymology difficult. Comparisons are typically made with Proto-Germanic *hringa- 'ring, circle' ({ref Derksen 2008}:251, {ref ESSJa} 13:25-27, {ref Kroonen 2013}:247, {ref Kluge 2011}:768). As {ref Kroonen 2013}:247 points out, however, the necessary reconstruction of *krengʰ- violates IE root structure constraints and may well point to a post-PIE origin for the Germanic and Slavic lexemes. Inexplicably, Kroonen also appears to consider that the lexemes are also related to Proto-Germanic *kringa- < PIE *greng̑ʰ- (cf. /cognate/9606/). An alternative possibility would be that both the forms as though from *krengʰ- and *greng̑ʰ- were independent loan events from a third source although without any firsthand knowledge of a substratum source this solution is speculative.

Germanic lexemes generally connected to a marginally attested strong verb *hwelban- ~ *hwelfan- ({ref Seebold 1970}:281, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:318, {ref Kroonen 2013}:265). The cognates within Germanic are generally connected to Gk. κόλπος 'bosom; womb; hollow space, pocket' to a reconstructable root *kʷelp- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:262; cf. also {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}, {ref Beekes 2010} s.v. Gk. κόλπος), although not acknowledged by {ref Seebold 1970}. Root not in {ref LIV²}, probably due to its marginal attestation as a strong verb in Germanic.
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' ({ref ALEW} 52, {ref ESSJa} 31:124-126, {ref Derksen 2015}:58-59, 497; cf. {ref LIV²} 677).
No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. {ref EWAia} II:294).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑enu, *g̑neu- ({ref IEW} 381-382, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:467-468, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:129-130, {ref Adams 2013}:205-206, {ref Beekes 2010}:283, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:343-344, {ref Demiraj 1997}:190-191, {ref Orel 1998}:137, {ref EWAia}: I:584-585, {ref Kroonen 2013}:296, {ref de Vaan 2008}:259, {ref Matasović 2009}:162). NB: traditionally considered a separate lexical root from PIE 2. *g̑enu- 'jaw, chin' (cf. {ref IEW} 380-382).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from a basic PIE root *k̑er- (cf. {ref Nussbaum 1986} for extensive discussion of formations in the meaning 'head' and 'horn' derived from this root). Cf. also {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:456-457, {ref Adams 2013}:235 [but cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:182 deriving to *gʰreh₁-u̯r̥], {ref Beekes 2010}:676-677, {ref EWAia} II:653, {ref Kroonen 2013}:259, {ref de Vaan 2008}:136-137, {ref Matasović 2009}:190-191).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(H)regʰ- 'to straighten oneself'. For the root reconstruction, cf. {ref ALEW} 835-836, {ref LIV²} 498. See also {ref Derksen 2008}:438, {ref Derksen 2015}:374-375.
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:15.
Germanic lexemes from PIE *dʰu̯n̥s-tó-, derived from PIE *dʰu̯ens- 'to scatter, to crumble' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:109, {ref LIV²} 159).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cf. /cognate/5284/ as well as 'ashes' /cognate/2463/ and 'smoke' in /cognate/123/.

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Baltic; perhaps to be connected with Lithuanian leĩlas 'slender', but the semantics of the comparison are difficult (cf. {ref ALEW} 580). Traditionally to a root 2. *lei̯- 'eingehen, abnehmen, schwinden; mager, schlank' in {ref IEW} 661-662, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:525.

This cognate class is coded for Proto-Tocharian *luwā- 'animal'; further connections uncertain. Pace {ref Adams 2013}:606-607, the comparison to Greek λέων is unsatisfactory as this word is likely to be a Near Eastern loanword, cf. Akkadian lābu, Ugaritic lbʾ, Hebrew lābī ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:635, {ref Beekes 2010}:854). Adams's further comparison to OCS lovъ 'the chase' and other Slavic lexemes in the meaning 'hunt' may be possible, but the etymology of these forms are not certainly established (cf. further discussion in /cognate/1145/).

A derivative of Portuguese apertar 'tighten, press, clamp', from Latin appectorāre 'press on the chest' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:44), further derived from Latin pectus 'chest'. For connections elsewhere in Indo-European, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:491, {ref de Vaan 2008}:453, and further discussion in /cognate/4015/.

notes: It is still debated whether the PIE root is *su̯el- or *su̯elH- (cf. ALEW s.v. svìlti; former: LIV²; latter: Kroonen, EtymDicGer). - As the meaning is not purely neutral 'burn', the cognate class should be exluded, if the OE and OHG words do not primarily mean 'burn'.

justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}, no. 8397 s.v. *pōḍ- 'burn'. No further etymology.

Connections outside Tocharian unclear. {ref Adams 2013}:297-298 proposes connections to PIE *dʰerg- comparing Lithuanian dérgia 'there is bad weather', Middle Irish derg 'red', Old English deorc 'dark', but these connections are not fully certain ({ref ALEW} 195-196 rejects extra-Baltic connections for the proposed Lithuanian cognates; the appurtenance of the Germanic and Celtic forms to a root *dʰerg- may well be possible, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:153, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:57-58, but the connection of Tocharian forms to this root are questionable. {ref Matasović 2009}:96 regards the connection of the Tocharian forms to this etymon doubtful; cf. further discussion in /cognate/1734/).

notes: with Slavic
justificationDiscussion: Related to Latvian makņa 'swamp, boggy place', cf. Lith. maknà 'id.' ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} I:399-400). Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic uncertain, possibly to Armenian mawr 'mud' (cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:301). Cf. also Proto-Slavic *mokrъ 'wet, damp' ({ref Derksen 2008}:322, {ref ESSJa} 19:144). [Not in {ref ALEW}].
Cf. 'shadow' in /cognate/8269/ for further discussion regarding the root ref. form.

Because the morphology of the related forms within Greek conform to the Caland system is suggestive that they are inherited from Indo-European, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1295-1296, {ref Beekes 2010}:1672-1673).

No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:471, cf. {ref LIV²} 601-2 s.v. ?2. *steu̯d- 'kalt werden'). A connection with the more common homophonous root 1. *steu̯d- 'stoßen', 'to hit' might be possible, but is difficult to justify semantically (cf.  {ref LIV²} 601-602). The root reference form as PIE ?*steu̯d- tentatively follows {ref LIV²}.

As though from Vedic ā́sadati 'sits near, approaches' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:67 no. 1483), a derivative of Vedic √sad- 'to sit' and ultimately to PIE *sed- 'to seat oneself' ({ref EWAia} II:692-693, {ref LIV²} 513-515).

The origin is obscure. It could be derived from an onomatopoeic interjection. An areal spreading is also not to be excluded. It can not be even assumed that the lexeme or the interjection it is hypothetically derived from had been present already in Proto-Slavic. Cf. {ref ESSJa} 13:81, 139, {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 3:160, 167-170, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 2:433-434 for further discussion. [Cf. also Indic *kutta- in /cognate/1599/, Iranic *kuti- in /cognate/3186/].
Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes derived to PIE *h₁egʷʰ- 'to drink' ({ref LIV²} 231; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:236-237, {ref Malzahn 2010}:810-811, {ref Adams 2013}:551-552).
Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry (through heat)' ({ref Malzahn 2010}:533-535, {ref Adams 2013}:63, cf. {ref LIV²} 257-258).

Romance forms from Latin exsūctus 'sucked out, dry' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:268 no. 3074), the past passive participle to Lat. (ex)sugere 'to suck (out)', further to PIE *seu̯k̑- 'to suck' ({ref LIV²} 539-540, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:664, {ref de Vaan 2008}:598).
No certain etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:218-219, {ref Beekes 2010}:269-270).

Derivatives from Proto-Indo-Iranic *bʰau̯H- 'be, exist' < PIE *bʰeu̯h₂-/*bʰu̯eh₂- ({ref EWAia} II:255-257, 268, {ref LIV²} 98-101, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:545 no. 9556-9557, {ref Henning 1971}:34).

notes: fr. Lat. SOLUM 'bottom, base, sole, ground'

justificationDiscussion: Originally 'stone' (cf. Lith. uolà 'rock') and traditionally connected with the same root as Lithuanian vélti 'to tumble, tousle' to PIE *u̯elH- (cf. {ref ALEW} 1214-1215, {ref Derksen 2015}:481 for further discussion).
IE root etymology unclear, cf. {ref LIV²} 92-93, 219-220; {ref Kroonen 2013}:77-78; {ref Seebold 1970}:137-138, {ref EWA 2}:290-292, 342-345.
Tocharian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ({ref LIV²} 487-488, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:462-462, {ref Malzahn 2010}:745-746, {ref Lucht 2007}:165).

Generally connected with the Indo-European word for 'fat, oil' from IE *selp- ({ref Adams 2013}:714-715, elsewhere in IE cf. discussion in {ref Beekes 2010}:415-416, {ref Demiraj 1997}:182, {ref EWAia} II:710-711, {ref Kroonen 2013}:424).

notes: < PIE *másdos- n. 'animal fat, marrow, a living being's fat inside bone or organ', root *masd- 'be/become fat', cf. ²LIV, p. 422 (IEW 694)
'big, tall, important, fat' < *sthūya- (Turner)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *telamon- 'earth, ground', a derivative to PIE *telh₂- 'to raise, support' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:22-23, {ref Delamarre 2003}:288-289, {ref Matasović 2009}:366, cf. {ref LIV² 622-623).

From Proto-Celtic *kʷrīyet- 'clay, earth, mud'; perhaps be further connected to Lat. crēta 'chalk' but further connections obscure ({ref Matasović 2009}:182-183, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:224).
Apparently a loanword from Old Norse hitta 'to hit upon, light upon, meet with' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

notes: element BONDI, BAND 'yeomen'

justificationDiscussion: The Modern Greek present stem ξέρω was backformed based on the Ancient Greek aorist stem ἐξεῦρον ({ref Babinotis 2010}:949, cf. ἐξευρίσκω 'find out, discover'). Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 698, but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:482-483 for further discussion.

Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:153-154, {ref HAB} IV:337-338), perhaps an Iranic loanword according to {ref Bailey 1979}:387, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:711). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯iz-].

Originally a root-noun in the sense *'visible, outer form' > '(outer) body; skin' (cf. Hittite tu̯ekka- 'body, person') from PIE *tu̯ek- 'be visible' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:684, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:346 no.6087, {ref LIV²} 654).

notes: Also Lat. -que

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cognate with 'and' in /cognate/567/ and and 'because' in /cognate/2562/
IE *(he)n, (h)eni; maybe ultimately cognate with 'at' in /cognate/2540/, but diverging views in literature, comp. also /cognate/2754/, e.g. ModE. IN.
cognate with terms for 'and' as in /cognate/966/ and 'near' in /cognate/2158/
IE *ui-tero-, = NHG WIDER-, WEITER, NE. WITH, cf. /cognate/1364/

notes: = Lat. UERSUS, TochB WRATTSAI  'against' (Matasovič)

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes continuing *skĭna-, a loanword from Germanic *skĭna- 'small piece of bone, shin', cf. Germanic scina 'thin strip, shin' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:659 no. 7994, {ref DCECH} II:761-762).
Romance lexemes continuing Latin rēnēs 'kidneys' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:596), further etymology obscure ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:569-570, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:519 for various suggestions).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8377; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

cf. Vedic yakṣá- m. 'appearance, phenomenon', 'supernatural being, ghost', RV+, MaitrUp., yakṣī- f. ~ yakṣiṇi- MBh., Mayrhofer EWAia II p. 391, Turner 1962-66, p. 601, no. 10395, 'a kind of fairy', 'spirit', 'bad spirit'
negating element NE-; lit.: not-good

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *k(w)o- = root of many (interrogative) pronouns, e.g. 'what' in /cognate/160/
maybe related to 'if' in /cognate/2751/ and 'in' in /cognate/2761/

notes: cognate with 'back' in /lexeme/23502/
element(s) UZTAI
element(s) TAPEC
root connection?

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/2567/, 'breathe' in /cognate/3738/, 'neck' in /cognate/9538/, 'nose' in /cognate/9218/, 'swell' in /cognate/9032/, 'rain' in /cognate/8821/, 'wind' in /cognate/3113/.

justificationDiscussion: Traditionally connected with Lithuanian al̃pti 'to be weak; to crave, to yearn after', but without any certain correspondences outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 35-36, {ref Derksen 2015}:52, {ref Karulis 1992} I:264-265).
No certain etymology outside of Italic (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:642-643, {ref de Vaan 2008}:581).

A denominal formation originating in Middle English. There are some possible correspondences, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:57 for some proposals and references to older literature, but ultimately no clear etymology outside of Germanic. {ref Kroonen 2013}:74-75 does not provide comparanda to support a root reconstruction *bʰreh₁- (not in {ref LIV²}).

notes: Proto-Iranian *gant 'to smell, stink', prob. non-IE borrowing (Cheung 2007:103-104)

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)} for further discussion).
Hellenic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *temh₁- 'to cut' ({ref LIV²} 625, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1103-1104, {ref Beekes 2010}:1465-1466, {ref Boryś 2005}:77, {ref Derksen 2008}:494).
Cf. Lith. gríežti 'to grit', no further etymology outside of (East) Baltic ({ref ALEW} 364).

As though from Latin *tāliare 'to cut' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:704-705), a derivative to Latin tālea 'a cutting, piece of wood'. No further etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:673-674, {ref de Vaan 2008}:605).

notes: *lātk-

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *graban- 'to dig', generally postulated to continue a PIE root *gʰrebʰ- 'to dig' ({ref LIV²} 201-202, {ref Kroonen 2013}:185-186, {ref Seebold 1970}:235-236). This lexical isogloss is, however, restricted to cognates in Germanic and Balto-Slavic and consequently it's PIE status remains uncertain. The potential relationship of this root to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' remains unclear (cf. {ref LIV²}).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'to tear (up)' ({ref LIV²} 510, {ref Derksen 2008}:442).

Germanic lexemes generally connected to Balto-Slavic lexemes, cf. RuCS dъlbsti 'to scoop, chisel', Lith. (nu-)del̃bti 'to cast down one's eyes', to PIE *dʰelbʰ- 'dig, excavate' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:92, {ref LIV²} 143), but cf. the reservations of {ref Seebold 1970}:153.

Cf. Lithuanian ràkti 'to stab, dig'; no further etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:498-499); traditionally compared to Vedic r̥kṣá- 'bald, bare' ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:694, {ref Karulis 1992} II:103, {ref IEW} 335) but cf. {ref EWAia} I:248 considering the proposed Vedic comparanda of dubious etymology. [Not in {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}].

notes: < PAL 'spade'

justificationDiscussion: Possibly to IE *drep- 'scratch, tear' according to {ref Adams 2013}:574, although note that the Anatolian evidence which he cites for a semantic parallel is not certainly from this root ({ref Malzahn 2010}:812-813, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:871).
Derived from Tocharian B krāke 'dirt, filth', which may in turn be a loan from Khotanese khārgga- 'id.' ({ref Adams 2013}:229-230).

An adjective derived to Standard Modern Greek βρόμα 'stench', considered by {ref Babinotis 2010}:279 to be a derivative of Ancient Greek βρομέω 'I make a noise' with a semantic change via the sense 'I smell bad' → 'I stink' perhaps via an intermediary sense 'I farted'. No further etymology.

Lit. 'not-clean', cf. Lithuanian týras. Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:679; for older proposals cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:413, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1109-1110). [Not in {ref ALEW} or {ref Derksen 2015}].

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *un-hraini- 'un-clean', an old verbal adjective to the nasal-present stem *kri-né/n-h₁- to PIE *kreh₁(i̯)- 'to sift, to separate'; but the verbal stem *hrinan- is not attested in Germanic ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:302-303, {ref Kroonen 2013}:241, cf. {ref LIV²} 366-367, {ref Lehmann 1986}:190).

Romance lexemes from Latin brūtus 'heavy, brute; brutish' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:121-122), generally considered to be a dialectal loanword from Sabellic with a labial reflex of initial *gʷ- from PIE *gʷr̥h₂-, cf. Latin grauis 'heavy' in /cognate/6470/ ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:76-77, {ref de Vaan 2008}:76).

Iberian Romance lexemes as though from Latin *sucīdus 'dirty', cf. Latin suc(c)īdia 'side of pork' derived from Latin sūs 'wild boar; pig' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:694, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:670, {ref de Vaan 2008}:603). For the reconstruction of the Indo-European word for 'wild boar; pig', cf. the discussion of {ref EIEC} 425.

notes: PA = neg. prefix
= Skrt. muṇḍaḥ 'shaved, hornless' (Turner 1931: 513)
"of imitative origin" (Buck 1949: 1071)
'rubbed down'?, = Grk. TRYO (Buck 1949: 1071)
IE *laiṵo- 'left, slow, weak'; = NE slow
Lat. TUNDERE 'beat, pound'

Bailey (1979: 19b)  connects this word to Saka ā̮ye 'ground, sole of foot' from āy- with Av. āi. He mentions a reconstruction by Morgenstierne (1942) proposed for NP xāk from *āhaka- 'ashes', which is followed by Klingenschmitt (2000: 213, fn.77).

justificationDiscussion: Derived from the Proto-Germanic. strong verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke' {ref Seebold 1970}:379-380, {ref Kluge 2011}:748, {ref Kroonen 2013}:406, 410. There is with no further accepted etymology outside of Germanic, cf. further discussion in /cognate/299/.
Possibly continuing a Proto-Iranic root *du̯ai-, although the evidence for such a root is limited to Middle and Modern East Iranic ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:46, {ref Cheung 2007}:81-82).
As though from Sanskrit *girati ʻdrips, falls' ({ref Turner 1962–1966} no. 4159). Further etymology uncertain.
As though from Sanskrit *khasati ʻfalls, slips' ({ref Turner 1962–1966} no. 3856), further etymology uncertain.
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *kret- 'to shake' ({ref ALEW} 524, 527; {ref LIV²} 370-371).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: unextended root form in Slavic terms /cognate/698/

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Tocharian unclear ({ref Adams 2013}:611-612).

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish ecla 'fear, dread', cf. ecal 'timorous, fearful' < *eks-gal, to which Old Irish gal 'valour' < Proto-Celtic *galā 'valor, ability', ultimately a derivative of PIE *gelH- 'to have power over' ({ref Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language (eDIL)}, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:149, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:5, {ref Matasović 2009}:149, cf. {ref LIV²} 185-186).

Germanic and Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₂egʰ- 'to get scared, become distressed' ({ref LIV²} 257, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:270, {ref Kroonen 2013}:3, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:23, {ref Matasović 2009}:26).

notes: maybe after Lat. PĀR, PARIS 'equal, matching', = NE PAIR

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'to set in motion' ({ref EWAia} II:418-419, {ref Cheung 2007}:176-177, {ref LIV²} 225-226).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *part- 'to fight, struggle', perhaps further related to PIE *per- 'to beat' with a dental extension? (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:298, {ref EWAia} II:160, {ref LIV²} 447).

notes: root cī- 'to attempt, fight', no further etymology

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin luctāre 'to fight' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:418), a frequentative verb based on PIE *lu⁽g̑⁾-to- 'bent' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:350, cf. {ref LIV²} 416 s.v. 2. *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'biegen').
Romance lexemes from Latin (com)battuere ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:85, 196), of obscure origin ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:68).
Derivative from PIE *peu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'to pierce, sting', cf. {ref LIV²} 480, {ref de Vaan 2008}:499 for further discussion.

Possibly continuing a formation (as though) from PIE *trud-no- according to {ref Pedersen 1909}:160, comparing Latin trudō 'to thrust, push', Gothic us-ϸriutan 'to maltreat' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:148-149, {ref LIV²} 651-652). The etymology of {ref IEW} 1026 to a dental-enlarged root *streu- is less likely. [Not in {ref Matasović 2009}].

Tocharian forms, according to {ref Adams 2013}:440, to be connected with PIE *pei̯H- 'to swell up' via a Schwebeablaut variant *pi̯eH- and connected with Vedic √pyā- 'to swell' but the existence of this variant remains uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} II:84, II:172; {ref KEWA} II:349, {ref LIV²} 464-465.

Derivatives from Proto-Indo-Iranic *pau̯š- 'to blossom, bloom' ({ref EWAia} II:153, 171-172). No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. For the Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:470, no. 8303 and 8306.
Loan from Finnic, cf. Livonian puk'k' (cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:85).

Generally compared with Vedic ándhas- 'sprout of the soma plant' which can be accounted for via an s-stem *h₂éndʰ-os- from which Greek ἄνθος would also be a regular reflex ({ref Beekes 2010}:104-105, {ref LIV²} 266, cf. {ref EWAia} I:79). See, however, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:89-90 with some reservations.

notes: Non-Persian words with additional -xVnV might all be loans from early Persian rōdxāna (or a later form), although this can be proved only for Mazanderani.
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow, stream' ({ref EWAia II:784-785, cf. {ref LIV²} 588).

Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *dānu-, probably to be further connected with Vedic dā́nu- 'dropping flow, dripping; drops, dew'(?); the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Iranic *dan- < Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰan- 'to run, flow' (< PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off', cf. {ref LIV²} 144-145) is not to be excluded ({ref ESIJa} II:450-451, cf. {ref EWAia} I:719-720, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:366-367).

Germanic and Italic lexemes reflecting PIE *h₂ekʷ-eh₂- 'water' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:7, {ref EWA 1}:99-103, {ref de Vaan 2008}:48, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:46). Pace {ref Kroonen 2013}, the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by {ref Beekes 1998}), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. {ref EWA 1} 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in /cognate/1735/).
Latin flūmen and Romance lexemes from PIE *bʰleu̯H-mn̥- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:228, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:292, {ref LIV²} 90).

Derived from PIE *pleh₃- 'swim, flow' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:147-148; as a verbal root cf. {ref LIV²} 485); in earlier literature reconstructed as a lengthened grade of *pleu̯- 'swim, float' (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:118-119).

{ref Adams 2013}:115 prefers to connect the Tocharian B forms with Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic words in meanings variously 'fruit (of a tree), berry, acorn'. The proposed etymology is certainly attractive but is not fully certain, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:27, {ref Kroonen 2013}:18-19, {ref ALEW} 1151-1152.

Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 559; cf. also {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:200, {ref Beekes 2010}:649, and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:452-453 (s.v. Hitt. karp(ii̯e/a)- 'to take (away), take up, lift, pluck').

notes: If the proposed etymology of {ref Neri 2007} holds, then cf. 'take' in /cognate/5158/.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Latin traditionally considered uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:520). A recent proposal by {ref Neri 2007}:71 plausibly considers *h₁e/om-o- 'what is to be taken', combined with a preverb *po- in Proto-Italic as *po-e/omo- 'taken off, picked' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:188-189; 479).

notes: the same as 'float', see /lexeme/20399/
origin?

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'become firm' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:894-895, {ref Beekes 2010}:1184, {ref LIV²} 461).

notes: element BHAVATI

justificationDiscussion: Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain; cf. {ref Adams 2013}:9-10 for various proposals.

Anatolian and Baltic lexemes generally connected to an old root noun *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁- (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:445-446, {ref ALEW} 1292). Often assumed to be further connected with Albanian zorrë 'guts' but this connection is ultimately uncertain (cf. discussion in {ref ALEW} 1292 and further references in /cognate/8287/); sometimes also connected with Lat. haru- in haruspex 'diviner (by inspection of entrails)' Umbrian arvia either 'entrails' or 'grain' but the interpretation of the Italic forms (and consequently their etymology) is disputed (cf. discussion in /cognate/8486/).

Variously compared with different words designating internal organs in other Indo-European languages, but no clearly reconstructable proto-form can be established (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1039-1040, {ref Beekes 2010}:1384-1385).
A word common to Western Romance languages, but of uncertain origin (cf. {ref DCECH} V:638-641).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: IE *(h)ei-, (h)iha-, (h)id-, the same root as in dem. pron. 'that' /cognate/2442/, 'this' /cognate/2437/ and 'and' in /cognate/1103/
IE *so, *se(h), *tod, see dem. pron. in /cognate/318/, prob. partly cognate with /cognate/1665/
cogn. with 'that' in /cognate/2439/, 'here' in /cognate/2693/ and maybe also 'other' in /cognate/269/

notes: cf. Lith. smagùs 'strong, heavy'
justificationDiscussion: The Baltic adjective is to be connected with the root of Lithuanian smõgti 'to hit, strike' whose root is generally further connected to Polish smagać 'to whip', etc. < Proto-Balto-Slavic *smāg-, further etymology uncertain ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:579, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:837-838, 848; cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:235-236).

Romance lexemes from Latin lūridus 'pale yellow, lurid' (({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 5:465-470, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:420), further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:371, {ref de Vaan 2008}:354).

notes: PIE *⁽g̑⁾ʰe/o- 'this', in LIPP Vol. 2 (pp. 285, 398) *-gʰo 'wahrlich, in der Tat' (Partikel, wortemphatisch, klitisch)
composition and root connection?

justificationDiscussion: From Proto-Tocharian *kər(ə)n-, proposed by {ref Adams 2013}:173-174 to be based on an unextended root variant *kreu̯- to PIE *kreu̯s- 'hit, beat' ({ref LIV²} 371, {ref IEW} 622), and accepted by {ref Malzahn 2010}:575-577.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5424, presumably of non-Aryan origin.
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a stem *ṭakk- 'cut, break', cf. Sanskrit ṭakkarā 'a blow on the head' first attested in Rājataraṃgiṇī (12th c. AD). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:300 no. 5421, 5424; {ref KEWA} I:455).
Derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ({ref LIV²} 7, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:32-34, {ref Schumacher 2004}:226-232, {ref Matasović 2009}:65-66, {ref LIV²} 72).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:188-189 for further discussion.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', possibly from a root ?*slak- 'to hit, beat' only otherwise attested Celtic, cf. Middle Irish slacc 'sword' ({ref Seebold 1970}:425-427, {ref Lehmann 1986}:314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:452, {ref LIV²} 564).

IE root etymology unclear. {ref LIV²} s.v. ?*dʰreb-, considers the forms to be possibly connected with OCS drobiti 'to splinter, pulverise' but regards this connection as uncertain. {ref Seebold 1970} and {ref Kluge 2011} see no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. {ref Kroonen 2013} derives from via a backformation to iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip' and accepts a root etymology with OCS drobiti, but reconstructs from *dʰrebʰ- to avoid reconstructing PIE *b.

Italic and Romance lexemes continuing PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80, {ref de Vaan 2008}:213; for Germanic lexemes in this set not in the target meaning, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:53).
Romance lexemes from Latin battuere 'hit, beat' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:85), of obscure origin ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:68).

Loan from Old Indic *vedhati 'pierces' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:701, {ref Strand 1998}), further to Indo-European *u̯edʰ(h₁)- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:496-497, {ref LIV²} 660). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

notes: IE *kap- (Buck 1949: 741)
comp. with Ir. GAIBIM 'take' seize', = Lat. HABERE < IE *ghab(h)- (Buck 1949: 740)
if Hitt. māhhan identical with mān 'as, how', then prob.  common pron. stem *mo- for Hitt. and Toch.

justificationDiscussion: Italic and Romance lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *u̯enH- 'to grow fond of' ({ref LIV²} 682-683, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:662, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:766 no. 9186).

notes: fr. Ir. FIADH  'animal' (Buck 1949: 191)
< Lat. SPONSUS < SPONDERE 'promise' (Buck)
Turner 1931: 562
element ECHT, EHE, AKTA 'marriage', OHG EWA 'law, marriage state'  (Buck 1949:  96), cognate with 'right' in /lexeme/25749/
element GENOT 'companion'
* bhṛ- 'bear, carry' (Buck 1949: 97)
element HUS 'house'

justificationDiscussion: Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ({ref IEW} 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:601 no. 10396; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:234-235, {ref HED A+E/I}:257-259, {ref Matasović 2009}:435).

From Proto-Slavic *morzъ 'frost' and to be connected with Albanian mardhë 'frost, ice', from PIE *merg̑⁽ʰ⁾-o- ({ref Derksen 2008}:326, {ref ESSJa} 20:10-14, 21:163-165, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:256, {ref Orel 1998}:245).

notes: = Skrt. YADI 'if' (Turner 1931: 522)

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: (J)AK and I/O/EF fr. the same stem *(h)e-, (h)ih(a)-, (h)id as in 'how' /cognate/1230/, relation with /cognate/2747/ doutbful

notes: lit. 'in case (that)'?
outside connections?

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: see also Alb. /cognate/424/, cognate with 'guts' in /cognate/1588/ and 'at' in /cognate/2535/.

notes: prob. loanword fr. Sanskr. (Turner 1931: 477)
element DE

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Middle Indic *jhilla- 'swamp, lake', cf. Prakrit jhillaï 'bathes', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:297 no. 5392).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit taḍāga- 'pond, tank, (artificial) lake', further etymology obscure ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:320 no. 5635, {ref KEWA} I:470).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rái̯as-, an s-stem noun formed to Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rai̯-'to stretch, extend', cf. Vedic √jray- 'id.', further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:606-607, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:449).

No accepted etymology outside of Germanic; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:292, for the suggestion that Proto-Germanic *saiwi- is a probable non-IE, pre-Gmc. loanword. {ref Kroonen 2013}:423, 435-436 accepts an etymology from IE *sei̯kʷ- without referring to other hypotheses.

The Germanic and Celtic forms in this class reflect a derived stem *kh₂p-no- or *kap-no- (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:261-262, {ref Matasović 2009}:197, {ref Kroonen 2013}:196-197}), for the reconstruction of the IE root as either *keh₂p- or *kap- cf. {ref LIV²} 345n1.

notes: Skrt. SAGARA- < SA 'river' +GARA 'drink, swallowing'

justificationDiscussion: Generally derived from Indo-European *gʰer- 'to desire, be delighted' ({ref LIV² 176-177 s.v. *g̑ʰer-, cf. now *gʰer- in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, {ref Adams 2013}:208-209, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:135-136, {ref van Windekens 1976}:188), but cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:604-605 with some doubts and possible alternative proposals.
Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes from PIE *(H)seu̯-i̯o- 'left' ({ref Adams 2013}:767, {ref EWAia} II:716, {ref Derksen 2008}:487-488).
Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek *ζαβρός / *ζαρβός (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:530 for further discussion).

In all likelihood an old loanword into Iberian Romance from the medieval forerunner of modern Basque eskerr, although it cannot be ruled out that the current Basque lexeme has not been influenced by the Romance forms (cf. {ref DCECH} III:469-472 for further discussion).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ({ref NIL} 526-540), cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1227-1228, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:534-535, {ref EWAia} II:77-78, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:438 no. 7747, {ref Kroonen 2013}:152, {ref de Vaan 2008}:462, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, {ref LIV²} 458).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'foot' in /cognate/225/, 'stand' in /cognate/6813/, 'fall' in /cognate/1126/, 'lie' in /cognate/8225/, 'sleep' in /cognate/9252/.

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *skel- 'bend, curve' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1013, {ref Beekes 2010}:1346).

As {ref Derksen 2008}: 228-229 points out, there are two candidates for the root etymology: PIE *kelH 'rise, rise above' {ref LIV²}: 349 and *kʷelh₁- 'turn, rotate' {ref LIV²}: 386-388 (reconstructed as *kʷel(H) by Derksen). From the formal, phonetic point of view there can not be any clue in Slavic. Moreover, the proximity of two proto-meanings (having the concept of movement in common) makes it in my opinion impossible to raise any convincing semantic arguments even in external comparisons with other IE forms. Cf. {ref ESSJa}: 10: 133. Therefore, any strict decision would be speculative.
Authors of the Slavic etymology rather tend to see *kʷel(H) here, see {ref Boryś 2005}: 243 or {ref Snoj 1997-2016}.

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:446, {ref Orel 2003}:334, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:485, {ref Kluge 2011}:800). For the root, cf. {ref LIV²} 555).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *koxsā/o-, further connected to PIE *kok̑so- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:214, {ref Matasović 2009}:220).

Romance lexemes from Latin rotella 'little wheel' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:610, {ref DCECH} V:85-86), a diminutive formation to Latin rota 'wheel' and further to PIE *ret- 'run' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:527, cf. {ref LIV²} 507).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic aṣṭhīvát- 'bony; knees', a derivative of Vedic aṣṭhī- 'bone', further continuing PIE *h₂ost- 'bone' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:41 no. 959, {ref EWAia} I:150-151).
Etymology uncertain. Probable parallel loans from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:166 no. 3243, {ref KEWA} I:359, {ref Burrow 1948}:377).
Derived from PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:353-355, {ref LIV²} 293-294).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10666 s.v. *rahati ʻremainsʼ, *rahyati, cf. raha- m. (RV, BhP.), rahas- n. (MBh.) ʻisolation, secrecyʼ - from 'be isolated, left over' via 'remain' and 'stay' to 'live' - compare the meaning of the root of /cognate/255/
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing a Vedic verbal stem *rahati, cf. Sanskrit ráhas- 'loneliness, solitude, secrecy' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:617 no. 10666). There are comparanda in Iranic, cf. Middle Persian rāz, Parthian rʾz 'secret, mystery' etc., but connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:442).

notes: = NHG AMME 'nurse', but Buck also considers connection with (M)AMMA (Buck 1949: 94)
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 997 s.v. *āī- ʻmother, auntʼ; nursery word
prob. related to Skt. VADHÚḤ 'woman, wife' (Turner 1931: 427)

justificationDiscussion: {ref Adams 2013}:714 connects the root of the Tocharian forms to Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'swell' (cf. /cognate/315/), but this etymological connection remains uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:489-490, {ref Kroonen 2013}:499).

Modern Greek βουνό 'mountain' from Ancient Greek βουνός 'mountain, hill' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:275), further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:190, {ref Beekes 2010}:231-232).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 459, no. 8141 s.v. *pāhāḍa- 'rock, hill' and no. 8140; compare RV gen. du. pāṣyóḥ 'stone, rock'
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:460 no. 8141 'rock, hill'.

notes: Turner 1931: 260

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/4527/, 'hand' in /cognate/1712/, 'thin' in /cognate/1923/, 'wide' in /cognate/5264/, 'smooth' in /cognate/6801/, 'earth' in /cognate/5892/, 'stand' in /cognate/8055/, 'tree' in /cognate/8103/.

justificationDiscussion: It is unclear whether the *-s- reconstructed is part of the root or s-stem morphology that has been transferred into thematic classes. Cf. {ref EWA 3}:142-145, {ref Kroonen 2013}:134 for further discussion.
Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ({ref Derksen 2008}:494, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4:183, {ref Boryś 2005}:77, 84 for various proposals.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin strictus 'narrow' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:686 no. 8305, cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 12:298). The further PIE root etymology is difficult as Latin strictus, probably represents a blend / contamination of PIE *strig- 'to brush, strip', and *strengʰ- 'to tie' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:591-592, cf. {ref LIV²} 603-604).

Etymological connections outside of Baltic uncertain, traditionally compared to Proto-Indo-Iranic *sau̯- 'to press, squeeze' but this etymological proposal is no longer widely accepted ({ref ALEW} 908, {ref Derksen 2015}:396, cf. {ref EWAia} II:713-714, {ref LIV²} 537-538).
No clear correspondences outside of Germanic, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:517-518, {ref Kroonen 2013}:456.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. There are some proposed possible cognates in Baltic, but these comparisons depend on the internal semantic reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *narwa-, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:421, {ref Kroonen 2013}:383. The proposed cognacy to the Baltic lexemes is rejected by {ref ALEW} s.v. OLith. *nérti (II). In the Iranic literature, the Germanic forms are sometimes connected to Indo-Iranian *nāraka- < PIE *ner- following {ref IEW} 976, however this view is not followed in the most recent etymological dictionaries (cf. {ref EWAia} II:37 s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'); cf. further discussion in /cognate/3247/.

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *maiwa- 'slim, narrow', as though from PIE *moi̯H-u̯o-, a derivative of PIE *mei̯H- 'to diminish' ({ref de Vries 1977}:399, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:397-398, {ref Kroonen 2013}:349, cf. {ref LIV²} 427).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *þrinhan-; further IE root reconstruction in this set follows {ref LIV²} 649, {ref Lehmann 1986}:365 to *trenk- 'to push', but cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:547 who argues for a root reconstruction *trenkʷ- on the basis of ON þryngva.

notes: Loan from Arabic qarīb

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:309, {ref Beekes 2010}:369-370 for various hypotheses.
Romance lexemes from Latin vīcīnus 'neighbour' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:777), further to Latin vīcus 'village, block of houses' and PIE *u̯ei̯k̑- 'settlement' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:675).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:186-187, {ref Adams 2013}:263 for various proposals).

Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to wear down, make old' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:338, {ref EWAia} I:576, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:304-305, cf. {ref LIV²} 165-166). For non-target Modern Hellenic lexemes attached to this set, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:268-269, {ref Babinotis 2010}:296.

notes: cf. Vedic purāṇá- 'prior, former, old', from purā́ adv. < *pr̥h₂éh₁ (instrumental, cf. purás < *pr̥h₂és etc.)
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from a PIE root *perh₂-, secondary to PIE *pr̥-, *pró-, *prí 'forwards, to the front' ({ref EWAia} II:146-147, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:469 no. 8283, {ref EWA 3}:300-301, {ref Kroonen 2013}:161, cf. {ref LIPP 2}:653, 633).

notes: < AOIS  'age'

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: (J)INY, EEN fr. the same stem as 'one' in /cognate/91/. comp. also /lexeme/11690/

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *laikan- 'to jump', further derived from PIE *lei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'to jump' ({ref Seebold 1970}:321-322, {ref Kroonen 2013}:323, {ref LIV²} 405).

Originally a denominal formation from Ancient Greek ταῦρος 'bull' in the sense of 'pull like a bull' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1446), further to be connected with Latin taurus 'bull', Lithuanian taũras 'auroch', Old Prussian tauris 'bison', OCS turъ 'buffalo', etc. ({ref Beekes 2010}:1455-1456, cf. also {ref ALEW} 1081-1082).

notes: < Sanskrit lambate (MhB), Vedic rámbate, PIE *lemb(H)-, cf. LIV, p. 411
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √ramb- ~ √lamb- 'hang down, dangle', {ref Turner 1962–1966}:636 no. 10954), further to PIE *lembH- 'to hang slack' ({ref EWAia} II:436-437, {ref LIV²} 411).
Iranic and Slavic lexemes from PIE *tengʰ- 'to pull' ({ref Cheung 2007}:391-392, {ref Derksen 2008}:493). For the root reconstruction, cf. discussion in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
The root etymology in this cognate set follows {ref LIV²} 154 to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to haul, to pull', cf. also {ref Kroonen 2013}:99, {ref Lehmann 1986}:93-94, {ref Seebold 1970}:160-162.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'walk' in /cognate/5824/, 'run' in /cognate/5027/, 'carry' in /cognate/5330/, probably also 'turn' in /cognate/660/.

justificationDiscussion: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'to crus, pound' ({ref ALEW} 374).

Albanian lexemes generally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'to strike, beat' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:379-380, {ref Orel 1998}:444, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:999, cf. {ref LIV²} 601 [without Albanian]). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning in this set, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:476.

The Modern Greek forms are from prefixed προ-ωθέω with various sound laws and analogical changes applied (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:1317), ultimately to IE *u̯edʰh₁- 'push' ({ref LIV²} 660, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1676-1677). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4153: presumably from a non-Indo-Aryan source

justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:308 no. 5512 *ṭhēḍḍ- 'push' with variants 2. *ṭhēll- . 3. *ṭēll-. Further etymology unclear.
Loanword from Middle English putten 'to push' ((ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:284, cf. {ref Broaderick 1984b}:356).

notes: Persian loan
Etymology disputed.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:818-819 and {ref Beekes 2010}:1101 for various competing proposals.
Italic, Celtic, and Germanic lexemes in this class continue a stem *u̯eh₁-ró-, Slavic lexemes are secondary adjectives derived from Proto-Slavic *věra 'faith, belief' as though from *u̯eh₁-r-eh₂

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: etym. dub. (Buck), the same in 'straight' in /cognate/1068/

notes: prob. related to the notion of 'true, truth', cf. Skt. SATYA- 'truth' (Turner 1931: 596)

justificationDiscussion: Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. {ref ALEW} s.v. Lith. lãbas, {ref LIV²} 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 speculatively considered a connection with Armenian law (cf. discussion in /cognate/8081/), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW}. A lemma for Lithuanian lãbas is lacking in {ref Derksen 2015}. Apart from the as yet uncertain proposal to Vedic rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

notes: etym. dub., maybe related to NE HAUL (Buck 1949: 549)
often 'reins, bridle', = Skt. RAŚMÍḤ 'string' (Turner 1931: 536), comp. /lexeme/22491/
fr. KONOPLJA 'hemp'

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: = OCS PO-VREŠTI 'bind', may be ultimately cogn. with /cognate/1209/

notes: NHG SCHNUR

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *peu̯H- 'to rot, to stink' ({ref EWAia} II:155, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:141, {ref ALEW} 834, {ref Derksen 2015}:374, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:219, {ref Kroonen 2013}:132, 158, {ref de Vaan 2008}:501, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:570 no. 6878, 6887, cf. {ref LIV²} 480-481).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √pac- 'to cook' and further derived from PIE 1. *pekʷ- 'to become ripe, make cooked' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:431 no. 7654, {ref EWAia} II:64, cf. {ref LIV²} 468).

Based on an Indic root *kuth- 'to stink' attested only quite late in Sanskrit, further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:169 no. 3282, {ref KEWA} I:228; see {ref EWAia} II:41 for an uncertain Vedic attestation of the root).

notes: < Vedic mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, polished, pure', later R. 'prepared, savoury' via Mbh. miṣṭa- 'dainty, sweet, pure, good', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 594f., no. 10299
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes continuing Vedic mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, washed, pure' > Classical Sanskrit 'prepared, savoury', further root etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:594-595 no. 10299, {ref EWAia} II:324-325).

notes: cogn. with 'hit' in /lexeme/14999/ (Turner 1931: 155)
if cogn. with NHG SCHEUERN 'to rub, scrub', then maybe = Dutch SC(H)UREN < Fr. ESCURER 'to clean' < Lat. *EX-CURARE 'to care for'? (Kluge 1989: 630)
comp.  also /lexeme/25796/

justificationDiscussion: Armenian lexemes generally derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut (off), scratch, shear' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:662-663, {ref LIV²} 556-557).
