As though from Proto-Germanic *hreiban- 'to seize, grasp', without certain correspondences outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:270-271, {ref Orel 2003}:187, {ref Kroonen 2013}:241).

Iberian Romance lexemes as though from Latin *rasicare, a late form of Latin rādere ({ref DCECH} IV:786-787), further etymology possibly to a root *rasd- with probable cognates in Celtic (cf. {ref LIV²} 496, {ref de Vaan 2008}:512).

notes: fr. 'hit, strike, be attached to' (Turner 1931: 552f)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *bitra- 'biting, bitter', an adjectival derivative to PIE *bʰei̯d- 'to split' ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:126-127, {ref Kroonen 2013}:65-66, cf. {ref NIL} 11-12, {ref LIV²} 70-71).
Hellenic, Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *mr̥g̑ʰ-ú- 'short' ({ref NIL} 497-499, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:236, {ref EWAia} II:364-365, {ref de Vaan 2008}:75).

Cf. also Lith. į́sas 'short'. Baltic lexemes from Proto-Baltic *insa-. Further etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, traditionally connected to Ved. iṣṇāti 'drive, propel' from PIE *h₂ei̯sh₂- 'to invigorate; to drive, propel' (cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:225, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:187). [Not in {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}].
Ossetic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *g̑ar- 'to sound, call' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:288-289, {ref LIV²} 161, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:470).
The ablaut and morphology of related vocabulary within Greek suggest a root *h₂u̯ei̯d-, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. {ref LIV²} 288, {ref Beekes 2010}:23).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'air', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:237, {ref EWA 5}:1488-1491, {ref Kluge 2011}:586, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:328, 342).
According to {ref Adams 2013}:617, probably to be connected with Ancient Greek ὀλίγος 'few, small', Albanian lig 'bad, evil; thin' etc. as a derivative from PIE *h₃lei̯g̑-.
Romance lexemes from Latin sentīre 'to sense, feel' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:645-646), further to PIE *sent- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:554, {ref LIV²} 533).

Nuristani lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell' in light verb constructions (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:214-215 no. 4014), further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:461-462).
Generally derived to IE *u̯er- 'observe, perceive' ({ref LIV²} 3. *u̯er- 'to observe, perceive', cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:886-888, {ref Adams 2013}:647-648).
Slavic lexemes from PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to perceive, see' ({ref LIV²} 561, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:91, {ref ESSJa} 4:136-138).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *stinkwan- 'to thrust, to clash; to stink', a derivative of PIE *stengʷ- 'to thrust, push' ({ref LIV²} 596-597, {ref Seebold 1970}:471-472, {ref Kroonen 2013}:480-481).
Of obscure etymology; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:66 for various unsatisfying proposals.
From Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:592). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:470, {ref Beekes 2010}:600-601 for various proposals.

notes: = NE EVEN
= NE LIKE, Goth. LEIK, NHG LEICHE 'body, corpse' (Buck 1949: 1069)

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of English ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: prob. fr. Lat. PLANUS 'flat' > NE PLAIN, cogn. with 'wide' in /cognate/667/ and 'thin' in /cognate/1923/

justificationDiscussion: Some aspects of the root reconstruction are disagreed upon (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:383 s.v. Lat. mītis), but generally the cognacy of the Celtic and Italic lexemes are agreed. {ref Matasović 2009}:278-279 suggests an alternative etymology s.v. Proto-Celtic *moyni- 'treasure, precious object' for potentially connected lexemes (W mwyn 'mild, tender, gentle', MoBret. moan 'tender, thin', OCo. muin 'thin' < *mēnV- < *meyHnV-), but is cryptic as to whether OIr. mín also should belong to this alternative etymology (not mentioned under the lemma for *moyni-).
No clear etymology outside of Tocharian ({ref Adams 2013}:26-27).

notes: related to Hitt. ṢE-, ṢAI- 'to be'? (Windekens 1976: 35)

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: the same stem as in 'who' /cognate/339/, = Skt. KÁŚCIT (Turner 1931: 67), KÁḤ (98), KECIT (105), see also comment on /lexeme/6637/

notes: outside connections? the same as 'few' in /lexeme/7132/
the same as in 'few' in /lexeme/25367/, etym.?

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: EENIGE = NE ANY, from 'one' in /cognate/91/, maybe also related to OPrus. /lexeme/21988/

notes: < Lat. SALIVA 'spittle'
IE *qaud-, = Lat. CUDERE 'strike, knock' (Windekens 1976: 36)
cogn. with 'wing' in /lexeme/8642/
< RAJA 'crack, slice' (Buck 1949: 564)
Walde has IE *sqēu- 'cut, divide, search' (1930: 2.552)
= Skt. CARPATAḤ 'lying flat to the head, open palm' (Turner 1931: 166)
< Lat. STRICTUS (http://buscon.rae.es/draeI/SrvltConsulta?TIPO_BUS=3&LEMA=estrecho)
< *chaṭa- and variants, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 271f., no. 4966
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:272 no. 4966 s.v. *chaṭa- 'stick, cane'. Further etymology uncertain.
Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit lakuṭa- (~ laguḍa-) 'club', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:629 no. 10875, {ref KEWA} III:84-85).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *staba- 'staff; letter'. Further connections not fully uncertain, possibly with Lithuanian stãbas 'post', Old Irish sab 'shaft, pole' < *stabʰ-o- or *stobʰ-o-? (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:471, {ref ALEW} 967).
Loanword from Livonian nuja 'stick' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:631).
Germanic forms as though from PIE *u̯olH-u-, a derivative of PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:393, {ref Kroonen 2013}:572; for the root reconstruction cf. {ref LIV²} 677).

Italic lexemes, derived as an instrument noun from a root *bak- whose distribution appears to be an isogloss restricted to Western Indo-European languages. Perhaps a European loanword from an unidentified source ({ref de Vaan 2008}:67, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:64, cf. {ref IEW} 93).
Etymology uncertain, possibly identical with Proto-Germanic *baina- in 'bone' (/cognate/191/) and 'leg' (/cognate/71/), cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:113.

notes: "imitative" (Buck)
comp. Sp. CHUCHO 'a long-earded owl' "so called fr. its cry or fr. its being supposed to suck the blood of children' (Diez 1864: 133)

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑u̯eh₁- 'to swell up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:728 no. 12565, 12568, {ref EWAia} II:623-624, {ref Cheung 2007}:341, cf. {ref LIV²} 339-340).

Greek and Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ei̯d- 'to swell' ({ref LIV²} 258-259, {ref Beekes 2010}:1053-1054, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:61). Albanian forms in /cognate/8292/ might be cognate to this set but ultimately uncertain, cf. discussion in that cognate class.
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:417, {ref Derksen 2015}:343-344, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:435-436).
Its Slavic and further IE cognacy is not entirely certain.
Romance lexemes from Latin inflāre 'blow into, inflate, swell' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:362), further to PIE *bʰleh₁- 'blow' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:226-227, {ref LIV²} 87).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek χονδρός 'granular, coarse' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1604-1605). Further etymology unexplained, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1268-1269, {ref Beekes 2010}:1643 for various hypotheses.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cf. Skrt. valkala- m. n. 'bark', Pali vakkalo m. 'bark', cf. Turner 1932: 430; cf. /cognate/1798/

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin spissus 'laborious, slow, dense' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:674). Further etymology uncertain; generally compared to the family of lexemes around Greek σπίδιος 'extensive, wide' and Lithuanian 'swarm (of bees)' (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:643, {ref de Vaan 2008}:581). The proposed Baltic connections should be rejected because the root requires an unvoiced dental and is semantically remote (cf. {ref ALEW} 959). The proposed Greek connections might still be possible, but the original semantics of the forms are uncertain (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1382).

notes: PIE *tói, originally a demonstrative (*tó-)

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: element AU- in Greek: IE *u-, maybe cognate with /cognate/2685/,  /cognate/2439/ and /cognate/1665/

Nep. UT(H)A comp. of U + TA (< Skt. -TRA loc. part.?) (Turner 1931: 47), cf. comment on 'he' in /cognate/1665/, U may be ultimately cogn. with AU- and E- in /cognate/3019/; NIA forms are built in parallel with 'here'; TJ: first part probably identical with cognate set 5069 of "that"

justificationDiscussion: Hittite maklant-, generally interpreted as a derivative *m(e)h₂k-lo-nt-, and root-cognate to the Caland adjective *mh₂k̑-ró- found in Proto-Germanic *magrá- 'meagre, slim', Gk. μακρός 'long, tall', Lat. macer 'meagre, lean' ({ref HED M} 19-20, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:545, {ref NIL} 478-481).

notes: = Skt. DURBALAḤ 'weak' (Turner 1931: 315)
= Skt.  MASṚṆAḤ 'soft'  (Turner 1931: 496)

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin fīnis 'boundary, limit' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:287), no certain further etymology (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:236-237, {ref de Vaan 2008}:222 for discussion of various proposals).
Root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:407-408 for two possibilities to either *bʰleg- 'shine' or *bʰel- 'speak, yell; bark' of which {ref Malzahn 2010}:721 prefers the former etymology.
Denominal verbs to Albanian mend 'mind', a borrowing from Latin mentem 'mind' (acc.sg.) ({ref Meyer 1891}:274, {ref Huld 1984}:91, {ref Orel 1998}:256).

notes: parallel Sanskritisms, cf. vicāra- m. 'pondering' (MBh.), Prakrit viāra- m. 'thought'

justificationDiscussion: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from derived from Vedic √cet- 'to recognise' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:261, no. 4815), ultimately from PIE *kʷei̯t- 'to observe, recognise', traditionally analysed as a root-extended form *kʷei̯-t- to a more basic root *kʷei̯- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:547-548, {ref LIV²} 382-383).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *men- 'to think' ({ref EWAia} II:305-306, cf. {ref LIV²} 435-436).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 5:154-156, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 1:552, {ref Rejzek 2001}:149, {ref Boryś 2005}:132).

Possibly from IE *smei̯d- 'to smear', cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:459, {ref LIV²} 569. See {ref Seebold 1970}:437-438 for older unconvincing proposals to Lat. mittere (ruled out as phonologically implausible by {ref LIV²}).

Possibly cognate with Hittite peššii̯e/a- 'throw', but the connection is disputed; cf. /cognate/8675/ for further discussion and references. Otherwise only Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:144-145, {ref LIV²} 242-243).

notes: = Skt. NṚTUḤ 'dancer < shake' (Turner 1931: 339)

justificationDiscussion: The etymology is obscure, probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Skok 1971-1974} 1:84-85). No certain etymology outside of Slavic: the etymology proposed in {ref ESSJa} 1:118-120 is ingenious but speculative.
Possibly a variant to the more widely attested root *terh₁- 'bore, rub' ({ref LIV²} 632), cf. {ref LIV²} 647 s.v. ?*treh₁-, {ref Kroonen 2013}:546, {ref Seebold 1970}:519.

Romance lexemes from Latin lanceāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:396), a denominal verb to Latin lancea 'lance'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly a Celtic loanword ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:339-340).
loan_notes: Latin lancea is certainly a loanword in origin, but it's precise origins are unclear (cf. Ernout & Meillet 1985:339-340).

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes as though from Latin *tīrāre, of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:725, {ref DCECH} V:505-508 for further discussion).

notes: < Lat. ERUNCARE 'weed out' (Buck)
< MHG BOZEN 'to strike' (Diez 1864: 86)

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian and Baltic lexemes whose cognacy is generally agreed, but root reconstruction difficult. Cf. comments of {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:392-393. LIV¹ reconstructs *seh₂(i̯)-, {ref LIV²} *sh₂ei̯-. As a compromise between the two versions of LIV and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}, we give *seh₂(i̯)- as the root ref. form for this class. See also {ref Derksen 2015}:397-398. For Indo-Iranic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. {ref EWAia} II:720-721.

Generally connected since {ref Fraenkel 1932}:229-230 to Lithuanian ker̃gti 'tie, bind' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:87-88, {ref Malzahn 2010}:573-574, {ref Adams 2013}:171-172) from a PIE root *kergʰ- or *kergʷʰ- (not in {ref LIV²}).

notes: cf. Vedic (Br) grathnā́ti, Sanskrit granthayati (MhB), grathati (Dhātup.), Pali gantheti; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 233, no. 4353, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 504f.

justificationDiscussion: From Proto-Germanic *knūϸan- ~ *knuttan- 'knot' and probably continuing a derivation of PIE *g̑enu- 'knee, nodule' ({ref de Vries 1977}:322-323, {ref Kroonen 2013}:298-299; cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:508).
Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin aptāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:46, {ref DCECH} I:389-390), further to PIE *h₁ep- 'grasp, seize' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:47, {ref LIV²} 237-238).
Denominal formation, but further details are disputed (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:963-964, {ref Adams 2013}:787-788 for further discussion).
Etymology outside of Iranian uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:104-105).

Romance lexemes from Latin gȳrāre 'to turn around in a circle' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:335), a denominal verb from Latin gȳrus 'circle', a technical term borrowed from Ancient Greek γῦρος 'ring, circle' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:286).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *tekti 'to flow, run', and further derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'to flow, run' ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:159, {ref Derksen 2008}:489, {ref LIV²} 620-621).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'come' in /cognate/15/, 'run' in /cognate/5199/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/3259/, 'river' in /cognate/5249/ 'swell' in /cognate/1881/.

justificationDiscussion: Baltic lexemes as through from PIE *greng̑ʰ- 'to turn' ({ref ALEW} 360-361, {ref LIV²} 191; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:305-306). The reconstructed root is restricted in attestation to Germanic and Baltic.
Continuing the Germanic strong verb *wendan-, and further to PIE *u̯endʰ- (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:554-556, {ref Kroonen 2013}:587, {ref Kluge 2011}:970, {ref LIV²} 681-682).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of the Vedic root √chard- 'to overflow', cf. causative stem chardáyati 'cause to overflow, vomit' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:273-274 no. 4998). Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:557)

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2538, Turner 1931: 565

justificationDiscussion: Light verb construction with Nepali बान्ता / bāntā 'vomit' as its semantic head. Loanword from Sanskrit vānta- 'vomited, ejected from the mouth' with subsequent sound change of initial v- > b- ({ref Turner 1931}:434).

The forms in this class from Proto-Germanic *spīwan- are generally compared with similar verbs denoting 'to spit' found elsewhere among the Indo-European languages ({ref LIV²} 583-584, reconstructing *spti̯eu̯H-, cf. non-Jena 175 'spit' in /cognate/305/). Reconstructing a common IE root for these forms, however, is extremely difficult, as the forms in various branches likely underwent deformations or reformations among individual daughter languages due to onomatopoeia or phonotactic reasons. Within Germanic these forms are more-or-less regular from *spīwan- / *speiw-a- (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:450-452, {ref Kroonen 2013}:468).

A negative verbal derivative of Breton lonk- 'swallow' (Old Breton lunc), i.e. to un-swallow ({ref Deshayes 2003}:472-473), further connected to Old Irish slucc-, Welsh llyncu 'to swallow' from Proto-Celtic *slu-n-k-e/o- and ultimately derived from PIE *sleu̯k- 'to swallow, gulp' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:593-595, {ref LIV²} 568, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:347, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:139).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ({ref LIV²} 572-573, {ref EWAia} II:769-770, {ref Cheung 2007}:348-349). For Punjabi, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:796, no. 13791.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'to wash' ({ref LIV²} 450, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1020-1021, {ref EWAia} II:54, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:410 no. 7167, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:16-17, {ref Matasović 2009}:290-291).
Continuing a derivative of Sanskrit kṣálati 'flows' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:190 no. 3664), further to PIE *gʷg̑ʰer- 'to drift in water, flow' ({ref {EWAia} I:428-429, {ref LIV²} 213-214).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE 3. *per- 'to beat' ({ref Derksen 2008}:427-428, {ref Boryś 2005}:478-479, cf. {ref LIV²} 473).

notes: comp. NPers. GŌŠĀ 'edge, corner'. Rather not: NP gušād is from Middle Persian wišād! MJK

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₁urH-ú- 'broad, wide', presupposing a full-grade root *h₁u̯erH- (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:483-484, {ref EWAia} I:227, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:90-91, {ref Untermann 2000}:310, {ref de Vaan 2008}:645).

From Medieval Greek φαρδύς < Ancient (εὐ-)φραδής 'wise; linguistically correct', with metathesis /fra-/ > /far-/ ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1523), further a derivative from the same root as Ancient Greek φράζομαι 'to consider, think (up), perceive', but with no known etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1588).

notes: loan, via Hindi farāḵẖ from Persian (Turner 1931: 401)

justificationDiscussion: Root etymology and connections outside of Italic disputed, cf. {ref Meiser 2002}:112, {ref de Vaan 2008}:329-330 for further discussion. For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:401.

notes: < Lat. SOCIUS (Buck 1949: 97), cogn. with 'husband' in  /lexeme/13423/
etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 83)
perh. fr. Skt YOJITĀ 'yoked, joined' (Turner 1931: 223)

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cogn. with 'fire, heat, hearth' in many Indian languages, therefore most prob. cogn. with 'warm' in /cognate/333/ (Turner 1931: 154)

notes: element FRAU, VROUW etc. 'woman'
element HUS, HUIS 'house'
< Lat. SPONSŪS 'betrothed, bridegroom' < SPONDĒRE 'promise'
Lat. FĒMINA 'a female', = FĒLĀRE 'suck'

justificationDiscussion: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek ἀέρας, a new α-stem morphologically remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀήρ, ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds, atmosphere', and ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er- ({ref Babinotis 2010}:70, {ref Beekes 2010}:27).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:385 no. 6732, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:381-383, cf. {ref EWAia} I:775-776, {ref Cheung 2007}:55-56, {ref LIV²} 153).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/2567/, 'breathe' in /cognate/3738/, 'neck' in /cognate/9538/, 'nose' in /cognate/9218/, 'swell' in /cognate/9032/, 'rain' in /cognate/8821/.

notes: cf. Urdu /lexeme/26095/; bāl-forms via *barza-/bazra- ? Note the similarity of bāl-forms with the well-attested Hamito-Semitic *bal- root "wing, feather" (Orel/Stolbova 1995: 52) with a short vowel.
The Pashai form is probably a feminine derivative of *ḍayanaka- or a similar form.
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *uḍḍīyate ~ *uḍḍayate 'flies up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:77, no.1697), further derived from Vedic √day-ⁱ (1) 'fly'; no further etymology ({ref EWAia} I:700, {ref KEWA} I:460).

notes: IE *lei-, li-, = Skt. LĪ- 'to vanish' (Windekens 1976: 70)
comp. /lexeme/19296/

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: 'dry' < Lat. EX-SUCTUS (Diez 1864: 418), thus prob. related to 'dry' in /cognate/2493/

notes: comp. Fr. NETTOYER 'to clean'
comp. OIr. REM- 'forth, ahead', RE 'in front of'

justificationDiscussion: Germanic and Celtic lexemes reflecting a u-stem noun *u̯idʰ-ú- with the zero-grade of the root. For the reconstruction given, see {ref ALEW} s.v. Lith. vidùs, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:585, {ref Matasović 2009}:420.
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *walþu- 'field, uncultivated area, wood', further from a PIE derived stem *uólH-tu- ({ref Kluge 2011}:968, {ref Kroonen 2013}:571-572).
No etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:626, {ref de Vaan 2008}:564).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:500). For Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:657, no. 11258.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: = Skt. KĀŠṬHA 'wood, timber' (Turner 1931: 85), see e.g. 'dig' in /cognate/986/

justificationDiscussion: This lexeme is derived from PS *šum- and has an onomatopoeic origin. Therefore, further IE cognates are uncertain.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:247, {ref Orel 2003}:264). {ref Kroonen 2013}:358 suggests a comparison with Ru. motýl' 'maggot'.
Of uncertain etymology, it is doubtful that the lexemes may be derived from Latin cossus 'a kind of larva' as previously supposed ({ref DCECH} III:287-290, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:211).
According to {ref Adams 2013}:548, to be derived from PIE 2.*u̯el- 'spin, roll' ({ref LIV²} 675).
The root is ideophonic. Any further etymology (as *(s)kreb-, cf. {ref ESSJa}) is speculative.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8393

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain. Traditionally considered a derivative of a root *terp-, an extended form of the root *ter- 'to bore' exclusive to Balto-Slavic ({ref IEW} 1078, {ref Karulis 1992} II:376), but cf. {ref LIV²} 632-633 now reconstructing *terh₁- for the assumed base root.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: either fr. Lat. BESTIA 'animal' or fr. the Germanic root of 'to bite' /cognate/187/ (Diez prefers the latter, 1864: 77)

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:410-411 for various proposals.

notes: Baltic goes back to *met-
justificationDiscussion: IE root identification uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 641-643, {ref Derksen 2015}:307, 314 for further discussion.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1135, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 164f.

justificationDiscussion: Original sense 'female breast' derived from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'to suckle' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:875-877).
Romance lexemes continuing Latin pilus 'hair' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:538 no. 6508), further etymological connections uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:507, {ref de Vaan 2008}:465).

notes: outside connections?Looks a bit like German un(d), loanword?
Perhaps with Slavic *mězga 'sap'?
justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain. Cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:601 making comparisons to roots in Pokorny {ref IEW} 697, 968.

Lexemes continuing Proto(-Insular)-Celtic *bā- 'to die' (cf. OIr. baïd 'die'), further derived from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ({ref LIV²} 205, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:1, {ref Schumacher 2004}:214-216, {ref Matasović 2009}:52, 59).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13036 s.v. Sanskrit saṃsāra- m. 'undergoing transmigration', 'secular life, the world', from sar-

justificationDiscussion: Tocharian lexemes generally derived from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew' ({ref LIV²} 168, {ref Malzahn 2010}:922-924, {ref Adams 2013}:691-692).
Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:153-155 for various proposals.

Hittite āššu-/āššau̯- 'good' is generally connected to Ancient Greek ἐΰς 'good, brave, noble' and Ved. sú- 'good' < *h₁su-, but the details of the inner-Anatolian stem formation is still debated ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:223-225).

To be related to Tocharian A motarts- (a colour term) but it is not possible to reconcile these two forms to a common Proto-Tocharian stem. Outside Tocharian some Slavic and Germanic comparanda are possible but remain uncertain (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:511-512 for further discussion).
Romance lexemes from Latin pantex 'belly, paunch' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:510), no further etymology (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:479-480).
Loan from Sanskrit pr̥thivī́- 'earth'.

Romance lexemes derived from Latin glācies 'ice' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:322); Latin glaciēs 'ice' and Romance descendants superficially appear to be related to *⁽g̑⁾el- but it is difficult to establish a clear etymological relationship (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:275, {ref de Vaan 2008}:263 for further discussion).

Romance lexemes from Latin testa '(pot)sherd, shell' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:719-720, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/1:272-283). For the semantic development, cf. similarly within Germanic: NHG Kopf 'head' < MHG kopf 'drinking vessel; skull' in /cognate/3857/. Latin testa 'earthenware vessel, potsherd' is may very well be a prehistoric loanword as suggested by {ref de Vaan 2008}:617, but this hypothesis remains conjectural as there is no known candidate for a source lexeme.

A derivative from Latin marcere 'be withered' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:436), perhaps further to PIE *merk- if related to Vedic √marc- 'damage, hurt' and Hittite markii̯e/a- 'to disapprove of, refuse' (so {ref de Vaan 2008}:364-365), but cf. {ref EWAia} II:323-324, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:559).

notes: Loan from Middle High German

justificationDiscussion: Romance forms based on the past passive participle of Latin balneāre 'to bathe' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:74-75), a nominal verb from Latin balneum 'bath, place for bathing', an old loanword from Ancient Greek βαλανεῖον 'id.' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:65, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:195).

Ossetic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *čarH- 'to come and go, wander', further to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:303, {ref Cheung 2007}:33-35, {ref EWAia} I:534-535, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'round' in /cognate/4906/, 'navel' in /cognate/7117/, 'yesterday' in /cognate/6487/, 'walk' in /cognate/1626/, 'turn' in /cognate/5879/.

justificationDiscussion: Similar to Indic *kutta- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Indic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also {ref ESIJa} IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:389 for similar Romance lexemes in the same meaning).

Ossetic lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *pa(s)nu-ka-, cf. Av. pąsnu, Ved. pāṃsu- 'soil, dust, sand' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:449), further probably to PIE ?*pē(n)s- ({ref EIEC} 499, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:114-115).
Adjective derived from Old Irish don 'misfortune', further etymology obscure ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:169).
Denominal formation to Proto-Indo-Iranic *nā̆kʰ-a- '(finger)nail' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:222, cf. {ref EWAia} II:4-5). For further etymological discussion cf. /cognate/2268/.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'claw' in /cognate/5097/, 'foot' in /cognate/1252/, 'leg' in /cognate/1231/, 'nail' in /cognate/2268/, 'thigh' in /cognate/7424/.

justificationDiscussion: To be connected with Avestan gaδā-, Old Indic gadā- 'club', but no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:281-282, {ref EWAia} I:460).
Etymology uncertain, perhaps a compound arf 'deep' + tæn 'groin' according to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:70 (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *čāt⁽ʰ⁾- ({ref ESIJa} II:252-253, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:285), on the connection of Khowar čhat to this class, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1936}:660.

According to {ref Cheung 2007}:32-33, from Proto-Iranic *čap- 'to seize, attach, stick, strike'. Further etymology uncertain, {ref Cheung 2007}:33 further speculates a possible connection to PIE *keh₂p- 'to seize, grasp' as semantically attractive; cf. also {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:306-307).

Ossetic lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *u̯i-tarta-, a verbal adjective to PIE *terh₂- 'to go through, cross over' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:344, {ref Cheung 2007}:382, cf. {ref EWAia} I:629-632, {ref LIV²} 633-634).

Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' ({ref EWAia} I:394-395, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:569, {ref Matasović 2009}:181-182). Perhaps connected to PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'worm' (cf. /cognate/172/ for further discussion).

Etymology uncertain. According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:148, to be connected to lexemes from PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, chop' in /cognate/697/; {ref Cheung 2007}:442 hesitates between etymologies to either Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh' or Proto-Iranic *xa(m)p/b- 'to dismount, descend, move away'.
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc. ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:619).

Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *bānu-, connected with Vedic bhānú- 'light, beam' and ultimately derivatives from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to sparkle, to shine' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:265-266, {ref ESIJa} 2:157-158, {ref EWAia} II:259-261, cf. {ref LIV²} 68-69, {ref NIL} 7-11).
Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE stem *pitu- ~ *pei̯tu- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:130 s.v. Vedic pitú- 'food, solid food).

Light verb construction with Ossetic cwan | cawæn 'hunt, chase' as the semantic head, from Iranic *či̯āu̯ana- from *√či̯au̯- 'to move, go', further to PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:318, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:40-42, {ref EWAia} I:552-553, {ref LIV²} 394-395).
Etymology uncertain, either an onomatopoeic formation or an East Caucasian loanword (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:620).
Exact origin uncertain, probably a Wanderwort (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:588).
loan_notes: Cf. Hungarian keszeg 'leuciscus; bream', Khanty kaśeu, Mansi kǟsen 'bream', Georgian kašaqi 'herring'

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Turkic, cf. Turkish dengiz 'sea' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:362).
loan_notes: Cf. Turk. dengiz 'sea'. To judge from the distance between the Pamirs and the Caucasus, probably an independent loan event from Sarikoli in /cognate/9655/

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: < Proto-Indo-Iranian *čárman- n. 'hide, skin, leather', cf. Early Vedic cárman- n. 'hide, skin' (RV), etc; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 255, no. 4701, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 537; cf. /cognate/5086/; please check Ossetic

justificationDiscussion: Either a loanword from West Caucasian or a nursery word (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:362).
loan_notes: Cf. Kabardian dedī, Svan dadil Lak tuti Tsakhur tet

justificationDiscussion: Compared by {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:183-184 to the root of Avestan saef- / sif- 'carry out a sliding, sweeping movement', no certain etymology outside of Iranic, sometimes compared to Vedic śíphā- (name of a river) but the connection remains uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:327-328, {ref EWAia} II:637).
Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *uz-maisa-, a derivative to PIE *mei̯k̑- 'to mix' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:281-282, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:261, {ref LIV²} 428-429).
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc. ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:619).

A preverbal derivative of Ossetic cæwyn | cæun 'to go', from Proto-Iranic *či̯au̯- 'to move, go', and ultimately from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:307-308, {ref Cheung 2007}:40-42, {ref EWAia} I:552-553, {ref LIV²} 394-395).
Loanword from South or East Caucasian ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:376)
According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:280, continuing Proto-Iranic *uz-tak-, where the root *tak- ultimately continues PIE 2. *tek- 'to weave, plait' (cf. {ref LIV²} 619-620).

According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:37-39, the Ossetic lexemes in this class continue an East Iranic root *rap- also found in Pamir languages (cf. Ormuri we-raf-s-, Shughni wi-ruv-d-). [Not in {ref Cheung 2007}].
Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:304, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:467 for older hypotheses).

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Indo-Iranic *(H)nār-, probably to be further to a root *(h₁)ner- on the basis of the comparison to Ancient Greek νέρθεν, ἔνερθεν 'from below', cf. also Sabellic 'left' in /cognate/3315/. Cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:156-157, {ref EWAia} II:37 for further discussion.

Indo-Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' ({ref LIV²} 394-395, cf. {ref EWAia} I:552-553, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:269 no. 4939, {ref Cheung 2007}:40-42, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:307-308).
Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *taxma-, cf. Avestan taxma- 'mighty', Old Persian taxma- 'id.' (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:306).
Etymology unclear; {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:114 suggests some bird names, e.g. Persian šīšū, šīšak 'a kind of partridge' as potential cognates (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).

Etymology uncertain, {ref Abaev 1959–1995}:18-19 suggests from Proto-Iranic *laštyaka- in comparison to Lithuanian lazdà 'stick' but without further parallels within Iranic; alternatively possibly an old loanword from Armenian lcʼakʼ 'lever' (Oleg Belyaev p.c.).
Derivatives of Proto-Iranic *tač- 'to flow, run, walk', further to PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, flow' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:286-287, {ref Cheung 2007}:373-374, {ref EWAia} I:610-611, {ref LIV²} 620-621).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'come' in /cognate/15/, 'run' in /cognate/5199/, 'river' in /cognate/5249/ 'swell' in /cognate/1881/, 'turn' in /cognate/3066/.

justificationDiscussion: According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:14-15, from Proto-Iranic *nas- 'to take' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:183-184 s.v. *Hnas- 'to reach, attain, take'), if so further to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, obtain' (cf. {ref LIV²} 282-284).

Ossetic lexemes continuing a lexicalised participle of Iron kærdyn, Digoron kærdun 'to cut', continuing Proto-Iranic *kart- 'to cut', and further to PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:582-583, I:584, Oleg Belyaev (p.c.), {ref Cheung 2007}:243-244, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560).

notes: on words ending in °x: Bailey (1979: 111a) assumes a -xa- suffix for this word. Klingenschmitt (2000: 203) calles this "Suffixtausch" of *-xa- and *-ka-.

justificationDiscussion: Ossetic lexemes probably continuing derivatives of a Proto-Iranic root *zag-, without certain etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:460, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:292-293).
Loanword from Slavic *o-met- 'swept snow; snowdrift' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:124).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. also {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:528).
Without certain etymology (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:276-277).
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Chechen kujg 'hand' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:644).
Of uncertain origin, perhaps an East Caucasian loanword? (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:383).
Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *tau̯ká- 'progeny, children', further etymology uncertain (cf.  {ref EWAia} I:670, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:309-310).
Probably loans from East Caucasian, cf. Lezgian rug 'dust', Tabasaran rug 'earth' (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.). {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:443-444 suggests Iranic *ru-ka- but gives no Iranic cognates.
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:319-320).

According to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:254 a derivative of Proto-Iranic *barz- 'high', cf. Av. bərəzant-, Ved. br̥hant- 'tall' etc., further to PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'to become tall; raise oneself' (cf. {ref LIV²} 78-79, {ref NIL} 30).
Parallel loans from Arabic آدَم / ādam 'human, person'.

notes: Loan from East Caucasian
justificationDiscussion: Loanword from East Caucasian ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:333-334).

notes: Loan from East Caucasian
justificationDiscussion: No clear connection to the inherited Iranic or Indo-European words for salt, probably a loan from East Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:310-311).
No certain etymology outside of Ossetic ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:507).

Cf. Old Lithuanian paũta 'egg, testicle', considered a vr̥ddhi-derivative to the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird' *put- (cf. 'bird' in /cognate/1109), but further etymology uncertain ({ref ALEW} 745-746).
Continuing PIE *h₂ek̑-mon- 'stone; sky', a derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:95-96, {ref EWAia} I:137-138).

{ref Matasović 2009}:118-119 connects to Balto-Slavic lexemes (OCS iskra 'spark', Lith. áiškus 'bright') via PIE *h₁ei̯sk-, however the etymology of these proposed Balto-Slavic cognates are disputed (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:214, {ref Derksen 2015}:45 connecting instead to *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'kindle' assuming a connection with OIc. eiskra 'rage with heated excitement; {ref ALEW} 24 assuming no clear cognates outside of Balto-Slavic). Consequently only a Proto-Celtic root ref. form has been given for this cognate set.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *tungla- 'star, celestial body(?)', further connections outside Germanic uncertain ({ref Lehmann 1986}:348, {ref Kroonen 2013}:526).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kъnęgъ 'ruler, duke, regent', a loan from Germanic *kuningaz 'king' ({ref Boryś 2005}:268-269, {ref Polański 1962-1994}:876-878).

Possibly cognate with Tocharian B yolo 'bad', Gk. ὀδύνη, Arm. erkn, OIr. idu (cf. {ref Schindler 1975}, {ref Watkins 1982}, {ref Adams 2013}:555-556), but these connections are uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:420-422, and more recently specifically regarding the Tocharian lexemes {ref Peyrot 2016} and further discussion in /cognate/7558/).
Indo-European root etymology uncertain (see note by Irslinger to this class); cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:442-443, {ref de Vaan 2008}:359, {ref NIL} 476n33 for competing proposals.
Lexemes from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:411-413).

Generally assumed to be connected with Proto-Germanic *sehwan- 'see' (cf. /cognate/288/) from PIE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' ({ref LIV²} 525-526), cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:704-706 (rejected, however, by {ref HED SA}:50-57 on the grounds that the etymology contravenes Sturtevant's Rule).
Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain, perhaps to the root *meh₁- 'to measure', but  ultimately unclear. Cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:571-572, {ref HED M} 116-119 for further discussion.
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₁u̯és-u- ({ref EWAia} II:533-534, {ref Starke 1990}:352-353).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:267-268, cf. {ref Melchert 1993a}:45).
Sabellic lexemes continuing a comparative formation derived to PIE *(h₁)ner- ({ref Untermann 2000}:492-493, Scarborough, p.c.).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ned⁽ʰ⁾- 'to link, connect' ({ref Untermann 2000}:493-494, {ref Falileyev 2000}:119).
Extra-Tocharian connections are uncertain (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:504-505 for various suggestions).
Lexemes continuing PIE *skabʰ- 'to scratch, to scrape' ({ref LIV²} 549, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:541, {ref Kroonen 2013}:438).

Hittite and Luvian adjectives derived from an a commonly inherited adjective identical with Hittite *maninkuu̯a- (adj.) 'near' (cf. {ref CHD L-N} 170-174). Further etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:554 for further discussion. For the purposes of an IE-CoR reference form, the reconstructed adjective on which the Hittite family of derived vocabulary is based has been given in lieu of reconstructing a Proto-Anatolian derived adjective. For the reconstructed stem of the adjective, cf. {ref CHD L-N} 170. See also 'near' in /cognate/5401/.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:484, {ref Orel 2003}:333 for a tenuous proposal to Av. kamna- 'few, little'. No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.

notes: cf. OCS loza 'vine'

justificationDiscussion: No clear etymology outside of Italic, possibly a loanword from an unknown Mediterranean source (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:340-341, {ref de Vaan 2008}:326).
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:515-516, cf. also {ref HED L}:40-44).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:267-268), cf. {ref Melchert 1993a}:45).
Loanword from Hattic eštan-, aštan- 'sun(god)' ({ref Tischler 1983}:428-430, {ref HED A+E/I}:465-468, cf. {ref Laroche 1947}).
Generally derived from a basic PIE root *bʰel- 'to blow, swell' ({ref Olsen 1999}:525, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:178-179).
Loan from Syriac, cf. Classical Armenian hašiw < Syriac ḥəšīḇ, 'considered, calculated' ({ref HAB} III:43, {ref Olsen 1999}:932). [MM: Proto-Armenian *haʃiu̯-].
From Classical Armenian gawazan 'rod, stave', a loanword from Iranic *gavāzan- 'oxgoad' ({ref Olsen 1999}:872, {ref HAB} I:525-526). [MM: Proto-Armenian *gau̯azan-a-].

Apparently related to tʿacʿ- the aorist stem of Classical Armenian tʿanam 'to (become) wet, to moisten, drench' (cf. {ref HAB} II:150-151), further to PIE *teh₂- 'to thaw, melt' ({ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:113-114, {ref LIV²} 616).

Origin uncertain, traditionally connected with PIE *peh₂u̯- 'few; little', but the connection is phonetically difficult to justify (cf. discussion in {ref Olsen 1999}:165). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰokʰ-u-(r)].
Of uncertain origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:942, cf. {ref HAB} IV:519). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰor-o-/-i-].

Denominal to Classical Armenian tʿiw 'number'. Further origins uncertain; either to be connected with Sanskrit tavá- 'strong, powerful' to a root *teu̯h₁- (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:23) or a borrowing from Hurro-Urartian, cf. Hurrian tiw- 'to say, speak', tiwə 'word; deed', (cf. {ref Diakonoff 1985}:599). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʰiu̯-].
Armenian lexemes probably to be derived from PIE *sengʷ- 'to go under, sink' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:90-91, {ref LIV²} 531-532).
Loanword from Iranic, cf. MPers clp 'mild, gentle; fatty, oily', MParth. crb 'smooth, mild' ({ref Olsen 1999}:893, {ref HAB} III:192. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃarp-o-].
loan_notes: Cf. MPers clp 'mild, gentle; fatty, oily', MParth crb 'smooth, mild'

notes: Origin uncertain.
justificationDiscussion: From Classical Armenian kṙowim 'to fight', denominative to kṙiw 'fight'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:16, cf. {ref HAB} II:670-671, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:431 for various proposals). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010} [MM: Proto-Armenian *kiṙiu̯-].

Etymology uncertain. Perhaps to be connected to Armenian cał- 'laugh' (< PIE *g̑elh₂-) 'to laugh' on the basis of the Hesychius gloss γελεῖν· λάμπειν, ἀνθεῖν 'shine, bloom', but this is uncertain (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:128, {ref Olsen 1999}:459, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:336 for further discussion). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsał-ik(-u/an)-].

Uncertain origin. Possibly an Iranian loanword (perhaps) via (inner-Armenian) *ba(δ)r-ii̯o/a- (cf. Skt. bhadrá- 'blessed, fortunate; happy; Av. hu-baδra- 'extremely happy'); cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:436. Cf. {ref HAB} I:422-424. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *bar-i̯o-].

Etymology uncertain. Formerly compared with Hittite karawar 'horn', Tocharian A kror, Tocharian B (oblique stem) krorīyai 'crescent, horn of the moon' via PIE *gʰréh₁u̯r̥ (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:155, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:182), but these proposed cognates may also be derived from PIE *k̑er- (cf. /cognate/2457/). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)łdʒ-iu̯r-].

loan_notes: loan from a Middle Iranian cognate of Sanskrit bahu-

justificationDiscussion: From PIE *seh₁dʰ-i̯o-, a derivative of PIE *seh₁dʰ- 'to reach the goal, be successful' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:99-100, {ref Olsen 1999}:186, cf. {ref EWAia} II:722-723, {ref LIV²} 517).

Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:943, cf. {ref HAB} II:468). Sometimes considered a loanword from Urartian ṣûə 'inland sea' ({ref Diakonoff 1985}:600), but the Urartian word could just as well be a loan from Armenian (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:140-141). With {ref Kölligan 2019}, cov could be an original epithet *di̯eu̯-o-bʰh₂u- meaning 'sky blue'. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsou̯-u-].

Etymology uncertain. Possibly a blend of PIE *spek̑- & *derk̑- (cf. {ref Meillet 1936}:135, {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:228, {ref Clackson 2017}:105-106); alternatively backformed to a root aorist etes < *dek̑-/dk̑- (cf. {ref Schmitt 1981}:146, {ref LIV²} 109-112).
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:471-472, {ref HAB} II:62-64, {ref Clackson 2017}:110 for further discussion. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)rkin-i-].
Origin uncertain according to {ref Olsen 1999}:942, a loanword from Caucasian according to {ref HAB} II:470-471. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsux-o-].

notes: Uncertain etymology.
justificationDiscussion: From Classical Armenian kangnem 'to raise, lift up; get up, rise again', further root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:607, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:381 for various proposals. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kang-(u)n-].
To be derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ({ref Olsen 1999}:62, see which for a discussion of the possible stem formations in Armenian; cf. also {ref HAB} I:452, {ref LIV²} 80).
It is difficult to decide whether the Armenian forms continue PIE *nedih₂- or reflects *nēdih₂- ({ref Olsen 1999}:84), cf. also {ref Martirosyan 2010}:502-503 who reconstructs *ned-o-.

notes: Uncertain origin. Formerly connected with Goth. dags 'day', Skt. dáhati 'burns', LIth. dagà 'heat of the Sun', etc; the latter, however, go back to PIE *dʰegʷʰ-, which is incompatible with the Armenian development.
justificationDiscussion: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian takʿ 'warm, hot'. Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:391). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, {ref Olsen 1999}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *takʰ-i-].

Armenian lexemes generally connected to the family of Greek θάλλω 'to bloom, flourish, grow' ({ref Clackson 1994}:118-120, {ref Olsen 1999}:51, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:231-232, 237-238). The PIE root reconstruction *dʰalh₁- for this class follows {ref LIV²} 132.

Iranic lexemes, often assumed to be connected with Vedic śákhā- 'limb, branch', although the correspondence of the word-initial sibilants is inexact. Only a reconstructed Proto-Iranic root reference form has therefore been given here, but cf. {ref KEWA} III:321-322, {ref EWAia} II:628 with further discussion.

Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'be(come) tall, raise oneself' ({ref Adams 2013}:399-400, {ref EWAia} II:232, {ref Bailey 1979}:299, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:8, cf. {ref LIV²} 78-79, {ref NIL} 30).

Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Beekes 2010}:848-849), perhaps to PIE *lep- ({ref LIV²} 413; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:630-632 for older, uncertain proposals to Baltic lexemes in /cognate/5979/.

Iranic lexemes as though from PIE *k̑r-uH- to the same root *k̑er- underlying various derived lexemes in the meaning 'horn' ({ref EWAia} II:653, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:285, cf. 'horn' in /cognate/2457/ for further etymological discussion).

Albanian lexemes to be compared with OHG questa 'tuft', Serbian gvȍzd 'forest' and derived from PIE *gu̯osd(o)- ({ref Jokl 1912}:204, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:69, {ref Demiraj 1997}:187-188, {ref Orel 1998}:133-134, {ref Holm 2011}:69).
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑rei̯H- 'to excel, be excellent' ({ref Bailey 1979}:400-401, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:98, {ref EWAia} II:665-666, II:669-670, cf. {ref LIV²} 337).

Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯š- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Vedic √ghoṣ- 'to sound'), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ({ref Cheung 2007}:115-116, {ref EWAia} I:518-519; {ref LIV²} 200 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s-).
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *sp⁽ʰ⁾erh₂g- 'to hiss, crackle'(?) (cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:315, {ref Cheung 2007}:198, {ref LIV²} 586).

notes: Could skarəna- be derived from *kʷelh₁-? *s-kr̩H-na- > skarna-
justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology. {ref Bartholomae 1899}:199 proposed a preform *skʰr̥̄na- as a na-participle to a putative Indo-Iranic root *skʰr̥̄-, and suggested a root-etymology to Ancient Greek σφαῖρα 'ball' (repeated in {ref Bartholomae 1904}:1587). This would require the reconstruction of a phoneme *kʷʰ to account for Av. -k- = Gk. -φ-, but such a phoneme is no longer posited for Proto-Indo-European.
No certain etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Matasović 2009}:385). For older proposals, cf. {ref IEW} 1024.
Loanword from Arabic قلب / qalb 'heart'.
Parallel loans from Old Turkic arqa.

notes: "to darken, make dark, stain"; consider Turkic kül "ashes", but it is not clear whether Turkic #k can be rendered by Iranic #x (maybe via *q). Kurdish ɫ / ḷ point however to *rd/rz (if not secondary), which would make a derivation from *xwṛta- "consumed" possible. However, the Kurdish vowels point to a historically long vowel (if not loan). Cf. Classic New Persian xwāl "soot (for the production of ink)" < xwārϑa- "substance for colouring" (taken from Rastorgueva/Edelman 2007: 481, Etymological Dictionary of Iranian languages, hu̯ar- „smear“). Note, however, LIV p.609 *su̯el- "schwelen, brennen", which would be equally good.
lit. "to make wind"
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes in light verb constructions, literally 'to make wind'. Cf. {ref EWAia} II:542 and 'wind' in /cognate/342/ for further etymological discussion.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/1662/, 'sun' in /cognate/5156/, 'wind' in /cognate/342/, perhaps also 'wind' in /cognate/9440/.

justificationDiscussion: A participle to the Ossetic verb xīlyn | xelun 'to crawl'. Further connected to Sanskrit khelati by {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:201, but the etymology of the compared Sanskrit verb is difficult to ascertain (cf. {ref KEWA} I:312 and cross-references). Ossetic xīlyn | xelun is not listed in {ref Cheung 2007}.

notes: unclear why Parthian bāšēd is sorted into this set (TJ)
basic meaning "radiant, shiny" etc.
Loan from Turkish

justificationDiscussion: No convincing etymology has been proposed. According to {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:228 from Proto-Iranic *fra-vārači- > *rworč > lworč (with dissimilation), but this is phonologically ad-hoc and semantically unsupported.

Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *hu̯ad- 'to become, make savoury, pleasant', further to PIE *su̯eh₂d- 'to make/become tasty' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:494-495, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:141, {ref EWAia} II:788-789, {ref NIL} 670-675, {ref LIV²} 606-607).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₃erg- ({ref LIV²} 301, {ref Matasović 2009}:300), formerly reconstructed as *perg- ({ref IEW} 819, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:30).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *kʷis-e/o- 'to see', a derivative of PIE *kʷei̯s- 'to perceive' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:431-434, {ref Matasović 2009}:180, {ref LIV²} 381-382).

notes: cf. *kauč- “to bend, draw into, contract”, which is possibly reflected in Abyānei köta/kuǰ- “to gnaw” (Cheung 2007: 249)

loan_notes: parallel loan from Turkic or single loan into Persian first?

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *steh₂- 'to stand', cf. Vedic stā́na- 'place for standing' ({ref EWAia} II:764-766, cf. {ref LIV²} 590-592).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: Generally connected to Lith. vir̃bas 'twig, rod', Rus. верба (OCS връба) 'willow' from a zero-grade fromation *u̯r̥b-, and Lat. uerbera '(rods for) punishment', uerbēnae 'twigs of the laurel' from the full-grade *u̯erb- ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:636-637, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:964), but {ref Beekes 2010}:1269-1270 is inclined to believe the word is of substratum origin.
Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take', further from PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ({ref Cheung 2007}:119-121, cf. {ref EWAia} I:505-507, {ref LIV²} 201).

notes: denominal word, cf. poh "aware, intelligent"
justificationDiscussion: Denominal verb based on Pashto poh 'aware, intelligent', a loanword from Lahnda *poh- which in turn continues Old Indic prabodha- 'awakening, knowledge' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:491, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:491 no. 8699).
Loanword from Turkish čök 'knee' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:242-243).
Anatolian, Hellenic, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref LIV²} 218-219, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:485-486, {ref EWAia} II:800-801, {ref Cheung 2007}:224-225).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'cut' in /cognate/6606/, 'hit' in /cognate/1998/, 'throw' in /cognate/8806/, 'hunt' in /cognate/1298/, 'tail' in /cognate/1935/, 'run' in /cognate/5193/.

justificationDiscussion: Adjective derived from the common Iranic word for 'stone, rock', cf. Old Persian aϑanga-, Avestan asan- 'stone' in /cognate/1179/.

Cf. Vedic parṣá- 'sheaf, bundle', Young Avestan parša- ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:75), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:101, cf. {ref KEWA} II:230 for various uncertain proposals).

Etymology unclear. A loan from the likes of Kalasha ṣäŋgřuři and Khowar šaŋgur 'guts' appears most probable. The Kalasha/Khowar forms, in turn, are etymologically unclear, being tentatively derived from *śrāna- 'cooked food; moist' by {ref Morgenstierne 1973a}: 144.

notes: Buck (1949: 1176f.) derives this word from "*noi-bho- from the root seen in Ir[ish] niam ‘brilliance’, Lat. nitēre ‘shine, glitter’.” For the inner-Iranic development with extension nai̯u̯aka- and accent shift see Klingenschmitt (2000: 212f.).
If related to Shughni bāf 'to be possible' and Tajik bob 'suitable' and assuming the etymology *upa-afya- ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}: 18) is correct, this must be a loanword on phonological grounds.
justificationDiscussion: Of expressive origin (cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:91 for further discussion).

This is obviously a complex predicate with an element 'war' + light verb "to do". 'war' could mean "there" (< *awáϑra) and 'kawǝl' in the sense of "put" (cf. German 'hineintun' : "to put in"). Cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:89 and {ref Cheung 2007}:238 s.v. Proto-Iranic *kar- 'to do, make' > Pashto kawəl (< PIE *kʷer- 'to do, make').

notes: probably derived from verb "bar" : "to carry"
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes probably to be derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry', as though via Proto-Iranic *baraka- ({ref ESIJa} 2:100, cf. {ref Henning 1971}:33-34, {ref Benzing 1983}:201).
Traditionally with PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' according to {ref IEW} 855, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:398-399, {ref LIV²} 304-305).
Presumably an early loanword from Persian rušnāyī 'light, fire' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:304, {ref Morgenstierne 1938}:466).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Identical with cognate/3551 in 'KILL' and cognate/1998 in 'HIT'

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes from Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive', further to PIE *u̯eg̑- 'to ride, drive' ({ref Cheung 2007}:429-432, cf. {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref LIV²} 661-662).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'carry' in /cognate/7547/, 'drink' in /cognate/1955/, 'fly_pst3sg' in /cognate/1993/, 'house' in /cognate/5142/, 'run' in /cognate/6778/, 'swim' in /cognate/7464/.

notes: Klingenschmitt (2000: 214 fn. 81) "ai. upāké 'in der Nähe'"
derivation of verbal root *dai̯H "to see" of cognate set 2012

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Arabic أرض / ˀarḍ ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:50-51)
Indo-Iranic lexemes probably continuing PIE ?*pē(n)s- ({ref EIEC} 499, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:114-115).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'to consume, eat', further connections uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:147-150, cf. {ref LIV²} 609).
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *HraiH- 'to defecate', further to PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to stream, flow' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:188, {ref LIV²} 305-306).
No Indo-European etymology or loan source has been proposed.
Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *mai̯θā-, cf. Avestan maēθā- 'change, evolution' ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:45-46, {ref MacKenzie 1990}:116).

notes: Mayrhofer (EWAia I 240) assume a relation with OInd. ū́dhan- "coldness".
justificationDiscussion: A connection with Vedic ū́dhan- 'coldness' is assumed by {ref EWAia} I:240, but further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain unclear.
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ({ref Cheung 2007}:55-56, {ref EWAia} I:775, cf. {ref LIV²} 153).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/2567/, 'neck' in /cognate/9538/, 'nose' in /cognate/9218/, 'swell' in /cognate/9032/, 'rain' in /cognate/8821/, 'wind' in /cognate/3113/.

notes: original meaning "to sharpen" via "peak" > "breast, chest"
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Iranic *sainaka- (cf. Avestan saēni- 'top, peak'), ultimately derivatives from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' via an intermediate sense 'peak; protuberance, top part' ({ref Korn 2005}:384, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:199-200, {ref EWAia} II:627, cf. {ref LIV²} 319-320).
Of uncertain etymology ({ref EWAia} I:487-488).
Iranic lexemes probably reflecting derivatives from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm, stiff' ({ref Bailey 1979}:229-230, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:250-251, {ref EWAia} II:116, cf. {ref LIV²} 461).

Kurdish lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *raxša- ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010) II:193-194), further connected to Proto-Indo-Iranic *raktá- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, Iranic *ra(n)ǰ- ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:424-425, {ref Cheung 2007}:313-314).

notes: The q-forms make a loan from Turkic likely (cf. kapmak 'to snatch'). Abaev (apud Cabolov) suggestes an onomatopoetic formation and Vasmer (apud Cabolov) noted Slavic verbs like Ukrainian хапати 'to grab, snatch' considering them a continuation of a PIE root *khap-. On this see also Cheung (2007: 234f.) *kop-.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology unclear. Inheritance of an Indo-European root *kap- (mechanically reconstructed to *keh₂p- in LIV with reflexes principally in Greek, Latin and Germanic) or a tentative Iranic-Slavic *kʰap- has been proposed, but the role of sound-symbolism cannot be securely addressed. Some of the forms in q- are most probably loans from Persian. Loans from Turkic are also assumed, but Edel'man considers the resemblance coincidental as many of the languages in question have no historic contacts with Turkic languages. A very early Turkic loan seems chronologically implausible.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:47 for further discussion. For proposed connections to Wakhi lup and Indic and Nurstani lexemes, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:227.
No etymology given in Morgenstierne (1974:48); onomatopoeic according to {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:227. Possible comparanda given by {ref ESIJa}: V: 74.

notes: Cf. Semitic *lib-/lub- "heart"; *lap "spleen, liver, heart"
Loan from Arabic (via Tajik?).

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic *āpula- 'abundant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:55, no. 1211), cf. Vedic vipula- 'extended, wide'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:557-558).

notes: 'dad'
Past. Part. used as adjective 'good'

justificationDiscussion: Internal reconstruction points to a root *tu̯eh₂p-, *ti̯eh₂p- or *⁽k̑⁾i̯eh₂p- ({ref LIV²} 361 reconstructs *Ki̯eh₂p-), but no cognates are known outside of Greek ({ref Beekes 2010}:1324).

Iranic lexemes denoting 'worm', possibly from Proto-Indo-European *per- 'pierce, pass through', a derivation paralleled by Ancient Greek τερηδών 'boring worm' from *terh₁- 'bore, rub', cf. {ref Bailey 1979}: 239. Another possibility would be a connection with Indo-Iranic lexemes meaning 'flea, noxious insect', Vedic plúṣi, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 267 for further references.
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original athematic root-present to PIE *ses- 'to sleep' ({ref LIV²} 536-537, {ref EWAia} II:716-717, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:746-747).

Indo-European root etymology disputed. Either to *deh₂u̯- in /cognate/8388/ (so {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:8-9, {ref Schrijver 1995}:316), or *dʰegʷʰ- in /cognate/368/ (tentatively {ref LIV²} 133-134). {ref Matasović 2009}:92-93 gives both etymologies under different lemmata. Cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:180.

Generally derived from PIE *h₁ep- 'grasp, seize' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:79, {ref Orel 1998}:157, {ref Holm 2011}:64, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:978, {ref LIV²} 237); perhaps further connected to Anatolian lexemes in /cognate/7598/ if the etymology of {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:614-616 is correct, but this remains disputed (cf. notes in that class).
Loanword from Latin or Romance floc(cus) ({ref Orel 1998}:100, {ref Holm 2011}:65).
Loanword from Latin coccum 'berry' ({ref Orel 1998}:189, {ref Holm 2011}:65-66).
Root etymology in this class follows {ref LIV²} 402, {ref de Vaan 2008}:350-351 to PIE *lei̯d- 'set in motion'.
Lexemes as though continuing Old Indic latā- 'creeper, vine' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:633 no. 10928). Further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} III:88).
According to {ref Strand 1998} to be connected with Vedic hári- 'golden, yellow' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:809 no. 13981). If so, further to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green'.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'moon' in /cognate/2337/, 'grass' in /cognate/1576/, 'green' in /cognate/6332/, 'white' in /cognate/2411/ 'yellow' in /cognate/7535/.

notes: 'un-seasonable'Strand 1998; g < #VkV
justificationDiscussion: Kâmkata-vari lexemes as if from Sanskrit (MBh.) akāla- 'wrong time, unseasonable' ({ref Strand 1998, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:1 no. 11).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Strand 2011a}.

notes: *pa-bim-sta < IE *bʰuh₂-men-
justificationDiscussion: According to {ref Strand 1998} from *pa-büm-sta- where Kâmviri büm 'earth' < Vedic bhūman- 'earth, world' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:545 no. 9556).

notes: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 785, {ref EWAia}: II:750
loan_notes: 'skeleton, tree'; lack of initial s indicates < IA

justificationDiscussion: Nuristani lexemes for 'woman', continuing compounds containing the word for 'daughter' (cf. Kâmviri ǰʹü 'daughter'), continuing PIE *dʰugh₂ter- 'daughter' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:370 no. 6481, {ref EWAia} I:737-738).

Nuristani lexemes as though from Indic rucaka- 'pleasing, sharp, acid', a derivative of Proto-Indo-Iranic *rau̯k/č- 'to shine' and further to PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:622 no. 10761, {ref EWAia} II:463-464, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'day' in /cognate/691/, 'eye' in /cognate/994/, 'good' in /cognate/1783/, 'moon' in /cognate/2336/, 'star' in /cognate/6295/, 'sun' in /cognate/739/, 'white' in /cognate/2401/.

justificationDiscussion: Continuing derivatives of Indo-Iranic *gʰaná- 'compact, firm, dense', cf. Sanskrit ghaná- 'id.' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:239 no. 4424). Perhaps further to a root *gʷʰen- 'to swell' (tentatively suggested by {ref EWAia} I:184-185, I:512, not in {ref LIV²}).
Etymology uncertain, cf. Ved. dhánu- 'dry land', dhánvan- 'desert'(?) ({ref EWAia} I:774, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:384 no. 6724)

Nuristani lexemes derived from a base *gharasya- 'sun's heat' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:239 no. 4440), ultimately to PIE *gʷer- 'to become warm' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:513, {ref NIL} 196-199, {ref LIV²} 219-220).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'bitter' in /cognate/6086/, 'burn' in /cognate/2243/, 'fire' in /cognate/396/, 'hot' in /cognate/333/, 'sun' in /cognate/2299/.

notes: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:310

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Latin pōmum 'fruit tree; fruit' ({ref Meyer 1891}:326, {ref Orel 1998}:314, {ref Holm 2011}:85-86).

Etymology disputed. Originally proposed a loanword from Latin sequor 'follow' by {ref Meyer 1891}:408 and followed by {ref Holm 2011}:86; alternatively considered since {ref Jokl 1911}:80-82 to be connected with Albanian shteg 'path', cognate with Greek στοῖχος 'row, line' and derived from PIE *stei̯gʰ- (followed by {ref Huld 1984}:114, {ref Orel 1998}:421; cf. {ref LIV²} 593-594, without Albanian). [Not in {ref Demiraj 1997}, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}].

Germanic lexemes continuing an early loan into West Germanic from Latin cūpa, cuppa 'cup, bowl'. For the semantic development, cf. similarly within Romance: Fr. tête 'head' < Lat. testa 'earthenware vessel, tile, sherd, vessel' in /cognate/3171/.
The loan event is taken here as so early that it would have introduced e lexeme into a very early form of Continental West Germanic, before these three lineages (standard German , Luxembourgish and Bernese) diverged from each other, so this is not a parallel loan.  Only these three would then have made the semantic shift to the 'head' meaning, whether in parallel or still at the stage of a later, narrower common ancestor of theirs.  That this shift is not yet recorded in our Middle High German list, however, supports the idea of parallel semantic shift, but after an original non-parallel loan to enter the Germanic lexicon (with an originally different meaning).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:120-121).

Negative compound as though from Sanskrit na- 'not' + rāma- 'good, pleasant', cf. RV su-rā́ma- ({ref Turner 1931}:536, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:615, no. 10636). Further to Skt. √ram- from PIE *h₁rem- 'become calm' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:435-436).

notes: Loan from West Caucasian
Loan from Sanskrit, cf. Vedic nā́raka-/nāraká-, Pali naraka-
Not in Turner 1962–1966; possibly related to Skt. vana- 'tree; timber' (Turner no. 11258)?

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:46-47, {ref Demiraj 1997}:113-114, {ref Orel 1998}:42-43, {ref Holm 2011}:70-71 for various suggestions and discussion.
Loanword, but precise source uncertain. Either from Romance rombulus or from Greek ῥύμβος.

Generally connected with PIE *h₃bʰreu̯H- 'eyebrow' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:67, {ref Holm 2011}:67), cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:48, {ref Orel 1998}:36-37 for a more tenuous comparison to a Messapic gloss in Hesychius and the Etymologicum Magnum.

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *cappayati 'chews', imitative of the sound of chewing ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:253, no.4675). Cf. cf. Pāli capucapukāra- ʻmaking the sound of chewing'. No further etymology outside of Indic

From Sanskrit śoṇita- 'blood' created to Vedic śóṇa- 'red, crimson; purple' with the suffix -ita- on analogy to Sanskrit lohita- 'blood' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:732 no. 12625), further from PIE *k̑óu̯-no- 'shining' ({ref EWAia} II:656-657).

Derived from Indic *kaṇṭa- (3) 'backbone, podex, penis' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:131-132, no. 2670). Perhaps identical with Skt. kaṇṭa- 'thorn' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:131, no. 2668), of uncertain further etymology (cf. {ref KEWA} I:146).
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:275, no. 5014; no further etymology.

notes: IE *pre(h)-, pr(h)- (Beekes)

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Hellenic, and Armenian lexemes from PIE *du̯ei̯- 'to fear, be afraid' ({ref Beekes 2010}:308, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:268). For the inclusion of Luvian k(u)u̯ai̯a- in this class, cf. {ref LIV²} 130.
As though from Sanskrit *baluvā-, cf. Sanskrit baluha- only attested by lexicographers ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:535, no. 9407). Further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} II:483).

Continuing Sanskrit vikala- 'deprived of a part or a limb or a member, mutilated, maimed, crippled, impaired, imperfect'. Probably originally a compound of kalā- 'small part' + vi- 'away from', but further etymology obscure ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:678, no. 11623, {ref EWAia} II:552, I:321-322, {ref KEWA} III:201-202).

notes: Loan from Dravidian

justificationDiscussion: As though from Sanskrit dōla- 'swinging' ({ref Turner 1962–1966} no. 6582). Further etymology less certain, but probably a loanword from an Austroasiatic language (cf. {ref KEWA} II:67 for further discussion).
loan_notes: Cf. Mayrhofer, KEWA for further discussion.

notes: Cf.  Turner 1962–1966 no. 11356 vartáyati 'causes to turn, whirls' RV. > Si. vaṭanavā tr. 'to turn round' (can this be a later semantic shift > 'to fall'???)

justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes from Vedic bhadrá- 'fortunate, delightful' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:533, no. 9377). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps from PIE *bʰend- if connected with Germanic *batiza- 'better', but the comparison is uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:244, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:118-119, {ref LIV²} 75). For Assamese and Bengali, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:535 no. 9408.

Of unknown origin. Traditionally connected with Germanic *buddǭ 'bud, seed-pod' but the comparison is uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} IV:112-113, {ref Olsen 1999}:937, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:552-556 for further discussion). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pi/utuł-o-].

Continuing Sanskrit kāṣāyá- 'brownish red, dyed reddish' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:159 no. 3119), presumably a Vr̥ddhi-formation to Vedic kaṣāyá- 'red, dull red'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:332).

notes: MBh.,cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7788

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: from Vedic pārśvá-, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 100f. s.v. parśu- f. 'rib'; cf. /cognate/1610/

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10924 etc.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: compare /cognate/6727/, probably old substrate loan from unidentified source; cf. also /cognate/3977/

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5574 ?

justificationDiscussion: Derived from Sanskrit valāhaka- m. 'rain-cloud, thunder-cloud', further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:665, no. 11411, {ref KEWA} III:162-163).
The Vedic root √cakṣ- is likely to have been an inner-Indo-Iranic reanalysis of an s-desiderative form of the root *kʷek̑- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:523, {ref LIV²} 383-385).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing PIE *sk̑⁽ʰ⁾ei̯d- 'to split, separate from, tear' ({ref LIV²} 547-548, {ref EWAia} I:561, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:276 no. 5041).

Italic and Celtic lexemes generally assumed to continue earlier *pe⁽k̑⁾tu- 'chest', although the Celtic forms would appear to continue *pu⁽k̑⁾tu- with secondary *-u- vocalism in the lexical root (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:491, {ref de Vaan 2008}:453, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:14-15, {ref Matasović 2009}:130).
Apparently a derivative of Latin cuppa 'cup, bowl' according to {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:223. Further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:158-159, {ref de Vaan 2008}:155).

notes: could this word be related to the verb var „zusammenhalten, einschließen, umhüllen, bedecken“? cf. EWAia II 512 , cf. Sanskrit vará- and derivations like varimán, várivas, all ≈ “Raum, Gebiet”

loan_notes: borrowing < Greek kótsi 'ankle' or Armenian koč 'block

justificationDiscussion: From Old Iranian čakāta- 'front part, forehead'(?), cf. Middle Persian čakāt, Persian čakād 'mountain peak', cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:257-258, {ref ESIJa} II:215-216.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing adjectival derivatives of Vedic pátra- 'wing, feather; leaf' in the sense 'leaflike, thin' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:437 no. 7736). Further to PIE *pet- 'to fall, fly' ({ref EWAia} II:71-72, 75-76, cf. {ref LIV²} 476, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fall' in /cognate/7561/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/1486/, 'feather' in /cognate/7563/, 'leaf' in /cognate/790/, 'river' in /cognate/1525/, 'run' in /cognate/5968/, 'sleep' in /cognate/8796/, 'wing' in /cognate/1567/

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1324, s.v. āruddha- 'blocked', ppp. of ā́ruṇaddhi RV, rudh- 'grow'

justificationDiscussion: Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *bando- 'top, peak', as though from Proto-Indo-European *bn̥d-no- which may be further connected to a PIE root *bend-, a root exclusive to Celtic and Germanic (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:54, {ref Delamarre 2003}:66, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:35).

Celtic lexemes generally connected to Lat. pūrus 'clean, pure, undefiled', Skt. pūtá- 'purified', etc. since {ref Pedersen 1909}:91 (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:26-27, {ref Matasović 2009}:143). The PIE root is now reconstructed as *peu̯H- (cf. {ref LIV²} 480 s.v. 1.*peu̯H- 'reinigen, läutern'), but cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:143 who alternatively suggests a connection to PIE *peh₂-u̯r̥- 'fire' and with an original meaning 'purified by fire', but this proposal has not been widely accepted.
Manx fliaghey continuing Old Irish flechud ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:168).
Derived from ScG. cas 'foot' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:95, further to Proto-Celtic *koxsā 'leg', PIE *kok̑so- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:214, {ref Matasović 2009}:220).
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ({ref Falileyev 2000}:76); root ref. form follows {ref Deshayes 2003}:316.

Continuing Vedic pā́ṇḍara- 'whitish-yellow, yellow, pale, white', a derivative of Vedic pāṇḍú- 'white, yellow, pale' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:454 no. 8047). Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:118).

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish greimm 'seizure, hold, grasp, profit, advantage, sway', ultimately nominal derivatives continuing Proto-Celtic *gremmen-, a derivative to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ({ref Matasović 2009}:167-168, cf. {ref LIV²} 201).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *derk̑- 'to look at, catch sight of' ({ref Delamarre 2003}:139-140, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:55-56, cf. {ref LIV²} 122).

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish tút, túth 'smell, stench' (cf. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:371). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:189 for references to an uncertain proposal to OHG stiuz.

Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; possibly further to IE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom, blossom' (so {ref IEW} 122, {ref Matasović 2009}:61; cf. 'leaf' in /cognate/252/, but rejected by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:50-51, {ref Delamarre 2003}:75). The proposed connection with Latin folium 'leaf' is uncertain (cf. 'leaf' in /cognate/8247/).

While these lexemes are not in {ref Turner 1962–1966}, this class is probably dealing with derivatives of Sanskrit ghuṇati, ghūrṇati 'to move to and fro' cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:242-243 no. 4485 *ghummati 'revolves' no. 4488 ghurati 'revolves' and no. 4497 ghūrṇati 'moves to-and-fro, moves about, is agitated. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Dravidian loan ({ref KEWA} I:360).
loan_notes: Loan status uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} I:360.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Slightly dubious class. Needs checking. Possibly related to /cognate/3063/ and /cognate/3062/ - investigate.

justificationDiscussion: Tsakonian σποΐα, π̔οΐα from Ancient Greek σποδία 'ash' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:507). Further etymology outside of Greek obscure ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}:771, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1040, {ref Beekes 2010}:1386).

notes: Perhaps derived in some way from Ancient Greek βύζην (adv.) 'close pressed' (Andriotis 1999).

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:6, {ref Beekes 2010}:7), cf. {ref Pinault 1979}, {ref Beekes 1996} for competing hypotheses.

Stem alternation between, e.g., nominative singular θρίξ, genitive singular τριχός due to Graßmann's Law point to a Proto-Greek stem *tʰrikʰ-, but further connections outside of Greek are unclear ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} I:684, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:441-442, {ref Beekes 2010}:556).

Etymology outside of Greek difficult; probably to IE *gres- (or *gras-) 'devour' (cf. {ref LIV²} 192, {ref IEW} 404) with dissimilation of *-r- in the root from the suffix *-tēr- (so {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:211-212); but cf. the objections of {ref Beekes 2010}:262.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. possibly also Lat. grāmen in /cognate/8369/ and Proto-Germanic *grasa-, but with difficulties; cf. discussion in the respective cognate classes.

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Lat. axungia ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:806, {ref Beekes 2010}:1088)

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek γεμᾶτος 'full', a derivative of Ancient Greek γέμω 'to be full' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:292), further derived from PIE *gem- 'to press, press together' ({ref LIV²} 186, {ref Beekes 2010}:265; cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:215).

Modern Greek φεγγάρι from Medieval Greek φεγγαρίον, a diminutive in -αριον, derived from Ancient Greek φέγγος 'light, splendour, lustre' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1528). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1184-1185, {ref Beekes 2010}:1559-1560).

Hellenic lexemes, originally from a derived adjective in *-nā to Ancient Greek σέλας 'light, brightness', i.e. Proto-Greek *selásnā- (cf. Lesbian σέλαννα 'moon'). Further etymology obscure ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:955, {ref Beekes 2010}:1318-1319).

Hellenic lexemes traditionally considered a derivation to the same root as Ancient Greek τρέχω 'to run' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1130), but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1501 considering this explanation semantically unconvincing, with aspects of the word formation also unclear from an IE point of view.

Modern Greek forms from Ancient Greek στρογγύλος 'round, spherical' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1343). Generally connected to Ancient Greek στράγξ 'squeezed out drop' and further to OHG strang ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}: II:810-811, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1064-1065}), although the semantic connection within Greek not overly persuasive ({ref Beekes 2010}:1415). Further etymology outside of Greek therefore uncertain.
A formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, originally in the sense 'chat, prattle', later generalised as the generic verb 'to say' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:615-616, {ref Beekes 2010}:827-828).
No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:122, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:640, {ref Beekes 2010}:861).
No consensus etymology; cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972}:585, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:384, and {ref Beekes 2010}:478 for various proposals.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *bōan- ~ *būan- 'to live, dwell', further derived from PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to grow, emerge, become' ({ref Seebold 1970}:124-126, {ref Kroonen 2013}:71, {ref LIV²} 98-101).
Nuristani forms refect Old Indic *ut-sthā-ti (-Strand).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰā́rā- 'cutting edge' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:389 no. 6793, {ref Strand 1998}, {ref EWAia} I:789).

notes: Sanskrit maṇi- 'hump; Adam's apple' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:557 no. 9732), further considered as though from PIE *monh₂-i- (~ *moneh₂-) 'neck' by {ref EWAia} II:293-294 and connected with Vedic mányā- (cf. /cognate/1728/), although this etymology is doubted by {ref Turner 1962–1966}:557 no. 9732 on semantic grounds, cf. also discussion in {ref KEWA} II:556-557.
justificationDiscussion: Nuristani lexemes as though from *mârâṇik, denoting 'back of neck'. Probably not connected with Sanskrit maṇi- 'hump; Adam's apple'.
Indo-Iranic lexemes probably reflecting PIE *gʷriH-u̯eh₂- ({ref EWAia} I:509). It is difficult to isolate a further root etymology.

notes: possibly related to Vedic (RV, AV) pavástam n. 'covering' (cf. Old Persian pavastā- f. 'skin, parchment'), cf. entries *pōta-, *pōtta- and *pōttha- 'cloth' (with variants) in Turner 1962-66, p. 477f., no. 8400, 8414

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: ideophonic, cf. 'swell' /cognate/7585/, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9102 *phūtka- ʻblowingʼ

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes as though from Sanskrit dhūli-, Indic *dhūḍi- 'dust, powder' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:391 no. 6835), further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} II:110).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 409, no. 7136 s.v. nikaṭam vel sim. adv. 'near' R.

justificationDiscussion: Albanian and Indic lexemes derived from PIE *ten- 'to stretch' ({ref LIV²} 626-627, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:284-285, {ref Orel 1998}:283, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:985, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:328 no. 5762, {ref EWAia} I:618-619).

notes: 'hard, sharp, punget, solid, hot (of wind)' (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3819; cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 302 and s.v. karkaraḥ; perhaps from an onomatopoetic PIE root *k(h₂)ar- 'rough, crackling' (?) (for the root structure compare *kh₂ad-, LIV, p. 359)
