Vedic mr̥dú- 'soft' (VS), 'weak' (AV), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10292

justificationDiscussion: From Proto-Celtic *slattā; further connections outside of Celtic are difficult (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:127-128, {ref Matasović 2009}:345).

notes: hrīsa- n. ‘brushwood’ http://iedo.brillonline.nl/dictionaries/lemma.html?id=21497

justificationDiscussion: Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *rak(k)an- '(sleuth) dog'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:432, {ref Kroonen 2013}:404).
From Old Norse pústr 'slap in the face' (n.) 'to pant, blow' (vb.). Probably further connected in some way with Middle Low German puster 'bellows', poesten, puysten 'blow' ({ref de Vries 1977}:429).
Originally a past participle to Old Norse hefja 'to raise', further to PIE *keh₂p- 'to grab, seize' ({ref Seebold 1970}:244-245, {ref Kroonen 2013}:198, cf. {ref LIV²} 344-345).
Possibly from PIE *bʰleu̯dh₂- if the comparison with Ancient Greek φλυδάω 'to be soft, weak' is correct (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:67, {ref Beekes 2010}:1579-1581 s.v. φλυδάω and φλιδάω).

Etymology uncertain. The etymology given by {ref de Vries 1977} relies on the outdated theory of root-extensions as in {ref IEW}. Additionally, the etymological connection of the comparanda given by {ref de Vries 1977} are questionable (cf. s.v. Gk. ἀλθαίνω in {ref Beekes 2010}, s.v. Ved. √ardh- in {ref EWAia}). Consequently, the basis upon which the traditional proposed etymology of Old Norse aldin rests, remains uncertain. Not in {ref Orel 2003} or {ref Kroonen 2013}.

North Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *spurda- (cf. Middle High German sporte 'tail', without attestation in East Germanic). Cf. {ref Orel 2003}:367, {ref de Vries 1977}:537 for uncertain attempts at an etymology outside of Germanic. [Not in {ref Kroonen 2013}].
Parallel loans from Low German brav, further borrowed from French brave, from Italian bravo (cf. {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).
loan_notes: Low German brav, via French brave, via Italian bravo.

justificationDiscussion: Extra-Germanic etymology unclear. Possibly from PIE *gʷet- if comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite', but the comparison is not entirely clear; cf. {ref LIV²} 212, {ref Kroonen 2013}:319, {ref Lehmann 1986}:277-278, {ref Seebold 1970}:318-320, {ref Olsen 1999}:811.
May go back to a root etymon *lei̯g- if connected with Baltic words connected with Lith. lýgus 'even, flat, similar' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:336-337, {ref ALEW} 584-586).

Derivatives ultimately from Proto-Germanic *dentan- 'to fall', via a nominal derivative *dunti- > Old West Norse dyttr 'a hit' from which a verbal derivative dytta 'to hit', cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:90-91, {ref Seebold 1970}:154.

Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Traditionally connected to a root *mer(ə)- with various root extensions (cf. {ref IEW} 739-740, {ref Seebold 1970}:352, {ref de Vries 1977}:393). {ref Heidermanns 1993}:417 does not propose an updated etymology. No lemmata in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}.

notes: May be a Low German loanword.

justificationDiscussion: {ref Kroonen 2013}:234 reconstructs Proto-Germanic *hnefan- as though from *knep-on-, but does not provide any cognates justifying an extra-Germanic etymology.

notes: Old Norse skoltr 'bone arch over the eye' (Norwegian skolt, skult, Swedish skult, dialect skulle), cf. ON skál 'skull'. < *skēlo-

justificationDiscussion: Continuing the Germanic strong verb *wendan-, and further to PIE *u̯endʰ- (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:554-556, {ref Kroonen 2013}:587, {ref Kluge 2011}:970, {ref LIV²} 681-682).
From Old Norse mjǫrkvi 'thick fog', a variant of myrkvi 'id.', to be derived from PIE *mergʷ- (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:390, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:409-410, {ref Kroonen 2013}:366).
Continuing Proto-Germanic *skufta- 'hair of the head', further connections uncertain ({ref Kroonen 2013}:449, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:313).

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse keppr 'cudgel, club', further from Proto-Germanic *kip(p)a-, related with Germanic to the weak verb *kippōn- 'to chop(?)', but without any certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Orel 2003}:289, {ref Kroonen 2013}:289)

To be connected with lexemes meaning 'to crack' in other Germanic languages (cf. OHG krahhōn, OE cracian), but ultimately of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok} s.v. kräkas, {ref Kluge 2011}:535).
Loanword from dialectal Swedish snafsa 'to snap; get dirty' ({ref Den Danske Ordbog}).

Generally considered a zero-grade derivative of Proto-Germanic *bautan- 'to beat' with an original meaning 'blunt, truncated thing' ({ref EWNl}), further possibly to be derived from an IE root *bʰeu̯d- 'to beat' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:56, {ref LIV²} 82).
Etymology uncertain, perhaps related to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:171).
Parallel loans from Low German.

Cf. Standard Swedish slå ihjäl 'beat to death', etymologically, Old Swedish i häl 'into hell' ({ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}). Traditionally further connected to the strong verb *helan- 'to cover, conceal' < PIE *k̑el-, if early Germanic speakers conceived of the realm of the dead as a hidden or hiding place (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:220-221), but as a mythological term this remains simply a conjecture ({ref Kluge 2011}:422, {ref Kroonen 2013}:204, not included among the derivatives to *hel-a- 'verbergen' in {ref Seebold 1970}:252).
According to {ref Den Danske Ordbog}, a blend of Middle Low German schubben 'rubbing', schuppen 'pushing, bumping', and Low German schüppen 'loosen (with a drawer iron)'.
loan_notes: Apparently a blend of various Low German loans 'schubben', 'schuppen', and 'schüppen'.

justificationDiscussion: Without certain comparisons outside of Germanic. Traditionally derived to the root *pleh₁- 'to fill, be filled', on the basis of Alb. plok, plogu 'crowd' < *pleh₁-g- and Lat. plēbēs < *plh₁-dʰueh₁-, Gk. πληθύς < *pleh₁-dʰuh₁-s with different derivational morphology (cf. {ref IEW} 799 {ref EWA 3} s.v. OHG folc, {ref Boutkan & Siebinga 2005} s.v. OFris. folk. No lemma in {ref Kroonen 2013}.
Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:404). Cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:386 for older proposals.
A derivative of OIr. secc (adj.) 'stiff, rigid, hard', originally a loanword from Latin siccus 'dry' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:60), cf. /cognate/4358/.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'dry' in /cognate/4358/ if the Brythonic forms are not parallel loans.

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Latin bestia ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:49).

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing secondary derivatives of a Celtic verbal root *klek- (cf. Old Irish clich- '(s)he moves', nominal cluiche 'game, event, sport'), probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:127).

Previously considered without a clear etymology by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:164-165), see now {ref LIV²} 538-539, {ref Schumacher 2004}:605-607, {ref Matasović 2009}:360 to PIE *seu̯h₁- 'incite, set in motion'.
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; perhaps to Lat. grossus 'fat' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:79, {ref Matasović 2009}:74, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:273).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: From Vulgar Latin grossus, possibly itself a borrowing from /cognate/185/. May be cognate to /cognate/4355/

justificationDiscussion: Verbal derivatives from the Middle Welsh noun brath 'a bite, biting' continuing Proto-Celtic *brozdo- 'point, tip' and further to a PIE root *bʰresdʰ- (cf. {ref Geiriadur Pryfsgol Cymru (GPC), {ref Matasović 2009}:80).

notes: Listed by Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru to be a Latin loan in Welsh so ultimately deriving from /cognate/867/. Alternative forms with initial h- are likely to be inherited, whereas these ones, with initial s- are borrowings.
justificationDiscussion: Brythonic lexemes derived from a loan event from Latin siccus 'dry' (cf. Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:60, {ref Falileyev 2000}:142-143)

loan_notes: Old French lard, lart (12th cent.) < Latin laridum 'fat'

justificationDiscussion: Loanword into Brythonic from Latin piscis 'fish' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:574, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. Welsh pysg 'fish').

notes: Common Brythonic loan from Latin fructus /cognate/227/
justificationDiscussion: Borrowing into Brythonic from Latin frūctus ({ref Deshayes 2003}:258, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. ffrwyth).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Common Brythonic borrowing from Latin viridis, /cognate/885/

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Celtic difficult to establish ({ref Matasović 2009}:239-240, cf. also {ref Deshayes 2003}:458).

Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *bando- 'top, peak', as though from Proto-Indo-European *bn̥d-no- which may be further connected to a PIE root *bend-, a root exclusive to Celtic and Germanic (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:54, {ref Delamarre 2003}:66, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:35).
Loan from Latin coccum '(berry which was used to produce scarlet dye)' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:139).
A loan from Latin certus 'determined, resolved, fixed, settled, purposed, certain' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:75-76).

loan_notes: loan Old French > Breton or common Brittonic loan < Latin equally probable

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian lexemes generally compared with Proto-Germanic *dankwa- 'dark' derived to a PIE root *dʰengʷ- ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:829, cf. also {ref Heidermanns 1993}:146).
Lexemes derived from Hittite ištamān- 'ear', further from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:411-413).
Etymology outside of Goidelic uncertain. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:104 proposed an etymology to a root *krei̯- 'split', but this was rejected by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:222.
No certain etymology outside of Celtic (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:43-44, {ref Matasović 2009}:341).
Loan from Latin pēnsum (cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} s.v. Welsh pwys).
Probably a loanword from Dravidian, cf. Tamil kaluḻ- 'become turbid', Kannada kaluhe 'dirt' ({ref KEWA} I:182).
loan_notes: Probable loanword from Dravidian, cf.  Tamil kaluḻ- 'become turbid', Kannada kaluhe 'dirt'

justificationDiscussion: Probably to be derived from Vedic √ray- 'flow' ({ref EWAia}:459); for the root reconstruction. cf. {ref LIV²} 305–306.

notes: cognate with OHG dorn 'thorn', etc., cf. IEW 1031; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 664
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes generally considered cognate to OHG dorn 'thorn', etc. < *tr̥-no-; perhaps further derived from PIE *(s)ter- 'be rigid', cf. Gk. στερεός 'stiff, hard' but this is less certain ({ref {EWAia} I:664, cf. {ref IEW} 1031),
Etymology outside of Indic uncertain, possibly to Old Norse hrista 'shake' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:413).
Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √rekh- 'to scratch', further to PIE *(h₁)rei̯k⁽ʷ⁾h₂- 'to scratch, score' ({ref EWAia} II:457, {ref LIV²} 504).
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic kṣudrá- 'small, minute' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:193, no. 3712), further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:434, 439; {ref LIV²} 372).

Etymology outside of Indic uncertain. Perhaps associated Nūristāni forms (e.g. Kati parši 'mountain' might allow a preform *parṣ- which in turn could be connected to PIE *pel(e)s- in Gk. πέλλα· λίθος (Hesych.), OHG felis, NHG Fels, etc., but this remains uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:125-126; cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:459, no. 8138).
From Vedic śilā́- 'rock, stone' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:721-722, no. 12459), further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:640).

Derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331).
Middle Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √sphā- 'to come fat, plump', further to PIE *sp⁽ʰ⁾eh₁- ({ref EWAia} II:776-777, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:799 no. 13828, cf. {ref LIV²} 584).

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword or of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:337, 329-330).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3624; Pali kiliṭṭha- 'soiled, morally impure'; LIV, p. 363 (IEW 602)
justificationDiscussion: Continuing a Sanskrit adjective kliṣṭa- 'distressed', derived to the lexical root √kleś- 'to torment, trouble' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:188, no. 3624). Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:419).
Loanword from Pāli aggini- , gini- 'fire', replacing Old Sinhalese aga 'fire' < Ved. agní- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:3 no. 55).
Cf. Sanskrit gaḍa- 'young of the fish Ophiocephalus lata or Cyprinus garra' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:212 no. 3970), only attested by lexicographers. Further etymology uncertain.

notes: presumably from 'to clump together', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4177, 4182, 4271

justificationDiscussion: Light verb constructions 'to become ice' with loanwords from Persian برف / barf 'snow' as the semantic-bearing head, cf. 'ice' in /cognate/7952/.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11384 s.v. vardhita- 'increased, strengthened' (MBh.), Pali vaḍḍhita
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:664 no. 11384 Skt. vardhita 'increased, strengthened, gladdened', a derivative of Vedic √vardh- 'to increase, grow'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:520-521; {ref LIV²} 228 mechanically reconstructs ?*Hu̯eRdʰ-).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7150
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic niktá- 'washed, purified' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:409 no. 7150), further derived from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'to wash' ({ref EWAia} II:54, cf. {ref LIV²} 450).

notes: < Sanskrit nir-mala- 'spotless, clean' (Up.) ('*having no dirt'), cf. mála-; cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7366; cog. with /cognate/692/
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit nirmala- 'spotless, clean', cf. Vedic mála- 'dirt' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:417 no. 7366). For the further etymology, cf. 'black' in /cognate/1575/, 'dirty' in /cognate/692/.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12525 s.v. *śudhya-; from Vedic śúdhyate 'becomes pure, clear; is purified, clear', cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 657; thus ultimately from PIE *k̑eu-dʰ- (from *k̑eu-), cf. LIV, p. 330
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯dʰ- 'to clean, make pure', cf. Vedic √śodh- 'to become clean, pure'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:726 no. 12525, {ref EWAia} II:657; {ref LIV²} 330 mechanically reconstructs PIE ?*k̑eu̯dʰ-).

notes: cf. Vedic nī́la- adj. 'dark coloured, dark blue, black blue, indigo' (also 'dark GRUE' = dark blue-green); further etymology unclear, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 51, Turner 1962-66, p. 426, no. 7563; some forms analogically influenced by *lohila-, cf. Vedic róhita- ~ lóhita- 'red'
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic nī́la- 'dark blue, dark green, black' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:426 no. 7563). Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:51).

notes: Loan from OIA (perhaps PII?) kap- ‘grey-green’, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 137, 825

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bodh- 'to wake up; to perceive, become aware; to know' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:525 no. 9279), further to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- 'to awaken, become alert' ({ref EWAia} II:233-235, {ref LIV²} 82-83).
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1938}:536, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:282).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhar- 'to carry' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:539 no. 9459 and 9465), cf. further PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref EWAia} II:246-249, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77).
Continuing Sanskrit jaḍa- 'cold, stiff, dull, stupid' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:281 no. 5090). Further etymology uncertain, probably a non-Indic loanword from Dravidian or Munda ({ref KEWA} I:414).
loan_notes: Exact loan source unclear, but certainly not inherited.

justificationDiscussion: Derivative adjective based on the outcome of Vedic gárbha- 'womb, foetus, offspring' cf. K. gab 'womb' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:217 no. 4055), further to PIE *gʷolbʰo- 'womb' ({ref EWAia} I:474-475).
Denominal formations to Vedic mr̥gá- 'wild animal'; further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:370-371).

Derivatives from Proto-Slavic *poļe 'field' (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:460, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012}:486-487, 506, {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 8:137), and further to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ({ref NIL 562-564, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:411). Taking into account the distribution and a rather non-trivial semantic derivation, one could expect, that this form developed in one of these languages and was diffused into the other. However, the source language is impossible to determine phonetically or morphologically.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'mountain' in /cognate/2804/, 'hand' in /cognate/1712/, 'thin' in /cognate/1923/, 'wide' in /cognate/5264/, 'smooth' in /cognate/6801/, 'earth' in /cognate/5892/, 'stand' in /cognate/8055/, 'tree' in /cognate/8103/.

notes: cognate with 'stick' cognate/1680/
justificationDiscussion: Cf. s.v. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:350 no. 6130 *daṇḍakakarman- 'forest-work'; the semantic head coded for cognacy in this set is Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick', without further etymology outside of Indic ({ref EWAia} I:692, {ref KEWA} II:11-12).

notes: cf. 9360 "freeze"; 9359 "cold"; 9361 "ice" and Cheung (2007: 39): "On *či̯aH³/čiH < (?) PIE *ḱi̯-, cf. *ǰi̯auH ‘to chew’ < PIE *ǵi̯euH-, see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. The variant *saiH/siH may derive from the variant *ḱ(e)iH-."
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *či̯aH-; further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:660-661; cf. {ref KEWA} III:383-384 for various older proposals).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:329, {ref Cheung 2007}:453 for various proposals.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5424, presumably of non-Aryan origin; cf. /cognate/2703/

justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:318 no. 5605 s.v. Indic *ḍhōṅga- 'projecting part of body', probably to be further connected with various words beginning with *ḍh- in the meaning 'lump' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:316 no. 5580) but further etymology obscure.
From Proto-Iranic *dai̯s- 'to show' (+ preverb *ham-), further to PIE *dei̯k̑- 'to indicate, show' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:147, {ref Cheung 2007}:51-52, cf. {ref LIV²} 108-109).
Light verb construction with Marathi माहित / mahit 'know' as the semantic head.
Continuing Sanskrit vāpī́ 'large pond, tank, pool'. For further etymological discussion, cf. {ref KEWA} III:188.

Continuing a Sanskrit compound agramāṁsa- n. 'heart', lit. 'foremost-meat' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:4 no. 77). The semantic-bearing head, Vedic māṁsa- 'meat', continutes PIE *mēms-ó- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:343-344, {ref NIL} 486-488).

notes: Wiktionary (unreferenced) gives Skt. bhára- 'bearing' (< *bʰer-). Not in Turner.

justificationDiscussion: As though from Indic *goḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee'; further connections unclear, perhaps related to *khuṭṭa- 'leg' in /cognate/9629/ ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:229 no. 4272).
From Sanskrit kaṅkāla- 'skeleton' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:129 no. 2603), further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref KEWA} I:137 for speculative suggestions.

Etymologically connected with the family of words surrounding Vedic pipīlá-, etc. 'ant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:463 no. 8201). Further etymological connections remain unclear, probably of substratum origin (cf. {ref KEWA} II:284-285, {ref EWAia} II:132-133).
Loanword from Sanskrit vyakti- 'visible appearance or manifestation; specific appearance, distinctness, individuality; an individual' ({ref Turner 1931}:570).

notes: first part would nearly fit with 7747 *leh₁g̑ʰ- which would give rāz-
justificationDiscussion: Traditionally with PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' according to {ref IEW} 855, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:398-399, {ref LIV²} 304-305).
An old borrowing from earlier Persian *rawšan- 'light, dawn' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:299)

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit ujjvala- 'blazing up, bright, clean' > 'white', further to Vedic √jval- 'burn' and ultimately PIE *g̑u̯elH- 'to burn, blaze' ({ref EWAia} I:607, {ref LIV²} 170-171).

notes: *grilla- 'wet, damp', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 235, no. 4386; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Indic *grilla- 'wet, damp', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:235 no.4386).

An Indo-Iranic and Albanian lexical isogloss from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, contemplate' ({ref LIV²} 141-142, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:969; cf. {ref EWAia} I:777-778 without discussion of proposed Albanian cognates).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10770

justificationDiscussion: Light verb constructions using parallel loans from Arabic as the semantic head, cf. Arabic milāḥa 'swimming, sailing', mallāḥ 'sailor' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:606-607).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 14018 s.v. *hallati intr. 'moves, shakes'
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic as though from Old Indic *hallati 'moves, shakes', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:810 no. 14018. Further etymology unclear.
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Korn 2005}:319).

notes: Loanword from Sanskrit punḍra- via Kâta-vari.

justificationDiscussion: Unclear whether T2209 or T11167 or contamination,

notes: Arabic loan via Persian

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Indic ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:74, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:774 no. 13415).

Originally a compound of Proto-Indo-Iranic *u̯r̥ćšá- 'tree' + √*ǰai- 'to win, conquer' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:572). This cognate set is coded for *u̯r̥ćšá- 'tree' as the semantic bearing head, cf. 'tree' in /cognate/2368/ for further discussion. For Proto-Iranic *ǰai- 'to win, conquer' < PIE *gʷei̯- 'to win, conquer' cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:222, {ref LIV²} 206.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯anH- 'to call', further to PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' ({ref Cheung 2007}:144-145, {ref LIV²} 611).

notes: *cul- 'fidget, itch' cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 265, no. 4874; probably of non-Indic origin
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:265 no. 4874 s.v. *cul- 'fidget, itch', further etymology obscure.

notes: *ava-ramp(h)ati, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 35, no. 811; cmpare Vedic raphitá-, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 433f.; thus ultimately from PIE*(h₁)rep(h₂)- 'pluck, tear', cf. ²LIV, p. 507
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10781 s.v. rundra ʻrich inʼ (lex.)
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3945; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13943; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5453; presumably of non-Indic origin
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8377; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

justificationDiscussion: Certainly related to Khotanese baičakama and Middle Turkic bäčkäm, but details are not completely clear. Benveniste (apud {ref Clauson 1972}: 295) argues for an Iranic word loaned into Turkic, which is supported by the general meaning of '(horse's) tail' in Iranic versus the specific meaning 'trophy (with an antelope's tail)' in Middle Turkic; the more general meaning 'tuft of hair' in later Oghuz Turkic is explained as a Persian loan. The argument in {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 96 that final -am (rather than -ǝm) is indicative of loanwords lacks evidence. At any rate, a loan back from Turkic or Persian is conceivable.

notes: cf. Turkish kuyruk "tail"

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Medieval Latin pāgānus 'non-Christian, pagan'. It is difficult, however, to determine when the lexeme was originally borrowed (cf. {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 4:472-473).
loan_notes: It is hard to determine precisely how and when the root arose in Ukrainian (it can be an old Common Slavic loanword but it also could pass to Ukrainian through Church Slavonic etc.).

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology. All existing hypotheses need special assumptions that are not impossible but hard to prove (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:80, 83, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 6:203, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 4:267).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- 'to rise, grow' (cf. {ref ESSJa} 15:194-200, {ref NIL} 245-246).

The etymology of the East Slavic term is unclear. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses links it to Slavic *polx- 'fear, frighten' and further to PIE *pelh₁- (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:410). It is semantically convincing. However, a phonetically regular reflex should have -olo- then, e.g. Russian **polohoj. A solution is to assume a borrowing from Polish płochy (or a phonetic conforming at the Polish word). However, such a borrowing would be very isolated. Further, the Polish-like form of the root has been attested (in derivatives) already from 14th-15th centuries and it is spread in all East Slavic dialects. Another solution is to assume a contamination with ploskij 'flat'. The probability is disputable. Still another solution is to assume an irregular phonetic change driven or supported by the frequency. The phonetic circumstances are very favourable in this case. The (hipothetical) missing vowel was unstressed and East Slavic stress is dynamic and relatively strong (at least nowadays). Further, it stand between a stop and a liquid. In sequences / pR / there is always a short (prothetic, unphonological) vowel with a quality resembling the next vowel. An unstressed and therefore short, etymological vowel in / pVR / can be very easily interpreted as a prothetic, unphonological vowel articulation (and, in fact, vice versa), especially in cases as *polox- with two identical vowels. Further, we can deal with a dialectal, northern Russian feature in this case which could spread as a lexicalized inter-dialectal borrowing (cf. {ref Zaliznâk 2004}:39-41). Note that the oldest, precisely located attestations of plox-forms are found in texts from northern Russia. A combination of some of the given solutions is also conceivable.

notes: PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split'
Some sources (cf. Derksen) suggest that the Polish word is an East Slavic (Ukrainian) loanword. The attestation is relatively late and there are some not fully certain phonetic clues.
scrape off, cut off > reject, refuse > throw out > throw

justificationDiscussion: Generally considered a derivative of a PIE *bel- ({ref Derksen 2008}:52, {ref ESSJa} 2:193-194, {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} I:105).
No certain etymology.
Due to its nursery character, any deeper etymology of this lexeme can not be convincingly proven.

Many sources link the Slavic lexeme to PIE *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)' {ref LIV²}. The meaning 'to heat' in Lithuanian kùrti is assumed to arise through an ellipisis of the objects in phrases like 'make a fire'. The Slavic lexeme and the Germanic ones are, however, not listed in LIV {ref LIV²}.
Nor the Slavic lexeme, neither the possible Germanic cognates show any traces of the 'make/do' meaning. Moreover, PS *kuriti has a specified meaning and refers clearly to burning with smoke (pleas note that the Gemanic meaning referring to the 'coal' fits here semantically very well). The Baltic etymology seems to have some formal issues. It seems reasonable to join the view of {ref Derksen 2008} and {Kroonen 2013} and assume a root distinct from *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)', *kerH- or *kerh₃-.

The etymology is disputable.
Greek σπόγγος and Latin fungus are considered to be (parallel) loanwords from a non-IE language (*spʰong-), cf. {ref Beekes 2010}: 1385 and {ref de Vaan 2008}: 250. Greek γαμφηλαί may be Pre-Greek or related to γόμφος, a cognate of PS *zǫbŭ 'tooth' {ref Beekes 2010}: 260, 282.
Lithuanian lexemes like gùbti, gum̃ba, gùbo; gaũbti, gaubiù, gaubiaũ; gum̃bas with derivatives, referring, in general, to 'bending, folding' and various 'protrusions, bulges', are related to PS *gŭb-, *ɡub-, *ɡyb- {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 161-162, 207, 77 (addenda). (However, {ref Smoczyński 2007} does not point to PS *gǫba directly.) Slavic and Baltic forms are derived from PIE *gʰeu̯bʰ-. As this root is limited to Balto-Slavic, it has been proposed, that is is a metathese-deformation of PIE *bʰeu̯gʰ-, cf. Gothic biugan 'bend' and Vedc paribhuját 'enfold'. See {ref Smoczyński 2007}: 162 and {ref LIV²}: 85-86, 188.
As it is convincing formally and semantically, I assume that PS *gǫba is derived from PIE *gʰeu̯bʰ-. Its further relationship to PIE *bʰeu̯gʰ- is not excluded but remains speculative.

The etymology is obscure. Although a single etymology of all Slavic lexemes listed in the citations below is formally and semantically possible, it can not be excluded that we deal here with more than one etymon (also with loanwords) with possible later mergers and contaminations. In any case, the hypothesis about an ordinary (Middle) German loanword in the case of the Sorbian, Polish and Czech lexemes for 'ball' seems to be at least an oversimplification.
However, even if we accept a single native etymon here, it is complicated to establish its further etymology and IE cognates without additional assumptions.
Cf. a semantically related PS leeme *gula, e.g. Polish gula 'bump'. Accordingly, expressive deformations are also possible.
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639, cf. {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1149).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'do' in /cognate/5215/, 'right' in /cognate/1238/, 'straight' in /cognate/1180/, and 'true' in /cognate/1207/.

justificationDiscussion:
Many sources link the Slavic lexeme to PIE *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)' {ref LIV²}. The meaning 'to heat' in Lithuanian kùrti is assumed to arise through an ellipisis of the objects in phrases like 'make a fire'. The Slavic lexeme and the Germanic ones are, however, not listed in LIV {ref LIV²}.
Nor the Slavic lexeme, neither the possible Germanic cognates show any traces of the 'make/do' meaning. Moreover, PS *kuriti has a specified meaning and refers clearly to burning with smoke (pleas note that the Gemanic meaning referring to the 'coal' fits here semantically very well). The Baltic etymology seems to have some formal issues. It seems reasonable to join the view of {ref Derksen 2008} and {Kroonen 2013} and assume a root distinct from *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)', *kerH- or *kerh₃-.
Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ({ref Derksen 2008}:494, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4:183, {ref Boryś 2005}:77, 84 for various proposals.
Loanword from (Eastern) Middle High German stomm, cf. Middle High German stam ({ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1474).

notes: No certain further etymology no matter numerous proposals (cf. ESSJa).

justificationDiscussion: Root etymology outside of Slavic disputed: Either to PIE *g̑u̯elH- 'to burn, blaze' or to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' (cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} II:103).
Although some IE comparisons can be disputable, the link to PIE *gʷerH- is formally and semantically convincing.

Slavic lexemes of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Boryś 2005}:422, 424, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1189. For a proposed comparison to Latin pānus 'tumour' see {ref Derksen 2008}:416 (but cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:444).

notes: cognate/4841/, /cognate/1291/
justificationDiscussion: Most scholars assume the relationship of the Slavic root to German kahl 'bald' and its further Germanic cognates. The hypothesis of ESSJa (accepted by some other scholars) is reasonable but more complex.

gloss_in_root_lang: back side, something that is at the back side

justificationDiscussion: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *legʰ- 'to lie (oneself) down' via Slavic *ob-log- 'wrap, belay' (cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}:419, {ref ESSJa} 28:17-18, {ref LIV²} 398-399).

Root only found in Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2008}:381-382, {ref LIV²} 316-317, cf. also discussion in {ref ALEW} 409-410). For the Slavic forms in this class the initial consonant is a part of a prefix (*ot-), which was subsequently was morphologically re-interpreted in the history of Slavic (*ot-jut- > *o-tjut- > *o-ťut-).

notes: <*čid-t-.The word is a compound 'not-clean'.

justificationDiscussion: Verb derived from Spanish pelear 'fight' (n.), in turn derived from Spanish pelo 'hair' regularly from Latin pilus 'hair' ({ref DCECH} IV:461-463, 465). Further etymological connections uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:507, {ref de Vaan 2008}:465).
Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁- 'to be hot' ({ref Untermann 2000}:54-55, {ref de Vaan 2008}:60, cf. {ref LIV²} 257).

Adjective derived from Latin sordēs 'dirt, filth, stain', generally further connected to Proto-Germanic *swarta- 'black' appearing to reflect an adjective *su̯ordo- 'black, dirt-colour' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:637, {ref de Vaan 2008}:576, cf. {ref IEW} 1052, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:574-575, {ref Orel 2003}:392).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:434, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref LIV²} 305-306).
No certain etymology outside of Italic (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:686, {ref de Vaan 2008}:615).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:243, {ref Olsen 1999}:908). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯at-a-].

notes: Iranian loanword.
justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Iranic (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:906, cf. {ref HAB} IV:195-196). [MM: Proto-Armenian *seu̯-o-/-i-].

notes: uncertain.
justificationDiscussion: Of uncertain origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:941), {ref HAB} II:666-667). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kurts-i-].
Loanword from Syriac ṭalyā ({ref Olsen 1999}:933, {ref HAB} IV:412-413). [MM: Proto-Armenian *təła-].
Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *slabъ 'weak', as though from PIE *slob-o- ({ref Derksen 2008}:452-453, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} s.v. *(s)leb- ‘schlaff werden’).
Etymology outside of Greek unclear ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:979-980, {ref Beekes 2010}:1294-1295). For older hypotheses, cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:665-666, {ref IEW} 1004.

No consensus etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:673-674, {ref Beekes 2010}:916-917); {ref Malzahn & Peters 2010} propose a connection to Tocharian B mäk- 'run', but the meanings are divergent (cf. 'run' in /cognate/7203/). {ref LIV²} 422 assigns to *magʰ- 'to be able'.
Hellenic lexemes continuing PIE *poi̯H-u̯eh₂- 'grass, meadow', cf. Lithuanian píeva 'meadow' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:922, {ref Beekes 2010}:1214-1215, cf. {ref ALEW} 769).
Greek θηρεύω is a secondary formation to an old IE root noun *g̑ʰu̯eh₁r- 'wild animal' (> AGk. θήρ) ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:435-436, {ref Beekes 2010}:547).

Generally considered a derivative of Ancient Greek κρύος 'cold' in the older literature (cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:28-29, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:588-589), although the stem-formation is obscure. {ref Beekes 2010}:787 therefore has rejected the older proposed etymology in favour of assuming a substratum borrowing from a 'Pre-Greek' language. A third possibility is that there has been some degree of contamination or blending of the lexical root underlying Ancient Greek κρύος with some other (substratum?) lexical material (cf. note by Scarborough in this class), although this too is a speculative solution.

Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)κτείνω 'to kill, put to death', derived from PIE *t⁽k̑⁾én-i̯e/o-, a derivative of the root *t⁽k̑⁾en- 'to injure' ({ref LIV²} 645-646, {ref Beekes 2010}:789-790, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:591). Wakhi šay- (past stem šit-) has presumably undergone the same semantic narrowing to the meaning 'kill', as against Vedic 'injure' and Avestan 'destroy' ({ref Morgenstierne 1938}: 543, {ref Cheung 2007}: 453).
Hellenic lexemes, ultimately derivatives from PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself in motion' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1106, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:822-823, {ref LIV²} 299-300).

Hellenic lexemes in the meaning 'round' as a derived relational adjective from Ancient Greek κύκλος 'circle, ring, wheel' < PIE *kʷe-kʷl-o- 'circle; wheel', a derivative to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ({ref Beekes 2010}:798-799, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'live' in /cognate/3185/, 'navel' in /cognate/7117/, 'yesterday' in /cognate/6487/, 'walk' in /cognate/1626/, 'turn' in /cognate/5879/.

justificationDiscussion: Of obscure origin, probably a prehistoric loanword (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:420, {ref Beekes 2010}:530 for discussion of various hypotheses). The different dialectal forms point to either a Proto-Greek or borrowed source form *tʰalak⁽ʰ⁾i̯a (vel sim.).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kneh₂- 'to shave, rub' ({ref Beekes 2010}:720-721, {ref LIV²} 372, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:546).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}: II:333, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:763-764, {ref Beekes 2010}:1033).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain; reminiscent of Lat. silva 'forest' but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1154-1155, {ref Beekes 2010}:1529-1530).
No known etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:519-520, {ref Beekes 2010}:679).
The etymology of this word is obscure.

Traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *kwasta- 'pine brush', Albanian gjeth 'foliage' < *gu̯osd-o- ({ref ESSJa} 7:185-186, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:227 and discussion to Albanian words for 'leaf' in /cognate/3390/), but considered to be of uncertain etymology according to ({ref Derksen 2008}:196). The traditional etymology has been tentatively accepted here.
Ultimately derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'make red' ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} III:207, cf. {ref LIV²} 508-509).
Etymology unclear, perhaps further to PIE *pelh₁- 'to make swing' ({ref Derksen 2008}:410-411, cf. {ref LIV²} 469-470).

notes: Unknown origin; cf. /lexeme/1878/.
justificationDiscussion: Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:965, cf. {ref HAB} III:596; not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}). [MM: Proto-Armenian *oi̯/u̯łił-o-].

notes: Loan from Latin
justificationDiscussion: Borrowing from Late Latin *virdis (Lat. uiridis), cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:69, {ref Deshayes 2003}:305-306.
The Breton verb chasseal was productively formed within Breton to chass 'dogs', a loanword from Old French chace 'hunt' (n.) ({ref Deshayes 2003}:153).
loan_notes: denominative verb from the Old French noun chace 'hunt' (12th cent.)

justificationDiscussion: Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.

notes: With nasal infix.
justificationDiscussion: From Proto-Slavic *gręsti 'go' and usually further derived from a PIE nasal-infix present *gʰri-n-dʰ- (cf. {ref LIV²} 203, {ref Derksen 2008}:188, {ref ESSJa} 7:123-124).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *truxlъ 'rotten' and ultimately derived from PIE *terh₁- 'to rub, bore' ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:239-240, cf. {ref LIV²} 632-633).
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to apprehend, behold' ({ref LIV²} 561, {ref ESSJa} 4:134-136, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:91).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:249-250, cf. also {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 4:123-124)
Slavic lexemes as though from PIE ?*gʰrebʰ-, a lexical root restricted to Balto-Slavic and Germanic (cf. {ref LIV²} 201-202, {ref ESSJa} 7:109-110, {ref Derksen 2008}:186-187).
Slavic lexemes to be derived from PIE *gʰlend⁽ʰ⁾- 'to look at, see, shine' ({ref Derksen 2008}:164, {ref ESSJa} 6:122-124, cf. {ref LIV²} 200).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 4: 9-10; 9: 110-111, {ref Derksen 2008}:218-219 for further discussion).

notes: Slavic reflexes of this root have most frequently the meaning 'slave', 'to work (hard)' etc.

justificationDiscussion: The link to PIE *terkʷ- is formally and semantically attractive. An alternative etymology points to PIE *(s)ter- 'hard(en)', cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}, but it has formal and semantic issues, cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4: 227.
Loanword from Old French brum ({ref Deshayes 2003}:144).

Celtic lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. {ref Kortlandt 2003}:77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in /cognate/6370/ which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. {ref EWAia} I:693-694, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:352 no. 6152, {ref Deshayes 2003}:170, {ref Matasović 2009}:90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in /cognate/328/.  Late parallel derivations in Indo-Iranic:  Gawarbati and Raji: Barzoki.

Celtic lexemes generally connected to PIE *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'bend' ({ref Matasović 2009}:248), but cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:332 for a speculative proposal to *leu̯s- in connection to Lat. lūridus 'pale (yellow)' (Schrijver himself admits "a mere possibility").

Old Prussian tiēnstwei (inf.) may be derived from PIE *tens- 'to pull' ({ref LIV²} 629, cf. {Ref Smoczyński 2005}:366-367, {ref Derksen 2015}:464, {ref ALEW} 1095). This root could well be secondary neo-root abstracted from a desiderative formation to *ten- 'to pull' already in PIE (cf. {ref LIV²} 629).
No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:762, {ref Beekes 2010}:1031).

Derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch', ultimately from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:465, {ref Derksen 2008}:115, 136, cf. {ref LIV²} 128-129).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.
Etymology uncertain. Loanword from Bulgar? (cf. {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 2:633

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *vyja 'neck'. Further etymology obscure ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} I:373, {ref Polański 1962-1994}:1034). Possibly cognate with Hittite u̯eḫ- 'to turn (oneself); to patrol' (cf. {ref LIV²} 663), but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:993-996 with an alternative etymology for the proposed Hittite comparandum.

Perhaps PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the BSl. acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾- ({ref Derksen 2008}:243, {ref Derksen 2015}:231-232), but connections outside of Balto-Slavic ultimately uncertain; perhaps PIE *kʷend- according to {ref ALEW}, but likewise extra-Balto-Slavic connections uncertain. Cf. also {ref ESSJa} 12:65-66.
No certain etymology outside of Slavic.

It is assumed of the Polish word to be a loanword from Czech (which can be further a loan from German). If it is true, the Kashubian word is most probably a loanword from Polish. An additional survey would be needed here. The Czech lexemes have probably also a complicated history. A contamination of two different etymona (on of which can be a loanword) is probable. Cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:677, {ref Rejzek 2001}:698.

Derived from Proto-Slavic *mog-/*mag- 'to be able' ({ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 3:336-337), further generally derived to an IE root *magʰ- 'to be able' (cf. {ref LIV²} 422, {ref Derksen 2008}:321, {ref ESSJa} 19:107-111).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- (Cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:706-709, {ref Derksen 2008}:415, 524 {ref LIV²} 668-669).

notes: Czech lexeme (which is also attested in other Slavic languages in a similar (but not-Swadesh) meaning) are derived from the Slavic word for 'belt' (it primarily denoted a kind of a fight in which one tries to down the other on the ground pulling parts of his clothes, like Judo).

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Slavic. The underlying root is doubtless onomatopoeic. Any deeper etymology (as PIE *per- 'hit' or *pres- 'spray' {ref LIV²}: 473, 492) would be highly speculative (cf. {Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:103, {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 5:167, 601-602, {ref Rejzek 2001}:496, Snoj 1997-2016).
Further connections outside of Slavic are uncertain ({ref ESSJa} 8:123, 160-161).

Connections outside of Armenian unclear; occasionally proposed to Gk. ξηρός 'dry' (cf. /cognate/1471/), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:182, {ref Olsen 1999}:965 {ref Beekes 2010}:1035-1036, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:546).

Many irregular developments, often assumed to be due to taboo deformation, but all the lexemes are generally assumed to come from a common Indo-European source. The metathesised stem *u̯orm- as found in Vedic, etc. is generally assumed to be a taboo-deformation while the forms found in Avestan maoiri-, Old Irish moirb are often assumed to be most closely reflect to the original ({ref EIEC} 24). For individual branches, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:630, {ref Beekes 2010}:982, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:482-483, {ref EWAia} II:507, {ref ESSJa} 19:241-249, {ref Derksen 2008}:326, {ref Kroonen 2013}:359, {ref de Vaan 2008}:243, {ref Matasović 2009}:278.
Of uncertain origin, unattested in Classical Armenian ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:366). [MM: < ⁽*⁾kəloɾ].

Cf. {ref LIPP 2} s.v. *g̑ʰés- 'gestern' for extensive discussion of the attempted reconstructions of forms in this class, also {ref NIL} s.v. *dei̯-, *di- under ?*(g̑ʰ)-di-es (with discussion in footnotes 6-18). The cognacy of the lexemes in this class is not disputed, however there remains much disagreement in the literature how the forms are derived in the attested languages from a common reconstruction. The two most commonly held hypotheses include (1) derivations related to the Germanic word for 'day' (cf. /cognate/200/, not without its own problems in derivation) as *dʰg̑ʰ-i̯es- (zero-grade root + comparative suffix or endingless locative) or (2) a compound of the Indo-European deictic *g̑ʰo- ~ *g̑ʰ- (cf. LIPP 2 275-276) in the zero-grade + the root *dei̯- ~ *di- 'shine' ({ref NIL} 69-81, cf. esp. fn6), which underlies words for day in many other branches (cf. /cognate/375/). For a recent extensive discussion of these and other hypotheses, cf. LIPP 2 269-270. For individual branches, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1692, {ref Demiraj 1997}:138, {ref Orel 1998}:68, {ref EWAia} II:822, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:313-314, {ref Kroonen 2013}:175-176, {ref de Vaan 2008}:283, {ref Matasović 2009}:155). Cf. also {ref Schindler 1977} and {ref Puhvel 1987} for further discussion on aspects of the IE reconstruction.
Derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'to burn' ({ref Bailey 1979}:164, cf. {ref LIV²} 133-134).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *dāsá-, cf. Vedic dāsá- 'non-Aryan; fiend, demon, evil-being; slave, servant', further connections uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:723-724, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:162-163, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:155).

Lexemes from Proto-Iranic *či̯au̯- 'to move, go', and ultimately from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:307-308, {ref Cheung 2007}:40-42, {ref EWAia} I:552-553, {ref LIV²} 394-395).
Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯k̑-/*u̯oi̯k̑- 'house' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1055-1056, {ref EWAia} II:584-585, cf. {ref LIV²} 669-670).

notes: Only found in the Pamiri core group (Shughni-Yazghulami). Contra Morgenstierne, Yazghulami čůš excludes a preform *θraxša- and presupposes *čaxša-. This could in principle be connected to Iranian *čak- 'strike,hit' (Cheung), but semantics are not really compelling.

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃nebʰ- 'navel' ({ref NIL} 385-387, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1080, {ref EWAia} II:13-14, {ref Derksen 2015}:562, {ref Kroonen 2013}:380, {ref de Vaan 2008}:639, {ref Matasović 2009}:33)
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1506-1507, {ref LIV²} 154). For the Tsakonian lexemes in this class, cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:556-557.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'walk' in /cognate/5824/, 'pull' in /cognate/2839/, 'carry' in /cognate/5330/, possibly also 'turn' in /cognate/660/.

justificationDiscussion: No precise correspondences outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:589, {ref Beekes 2010}:786-787). The closest possible correspondences are in Balto-Slavic (cf. OCS kryti 'hide', Lith. kráuti 'heap' in /cognate/5275/), but the connection is uncertain.
Hellenic lexemes as though from PIE *skl̥h₁-ró-, an derived adjective to PIE *(s)kelh₁- 'to dry out, dry up' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1012-1013, {ref Beekes 2010}:1345-1346, cf. {ref LIV²} 553).

Hellenic, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *mus- 'fly, gnat', cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:976, {ref Demiraj 1997}:270, {ref Orel 1998}:268, {ref ALEW} 673-674, {ref Derksen 2015}:326, {ref ESSJa} 20:170-172, {ref Derksen 2008}:330-331, {ref de Vaan 2008}:397).

Hellenic, Armenian, and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂leh₁- 'to grind up' (cf. {ref LIV²} 277, {ref Beekes 2010}:65, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:26-27, {ref Cheung 2007}:166, {ref Bailey 1979}:22, {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:93).

Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn', without any clear correspondences outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:104-105, 110-111, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:78, {ref ESIJa} III:196-203).

notes: From the divine name Ahura Mazdā, the principal deity in Zoroastrianism.
justificationDiscussion: From the divine name Ahura Mazdā, the principal deity in Zoroastrianism ({ref Bailey 1979}:40). The name is often hypothesised to have originally meant 'wise lord' (vel sim.), although the grammatical relations in the noun phrase remain disputed (cf. {ref Encyclopædia Iranica} s.v.). Because of the substantivisation of the noun from a compound theonym, it is difficult to isolate a semantic head for etymological analysis. For etymological discussion of the individual elements of the original compound / noun phrase, cf. {ref EWAia} I:147-148 (~ OAv. ahura-), {ref EWAia} II:378 (~ OAv. mazdā-).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref LIV²} 76-77, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:397-398, {ref Beekes 2010}:1562-1564, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:176, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:965, {ref EWAia} I:246-249, {ref Cheung 2007}:6-10, {ref Seebold 1970}:104-106, {ref Kroonen 2013}:59, {ref de Vaan 2008}:213-214, {ref Matasović 2009}:62).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fruit' in /cognate/3612/, 'full' in /cognate/7361/, 'give' in /cognate/1709/, 'grind' in /cognate/7643/, 'heavy' in /cognate/4519/, 'hit' in /cognate/9916/, 'play' in /cognate/1730/.

justificationDiscussion: Root assignment to PIE *kʷer- (cf. {ref LIV²} 391-392, {ref IEW} 641-2). Alternatively, the IIr. cognates assigned to this root might be with *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' (cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:287, {ref KEWA} II:540-542). For the Modern Indic forms, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:554 no. 9696.

Iranic and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *duh₂-ró- ({ref Bailey 1979}:161, {ref EWAia} I:739, {ref de Vaan 2008}:184; for the root *du̯eh₂- 'to remove, separate from' cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda})

notes: IE root *dʰer- (LIV² 145-6) must be separated from "enlargement" *dregʰ- (class E, LIV² 126).

justificationDiscussion: A probable Greek-Albanian isogloss (cf. {ref LIV²} 362, {ref Orel 1998}:353-354, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:993, {ref Frisk 1960-1972} I:865, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:538 {ref Beekes 2010}:709).
Root only attested in Indo-Iranic, further IE connections uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:153, {ref Cheung 2007}:153, {ref LIV²} 222).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:241-242, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:114 no. 2420); for Khotanese cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:492.

Pace {ref Deshayes 2003}:687 who assumes a borrowing via French estachier, a direct borrowing from Germanic *staka- 'stake, picket' seems more likely from a phonological point of view (Britta Irslinger, p.c.).
A borrowing from Old French baler 'to dance' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:88).

Indo-Iranic lexemes, probably to be further derived from the same root as Vedic √vas- 'to live, reside, spend the night', and further to PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:300, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:676 no. 11591, {ref EWAia} II:531-532, cf. {ref LIV²} 293-294).

Ossetic lexemes connected with other Indo-Iranic words for 'sand, dust' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:187-188). The correspondence of Indic *s- with Iranic *θ-, *s- is irregular, suggesting a possible parallel loan from a third-source or lexical contamination within Indic or Iranic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:772, no. 13386); {ref EWAia} II:728, however, considers the Indic and Iranic forms not to be separated.

Very similar in form and meaning to Latin dulcis 'sweet', but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. Perhaps the Italic and Greek lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:228-229, {ref Beekes 2010}:227-228). Cf. further discussion in /cognate/7772/.
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *pik̑-ro-, a derivative to PIE *pei̯k̑- 'to cut out, carve out' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:900-901, {ref Beekes 2010}:1190, cf. {ref LIV²} 465-466).

loan_notes: second part eur 'hour' borrowed from rather a descendant of Latin oria

notes: For the discussion on the Slavic cognates cf. /cognate/5209/ and /cognate/5149/.
justificationDiscussion: Tocharian, Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of a PIE root *s⁽k̑⁾eH- where the indeterminate laryngeal is probably *-h₂- on the basis of Ancient Greek σκηνή (West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́) 'tent' < *'cloth to provide shade' < *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂-néh₂ ({ref Beekes 2010}:1350-1351). Also attested in Greek is σκότος 'darkness, gloom' which must formally continue *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-to- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1359-1360). It is probably best to separate these as distinct roots, although formally they may well be (sandhi?) variants of one another at the PIE level. For further discussion cf. {ref Adams 2013}:773, {ref Beekes 2010}:1350-1351, {ref Andriotis 1974}:498, {ref Demiraj 1997}:201, {ref Orel 1998}:147-148, {ref EWAia} I:559-560, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:275-276 no. 5027, {ref Derksen 2008}:447).
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *tres- 'to tremble, be afraid' ({ref LIV²} 650-651, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:393-394, {ref EWAia} I:678-679).
Possibly from Proto-Iranic *safša- ({ref Bailey 1979}:416-417); {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:340 also considers the possibility of a loanword from Turkic sač, čač 'hair (on the head of a person)'

Etymology outside of Greek unknown, possibly to PIE *h₂eu̯- 'to perceive' if a de-adverbial formation as though from *h₂ou̯is-i̯é- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1059-1060, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:785-786).
Of imitative/onomatopoeic origin, cf. {ref HED H}:7-8, HW² Ḫ. Unlikely to be etymologically related to the comparanda given by {ref Weeks 1985}:223 for phonological reasons.

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas- 'to eat, consume' without certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:187, {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:37, {ref Cheung 2007}:93, {ref EWAia} I:514). {ref LIV²} 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike down', further connected to PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, hew' ({ref Cheung 2007}:234-235, cf. {ref LIV²} 555).
Loanword from Persian هوشیار / hūšyār 'alert, clever, sober' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:407, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1938}:552).
If a derivative from Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'consume' (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:504) then perhaps to be linked with 'eat' in /cognate/27/, 'drink' in /cognate/3691/.

notes: probably identical with *h₂eu̯-

justificationDiscussion: Often connected with the family of Ancient Greek πείρω 'pierce, run through' (cf. {ref LIV²} 472-473 s.v. 1. *per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren') with a velar extension to the root, but the root and stem formation remains nonetheless obscure (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:934-935, {ref Beekes 2010}:1229-1230).

Of obscure origin, probably a prehistoric loanword (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:420, {ref Beekes 2010}:530 for discussion of various hypotheses). The different dialectal forms point to either a Proto-Greek or borrowed source form *tʰalak⁽ʰ⁾i̯a (vel sim.).

Root etymology for the Hellenic lexemes in this class follows {ref LIV²} 535 as though from PIE *sr̥-i̯é- to PIE 3. *ser- 'to take, seize, grasp', but cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} I:43-44, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:38, {ref Beekes 2010}:42 (without reference to new literature in {ref LIV²}).

notes: The PIE root means "to swell". Mayrhofer groups a number of lexemes together which match the semantic field of "(leiblilche) Auswüchse, Schwellungen" [protuberances].

justificationDiscussion: Origin uncertain, cf. {ref HAB} IV:463-464, {ref Olsen 1999}:42, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:630-631 for various proposals. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsʰurt-o-].
Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:660-661; cf. {ref KEWA} III:383-384 for various older proposals).
Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ({ref Adams 2013}:566, cf. {ref LIV²} 293-294).

Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE r-stem *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'water', cf. Vedic vā́r- 'water'. The root *u̯eh₁- is possibly a variant of PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:544-545, {ref NIL} 715-717).

Nuristani and Modern Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of', cf. Vedic kāś- 'to be visible, appear', Proto-Iranic *kas- 'to look, appear' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:159 no. 3114, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:40, {ref Cheung 2007}:245-246, {ref EWAia} I:344-345, {ref LIV²} 383-385).

Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off' ({ref EWAia} I:537, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:255 no. 4701, {ref Boryś 2005}:553, {ref Derksen 2008}:234, 452; cf. {ref LIV²} 556-557).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:434-435, {ref Kroonen 2013}:453-454. Perhaps to an IE root *sleh₁b- 'be slack'(?) if to be connected with Lith. slobstù, slõbti 'be weak' (cf. {ref LIV²} 565).

notes: Middle and New Iranic languages exhibit an additional nominal suffix (e.g. Middle Persian -īg).
justificationDiscussion: The Iranian forms in this set are based on a secondary root *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' of denominal origin, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:412-413). For the primary verbal root, cf. {ref LIV²} 668-669 s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁-.
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *ret- 'to run' ({ref LIV²} 507, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:23, {ref Schumacher 2004}:538-543, {ref Matasović 2009}:310).

Traditionally derived from PIE *mud-so- ({ref Matasović 2009}:281, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:65, {ref IEW} 742) in comparison to Greek μύσος 'filth', however the etymology of the Greek form is unclear (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:985).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- '(finger)nail' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1086-1087, {ref EWAia} II:4-5, {ref ALEW} 681-682, {ref Derksen 2015}:327, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164, 170-173, {ref Derksen 2008}:355 {ref de Vaan 2008}:641, {ref Matasović 2009}:36). Indo-Iranian forms go back to an aberrant *(H)nákha-; some show early nasalization due to blend with aṅgúri- ~  aṅgúli- 'finger, toe' (°-aṅgulá-) or aṅguṣṭhá- 'thumb'; aṅká- 'hook' (RV) and later aṅkurá- 'hooked' may also have played a role, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}, no. 6914 + 134f. 137f., 100, 109; Addenda 6914
Perhaps from PIE *u̯élk̑-u-, if cognate with Skt. valśa- ‘sprout’, OCS vlasъ ‘hair’, Russ. vólos ‘hair’ ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:997).

The PIE root underlying these lexemes is generally reconstructed as *(s)per- 'to fly' ({ref ALEW} 955-956, {ref EWAia} II:97, cf. {ref LIV²} 579-580; without s-mobile {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:646-647). {ref Derksen 2008}:396 and {ref Derksen 2015}:419 favour a reconstruction *perH- in view of the Baltic acute accent in forms such as Lithuanian papártis and Latvian papãrde (cf. also {ref Derksen 1996}:79).
Loan from Old French grif 'claw' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:663).
loan_notes: Borrowed from Old French grif (13th century) from Old High German grifân with the development *skrif > skirf and dissimilation.

justificationDiscussion: No generally agreed etymology ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}:64-66, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:609-610, {ref Beekes 2010}:817-818. For a recent attempt, cf. {ref Nikolaev 2010}.
IE root etymology difficult. This class tentatively follows {ref Beekes 2010}:1503-1504, {ref LIV²} 650 s.v. *trep-, but cf. also {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1132-1133.
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat' ({ref NIL} 486-488, {ref Beekes 2010}:947).
An isolated archaic r/n-stem, probably connected with Vedic dhánuṣ- 'bow' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:210, {ref EWAia} I:773-774).

Tocharian, Indic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *su̯eh₂d- 'to make/become tasty' ({ref NIL} 670-675, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:795-796, {ref EWAia} II:788-789, {ref Kroonen 2013}:503, cf. {ref LIV²} 606-607).

Latin currere 'to run' and Romance lexemes continuing a PIE zero-grade thematic present stem *⁽k̑⁾r̥s-e/o-, derived from PIE *⁽k̑⁾ers- 'to run' ({ref LIV²} 355, {ref de Vaan 2008}:157-158, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:224 no. 2415).

In spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. {ref Hamp 1972}). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:322, {ref Beekes 2010}:299-300) generally follow the proposal of {ref Kortlandt 1985a}, assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'.

Anatolian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to crush, grind' ({ref LIV²} 432-433; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008} 547-548, {ref ALEW} 610-611, {ref Derksen 2015}:302-303, {ref ESSJa} 18:90-91, {ref Derksen 2008}:307}, {ref Kroonen 2013}:351, {ref de Vaan 2008}:386-387, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:58, M:32, {ref Matasović 2009}:255).
Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *kers- 'to cut (off)' ({ref LIV²} 355-356, {ref Malzahn 2010}:579-581, {ref Adams 2013}:176-177, cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:92).

Reflecting Proto-Celtic *bal-ni- 'to throw away, die', further derived from PIE *gʷelh₁- 'to throw' ({ref LIV²} 208, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:98, {ref Schumacher 2004}:211-212, {ref Matasović 2009}:53).

Italic lexemes continuing a derivative of PIE *dʰeh₁-k- 'to make, produce' ({ref LIV²} 139-140), widely considered to be connected to PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place, to set up; to do' ({ref LIV²} 136-138), but the origins of the k-element on the root remain obscure (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:198-199).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯d- 'to let go, release' ({ref ALEW} 567, 577-578; {ref LIV²} 402-403).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 480, {ref Smoczyński 2005}:191 for further discussion.

Compound verb with preverb ad- + claidid 'dig'. The verb continues Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'to dig, bury', probably via a periphrastic formation *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o- 'to make a stroke/stab' to PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:410-413, {ref Matasović 2009}:206, Britta Irslinger, p.c., cf. {ref LIV²} 350, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:111-112)

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'wood' in /cognate/3506/, 'tree' in /cognate/1074/, 'guts' in /cognate/5537/. For the reconstruction given, cf. ALEW s.v. Lith. vidùs.

justificationDiscussion: Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ({ref IEW} 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:97-98, {ref Derksen 2015}:530-531, {ref Kroonen 2013}:89, {ref Kluge 2011}:907 for further discussion.

Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place, to set up; to do' ({ref LIV²} 136-138; {ref ESSJa} 4:231-232; 5:7-8, {ref Derksen 2008}:102-103, {ref Seebold 1970}:157-160, {ref Kroonen 2013}:98, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:209-213, {ref de Vaan 2008}:198-199, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:271-272 no. 3128). The Italic forms in this class are generally agreed to be cognate, although exhibiting an extension *-k- of unclear origin (listed as a separate lemma ?*dʰeh₁k- in {ref LIV²} 139).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xudъ 'small, thin' and generally further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'to scatter, to crumble into small pieces' (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:111-113, {ref Derksen 2008}:205, {ref Polański 1962-1994}:198-199, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'to take, to obtain' ({ref LIV²} 250-251, {ref Derksen 2008}:350, {ref ESSJa} 25:19-23, {ref ALEW} 698-700).

notes: Reflexes of this root in Slavic have meanings 'hail', 'black, rain cloud', 'cloud', 'rainbow' etc.

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ 'black', further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾r̥s-nó- ({ref ESSJa} 4:155-157, {ref Derksen 2008}:92).

Most of the scholars ascertain that the etymology of PS *kut- is obscure. The etymologies of {ref ESSJa} and {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989} assume PIE roots (root extentions) not supported by {ref LIV²}. The etymologies are also hardly convincing semantically (the issue is, however, caused to a great extent by the semantic span within attested Slavic lexemes belonging here). Thus, they are not accepted here.
The etymology is not entirely clear but the word is probably related to Proto-Slavic onomatopoeic *pukati 'bang, knock, beat' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:489-490).
Due to its nursery character, any deeper etymology of this lexeme can not be convincingly proven.

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic  *sadъ 'plant', cf. Proto-Slavic *saditi 'to plant' from the causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to sit' ({ref Derksen 2008}:442-443, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1263, 1279-1280, {ref NIL} 590-600).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *tu̯erH- 'to grasp' ({ref Derksen 2008}:501, {ref ALEW} 1143, cf. {ref LIV²} 656).
As though from Proto-Slavic *životŭkŭ 'small stomach', the diminutive of *životŭ 'stomach' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:1054-1055), cf. 'belly' in /cognate/2238/ for further etymological discussion.

Armenian, Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *dṓm, (gen.sg. *dém-s) 'house' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:618, {ref EWAia} I:697, {ref ALEW} 684-686, {ref Derksen 2015}:328, {ref ESSJa} 5:72-73, {ref Derksen 2008}:113, {ref de Vaan 2008}:178-179).

The original meaning was 'cart with a tent, living cart, tent' > 'house', a derivative of Proto-Slavic *vezti 'drive, carry', ultimately from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'move, go (by a vehicle)'. (cf. {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1608, cf. {ref LIV²} 661-662),
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'carry' in /cognate/7547/, 'drink' in /cognate/1955/, 'fall' in /cognate/3661/, 'fly_pst3sg' in /cognate/1993/, 'run' in /cognate/6778/, 'swim' in /cognate/7464/.

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:417, {ref Derksen 2015}:343-344, {ref Boryś 2005}:424, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:435-436). The verbal root is preserved in Baltic (cf. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell').
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'to run away, flee' (cf. {ref LIV²} 67, {ref ESSJa} 2:58-60, 92, {ref ALEW} 103-104, {ref Derksen 2008}:40-41, {ref Derksen 2015}:85-86).

The history of the Slavic lexeme(s) for 'shadow' is complicated. It can not be excluded that we deal here with one single etymon. However, we had to assume irregular phonetic changes, contaminations and taboo-deformation in this case. It is also possible that we deal here with two or three independent etyma even from the most deep etymology perspective. Only PS *sěnĭ has a convincing further IE etymology and cognates that are relatively unproblematic from the phonetic point of view. PS *těnĭ and *stěnĭ can be derivatives of / results of a contamination with PIE *temH- 'dark' {ref LIV²}: 624 or PIE *stei̯h₂- 'stiffen' < probably PIE *steh₂- 'stand' {ref Kroonen 2013}: 472.

The root etymology in this set tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 238 to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' via a stem formation *h₁r̥-sk̑é-, although formally the Hellenic lexemes may also reflect a secondarily thematised present stem *h₁erg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ- to *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'to climb, ascend' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:377, {ref Beekes 2010}:468).

Hellenic and Celtic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1097, {ref Beekes 2010}:18-19, {ref Falileyev 2000}:3, {ref Schumacher 2004}:189-193, cf. {ref LIV²} 255-256). The Tsakonian lexemes in this class might instead go back to AGk. ἥκω 'I have come' (so {ref Andriotis 1974}:270), but a derivation from AGk. ἄγω 'go, drive' is more plausible (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
Parallel loans from German (cf. {ref Polański 1962-1994} 243-244, {ref Rejzek 2001}:272).

Traditionally compared to Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather' and further connected with PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- via *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- or *u̯edʰrom, although there are formal difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic comparanda (cf. discussion in /cognate/9440/). The difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic form, however, do not preclude the possibility of the derivation of the Slavic form being ultimately derived from PIE **h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow', however the uncertainty over the etymological identity of the proposed Germanic cognates weakens the case somewhat (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:513, {ref Kroonen 2013}:583-584, {ref Snoj 1997-2016} 4:287-288).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/1662/, 'swell' in /cognate/3436/, 'wind' in /cognate/342/, perhaps also 'wind' in /cognate/9440/.

justificationDiscussion: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *sal- 'salt' ({ref NIL 586-590, cf. {ref ALEW} 586-587, {ref Derksen 2015}:387-388, {ref Derksen 2008}:459. Cf. 'salt' in /cognate/283/ for further discussion of the root reconstruction.

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁em- 'to take' ({ref LIV²} 236, cf. {ref ALEW} 395-397, {ref Derksen 2015}:200-201, {ref ESSJa} 6:71, {ref Derksen 2008}:158, 533). The cognacy in this class follows {ref LIV²} 236 s.v. *h₁em-, but cf. also {ref LIV²} 453 s.v. 1. *nem-; it is possible that these two roots formed a rhyming pair in PIE.

The etymology is considered as uncertain and relatively many different IE comparanda are given, cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 3: 315, {ref Boryś 2005}: 613, {ref Rejzek 2001}: 74. However, the hypothesis of {ref Derksen 2008}: 35, 466 is attractive and has been adopted here. For the semantic development see also /cognate/7765/.

notes: Further etymology uncertain. It is probably an expressive variant of PS *svig- (cf. Polish śmigać and dialectal świgać) which can be linked to PIE *su̯ei̯- 'bend, spin, wave'.

justificationDiscussion: Slavic innovation (maybe taboo-motivated) without certain etymology. There are two most popular hypotheses on its etymology: 1) *demh₂- 'build' > 'wood used/good for building' > 'oak'; 2) *dʰu̯eh₂- 'smoke' > 'dark' > 'tree with dark wood'. {ref ESSJa} links it to *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' > 'lowland tree'. None of the versions seems to be really convincing.

While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of providing a root reference form for this cognate set, we have followed the analysis of {ref Beekes 2004}, cf. also {ref Beekes 2010}:470-471) s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. {ref LIPP 2} s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-. For the lexemes in this class cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:259, {ref Beekes 2010}:470-471, {ref ALEW} 1174-1175, {ref Derksen 2015}:485, {ref Derksen 2008}:513, 536. (–MJCS). The first vowel is irregularly reduced in Slavic, cf. Slavic večer- 'evening' with a regular reflex. (–LJ).

Italic and Romance lexemes from Latin umbra, possibly to be further connected to Lithuanian ùnksna 'shade, shadow' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:639, {ref Derksen 2015}:479, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1164) but cf. {ref ALEW} 1147, 1149-1150, doubting connections outside of Lithuanian and with further discussion. Further connections outside of Italic consequently unclear.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Hellenistic or Roman period Greek *ὀσπίτιον, via Medieval Greek σπίτι(ν), either a Hellenistic or Late Antique loan from Latin hospitium 'lodging, guest-house' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1314).
loan_notes: From Latin hospitium: late antique or earlier medieval borrowing, not attested in Classical texts but borrowed before the procope of unstressed vowels

justificationDiscussion: Latin and Romance lexemes, traditionally compared to Sanskrit amlá- 'sour, acid', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, cold', but many formal details remain unclear (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:25, {ref de Vaan 2008}:37; cf. {ref EIEC} 69). For Modern Romance forms, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:31-32.

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *lixъ 'superfluous, incorrect' and generally further derived as though from PIE *lei̯kʷ-so- (cf. {ref ESSJa} 15:99-102, {ref Derksen 2008}:278, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 2:505, {ref NIL} 451-453).

Origin and structure uncertain, cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:419, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 4:255, {ref Rejzek 2001}:455-456, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1053-1054, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:186 for various proposals.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *orbiti 'do, work', a derivative of *orbъ 'servant, slave' and ultimately derived from PIE *h₃erbʰ- ({ref ESSJa} 32:116-118, {ref Derksen 2008}:373).
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to perceive, see' (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:86-88, {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} III:253, {ref LIV²} 561).
Loanword from Polish budynek 'building', itself ultimately a loanword from Middle German buding 'building' ({ref Boryś 2005}:45).

Most often interpreted as containing PIE *dʰeh₁- 'put' ({ref LIV²}: 136-138), cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}: 688, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4: 255, see below. An alternative is to compare is with PIE *Hou̯Hdʰ-, cf. Russian udit' 'swell, fill with' and PS *vymę 'udder' and English udder, cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 149, {ref Derksen 2008}: 507, 534-535 and {Boryś 2005}: 663. This latter etymology seems to be more attractive, however in light of the shortness of the root (2 phonemes) and the lack of any IE cognates with a similar meaning, it remains speculative.
Shortened from 'white head', cf. older Polish białogłowa 'women'. Cf. 'white' in /cognate/1190/ for further etymological discussion.

The etymology and further cognacy is obscure. It can be derived from PIE 2*(s)ker- 'scratch, cut off, shear' ({ref LIV²}: 556-557), cf. {ref EWAia}: 537 and {ref Kroonen 2013} or *ser- 'knot together' {ref LIV²}: 534, {ref de Vaan 2008}: 557-558 and {ref ESSJa}: 8: 75. See {ref Vasmer 1953-1958} for a summary of existing hypotheses.
Continuing a causative stem formation *tu̯orH-éi̯e- to PIE *tu̯erH- 'to grasp' ({ref LIV²} 656, {ref Derksen 2008}:501).
Derived from Proto-Slavic *goniti 'chase, persecute', ultimately derived from *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref ESSJa 7:23, 196-197, {ref Derksen 2008}:177, {ref LIV²} 218-219).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'cut' in /cognate/6606/, 'hit' in /cognate/1998/, 'kill' in /cognate/3551/, 'throw' in /cognate/8806/, 'hunt' in /cognate/1298/, 'tail' in /cognate/1935/.

justificationDiscussion:
The etymology of this root is not entirely clear.
The hypothesis about a borrowing from Gothic is rather speculative because the Gothic form *gataws itself is not attested and only reconstructed (as a nominal derivative of gataujan 'fulfil, act, accomplish') {ref ESSJa}. The Albanian gat 'ready' etc. is most probably a loan from Slavic {ref Orel 1998}, note also a suspiciously similar set of meanings {ref ESSJa} here.
The idea about a derivation of the Slavic lexemes from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'walk, go' with a semantic development '(get) ready to go, prepare(d) for a journey' > '(get) ready, prepare(d)' (> 'do, make') has good IE parallels (cf. German bereit and fertig with secondary derivatives as vorbereiten, zubereiten 'prepare, make', anfertigen 'make', English ready). An issue is that the meaning 'go' is hardly (if ever) attested in Slavic. Its hypothetical traces in Old Russian are very sparse and not unambiguous: negotovami dorogami 'untrodden roads'. However, this etymology seems to be reasonable and is adopted here.
Loanword from Germanic *hūsa- ({ref ESSJa} 8:159-160, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *tekti, in turn derived from PIE *tekʷ- ({ref Derksen 2008}:489, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:159, cf. {ref LIV²} 620-621).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'come' in /cognate/15/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/3259/, 'river' in /cognate/5249/ 'swell' in /cognate/1881/, 'turn' in /cognate/3066/.

justificationDiscussion: Of onomatopoeic origin from the interjection 'joj, joh' (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}:232, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
Loan from German Krampel, Krämpel 'claw' ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
Slavic lexemes from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ({ref Derksen 2008}:115, {ref LIV²} 128-129, cf. {ref ESSJa} 5:101-102 assuming a basic root *der- with a root extension).

Etymology disputed.
