There are two main possibilities: either to (1) pre-form *kuHso- '(place of) protection', a derivation from the IE verbal root *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover', or to (2) pre-Proto-Germanic *kudʰso- to the IE verbal root *keu̯dʰ- 'to hide' cf. {ref EWA 4}:1288-1290 for further details of either etymology, with references; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:260.

Traditionally considered cognate with Proto-Germanic *hakan- 'hook' ({ref ESSJa} 10:109-110, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 2:275, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:387), although extra-Germanic connections to the Germanic comparanda are doubted by {ref Kroonen 2013}:203 on the basis of formal difficulties. [Not in {ref Derksen 2008}].

notes: The Etymological Dictionary of Belarusian claims that this lexeme is a derivative from Proto-Slavic *kyp- 'seethe' (Proto-Indo-European ku̯eh₁p-). However, it seems unconvincing.

justificationDiscussion: The etymology is disputable and not entirely clear, cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 1: 15, {ref Boryś 2005}: 28 or {ref Rejzek 2001}: 74. However, the hypothesis of {ref ESSJa}, considered also by {ref Derksen 2008}: 35, is attractive. For the semantic development see also /cognate/7765/.
There is no certain etymology ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:396). The relationship to Proto-Slavic *prǫtŭ and Russian prygat' is dubious.

The history of the Slavic lexeme(s) for 'shadow' is complicated. It can not be excluded that we deal here with one single etymon. However, we had to assume irregular phonetic changes, contaminations and taboo-deformation in this case. It is also possible that we deal here with two or three independent etyma even from the most deep etymology perspective. Only PS *sěnĭ has a convincing further IE etymology and cognates that are relatively unproblematic from the phonetic point of view. PS *těnĭ and *stěnĭ can be derivatives of / results of a contamination with PIE *temH- 'dark' {ref LIV²}: 624 or PIE *stei̯h₂- 'stiffen' < probably PIE *steh₂- 'stand' {ref Kroonen 2013}: 472.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: May be related to the other Slavic lexemes for shadow (cf. Proto-Slavic *sěn- in /cognate/5058/, Proto-Slavic *těn- in /cognate/5149/) but with irregular sound changes and contamination. No certain solution.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:244, {ref ESSJa} 12:70-74, {ref Snoj 1997-2016} for further discussion.

notes: Note that the original Slavic meaning was 'good'. The meaning 'sweet' in some South Slavic languages is a later innovation.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain ({ref ESSJa} 2:174, {ref Derksen 2008}:51-52). Some attempts have been made to connect the root to the same found in 'white' < PIE *bʰelH- (cf. /cognate/1190), but the additional *-g- found on the stem lacks a convincing morphological explanation.
Slavic lexemes generally derived from a causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to seat (oneself)' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:202-203, {ref ESSJa} 8:49-52, {ref LIV²} 513-515).

The link to PIE *terkʷ- is formally and semantically attractive. An alternative etymology points to PIE *(s)ter- 'hard(en)', cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}, however it has formal and semantical issues (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4:227)
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:418, {ref LIPP 2}:639, cf. {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 5:577-581, 586-584).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'right' in /cognate/1238/, 'say' in /cognate/4832/, 'straight' in /cognate/1180/, and 'true' in /cognate/1207/.

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Turkish kanca 'hook' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 2:201).

In {ref ESSJa}: 3: 103 it is claimed that this word can be native. The support were East Slavic dialectal but referring to various kinds of 'onion' or 'beet', cf. also PS *buta, *butati, *butiti. However, it is possible that we deal with two different etyma here.
loan_notes: It is sometimes claimed (cf. ESSJ) that the word is native (PS *but-).

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *garj́ʰ- 'to lament'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:475, 495, {ref Cheung 2007}:111-112). {ref LIV²} 187 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾eRg̑ʰ-.

notes: Considering the Parthian form gwyʾw and the ZMP form gwbyʾ, one may reconstruct a bilabial glide. There is a possibility that this word is a compound of gauu- "cow" and a second element, cf. Old Ind. *Hyavas- "pasture" or  yáva- "wheat".

Bailey (1979: 50f.) connects the house word kata- and the city word kanthā- in Saka with a verbal root 'kan' "to cover, hide". Cheung (2007: 232) notes the Sogdian city word knδh (and variants) with the root 'kanH' "to dig". This would not work with the hourse word because kn̩Hta- would give kāta-. It may rather be the root 'kan'  "to throw, place, put; destroy' (Cheung 2007: 229, although the 'destroy' meaning may rather derive from 'kanH' "to dig"). Note Old Ind. khánāmi, which if deriving from *kh₂ would account for the other Iranic house word xān-.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed. {ref ESIJa} 4:340-348 groups Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' together with Proto-Iranic *xāna- 'house', both as derivatives from Proto-Iranic *kanH- (1) 'to dig' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:232-233), although this etymology is rejected by {ref Bartholomae 1904}:432. Alternatively {ref Bailey 1979}:50 considers to a verb *kat- 'to cover, hide' (rejected by {ref ESIJa} 4:340-341). If from a PIE root *kenH- 'to dig', the aspiration found in xāna- is difficult to account for in Iranic except by comparison with Vedic khan- 'to dig', although this is usually explained by contamination with kha- 'canal, opening, hole', khā́- 'source, spring' within Indic ({ref Cheung 2007}:233). In view of the formal difficulties, Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' and *xāna- 'house' have been split into separate cognate sets. For further discussion regarding the difficulties of the reconstruction of the Indo-Iranic root 'to dig', cf. /cognate/7327/.

notes: Note Old Ind. khánāmi, which if deriving from *kh₂ would account for the Iranic ‘house’ word xān- (besides the kadag-forms). If it is related to “dig”, the question remains, why this verb usually appears with #k and not #x (cf. Mayrhofer 1992: 445), cf. also Cheung (2007: 231) “In many Iranian languages the roots *kan1 ‘to throw’, *kanH1 ’to dig’ and *kan2 ‘to fill’ forms are homonymous and therefore often show mutual interference.”
justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed. {ref ESIJa} 4:340-348 groups Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' together with Proto-Iranic *xāna- 'house', both as derivatives from Proto-Iranic *kanH- (1) 'to dig' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:232-233), although this etymology is rejected by {ref Bartholomae 1904}:432. Alternatively {ref Bailey 1979}:50 considers to a verb *kat- 'to cover, hide' (rejected by {ref ESIJa} 4:340-341). If from *kenH-, the aspiration found in xāna- is difficult to account for in Iranic except by comparison with Vedic khan- 'to dig', although this is usually explained by contamination with kha- 'canal, opening, hole', khā́- 'source, spring' within Indic ({ref Cheung 2007}:233). In view of the formal difficulties, Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' and *xāna- 'house' have been split into separate cognate sets. For further discussion regarding the difficulties of the reconstruction of the Indo-Iranic root 'to dig', cf. /cognate/7327/.
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *dʰeu̯- 'to move, go' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:789-790, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:389 no.6802, {ref Cheung 2007}:65-66, {ref LIV²} 147-148).
lit. 'milk', Iranic adjective formation *xšīraina-. No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref KEWA} I:290, {ref EWAia} I:490).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ({ref LIV²} 201, {ref EWAia} I:505-507, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:227 no. 4236, {ref Cheung 2007}:119-121).

There is no generally accepted etymology for Proto-Germanic *klawō- outside of Germanic ({ref Kluge 2011}:496-497, {ref Kroonen 2013}:292). {ref Adams 2013}:219 suggests a possible connection to with Proto-Tocharian **kolʸ- 'animal's foot'(?) but this remains uncertain.
Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *karš-/*xrah- 'to draw, plough', further to PIE *kʷels- 'to draw a furrow' ({ref Cheung 2007}:241-243, {ref EWAia} I:319-320, {ref LIV²} 388-389).
Loanword from Anglo-Norman carier ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 499-500 to PIE *reh₁dʰ- 'to successfully accomplish', but cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:432, 437.

Despite of the formal similarity of Polish miano and Kashubian miono with doubtless reflexes of PS *jĭmę, *jĭmene, the relationship of the former to the latter is far from clear. The main formal problem is the root vowel (*-ě- vs. *-e-). The lack of initial i- in miano, miono is, in general, not a crucial issue.
Some sources entirely ignore the formal problems {ref Derksen 2008}, {ref ESSJa}. Vasmer proposes a protoform *jĭměn- for Polish miano {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 130, however he does not explain the nature of this irregular lengthening.
Polish etymologists assume that imię and miano are two distinct etymona, the former being a reflex of a common IE lexeme for 'name' and the latter being a derivative of a verbal root referring to 'thinking', 'mentioning', 'considering as', 'giving a name' etc. Cf. {Boryś 2005}: 320. The formal anlysis is hindered by morphological levellings and conaminations. If Kashubian miono is derived from PS *měno, -o- has been taken from plural forms of *jĭmę, *jĭmene, cf. Polish imiona 'names'. According to the general policy, a cautious view is adopted here. As to the root reference form *men-, see {ref LIV²}: 435-436.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *srau̯- 'to hear, listen', further to PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ({ref Cheung 2007}:356-357, {ref EWAia} II:666-667, {ref LIV²} 334-335).

notes: Bartholomae (1904: 1523) quotes the reconstruction *srān°. In Ossetic also "belt".
justificationDiscussion: Modern Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *rāna- 'upper part of the leg, thigh', cf. Avestan rāna- 'id.' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:201, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:91). Further etymology uncertain, but cf. {ref EWAia} I:108, III:21 for proposed but uncertain cognates in Indic.

notes: s, not š, in Nuristani.
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dau̯šā́- 'evening; night', no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:750, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:376 no. 6590).
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰrem- 'to buzz, to bellow' ({ref Cheung 2007}:24, {ref LIV²} 94).

notes: cf. Avestan frā̊nk-/ Instrumental sg. frača and Old Indic prā́ñc-
Bailey (1979: 285) discussing Saka bīma- "rock" suggests a verbal root *vai- "to cut" (cf. Cheung 2007: 407). Cf. Av. vaēma- "Felsspalte, Felskluft".
cf. Avestan xšuuiptauuaṇt- "mit Melkmilch versehen"; *xšu̯iptī̆ka- (?)

justificationDiscussion: Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, flow' ({ref Adams 2013}:267, {ref EWAia} I:610-611, {ref Bailey 1979}:121-122, 182-183, cf. {ref LIV²} 620-621).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'come' in /cognate/15/, 'run' in /cognate/5199/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/3259/, 'swell' in /cognate/1881/, 'turn' in /cognate/3066/.

justificationDiscussion: Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *ter- 'to speak' ({ref ALEW} 1076-1078, {ref LIV²} 630-631

notes: = Lat. CORRERE (Buck 1949: 677)

justificationDiscussion: Root ref. form follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, but note that the Proto-Luwic form this class represents may also formally represent *gʷelH-. Cf. {ref LIV²} 679.

Etymology disputed. {ref Orel 1998}:496 and {ref LIV²} 620-621 assign the verb to *tekʷ-, against which cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1001-1002. {ref Holm 2011:57} also rejects *tekʷ-, instead suggesting *dʰgʷʰei̯- 'hinschwinden, sterben' as a more plausible alternative. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1001-1002 propose a speculative etymology to a root *dekʷs-.
Generally considered to go back to an IE root *kʷer- 'to cut (off), to cut up' ({ref LIV²} 391-392, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:486).
An derivative of the root *u̯eh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'to break' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:939-940, {ref LIV²} 664-665).

There are several different nominal derivations within Germanic here that are based on PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split' ({ref LIV²} 70-71); cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:66, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:115, 126-127, {ref Kluge 2011}:127, {ref Lehmann 1986}:58-59, {ref de Vries 1977}:30).
An i-stem adjective derived to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:620-621, {ref NIL} 562-564).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/4527/, 'mountain' in /cognate/2804/, 'hand' in /cognate/1712/, 'thin' in /cognate/1923/, 'smooth' in /cognate/6801/, 'earth' in /cognate/5892/, 'stand' in /cognate/8055/, 'tree' in /cognate/8103/.

justificationDiscussion: Continuing Proto-Iranic *gaH- 'to go, move', from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ({ref Bailey 1979}:114-115, {ref Cheung 2007}:93-94, {ref EWAia} I:482, {ref LIV²} 205).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:524, {ref de Vries 1977}:624 for further discussion.
Root ref. form in this class follows {ref LIV²} 243 s.v. *h₁eu̯-, but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:227-229 reconstructing *h₂eu̯-.
Possibly from PIE *mergʷ- if to be compared with Proto-Germanic *merkwa- 'dark' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:562-563, cf. also {ref Heidermanns 1993}:409-410, {ref Kroonen 2013}:366).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:666).
The root reconstruction in this cognate set follows {ref LIV²} 307, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:828-829, {ref Beekes 2010}:1113 for additional discussion.
From PIE *mneh₂- according to {ref Starke 1990}:147; tentatively accepted by {ref LIV²} 447.
Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:592). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:470, {ref Beekes 2010}:600-601 for various proposals.
Balto-Slavic lexemes from PIE *(h₂)u̯elk- 'to drag, pull' ({ref Derksen 2008}:514, {ref Derksen 2015}:504, {ref ALEW} 1244-1245, {ref LIV²} 289-290).
Slavic lexemes generally derived from PIE *kreu̯H- 'to heap up; to cover' ({ref LIV²} 371, {ref Derksen 2008}:254). For older hypotheses, cf. {ref ESSJa} 13:71-72.
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *ugʷ-ro- 'wet', a Caland adjective in *-ro- to *u̯egʷ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1525-1526).
No clear correspondences outside of Greek ({ref Beekes 2010}:1038). For an attempt at an IE etymology, cf. {ref LIPP 2} 392, 717.

Germanic lexemes, generally considered a compound of Gmc. *ǣ- 'weg, fort' and the stem of the Germanic verb *maitan- 'schneiden', with a -jōn- suffix for forming a nomen agentis, cf. {ref EWA 1}:203-204, {ref Kluge 2011}:38, 613. Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:24 for alternative hypotheses for the reconstruction of the initial prefix.
From PIE *treu̯d- 'to strike' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:630, {ref LIV²} 651-652; cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:704).
No certain etymology ({ref ALEW} 242).

notes: The Tocharian words derive either from ie. *dʰeu̯H- or *dʰu̯eh₂-, cf. /cognate/2463/. On of these roots might in fact be the basis for ie. *dʰu̯ens- from which the Germanic 'dust'-words are derived (cf. /cognate/2464/), but they cannot be assigned the same cognate class on this level of analysis and regarding the state of the art concerning root extensions. -  Also cf. 'ashes' /cognate/2463/ and 'smoke' in /cognate/123/.

justificationDiscussion: Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *wambō- 'womb, belly'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:393, {ref Kroonen 2013}:572, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:674).

Latin and Romance lexemes derived from PIE *peh₂u̯- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:448, 450-451, although note that Catalan poc directly continues Latin paucus 'few, small in number', not Latin paruus 'small' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:519).

Latin cōgitō 'to think, consider', a derived frequentative/intensive form of Latin agō 'to drive' < PIE *h₂eg̑- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:15-18, {ref de Vaan 2008}:30-31). For the Romance forms in this class cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:838-842, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:192.
Loanword from Latin piscem 'fish' ({ref Meyer 1891}:329, {ref Huld 1984}:103, {ref Orel 1998}:316-317, {ref Holm 2011}:63)

Exact derivation of the Tocharian B word from the PIE root debated, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:590 and {ref ALEW} 560 s.v. lãšišas. Cognates in other branches specifically mean 'salmon' (cf. {ref EIEC} 497 for further discussion).
Loanword from Latin spīna 'thorn, spine; spine, backbone' ({ref Orel 1998}:430).
Loanword from Middle Low German slichts ({ref Karulis 1992} II:227).
Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:640 for discussion and suggestions.

Latin flāuus 'yellow', from PIE *bʰleh₃-u̯o-, a derivative of PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:225, cf. {ref LIV²} 88). For Old Irish blá attached to this class not in the target meaning, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:54-55).
Loanword from Italian frutto 'fruit' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1562).

notes: cf. IEW 951ff.

justificationDiscussion: Probably from a compound containing *h₁en- 'in' + temh₁- 'cut off' ({ref Adams 2013}:92-93).
Generally considered a loanword from Albanian lule 'flower' or Latin līlum 'lily' (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:791-792).
loan_notes: Generally considered a loanword from either Albanian lule 'flower' or Latin līlium 'lily'.

notes: From Old French escorce which itself either goes back directly to Latin or is a loan from Medieval Latin scorcia, cf. http://www.etymologiebank.nl/trefwoord/schors. Thus ultimately connected to /cognate/182/.

justificationDiscussion: Modern Greek lexemes derived from Ancient Greek κάμνω 'exert oneself, build; be tired (from work)' → 'make something (using technical means)' → 'make, do' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:629), ultimately derived from PIE *k̑emh₂- via a nasal-present stem *k̑m̥-né/n-h₂- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:490, {ref Beekes 2010}:632, {ref LIV²} 323-324).
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:901-902 for a critical appraisal of previous proposals.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:158 for various proposals).
Without clear correspondences outside of Greek ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:236-237, {ref Beekes 2010}:951-952).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing an Ancient Greek denominal verb μυρίζω 'to salve, perfume', derived from Ancient Greek μύρον 'salve, perfume' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:903). Perhaps further cognate with Germanic Celtic words 'to smear, fat' (OHG smero 'smear', OIr. smi(u)r 'marrow') < *smer-u-, but a Semitic loanword may well be equally as likely; cf. AGk. μύρρα 'myrrh, sweet-smelling word of the myrrh plant', Aram. mūrā, Heb. mōr, Arab. murr 'myrrh' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:983).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:243-244, {ref Beekes 2010}:289-290, 293).

Romance lexemes from Latin āēr 'air' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:18), an early loanword in Latin (already attested by Ennius, late 3rd - early 2nd c. BCE) from Ancient Greek ἄηρ ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:11).
loan_notes: Early loanword event in Latin (already attested Ennius, late 3rd - early 2nd c. BCE).

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:147, {ref de Vaan 2008}:141).

notes: Loan from English 'bite'.
justificationDiscussion: A borrowing from English 'bite, bit' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:36).
The root etymology in this cognate set follows {ref LIV²} 154 to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to haul, to pull', cf. also {ref Kroonen 2013}:99, {ref Lehmann 1986}:93-94, {ref Seebold 1970}:160-162.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'walk' in /cognate/5824/, 'run' in /cognate/5027/ 'pull' in /cognate/2839/, probably also 'turn' in /cognate/660/.

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes reflecting Proto-Germanic *wai̯nōn-, a weak verb presumably derived from Proto-Germanic *wai- 'woe'. Further connections among the Indo-European languages going back to a PIE interjection *u̯ai 'woe!' (e.g. Latin vae, Old Irish fae, Welsh gwae, etc.) may be possible, although parallel onomatopoeic formations cannot be ruled out in principle ({ref Kluge 2011}:979, 975, {ref Kroonen 2013}:566-567; cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:650, {ref Matasović 2009}:405, {ref IEW} 1110-1111).
Etymology outside of Italic unclear ({ref Untermann 2000}:821-822, {ref de Vaan 2008}:651-652).
From PIE *treb- 'dwell', a Western Indo-European isogloss common to Celtic, Italic, Germanic, and Baltic ({ref Untermann 2000}:765-766, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:388-389, {ref ALEW} 1126).

As though from PIE *solH-i- ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:709-711). Cf. however {ref HED SA} alternatively considering connections to other vocabulary from a Hittite stem *sall- 'swell, expand' to be ultimately connected with Proto-Germanic *swellan- (but cf. 'swell' in /cognate/315/, generally considered without certain etymology). Cf. also Tischler Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar 2/1:767-775 for further discussion.
Etymology uncertain, possibly to PIE *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' if from *dʰēubotyo- (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:296-297).
Generally derived from a PIE s-stem *h₁regʷ-os- ({ref Olsen 1999}:203, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:259-261).

Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *nebʰ- '(to become) wet, cloudy, vaporous' ({ref NIL} 499-504, cf. {ref EWAia} I:94, II:13, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:400 no. 6955c, {ref de Vaan 2008}:299, {ref Untermann 2000}:95-96).

Root etymology disputed. Traditionally to IE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. {ref IEW} 21-22, {ref Buck 1949}:1069, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:806-807), but this is difficult from a morphological point of view. Alternatively {ref Narten 1986}:204-214 has proposed a comparison with Ved. √akṣ- which could allow a Greek zero-grade formation *h₃k̑s- > ὀξ-, but this proposal has not been met with widespread acceptance (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1089).
Classical Armenian am 'year' seems to continue an old deverbative stem *sem-(e)h₂- ({ref Olsen 1999}:60, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:45-46; cf. {ref EWAia} II:704).

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *takan- 'to touch; take', probably further to be derived from PIE *teh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'to touch, grasp' ({ref LIV²} 616-617, {ref Kroonen 2013}:507, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:507).
Continuing Old English tacan, an early borrowing from Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic taka 'to grasp, seize', etc. ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Romance lexemes from Latin portāre 'carry' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:554), further probably a denominal verb to Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'a passage, crossing' and to PIE 1. *per- 'come through, cross' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:482-483, cf. {ref LIV²} 472-473).

Umbrian pelmner from a Proto-Italic stem *pelp-men-, cf. Latin pulpa 'meat', pulmentum 'meat dish' < Proto-Italic *pelp-men-to-, pointing to a Proto-Italic root *pelp-. No further known cognates outside of Italic, however (cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:528, {ref de Vaan 2008}:497-498).

The Celtic and Italic lexemes in this class are generally agreed to be cognate, although some aspects of the formal reconstruction of a common root are uncertain ({ref LIV²} 195, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:277-278, {ref Schumacher 2004}:318-324, {ref Matasović 2009}:148-149).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Possibly related to 'give' in /cognate/228/ (cf. notes in LIV²).

justificationDiscussion: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian krak 'fire, flames', further origin uncertain, perhaps an Iranian loan ({ref HAB} II:678-679, {ref Olsen 1999}:943), cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:378; cf. s.v. for less likely proposed Indo-European etymologies). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kur-aka-].

Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic rúh 'growth, spurting' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:624 no.10795), further to Vedic √rudh- 'to grow' from PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- 'to rise, grow' ({ref EWAia} II:467-468, cf. {ref LIV²} 248-249).
Etymology uncertain ({ref Kluge 2011}:536).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. SMG 'swell' in /cognate/8318/ (derived from West Greek loan), Italiot 'swell' in /cognate/6020/ (inherited).

justificationDiscussion: Possibly to be connected with Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip-joint' ({ref HED A+E/I}:424-425), but this is disputed (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:602-603). In view of the phonological similarity and the areal proximity of the languages it could be possible that both Greek ἰσχίον and Hitt. iškiš- are both independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:402).

The only plausible etymology outside of Anatolian is the proposed connection with Armenian argand 'womb' with the proviso that the Armenian sound laws permit it ({ref Čop 1955}, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:733), but this proposal rejected by {ref Martirosyan 2010}:130-131.

From PIE *u̯erh₁- 'to be hot'; the root reference form for this set follows the reconstruction of {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:923-925, cf. {ref LIV²} 689 reconstructing *u̯erH- with indeterminate final laryngeal.

To maintain the connection with Lat. albus, Gk. ἀλφός, etc. (cf. /cognate/955/), one must postulate reconstructing a fourth laryngeal that is a-colouring but lost in Anatolian (i.e. *h₄elbʰo-); alternatively one could reconstruct *albʰo- with an original *a in the root but this likewise a less satisfactory solution (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:169).
No clear Indo-European etymology ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:440), cf. {ref HED K} 66-72 for older unconvincing proposals.

notes: Initial H may be either *h₁ or *h₃ (Kloekhorst 2008:167-168).
justificationDiscussion: A root restricted to Anatolian. {ref LIV²} 234-235 mechanically reconstructs ?*h₁e⁽k̑⁾- 'to die'; {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:167-168 assumes *Hók- / *Hk- with indeterminable laryngeal under the assumption that laryngeals merged with *h₁ before *o in Anatolian (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2006}).
Hittite ḫātant- 'dry' is originally an participle derived to PIE *h₂ed- 'to dry up' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:328-329, {ref LIV²} 255).
Root ref. form follows {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:564-566 to *meu̯h₁- 'to move (oneself), but cf. {ref LIV²} 445-446 reconstructing *mi̯eu̯h₁-.
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *neh₂- 'to become afraid' ({ref LIV²} 449, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:591-592).
Root ref. form and analysis follows {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:358-360. For older proposals cf. {ref HED H}:363-368.
No clear etymology; often considered to be a non-Indo-European Wanderwort (cf. {ref Weeks 1985}:125, {ref HED A+E/I}:32-33 for further discussion).

Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ({ref IEW} 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:601; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:234-235, {ref HED A+E/I}:257-259, {ref Matasović 2009}:435).
Maybe to be connected with Hittite šiš- 'to prosper, proliferate', but no further etymology outside of Hittite ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:749, 756-757).

Probably an from an IE s-stem *h₃er-es- 'high' to PIE *h₃er- 'rise' (cf. {ref LIV²} 299-300) that has been secondarily transferred into -r/n- inflection, which is morphologically productive in Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:314-315).

For the root reconstruction, see {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} for {ref LIV²} 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben', cf. also {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:945-946.

Literally a participle to the verbal root ā(i)- 'to be hot'; further etymology uncertain. For competing IE root analyses cf. {ref LIV²} 229, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:164-166, with references to further literature.
By internal reconstruction, possibly from a nasal-infix stem *h₂ur-n-H to a root *h₂u̯erH- although there are no certain cognates outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:372; not in {ref LIV²}).
Etymology uncertain ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:533-534, cf. {ref HED L}:111-114, 127-128).

No convincing etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:525). {ref HED L}:97-98 suggests a connection to Armenian leard, but the Armenian forms are more generally considered to be connected to the inherited IE word for 'liver' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:306-307 and notes to /cognate/718/).
Derived from PIE *h₂edʰ⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to press' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:334-335, {ref LIV²} 255).

Derived from Hittite *maninkuu̯a- (adj.) 'near' (cf. {ref CHD L-N} 170-174). Further etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:554 for further discussion. See also 'short' in /cognate/3324/. For the reconstructed stem of the adjective, cf. {ref CHD L-N} 170.

Always written using the Sumerograms LÚ.ŠU.GI, but probably to be related to Hitt. mēḫur 'time, period', from which a stem *meḫuu̯ant- can be reconstructed on the basis of derived vocabulary ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:568-569, cf. derived factitive verb meḫuu̯andaḫḫ- 'to make old; to age', etc.). Further root etymology disputed. According to {ref Eichner 1973}:53-107, ultimately to PIE *meh₂- 'to be at the right time'; {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:567-568 to *mei̯h₂- 'disappear' (= {ref LIV²} 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, verschwinden sein'), or to *meh₁- 'measure' (semantically better, but formally more difficult). {ref Yakubovich 2011}:277-279 argues to *meh₁-, with the presence of Hitt. -ḫ- explained by secondary epenthesis.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:349-352 for a critical survey of previous proposals.

Generally agreed to be derived from PIE *seu̯h₁- 'incite, set in motion', but some debate remains over the precise details of the verbal stem formation (cf. {ref LIV²} 538-539, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:797-798).

Etymology uncertain, possibly connected with Ancient Greek αἰονάω 'to moisten' (cf. {ref Melchert 1994}:102), but this proposal is not without some formal difficulties ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:340-341, cf. also {ref HED H}:301-304).
IE root etymology disputed, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:493-494 for a critical discussion of competing alternatives; see also {ref HED K} 245-248.
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *h₁erH- 'to wash', cf. TochA yär- 'to bathe' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:197-198, {ref LIV²} 239).
Anatolian lexemes derived from PIE *nei̯H- 'to lead' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:598-600, {ref LIV²} 450-451).

Etymology in this class follows {ref Oettinger 1979}:523-524, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:195-196 to *h₃er-; but cf. {ref LIV²} assigning to *h₁er- (although {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} also listing *h₃er- as a possible root etymology).
Possibly to *h₁u̯ers-, if cognate with Vedic varṣá- 'rain', and Ancient Greek ἐέρση 'dew' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:971-972).
Etymology uncertain; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:878-879 for a speculative proposal based on a possible etymological figure.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fleugōn 'fly', continuing a derivative from a root *pleu̯k- that is generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:146, {ref EWA 3}:385-388).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'wing' in /cognate/343/, 'bird' in /cognate/186/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/224/, 'swim' in /cognate/8317/, 'hair' in /cognate/1902/, 'feather' in /cognate/2263/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain. {ref HED A+E/I}:260-261 suggests to *ei̯-gʰ- ({ref IEW} 296) : Lith. eigà 'a going', Gk. οἴχομαι 'go off, be gone', ἴχνος 'footstep, track', TochB yku 'gone', thus egdu < *ei̯gʰ-tu- 'a going' > 'leg' by metonymy, but this is speculative. No lemma in {ref Kloekhorst 2008}.
Etymology unknown. {ref Melchert 1994}:132 compares Lat. surcus 'twig, sprout', but {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:792-793 argues that the Latin comparandum is a ghost word.
Etymology uncertain; cf. {ref HED A+E/I}:178-182 and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:212 for various proposals.
No known etymology ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:980).

From PIE *(s)lei̯-, perhaps via an extended variant *(s)lei̯b- (cf. {ref LIV²} 566 s.v. ?*(s)lei̯b- 'scheifen, gleiten', only Germanic), cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:134, {ref Deshayes 2003}:458, {ref Matasović 2009}:239, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}.

{ref Kloekhorst 2008}:393-394 considers the root to be an m-extended form of *seh₂- 'bind', but even if so Skt. sā́man- 'song, hymn' < *sh₂óm-en- demonstrates that such a formation must have already been of PIE date. The root ref. form for this class has therefore been given as *sh₂em- [Not in {ref LIV²}.]

Root ref. form follows the reconstruction of {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:1021-1022, although there are no known cognates outside of Anatolian. Not in {ref LIV²}. For the morphological analysis and connection to Hittite zaḫḫai-, cf. {ref Melchert 2015}.
Anatolian lexemes continuing PIE *di̯eu̯-ot-, further derived from PIE *dei̯- '(to be) bright, to shine' ({ref NIL} 69-81, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:766-767).
From Proto-Germanic laugnjan- 'to keep hidden, deny', further possibly to a root ?*leu̯gʰ- 'to lie' (cf. {ref LIV²} 417, {ref Kroonen 2013}:328-329).
Latin abscondere 'to hide', unprefixed verb -dō, -dere from PIE *dʰeh₁- 'put, place; do' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:175-176, {ref LIV²} 136-138). For the Romance lexemes, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:4.

Generally connected to Gk. κιχάνω < *gʰeh₁- ({ref LIV²} 196, {ref Kroonen 2013}174-175). Whether these forms are to be further connected on one hand to Arm. gam 'come' (so {ref LIV²}) or to Indo-Iranian lexemes (so {Kroonen 2013}) would decide whether to reconstruct initial *g̑ʰ or *gʰ.
As though from *h₂er-u-ti- to PIE *h₂er- 'to fit (together), join' ({ref Melchert 1988}:224-225).
Etymology outside of (East) Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:568, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:819-820 for further discussion.
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g̑- 'to belch, to vomit' (cf. {ref ALEW} 848-849, 877-878, {ref Derksen 2015}:385, {ref Karulis 1992} II:134, {ref LIV²} 509).

notes: perhaps from PIE *sek- 'to cut'

justificationDiscussion: Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 421, {ref Kluge 2011}:590, but cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:350.

Tocharian lexemes generally derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear', although some uncertainty remains over the precise nominal stem formation ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:145-146, {ref Adams 2013}:249, cf. {ref LIV²} 336-337).
Probably a loan from Tocharian B ({ref Adams 2013}:115, {ref Carling 2009}).
Extra-Tocharian connections unclear, possibly to be connected within Tocharian to Tocharian A kāts, B kātse 'belly', cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:112, {ref Adams 2013}:165-166 for further discussion.
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:427-428); cf. {ref HED K}:14-15 for unconvincing attempts to relate to Old English hōc 'hook', etc.
Germanic lexemes from a denominal formation based on Proto-Germanic *mati- 'food' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:247, {ref Kroonen 2013}:358, cf {ref Orel 2003}: 263).

notes: Kroonen writes that the Germanic words may either be related to forms such as Greek κρατύς and Sanskrit krátu- (with Germanic showing Schwebeablaut) or related to Lithuanian kir̃sti 'to turn sour'. According to ALEW, this verb is derived from the PIE root *(s)kert- 'to cut, to cut in two'.In the EWA, the two explanations Kroonen mentions are actually unified, the root reconstruction being "uridg. *(s)kret- (oder [s]kert- [?])".The LIV² only has a root *(s)kert-.
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *hardu- to be derived from PIE *kortú- from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (up)' (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:280-282, {ref Kroonen 2013}:211).
A derivative of PIE *klep- 'to (secretly) steal, hide' ({ref Smoczyński 2005}:33-34, cf. {ref ALEW} 940-941, {ref LIV²} 363-364).

Traditionally to PIE *sem- 'one, a unity' (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:715, with references to earlier literature), but alternatively to PIE *(s)k̑ens- (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:925-926, {ref EWAia} II:836). The traditional etymology is not impossible, although the initial ṣ- is unexpected, and does not account for the root final *-s- (Ron Kim, p.c.), therefore the latter etymology is more preferable.
Generally derived from PIE *kers- 'to cut (off)' ({ref LIV²} 355-356, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:454-455, {ref Malzahn 2010}:582-583, {ref Adams 2013}:178-179).
Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'to stick; be pointy' ({ref Kluge 2011}:879, {ref EWNl} 4:272-273, {ref Kroonen 2013}:476, {ref LIV²} 592-593).

Generally connected to PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to ignite, burn' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:118-119, {ref Adams 2013}:225-226). For the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} (formerly {ref LIV²} 345 1. *keh₂u̯-).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'burn' in /cognate/1461/, 'day' in /cognate/2234/, 'dry' in /cognate/8281/, 'hard' in /cognate/8428/, 'fog' in /cognate/6235/.

justificationDiscussion: Connections outside of Albanian uncertain, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:120, {ref Orel 1998}:481, {ref Holm 2011}:55-56 for various attempts at an IE root etymology and further discussion.

Etymology outside of Tocharian disputed (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:972). Several possible etymological proposals: {ref Adams 2013}:792 derives the root from PIE *streu̯g- 'streichen, abwischen' ({ref LIV²} 605, without Tocharian); {ref Meillet 1911}:461 assumed a k-extension of *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' ({ref LIV²} 588, without Tocharian); {ref Hackstein 2003}:84 has preferred *su̯ergʰ- 'krank sein, sich sorgen' ({ref LIV²} 613-614, without Tocharian).

Derived from PIE *u̯edʰ(h₁)- 'hit, strike' ({ref Malzahn 2010}:876-877, {ref Adams 2013}:641, cf. {ref LIV²} 660). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
Extra-Tocharian connections unclear ({ref Adams 2013}:68)
Connections outside of Tocharian unclear ({ref Adams 2013}:478).
No certain etymology, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:61-62 for a survey of various proposals.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:96 for various proposals.

notes: with parallel sound substitutions: kʰ for x
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loanwords from Persian خون / xūn 'blood'.

Parallel loans from Indic lexemes continued by Sanskrit haḍḍa- 'bone' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:807 no. 13952, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:35). The Pashto form represents a diminutive and matches Gawarbati haḍoki.
Loanword from Slavic *kostъka ({ref Orel 1998}:187, {ref Holm 2011}:53-54).
Loanword from Low German borst 'chest' (cf. Middle Dutch borst 'id.').
Parallel loans from English breast.

loan_notes: probably either a Dardic loan or a chance similarity

justificationDiscussion: The etymology in this cognate set is tentatively assigned to PIE *h₃rei̯H- following {ref Orel 1998}:366, {ref Holm 2011}:56, but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:344, {ref Holm 2011}:56 for discussion of alternative etymologies.
Loan from Pāli sītala- 'cold', cf. Sinhalese hīl 'cold' as the inherited reflex from Sanskrit śītalá- 'cold' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:723 no. 12487).

From Old Norse reikna, a loanword from Middle Low German rekenen ({ref de Vries 1977}:438).  Since this is already found in Old Norse, its presence in both Elfdalian and Swedish can be presumed to reflect a parallel shift to this meaning, not a parallel loan.
Loanword from Latin numerāre 'to count, enumerate' ({ref Orel 1998}:291).
Originally a loanword into Middle English from Old French cunter, conter ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Loanword into Middle English from Old Norse deyja 'to die', replacing various Old English expressions steorfan, sweltan, or periphrastic wesan déad ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
A denominal formation from Breton kaw 'hollow', originally a borrowing from Latin cavus 'hollow, excavated' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:377).
Loanword from German schmutzig 'dirty' ({ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).

Late loanword from Balkan Romance, showing no trace of rhotacism in Tosk ({ref Huld 1984}:107, {ref Orel 1998}:356). Due to the apparent lateness of the borrowing, this loan is treated as separate loan events in Gheg and Tosk (cf. [Tosk-based] Standard Albanian in /cognate/5925/).
loan_notes: Relatively late loanword from Lat (acc.sg.) canem or, rather, from its Balkan continuations, reflected in the lack of rhotacism in Tosk.

justificationDiscussion: Loan into East Slavic from Iranic *sabāka- 'dog' ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:702-703, cf. {ref Černyh 1999} 2:183, {ref Šanskij et al. 1975}:419).
Parallel loans from Persian گرد / gard 'dust'.

Difficult case to analyse.  The term is known across various North Germanic languages:  Faroese, Swedish, Danish and Riksmal.  Because Riksmal lexicon derives from Danish essentially only in the last few centuries, those can be considered not parallel, whereas the case seems to support more a parallel loan view for the other languages.  The Riksmal and Danish are therefore now to be split off into a separate non-parallel loan cognate set, https://cobl.info/cognate/9687/.  (An alternative analysis is that the loan event was into very early Norse, with a meaning shift in parallel since, but since no Old Norse form is registered here, we do not follow that analysis.)
Loan from Tajik
From Middle English egge, a loan from Old Norse egg 'egg', replacing Old English ǽg 'egg' which continued the inherited lexeme ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Continuing a derivative of PIE *Hei̯k̑- 'to take possession of' ({ref LIV²} 223, {ref Malzahn 2010}:543-544, {ref Adams 2013}:107-108).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:278 for discussion of various proposals.
Probably to be connected with lexemes for 'belly' in /cognate/854/ ({ref Adams 2013}:651).
No known etymology ({ref Adams 2013}:401).
Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ({ref Adams 2013}:678, 683-684, 698, {ref EWAia} I:594-595, {ref MacKenzie 1990}:127).

notes: cf. Lith. vidus 'middle, interior'. The Latgalian form is a compound with -puse 'half', perhaps formed independently from the Lith. word.

justificationDiscussion: Loans from Middle Low German (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:144).

Generally considered a loanword from Latin ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:128) but occasionally disputed (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:587). On upholding the loanword hypothesis, cf. comments by Irslinger in this class.
Unexpected vocalism points to parallel loans from Persian.
Parallel loans from Persian ناخن / nāxun 'nail', in some cases with sound substitution kh for x; Sanskrit nakha- 'nail' also may have had influence.
A Wanderwort of obscure origin, cf. {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:123-124, {ref Rejzek 2001}:701, {ref Skok 1971-1974} 3:569, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 1:279 for various proposals.
Loanword from Scots, cf. Middle English flour, Old French flour ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:176).
Loanword from Old French flour, flur, flor ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

A register-loanword into Standard Modern Greek from Katharevousa (expected †μίχλη, vel sim.). A reflex of the expected word might be found in SMG μούχλα 'mould, mildew' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); cf. also respective entries in {ref Andriotis 1999}.
Parallel loans from from Latin frūctus (or in some cases, its Old French derivative fruit).
Parallel loans from Persian میوه / mīwah 'fruit'.
Loan from Latin frūctus 'fruit' ({ref Orel 1998}:103).
Loan from (Low) German voll 'full' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:1095).

notes: سبز with sound substitution uj for z
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Persian سبز / sabz.
Loan from Low German grö̂ne 'green' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:187).
Loanword from Polish wątroba 'liver' ({ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 2:53).
Borrowing from Tajik сар / sar 'head' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:308).
Loanword from Middle Low German swâr 'heavy' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:802).
Parallel loans from Persian (شكار (كردن / šekār (kardan) 'to do a hunt; hunt'

Generally considered to be a (at least a semantic) loanword from Middle Low German ({ref de Vries 1977}:289; no North Germanic cognates connected by {ref Kroonen 2013}:271-272 s.v. Proto-Germanic *jakk/gōn-).
If this is only a semantic realignment by contact influence, then technically it is not to be considered a loanword in CoBL, but a semantic realignment of a still cognate word.  
But since this is analysed as a loanword from Middle Low German, by that period fragmentation of North Germanic varieties had already begun, so this is to be taken as a parallel loan.
Denominal verb derived from Kashubian jachta 'hunt' (n.), a loanword from German Jagd ({ref Boryś & Popowska-Taborska 1994-2010} 2:327-328).

loan_notes: *j- > z- points to a Pers/Tajik loan.

justificationDiscussion: The English word for 'lake' might be inherited from Germanic (cf. OHG lacha 'bog, mire'), but if so in the meaning 'lake' it would appear to be a semantic borrowing from Latin lacus (cf. similarly Greek: Italiot λάκκ̔ο in /cognate/8394/ which might be a semantic calque based on Italian); the cognate Germanic lexemes are unrelated to Lat. lacus, and probably further connected to PIE ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'drip' (cf. {ref LIV²} 397), otherwise only attested in Celtic ({ref EWA 5}:976-978). If from PIE ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'drip' then possibly to be connected with Armenian lič in /cognate/607/.
loan_notes: Either a direct borrowing from Old French lac, or a semantic borrowing from Old French lac, reinterpreting inherited material (cf. OE lacu 'small stream of running water' < Proto-Germanic *lak-, cf. OED, EWAhd)

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Early Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic leggr 'leg' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Loan from Latin *camba ~ gamba 'leg' ({ref Huld 1984}:80, {ref Orel 1998}:177, {ref Holm 2011}:63).
Loanword from Modern High German leben 'to live' ({ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:796).
Parallel loans from Persian (زندگى (كردن  / zendegī (kardan) 'to live'.
Parallel loans into Modern Indo-Iranic languages from Persian جگر / ǰigar 'liver'

notes: Parallel loans from Skt. yákr̥t /lexeme/22444/
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Sanskrit yákr̥t 'liver'.

loan_notes: The Turkish word is a borrowing from Persian, see cognate class http://cobl.info/cognate/718/.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Persian مرد / mard 'man, person'.
Loanword from Low German kerl 'man' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:865-866).
Parallel loans from Persian گوشت / gūšt 'meat'.
Parallel loans from the Sanskrit compound candrá- 'bright' /cognate/2338/ + mā́ḥ 'moon' /cognate/2232/.

notes: Loan from Low German.
justificationDiscussion: Loan from Low German mân 'moon' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:396).
Parallel loans from Persian کوه / kūh 'mountain'.
Loanword into Middle English from Old French montaigne ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

notes: Loanword from Italian
justificationDiscussion: Certainly a borrowing from Latin gula or Italian gola 'throat' ({ref Meyer 1891}:126, although aspects of the loan chronology remain disputed (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:66, {ref Orel 1998}:120, {ref Holm 2011}:72).
Parallel loans from Persian تنگ / tang 'narrow'.
Lexemes continuing Old Breton strit, a loanword from Latin strictus 'drawn together, close, strait, tight' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:699)

notes: Loan from Latin angustus 'narrow'.
justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Latin angustus 'narrow' ({ref Meyer 1891}:307, {ref Huld 1984}:98, {ref Orel 1998}:298).

notes: cf. Persian نزدیک næzdi:k - via Urdu? - outside Urdu with sound substitution j for zd

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Persian گردن / gardan 'neck'.

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Latin veterem 'old' (acc.sg.) ({ref Meyer 1891}:476, {ref Huld 1984}:131, {ref Orel 1998}:512).

loan_notes: Either from Old Norse or Swedish

justificationDiscussion: Plausibly a loanword from Low German, cf. Old Frisian menniska ({ref de Vries 1977}:378). The Icelandic forms however do not show umlaut characteristic of the West Germanic forms, and may have been influenced by Old Icelandic mannr.
Loanword from Old Russian человҍкъ 'person' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:175).
Loan from Latin lūdere 'to play' ({ref Meyer 1891}:242-243, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:231-232).
Parallel loans from Middle Low German.
Parallel loans from Middle Low German trecken 'to pull' (cf. {ref Den Danske Ordbog}).
Loanword from Anglo-Norman, cf. Old French, Middle French pousser 'to push' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Loan from Latin pulsus 'a pushing, beating, striking' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:595-596)
Based on Bret. bou(n)t, a loanword from Old French boute (deverbal from Old French bouter 'hit, push').
loan_notes: Borrowed from Old French boute < bot 'blow, ' (1160), bouter 'to collide, to clash, to push' (1190).

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *kraviya- 'bloody, raw' {ref Turner 1962–1966}:186 no. 3585), cf. Vedic kraviṣ- 'red, bloody flesh', ultimately from PIE *kreu̯h₂-s-, a derivative of *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body' ({ref NIL} 444-448, {ref EWAia} I:411).
Loanword from Persian سرخ / sorx 'red'.
Parallel loans from Persian راست / rāst 'right'.
Loanword from Low German recht 'right' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:634-635).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: from the notion of 'long'? comp. Pers. darəɣa 'long', see also 'lake' in /cognate/2771/ and 'sea' in /cognate/2011/

justificationDiscussion: (Parallel?) loan from Middle Low German.
Generally assumed to be a loan from (early) Middle Iranian, cf. {ref Tremblay 2005}:426, {ref Adams 2013}:657-658 for recent discussions and references to further literature.
Loan from early Scandinavian, cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}.

The North Germanic lexemes in this set are likely to be loans from Middle Low German, of a word originally borrowed from Old French.

See the other loan event cognate sets that also go back to this same Old French source:
https://cobl.info/cognate/9688/ in Dutch;  
https://cobl.info/cognate/9689/ in Upper German, 
https://cobl.info/cognate/9690/ as a parallel loan into English and Frisian

Cf. {ref Den Danske Ordbog}. {ref Kluge 2011}:777-778, {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}, {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).

Loan from Middle Persian.

Loan from Low German, cf. Middle Low German sât 'seed' ({ref Polański & Sehnert 1967}:135).
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. Persian: Tehran تیز / tīz 'sharp'.
Loan from Middle Low German scharp, scherp 'sharp' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:806).
Modern North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse kortr, a loan from Middle Low German (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:327 s.v. kortr, kurtr).
According to {ref Orel 1998}:425, a loanword from Germanic *skurta- 'short'.
Loanword from Latin cantāre 'sing' ({ref Meyer 1891}:187, {ref Huld 1984}:80, {ref Orel 1998}:178)
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. Middle Persian pwst / põst 'skin', Persian: Tehran پوست	 / pūst 'id.'.
A loan from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Norse skinn), already attested in Old English schynn, scynn, scin ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Latin caelum 'sky' ({ref Meyer 1891}:225-226, {ref Huld 1984}:107, {ref Orel 1998}:360).
Loanword from Old French sentir 'to perceive' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:643).
Parallel loans from Persian هموار / hamwār 'smooth, flat, level'
Parallel loans from Middle Low German glatt 'smooth'.

North Germanic lexemes continuing Old Norse slangi, a loan from Middle Low German slange 'snake' ({ref de Vries 1977}:513).  But if the source is as late as Middle Low German, then the Icelandic and Danish lineages should be considered by then already divergent, and therefore this is a parallel loan.
Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Persian برف / barf 'snow' (cf. /cognate/126/).
A loan from Middle English batte, in turn borrowed from Old French batte ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:31)

Two possibilities: Either (1) as a loan from Romance *notāre (with irregular root vocalism from Lat. natāre 'swim', so {ref Meyer 1891}:311, {ref Orel 1998}:301), or – perhaps better – (2) directly derived to PIE *(s)neh₂- (so {ref Huld 1984}:148, {ref Holm 2011}:83). No discussion in {ref Demiraj 1997} or {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}.
Parallel loans from Middle Low German swanz 'trailer; tail, penis' (cf. {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).

notes: Loan from early Scandinavian

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Old French songer (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:677).
Parallel loan event from Middle Low German denken 'to think, remember' (cf. {ref EWA 2} 579).
Derived from Middle Breton liam, a borrowing from Old French liem ({ref Deshayes 2003}:463).
Loan from Middle Low German dreien 'to turn'.

notes: Loan from Italian

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Persian گرم  / garm 'hot'.
Since the source is as late as Middle Low German, then the Faroese and Danish lineages should be considered by then already divergent, and therefore this is a parallel loan.

notes: Parallel loans from Persian (after p > f, but before ē > ī)

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Old Norse vængir ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Parallel loans from Sanskrit strī- 'woman, female, wife'.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3245
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing *kuḍī- 'girl, daughter', probably a loanword from Munda or Dravidian, cf. Skt. kuḍáti 'acts like a child' (Dhātup.) ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:167 no. 3245).
Parallel loans from Sanskrit jāṅgala- 'jungle, wild forest'.

Considered to be a loanword from Medieval Latin boscus in earlier literature, but given that the Medieval Latin form (and its descendants in modern Romance languages) have no clear etymology from earlier Italic, the Germanic forms are now generally considered to be inherited, although their further etymology is obscure. It remains possible that the Medieval Latin and the Germanic forms are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref EWA 2}:474-476, {ref Kluge 2011}:165).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Needs re-checking (Freiberg). Should be cognate with /cognate/2685/.

gloss_in_root_lang: to measure, to judge, to ensure obeying, to take care

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:58); {ref LIV²} 456 mechanically reconstructs PIE ?2. *neu̯d- 'stoßen' (cf. {ref IEW} 767).

Proposed to Sanskrit nudati (otherwise isolated, cf. {ref KEWA} II:176, {ref LIV²} 456 s.v. ?2. *neu̯d- 'stoßen') by {ref Jasanoff 1978b}:39 via a pre-form *nud-sk̑e/o-, but this connection is formally difficult from a Tocharian perspective (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:682-683, {ref Adams 2013}:356-357 for further discussion).
Probably a loanword from Middle Iranian ({ref Adams 2013}:48).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain ({ref Adams 2013}:628).
For the root etymology, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:909-910, with references to further literature; cf. also discussion by {ref Adams 2013}:658-660.

Probably a formation derived from TochAB kät- 'strew (on purpose); sow (seeds)' ({ref Adams 2013}:686), further to PIE *(s)kedh₂- 'shatter, disperse' ({ref Malzahn 2010}:564-565, {ref Adams 2013}:166-167, cf. {ref LIV²} 550-551).

Perfect medio-passive participle < *βρέγμενος to βρέχομαι, the medio-passive of Ancient Greek βρέχω 'to wet, moisten'. Further etymology obscure; older literature assumed a Schwebeablaut variant *mregʰ- to a root *mergʰ- 'to moisten' only otherwise found in Balto-Slavic, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:195, {ref Beekes 2010}:238 for further discussion (not in {ref LIV²}).
Etymology outside of Greek unclear, possibly a prehistoric loanword (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:90-91, {ref Beekes 2010}:106).

Cf. Standard Modern Greek ανασαίνω, from Medieval Greek ἀνασαίνω, formed as a denominal verb in -αίνω from the Ancient Greek abstract noun ἄνεσις 'loosening, relaxing' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:131), further to Ancient Greek ἵημι 'to send away, let go, throw' from PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw' ({ref Beekes 2010}:581-582, {ref LIV²} 225).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: PIE *(h₁)i̯ú(:)(s) seems to be derived from the pronoun *(h₁)i-, cognate with the relativizer (relativizing pronominal adjective) *(h₁)i̯ó- (Pooth); structured parallelly to *tú(:) ~ *té(u)- besides *tó-, etc.; presumably cognate with 'they' in /cognate/3016/. Some of the forms go back to a different stem *u̯ó-. The suppletion may well be post-PIE.ATTENTION: This cognate class needs thorough revision (Pooth). Some of the forms do not belong here.

justificationDiscussion: Tsakonian lexemes from Ancient Greek τρέχω 'to run' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:556-557), further to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1506-1507, {ref LIV²} 154).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'run' in /cognate/5027/ 'pull' in /cognate/2839/, 'carry' in /cognate/5330/, probably also 'turn' in /cognate/660/.

justificationDiscussion: From Ancient Greek κοβαλεύω 'to carry as a porter', a derived verb from the nominal κόβαλος ({ref Babinotis 2010}:717); further origins obscure (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:550, {ref Beekes 2010}:727-728}).

Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'spine, back' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1207). Further etymology outside of Greek disputed; older literature compares to Lith. ražis 'stubble', from a preform *urág̑ʰ-i-, although the supposition of such a form would require postulating *a ~ *ā ablaut (with a full or lengthened grade in ῥᾱχός or ῥηχός) (cf. {ref IEW} 1180, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:968-969, {ref Beekes 2010}:1277-1278).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek στεγνός 'watertight, waterproof', originally as a substantive τὸ στεγνόν 'covered dwelling' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1325). Further derived from PIE *(s)teg- 'to cover' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1046, {ref Beekes 2010}:1393, cf. {ref LIV²} 589).

Modern Greek forms in this class continue Ancient Greek ἀκοντίζω 'hurl a javelin' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), a derivative to Ancient Greek ἄκων, -οντος 'javelin, dart', in turn derived from the PIE root *h₂ek̑- 'sharp, point' ({ref Beekes 2010}:59).

Tsakonian lexemes based on a new present stem backformed from the Ancient Greek suppletive aorist stem ἔδραμον to the old present stem τρέχω ({ref Andriotis 1974}:215-216), further to PIE 1. *drem- 'to run' ({ref Beekes 2010}:351, {ref LIV²} 128).
Perhaps derived from PIE *leh₂d-, although the postulated root is based entirely upon internal reconstruction of the Greek evidence (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:65-66, {ref LIV²} 401-402).

As though from a Sanskrit compound *kṣāradhānikā 'receptacle for ashes' (kṣārá- 'caustic substance', dhā́na- 'container'; cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:191, no. 3677). Further connections outside of Indo-Iranic are uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:430, {ref KEWA} I:288).
Parallel loans from Persian بد bad 'bad'
loan_notes: In Pashto, the loan event must have taken place after inherited short *a was reduced and inherited OIr. *d > l.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel Sanskritisms, cf. /cognate/754/.
An old borrowing from Persian/Tajik xān(a)- 'house' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:409).
Loan from Church Slavonic used in place of the inherited Russian lexeme солодкий ({ref Vasmer 1953-1958} II:657, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} III:666).
Learned re-introduction (or adaptation) of Ancient Greek ὑγρός 'wet', lacking the characteristic loss of initial unstressed vowels found elsewhere in Modern Greek (cf. {ref Andriotis 1999}).
Loanword from Middle Low German made 'worm' ({ref Polański 1962-1994} III:388).
Parallel loans from Persian. The Pamir words (Wakhi, Sarikoli) are probably loaned from Tajik.
Loanword from Russian год 'year' (cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} I:127).

notes: Original meaning probably "Hülle, Decke". Note that Persian requires accent shift to *páu̯astā- for *áu̯a > ō and au̯á > awa (Klingenschmitt 2000: 214f.).

justificationDiscussion: Ultimately from a diminutive formation from Ancient Greek πέσκος 'skin, rind', no clear etymology outside of Greek, cf. {ref Andriotis 1999}:1168, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:890, {ref Beekes 2010}:1180.
Based on a loanword from Italian largo ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:291). Tsakonian αλάργα is treated as a separate loan event in /cognate/6167/.
Loanword from dialectal southern Italian ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:301-302).
Originally a root-noun in the sense *'visible, outer form' > '(outer) body; skin' (cf. Hittite tu̯ekka- 'body, person') from PIE *tu̯ek- 'be visible' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:684, {ref LIV²} 654).
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 720-721).
According to {ref Adams 2013}:731-732 to be derived from PIE *smer-(u̯)o- 'fat, grease'.
No certain etymology outside of Tocharian. Cf. {ref Adams 2013}:778 for some proposed Balto-Slavic comparanda, but no etymology given by {ref Malzahn 2010}. Not in {ref LIV²}.
Of uncertain etymology, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:920-921 and {ref Adams 2013}:687-688 for discussion of various proposals.
Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 386-388 to a causative-iterative stem *kʷolh₁-éi̯e- derived to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn'.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'round' in /cognate/4906/, 'live' in /cognate/3185/, 'navel' in /cognate/7117/, 'yesterday' in /cognate/6487/, 'walk' in /cognate/1626/.

justificationDiscussion: According to {ref Adams 2013}:318 to be derived from PIE *dʰeu̯H- 'move quickly back and forth' via a semantic development 'make arise (a cloud of dust)' > 'covered in dust', 'yellow'.
Parallel loans in Modern Greek dialects from Turkish toz 'dust'.

Denominal verb to Armenian kʿayl 'step'. Of uncertain etymology, traditionally taken to reflect IE *kl̥-i̯e- (PIE *kel-); cf. Gk.  κέλλω 'drive; put to harbor'; Lat. celer 'fast' ({ref Olsen 1999}:211, cf. {ref HAB} IV:549). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰai̯l-]. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

Connections outside of Armenian uncertain. Within Armenian probably to be connected with Classical Armenian kuṙn '(anatom.) back; side', which in turn – if the original semantic meaning was 'curved/bending body-part' – may be related to Classical Armenian kor 'curved, crooked' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:376, cf. id. 382, 373-374). {ref HAB} II:669 offers no etymology. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kuṙ(-tʰ)-un-].
Cf. Classical Armenian mēǰ- 'the middle; back' < PIE médʰ-i̯o- ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:466-467, {ref NIL} 465-466).
Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:546-547 for various proposals; not in {ref Martirosyan 2010} or {ref Olsen 1999}). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰam-ii̯o-].

To be connected to the same root as Classical Armenian hogi 'spirit, soul', hewam 'I pant, puff; am breathless', probably from a formation *p⁽ʰ⁾eu̯H-io- ({ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:466, {ref HAB} III:115-116, {ref Olsen 1999}:441). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Generally derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'wide, flat' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:415-416, {ref NIL} 562-564 for further discussion).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/4527/, 'mountain' in /cognate/2804/, 'hand' in /cognate/1712/, 'thin' in /cognate/1923/, 'wide' in /cognate/5264/, 'smooth' in /cognate/6801/, 'stand' in /cognate/8055/, 'tree' in /cognate/8103/.

notes: Unknown etymology.
justificationDiscussion: No known etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:962, cf. {ref HAB} I:624-625). [MM: Proto-Armenian *daṙ-in-].

Generally derived as though from PIE *gʷʰe/oidʰ-i̯o- and connected with Slavic lexemes for 'liquid, watery', although some debate remains over the more precise aspects of the stem formation in Armenian (see {ref Martirosyan 2010}:210-211 for detailed discussion, cf. also {ref HAB} I:550-551, {ref Olsen 1999}:811).
Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂er- 'to fix, fit together' ({ref LIV²} 269-270, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:112).

Generally assumed to reflect a derivative of PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step', originally a suppletive aorist stem to PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:249-250, 344-345, {ref LIV²} 205).

No generally accepted etymology (cf. {ref HAB} 3:51-52, {ref Olsen 1999}:90, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:392-393). The term should not be separated, however, from Armenian hat, o-stem, 'grain, seed; piece, cut', which might be derived from PIE *h₂ed-os n. 'sort of cereal, grain' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:392-393 for further discussion). If so, then connected to PIE *h₂ed- 'bite; eat'.

Two possible Indo-European etymologies, either (1) derived to PIE *h₂eh₁- as a denominal verb from *ayr- 'fire' compared to Av. ātar-/āθr- 'fire', Lat. āter 'black, dark', OIr. āith 'furnace', Palaic ḫā- 'be hot' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:418), or (2) from PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ-, cf. Gk. αἴθω 'to kindle, burn', Skt. edh- 'to set alight, kindle; shine' ({ref Jasanoff 1979}:145, {ref Viredaz 2003}:85). Alternatively {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:98n16 has assumed an Iranian loanword. (Cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:63).
Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 455-456, {ref Derksen 2015}:228, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:278.
Loanword from Turkish sert 'hard, stiff', cf. SMG σέρτικος 'heavy, strong (of blends of tobacco and cigarettes)' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1260).
Uncertain etymology (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). See further discussion below.
Loanword from Turkish göğüs 'chest'.
Loan from Turkish, cf. Turkish dövüş 'fight' (n.), dövüşmek 'to fight'.
Loanword from Turkish puslu 'misty, hazy'.
Loanword from Turkish meyve 'fruit', in turn a loanword from Persian mive 'fruit' (cf. {ref Dawkins 1916}:623).
From Ancient Greek τρέχω 'run' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:510). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'run' in /cognate/5027/.
Loanword from Turkish göl 'lake'.
A secondary semantic development from Modern Greek νερό 'water'. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'water' in /cognate/1563/.
Loanword from Turkish yuvarlak 'round'.
Loan from Turkish keskin 'sharp' (cf. {ref Dawkins 1916}:684).
Romance loanword, cf. Standard Italian coda 'queue, tail'.

Modern Greek lexemes continuing Medieval Greek ἐπαίρνω, a remodelled nasal-present stem continuing Ancient Greek ἐπαίρω 'lift up' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1021), except Tsakonian: Peloponnese αζ̌ίκ̔ου < *αρ-ίσκω ({ref Andriotis 1974}:76), both continuing the basic verbal root of Ancient Greek αἴρω ~  ἀείρω 'to raise'. Probably further to a PIE root *h₂u̯er- 'to hang' ({ref LIV²} 290, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:23-24).
Loanword from Turkish but 'thigh, rump' (cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:899).
Loan from Turkish kanat 'wing'.
Loan from Turkish kötü 'bad'.
Semantic shift from Ancient Greek καρδία 'heart' ({ref Dawkins 1916}:607), cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:644, {ref NIL} 417-423, and 'heart' in /cognate/6458/ for further etymological connections.
Tsakonian lexemes as though from Ancient (Doric) Greek *φοῦσκα 'lower abdomen, stomach'; no certain further etymology ({ref Andriotis 1974}:589), {ref Beekes 2010}:1599-1600).
Etymology outside of Celtic obscure, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:253, {ref Lucht 2007}:329-330, {ref Matasović 2009}:227-228 for further discussion.
Indo-Iranic lexemes to be connected with the same root found in Vedic úru- 'wide' ({ref EWAia} I:226-227), cf. 'wide' in /cognate/3090/ regarding the root reconstruction *h₁u̯erH-.

notes: Loan from Latin.
justificationDiscussion: Late loanword from Balkan Romance, showing no trace of rhotacism in Tosk ({ref Huld 1984}:107, {ref Orel 1998}:356). Due to the apparent lateness of the borrowing, this loan is treated as separate loan events in Gheg and Tosk (cf. Gheg in /cognate/5505/).

From Classical Armenian gēš 'corpse, carrion, dead body' (subst.); 'bad, ill' (adj.), further etymology uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:944; not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, for older etymological proposals cf. {ref HAB} I:550, {ref IEW} 1134).

notes: Possibly of onomatopoeic origin.
Cognate with 'blow' /lexeme/31051/

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ({ref ESIJa} I:140-143). Traditionally connected by {ref IEW} 301 to Proto-Germanic *īsa-, but this proposed cognacy remains uncertain, cf. {ref EWA 5}:195-199, {ref Kroonen 2013}:271.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Connection with Germanic lexemes in /cognate/245/ debated, thus also cf. references given there. Cf. 'freeze' in /cognate/45/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:130, {ref Jokl 1911}:23-25, {ref Demiraj 1997}:226}, {ref Orel 1998}:198 for discussion and references to further literature.
Both the Indic and the Germanic cognates in this class are based on participial formations derived to PIE *h₁es- 'to be'.
Loanword from Middle High German bom, boum 'tree' ({ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:51
No certain etymology (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:362-363, {ref HAB} II:587 for further discussion).

From Classical Armenian lełi 'gall', generally considered of uncertain etymology (cf. {ref HAB II:275), but cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:440 who suggests a reconstruction *g̑ʰelh₃iom 'yellow (substance)' > †jełi which could have been subject to a tabooistic deformation or influenced by semantically related leard 'liver'. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *leł-io-].
Origin unknown (cf. {ref HAB} III:202). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010} or {OIsen 1999}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃei̯r(-)ana-].

Armenian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *leh₂- 'to bark'. The assignment of Armenian forms to this class follows {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:104-105, {ref LIV²} 400-401 (not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}); for Iranic cf. {ref EWAia} II:443, {ref Cheung 2007}:306.

Root etymology uncertain, probably connected in some way with Armenian gam 'to come' from PIE *gʰeh₁- according to {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:95-96 (cf. /cognate/580/); {ref LIV²} 668-669 suggests deriving from a nasal present stem *u̯i-n(e)-h₁- to *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach'. See {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:95-96 for further discussion. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, cf. {ref HAB} I:567-568.

From Classical Armenian ertʿa- 'go'. The etymology in this class follows {ref LIV²} 590-592, {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:96, 104 to *per-steh₂-, but cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:263 who instead prefers a denominal formation from ertʿ 'going, journey' as though from a nominal stem *h₁r-sk-ti-, and in which case could be root-cognate with Greek ἔρχομαι 'come, go' in /cognate/5151/.

Origin uncertain. Since {ref Pedersen 1906}:379 connected with Greek γοργός 'grim, fierce, terrible', Old Irish garg(g) 'raw, wild' (cf. {ref HAB} II:552, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:392), but this proposed etymology is rejected by {ref Beekes 2010}:283, {ref Matasović 2009}:151. Not in {ref Olsen 1999} or {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

Of uncertain origin, possibly an Iranian loanword ({ref Olsen 1999}:965, cf. {ref HAB} IV:82). {ref Martirosyan 2010}:552 considers the proposed etymology to PIE *bʰendʰ- 'to bind, fasten', but this requires the assumption of Grassmann's Law in Armenian, for which there are no other parallel examples.

Generally derived as a causative to the same root as Armenian ankanim 'I fall' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:280, cf. {ref HAB} II:128), ultimately from PIE *sengʷ- 'to go down, sink'. Cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:280 for further discussion.

Denominal from Armenian xorh 'thought', probably an Iranian borrowing but there is no certain etymology (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:624, {ref HAB} II:409). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xorh-].
Armenian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *med- 'to measure' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:470-471, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:48-49, cf. {ref LIV²} 423).
No clear etymology. Perhaps from PIE *h₃st-dʰ- (cf. Gk. ὀσφύς 'loins') an extension of PIE *h₃ost- 'bone' but this remains an uncertain conjecture ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:10, {ref Olsen 1999}:149).

From Classical Armenian zist 'thigh, flank', probably to be interpreted as a compound of Proto-Armenian collocation *(ə)z- < PIE *h₂mbi̯V 'around, about' and *hist-o- < PIE *si-sd-e/o- 'to sit' ({ref HAB} II:96, {ref Olsen 1999}:72, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:275).

Denominal to Classical Armenian mart 'fight, battle, combat'. Connections outside of Armenian uncertain, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:81, {ref Olsen 1999}:90. {ref HAB} III:289 for tentative speculations. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Caucasian loanword, cf. e.g. Mingrelian č̣anǯi 'fly' ({ref HAB} III:184-185, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:939). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃantʃ-i-].
Classical Armenian tʿakʿowcʿanem, secondarily derived from Classical Armenian tʻakʻcʻi- 'hide oneself' as though from PIE *pth₂k-eh₁-sk̑e/o- (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:79, 262; {ref LIV²} 495).
Apparently a loan from Tungusic according to {ref HAB} II:437. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsa(-)tsuk-a-].

The Goidelic forms from OId Irish nél cannot reflect an inherited formation based on IE *nebʰ-l- and consequently a loanword from Latin is generally assumed, possibly via Brythonic (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:8, {ref IEW} 315).
loan_notes: May also be a loan from Proto-Germanic. Goidelic forms may be borrowed themselves from Brythonic.

justificationDiscussion: The Classical Armenian present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair in Proto-Armenian. The present stem may be derived from *h₃erg-, cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'perish', ḫarnik- 'destroy' ({ref LIV² 301, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:215-216 for further discussion). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.

Originally denominal to Classical Armenian xowpʿ-n 'cover', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref HAB} II:423, {ref Olsen 1999}:211, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:350 for various proposals). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *xupʰ-].
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Avestan pūiti- 'rottenness', Middle Persian pwtk' 'foul, rotten' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:256, {ref Olsen 1999}:913). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰut-o-].

Probably from Armenian *əndi (< PIE *h₂ent-i) prefixed to *tʰana- (< PIE ?*pt-n(e)-h₂-) ({ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:114-115, {ref LIV²} 479). Alternatively {ref HAB} II:125-126, {ref IEW} 908 proposes to PIE *sent- 'gehen' but this is phonologically difficult (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:114).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fall' in /cognate/7561/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/1486/, 'feather' in /cognate/7563/, 'leaf' in /cognate/790/, 'narrow' in /cognate/4064/, 'river' in /cognate/1525/, 'sleep' in /cognate/8796/, 'wing' in /cognate/1567/

justificationDiscussion: Either a direct borrowing from Iranic or a secondary denominal verb from a borrowed substantive vaz 'leap, jump' (cf. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:242, {ref Olsen 1999}:908). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯az-].
loan_notes: Cf. Parthian wz- 'to move swiftly, fly; travel'; cf. Ved.váhati, etc.

notes: From the ALEW-article it seems that Old Prussian instran is formally best compared with Old Norse ístr 'Bauchfett', Latvian îstri (pl.) 'Nieren'. According to LIPP 2: 226, ístr may go back to *ens-tro-, if én-s may be reconstructed already for PIE (cf. op. cit. 225 fn. 28). - Cognate with words for [guts] in /cognate/1588/.
The common denominator is the core element  (synchronically the third person deictic pronoun) -ն- -n- from PIE *no-.

justificationDiscussion: Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:944, cf. {ref HAB} IV:280). [MM: Proto-Armenian *stu(-)u̯er-a-].

Two possible etymologies: Either identical to Lat. porrō 'forward' if from *p(o)rsōd, alternatively from *πόρσω, derived from πρός 'towards' (< PIE *próti) with a commonly found liquid metathesis. Since both derivations have similar semantic paths of derivation it is difficult to choose between the two possibilities ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:929, {ref Beekes 2010}:1223).
Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original u-stem *di̯éu̯- ~ *diu̯- 'sky, day' to PIE *dei̯- 'be bright, shine' ({ref NIL} 69-81, {ref EWAia} I:750-752).
Lexemes derived from a Proto-Balto-Slavic root *lop-; no certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ({ref Derksen 2015}:273, {ref ESSJa} 16:56-57, 16:77).

Armenian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g- 'to belch, vomit' ({ref Olsen 1999}:764, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:714-715, {ref Derksen 2008}:441-442, {ref Boryś 2005}:536, cf. {ref LIV²} 509).

Generally further connected with Classical Armenian lerk 'hairless, bald' and sometimes compared with Old Irish lerg 'surface, level' (cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:105), but this proposed etymology is quite uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:965, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:244). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, cf. {ref HAB} III:555-556.
From Classical Armenian hartʿ 'flat, even, level', further etymology uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:964, cf. {ref HAB} III:58-59).

Root etymology disputed (cf. esp. {ref Demiraj 1997}:257-258); possibly related to cognates from PIE 2. *h₂er- ({ref LIV²} 270-271, so {ref Hamp 1965}:140, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:983), but alternative etymologies are also possible (cf. also {ref Meyer 1891}:261, {ref Jokl 1911}:53-54, {ref Huld 1984}:89-90, {ref Orel 1998}:246).

Uncertain etymology. Typically explained as a blend of *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' and *dluku- 'sweet', *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' or *saldu- 'salty' ({ref Clackson 2017}:113, cf. {ref HAB} IV:546). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰałtsʰ-u-(r)].

notes: Loan from Iranian.
justificationDiscussion: A loan from Iranic ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:99-100, {ref Olsen 1999}:864). [MM: Proto-Armenian *anoi̯ʃ-i-].

notes: Perhaps an Iranian loan.  The modern Armenian forms go back to CA պառակեմ paṙak-e-m 'I lie (down or in wait)', a denominative of պառակ paṙak '(adj.) laid at full length; (n.) flank, chop (of meat), cutlet' (also 'sheep-pen; herd).
justificationDiscussion: [MM: Proto-Armenian *paṙ(-)aka-].

Of uncertain origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:942), traditionally connected with Proto-Slavic *bedro- (cf. {ref IEW} 96, {ref HAB} IV:101, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:642). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *port-o-].

Origin uncertain, perhaps from *m(u̯)elh₂- 'grind' (cf. młel 'chaff, dust', mamowł 'press(ing machine))? Cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:953, {ref HAB} III:331-332. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *muł-].

Etymology uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:941, cf. {ref HAB} IV:56-57). Perhaps a blend of an Iranic loanword and an element connected to the Germanic 'neck' words according to {ref Pisani 1934}:55, cf. {ref Clackson 2017}:112. For further discussion cf. {ref HAB} and note by Macak to this class. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *par-].
Loanword from Iranic ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:189-190, {ref HAB} 3:198). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃerm(-)aka-].

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian hast 'firm, steady, tough; thick, dense', generally connected with Germanic lexemes for 'hard, steady, strong, dense' (OIc. fastr, OHG festi, fasti) from PIE *past- ({ref Olsen 1999}:201, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}390-391, but preferring the hypothesis of an old European loanword in PIE on the basis of medial *-a-).

Of uncertain origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:941), perhaps a Semitic loanword according to {ref HAB} II:517-518 (cf. Akkadian kūšu 'skin', Arab. qašʿa 'dry skin' [< Sumerian kuš 'skin']). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kaʃ-ii̯a-].
From Classical Armenian kayṙi, of uncertain origin ({ref HAB} II:507-509, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:380). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Loanword from Persian پست past 'low, inferior, small' (cf. {ref HAB} IV:77 {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:636).

From Classical Armenian šowkʿ 'shadow', further etymology uncertain ({ref HAB} III:541, cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:595 for a more recent proposal). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}, no etymology given in {ref Olsen 1999}:17. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ʃukʰ-o-].

Denominal to Classical Armenian vax 'fear, dread; steep place, precipice'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref HAB} IV:294-295; not in {ref Olsen 1999} or {ref Martirosyan 2010}). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯ax-].

notes: Unknown etymology.
justificationDiscussion: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian krem 'to bear, to carry'. Further etymology uncertain. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ki/ur-].
From Classical Armenian eraxay 'child'. [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)rexa-].
Due to its nursery character, any deeper etymology of this lexeme can not be convincingly proven.

From Ancient Greek σύρω, remodelled as a -νω present in Modern Greek varieties ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1259); probably further derived from PIE *tu̯er- 'sweep' although the details of the stem formation remain debated (cf. {ref Vine 1999a}:570-571, {ref Beekes 2010}:1424-1425).
