Perhaps PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the Balto-Slavic acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾- ({ref Derksen 2008}:243, {ref Derksen 2015}:231-232), but connections outside of Balto-Slavic ultimately uncertain; perhaps PIE *kʷend- according to {ref ALEW} 464-465, but likewise extra-Balto-Slavic connections uncertain. Cf. also {ref ESSJa} 12:65-66.
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic múkha- 'mouth, face'. No secure etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} II:360, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:585 no. 10158).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'muzzle', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Kroonen 2013}:374, not in {ref Boutkan & Siebinga 2005}).

notes: Not in Morgenstierne (2003).

justificationDiscussion: A verbal derivative of Ancient Greek φῦσα 'breath, bellows', further connections outside of Greek unclear (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1599-1600)
Lexemes based on loans from Latin numerus 'number', cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:538).
Loanword from Persian.
A borrowing from Old French poldre, itself ultimately from Latin pulverem, ({ref Deshayes 2003}:596).
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:210 no. 3943 *khōla- (2) 'cavity, hollow', further etymology uncertain.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic dhā́ra- 'cutting edge', etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:388 no. 6788, cf. {ref EWAia} I:788-789).

notes: այս ay-s is a compound pronoun with PIE *ai̯- (cf. Skt. ay- 'this here; he'; e-ṣá, e-tá 'this here'; OP ai-ta 'id.') + PIE *k̑ó- (cf. Gsg. այսոր ay-so-r). Cf. այդ ay-d 'this here (by you)' < Proto-Armenian *ai̯-do- (ultimately from PIE *to-); այն ay-d 'that one (over there by him/her/it)' < Proto-Armenian *ai̯-no-.

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pei̯H- 'to swell up' ({ref EWAia} II:83-84, {ref LIV²} 464-465).
Derived from Classical Armenian kełt 'filth'. Further etymology obscure ({ref Olsen 1999}:963, cf. {ref HAB} II:570-571). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kełt-].

notes: Unknown etymology. (e)i̯-n-
justificationDiscussion: Of uncertain etymology.

A nominal compound, lit. 'bird-produce'. Cognacy in this set is coded for Armenian Arm. haw 'bird', continuing PIE *h₂eu̯-i- 'bird' (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:398-399). PIE *h₂ōu̯ió- 'egg' is considered by some to be a vr̥ddhi-derivative of this stem (cf. 'egg' in /cognate/28/ for further discussion).
From Classical Armenian mirg, a loan from Iranic, cf. Sogdian mγδʾk 'fruit' ({ref Olsen 1999}:895, {ref Benveniste 1964}:5). [MM: Proto-Armenian mirg]
Origin uncertain ({ref Olsen 1999}:944, cf. also {ref HAB} IIi:262, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:511). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *mar-].

Modern Greek lexemes from Hellenistic Greek δίδω 'give' (Ancient Greek δίδωμι) with the present stem re-characterised as a nasal present stem δίνω ({ref Babinotis 2010}:374), further to PIE *deh₃- 'give' ({ref Beekes 2010}:331-332), cf. {ref LIV²} 105-106).
Probably to be derived from Vedic √sthā- 'to stand' < *steh₂- 'to stand' ({ref EWAia} II:764-767, {ref NIL} 641).

Indo-Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *reu̯dH- 'to howl, to weep' ({ref LIV²} 508, cf. {ref EWAia} II:465-466, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:627 no. 10840, {ref Cheung 2007}:194, {ref ALEW} 847-848, {ref Derksen 2015}:377).
Loan from Church Slavonic нєбо 'sky' ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:53).
Loan from Italian petto 'chest'.
Modern Greek lexemes continuing a loanword from Latin gula 'throat, gullet' into Hellenistic Greek, cf. Standard Modern Greek γουλιά ({ref Babinotis 2010}:318).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Greek, and Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *sem- 'one (collective)' ({ref LIPP 2}:671-679, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:750-751, {ref Adams 2013}:721-722, {ref Beekes 2010}:394, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:467-468).
Nuristani lexemes as though from OIA riya- 'release, let go', ultimately from PIE *lei̯- 'slimy; glide', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 621.

gloss_in_root_lang: 'to hit, to meet with, to come together'

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:61-62 for various doubtful suggestions.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: The Catalan lexeme had been in /cognate/343/ before, but seemed not really to belong there. Is it a loanword from Germanic? (Freiberg)

justificationDiscussion: Etymology in this class follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1008-1009 to PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. {ref LIV²} 677), but cf. {ref Huld 1984}:130, {ref Orel 1998}:511 to 2. *u̯el- 'spin, roll' (cf. Lat. uoluō 'turn', etc.).
Loanword from Italian manco 'useless' (cf. also Albanian: Arbëresh manka 'left' in /cognate/8517/). [Not in {ref Rohlfs 1964}]
Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:767, {ref Beekes 2010}:1037-1038; cf. {ref ALEW} 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.
Loanword from Turkish, cf. Turkish avlamak 'to hunt' (cf. also {ref Dawkins 1916}:665).

notes: Loan from Turkish
justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Turkish deniz 'sea' ({ref Dawkins 1916}:674).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'become warm, hot' ({ref NIL} 196-199, {ref ESSJa} 7:42, 55-56, {ref Derksen 2008}:178-180; cf. {ref LIV²} 219-220).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'burn' in /cognate/2243/, 'day' in /cognate/3850/, 'fire' in /cognate/396/, 'hot' in /cognate/333/, 'sun' in /cognate/2299/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:289, {ref de Vaan 2008}:279).
Parallel loans from Church Slavonic ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:102, 105, {ref Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-} 2:174).
Perhaps to be connected to Latin cupiō, -ere 'to desire', but etymology ultimately unclear ({ref Untermann 2000}:405-406, {ref de Vaan 2008}:155).
Loan from Middle German rechen 'to count' (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:507-508).

Root assignment in this class follows {ref LIV²} 556-557 to *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off' rather than *(s)kerH- 'to separate, split' (so {ref Kroonen 2013}:443-444). PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ({ref LIV²} 559-560) is widely considered a variant of this root with a dental extension (cf. {ref LIV²} for further discussion).

Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes based on Vedic pipīlá- 'ant', of unknown origin ({ref EWAia} II:132-133, {ref KEWA} II:284-285). The modern forms exhibit six main variants, for which cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:463, no. 8201.

notes: with variants, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 316f., no. 5589ff., 5598f.; substrate?

justificationDiscussion: Modern Greek and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE 2. *kʷei̯- 'to gather, pile' (cf. {ref LIV²} 378-379, {ref Andriotis 1974}:458, {ref Beekes 2010}:1216, {ref Derksen 2008}:89, {ref ESSJa} 4:112-115).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *laṣṭi- 'stick', perhaps a contamination of Vedic yaṣṭí- 'stick, pole' with lakuṭa- 'club' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:637 no. 10991). Further connections are uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:406).

notes: not finally clear
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic kāṣṭhá- 'piece of wood', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:159 no. 3120, {ref EWAia} I:345-346).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed {ref LIV²}. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}. I assume the root *peu̯H-, cf. PG *fūla- 'filthy, foul' {ref Kroonen 2013}. The meaning 'dust' could develop from 'rotten wood'. Cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}.

Attempts at an Indo-European etymology (cf. {ref IEW} 392, {ref HAB} II:446-447) are unconvincing ({ref Olsen 1999}:936). The best etymological proposal so far is the suggestion of a Hurro-Urartian loanword, cf. Urartian ṣârə 'orchard'; Hurrian sarme 'wood' (cf. {ref Diakonoff 1985}:600). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsar-o-].

Root reconstruction difficult. A contamination between two (possibly related) roots *teu̯h₂- and *teu̯k- is a possibility. Cf. discussion in citations to this cognate class. Cf. also Germanic words for 'thigh' in /cognate/6956/. The PIE root reference form *teu̯(h₂)k- is provisional only.
Loan from Polish rachować 'to count', itself ultimately a borrowing from Middle German rechen 'to count' (cf. {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 5:33)
From Vedic kapā́la- 'skull, cranium' ({ref Turner 1931}:79, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:137 no. 2744), further etymology disputed (cf. {ref EWAia} I:300).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat' ({ref EWAia} II:169, {ref LIV²} 466-467; cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:460 no. 8140, 465 no. 8221).
As though from Indic *phutta- 'insignificant', cf. Bashkarik phut 'fly' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:511 no. 9085). Further etymology uncertain.

notes: mālikā- f. derived from Late Vedic mā́la- f. 'wreath, garland', cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 628; Turner 1062-66, p. 580, no. 10092; ultimately of Dravidian origin
justificationDiscussion: From Late Vedic mā́la- 'wreath, garland', probably a loanword from Dravidian, cf. Tamil mālai 'wreath, garland' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:580 no. 10092, cf. {ref KEWA} II:628, {ref EWAia} II:351).

Indo-Iranic lexemes from Vedic áṅgāra- 'glowing charcoal' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:6-7, no. 125), probably further from a PIE nominal formation *ángol-/*angl- or *Héngol-/*Hengl- (cf. {ref ALEW} 41 s.v. OLith. anglìs 'coal'). A further connection to Vedic agní- 'fire' could be possible, but the details remain uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:48). For Nuristan languages, cf. {ref Strand 1998}.

Armenian and Italic lexemes generally admitted to be cognates from a PIE s-stem *k̑ruH-s-, vel sim. In principle, however, the Armenian lexemes might be a loan from Iranic (cf. Av. sraoni- 'buttock, hip'). Cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:79, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:585-586, {ref de Vaan 2008}:147 for further discussion.

Of unknown origin ({ref Olsen 1999}:964). Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}. For older, now untenable proposed etymologies to Germanic *narwa- 'narrow', cf. {ref HAB} III:439-440, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:565, and further comments by MM in the cognate class citations. [MM: Proto-Armenian *neɫ-o-].
Probably inherited from Indo-European in view of the morphology, but there are no known cognates outside of Hittite (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:987).

It is unclear whether Josef Elfenbein apud {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:38 is implying that Pashto kāl 'year' is cognate with the Indic lexemes in this class, or that it is a loanword. If cognate, together with the Indic lexemes from Vedic kālá- 'time, point in time' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:157, no. 3084) they would point to a Proto-Indo-Iranic *kālá-. The cognacy of these forms has been tentatively accepted here for now. No further certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic, cf. {ref EWAia} I:343 for a discussion of the main possibilities.

No certain etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:940, cf. {ref HAB} I:77-78, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:5-7). Cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:6-7 for further discussion and a tentative proposal to PIE *p(e)h₂u̯- 'small'. [MM: Proto-Armenian *(h)ag-ii̯a-].

notes: cf. Geiger, W. (1941): An Etymological Glossary of the Sinhalese Language. Colombo, p. 47, no.687: "The initial k for g shows Tamil influence."

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Persian cf. /cognate/1831/

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 273, no. 4994 s.v. *chapp- ~ *chipp-; further etymology unclear
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from an Indic stem *chapp- ~ *chipp- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:273 no. 4994), further etymology obscure.

notes: the ad- of Vedic adás (adó) corresponds to Hittite ed- in edi, edani, etc. (suppletive to nom. c. asi); in Vedic suppletion with m.f. asáu ~ amú-, Vedic gen. amúṣya, Pali amussa ~ asu constitutes the ultimate origin of the NIA forms
cf. Turner 1931: 292, blend

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes generally connected to Latin orbus 'deprived of, childless, orphaned', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphaned' ({ref EWAia} I:119-120, {ref KEWA} I:52, cf. also {ref Weiss 2006}:256n30, {ref de Vaan 2008}:433, {ref Beekes 2010}:1113-1114).

notes: "B[ashkarik] [sic] lúkuṭ; K[ashmiri] lŏkuṭ, f. °küṭ 'small, shorter, younger'" (Turner q.v.)

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic ślakṣná- 'slippery, smooth, soft' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:738), further to PIE *slegh₂snó- ({ref EWAia} II:673), probably to be abstracted to a more basic root *(s)legh₂- (cf. Ancient Greek λαγαρός 'slack, loose').

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from PIE *slegh₂snó- ({ref EWAia} II:673, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:25-26), probably to be abstracted to a more basic root *(s)legh₂- (cf. Ancient Greek λαγαρός 'slack, loose'). Considered by {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:25-26 to be a variant of PIE *(s)lei̯- with a root-extension *-g̑-, but this conjecture remains uncertain.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8152 s.v. 'slimy, slippery'
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit picchala- 'slimy, slippery' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:460 no. 8152). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loan from a non-Indic source ({ref KEWA} II:271).
Derived within English, with metathesis, from Middle English drit + -y suffix, probably originally a loan from Old Norse drit 'excrement' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

First securely attested as Middle English dogge, generally considered to be of unknown etymology (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}. Cf. {ref Gąsiorowski 2006} for a recent attempt to derive Old English *docga from the colour adjective dox (gloss) 'dark haired, dusky'.
Of uncertain origin, perhaps a loan from early Scandinavian ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Modern Greek lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ὀρθός 'upright, straight; right, true'. Further etymology disputed, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:818-819 and {ref Beekes 2010}:1101 for various competing proposals.
From Ancient Greek ἑστία 'hearth, fireplace, altar' ({ref Dawkins 1916}:600), no further etymology (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:379, {ref Beekes 2010}:471-472 for further discussion).

Pontic Greek άψιμο(ν) a derivative of the aorist stem ἄψ- to Ancient Greek ἄπτω 'to join, attach; kindle', cf. Medieval Greek άψιμο ‘fever’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; not in {ref Andriotis 1974}), further to PIE *h₂ep- 'to join, fit' ({ref Beekes 2010}:120-121, cf. {ref LIV²} 269).
Tsakonian (ι)κ̔άρα < Ancient Greek ἐσχάρα ‘hearth’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:379-380, {ref Beekes 2010}:472).

notes: Connected with SMG δουλεύω 'I work' in the sense 'worked, finished' > 'smooth'??? (-MJCS)

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Italian anca 'hip'.

Connection to a common root *gʷʰreh₁- follows {ref LIV²} 221 and {ref Beekes 2010}:1121, but cf. the reservations of {ref EWAia} I:520. For Modern Indic lexemes attached to this set, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:244, no. 4520, p.245 no. 4531; {ref KEWA} I:362. For this Hellenic lexemes in this cognate set, this class encodes the compound element -φραίνομαι.

Hellenic lexemes as though from PIE *ken(H)-is- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:562, {ref Beekes 2010}:746-747, {ref Babinotis 2010}:706, 1284, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:115). The connection of Albanian hi 'ash' to this class (cf. /cognate/850/) presupposes the reconstruction of an s-mobile root *(s)ken(H)- (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:74, {ref Orel 1998}:47).
Based on a loanword from Italian largo. Greek: Italiot λάργκα treated as a separate loan event in in /cognate/5868/.

notes: cf. Pali jotati 'shines', joteti 'makes clear', Prakrit joyaï ~ jovaï ~ joi 'shines, sees', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 377, no. 6612

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as a transferred adjective in the phrase nummi aspri 'rough coins', the original semantic development to 'white' appears to have been '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:223-224, {ref Beekes 2010}:154, cf. /cognate/1565). In Italiot Greek the semantics further developed 'white' → 'white ash' → 'ash'.

Cf. SMG άχαρος ᾽without grace, elegance, beauty' from Ancient Greek ἄχαρις, remodelled as an o-stem άχαρος ({ref Babinotis 2010}:246), further to PIE *g̑ʰer(H)- 'desire, enjoy' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1606-1607, {ref LIV²} 176-177).

Cf. Standard Modern Greek τρανός 'very big in power or importance', from Hellenistic Greek τρανός, morphologically remodelled from early Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear distinct' < PIE *tr̥h₂-n-, cf. PIE *terh₂- 'to pass through, cross' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1444, {ref Beekes 2010}:1498-1499, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1128).

Cf. SMG αδρός 'sizable, stout' from Ancient Greek ἀδρός 'thick, stout, bulky', further a derivative of PIE *seh₂- 'to satiate' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:69, {ref Beekes 2010}:22, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:20, 121-122).

From Ancient Greek κύανος ({ref Andriotis 1974}:285), the name of a dark blue substance, 'enamel, lapis lazuli, blue copper carbonate', attested already in Mycenaean via ku-wa-no. Possibly an early loanword from an Indo-European Anatolian language, cf. Hittite kuu̯anna(n)- '(blue as) copper, ornamental stone' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:594-594, {ref Beekes 2010}:793).
loan_notes: Cf. Hittite kuu̯anna(n)- '(blue as) copper, ornamental stone'

justificationDiscussion: A formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, originally in the sense 'chat, prattle', later generalised as the generic verb 'to say' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:615-616, {ref Beekes 2010}:827-828).
No convincing etymology outside of Greek ({ref Beekes 2010}:551), but {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:438, {ref Beekes 2010}:551 for older proposals to Germanic lexemes.
From Ancient Greek ἀ-κάθαρτος 'un-cleansed' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:604); no further etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:478-479; {ref Beekes 2010}:614-615)

Modern Greek forms to be derived from Ancient Greek εὐθύς 'straight' (via εὐθειάζω with various analogical re-characterisations of the present stem, cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:1565-1566 for further discussion); no further satisfactory etymology outside of Greek; for some possible explanations within Greek cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:384-385, {ref Beekes 2010}:479.

Indo-Iranic, Slavic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' ({ref NIL} 698-700, cf. {ref EWAia} I:623-624, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:323 no. 5679, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:81, {ref Derksen 2008}:490, {ref Matasović 2009}:375, {ref LIV²} 629-630).

From α- (privative prefix) + the verbal adjective of (α)παλαίνω 'to wet', i.e. 'not wet' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); The verb (α)παλαίνω is a variant of ἁπαλύνω 'to soften', which is in turn derived from Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak', with no further etymology outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:95, {ref Beekes 2010}:113).

From Ancient Greek σαχνός 'tender' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), often further assumed to be connected to σώχω, ψώχω 'to rub down' but the details of the derivation are unclear; further etymology outside of Greek lacking ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:991, {ref Beekes 2010}:1314).

Cf. Vedic raśmi- 'rein, ray of light', Sinhalese rasmiya 'rays', rasnaya 'heat' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:616 no. 10648). The root of Vedic raśmi- is not attested verbally, but cognates in Iranic allow for the reconstruction of a basic root *rać-, probably 'to bind' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:440-441).
Loanword from Italian l'occhio 'the eye' with the Italian definite article analysed as part of the nominal stem.
loan_notes: Definite article analysed as part of the stem in the borrowed form.

justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes from Vedic uṣṇá- 'hot', derived to Vedic √oṣ- 'to burn' and further connected with PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'id.' ({ref EWAia} I:281, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:112, no. 2389; {ref LIV²} 245).

Morphological evidence points to the lexical root being inherited from IE (?*h₂lei̯bʰ-), but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:64); cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:57 for older hypotheses.
A loanword into Tsakonian from Medieval Greek (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
Parallel loans from Persian مکان 'place, location', ultimately from Arabic مکان 'id.'.
Root ref. form follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl, seethe' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:606, {ref de Vaan 2008}:524-525, {ref Derksen 2008}:434-435, cf. {ref LIV²} 305-306).
Parallel loans from Old French.  See also https://cobl.info/cognate/9691/, a further cognate set with the same Old French loan source, but including inheritance after the initial loan event..

Italiot Greek lexemes continuing a diminutive formation *σκουλλίον 'little neck' to Ancient Greek σκόλλυς 'fringe of hair' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:466-467). Further etymology disputed (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1020-1021, {ref Beekes 2010}:1356).

From Ancient Greek ῥύγχνος 'snout, beak' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:482). This is further connected to Armenian ṙngunkʻ 'nostrils, nose' by {ref Frisk 1960-1972} and {ref Beekes 2010}, but the lexeme may well also be expressive in origin (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:978-979).

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek ἀέρας, a new α-stem morphologically remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀήρ, ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds, atmosphere', and ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er- ({ref Babinotis 2010}:70, {ref Beekes 2010}:27).

Etymology outside of Celtic obscure ({ref Matasović 2009}:60, cf. Deshayes 2003}:98-99). {ref Delamarre 2003} suggests an etymology to an onomatopoeic IE root *buk- 'bark, scream', although the vocalism of Gaulish bocca rather than *bucca is unexpected.

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ἀληθινός 'true, genuine' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:25), further perhaps to be derived from PIE *leh₂d-, although the postulated root is based entirely upon internal reconstruction of the Greek evidence (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:65-66, {ref LIV²} 401-402).
From Ancient Greek ἐκκλύζω 'wash out, wash away' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:227), further to PIE *k̑leu̯H- 'purify' ({ref Beekes 2010}:718-719, {ref LIV²} 335).
Probably to be derived from the inherited word for 'honey' μέλι < PIE *melit- ({ref Andriotis 1974}:370, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:925-926). Regarding the IE 'honey', cf. {ref EIEC} 271.

notes: (α)φέγκη < ΑG αὐθέντης ‘lord, master’ (-Liosis).

justificationDiscussion: Continuing Medieval Greek σκιάζομαι 'to be frightened' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:462, cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:498), denominal to Ancient Greek σκία 'shadow'. For further discussion of the etymology of this root, cf. 'shadow' in /cognate/5058/.

Cf. SMG χώνω, from Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'heap up, raise, fill with earth' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1619), further to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1654, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1281, cf. {ref LIV²} 179).
Loanword from French jambe 'leg' ({ref Varella 2006}:252).
No clear etymology outside of Greek (cf. discussion in {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1290-1293 s.v. ψιλός, ψίω, ψῆν; {ref Beekes 2010}:1668-1669 s.v. ψιλός).
From Hellenistic Greek λεγνός, which according to the lexicon of Hesychius is the antonym of ἀδρός 'stout, fat' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). No further etymology.
Tsakonian λιανέ from Medieval Greek λειανός, ultimately a derivative of Ancient Greek λεῖος 'smooth'. For further justification of the root ref. form, cf. discussion in 'smooth' /cognate/8405/.

Italiot τσ̌υλι(μ)μένο (< *κυλι(σ)μένος), the passive participle of τσ̌υλίω /τσ̌υλλίτζω ‘to roll (on a dirty surface), to make dirty’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c., cf. {ref Rohlfs 1964}:282-283). Further etymology disputed: possibly to IE *kʷel(h₁)- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:598, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388), but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:800, who sees the word based on a substratum borrowing.
Possibly a compound of σ̌ομό (< θερμό) ‘food’ + ἐλατός ‘driven’, cf. Tsak. γαϊδουρο-άτα (< -ἐλάτης ‘driver’) (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further etymology uncertain.

Greek: Pontic ροΐζω 'fall' from Ancient Greek ῥοΐζω 'to drench (of horses)', a derivative of PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow, stream' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:482, {ref Beekes 2010}:1281-1282, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:970-971, cf. {ref LIV²} 588).
From Ancient Greek ῥεῦμα 'that which flows' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:438, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1210), further to PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1281-1282, {ref LIV²} 588).
Loanword from Turkish kelle 'head' ({ref Varella 2006}:268).
Loanword from Venetian rozza 'stone' ({ref Varella 2006}:251).
Loanword from Turkish orman 'forest, woods'.
Of obscure origin, perhaps to Ancient Greek ἐξ-(αν)αλίσκω 'consume' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
From Ancient Greek μόλω, the aorist subjunctive to Ancient Greek βλώσκω 'go, come' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:381), further to PIE *melh₃- 'to come' ({ref Beekes 2010}:223, {ref LIV²} 433-434).

notes: Loanword from Slavic.
justificationDiscussion: A loanword into Medieval Greek from Old Slavic logŭ ({ref Babinotis 2010}:786).
Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:767, {ref Beekes 2010}:1037-1038; cf. {ref ALEW} 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.
Loanword from Turkish pus 'fog, haze'.
From Ancient Greek δεῖσα 'slime, filth' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:202). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:259, {ref Beekes 2010}:311 for references to conjectural hypotheses).

Italiot καμουλία < Medieval Greek καύμα, κάμα ‘excessive heat’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; cf. also {ref Rohlfs 1964}:192). Further connected to the same root as Ancient Greek καίω 'to burn', to which cf. 'burn' in /cognate/1461/ for further etymological discussion.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'burn' in /cognate/1461/, 'day' in /cognate/2234/, 'dry' in /cognate/8281/, 'hard' in /cognate/8428/, 'sun' in /cognate/5455/.

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Turkish çayır 'meadow, grass' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

From Ancient Greek κρούω 'to strike, stamp, knock' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:337, {ref Babinotis 2010}:736), possibly further connected to TochAB kärn- if the lexemes in /cognate/2701/ reflect an unextended form of the same Indo-European root (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:785-786, {ref LIV²} 371).
From Hellenistic Greek κέλλα 'room, chamber', a loanword from Latin cella 'storeroom, chamber' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
From Ancient Greek σφάζω ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:493-494), further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1073, {ref Beekes 2010}:1426-1427).
From Ancient Greek ἐξευπορῶ 'to supply, deliver' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:246), further to PIE *perh₃- 'to provide, make available' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1222, {ref LIV²} 474-475).

From Ancient Greek στρεβλός (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), perhaps further to be derived from Ancient Greek στρέφω 'to twist, turn' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1062-1064, {ref Beekes 2010}:1412), but otherwise of obscure origin.

A derived verb from Modern Greek γούλα 'throat, neck' (cf. SMG αναγουλιάζω 'feel sick, be inclined to vomit', {ref Babinotis 2010}:116), in turn a loanword from Latin gula 'throat' (cf. 'neck' in /cognate/6065/).
loan_notes: A verbal derivative from Greek γούλα 'throat, neck', a loanword from Latin gula 'throat, gullet'

justificationDiscussion: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek σύρω, remodelled as a -νω present in Modern Greek varieties ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1259); probably further derived from PIE *tu̯er- 'sweep' although the details of the stem formation remain debated (cf. {ref Vine 1999a}:570-571, {ref Beekes 2010}:1424-1425).
From Ancient Greek *ἀνεμόω 'blow' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:110), a derivative to ἄνεμος 'wind', further to PIE *h₂enh₁- 'blow' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:101-102, {ref LIV²} 267-268).
Etymology disputed: either to Ancient Greek. ῥίς 'nose' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:480, cf. /cognate/2356/) or Ancient Greek. θίς 'heap, dune' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

From Ancient Greek ὀξεῖα, the feminine stem of Ancient Greek ὀξύς (adj.) 'sharp' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:411). Root etymology disputed. Traditionally to IE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. {ref IEW} 21-22, {ref Buck 1949}:1069, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:806-807), but this is difficult from a morphological point of view. Alternatively {ref Narten 1986}:204-214 has proposed a comparison with Ved. √akṣ- which could allow a Greek zero-grade formation *h₃k̑s- > ὀξ-, but this proposal has not been met with widespread acceptance (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1089).
Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek βέργα, a loan from Latin virga 'twig, bough, branch' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:263).

From Ancient Greek συλλογίζομαι 'reckon, compute' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:526), from συν- 'with' + λογίζομαι 'count, reckon' a denominal verb in -ιζω from Ancient Greek λόγος 'computation, reckoning', and o-grade noun from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' ({ref Beekes 2010}:841, cf. {ref LIV²} 397, {ref IEW} 658).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Medieval Greek ὀψές, with final -ς taken on analogy to (ε)χτές 'yesterday', from Ancient Greek ὀψέ 'a after a long time, at length, late' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1626), further from PIE *h₁op-s-, cf. *h₁ep- 'on' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1139).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek βοάω 'to cry, shout' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:185), a denominal verb to Ancient Greek βοή 'cry, shout'. No certain further etymology, possibly an onomatopoeic formation (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:182-183, {ref Beekes 2010}:224).
From Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:284). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:470, {ref Beekes 2010}:600-601 for various proposals.
Loanword from Tocharian B eprer ({ref Carling 2009}:74-75, {ref Adams 2013}:70).
Loanword from Low German runt 'round' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:655).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ({ref LIV²} 357, cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:231, {ref ESSJa} 4:85-87, {ref Derksen 2008}:86).
Loanword from Middle English battle, cf. Scottish Gaelic baideal 'battle, battlement' ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:37, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:26).
The root etymology in this set follows {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:673-674, assuming a prefix pe- 'away, thither' to verbal dā- 'take' < PIE *deh₃- (cf. {ref LIV²} 105-106).

NB: The Hittite lexeme is somewhat dubious in this meaning (cf. {ref CHD P}, s.v.); Etymology unclear: According to {ref HED PA}, from the same stem as Hitt. partāu̯ar 'wing' from PIE *(s)per- in /cognate/5101/, cf. also cautiously Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, p.506; however unconnected by {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:646-647.
Etymology uncertain, perhaps with PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'throw' according to {ref LIV²} 225, but rejected by {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:381-382 on formal and semantic grounds.

In origin a verbal adjective to Tsakon. λεχούκ̔ου 'lay (a child) in bed; incubate, warm (smth.)' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); the verb is derived from Ancient Greek λεχώ 'a woman in childbed, a woman who has just given birth' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:353). Further to be connected to Ancient Greek λέχος 'bed', λέχεται 'lie down in bed' from PIE *legʰ- ({ref Beekes 2010}:852-853, cf. {ref LIV²} 398).

Cf. SMG χλιός 'warm', χλιαίνω 'to make warm' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:569, {ref Babinotis 2010}:1601), probably further to an IE root *g̑ʰlei̯- 'gleaming, clear' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1637-1638), but cf. the reservations of {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1263 on the comparative semantics.

A verbal adjective derived from Hellenistic Greek βράζω 'boil, froth up' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:277). No further etymology, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:193, {ref Beekes 2010}:235-236 for various uncertain proposals.

Originally a passive participle of Ancient Greek χυλόω 'convert into juice; extract the juice from' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further etymology difficult; traditionally connected the same root as χέω 'pour' < *g̑ʰeu̯, but long -ῡ- is unexpected for the zero-grade of this root and difficult account for (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1280, {ref Beekes 2010}:1653).
Derived from Ancient Greek ἁπαλύνω (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further a denominal verb to Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak' of uncertain etymology ({ref Beekes 2010}:113).
From Ancient Greek κωφίας 'a kind of snake' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:344). No clear cognates outside of Greek ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:528, 607; {ref Beekes 2010}:816).
The semantic-bearing morpheme -εις is identical with Ancient Greek εἷς 'one'; cf. /cognate/6066/ for further etymological information.
A derivative from the same root as Ancient Greek πλάσσω 'shape, form' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1111), further etymology obscure ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:910-911, {ref Beekes 2010}:1203).

From Ancient Greek λακτίζω 'kick with the heel or foot' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:347), a derivative to λάξ (adv.) 'with the heel or foot' without convincing IE etymology (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:619, {ref Beekes 2010}:831-832).

From Ancient Greek *συμπιάζω (AGk. συμπιέζω), cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:528. Further etymology disputed, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:899-900, {ref Beekes 2010}:1189, for references to further literature.

From Ancient Greek ἐμπλέκω ‘to entwine’ ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:145, further from Ancient Greek (ἐμ)πλέκω 'to braid, knit, wind, twine' and ultimately derived from PIE *plek̑- 'to braid, twine' ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:914-915, {ref Beekes 2010}:1206-1207, {ref LIV²} 486).
From Ancient Greek τύπτω 'to hit, beat' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:563). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'hit' in /cognate/7794/.

Tsakonian νίου 'hear' from Ancient Greek νοέω 'perceive, observe, apprehend' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:395), which is turn a denominal verb from Ancient Greek νόος 'mind, sense, intellect'. Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:756-757, {ref Beekes 2010}:1023).

From PIE *meu̯h₂ or *meu̯h₃- according to {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:587-588 (cf. Gk. μῡ́ω 'to close the eyes'; {ref Oettinger 1979}:161ff.); the proposed Greek comparandum is listed under ?*meu̯s- in {ref LIV²} (only Greek), and may formally reflect either *meu̯H- or *meu̯s- (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:988).

Root etymology in this set follows {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:366-368, {ref Oettinger 1979}:480-481 to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' ({ref LIV²} 287), however cf. {ref HED H} 423, {ref LIV²} 287-288 preferring to set up *h₂u̯ei̯- to a perfect stem ?*h₂e-h₂u̯ói-/u̯i- considering the semantics 'blow' > 'run' semantically problematic.
Baltic lexemes to be connected with PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' (cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:260, {ref Derksen 2015}:229-230, 247-248, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560).
Generally derived from a PIE root 2. *ser- 'to string together, connect' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:727, {ref LIV²} 534-535).
Old Prussian lexeme, generally derived from PIE *lou̯k-sneh₂-, a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' ({ref Derksen 2015}:561, cf. {ref LIV²} 418-419).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'day' in /cognate/691/, 'eye' in /cognate/994/, 'good' in /cognate/1783/, 'moon' in /cognate/2336/, 'salt' in /cognate/3845/, 'sun' in /cognate/739/, 'white' in /cognate/2401/.

justificationDiscussion: Baltic lexemes as though from PIE ?*seu̯k- ({ref LIV²} 540, {ref ALEW} 988-989), although there are no certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic so an IE provenance is not assured. [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}].
Anatolian, Albanian, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *mel(it)- 'honey' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:580-581, {ref Demiraj 1997}:169-170, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:50-51).
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:803-805, {ref LIV²} 105-106).
For the etymology, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:545-546; for the root ref. form cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.

Albanian forms since {ref Meyer 1891}:23-24 compared with Greek φαίνω 'appear', a remodelled nasal-present stem *bʰ-né/n-h₂- to PIE 1. *bʰeh₂- 'shine' ({ref LIV²} 68-69, {ref Huld 1984}:43, {ref Demiraj 1997}:97-98, {ref Orel 1998}:22).
Borrowing from East Romance, cf. Romanian luptă 'fight' < Latin lucta 'wrestling' ({ref Orel 1998}:233)

Etymology uncertain. {ref Orel 1998}:30 considers a loan from Latin molere; {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:967 consider the lexemes inherited, possibly but not certainly to be connected with PIE *melh₂- since the stem formation remains unclear.
Loan from Latin fortis 'strong' or Italian forte 'id.' (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:110, {ref Orel 1998}:101).
Albanian forms derived to an original loan from Latin līmāre 'to file, polish, finish' ({ref Orel 1998}:222).
Loan from Latin coxa 'hip' ({ref Meyer 1891}:193, {ref Orel 1998}:188).

notes: Loan from Latin
justificationDiscussion: Generally regarded as a loan from Latin arēna 'sand' ({ref Demiraj 1997}:295, {ref Orel 1998}:370-371), but cf. {ref Holm 2011}:76-77 for a tentative proposal to the lexemes from PIE *h₁er- (cf. NHG Erde, etc. in /cognate/207).

Since {ref Jokl 1912}:192-195 generally connected with Ancient Greek σκέπω 'to cover, protect' from PIE ?2. *(s)kep- 'to cover', cf. {ref Orel 1998}:104, {ref LIV²} 555 (without Albanian cognates listed).
Loanword from Latin hospitium 'lodging, inn' (with metathesis of p and t in the borrowed form), cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:415-416, {ref Huld 1984}:115, {ref Orel 1998}:438.
Probably based on a loanword from Latin crucem 'crosswise, askew' ({ref Orel 1998}:183); earlier {ref Meyer 1891}:188 supposed a loan from Latin cortīna 'round vessel, cauldron'.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Proto-Indo-Iranian *j́ʱangʱā- f, *j́ʱangʱa- m., cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 564, cf. 'go' in /cognate/8326/.

notes: loan from Persian ران cf. /lexeme/47728/
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9742; further etymology unclear, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 294
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes connected with Vedic máṇḍala- 'circular, round' (adj.), 'disc' (n.) (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:559 no. 9742). No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. {ref EWAia} II:294).
Old Prussian lexeme derived from PIE *u̯orgʰó- 'outcast, ostracised' (cf. {ref ALEW} 1189-1191, {ref Derksen 2015}:489-490).
No clear etymology outside of Balto-Slavic; probably further connected to Lithuanian píepala 'quail (coturnix coturnix)'. Cf. discussion in {ref ALEW} 766.

Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Gk. καπνός 'smoke' ({ref ALEW} 545-546, {ref Derksen 2015}:268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison.

notes: some NIA forms may be blends with grāsa m. ʻmouthful', √gras- 'devour', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4379
justificationDiscussion: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic ghāsá- 'food, pasture grass' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:241 no. 4471), a derivative of Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, consume', cf. Young Avestan gah- 'to eat, devour'; further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:514; {ref LIV²} 198-199 mechanically reconstructs ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume').

No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic according to {ref ALEW} 1218-1219. {ref Derksen 2015}:497 connects the Balto-Slavic forms with Germanic *warha- following {ref Kroonen 2013}:574, but this proposal has not yet been widely accepted.
Generally connected to an IE root *pi̯eh₂- 'to hit, beat' ({ref LIV²} 481-482), but cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:360, {ref ALEW} 782-784 regarding some difficulties pertaining to the root reconstruction.

As though continuing Sanskrit cāra- *'grazing, fodder' (< 'motion, course'), cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:258 no. 4471. Further derived from Vedic √car-ⁱ 'to move oneself, go, walk, move, stir, roam about, wander', ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, turn oneself around' ({ref EWAia} I:534-535, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388).

Precise root identification uncertain. {ref LIV²} 399 suggests a connection to *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen', but cf. {ref ALEW} 576 which also suggests the possibility of connections to the root *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' (cf. {ref LIV²} 681-682) with a laryngeal metathesis.
Lit. 'not-clean', cf. Lithuanian švarùs 'clean', of uncertain etymology ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:654, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1040 for older proposals). [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}].
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *dʰer- 'to fix, make firm' ({ref LIV²} 145-146, {ref ALEW} 177-180, 193-194, {ref Derksen 2015}:116, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:93-94).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:325-326, {ref ALEW} 896-897 for further discussion.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1638, {ref EWAia} II:805-806, {ref ALEW} 1285-1286, 1296, {ref Derksen 2015}:511-512, {ref Derksen 2008}:541, {ref Matasović 2009}:160).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'moon' in /cognate/2337/, 'grass' in /cognate/1576/, 'red' in /cognate/3832/, 'white' in /cognate/2411/ 'yellow' in /cognate/7535/.

justificationDiscussion: Without certain etymology ({ref Smoczyński 2005}:382).
Etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Germanic (cf. {ref ALEW} 878-879, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:524).

As though from PIE *k̑éh₁k⁽ʷ⁾o- 'mowed grass'; The Old Prussian form shows some unexpected deviations from the East Baltic cognates (Lith. šė́kas 'grass, hay', Latv. sȩ̂ks 'freshly cut grass as cow-fodder'). Cf. {ref ALEW} 1017 for further discussion.
More precise origins uncertain, but possibly a loanword from Greek (cf. {ref Orel 1998}:257 and discussion in /cognate/6209/).

notes: cf. S, Cr. čȉt 'whole'
justificationDiscussion: Extra-Baltic connections unclear. The traditional connection to the family of Serbo-Croat čȉt 'whole', etc. is improbable ({ref ALEW} 490, cf. also {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:252, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:285). [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}].

No clear etymology outside of Baltic. A connection with PIE *klep- '(secretly) steal', hide' is often considered, but is only possible if one considers a secondary s-mobile and if the initial cluster *skl- can be simplified to *sl- ({ref LIV²} 363-364, {ref ALEW} 940-941).
Connections outside of Germanic uncertain ({ref Seebold 1970}:241, {ref Lehmann 1986}:160-161, {ref LIV²} 202), but cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:187-188 for proposed connections in Indic and Celtic.

Romance lexemes from Latin casa 'small house, hut, cabin' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:165-166). Further origins uncertain, possibly a loanword from one of the non-Indo-European languages of Ancient Italy ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:103, {ref de Vaan 2008}:96).

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain. Sometimes compared to Lithuanian gaĩla 'painful, unfortunate, pitiable', although the connection is uncertain due to the diverging semantics ({ref ALEW} 280-281, cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:161, accepting the etymology).

notes: parallel nursery words; cannot be considered cognates (compare Kölsch Bap 'daddy'); does Kashmiri بابء belong here?
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3890; compare 'fear' from *der- 'peirce, tear, split, burst' /cognate/2259/

justificationDiscussion: Cf. Old Lithuanian krẽklas 'female breast'; no certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 523).
No certain etymology ({ref ALEW} 308).
Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *ḍhākka- 'back, waist' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:316, no. 5582). No further etymology.
Cf. Lithuanian žíedas 'blossom, flower'. No certain etymology outside of Baltic ({ref ALEW} 1304-1305).

Cf. Old Lithuanian butà 'building, house, dwelling'; these Baltic lexemes are not to be separated from Proto-Celtic *butā- 'house' (cf. Old Irish buth, Middle Welsh bod); perhaps a derivative of PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to grow, originate, become', although the short vowel found in the Baltic forms is problematic and has led some to consider an old loanword from Continental Celtic into Proto-Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 153, {ref Derksen 2015}:107, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:83, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:68).
Cf. Latvian sēta 'fence', generally considered to be a derivative of PIE *seh₂(i̯)- 'to tie, bind' ({ref Karulis 1992}:175, for further discussion on the root reconstruction, cf. /cognate/3055/).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult, possibly further derived from PIE *pr̥-sth₂-o/i- ({ref Catt 2014}; cf. also {ref EWAia} II:100-101, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:474).

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: Certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking ({ref ALEW} 933, cf. {ref LIV²} 562). Identical to 'fly_V' in /cognate/2273/.

Romance lexemes from Latin levāre 'to lift up, raise' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:405-406, cf. {ref DCECH} III:636-638), a derivative of Latin levis 'light in weight' and further to PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light (in weight)' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:336).

notes: seng- 'thin, slender' and suffix -an
justificationDiscussion: Goidelic lexemes from Old Irish sengán 'ant'. Etymology uncertain, perhaps to be connected with Proto-Germanic *swengwan- 'to swing' (so {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:85-86, but proposed connections for this verb outside of Germanic are rejected by {ref Seebold 1970}:493, cf. {Kluge 2011}:836).

From Old Irish olc and generally further connected with PIE *u̯ĺ̥kʷo- 'wolf' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:400, {ref McCone 1985}:173–175; cf. also {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} O:20 for references to older literature).

notes: Probable Lallwort / nursery lexeme.

justificationDiscussion: A loanword from either Thraco-Dacian or Albanian ({ref Schulte 2009}:252), cf. the parallel borrowing of Medieval Greek *κοπέλι(ον) from Albanian kopil in /cognate/5836/.
To be connected with Old Irish uis 'sweet, suitable, appropriate', but further etymology obscure ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:21-22).

Possibly cognate with 'bite' in /cognate/4968/ if IE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth' is ultimately derived from *h₁ed- *'bite' → 'eat', cf. notes to 'tooth' in /cognate/328/ for further discussion. In any case the denominal verbs in /cognate/4968/ are a secondary replacement from the inherited primary verbal stem derived from *h₁ed-.
Etymology uncertain ({ref Matasović 2009}:363-364), for various proposals cf. {ref IEW} 1050, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:90).
No certain etymology, probably of expressive or imitative origin (cf. {ref DCECH} IV:498-502).

notes: Lallwort / Nursery Lexeme

justificationDiscussion: {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:195 suggested a connection to a basic root *ges- and to be compared with Latin gerere 'to carry, bear about' (past participle gestum), however the root etymology of Latin gerō, -ere is disputed. {ref Schrijver 1991}:18-19 tentatively rehabilitates an old proposal by Osthoff to *h₂eg̑- via a perform *h₂g̑-és-, and this followed by {ref de Vaan 2008}:259, but cf. the skepticism of {ref Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954} I:595-596, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:273-274. If the connection of Scottish Gaelic giùlain to a neo-root *ges- (< *h₂g̑-és-?) is to be maintained, this would be a unique Italo-Celtic lexical(-morphological) isogloss. Given the multiple degrees of speculation required to posit an ultimate root etymology to PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' for this exclusively Scottish Gaelic cognate set, the root reference form has been given as the Gaelic form itself.

Romance lexemes from Latin metus 'fear, alarm' ({ref DCECH} IV:66-67), no further etymology outside of Italic (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:402, {ref de Vaan 2008}:378 for various uncertain proposals).

Romance lexemes in light verb constructions using on Latin pavor 'fear' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:520, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 8:86), further probably to a root *peu̯- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:451, cf. {ref IEW} 827, not in {ref LIV²}).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deu̯k- ({ref LIV²} 124, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:181, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:250 no. 2785, {ref  {ref Matasović 2009}:108).

notes: Loan from English.
justificationDiscussion: Loanword from English 'carry' (first attested 1500s) ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Identical to Irish cliabh ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:83-84) from Old Irish clíab 'basket, woven container, hive'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:118 for a suggestion to Old Norse hlíf 'shield'.

Romance lexemes from Latin machināre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:423), a denominal verb to Latin machina 'machine, mechanical device', in turn an early loanword from (West) Greek μᾱχανᾱ́ 'id.' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:376).
loan_notes: Latin machināre is denominal to machina 'engine, mechanical device', a loanword from (Doric) Greek

justificationDiscussion: Cf. Sanskrit kaṭhiná- 'hard, firm', probably a loanword from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:132 no .2650, {ref KEWA} I:144).
Romance nominal derivatives based on a loanword from Old High German grīfan 'to grasp, grab' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:330, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 16:73-80).
Loan from North Italian
Loan from Italian persona 'person'.
Loanword from North Italian

notes: Loan from Old High German
cf. Sanskrit (Dhātup.) kaḍḍati, Turner 1962-66, p. 133, no. 2657; loan from a substrate (Munda or Dravidian), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p 144; perhaps related to /cognate/6387/
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:133 no. 2657. Sanskrit (Dhātup.) kaḍḍati 'is hard'. {ref KEWA} I:144 groups with kaṭhiná- 'hard, firm' as part of a group of probable loans from Dravidian (cf. Tamil kaṭṭu 'hardness').
Loanword from Middle Low German schrī(e)n.

notes: cf. Persian سفت seft
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans into Indic from Persian.
Loanword from Italian or Latin combatt(u)ere 'to fight'.
Probably an onomatopoeic form in origin ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:241). Cf. also {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:109, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Deshayes 2003}:425-426.

Romance lexemes from Latin mansio 'a staying, a remaining; lodging' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:433, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 6/1:234). Further to PIE 2. *men- 'stay, wait' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:362, cf. {ref LIV²} 437).

Etymology disputed. Originally proposed a loanword from Latin sequor 'follow' by {ref Meyer 1891}:408 and followed by {ref Holm 2011}:86; alternatively considered since {ref Jokl 1911}:80-82 to be connected with Albanian shteg 'path', cognate with Greek στοῖχος 'row, line' and derived from PIE *stei̯gʰ- (followed by {ref Huld 1984}:114, {ref Orel 1998}:421; cf. {ref LIV²} 593-594, without Albanian). [Not in {ref Demiraj 1997}, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}].
Etymology unclear, perhaps a loan from Slavic *grebǫ 'to rake up', cf. Serbian grebeti 'scratch' according to {ref Meyer 1891}:125, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:116.
Derived from Latin complēre 'to fill, complete' (cf. {ref DCECH} II:290), further to PIE *pleh₁- 'be filled, become full' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:472-473, {ref LIV²} 482-483).
No certain etymology ({ref Schrijver 1995}:223). {ref Deshayes 2003}:281 considers a loanword from English wail.
Probably a loanword from Brythonic, cf. Welsh cwyn 'complaint' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:18-19), but cf. the discussion of {ref Le Mair 2011}:177.
A loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian njušiti 'to smell' (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:311, {ref Orel 1998}:301-302).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:98 for various proposals.
Denominal formation from Welsh cri 'cry', respectively a loanword from English cry ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

From Latin barbatus 'bearded' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), a derivative of Latin barba 'beard'. For the IE reconstruction see {ref ALEW} 97, but cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:69 considering a European loanword on the basis of having to reconstruct PIE *a.
Loanword from Slavic *glъtъ 'sip, gulp' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

notes: Related to Turner no. 1935???

justificationDiscussion: Generally derived from Proto-Celtic *tuk-slo- ({ref Deshayes 2003}:734, but cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:393-394 preferring *tullo-), ultimately derived from PIE *teu̯k- 'beat, hit' ({ref LIV²} 640).

Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *ha(u)beda- ~ *ha(u)buda- 'head' and Italic lexemes from Latin caput, generally considered root and suffix cognate, but further identification of an Indo-European root etymology remains controversial. A frequent suggestion is to PIE *keh₂p- 'to grasp, seize' found in Latin capiō, -ere 'id.' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:215, {ref de Vaan 2008}:91). Alternatively a frequent comparison is made to Sanskrit kapā́la- 'cup, skull' with a different nominal suffix, but this cognate relationship remains uncertain ({ref Kluge 2011}:530-531, {ref KEWA} I:155, {ref EWAia} I:300).

Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish rúamor 'digging', derivative of rúam 'spade'. Further etymology unclear, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:48-49 for various previous proposals which remain uncertain.

notes: etymology unknown.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:135, {ref Holm 2011}:54-55, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:265 for further discussion.
Cognacy in this class follows {ref Demiraj 1997}:200-201 deriving to PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'to kindle, ignite (smth.)', but cf. {ref Orel 1998}:147.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *gn-ii̯o- 'to beget; to make, do', a derivative of PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to produce, beget' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:149, {ref Schumacher 2004}:339-347, {ref Matasović 2009}:163-164, {ref LIV²} 163-165). The Goidelic lexemes in this set continue a compound with the preverb de-, di- 'from, away from'.

Brythonic Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *u̯reg-e/o- 'to make, do', ultimately from PIE *u̯erg̑- 'to act, do' ({ref LIV²} 686-687, cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:76, {ref Schumacher 2004}:707-711, {ref Matasović 2009}:429-430).
From Old English brid, further etymology unknown ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).

Loans from Low German (cf. {ref Den Danske Ordbog}).  Given that Danish is the main lexical source of Riksmal, and the latter derives from it within the last few centuries, the loan event here should arguably have been into Danish before the derivation of Riksmal, and therefore not 'parallel'.

From PIE *g̑erh₂- 'wear down, make old' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:271, {ref Kroonen 2013}:312; cf. {ref LIV²} 165-166); for the Romance lexemes in this class from Latin granum 'grain, seed', cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:327-328.
Etymology disputed, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:226, 494, 511-512; {ref Holm 2011}:50-51 for further discussion.
From Old English cest 'box, coffer', perhaps a loanword from Latin cista 'box, chest', but not fully clear (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:275, {ref Orel 2003}:226-227). Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:314 for a speculative proposal to Sanskrit jáyati 'to overpower'.
Loan from Slavic zapadati 'to fall' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:424, {ref Orel 1998}:514-515 for various proposals and further discussion.
Loanword from Old French crier ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:564-565, {ref de Vries 1977}:684).

notes: variant of PIE *kʷo--

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sweltan- 'to dwindle, starve, perish'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly to a PIE root ?*su̯eld- 'to starve, die' if to be connected with Armenian  kʻalcʻ 'hunger' < ?*su̯l̥d-sk̑o- (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:336, {ref Kroonen 2013}:499, cf. {ref LIV²} 610).

No certain etymology outside of Italic; previous proposals to Old Icelandic sax Old High German sahs 'knife' are unsatisfactory semantically and formally (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:597, {ref de Vaan 2008}:541 for further discussion).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *k̑erd- 'heart' ({ref NIL} 417-423, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:469-471, {ref Beekes 2010}:644, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:576-578, {ref EWAia} II:818, {ref ALEW} 1032-1034, {ref Derksen 2015}:448-449, {ref Derksen 2008}:485, {ref de Vaan 2008}:134-135, {ref Matasović 2009}:223-224). The irregular correspondence of Proto-Indo-Iranic word-initial *j́ʰ- (> Ved. h-, Av. z-) is presumably due to contamination with Proto-Indo-Iranic outcome of PIE *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁- 'guts', cf. /cognate/2672/.
Lit. 'un-washed', from Proto-Germanic *þwahan- 'wash'. Further etymology outside of Germanic obscure ({ref Lehmann 1986}:369, {ref Kroonen 2013}:555).

Romance lexemes from Latin prehendere 'grasp, seize' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:558-559, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 9:339-354), further derived from PIE *gʰed- 'grasp' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:487, {ref LIV²} 194).

Romance lexemes from Latin levāre 'to lift up, raise' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:405-406), a derivative of Latin levis 'light in weight' and further to PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light (in weight)' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:336).

notes: Loans in Kurdish would be old, viz. before *rd/rz > ł in Kurdish vs. l in Persian.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: loan from Persian دل del, cf. /lexeme/35802/, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 818, but ultimately cognate with /cognate/6485/

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:163-164, {ref Kroonen 2013}:75, 150 for proposed further connections.
Romance lexemes from Latin coxa 'hip' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:212), further to PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:140).

A semantic extension from Proto-Germanic *burzda- 'board; table'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared to a root *bʰerdʰ- 'to cut' ({ref IEW} 138, {ref de Vries 1977}:50) but only uncertainly postulated as ?*bʰerdʰ- in {ref LIV²} 77-78. Alternatively {ref Kroonen 2013}:74, 86 proposes an etymology comparing a secondary zero-grade form *bruzda- > ON broddr 'tip, edge, shoot', OHG brort 'point, margin' and Old Irish brot 'goad, spike' from an o-grade formation to a postulated root *bʰrezdʰ-.
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:95, {ref LIV²} 157-158, {ref Kroonen 2013}:102 for further discussion).
Denominal verbs from a Germanic loanword *stakka 'stake, vine stake' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:678, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:195-206).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, and Italic reflecting different derivatives from PIE *gʷerh₂- (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:173-174, {ref Adams 2013}:230-231, {ref Beekes 2010}:202-203, {ref EWAia} I:490-491, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:91 no.1962, {ref Karulis 1992} I:321, {ref Kroonen 2013}:312, {ref de Vaan 2008}:272, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:328 no. 3855).
No certain etymology ({ref Deshayes 2003}:338).
Continuing Old Irish úr 'soil, earth' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:387), further etymology unknown (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} U:26 an evaluation of various uncertain proposals).
Etymology uncertain. No etymology given in {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}; not in {ref Falileyev 2000}, {ref Matasović 2009}, {ref Schumacher 2004}, or {ref Stokes 1894}.

Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *pleh₂g- 'to beat'. There is anomalous devoicing of the velar in Slavic, but the two variants *pleh₂g- and ?*pleh₂g- are accepted to be the same root by {ref LIV²} 484-485). Cf. also {ref Derksen 2008}:402, {ref Boryś 2005}:443, {ref de Vaan 2008}:469-471.

Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *dānu-, probably to be further connected with Vedic dā́nu- 'dropping flow, dripping; drops, dew'(?); the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Iranic *dan- < Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰan- 'to run, flow' (< PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off', cf. {ref LIV²} 144-145) is not to be excluded ({ref ESIJa} II:450-451, cf. {ref EWAia} I:719-720, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:366-367).

notes: Assamese and Bengali both add a participle form of 'to go' (inherited in Assamese, loaned from Sanskrit in Bengali) as first member of a compound.
justificationDiscussion: Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 386-388.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'round' in /cognate/4906/, 'live' in /cognate/3185/, 'navel' in /cognate/7117/, 'walk' in /cognate/1626/, 'turn' in /cognate/5879/.

justificationDiscussion: No convincing etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:39).

notes: loan from Pashto

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin uadere 'to advance, proceed' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:760), further to PIE *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'to stride' (cf. {ref LIV²} 664, {ref de Vaan 2008}:650).
Romance forms derived from Latin vīscus, -eris 'inner part of the (animal) body, entrails', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:741, {ref de Vaan 2008}:683).

Romance lexemes based on a denominal verb from Latin fīlum 'thread, string' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:286-287, {ref DCECH} III:361-362); further from PIE *gʷʰiH-(s-)lo- 'sinew, sinew thread'. The Italic forms require the reconstruction of initial voiced-aspirated *gʷʰ-, but other proposed cognates from Indo-Iranian and Greek suggest initial *gʷ- without aspiration (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:220; listed in {ref IEW} 489 with only Italic, Celtic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes connected).

Romance forms from Latin cīrcā, an adverbial form of Latin cīrcus 'circle; circus' ({ref DCECH} II:42). Further probably a loanword from Ancient Greek κίρκος, κρίκος 'ring' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:122-123, {ref de Vaan 2008}:115).

From Latin mūsculus 'muscle' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:476), a derivative of Latin mūs 'mouse', from PIE *mūs, (gen. mūsós) (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:424, {ref de Vaan 2008}:396-397). Precise stem analysis difficult; the attested languages consistently show a non-ablauting nom.sg. *mūs, but it is unclear whether this is inherited as such from PIE, or the result of secondary compensatory lengthening from laryngeal loss (e.g., {ref de Vaan 2008}:396-397 assuming a stem *muH-, cf. also {ref EIEC} 387 assuming *mūs < *mus-s).

This class is coded for Walloon jambe, from Latin camba, gamba 'horse's ankle' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:143, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:111-120), most likely to be a loanword from Ancient Greek καμπή 'a bending, winding' in the technical language of horse veterinarians and breeders ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:267).
loan_notes: Borrowed into Latin from Ancient Greek as a terminus technicus; acquired specialised meaning 'leg' only later in Romance.

justificationDiscussion: Probable loanwords from (Gascon) Occitan barrique 'barrel, wine cask' (cf. {ref DCECH} I:524-525).  Probable parallel loanword, after Portuguese and Spanish were already divergent.
Etymology unknown (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated, but the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is generally agreed. For the Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes in this class, cf. {ref ESSJa} 4:184-187, {ref Derksen 2008}:133, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:360-361, {ref Kroonen 2013}:327, {ref de Vaan 2008}:348, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:415 no. 5116, 5119. The reconstructed root form for this class follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref DCECH} VI:849-851 for various proposals.
Loanword from English 'to cuff', i.e. 'to strike, buffet' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Loan from Scots English debate (?), cf. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:299, 354.

Identical to Irish cogadh ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:56), from Old Irish cocad 'war; means of waging war', a compound of com- + cath 'battle' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:137. The extent to which there are further Indo-European connections is debated; generally further connected to Hitt. kattu- 'enmity, strife' (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:466), and Proto-Germanic *haϸu- 'battle' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:214-215), and perhaps further to Sanskrit śátru- via a different stem formation (but cf. the reservations of {ref EWAia} II:607). Traditionally reconstructed as *k̑atu- ({ref IEW} 534, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:195), but because the Leiden school denies the reconstruction of an Indo-European phoneme *a, alternative reconstructions *k̑h₂et- and *⁽k̑⁾h₃-tu- are proposed respectively by {ref Kloekhorst 2008} and {ref Kroonen 2013}. Here the traditional reconstruction of {ref IEW} has been tentatively followed.
Loan from Standard German kämpfen 'to fight'.

Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin gurdus 'blockhead, stupid person' ({ref DCECH} III:173, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:333). A root-etymology to a zero-grade form *gʷr̥d-  might be found with the family of lexemes found in Greek βραδύς 'slow', Lithuanian gurdùs 'id.', Latv. gur̃ds 'tired', OCS grьdъ 'haughty, proud' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:275, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:275); in antiquity the grammarian Quintilian considered Latin gurdus a word of Spanish origin.

notes: Preserved -d- in Modern Indic presupposes parallel loans from Sanskrit nadīḥ, cf. /cognate/808/.
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Sanskrit nadī- 'river'
Probably a loanword from Andalusian Arabic ġárfa 'handful' ({ref DCECH} III:102)
Generally assumed to be a loanword from Continental Celtic, cf. Gaulish *banno- 'horn'.
Loan from Old Spanish chifle 'whistle; container made of horn'.

A derivative of Portuguese apertar 'tighten, press, clamp', from Latin appectorāre 'press on the chest' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:44), further derived from Latin pectus 'chest'. For connections elsewhere in Indo-European, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:491, {ref de Vaan 2008}:453, and further discussion in /cognate/4015/.

Portuguese from Latin ad noctem 'at night' ({ref Williams 1962}:84-85, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:491), from PIE *nekʷt- 'night', a t-stem derivative to PIE *negʷ- 'become dark' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:416-417, {ref NIL} 504-513).
From Latin costa 'rib, side' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:211, {ref DCECH} II:278-279), further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:146, {ref de Vaan 2008}:140)
Parallel loans from Sanskrit samudrá- 'gathering of the waters, sea, ocean', cf. /cognate/730/

Romance lexemes derived from Latin coactāre 'press together' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:188-189, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:809), a derivative of Latin agere 'to drive' from PIE *h₂eg̑- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:30-31).
Contrarary {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:275, probably an onomatopoeic formation (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 3:762-764).
A derived adjective from Old French çucre 'sugar', ultimately a loanword from Arabic sukkar 'sugar' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 19:161-164).
Derived from Old French crues, cf. French creux 'hollow'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps Gaulish? (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:1362-1365).

East Romance lexemes from Latin *sappere ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), originally a denominal verb from Latin sappa 'a kind of mattock'. Further etymology obscure; an Illyrian loanword? (Cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:801, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:594).

Derived from a PIE base *k̑uH-, if to be connected with Skt. śū́la- 'spear' with the shortened vowel length in Celtic and Italic due to Dybo's Law (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:150, {ref Matasović 2009}:229).
Welsh lexemes continuing PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' ({ref Matasović 2009}:181-182, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'worm' in /cognate/172/.
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:13, {ref Matasović 2009}:185); cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} for a survey of older proposals.
Etymology uncertain ({ref Deshayes 2003}:669).

Without clear etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:703). Cf. {ref Hill 2003}:128 for a recent attempt to connect with Germanic, but also the critical appraisal of {ref de Vaan 2008}:630).

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish mes(s) 'tree fruit, mast' ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:298, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:246). Further IE root etymology in this set follows {ref NIL} 463-465 to PIE *med- 'to become full, sated', but cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:268-269.
Loanword from Persian سایه / sāyeh 'shadow'.

notes: Sanskritisms, cf. Old Bengali chāa ~ chāva 'shade', Hindi chāī̃, see Turner 1962-66, p. 257f., no. 5027
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Sanskrit chāyā- 'shadow'.
East Romance lexemes from Latin recēns 'of recent origin, fresh' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further to PIE *ken- 'fresh, recent' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:516, cf. {ref LIV²} 351).

Romance forms from Latin quirītare 'to make a public outcry' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 2:1484), a verbal derivative to Latin quirīs, -ītis 'name for Rome's citizens in their peacetime function'; further origins obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:559, {ref de Vaan 2008}:509-510).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin horridus 'standing on end, rough, shaggy, bristly, prickly' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:350, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:486-487), further derived from Latin horreō 'to be stiffly erect, shudder' and ultimately derived from PIE *g̑ʰers- 'to bristle, stiffen' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:290, {ref LIV²} 178).
Loan from Turkish murdar 'unclean' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Loanword from Slavic prachŭ 'dust' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

From Latin pavimentum 'pavement' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), derived from Latin paviō 'to thump, pound, strike' and further to PIE *pi̯eh₂- 'beat' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:451-452, cf. {ref LIV²} 481-482).

Continuing older Irish cor 'put, place; let go; twist, turn', traditionally connected to a root *(s)ker- 'turn, bend' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:204-206, though now generally rejected. {ref Schrijver 1997a}:297 instead suggests a possible root *kur- for related vocabulary for the proposed connection to Latin curvus 'curved, bent', Greek κυρτός 'curved', but cf. also discussion of {ref de Vaan 2008}:158, {ref Beekes 2010}:758-759 respectively regarding the proposed Latin and Greek cognates.
Lexemes continuing denominal verb pappāre from Latin pap(p)a, a child language word for 'food' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:511 No. 6214, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:511).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *menH- 'to step, stamp on' ({ref Matasović 2009}:276, cf. {ref LIV²} 438).
Goidelic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'to rise, to stride' ({ref LIV²} 593-594, cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:637-640, {ref Matasović 2009}:376).
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:178 no. 3441, to Vedic kr̥śá- 'lean, thin', further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾erk̑- 'to emaciate' ({ref EWAia} I:318-319, 395-396, cf. {ref LIV²} 355).

Iranic lexemes with no certain etymology. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}: 113 connects them with the Indo-Iranic root for 'flap, flutter'. {ref Cheung 2007}: 83 follows this proposal for the words of the Shughni group, but omits Wakhi (presumably an oversight.

Romanian ceață, from Latin caecus 'blind' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further to be connected with Old Irish cáech 'one-eyed', Goth. haihs 'id.' via PIE *⁽k̑⁾eh₂i-ko- or similar ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:82, {ref de Vaan 2008}:79).
Loan from Persian ستاره / setāreh 'star'.

Romanian pădure, as though from *padule(m) < Latin palūde(m) 'fen swamp' (nom.sg. palūs) with metathesis ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:507, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further generally compared to Skt. palvala- 'pond, pool' and Lith. pélkė 'bog, marsh' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:442, cf. {ref EWAia} II:105, but {ref ALEW} 753 against the connection of the Baltic lexemes).
Loanword from Germanic *brekan- 'break' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:267, cf. French broyer 'grind').

From Latin tālem 'of such kind' acc.sg., ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:705 s.v. talis), further from PIE *teh₂li- 'such', either an adjective derived to the pronominal stem *teh₂- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:605) or a univerbation of a decollective adverb *téh₂-h₁ with a deictic particle *li (so {ref LIPP 2} 490).
Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:317-318, {ref DCECH} III:353-354), further to PIE *⁽g̑⁾el- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:256).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10299, s.v. mr̥ṣṭá-, either from marś- (< Hmelk̑-) or marj- (or blend), cf. LIV, p. 280f. with Anm. 1
justificationDiscussion: IE root etymology uncertain: either to {ref LIV²} 226-227 *Hmelk̑- 'abstreifen, (ab)wischen' (> Ved. √marś- 'touch, stroke, handle') or {ref LIV²} 280-281 *h₂merg̑- (> Ved. √marj- 'wipe, rub, cleanse'). A blend might also be possible. (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:594-595 no. 10299, {ref EWAia} II:325-326, 331-332, 373.

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Old Indic madhurá- 'sweet', a secondary derivative of Old Indic mádhu- 'honey, mead' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:562 no. 9793), further from PIE *medʰu- 'mead, honey; sweet drink; alcoholic drink' ({ref EWAia} II:302-303, cf. {ref EIEC} 271).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *Hnas- 'to reach, attain, take', further to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, attain' ({ref Cheung 2007}:183-184, cf. {ref LIV²} 282-283).
Romanian lexemes from Lat. frondea ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:244 for further discussion).

notes: *k̑lou̯ni- > *srauni- > šōn° → šun° (Wakhi would regularly develop *sr > ṣ̌)
loan_notes: Early loan from some Eastern Iranic source with *sr > š; alternatively simply Persian, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1938}: 544.

justificationDiscussion: As though from Latin *stancus ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:679, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further to Latin stant-, the participle of stāre 'to stand' (cf. /cognate/309/ for further etymological discussion).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Slavic trajati, cf. Serbo-Croatian trȁjati 'to last, continue' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
From Latin gula, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:284-285, {ref de Vaan 2008}:275 for further discussion).

notes: Sanskritism

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin fracidus 'very soft' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:297-298), a derivative of Latin fracēs 'grounds, dregs (from olive pressing)'. Further etymology obscure (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:251, {ref de Vaan 2008}:238 for various proposals).

Romanian alerga, as though from Latin *allargāre, a verbal derivative of lārgus ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:28, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:342, {ref de Vaan 2008}:327).
Loan from Bulgarian nasip 'bank, embankment' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

From Latin ex-pōnere 'to put out, set forth' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further probably derived from PIE *tk̑ei̯- 'settle, inhabit' (cf. {ref LIV²} 643-644, {ref de Vaan 2008}:479 for discussion of the stem formation in Italic).
Loanword from German schwach 'weak' [Not in {ref Karulis 1992}].
Lit. 'not-good'. Further etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. discussion under 'good' in /cognate/678/.

Romance lexemes from Latin recentāre 'refresh; wash with water; clean' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:589-590), a derivative of Latin recēns 'of recent origin, new, fresh', further to PIE *ken- 'fresh, recent' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:516, cf. {ref LIV²} 351).
Romance lexemes from Latin prīmus 'first' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:560), further to PIE *pr(e)i- 'before' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:488-489, {ref LIPP 2} 640).

Romance lexemes from Latin dēlicātus 'luxurious, self-indulgent' ({ref DCECH} II:439-440, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:234), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:168, {ref de Vaan 2008}:321-322 for discussion of various proposals).
Probably a borrowing from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian vrtjeti 'spin', Bulgarian въртя 'turn' + prefix în- (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).

notes: < Old Marathi tāṁbaḍā ʻredʼ, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 329, no. 5779 s.v. Vedic tāmrá- adj. ʻdark red, copper-colouredʼ (VS), n. ʻcopperʼ (Kauś), tāmraka- n. Yājñ. (√tam-), cf. PIE *tmHró- from *temH- 'be dark, dull, wan, mat, lacklustre, beamless, dim, tarnished' and 'faint', cf. ²LIV, p. 624 with note 1
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10948 s.v. lábhate (~ rábhate), analogically influenced by MIA deti and neti 'takes', thus e instead of a
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes derived from Old Indic √labh- 'to grasp, seize', ultimately from PIE *lembʰ- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:635 no. 10948, {ref EWAia} II:434-435, {ref LIV²} 411-412).
No satisfactory etymology. Some attempts have been made to relate to PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink', cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:267 for further discussion.

notes: From older Iranian *miθra-, name of the sun god
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *mitrá- 'contract; god of contract', further etymology disputed (cf. {ref EWAia} II:354-355, {ref Encyclopædia Iranica} s.v. Mithra).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- '(to make) red' ({ref NIL} 580-584, {ref EIEC} 480-481, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:570-571, {ref Beekes 2010}:465-466, {ref EWAia} II:471, {ref ALEW} 847, {ref Derksen 2015}:376-377, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Kroonen 2013}:406, {ref de Vaan 2008}:527, {ref Matasović 2009}:315, {ref LIV²} 508-509).

notes: Cf. present day French route 'way, path'
justificationDiscussion: Denominal verb from the Walloon equivalent of Modern French route 'way, path' < Lat. rupta (via) 'broken path', the feminine past passive participle to Latin rumpere 'to burst, break open', further to PIE *(H)reu̯p- 'to break, tear up (intr.)' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 10:569ff., {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:616, {ref de Vaan 2008}:529-530, cf. {ref LIV²} 510-511).

Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes reflecting different derivations from PIE *dek̑s- 'to be suitable' ({ref Beekes 2010}:316-317, {ref Demiraj 1997}:137-138, {ref Orel 1998}:67-68, {ref EWAia} I:690-691, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:349 no. 6119, {ref ALEW} 199, {ref Derksen 2015}:124, {ref ESSJa} 4:218-219, {ref Derksen 2008}:100-101, {ref Kroonen 2013}:512, {ref de Vaan 2008}:168, {Matasović 2009}:97, cf. {ref LIV²} 112)

Possibly to be connected with Greek κακός (cf. {ref Orel 1998}:175, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:239, {ref Beekes 2010}:619-620), but it is difficult to be fully certain of the etymology (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:216-217); cf. discussion in /cognate/7332/.
Generally connected with Vedic ásita 'dark coloured, black' and Young Avestan āhita- (if meaning 'spotted, unclean'). Further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:482, {ref EWAia} I:146).
Loanword from Sanskrit vyakti- f. ʻindividualʼ BhP.
