As though from Proto-Iranic *fra-jan- to Proto-Iranic *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike', ultimately to PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref Cheung 2007}:224-225, {ref EWAia} II:800-801, cf. {ref LIV²} 218-219).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hit' in /cognate/1998/, 'kill' in /cognate/3551/, 'throw' in /cognate/8806/, 'hunt' in /cognate/1298/, 'tail' in /cognate/1935/, 'run' in /cognate/5193/.

notes: cf. Turner 1931: 534, 1962-66, no. 10539 s.v. rakta- ʻcoloured, dyedʼ (ŚB), ʻredʼ (ŚāṅkhGr̥.), n. ʻbloodʼ (Mn.), °aka- ʻredʼ (VarBr̥S) (√rañj-), Pali Prakrit ratta-, Rom. rat m.; cf. /cognate/1814/; LIV, p. 587
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit rakta- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:610, no. 10539; {ref EWAia} II:424-425, {ref LIV²} 587).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *stembʰH- 'to support, to lift' ({ref EWAia} II:754, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:788 no. 13676, {ref Cheung 2007}:362, cf. {ref LIV²} 595-596).

From Ancient Greek τρανόω 'make clear, plain, distinct', a secondary verbal derivative via Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear, distinct', ultimately from PIE *terh₂- 'to pass, cross' ({ref Dawkins 1916}:652, {ref Beekes 2010}:1498-1499, cf. {ref LIV²} 633-634).

Cappadocian ανανούμαι 'think' from Ancient Greek ἀνανοέω 'call to mind' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:101-102), which is turn a denominal verb from Ancient Greek νόος 'mind, sense, intellect'. Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:756-757, {ref Beekes 2010}:1023).
Parallel loans from Sanskrit hr̥dayam 'heart'.

Pontic Greek ανασμαίνω from Ancient Greek ἀνασθμαίνω 'to breathe with difficulty', a denominal verb to Ancient Greek ἄσθμα 'short-drawn breath, panting' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:148). Older attempts to connect Ancient Greek ἄσθμα to ἄνεμος 'wind' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:122-123) are formally impossible ({ref Beekes 2010}:148) as one would expect a base ἄνε- from the root *h₂enh₁-. Consequently, there is currently no known etymology outside of Greek.

notes: βαστώ < MedG βαστώ < ΑG βαστ-άζω (-Liosis).

justificationDiscussion: Pontic ρασ̌ί(ν) 'mountain' < Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'spine, backbone' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:477). Further traditionally compared with Lithuanian ražis 'stubble' to a putative PIE *u̯rā̆gʰ- ({ref IEW} 1180, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:968-969), but the necessity to reconstruct *a ~ *ā ablaut to account for the Greek forms is suspicious from an IE point of view ({ref Beekes 2010}:1277-1278). Perhaps the assumption of a prehistoric loanword is a better hypothesis.
Linked by Horn (1893: 160) to the Sanskrit verb śak- "to be able", cf. also śakti- "power" etc.

From Hellenistic Greek πιάζω, analogically remodelled into the -νω class inflection ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1189, Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further to Ancient Greek πιέζω, of uncertain etymology (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:899-900, {ref Beekes 2010}:1189 for various proposals).

notes: αμπουλουγκώνομαι < Ηell./MedGr κολυμβ(ώ) (perhaps with prefix ἐν-; νκ ~ μβ metathesis) -ώνω, cf. κουλουμπώννομαι ‘swim’ < AG κόλυμβος (-Liosis).

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Latin galbinus 'greenish-yellow' ({ref Orel 1998}:131, {ref Holm 2011}:64, cf. 'yellow' in /cognate/1409/).

A denominal adjective from Ancient Greek ῥόδος 'rose', in turn a loanword from the East, probably from Old Iranian *u̯r̥da- 'rose' (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:976-977, {ref Beekes 2010}:1289-1290).
loan_notes: Derived adjective to Ancient Greek ῥόδος 'rose', a loanword probably from Iranic.

notes: PIE *u̯éi ~ *u̯éi̯es (as if it was a plural of an i-stem, cf. tréi̯es); some forms go back to a different stem *(h₁)més. There is even a third stem *nó-. PIE is thus likely to be of the type of languages who exhibit a first person plural inclusive versus exclusive distinction, which then collapsed. This cognate class is full of flaws and should be revised, double-checked, or even excluded. The reconstruction of the PIE word for 'WE' is not finally solved and proposing a single cognate class, as it stands, can only lead to mistakes (Pooth).

justificationDiscussion: From earlier Greek ῥαπίς, with contamination from Lat. ramus ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:435, {ref Andriotis 1974}:477). Further etymology within Greek uncertain ({ref Beekes 2010}:1275).
Derived from Ancient Greek θεωρέω 'to view, look, behold' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), no certain etymology outside of Greek: for further etymological details cf. 'see' in /cognate/8257/.
From Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip, hip-joint'. No further etymology (cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:285, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:472, {ref Beekes 2010}:602-603).
Root ref. form follows {ref LIV²} 559.

notes: cf. Sanskrit nāśaka- (MBh) 'destroying, wasting'

justificationDiscussion: As though from *ἐξ-ίστημι > Tsakon. τσ̔ιτ̔αίνου, i.e. τσ̔ι- 'un' < ἐξ- + τ̔αίνου 'to get up' < ἵστημι 'stand' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). For further etymology, cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing derivatives of Sanskrit gola- 'ball, round object' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:232 no. 4321), cf. also variant guḍá- (1) m. 'globe, ball' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:223 no. 4181), presumably a Dravidian loanword (cf. {ref KEWA} I:349).
Nuristani lexemes derived from the same root as Vedic yávasa- 'grass' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:603 no. 10436), further derived from PIE *i̯éu̯-o- ({ref EWAia} II:404).

notes: Cf. Vedic (RV) píṇḍa- m. 'lump, clod, piece' *piṇḍara-, Turner 1962-66, no. 8171, 8168; Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 128; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing *piṇḍara- 'round like a lump' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:462 no. 8171), derived to Vedic pinḍa- 'lump, clod'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:128).

Cf. Avestan gaēsa- 'hair'. According to {ref Bailey 1979}:84 the Avestan and Khotanese forms may be related via a more basic root *gai̯- to a group of Iranic words also found in Proto-Iranic *gaip/b- 'to spin (thread)', but the proposed derivational morphology in such a connection is entirely unclear (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:96-97).
From Ancient Greek τραύσανον 'firewood' (Hesych.) (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further etymology disputed (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1129, {ref Beekes 2010}:1500).
Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √dru- 'to run, hurry', ultimately to PIE *dreu̯- 'to run' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:378-379 no. 6624, 6634, {ref EWAia} I:755-756, {ref LIV²} 129).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √yā- 'to go, advance, set out, travel', further to PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- ({ref EWAia} II:407-408, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:604, no. 10452, cf. {ref LIV²} 309-310.
Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √gam- < PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come', present stem gaccha- < *gʷm̥-sk̑e/o- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:211 no. 3955, {ref EWAia} I:465-466, cf. {ref LIV²} 209-210).

notes: perhaps from Vedic (ud- +) drāpáyati (ŚB), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 379, no. 6634

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing an Iranic root *Hrab/f-, further connections outside of Iranic uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:184-185).

notes: Pr. Ts μά(η) is probably a child-language instance (-Liosis).

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:601, {ref Beekes 2010}:805-806 for various proposals.

Nuristani lexemes continuing a derivative of the same root found in Vedic turá- 'quick' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:335 no. 5874), further to PIE *tu̯er- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:684-685, {ref LIV²} 655).
A borrowing from Standard Modern Greek (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; see note below).

notes: Ancient Greek σύρω.
original meaning "to shine, to bloom"
justificationDiscussion: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *spaič- 'to shine; to bloom'; further etymology outside of Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:437, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:350).

Often considered cognate with Lat. crūdus 'raw, bloody, rough' although aspects of the nominal stem formation remain unclear, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:250-251, {ref de Vaan 2008}:146; against a connection with Lat. crūdus, cf. {ref NIL} 448n30, with references.
Cf. Old Irish folach 'hiding'. For various etymological proposals, cf. {ref Bergin 1938}:220-222.

Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE 1. *k̑el- 'to hide' ({ref LIV²} 322-323, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:252-253, {ref Kroonen 2013}:218, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:53-54, {ref Matasović 2009}:199).

Etymology uncertain. For a conjectural proposal to the family of words surrounding Lithuanian ùpė 'river' < PIE *h₂ep- 'water', cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1169. [Not in {ref ALEW} or {ref Derksen 2015}.]
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic, cf. {ref ALEW} 522-523, {ref Derksen 2015}:219, 256-257 for further discussion.

Originally a feminine adjectival form of Vedic pr̥thú- 'wide, broad' <*pl̥th₂-ú- as an epithet of the earth, further to PIE *pleth₂- 'to become wide, broad; to spread out' ({ref EWAia} II:161-163, {ref NIL} 564, cf. {ref LIV²} 486-487).
Comparable to Avestan spəṇta- 'beneficent' and further to PIE *k̑u̯eh₁- 'to swell up' ({ref Bailey 1979}:394-395, {ref EWAia} II:678, 623-624; cf. {ref LIV²} 339-340).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. in Vollstufe I cf. 'belly' in /cognate/1454/, 'dig' in /cognate/865/.

notes: cf. Vedic (ŚB) abhyàkta- 'anointed', nasalization due to blend with abhyaṅga- 'anointed' (Mn.) (both from √añj-), palatal due to *bhiyajyate 'is smeared, get wet'; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 542; parallel derivations
justificationDiscussion: Derivatives of Vedic √añj- 'smear, anoint' + abhi- 'towards, on, upon' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:542 no. 9500-9503). Root further to PIE *h₂engʷ- 'to anoint, smear (smth. on smth.)' ({ref EWAia} I:52, {ref LIV²} 267).

notes: Bailey (1979: 19b)  connects this word to Saka ā̮ye 'ground, sole of foot' from āy- with Av. āi. He mentions a reconstruction by Morgenstierne (1942) proposed for NP xāk from *āhaka- 'ashes', which is followed by Klingenschmitt (2000: 213, fn.77).
justificationDiscussion: Identical to a word for 'ashes' with special development of the semantics

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 331, no. 5812 and p. 789, no. 13693; Sinhalese e in teta from temanavā < *temayati
justificationDiscussion: Continuing an Indic stem *tinta- with medial -e- vocalism taken over from temanavā < *temayati. Further connections difficult (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:331 no. 5812).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin reus 'defendant, accused' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}) and also related to Latin rēs 'property, goods; thing, matter, affair', further to PIE *(H)reh₁- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:521-522 for discussion of the Italic stem formation; for the root reconstruction cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:520-521, {ref LIV²} 499).
Loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian, Slovenian umoriti 'to murder, kill' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Etymology outside of (East) Baltic obscure, see {ref IEW} 986, {ref Karulis 1992} II:256 for various older proposals. Cf. also {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:859 s.v. Lith. spalvà 'colour'.
Derived from Hungarian gând 'thinking, thoughts', a loanword from Hungarian gond ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Lit. 'to go by foot'; Romanian merge 'to go' from Latin mergere 'to sink' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, further to PIE *mesg- 'to plunge, sink' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:375, {ref LIV²} 441).
Balkan loanword from Albanian or Thraco-Dacian (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, {ref Schulte 2009}:252).
loan_notes: A Balkan Wanderwort, cf. Albanian kopaç, Hungarian kopács.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Loan from French, cf. /cognate/2677/ and citation there.

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin eruncāre ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:258), further to PIE *h₃reu̯k- 'to dig, pluck (out)' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:530, {ref LIV²} 307).
Romanian merge 'to go' from Latin mergere 'to sink' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, further to PIE *mesg- 'to plunge, sink' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:375, {ref LIV²} 441).
Loanword from Greek φρίκη 'horror' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
East Romance lexemes for 'heart' from Latin animus 'soul, spirit, heart' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further from PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'breath' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:43, cf. {ref LIV²} 267-268).
Loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian loviti 'hunt', etc. ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/1145/).

From Latin minutalia 'small, insignificant (things)' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:459; {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), a derivative of Latin minus from PIE *mei̯H- 'to lessen, diminish' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:381-382, cf. {ref LIV²} 427).

Romanian împinge continues Latin im-pingere ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:358 no. 4309), the remaining Romance lexemes continue Latin ex-pingere ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:266 no. 3048). The non-prefixed verb, Latin pāngere 'to beat, strike' continues a nasal-present stem formation to PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:442-443, {ref LIV²} 461).

Probably to Latin mīca 'small grain, crumb' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:456, {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), further etymology difficult. The best recent proposal is of {ref Nyman 1987}, who argues for an original meaning 'grain of salt' and derives from the same root as Latin micō, -āre 'to quiver, dart, flash' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:378, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:402).
A loan from South Slavic mirosati, cf. Serbo-Croatian mirisati 'to smell' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:231, {ref Kroonen 2013}:339; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:371-372 for discussion of variant forms within Germanic).
Romanian neted is from Latin nitidus 'bright, shining' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), but further connections outside of Italic are obscure ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:442, {ref de Vaan 2008}:410).
No known etymology ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
From Latin boreās 'north wind; north' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:107, cf. {ref DCECH} I:614), an old loanword from Greek βορέας 'north wind; north' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:73-74).
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref DCECH} I:227-229 for discussion of various hypotheses).
Etymology uncertain.

Romance lexemes from Latin portāre 'carry' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:554), further probably a denominal verb to Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'a passage, crossing' and to PIE 1. *per- 'come through, cross' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:482-483, cf. {ref LIV²} 472-473).

Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Gk. καπνός 'smoke' ({ref ALEW} 545-546, {ref Derksen 2015}:268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison.
No known etymology ({ref ALEW} 663, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:406-407).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *i̯eu̯- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:607 no. 10507, {ref EWAia} II:402-403, {ref LIV²} 314, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:423).
Cf. Lith. gróbas 'intestine', Latv. grābs 'sausage'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 369 for further discussion.

The initial prefix ie- (cf. Lith. į-) is widely considered to continue a form of PIE *h₁en- 'inside' (cf. lexemes derived from the comparative degree *h₁en-ter- in /cognate/1588/), but the analysis of the rest of the compound remains disputed. Traditionally compared with either Lithuanian į́sčios 'womb, entrails, interior' or Lithuanian ìnkstas 'kidney' (cf. {ref Derksen 2015:202, 205; {ref ALEW} 398, 401; {ref Karulis 1992} I:334-335 for further discussion).

According to {ref Bailey 1979}:447, from Proto-Iranic *harta- or *hr̥ta- to an Iranic base *har- 'go up; pass'. Further root etymology uncertain: {ref Bailey 1979}:447 suggests either to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' ({ref IEW} 326-9, {ref LIV²} 238) or *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ({ref IEW 326-9, {ref LIV²} 299).

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indic *khucc-, possibly an extended form of the same root found in Vedic √skav- 'to tear, pluck'? ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:205-206, no. 3890; for Ved. √skav- cf. {ref EWAia} II:751). Further origins uncertain.
Derived from PIE *(s)teg- 'cover' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:39-40, {ref Matasović 2009}:376; cf. {ref LIV²} 589).

notes: probably old substrate loan from unidentified source

justificationDiscussion: Root ref. form in this class follows {ref LIV²} 353-355, {ref Schumacher 2004}:401-403, but cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:72, {ref Matasović 2009}:202-203 for older proposals.

From Old Irish caithid 'use, spend; hurl, throw'; the diverse semantics of the verb make the etymology difficult to explain. Probably further connected to Gaulish cateia, glossed in Servius's commentary to the Aeneid (7.741) as a 'tela gallica' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:24; cf. {ref Delamarre 2003}:110).

Traditionally considered a derivative of a putative PIE *(s)plei̯g̑ʰ- 'spread the legs' according to {ref IEW} 1000, but the proposed cognates justifying this root reconstruction are very uncertain (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:131-132, {ref KEWA} II:387, {ref Beekes 2010}:1211).

Cf. MIr. cethramthu 'quarter, fourth part' in the sense of 'quartered human body; thigh' ({ref Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language (eDIL)}), further to OIr. cethair 'four' from PIE *kʷetu̯or- 'four' (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:179).

A securely Brythonic family of words, cf. Welsh morddwyd 'thigh(-bone), haunch, ham', but outside connections remain difficult to ascertain (cf. {ref Schrijver 1995}:239-240, {ref Deshayes 2003}:522-523, {ref Pedersen 1909}:70, and {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} for further discussion).
No certain etymology ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B:76).
Loan from Latin baptisma.

Perhaps further from PIE *koi̯(H)lo- if connected with Latvian kaîls 'naked, bald', but the comparative semantics are rather remote (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:6, {ref Matasović 2009}:220).

Derived from Old Irish cas 'curly, woven, twisted'; formerly proposed to PIE *kes- 'to comb' (so {ref IEW} 585, but the -a- vocalism is difficult to account for ({ref Matasović 2009}:194; cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:44-45 for a survey of earlier hypotheses.

Scottish Gaelic gorm 'green', continuing Old Irish gorm 'blue, green'; within Celtic cf. also Middle Welsh gwrm 'brown', Old Breton uu(o)rm- 'brown'. Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain: Previous proposals have included (1) {ref Stokes 1894}:114, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:202 as a derivative of PIE *gʷʰer- in the sense 'the warm colour', (2) {ref IEW} 1152 considering a loanword from Anglo-Saxon wurma 'Purpurschnecke; woad; purple'. {ref Matasović 2009}:169 does not consider any IE etymology to be viable.
Loanword from Latin permedius ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Probably loans from Old Indic kiṭṭāla- 'copper vessel' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:161).

According to {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:15 to be connected with Latin umerus 'shoulder', Ancient Greek ὦμος 'id.', Goth. amsa 'id.', Skt. áṃsa- 'id.', although without clear antecedents in earlier Celtic. If so, then to PIE *h₃ems-o- (cf. 'back' in /cognate/7111/). [Not in {ref Matasović 2009}].

Continuing OId Irish pecthach, pecach 'sinner', a derivative of Old Irish peccad 'sin', itself ultimately a borrowing from Latin peccatum 'sin' (cf. {ref Broaderick 1984b}:348, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} P:5).
From Old Irish nech (indefinite pronoun) 'anyone, someone', originally a compound of PIE *ne 'not' + *kʷo- (relative pronoun) 'who' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:6).
Loan from Middle English person(e) or directly from Old French person ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Scots Gaelic can, from Old Irish canim 'sing' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:68, further to PIE *⁽k̑⁾an- 'sing' ({ref LIV²} 342-343, {ref Schumacher 2004}:387-390, {ref Matasović 2009}:187-188).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).
According to {ref Deshayes 2003}:97, a loanword from regional Latin *batto-, in turn borrowed from Gaulish batta (cf. Fr. batte).

Lit. 'to throw, cast out'. Cognacy is coded for the verbal head cuir 'throw' from Old Irish -cuirethar (cf. eDIL); synchronically suppletive to fo·ceird 'throw' within Irish but from the same Indo-European root ({ref LIV²} 353-355, cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:401-403), for older hypotheses cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:276-277.

Lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:732 no. 12620, {ref EWAia} II:655-656, {ref LIV²} 331).

Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Indic *uddrāti 'flees, flies' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:93 no. 2001), further connected to Vedic √drā- 'to run, make haste' and ultimately to PIE *dreh₂- 'to run (away)' ({ref EWAia} I:757, {ref LIV²} 127).

Celtic lexemes from PIE *preu̯s- following {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:137, {ref Matasović 2009}:140, but cf. doubts in {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:24-25, {ref EIEC} 287. Cf. 'freeze' in /cognate/226/.

Possibly to IE *teuto- if cognate with Lat. tūtus 'safe', Goth. ϸiuϸ 'good' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:164-165; cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:387 with some doubts). The proposed connections with the Italic and Germanic lexemes are judged difficult by {ref Lehmann 1986}:362-363 and not considered by {ref de Vaan 2008}:632-633. For possible semantic parallel for a euphemism, cf. Greek ἀριστερός in /cognate/1504/.

Nuristani lexemes, to be connected with Vedic kákṣa- 'undergrowth' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:128 no. 2589). No certain further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:288).

Manx lexemes representing a light-verb construction 'to make a song' where for the purposes of cognacy Manx arrane 'song' is encoded as the semantic bearing head (cf. {ref Broaderick 1984b}:12). From Old Irish amrán 'song; a kind of poem', a diminutive of amar 'sorrow, suffering'. Further to Welsh afar 'sadness, lamentation' but of uncertain etymology outside of Celtic ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:65).
A borrowing from English savour ({ref Broaderick 1984b}:422-423).
Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit kakkhaṭa- 'hard, solid' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:128, no. 2587). No further etymology.
Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic amā́ 'at home, in the house' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:25 no. 560). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} I:95.

loan_notes: = “markhor drive”; T. 5748 tāḍa- ‘clap’; clapping used to drive animals over cliffs?

justificationDiscussion: Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Old Indic *nigāti (ni- 'down' + √gā- 'to take a step'), cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:410 no. 7165. Root etymology further to PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ({ref EWAia} I:482, {ref LIV²} 205).
Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic ánna- 'food' reflecting PIE *h₁éd-no-, cf. PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:18 no. 395, {ref EWAia} I:79-80).

notes: āryikā-, āryaka-, from Vedic ā́rya- 'gentleman, nobleman'

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'carry' in /cognate/7547/, 'drink' in /cognate/1955/, 'fall' in /cognate/3661/, 'fly_pst3sg' in /cognate/1993/, 'house' in /cognate/5142/, 'swim' in /cognate/7464/.

justificationDiscussion: Cf. Turner 1962–1966:262, no. 4822 *cimb- 'pinch' > Hindi cimṭā, cyū̃ṭā m. 'pincers'???
The sequence -lu- points to Polish origin.

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though continuing a derivatives of Vedic mr̥ṣā 'in vain, wrongly' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:594 no. 10298, {ref Strand 1998}, further derived from Vedic √marṣ- 'to forget' and further to PIE *mers- 'to forget' ({ref KEWA} II:678-679, {ref EWAia} II:332, cf. {ref LIV²} 440-441).
No certain etymology (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.), {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:414-415 proposes connections to PIE *(H)rebʰ-ró- (cf. Old Church Slavonic reboro 'rib, side', Old High German rippi, ribbi 'rib').
Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit √ḍhauk- 'approach, bring near'; of uncertain etymology, probably a loanword ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:318 no. 5610, {ref KEWA} I:465).

According to {ref Bailey 1979}:469, to be connected with Baltic adjectives meaning 'red, ruddy' from a basic root *ser- ({ref IEW} 910-911). The extra-Baltic connections to the proposed comparanda in Lithuanian sar̃tas 'red-brown, chestnut (of a horse)', etc.  have been recently doubted by {ref ALEW} 891, but cf. {ref Smoczyński 2007}:534.
No certain etymology outside of Indic ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:132, no. 2641; {ref EWAia} I:290).
Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} II:336, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:76-77.
Ossetic lexemes, probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:336).
Lexemes belonging to the complex field of **paṭ- 'membrane, covering, leaf', which seems to blend several original roots.
Of uncertain origin, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:747 no. 8975, {ref DCECH} 5:539-543 for further discussion.
Romance lexemes from Latin colubra 'snake' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:195), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:133-134, {ref de Vaan 2008}:126 for various proposals).

Indo-Iranic lexemes generally connected to Proto-Germanic *agla- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:46, {ref Lehmann 1986}:10, {ref Kroonen 2013}:4-5). For the root etymology to PIE *h₂egʰ- 'become afraid, sad', cf. {ref LIV²} 257.
Romance lexemes derived from Latin plānus 'level, flat' and further derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'id.' (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 9:27, {ref de Vaan 2008}:470, {ref NIL} 562-564).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/4527/, 'mountain' in /cognate/2804/, 'hand' in /cognate/1712/, 'thin' in /cognate/1923/, 'wide' in /cognate/5264/, 'earth' in /cognate/5892/, 'stand' in /cognate/8055/, 'tree' in /cognate/8103/.

justificationDiscussion: Mycenaean pa-si (= Attic φησί), derived from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to speak, say' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1566-1567, {ref LIV²} 69-70, cf. {ref Aura Jorro 1993}:88).

notes: From Lat. de 'from' parte (abl. of pars, partis 'part').
justificationDiscussion: An adverb based on the Latin phrase dē parte ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), from Latin pars, partis 'part' a late inner-Latin derivative to the same root as Latin pariō 'to give birth to, bear' derived from PIE *perh₃- 'to provide' (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:485, {ref de Vaan 2008}:445-446, 448, {ref LIV²} 474-475).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:219 no. 4104, {ref KEWA} I:332, {ref EWAia} I:480).

From Latin saltus 'jump, leap; narrow passage, woodland' ({ref DCECH} V:321), further to PIE *sel- 'jump' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:590, {ref de Vaan 2008}:535-536; for the root reconstruction cf. {ref LIV²} 527-528).
Romance lexemes with nominal *ped- (from Lat. pēs, pedis) as semantic-bearing morpheme in a light verb construction. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'foot' in /cognate/225/.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'foot' in /cognate/225/, 'leg' in /cognate/2783/, 'fall' in /cognate/1126/, 'lie' in /cognate/8225/, 'sleep' in /cognate/9252/.

justificationDiscussion: From Latin repōnere 'to put back, down; replace' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 10:269-270), further probably derived from PIE *tk̑ei̯- 'settle, inhabit' (cf. {ref LIV²} 643-644, {ref de Vaan 2008}:479 for discussion of the stem formation in Italic).
As though from Latin *mūkyāre, a denominal verb from a stem *mūc- (cf. Old Irish múchaim 'I hide'), cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002}:6/3:197, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:471).
loan_notes: A denominal verb based on a noun of Celtic origin, cf. von Wartburg, FEW 6/3:197 for further discussion.

justificationDiscussion: From Latin gracilis 'slender, slight' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4::201-203, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:326), no certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:279, {ref de Vaan 2008}:268).
Old French fesse, from Latin fissus 'split' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 3:581-582), the past passive participle of Latin findere 'to split' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:221).
A loan from Germanic *handjan- (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 16:139).
Borrowing from Old Low Franconian sûr 'sour' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:288-289, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:698).
Etymology unknown, cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 21:57 for further discussion.

notes: Originally based on a compound of må (< Lat. malum) + sir 'pur' (Walloon Wiktionary).

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Germanic *sunni-, cf. Old French songne 'worry, concern' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:272-282, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:667 no. 8089a).
Probably to a Romance root *bot- of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} I:420-423).

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966
< varṇáyati (denominal) 'relates, describes' (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 661, no. 11342; from varṇá- m. 'sound, syllable' (AitBr.)
justificationDiscussion: As though from Sanskrit varṇayati 'relates, describes', a denominal formation to Sanskrit varṇa- 'sound, syllable' and probably a specialised semantic development of Sanskrit várṇa- 'type, kind, colour', a derivative of Vedic √var-² 'to cover, conceal, hide, surround'. Further root etymology difficult; the Vedic root appears to continue a conflation of several different IE sources that have become homophonous (cf. {ref EWAia} II:512-513, {ref LIV²} 227-228 s.v. *Hu̯er-, 674 s.v. *u̯el- and 684 s.v. 1. u̯er-).

Romance lexemes as though from Latin *nōdicāre 'to knot' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 7:169, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:489), a verbal derivative from Latin nōdus 'knot'. Further root etymology uncertain, possibly to Germanic lexemes meaning 'net', cf. Gothic nati, Old Icelandic nót 'net' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:412, {ref Kroonen 2013}:384, {ref Lehmann 1986}:263-264 for further discussion).

notes: Nu. forms from OIA. vi-str̥-ta- ‘spread; wide’  T. 12011 (-Strand).
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes from *vi-str̥ta- 'spread, expanded, wide', Sanskrit vistr̥ta- 'id.' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:694-695 no. 12011), a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew', and ultimately further to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:756-757, {ref LIV²} 599-600).

notes: < Vedic mantráyate (denominal) 'speaks (*recites mantras)' (RV), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 565, no. 9837
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic mantráyate 'speaks', a denominal formation to Vedic mántra- 'speech, sacred text or speech, a prayer', a nominal derivative from PIE 1. *men- 'to think' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:565 no. 9837, {ref EWAia} II:311, 305-306, cf. {ref LIV²} 435-436).

Cf. Latv. glabât 'keep, guard, protect; bury, hide', from PIE *gleh₁bʰ- 'to encompass, cover' according to {ref ALEW} 343, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:187 assumes *glebʰ-. Cf. also discussion of {ref Derksen 2015}:180-181. (Not in {ref LIV²}).

notes: For the IE reconstruction, see ALEW.
justificationDiscussion: The root assignment for this set follows {ref ALEW} 674-675 in connection to Vedic muṣṭi- 'fist', Young Avestan mušti.masah- 'fist-sized', and Tocharian B maśce 'fist', cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:326-327 dismissing earlier proposals to Ancient Greek ἀμύσσω 'scratch, tear, lacerate', ἀμυχή 'rent, wound', and Latin mūcrō f. 'point (of a sword etc.)' from a putative root *h₂meu̯k̑-, also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:413.
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' (cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:192, {ref ALEW} 495-496, {ref LIV²} 559-560).
Loanword from Germanic *harpa 'curved instrument' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:341, {ref DCECH} I:344-345 for further discussion).

Romance lexemes derived from Latin fascis 'bundle of rods; (symbol of) power' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:279), further to be connected with Celtic lexemes, cf. Old Irish basc 'necklace', Welsh beich 'burden', Breton bec'h 'load' < PCl. *baskio-, as a unique Italo-Celtic isogloss from *bʰaski-, probably a non-Indo-European loanword in origin (cf. {ref Schrijver 1991}:102-103, {ref de Vaan 2008}:203).
Loanword from Finnic (cf. {ref Karulis 1992}:561).

Probably distantly related way to *kseu̯-, perhaps originally abstracted from a nasal-present stem, but if so this neo-root would be apparently already an IE development to judge from the existence of a Latin cognate novācula 'knife' (cf. {ref LIV²} 373, {ref EWAia} I:441).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:188-189 s.v. Latvian sit 'to hit' for further discussion.

Hellenic and Indic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *kseu̯- 'to shave, scratch' ({ref LIV²} 372). Modern Hellenic lexemes are derivatives of Ancient Greek ξύω 'to shave, smooth, scratch' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:956, {ref Beekes 2010}:1039-1040), while Middle and Modern Indic forms are from Sanskrit kṣuráti, churati 'cuts, scratches, digs', Pali khurati 'scrapes' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:194 no. 3729, cf. {ref EWAia} I:435-436). Perhaps an extension of the root *kes- in /cognate/6265/.
A probable nursery word, but cf. {ref Tischler 1991}:393-394 for various alternative proposals.

Cf. Old Lithuanian klùpti 'to fall on the knees, stumble', traditionally connected to an IE root *kleu̯b- 'to stumble, hop' ({ref LIV²} 364, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:293, 301-302), but cf. {ref ALEW} 510-511 objecting to the comparative semantics. [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}]. Cf. also 'run' in /cognate/6948/ and 'walk' in /cognate/332/ for the proposed Germanic comparanda in Gothic us-hlaupan, etc.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: ideophonic like many verbs for 'vomit' (compare Colloquial German kotzen, etc.); thus perhaps related to pejorative ka-, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2574b (NB. Urdu [ʔulʈɪ kəɾnə] belongs to /cognate/1625/)

justificationDiscussion: The root of the Hittite formation is generally compared with Ved. párvata- 'mountain' < *pér-u̯n̥-to- (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:668-669, {ref HED PE, PI, PU}:23-26; cf. {ref EWAia} II:99).
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:757-758).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kep- 'to chop, hit' (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}:594, {ref LIV²} 555).

No certain etymology. Traditionally compared to Lithuanian garbinỹs, garbìnis 'lock of hair', but the semantic distance makes this etymology doubtful ({ref ALEW} 295-296, cf. {ref IEW} 387 reconstructing *gerb-, but note that this reconstruction violates the known restriction on IE roots beginning and ending with voiced-unaspirated stops).

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 92-93, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:46 for further discussion. Older etymological works assumed a connection to PIE *h₃nebʰ- in /cognate/5026/, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:33.

notes: Loan from Russian

justificationDiscussion: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *rand- 'to scrape, smoothen' (+ *fra-), further to PIE *lendʰ- 'to lower, go down' ({ref Cheung 2007}:312-313, cf. {ref LIV²} 412-413).

West Germanic lexemes in light verb constructions with derivatives of PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'to restrict, hinder' as the nominal semantic-bearing head. ({ref Kluge 2011}:45, {ref Kroonen 2013}:28-29). The Dutch and Frisian lexemes are prefixed with initial *be- ({ref EWNl} I:216). For the PIE root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 264-265.
Parthian and Middle Persian lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ham-dais- (PIr. *dais- 'to show'), further to PIE *dei̯k̑- 'to show, indicate' ({ref Cheung 2007}:51-52, cf. {ref LIV²} 108-109).

There are two widespread hypotheses as to the etymology of this root. It has been assumed that it is a loan from Germanic *óƀāt-. However, it seems that the exact source of this (Proto-Slavic) loanword has not been identified. There are also phonetic issues (*-o-, -ť-) which should be explained if the loanword hypothesis is accepted. Another possibility is to assume a derivation from PIE root *h₂u̯eg- 'grow, rise, become large' > PS *(o-)voktĭ > *(o-)voť-. Then the word would be related to German wachsen 'grow' etc., cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}: 566.
According to {ref EWNl}, an early loanword from Latin plūma 'feather'.

notes: ? cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4883
*dʰelgʰ- according to a previous root ref. input. Merge with /cognate/218/???

justificationDiscussion: Ossetic lexemes of disputed further etymology, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:552, {ref Cheung 2007}:158, {ref LIV²} 223 for proposals and further discussion.
Etymology obscure (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:200 for discussion)
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *hulta- < PIE *kold-o- (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:423, {ref Kroonen 2013}:254; cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:708-709).

Apparently continuing a verbal root √mac- attested in various meanings by Sanskrit lexicographical works which may have further IE connections but ultimately uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:555 no. 9710, {ref KEWA} II:548).
The etymology is obscure. Even the Baltic cognacy is uncertain.
Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives from PIE 1. *per- 'to cross, go through' ({ref LIV²} 472-473, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:186-188, {ref Kroonen 2013}:128).
Identical with 'tail' words in North and West Germanic. Possible comparisons outside of Germanic, but ultimately uncertain. Cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:338, {ref Kroonen 2013}:504 for further discussion.
A derivative of Hittite iškii̯e/a- 'to daub, salve'. Further etymology unclear, cf. {ref Tischler 1983}:404, {ref HED A+E/I}:426-428 for various proposals.
Etymology outside of Germanic difficult (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:135, {ref Lehmann 1986}:115).
Derived from Ossetic ad | adæ 'taste', possibly further to PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' but this proposal is quite speculative (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:28).

Nuristani lexemes loaned from Indo-Iranic *stʰala- 'dry land, ground place; flat surface, roof'. Traditionally connected to the Sanskrit (Dhātupāṭha) root √sthal- 'to stand (firm)', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Strand 1998}, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:793 no. 13744, {ref KEWA} III:525).

notes: < 'fine, minute, thin, small' according to Turner 1962-66, no. 13548 s.v. *sūṅkṣa-

justificationDiscussion: As though from Vedic √bhal- 'to expound, describe', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:535 no. 9406, cf. {ref KEWA} II:482-483).

Nuristani lexemes as though from Old Indic *caṅkr̥tati 'cuts again and again' ({ref Strand 1998}, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:247 no. 4562), further derived from Vedic √kart- 'to cut', and ultimately PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ({ref LIV²} 559-560, {ref EWAia} I:315-316).

notes: cf. ākhu-kirí- (MS), Turner 1962-66, no. 3175; thus < PIE *kerH- (3.) "austreuen, schütten" (LIV, p. 353)
justificationDiscussion: Cf. Dameli kīr 'snow' < Sanskrit kiri- 'scattering, heap' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:162 no. 3175). Further to Vedic √karⁱ-² 'to scatter, disperse' and ultimately to PIE 3. *kerH- 'to scatter, disperse' ({ref EWAia} I:311, {ref LIV²} 353-354).

Etymology uncertain. {ref Bailey 1979}:395 proposed *k̑i-es-d- derived to PIE *k̑ei̯h₂- 'to move' (cf. {ref LIV²} 346, {ref IEW} 538-539), but the function of the nominal morphemes ('increments') proposed in order to satisfy the etymology formally remains unclear.

notes: cf. Old Indic namrá- "untertan, ergeben, demütig, unterwürfig", lit. "biegsam". This cognate set may rather mean 'soft'.

justificationDiscussion: Probably a Caucasian loanword, although the exact source language is difficult to ascertain (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:320).
Root etymology in this class follows {ref LIV²} 79-80, cf. also {ref Seebold 1970}:106-107, {ref Kroonen 2013}:60 for further discussion.
Lexemes as though from Indic *muṭṭa- 'defective' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:587 no.10187.1).

Perhaps a primary verbal adjective in *-to- to the IE root *(s)leup- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 964f.) only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic, cf. {ref Faltings 2010}:372-374. Etymology otherwise obscure.

A regional word with no etymology. A mechanical root preform might be *čal-, assuming Wakhi has undergone metathesis, but the sound -q- has been taken as a loan indicator, so the Wakhi form could be loaned from Khowar tseq, excluding the Sarikoli and Shughni forms.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'to run', a nasal-infix present stem formed to PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl' ({ref Seebold 1970}:375-377, {ref Kroonen 2013}:413-414, {ref LIV²} 305-306).

Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Generally compared with Baltic material via Lith. klaũpti 'kneel down', etc. (cf. {ref LIV²} 364, {ref Kroonen 2013}:229, 232), but the connection is uncertain on semantic grounds (cf. {ref ALEW} 502-503}).  For older hypotheses, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:259-260, {ref Lehmann 1986}:382-383.
Lexemes continuing Old Norse springa from Proto-Germanic *spring/kan- 'to break out, leap', ultimately from PIE *(s)préngʰ-e- ({ref LIV²} 583, {ref Kroonen 2013}:470, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:457-458).
Loan from Arabic جلد 'leather, skin'

Root reconstruction difficult. A contamination between two (possibly related) roots *teu̯h₂- and *teu̯k- is a possibility. Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:540 and 'thick' in /cognate/1247/ for further discussion. The PIE root reference form *teu̯(h₂)k- is provisional only.

This set is coded for PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'swell', whence Proto-Germanic *balgi- 'skin bag' > 'belly, stomach' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:49), Proto-Celtic *bolgo- 'sack, bag, stomach' ({ref Matasović 2009}:70, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}. NB: Welsh: North botwm bol 'button-belly' is a calque from English belly-button.

Nuristani lexemes in this set represent a light-verb construction 'to make a song', where cognacy in this set is assigned to the semantic bearing head 'song', as though from Old Indic *lalla- ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:636 no. 10972), probably further of onomatopoeic origin.

notes: variant of kūdak < *kau̯tá-?

justificationDiscussion: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *kamb- 'lesser', further to PIE *kemb- assuming a connection with Hittite kappi- / kappai- 'small' (cf. {ref Schmitt 2014}:198-199, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:439).

notes: ṭálati *’moves aside’; doubtful < *til- ‘go’ because of ṭ, cf. {ref: Turner 1962–1966}: 302
Sanskritism, cf. tīkṣṇa-, Vedic tīkṣṇá-
justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Sanskrit tīkṣṇa- 'sharp'.
Lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *ričaka-, cf. Vedic √rekh- 'to scratch', further to PIE *(h₁)rei̯k⁽ʷ⁾h₂- 'to scratch, score' ({ref Bailey 1979}:363, {ref EWAia} II:457, cf. {ref LIV²} 504).
Etymology uncertain, perhaps from Iranic *āyavana-, cf. Avestan ayaona- 'dwelling' with the meaning 'shadow' arising via *'shelter' (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:87).
Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Continuing Middle English smellen, smüllen, further etymology uncertain ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *čai̯H- 'to sew', without certain etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:29).

Derivatives of Ossetic myg | mugæ 'sperm', according to {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:137-138 to be further connected to Latin mūcus 'snot, mucus', Ancient Greek μύξα 'mucus, discharge from nose' to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, remove (smth.)' (cf. {ref LIV²} 443-444) as a Scythian-European isogloss.

Originally a participle to the weak verb 'to stretch' (OE streccan), possibly to be further derived from *strak(k)a- 'tight, taut' ({ref Orel 2003}:380), but cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:559-560, who considers that the adjective may have been back-formed from the verb. Further etymology uncertain.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic vī́kṣate 'looks at, sees' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:696 no. 12041), further to Vedic √īkṣ- 'to perceive, view, see' continuing a reduplicated desiderative stem *h₃i-h₃kʷ-s- to PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' ({ref EWAia} I:203, {ref LIV²} 297-298).
Etymology uncertain. First connected by {ref Bailey 1979}:383 to Vedic aváni- 'stream', but this proposal has been judged to be unclear by {ref EWAia} I:131.

notes: Nursery word.

justificationDiscussion: Nuristani lexemes as though from Old Indic *ākṣundati 'tramples' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:46 no. 1030, {ref Strand 1998}), derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic √kšud- 'to disperse, scatter', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:439).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:330-335).
Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:104-105, {ref Kroonen 2013}:136 for various proposals.
Origin uncertain, perhaps a loanword from South Caucasian (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:631).
Forms from Proto-Germanic *ūtian-, secondarily derived to Proto-Germanic *ūd- 'out' ({ref de Vries 1977}:680), further to PIE *úd- 'upwards, up; out' (cf. {ref LIPP 2} 824).

An intensive formation to Proto-Germanic *ϸrug-. The root occasionally compared to Lith. trū́kti 'break, tear in two' (cf. {ref EWA 2} 813-815, but this connection is not fully certain (cf. {ref ALEW} 1118-1119).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:336 s.v. Goth. *swinϸs. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:577-578 s.v. PGmc. *swenϸa- favours a comparison with IE *seg̑ʰ- 'overpower, seize' (LIV² 515-516), cf. ad loc. for references to further literature. For older comparisons to Lith. siunčiu 'send', cf. {ref IEW} 1048, reconstructing *su̯ento-, *sunto- (but qualifying the entry "nur Germ.?").
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived to Vedic √grabh- 'to take, seize' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:227 no. 4236), further to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize, grasp' ({ref EWAia} I:505-506, {ref LIV²} 201).
Loanword from Indic? (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:149 no. 2922).
Child language formation {ref Carruba 1970}: 66.
IE etymology uncertain, possibly a loanword? ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:540-541).

As though continuing ā-lagna- 'fastened to', a derivative of Proto-Indo-Iranic *√lag- 'to stick, attach', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:61 no. 1356.2, {ref Strand 1998}, {ref EWAia} II:473).
Root etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:313, {ref Orel 2003}:347, {ref Kroonen 2013}:452 for further discussion.
No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:231, {ref Kroonen 2013}:339; cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:371-372 for discussion of variant forms within Germanic).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:793, {ref Kroonen 2013}:443 for various proposals).

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:446, {ref Orel 2003}:334, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:485, {ref Kluge 2011}:800). For the root, cf. {ref LIV²} 555). The semantics of Luxembourgish Schank appear to have shifted from the sense 'leg, thigh, shinbone' found elsewhere in Germanic.
West Germanic lexemes probably originally based on an onomatopoeic formation ({ref Kluge 2011}:414, {ref EWNl} II:475).
West Germanic formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:540 s.v. Standard High German kreischen.
Adjective derived from Proto-Germanic *hurhwa- 'dirt, mucus'. Further connections unclear, perhaps to Middle Irish corcach 'moor'? (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:258).

Cf. Standard German Boden, continuing PIE *bʰudʰ-men-; the root appears to only be attested in the zero-grade. It is unclear whether the full-grade form would be *bʰeu̯dʰ- or *bʰu̯edʰ- ({ref EWA 2}:222-225, {ref Kluge 2011}:137, {ref Kroonen 2013}:82, cf. {ref EWAia} II:228-229).

Perhaps an extension to an original onomatopoeic base *mu- and connected to the more widely attested PIE *mus- in /cognate/5031/, but this proposed connection remains speculative. Cf. {ref Orel 2003}:278, {ref Kluge 2011}:637, {ref Kroonen 2013}:379-380.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; may be a formal match to Ancient Greek ῥίπτω 'throw' but the semantic match is quite difficult (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:565, {ref Kluge 2011}:755, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:975, {ref Beekes 2010}:1287-1288 for further discussion).
Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 557-558, {ref Kroonen 2013}:440-441. Possibly an extended form of the root *(s)ker- 'to cut', cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:487.
According to {ref EWNl}, to be connected with PIE *(s)teup-/*(s)teub- 'to hit, beat' (cf. {ref LIV²} 602-603 s.v. *(s)teu̯p-, without Germanic lexical material listed).

Cf. Standard German hauen, from Proto-Germanic *hawwan- 'to hew, chop' and further derived from PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to beat, to split' ({ref LIV²} 345-346, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:251-252, {ref Kluge 2011}:399, {ref Kroonen 2013}:218).

Simplified from the phrase 'ums Leben bringen', cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:940. Further IE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally analysed as a conflation of the roots *bʰer- 'to carry' and *h₁nek̑- 'take, receive' (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:136-137, {ref Kroonen 2013}:77).
Loanword from Sanskrit tvác- 'skin, bark'.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5005: "H. chāl f. ʻbark, skin, peelʼ, chālī f. ʻsmall blisterʼ, chālā m. ʻskin, hideʼ (→ P. N. chālā m.)"
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit or Prakrit challī- 'bark' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:274, no. 5005). Of non-IE origin, possibly Dravidian or Munda (cf. {ref KEWA} I:405-406).

notes: re-sanskritized forms of the respective inherited forms, cf. /cognate/6949/ - note that this phenomenon is different from a simple loan event
ākāśá 1008 ākāśá m. ʻ sky ʼ ŚBr. [√kāś]

The Palula aspirate is unclear and does not appear in older sources (drakaṛ Turner ad rem). dr > l is regular in Gawri and Gawarbati. The -i- in Gawarbati might be due to the influence of līgāla- < dīrgha- 'long', as already suggested by Buddruss (apud Turner) for the Woṭapuri cognate.
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes as if from *drakk-, only reflected in 'Dardic'.

notes: possibly base of *kʷels-, but not well attested outside Iranian

justificationDiscussion: According to {ref Bailey 1979}:466, probably from the same root as Khotanese ajs- 'to cling to, pursue' (with the semantic development in the sense of 'cling to the scent of' vel sim.). Further probably to PIE 1. *seg- 'to adhere, cling to' ({ref Cheung 2007}:128-129, {ref EWAia} II:688-689, {ref LIV²} 516).

notes: from PIE *h₂ek̑  'sharp, pointed; stone, rock'; cognate with 'stone' /cognate/1179/ - NB. sky (and daylight) was mythically seen as coming out of the rock (cf. the Vedic Vala-myth) and thus as originating from/being made from rock/stone.
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'stone' (gen.sg. *h₂k-n-és-), an *mn̥-stem nominal derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ({ref EWAia} I:137-138).
The dubious semantics of the Hittite lexeme make etymological identification difficult (cf. {ref CHD L-N}:253). For various uncertain proposals, cf. {ref Tischler 1991}:210-211, {ref HED M}:124-125.
As though from Sanskrit *ghum(m)ati, further root etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:243 no. 4485).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian.
To be connected with Hittite Hitt. šani- 'the same, one and the same', but further etymology outside of Anatolian unclear (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:722-723).

Related to Luvian īš(ša)ra/i- 'hand' via an unattested derivative *išaru-/išaru̯a- 'right-hand' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:471-472, cf. {ref NIL} 170-173). For further etymological details cf. 'hand' in /cognate/411/.
Denominal verb, cf. Cuneiform Luvian āaš- 'mouth' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:166-167, cf. {ref NIL} 387-390). For further etymological discussion cf. 'mouth' in /cognate/796/.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 476

justificationDiscussion: Generally assumed to be a nursery word (cf. {ref Tischler 1991}:345-346).
To be derived from Vedic √kar- 'to make, do' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:147, no. 2900, {ref KEWA} I:176, {ref EWAia} I:307-309).

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, see {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:683 for a critical discussion of earlier proposals. {ref HED PE, PI, PU}:146 considers a connection to Lithuanian pùsti 'swell', but cf. {ref ALEW} 831-833 s.v. pùsti 'anschwellen' and pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen' against any clear correspondences outside of Baltic for the proposed comparandum.
Cf. Lith. võras 'old', further etymology uncertain ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:767, cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:1274).
An early 20th century neologism '(human) being' derived to the same stem as esù 'I am' < PIE *h₁es- 'to be' ({ref Smoczyński 2007}:25, cf. {ref LIV²} 241-242).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Tischler 1983}:58, {ref HED A+E/I}:139-140).
No certain etymology ({ref ALEW} 1285).
Semantic identification not fully certain, therefore etymology also uncertain (cf. {ref Melchert 1993a}:173).

Indic lexemes from Vedic bā́hya- ʻexternal, being outside' (AV), via 'foreign, strange' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:521, no. 9235. Further to PIE *bʰeg̑ʰ- according to {ref EWAia} II:220 on the basis of proposed Balto-Slavic comparanda (Lith. bè, Latv. bez, OCS bez 'without', cf. {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:38a), but more recently cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:38, {ref ALEW} 101-102 without connection to the Indic lexemes.
Semantic identification not entirely clear ({ref Melchert 1993a}:9), therefore etymology also uncertain.
Of uncertain origin, possibly a Dravidian loanword? Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}161, no. 3153.
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *ten- 'to stretch, span' ({ref ALEW} 1111, {ref Derksen 2015}:467-468, cf. {ref LIV²} 626-627).
A loanword from Hurrian ({ref Starke 1990}:220, {ref Melchert 1993a}:285, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:936).
Baltic lexemes continuing a PIE u-stem *lig-u-, further to a PIE root *lei̯g- 'equal, similar, alike' (cf. {ref ALEW} 584-586, {ref Derksen 2015}:286).

Indic lexemes continuing Vedic ramyà- 'to be enjoyed, beautiful' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:616 no. 10636), further derived from PIE *h₁rem- 'to be calm' ({ref EWAia} II:435-436, cf. {ref LIV²} 252-253).
Root reference form for this class tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 562, but cf. {ref ALEW} 933-935 for further discussion.

notes: Etymology uncertain, perhaps from PIE *k̑elH- 'cold'.
justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Lithuanian (cf. {ref ALEW} 1022).

The lexeme is doubtless a loanword whose the ultimate source is Latin frūctus. However, the direct source is disputable. Some scholars assume Polish {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 208, {ref Šanskij et al. 1975}: 474, some German or Dutch {Černyh 1999}: 2: 325, some mention the ultimate source only {ref Šapošnikov 2010} 2: 485, {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 6: 134.
Possibly to be derived from PIE *dens- 'to become informed; skilled' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:853-855, cf. {ref LIV²} 118-119).
Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:127-128 for various proposals.

{ref Adams 2013}:219 suggests a possible connection to Proto-Germanic *klāwo- 'claw' but this remains uncertain. For the proposed Germanic cognates, cf. discussion in {ref Kluge 2011}:496-497, {ref Kroonen 2013}:292.

notes: Wider connections uncertain

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-), a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ({ref NIL} 639, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:795 no. 13776, {ref EWAia} II:768-769, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:266, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:158-159, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:557-558, {ref Kroonen 2013}:482).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: Derived from PIE *u̯elh₂- 'hit, strike' ({ref Malzahn 2010}:872-873}, {ref Adams 2013}:639; for the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

Cf. Sanskrit gāḍha- 'dived into; pressed together, thick, firm' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:220 no. 4118), derived from Vedic √gāh- 'to dive into, bathe in, plunge into; penetrate, enter deeply into' and ultimately to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- 'to go into water, wade into' ({ref EWAia} I:486, {ref LIV²} 183).

Generally further connected to Greek ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness' and Armenian *ałǰ- in ałǰutʻiwnkʻ 'darkness' ({ref Derksen 2015}:555, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:184, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:37-39 for further discussion).

Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₃ems- 'shoulder, upper part of the arm' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:461, II:227-228, cf. {ref EWAia} I:37). Cf. Proto-Germanic *amsa- 'shoulder' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:30, {ref Kroonen 2013}:25), Ancient Greek ὦμος 'shoulder' ({ref Beekes 2010}:1679-1680).

Tocharian lexemes, generally compared with  Vedic vā́stu- 'residence, abode' and Ancient Greek ἄστυ 'town', which may continue a proto-form *u̯ā̆stu- (< *u̯éh₂stu- ~ *uh₂stéu̯-?). Further root etymology unclear. A connection with PIE *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' (cf. {ref IEW} 1170-1171, {ref LIV²} 293-294) is semantically attractive but uncertain (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:134, {ref EWAia} II:549, {ref Beekes 2010}:158-159 for discussion and references to further literature).

notes: orig. 'right, true'
justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. {ref ALEW} 1106-1108, {ref Derksen 2015}:465 for further discussion and various proposals.
According to {ref Adams 2013}:706-707, a fossilised feminine accusative singular of the gerund śwālle ‘suitable for eating’ fromśu- 'eat' from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂-.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:662-664, {ref Adams 2013}:317 for various proposals.
Tocharian lexemes continuing PIE *kʷolh₁-o- 'turning point' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:126, {ref Adams 2013}:211), a derivative of PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn' ({ref LIV²} 386-388).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'round' in /cognate/4906/, 'live' in /cognate/3185/, 'yesterday' in /cognate/6487/, 'walk' in /cognate/1626/, 'turn' in /cognate/5879/.

justificationDiscussion: Likely to be connected to Old Lithuanian žieždrà 'Sand', but there are difficulties in reconciling the forms to a single Proto-Baltic reconstruction; no certain connections outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 1307-1308 for further discussion).
Precise semantics uncertain, therefore etymological comparisons remain speculative (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:87, {ref Adams 2013}:151).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:97-98 for a survey of various proposals.

To be derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound' ({ref LIV²} 187); possibly originally an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ({ref ALEW} 331-332). Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 210-211.
Of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:288-289).

{ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:591 supposes a connection to Sanskrit káuti 'cries'. The Indo-Iranic forms are traditionally connected to a wide range of sound-imitative words from a root *kā̆u-, *kē̆u-, *kū- according to {ref IEW} 535-536, but a parallel onomatopoeic origin may well be possible (cf. {ref KEWA} I:274). [Not in {ref Cheung 2007}.]
Etymology unclear, cf. {ref Karulis 1992} I:266-268 for further discussion.
Light verb constructions with parallel loans from Persian نخجیر / naxčīr 'hunt, prey' as the semantic head.
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *gʰrem- 'to roar, rage' ({ref Smoczyński 2005}:164-165, cf. {ref LIV²} 204). For non-target Khwarazmian maγmeda in this set, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:122.
No known extra-Tocharian connections ({ref Adams 2013}:64).

Etymology dubious. {ref Adams 2013}:517 connects to a putative PIE *mel- 'member' comparing Gk. μέλος 'member', Breton mell 'knuckle' < *melso-, Lith. mélmenys 'fat around the kidneys', Skt. márman- 'member, vulnerable part of the body', but the etymologies of these compared lexemes are all for the most part considered to be unknown or dubious (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:927-928, {ref EWAia} II:329, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:386).

Continuing Vedic goṣṭhá- m. 'cow-house', a compound of Vedic gav- 'cow, steer' < PIE *gʷou̯- 'id.', and *steh₂- 'to stand', lit. 'standing place for cows' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:232 no 4336, cf. {ref EWAia} I:502, I:478-480, II:764-766). This cognate set is coded for *steh₂- 'to stand' (> ºṣṭá- ºṣṭā́(na)- 'standing place').
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:159-161 for various proposals.

Continuing a nominal derivative from Proto-Germanic *bangōn- 'to beat, hit', if not onomatopoeic possibly further connected to verbs continuing PIE *bʰ-né/n-g- from *bʰeg- 'to break' ({ref Kluge 2011}:109, {ref EWNl} I:265, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:35, not listed in {ref LIV²}).
Etymology outside Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:192, {ref Kroonen 2013}:247, 251 for various proposals.
Probably root-cognate with Lith. žãbas 'rod, switch', in which case we may reconstruct a common root *g̑ebʰ-, cf. {ref Orel 2003}:208, {ref Kroonen 2013}:276-277, {ref ALEW} 1280.
Cf. Lith. vė̃zdas 'stick'. No certain etymology ({ref ALEW} 1228-1229), perhaps a loanword from Belarusian vjaz 'elm' according to {ref Smoczyński 2007}:745.
Probable loanword, either from Turkic or West Caucasian ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:404).
loan_notes: Cf. Turkic čika 'hair', Ubykh šequ 'hair of the head'.

justificationDiscussion: Cf. discussion s.v. Old Lithuanian stãbas 'graven image, idol' < ?*stobʰ-ó-  in {ref ALEW} 967. The status of this IE reconstruction remains uncertain, cf. Proto-Germanic *staba- 'stick' in /cognate/2980/ and {ref Kroonen 2013}:471.

Iranian root *sau̯H- 'to rub, wear, whet', either a u-stem derivative of Proto-Iranian *saH- (from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)-, cf. {ref EWAia} II:627), or a contamination of two semantically similar roots *dauH- and *skauH- (so {ref Cheung 2007}:340-341); cf. also {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:278, {ref MacKenzie 1990}:120.

notes: connection with Sanskrit pinaṣṭi, piṁṣati is not clear, cf. /cognate/6111/
justificationDiscussion: As though from Sanskrit *prabhindati 'splits' from Vedic √bhid- 'to split; to break, cut (to pieces)', perhaps influenced in its semantics from Sanskrit piṁṣáti, cf. /cognate/6111/ ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:491 no. 8714, cf. {ref Turner 1931}:379). Further to PIE *bʰei̯d- 'to split' ({ref EWAia} II:273-274, {ref LIV²} 70-71).

Appears to be related to Lithuanian taukaĩ, Latvian tàuki 'fat'. There are, however, enormous difficulties in reconciling this group of related Balto-Slavic lexemes to a PIE proto-form. Cf. {ref ALEW} 1081, {ref Derksen 2008}:499-500, {ref Derksen 2015}:459-460 for further discussion. A contamination or blend of between two roots *teu̯h₂- ({ref LIV²} 639-640) and *teu̯k- ({ref LIV²} 641) is a possibility. Cf. also Proto-Germanic *ϸeuha- 'thigh' in /cognate/6956/. The PIE root reference form *teu̯(h₂)k- is provisional only.
Cf. Latvian maût 'to submerge, swim', Lithuanian máuti, further to PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- 'to move (oneself)' ({ref ALEW} 621-622, {ref Derksen 2015}:308, 543-544, {ref LIV²} 445-446).
Derived from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'take, obtain' ({ref LIV²} 250-251, {ref Malzahn 2010}:538-539, {ref Adams 2013}:81-82).
Loan from Russian лытка 'leg, calf, shin, thigh, heel'.
Unclear, cf. {ref Karulis 1992}:298 for older hypotheses and {ref Smoczyński 2007}:600 s.v. Lith. stel̃bti. (Not in {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}).
Etymology uncertain (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.; cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:280 for an earlier, unconvincing proposal).
Loanword from Old Russian думать 'to think' ({ref Karulis 1992} I:223).
Lexemes based on an Iranic root čak- ({ref Abaev 1959–1995}:I:387-388, cf. {ref Benzing 1983}:213).
Loan from East Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).
Probably a loan from Turkic qabar, qapar- 'bulging, swelling' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:278).
A derivative of Tocharian tsäm- 'to grow', in turn derived from PIE *demh₂- 'to build' (cf. ref Adams 2013}:804, {ref Malzahn 2010}:984-987).

{ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:88-89 interprets the Ossetic lexemes as from a *warāka- to a root *war- 'bent', although good correspondences within Iranic are lacking; there are similar East Caucasian terms which Abaev interprets as loanwords from Alanic (cf. Bats varang 'shoulder', Ingush voruv, Chechen vare 'thigh'), but it is possible the loans occurred in the opposite direction (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).
Similar to nursery words for 'meat' in Caucasian languages, cf. Gruz. čičia, Svan. ʒiʒil, Chech., Ing. žižig ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:397).
loan_notes: Loanword or independent nursery word formation?

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995}:623 who tentatively suggests maybe originally compound k'æj-zæx 'stone-earth'.
Connected to PIE *nebʰ- by {ref van Windekens 1976} and {ref Adams 2013}:70, but this etymology remains uncertain; cf. {ref NIL} 503n21 for further discussion.
Loanword from East Caucasian (cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:408-409).
Generally considered a nursery word (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:614).
Probably a loanword from South Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.)

From Proto-Iranic *abi- or *apa- + *snaH- 'to wash, swim', via an intermediate meaning 'to clean up', further to PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:111-112, {ref Cheung 2007}:348-349, cf. {ref LIV²} 572-573).
West Caucasian loanword, cf. Kabardian tẖapä, Adyghe tẖap 'leaf' ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} III:351).

Middle Indic lexemes from Vedic vr̥ddhá- 'grown, large', a derivative to Vedic √vardh- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:699, no.12073), further connections outside of Indo-Iranic are difficult (cf. {ref EWAia} II:520-521; {ref LIV²} 228 mechanically reconstructs ?*Hu̯eRdʰ-).

According to {ref Bailey 1979}:437 to be connected with Ancient Greek σκαιός 'left, western', Latin scaeuus 'left, inauspicious' < as though from *skeh₂-i-uo- 'shaded; left' (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1339, {ref de Vaan 2008}:541-542). For further discussion regarding the root reconstruction cf. 'shadow' in /cognate/5058/.

Denominative verb to TochB śerwe 'hunter', further etymology disputed. A popular analysis (Jasanoff apud {ref Nussbaum 1986}:8, followed by {ref Ringe 1996}) considers TochB śerwe to a vr̥ddhi formation from PIE *k̑er-u̯o- 'stag' (*k̑er-, cf. 'horn' in /cognate/2457/, 'head' in /cognate/53/), but other analyses are possible (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:694-695). Proto-Tocharian root ref. form *śerwë follows Ringe (1996:11).
Loan from Old Indic *ṭakk- (1) 'remain, stop' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:300).
Strand (4/14/20): = “down go”; < Nur. *vü < *üva < PIE *upo?

Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vr̥kká- 'kidney', apparently a semantic development from 'kidneys' > 'heart' > 'chest' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:698, no. 12064). Possibly further to Vedic √vart- 'turn, roll' < PIE *u̯ert- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:571-572).
Parallel loans from Persian سينه sīneh 'chest'.
Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:147-148, {ref Malzahn 2010}:619-620, {ref Adams 2013}:238-239 for various proposals.

Etymology unclear ({ref Adams 2013}:483-484); {ref Malzahn & Peters 2010} suggest a relationship with Greek μάχομαι 'fight' < *megʰh₂-, but the meanings are divergent and the etymology of μάχομαι remains disputed (cf. 'fight' /cognate/4897/).
Root ref. form follows {ref ALEW} 810-811; cf. {ref LIV²} 493, more tentatively reconstructing ?*pret-.

Cf. Standard German hauen 'to chop, hit', continuing Proto-Germanic *hawwan- 'to hew, chop' and further to PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to hit, split' via metathesised *keuh₂- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:218, {ref Seebold 1970}:251, cf. {ref LIV²} 345-346).
Probably to be connected with Latin stringere 'to bind fast, tighten' ({ref Kluge 2011}:891, cf. {ref LIV²} 603-604).
Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:787-789, {ref Adams 2013}:529-531 for further discussion.
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *gōda- 'suitable, good', a derivative of PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:162-163, 184, {ref EWA 4}:694-697, cf. {ref LIV²} 195).
No known etymology ({ref Adams 2013}:675).

Generally agreed to continue a derived n-stem to PIE *k̑er-h₂- 'head' ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:175, {ref Adams 2013}:230). For further etymological discussion regarding the basic root *k̂er- cf. 'head' in /cognate/53/ and 'horn' in /cognate/2457/.
Probably to be derived to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' (cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:626-628, {ref Adams 2013}:626-628, with references to further literature), but not fully certain (Ron Kim, p.c.).
From PGmc. *uber- 'over' + *geban- 'to give'. For the problems of the IE root reconstruction, cf. 'give' in /cognate/228/.

These Tocharian lexemes are probably better explained via PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'to sting' (cf. {ref LIV²} 142, {ref Ringe 1988-1990}:71), although are sometimes considered derivatives of *denk̑- 'to bite'. Cf. also {ref Malzahn 2010}:975-976, {ref Adams 2013}:800.

Lexemes continuing Indo-Iranic *drau̯- ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:400-401, {ref Bailey 1979}:170). Further etymology uncertain, conjecturally connected in older literature (cf. {ref IEW} 276) to Gk. θρίξ, τριχός via root IE *dʰreu̯- with the assumption of root extensions *dʰr-ei̯-gʰ-, *dʰr-ei̯-kʰ-.
Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to become cold, freeze' ({ref Matasović 2009}:185, cf. {ref NIL} 416-417, {ref LIV²} 323).
This class encodes Proto-Indo-Iranic *kárna- 'ear'. The Khowar and Kalaṣa-alâ lexemes represent light verb constructions. Cf. 'ear' in /cognate/768/ for further etymological discussion/
Cf. s.v. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:310 no. 5524 *ḍagga- (2) 'defective'.
Loanword from English '(to) fly' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
A Brythonic word of uncertain origin ({ref Deshayes 2003}:99, cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Celtic *kom-ber-e/o- 'bring together', whose basic verbal root *ber- continues PIE *bʰer- 'to carry, bring' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:218-223, {ref Matasović 2009}:214, 62, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Deshayes 2003}:382-383).
Tocharian A wräṣ 'breathe', a derivative of PIE 3. u̯er- 'to observe, perceive' ({ref LIV²} 685-686, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:892).
Root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:892-893 for further discussion.
Generally connected to PIE *gei̯bʰ- 'bend' ({ref IEW} 354, cf. Lat. gibber 'humpbacked', Lith. geibùs 'frail') after {ref Starke 1990}:504-509; etymology followed by {ref Melchert 1994}:254.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:205, {ref ALEW} 368, 521-522 for further discussion.

Perhaps cognate with Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- 'neck', although there remains some uncertainty over formal aspects of the etymology ({ref Hilmarsson 1996}:162-163, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:234-235), {ref van Windekens 1976}:225-226).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff', further from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' ({ref Matasović 2009}:334).

This set is coded for the Welsh botwm 'button' a loan from Middle English botoun 'button' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}). NB: Welsh: North botwm bol 'button-belly' is a calque from English belly-button.
Loanword from English '(to) hit' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pekʷ- 'to become ripe; to cook' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:430 no. 7641, {ref EWAia} II:46, {ref Matasović 2009}:180, cf. {ref LIV²} 468).
Loan from Old French dous ({ref Deshayes 2003}:199).
Derviative within Breton to Middle Breton czucr, a loan from Old French çucre 'sweet'.
Borrowing from Old French estanc 'pond', itself ultimately from Latin stagnum 'body of standing water, pond, pool, fen, etc.' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:689).
A loan from Old French ({ref Deshayes 2003}:639).
From Old Breton sco 'stroke, blow', further etymology obscure ({ref Deshayes 2003}:666).
Generally derived to PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew' ({ref Adams 2013}:691, 706, cf. {ref LIV²} 168).

A word with uncertain further connections outside of Brythonic (cf. Middle Breton lencquernenn, Late Breton lenkernenn). {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)} suggests doubtfully perhaps to PIE *slenk- at the root of Old High German slango 'snake' (cf. /cognate/302/).
Loanword from Old French flor 'flower; choice, elite' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:243).
Loan from Latin pallaca (Late Latin *placca) 'concubine; girl' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:582).

A denominal formation to Welsh twrch 'hog, (wild) boar; mole' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}), further to Proto-Celtic *tworko- 'boar' from PIE *tu̯ork̑-o- 'cutter, boar', a derivative to PIE *tu̯erk̑- 'to cut' ({ref Matasović 2009}:395, {ref EIEC} 425, cf. {ref LIV²} 656).
Probably to be derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'beat' ({ref Starke 1990}:313-316, {ref Melchert 1993a}:269).
As though from *cīssa- 'sharp pain' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:263 no. 4847). No further etymology.
Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √yā- 'to drive, move oneself', ultimately to PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:58 no. 1288, {ref EWAia} II:407-408, {ref LIV²} 309-310).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-SlavicLexemes derived from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ({ref LIV²} 232-233, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:992-993, {ref Andriotis 1974}:437, {ref Beekes 2010}:388, {ref EWAia} I:102, {ref Cheung 2007}:154-157, {ref ALEW} 259-261, {ref Derksen 2015}:151, {ref ESSJa} 8:247-248, {ref Derksen 2008}:216).

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' ({ref LIV²} 209-210, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:170-171, {ref EWAia} I:465-466, {ref Cheung 2007}:98-101, {ref Seebold 1970}:315-317, {ref Kroonen 2013}:316, {ref de Vaan 2008}:661, Meyer-Lübke 1935}:767 no. 9200).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: cf. ²LIV, p. 504, thus ultimately related to /cognate/4401/

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *meh₁- 'to measure' ({ref LIV²} 424-425, cf. {ref Babinotis 2010}:852-853, {ref Beekes 2010}:939-940, {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:199-201, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:596 no. 10329, {ref EWAia} II:341-343).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √krand- 'to neigh (of a horse), roar (of clouds, wind, water); cry piteously, lament, weep' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:185), further etymology outside of Indic uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:408-409).

notes: perhaps from vad- 'raise one's voice, sound, speak', vádati (RV)
cf. Sanskrit buk-kāra- m. 'the roaring of a lion, cry of any animal', bukkati 'barks' (Dhātup.)

justificationDiscussion: Cf. Sanskrit cī́ra- n. 'strip (of bark or cloth)' and denominal verb *cīrayati 'splits' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:263 no. 4843, 4844). Further etymology outside of Indic uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:545), cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:103 for an uncertain comparison to Khotanese cile 'dress'.

Root ref. form for this class follows the reconstruction of {ref LIV²} 344 ?*k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂- 'to dig', but cf. {ref EWAia} I:455-456 and {ref Cheung 2007}:232-233. We may be dealing with a specifically IIr. root *kanH- (< ?*kenh₁-, if the comparison to Phrygian keneman (a monument or part of it) is correct). {ref LIV²} 344n1 assumes the creation of a neo-root within Indo-Iranic on the basis of the nasal-present stem *k⁽ʷ⁾-né/n̥-h₂-.
loan from Arabic اخسأ

The Hittite stem is paradigmatically suppletive; this cognate set is coded for 3.sg.pres.act. tēzzi < *dʰeh₁-ti ≠ ter-/tar- (< PIE *ter- 'to speak'), cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:857–858, 870–871; {ref LIV²} 136-138.

Possibly to be connected with Proto-Albanian *kakii̯ā̆- (cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:239), but it is difficult to be fully certain of the etymology (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:619-620. Cf. further in /cognate/6597/.
Loanword from French cacher 'to hide'.
Derived from PIE *bʰelH- 'to sound' ({ref ALEW} 113-115, {ref Derksen 2015}:90, cf. {ref Smoczyński 2005}:54ff. {ref LIV²} 74).
Possibly to be connected with Vedic kurkurá- 'dog'? Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:164, no.3219. Otherwise uncertain.
Cf. Vedic sú-mahānt- 'very great, huge' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:778, no. 13493), for further etymology ultimately to PIE *meg̑- 'big' cf. {ref EWAia} II:337-338, {ref NIL} 468-478).

As though continuing Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:511 no. 9092), perhaps continuing a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit phálati 'to burst' ({ref KEWA} II:398).
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:301 no. 5441 s.v. *ṭaḍḍha 'distant'; further etymology uncertain.
Armenian and Germanic lexemes derived from the PIE local adverb *per- 'through, beyond, over; very' ({ref LIPP 2}:607-614, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:404, {ref Kroonen 2013}:137).
Probably a loanword from French ciel 'sky'.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4671ff.

cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10063 s.v. māra- m. ʻdeathʼ (VarBr̥S.), ʻkillingʼ (Rājat.); New Indo-Aryan words meaning ʻstriking, blowʼ from mārayati which continues the polysemy of Vedic hánti (han-) 'beat, slay, kill'; cognate with /cognate/712/

justificationDiscussion: As though continuing Latin *reiectāre 'to throw back' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:594-595), a frequentative of Lat. iaciō, -ere + prefix re- with root etymology going back to PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw, let go' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:292-293, {ref LIV²} 225).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4272 s.v. 'foot, leg, knee'; cognate with /cognate/4586/; related to /cognate/7597/?
justificationDiscussion: As though from Indic *goḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee'; further connections unclear, perhaps related to *khuṭṭa- 'leg' in /cognate/9629/ ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:229 no. 4272).
Loan from Middle German komen 'to come' ({ref Polański 1962-1994}:271-273).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhar- 'to carry', further to PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:535 no. 9397, {ref EWAia} II:246-249, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4094 s.v. *gavatta- ʻcattle-fodderʼ, gáv- 'cow' + *atta- 1 'eaten'
justificationDiscussion: As though from Sanskrit *gavatta- 'cattle-fodder', a compound containing Skt. gáv- 'cow' + *atta- 'eaten' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:219 no. 4094). The cognacy in this cognate set reflects the element *atta- 'eaten' continuing a derivative of PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat' (cf. 'eat' in /cognate/210/).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9531 s.v. *bhuṇḍa- 2 ʻbellyʼ
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4883 cūḍā- 3 f. ʻtopknot on headʼ
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:266 no. 4883 cūḍā- 'topknot on head', probably a Middle Indic formation as though from a participle *kṣur(i)ta- to Vedic kṣuráti 'to cut, scrape' from Vedic kṣurá- 'razor', a nominal derivative of PIE *kseu̯- 'to scrape, to whet' (cf. {ref KEWA} I:292, 397, {ref LIV²} 372).

notes: via 'strong' from 'overpower, have power over', cf. LIV, p. 515; Turner 1962-66, no. 13298ff.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Persian آسمان / āsmān or Tajik осмон / osmon 'sky'.
