notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 645, no. 11083: s.v. Vedic lúpyate 'is lost, is removed' (TS), apalupyate 'perishes' (AV) "replaced in MIA. by *lukka- in P[rakrit] lukkaï intr. 'hides'"
construction with t̪ʰɑːʋon < stāpháyati, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13756, initial part presumably non-Aryan, cf. ibid. no. 4937f.?

justificationDiscussion: Continuing a derivative of Sanskrit √gharṣ- 'to rub', further connections remain unclear ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:240 no. 4450, {ref EWAia} I:513-514)

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11004 and s.v. lag-
justificationDiscussion: As though from Sanskrit lāgayati 'lays on', the causative stem to √lag- 'to stick, attach'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:638 no. 11004, {ref EWAia} II:473)
Valid under the assumption that this is the same etymon as d(h)yūm in Morgenstierne 1941:34.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11480 s.v. vāṭa- m. 'enclosure, fence' (MhB.): "Early east MIA. < *vārtra-", from 1. var-
justificationDiscussion: Cf. Sanskrit vāṭa- m. 'enclosure, fence', a formation originating in Middle Indic as though from Sanskrit *vārtra- or Sanskrit *vārta- < PIE *u̯orto- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:670 no. 11480 + addenda; cf. {ref Burrow 1975}:68). For the root, cf. Vedic 2. √var- 'to cover, conceal, hide, surround'. Further root etymology difficult; the Vedic root appears to continue a conflation of several different IE sources that have become homophonous (cf. {ref EWAia} II:512-513, {ref LIV²} 227-228 s.v. *Hu̯er-, 674 s.v. *u̯el- and 684 s.v. 1. u̯er-).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *sáras-, an s-stem to a root *sel- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:708, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:765 no. 13254).
Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit pallava- 'sprout, shoot, twig', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:450, {ref KEWA} II:235-236).

notes: Deriv. of Si. koli 'the tree'???

justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)per- 'to fly' ({ref EWAia} II:97, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:446 no. 7918, cf. {ref LIV²} 579-580).

Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit kāleyaka- 'a particular part of the intestines; liver' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:158 no. 3103). Further etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref KEWA}, {ref EWAia}].

notes: Cf. Turner 1962–1966:291 no. 5286 jyḗṣṭha ʻ first, chief ʼ > K. zyuṭhᵘ, dat. ziṭhis ʻ old, elder ʼ???

perhaps PIE *li̯ú-, if *li̯ > Vedic y but Germanic l-, cf. 'liver' (if from *li̯ekʷ- ~ *li̯ep- but not *Hi̯ekʷ-); Proto-Germanic *lūs < *li̯ú-s etc. with reanalysis of the ending -s (?) (R.P.); not fully clear.
justificationDiscussion: Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

notes: re-sanskritized? not among Turner 1962-66, no. 9827f. mánuṣa- and manuṣyà-

justificationDiscussion: See also the independent loan of the same ultimate Greek source lexeme, via Latin and Norman 'French' into English at https://cobl.info/cognate/9719.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic jyótsnā- 'moonlight night' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:292 no. 5301), derived from Vedic √jyot- 'to shine' a phonetic variant of Vedic √dyot- 'to shine', a neo-root further to the same root as Vedic dyáv- 'sky', itself a derivative of PIE *dei̯- 'shine' via *di̯-éu̯- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:604-606, II:750-754, {ref NIL} 69-81).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic kaṇṭhá- 'throat' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:134 no. 2680). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Dravidian (cf. {ref EWAia} I:292, {ref Burrow & Emeneau 1984}:127).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13264 s.v. saru- 'fine' lex.
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit saru- 'fine', only attested in lexicographical works ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:766 no. 13264). Further etymology unclear ({ref KEWA} III:445).

notes: Parallel loans from Sanskrit
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Sanskrit nā́bhiḥ 'navel'.
Parallel loans from Persian ناف / nāf 'navel'.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5607 s.v. *ḍhōṭṭa-

justificationDiscussion: Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ({ref Derksen 2008}:494, cf. {ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4:183, {ref Boryś 2005}:77, 84 for various proposals.
From Ancient Greek κράζω 'to croak, cry' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:575-576, {ref Beekes 2010}:767-768).

As though continuing Sanskrit alupta- 'not cut off, undiminished' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:32 no. 719), derived from Vedic √lop- 'to break, damage, destroy' and further to PIE *reu̯p- 'to break, tear (apart)' ({ref EWAia} II:482, {ref LIV²} 510-511).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10459 s.v. yā́nam n. ʻgoing, vehicleʼ (RV), Prakrit jāṇa- n. ʻriding, driving, vehicleʼ; for le cf. /cognate/6587/ < PIE *lembʰ-
justificationDiscussion: Light verb construction where the light verb is jānā 'to go' and the semantic head is le/lai, ultimately from PIE *lembʰ- (cf. /cognate/6587/)

Identical to the general word for 'foot' and 'leg' in many other Slavic languages (cf. 'foot' in /cognate/1252/, 'leg' in /cognate/1231/), and ultimately derived to the same root as the widespread root *h₃negʷʰ- also found in '(finger)nail' and 'claw' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:354-355, {ref ESSJa} 25:161-164).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2450
justificationDiscussion: Continuing Vedic r̥ñjáti 'makes straight, pulls, stretches' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:117 no. 2450), a derivative of Vedic √raj- 'to direct, stretch, attain' and further to PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to make straight, stretch out' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:425, {ref LIV²} 304-305).
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *(ava-)kaḍḍh- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:133 no. 2660, 822 no. 14245), further etymology uncertain.
Possibly a Dravidian loanword, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:353 no. 6173.

notes: cf. Bshk. muč- 'to open (of a cloud)', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10181

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit pānīya- 'water' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:456 no. 8082), a derivative of Vedic √pā- 'to drink' and further to PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ({ref EWAia} II:113-114, {ref LIV²} 262).

notes: cf. Vedic varṣám n. 1. ʻrain ʼ (RV+), m. pl. varṣā́ḥ ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV), 2. ʻyear' (ŚB) (root vr̥ṣ-), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 446, no. 1139: Pali vassa- m. n. ʻrainʼ, pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ, Prakrit vāsa- m. (or < vārṣa-), varisa- m. n. - ultimately cognate with 'year' in /cognate/1634/; for Marathi pāūs < pra-vŕ̥ṣ- f. 'rainy season' cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8964
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂u̯ers- 'to rain' ({ref EWAia} II:522-523, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:664 no. 11392, cf. {ref LIV²} 291-292)
Parallel loans from Persian بارش / bārish 'rain, precipitation'.
Loan from Sanskrit vr̥ṣṭi-.
Loan from Persian رود / rūd 'river, stream, flood'.

notes: Sanskritism, cf. Vedic varṣā́ḥ m. pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV) (root vr̥ṣ-)

maybe related to śikyà- n. (AV) 'rope-sling for carrying things', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12427f, see also s.v. *śikyadhara- m. 'hook at the end of the pole which carries the looped cord for holding the strings of a balance' or *śikyākāra-, Bi. Mth. sikahar 'net for hanging up pots &c. in a house'
< Vedic úpaviśati 'approaches' (RV), 'sits down' (ŚB), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 105, no. 2245: "Contamination with vásati"; for Maithili cf. no. 2249
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic úpaviśati 'approaches' (RV), 'sits down' (ŚBr.), a derivative of Vedic √veś- 'to enter, enter in or settle down on, go into' and further to PIE *u̯ei̯k̑- 'to enter, step in' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:105 no. 2245, {ref EWAia} II:584, {ref LIV²} 669-670).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √vas- 'to live, reside, spend the night' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:667 no. 11435), further to PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ({ref EWAia} II:531-532, cf. {ref LIV²} 293-294).

notes: from 'creature' via 'any animal of the lowest order, insect, worm', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5110
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic jantú- m. 'offspring, creature, man', via a secondary semantic shift 'any animal of lowest order, insect, worm' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:282 no. 5110). Further from PIE *g̑enh₁-tú-, a derivative of PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to produce, beget' ({ref EWAia} I:570, cf. {ref NIL} 139-153, {ref LIV²} 163-165).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a stem *khaḍa- *'erect'(?), further etymology unclear ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:198 no. 3784, cf. {ref EWAia} I:443).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12622
PLEASE REVISE ENTRY! cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13253
The loan note "hard to tell if from Persian āftāb" probably refers to Kashmiri alone.
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4344
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit guḍa- (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:224 no. 4182, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:233 no. 4344). Further etymology uncertain, possibly an Austroasiatic loanword (cf. {ref KEWA} I:338).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8792 s.v. právahati, cf. pravāhayati 'causes to swim away'; for Kashmiri cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11612 (?) - different derivations
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing different derivatives and light-verb constructions derived from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to carry, drive' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:494 no. 8792, p.677 no. 11612, {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref Cheung 2007}:429-432).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'carry' in /cognate/7547/, 'drink' in /cognate/1955/, 'fall' in /cognate/3661/, 'fly_pst3sg' in /cognate/1993/, 'house' in /cognate/5142/, 'run' in /cognate/6778/.

notes: Hindi and Urdu forms are from the variant tiráte 'cross over, sail across', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 331.
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes as if from tárati, Vedic 'cross (a river)', Classical Sanskrit 'float, swim', ultimately going back to PIE *terh₂- 'cross'. Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 324.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 6419: "poss. all NIA. forms, and cert. those of Dard. with l-, are < Ir., Av. duma- [...]. But. besides Kal., some derivatives [...] suggest possibility of orig. IA. form" - Hindi and Urdu may have Persianized forms of an originally inherited form; not a simple loan event - for the sequence *Cumbʱa- compare Vedic kumbhá- m. 'pot' and Av. xumba-

justificationDiscussion: As though continuing Indic *laṭṭa- 'hanging, tangled', further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:633 no. 10918).

notes: cf. Vedic nom. sg. m.f. asáu, gen. amúṣya, compare Hittite asi

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Indo-Aryan forms are from Vedic ārá-, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1295, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 107 - should be merged with /cognate/2438/ and also /cognate/2439/; PIE form must be *h₁al- ~ *h₁an-, compare Hittite anna- ‘former, old’ and anni- ‘that, the already mentioned one'
Romance forms from Latin ECCU 'look!' + ILLE 'that' (Dietz 1864: 356), cf. Romance terms in /cognate/323/

justificationDiscussion: Root etymology possibly to PIE *h₃ekʷ- as in Ancient Greek ὄσσε 'eyes' (dual), but the stem formation is very unclear ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:452-453, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:811-813}, {ref Beekes 2010}:1133-1134). Cf. note by Scarborough in cognate set citations for further justification and discussion.

From Ancient Greek ξηρός (adj.) 'dry' ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:355), further connections outside of Greek unclear; occasionally proposed to Arm. čʻor 'dry' (cf. /cognate/5006/), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:182, {ref Beekes 2010}:1035-1036, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:546).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: *(h₁)e- + *séh₂- + *=u, cognate with /cognate/3005/, /cognate/3006/ and /cognate/3011/; cf. also 'that' /cognate/2683/; from Vedic asáu ~ amú-, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 972

cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4411
cf. Young Avestan tiγra-, Old Persian tigra- 'sharp' < Proto-Indo-Iranian *tigrá-, compare Vedic tigmá-, cf. Maryhofer EWAia I, p. 668f.
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4859

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic dunóti 'distresses' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:366, no. 6410), further derived from PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to catch fire' ({ref EWAia} I:707-708, {ref LIV²} 104-105).

notes: from *u̯ert- 'turn, roll, spin', Vedic vartáyati (RV), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11356

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: same as root as in 'that' /cognate/2442/, 'what' /lexeme/25011/, 'he' /cognate/2678/, 'here' /cognate/1666/, 'how' in /cognate/1230/, 'other' in /cognate/448/ and 'they' in /cognate/3005/; for Sinhalese cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2528; PIE *(h₁)í- seems to be the base of the 2pl pronoun *Hi̯ú- (*Hi̯éu-) and the relativizing pronominal adjective *Hi̯ó- (thus *h₁i̯ó-), pointing to *h₁í- not just *í- (Pooth)

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5545 and 11004
Cf. Turner 11984 *viṣēcana 'discharging' or 11985 *viṣkirati 'scatters'???
Dhātup., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3747
lex., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3228; Prakrit kuḍa- m. 'tree'
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:165 no. 3228 kutá- 'a kind of tree'. Further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} I:221).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10187; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing *muṭṭha- 'defective', no further etymology ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:587 no.10187).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7777; Morgenstierne Göteborgs Hösskolas Aarsskrift xli 35, 3, 36

An earlier note, I assume by Roland Pooth, pointed to Turner 1962-66, no. 13358 s.v. Vedic sāráyati > Si. harinavā 'to dismiss'. If this etymology is correct, then superset id 445 to PIE *sel-, but I'm not sure this etymology is correct. (–MJCS, 25.08.2020).

justificationDiscussion: From Latin spīna 'thorn, prickle; spine' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:673). Further etymology uncertain ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:642, cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:692-693). {ref de Vaan 2008}:580-581 (following {ref IEW} 981-982) suggests a possibly cognate relationship to Slavic lexemes, e.g. Ru. спина 'back', but it is not certain whether these forms are actually root cognate or loanwords from Latin (cf. discussion in /cognate/2059/).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4969
Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: Continuing a derivative of Vedic *√vraj- 'to roam, stride' and further to PIE *u̯reg- 'to follow a trace, trail' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:65-66, {ref LIV²} 697, cf. {ref EWAia} II:594).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7618 who connects Indo-Aryan *pakk- 'move forward, reach' to Vedic pakvá- 'cooked, ripe' > Pali pakka- 'reached, sufficient, able'; thus via 'reached' and 'reach' to 'go on well, succeed, go, tread, advance'; interesting
justificationDiscussion: Connected to an Indic stem *pakk- 'move forward, reach', which {ref Turner 1962–1966}:429 no. 7618 suggests might be connected to Skt. pakvá- 'cooked, ripe'. If so, then there might be a further root etymology to PIE *pekʷ- 'become ripe, cooked', cf. {ref EWAia} II:62.

notes: Dhātup., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5836; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
justificationDiscussion: Apparently continuing Sanskrit tillati 'goes', only attested in the Dhātupada lexical list, further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:332 no. 5836, {ref KEWA} I:505).

notes: Loan from Germanic.
justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes loaned into Late Latin from Germanic *blanka- 'colourless(?)' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 15/1:138-146, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:100; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:67).

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: the same root as in 'what' /cognate/160/ and 'some' in /cognate/2937/, see comment on 'some' in /cognate/2948/

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *su̯ep- 'to fall asleep' ({ref LIV²} 612, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:787-789, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:667-668, {ref EWAia} II:791, {ref Cheung 2007}:145-147, {ref Derksen 2008}:481, {ref Kroonen 2013}:489, {ref Seebold 1970}:482-483).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek ὀψάριον 'little side-dish', a diminutive formation to Ancient Greek ὄψον 'cooked or prepared food', but esp. at Athens 'fish' ({ref Babinotis 2010}:1624), further from an o-grade derivative *h₁op-s to *h₁ep- 'on, upon' with the sense of being a supplementary dish eaten on top of grain or bread ({ref Beekes 2010}:1139-1140).

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966
tentatively perh. to Turner 1962-66, no. 8996
prob. lw. Sk. sahita- provided with (at end of cmpds.).]
cf. Turner 1962-66, no 9962
nursery word for 'mother', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9198

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green'. Regarding the irregular correspondence of the initial velar in Lithuanian and Old Prussian, see {ref Derksen 2015}:169-170 (but cf. {ref ALEW} 309). For individual branches cf. {ref Dawkins 1916}:661, {ref Beekes 2010}:1638, {ref EWAia} II:805-806, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:809 no. 13990, {ref ALEW} 309, {ref Derksen 2015}:169-170, {ref Derksen 2008}:565-566, {ref Kroonen 2013}:174).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'moon' in /cognate/2337/, 'grass' in /cognate/1576/, 'green' in /cognate/6332/, 'red' in /cognate/3832/, 'white' in /cognate/2411/.

notes: *tuṣma-, in analogy to 2sg pronoun Vedic tuvám (tu°) etc. but not newly derived from it, just modified from older yuṣma-

justificationDiscussion: Romance forms based on Latin flō, flāre 'to blow', ultimately derived from PIE *bʰleh₁- 'blow' (cf. {ref {de Vaan 2008}:226-227, {ref LIV²} 87).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from Old Indic *bura- 'defective' ({ref Turner 1962–1966} 526 no. 9289). No further etymology.

Uncertain, perhaps to in some way to Sanskrit madhurá- 'sweet' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:562 no. 9793)? If so, then to be connected with PIE *médʰu- 'sweet drink, honey' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:302-303).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11456 s.v. vahana- n. 'carrying' (MBh.)
justificationDiscussion: Light verb construction, coded for Bengali bahan < Sanskrit vahana- 'a carrying' derived from Vedic √vah- 'to drive, ride (a cart, chariot)' and further to PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to float, drive' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:668 no. 11456, {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref LIV²} 661-662).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'drink' in /cognate/1955/, 'fall' in /cognate/3661/, 'fly_pst3sg' in /cognate/1993/, 'house' in /cognate/5142/, 'run' in /cognate/6778/, 'swim' in /cognate/7464/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain; perhaps originally 'to carry on the back', cf. Skt. vr̥kká- 'kidney' ({ref Turner 1931}:460, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:527, no. 9311).
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:336 no. 5884 tulayati 'lifts' > K. tulun 'to lift', further to PIE *telh₂- 'to raise' (cf. {ref KEWA} I:516, {ref LIV²} 622-623).
Indo-Iranic lexemes of onomatopoeic origin, imitative of suckling, cf. Skt. cuci- 'female breast' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:264, no. 4855; cf. {ref KEWA} I:394-395).

Indo-Iranic and Balto-Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₂seu̯s- 'to become dry' ({ref EWAia} II:648-649, 658, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:724, 727 no. 12548, 12508; {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:250-251, {ref ALEW} 892-893, {ref Derksen 2015}:390, {ref Derksen 2008}:473-474, cf. {ref LIV²} 285).
Uncertain, loan from Iranic (cf. /cognate/68/)?
Cf. Standard German holen 'to fetch, get'. Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ({ref EWA 4}:774-777).
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to grind, crush' ({ref de Vries 1977}:392, {ref Lehmann 1986}:260, cf. {ref LIV²} 432-433).

Possibly cognate with Anatolian lexemes for 'bad' in /cognate/3299/ (so {ref Adams 2013:555-556}; tentatively mentioned but not explicitly rejected by {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:420-422). Alternatively a loan from Old Turkish ({ref Peyrot 2016}:327-335).

notes: parallel Persian loans, with sound substitutions j for z in Magahi, Marathi, Nepali

justificationDiscussion: Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived traditionally assigned to a root *peth₁- 'to fall' ({ref LIV²} 477-478, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:905-906, {ref Beekes 2010}:1195-1196). See now {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} considering a more basic PIE root *pet- 'to fall; to fly' merging also 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' ({ref LIV²} 479). Cf. also {ref EWAia} II:71-72).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fly_V' in /cognate/1486/, 'feather' in /cognate/7563/, 'leaf' in /cognate/790/, 'narrow' in /cognate/4064/, 'river' in /cognate/1525/, 'run' in /cognate/5968/, 'sleep' in /cognate/8796/, 'wing' in /cognate/1567/

justificationDiscussion: Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:658-659, {ref Beekes 2010}:1248, {ref EWAia} II:75-76, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:435-436 no.7721, {ref Kroonen 2013}:138-139, {ref de Vaan 2008}:458, {ref Lucht 2007}:151-152, {ref Matasović 2009}:129). For the root reconstruction *pet-, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fall' in /cognate/7561/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/1486/, 'leaf' in /cognate/790/, 'narrow' in /cognate/4064/, 'river' in /cognate/1525/, 'run' in /cognate/5968/, 'sleep' in /cognate/8796/, 'wing' in /cognate/1567/
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11225 s.v. Sanskrit vaḍra ʻbigʼ (lex.); scarcely < vr̥ddhá-; PPP of vr̥dh- 'grow (strong), make grown strong'; cf. 'big' /cognate/753/

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 6216
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit dálati 'cracks, splits', probably an l-form of the same root as Vedic √dar- 'to scatter, split' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:355 no. 6216, {ref KEWA} II:24), further to PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' ({ref EWAia} I:701-703, {ref LIV²} 119-121).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ({ref LIV²} 232-233, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:616-618, {ref Adams 2013}:64-66, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1002-1006, {ref EWAia} I:102, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:23 no.497, {ref ALEW} 259-261, {ref Derksen 2015}:151, {ref ESSJa} 8:247-248, {ref Derksen 2008}:216, {ref de Vaan 2008}:191-192).

notes: derived *-tá- participle/adj. from Proto-Indo-Iranian *d(ʱ)arj́(ʱ)- '(be/become/make) fix, solid', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 371, no. 6508, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 706f.
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *d⁽ʰ⁾arjʰ- 'to fix; be firm, strong', further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:371 no. 6508, {ref EWAia} I:707-708).
Italic lexemes from PIE *mei̯H- 'to diminish' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:381-382, {ref Untermann 2000}:477-478, cf. {ref LIV²} 427). For Sardinian, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:459 s.v. 5594 Lat. minus.

notes: presumably ideophonic nursery word
justificationDiscussion: Presumably a nursery word in origin (cf. {ref Turner 1931}:30, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:45 no. 997).

notes: from Sanskrit raṭati 'howls, shouts', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1301 s.v. āraṭa- n. ʻcrying outʼ (Pāṇ.), 2. āraṭi- f. ʻnoiseʼ (Kathās.), √raṭ-
justificationDiscussion: From Sanskrit √raṭ- 'to howl, shout' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:59 no. 1301, 1302); no certain further etymology, probably onomatopoeic (cf. {ref KEWA} III:36).
Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *gʰr̥dʰ-ó- ~ *gʰordʰ-ó- 'enclosure' ({ref EWAia} I:495, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:239, no. 4428; {ref Kroonen 2013}:169, cf. {ref LIV²} 197).
Probably to a root *ṭan- 'be tight' found in NIA languages (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:301 no. 5443), further etymology obscure.

notes: cf. lápati (AV) 'chatters, talks'; via 'whisper', 'talk secretly, make secrets'
ideophonic - compare Lithuanian /cognate/6872/ (parallel ideophonic creations?)

justificationDiscussion: Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed  {ref LIV²}. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.

Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit piccha- 'tail-feather' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:460 no. 8151), further etymology unclear ({ref KEWA} II:270-271; cf. also 'tail' in /cognate/1260/ ???).

Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} II:660-661; cf. {ref KEWA} III:383-384 for various older proposals). For Kashmiri šuh, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:723 no. 12485 śītá- 'cold' (i.e. the regularly past passive participle formed to Vedic √śyā-), for Nuristan languages cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:731 no.12614.

Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from Vedic khyā- 'to see', ultimately from PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ({ref EWAia} I:420-421, I:456-457; {ref LIV²} 383-385). For Marathi, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:48 no. 1074 *ācikhyati 'communicates'; for Nuristan languages, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:745 no. 12842 sáṁkhyāti (*saṁkśāti) 'reckons'.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic vā́ma- 'left', presumably a euphemistic replacement from Vedic vāmá- 'dear', no further etymology ({ref EWAia} II:543-544, {ref KEWA} III:189, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:672-673, no. 11533).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5853 s.v. tuṇḍa- n. ʻbeak, trunk, snoutʼ (TĀr. MBh.); cf. ibid. no. 10163 s.v. mukhatuṇḍaka m.n. (?) ʻmouthʼ Divyāv. (múkha- + tuṇḍa-) cf. /cognate/6016/
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:509-510 s.v. tuṇḍa- 'beak, trunk, snout'. Etymology uncertain, probably a loanword of non-Indic origin (cf. {ref KEWA} I:509-510).

notes: blends of word of different origins, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4111 s.v. *gāṭṭa- ʻneck, throatʼ and no. 4459 s.v. ghāṭā- f. ʻnape of neckʼ (Suśr.), no. 4124; cf. Vedic gā́tram

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Sanskrit khúra- without certain etymology, possibly loans from Dravidian (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:207 no. 3906; {ref KEWA} I:310, {ref EWAia} I:454, cf. {ref Burrow 1948}:376). Perhaps further connected with lexemes as though from Sanskrit *khuṭṭa- 'peg, post' in /cognate/9629/, but these could also be parallel loans.

Etymology outside of Anatolian disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in /cognate/7599/ ({ref LIV²} 229, {ref Adams 2013}:107, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. {ref Adams 2013}:107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.

Etymology disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in /cognate/7599/ ({ref LIV²} 229, {ref Adams 2013}:107, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. {ref Adams 2013}:107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.
No satisfactory etymology (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:538, {ref KEWA} II:491-492, {ref EWAia} II:243-244).
Parallel loans from Persian.
loan_notes: probably borrowed before *rd > l (i.e. Old Persian)

notes: cf. Middle Persian kamar "waist, belt, girdle"; Horn (1893:193) relates this word to Av. kamarā- "belt".

justificationDiscussion: From Latin fructus 'produce, reward, fruit' (G. Cadorini, p.c.), derived further from Latin fruor, fruī 'to enjoy (the produce of)' from PIE *bʰruHg-i̯é/ó- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:244-245).
Friulian vaî is from Latin uagiō, -īre 'to cry' (G. Cadorini, p.c.), further etymology unclear ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:711, {ref de Vaan 2008}:651).

notes: Derived from the Friul. verb asiâ, a loan from Old French aisier (–G. Cadorini)

justificationDiscussion: From Latin cōlāre 'to percolate, sieve' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:193), a denominal verb to Latin cōlum 'sieve, wine filter', no further certain etymology ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:193).

notes: From Lat. *undulare (cfr. undulatus, -a, -um 'having a wavy form, billowing') or better derivation from Friul. vongule < Lat. undula (–G. Cadorini)
From Lat. stāre (aux. verb) + Lat. susum (< sursum) 'in a higher position, above' (–G. Cadorini)

justificationDiscussion: From Latin *plattare, a derivative of Latin plattus 'flat, level', in turn a loan from Greek πλατύς ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:547)

notes: "From a pre-Indoeuropean root meaning "to cut", attested in Romanian and Bulgarian too." (–G. Cadorini)

justificationDiscussion: From Latin longa (G. Cadorini, p.c.); for further cognates and the etymology cf. 'long' in /cognate/257/.
Etymology unknown. Derivation from Lat. suburgere or superurgere? From a verb in some German language related to Old High German sweran? (G. Cadorini, p.c.)

notes: Etymology unknown. From a verb in some German language related to Germ. rutschen? (–G. Cadorini)

justificationDiscussion: Etymology unknown, perhaps a loanword from Germanic language related to Modern German rutschen? (G. Cadorini, p.c.).
Derived from the inherited word for 'nose'. For further etymological discussion, cf. /cognate/267/.
Loan from Slovenian modrak (G. Cadorini, p.c.)

notes: From Lat. dividere (–G. Cadorini)
Derivation from Friul. curtìs "knife" from a substantive  derivated from Lat. culter, -i
Etymology unknown. Cfr. Sp., Pg. chupar (–G. Cadorini)

justificationDiscussion: Friulian cjoli, from Latin tollere (G. Cadorini, p.c., cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:727), further a nasal-infix present stem formed to PIE *telh₂- 'raise up' in origin ({ref de Vaan 2008}:621-622, {ref LIV²} 622-623).
From Latin ambulāre ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:33 no. 412), further to PIE *h₂elh₂- 'go aimlessly, randomly' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:38, {ref LIV²} 264).

Lit. 'congealed/frozen water'. Cognacy in this set is coded for Sinhalese දිය diya 'water' < Vedic udaká- 'water', further derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:89 no. 1921, {ref EWAia} I:215-216, cf. {ref NIL} 706-715). For the modifer 'congealed/frozen', cf. 'freeze' in /cognate/7652/.

Pace {ref Katz 1998} who argues for a compound 'eel-snake' consisting of elements *illui̯- (cf. Proto-Germanic *ǣla- 'eel') and *anka- 'snake' (Latin anguis, Greek ὄφις), Hittite illui̯anka- is generally considered a Hattic loanword ({ref HED A+E/I}:358-359, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:384).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12961
justificationDiscussion: Continuing Vedic sáṁbharati 'brings together, prepares, rolls up' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:751 no. 12961), a derivative of Vedic √bhar- < PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref EWAia} I:246-249, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77).

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1858
justificationDiscussion: Sinhalese osananavā 'to carry', as though from Sanskrit *ut-śrāpayati > ucchrāpayati 'raises' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:85), further derived from Sanskrit √śray- 'to lean' and ultimately from PIE *k̑lei̯- ({ref EWAia} II:665, {ref LIV²} 332-333).
Probably of onomatopoeic/imitative origin (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:511, no. 9090; {ref KEWA} II:307).
It's disputable if the Slavic word belongs to PIE ?*dʰreb- or *dʰrebʰ-. The majority view is adopted here.

notes: inner fat
justificationDiscussion: The relationship to PIE *sed- is addopted here.

notes: Loan from Arabic via Old Iranian: cf. http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arabic-ii

justificationDiscussion: The root has an onomatopoeic origin and and its reflexes show various instances of an irregular phonological development. No certain further IE cognates (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:122-123, 129-135; {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 6:161, {ref Boryś 2005}:57).
The reconstruction and the further IE cognacy is not entirely clear.
Loanword from German, possibly via Polish ({ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} 1: 317-318).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. {ref ESSJa} 8:21-22, {ref Boryś 2005}:57).

A relationship of this lexeme to PS *trěskati, a lexeme referring to sounds made by splitting or cracking things, seems reasonable. For the semantic development cf. PS *drobŭ *drobŭ (>)'guts' and PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush' (cognate/1153/). However, taking into account ideophonic origin of the PS root(s) and the irregular sound shape of PS *troxa that has to be assumed by accepting this relationship, no reliable further etymology can be found.
Loanword from Arabic قرن / qarn 'horn'.
Loanword from Arabic (dial.) salj (cf. Standard Arabic ثلج / thalj 'snow').
Loan from Arabic جناح / janāḥ 'wing'.

The etymology is not entirely clear due to possible expressive deformations and contaminations.
I adopt here the view of {ref ESSJa}, see below. However, it has to be treated with caution. Another possibilities, proposed in {ref Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012} (see below), are a relationship to PIE *trenk- (cf. {ref Boryś 2005}: 641 and {ref LIV²}: 649) or to cognate/4961/ (without certain further etymology).

notes: Cheung (2007: 379) assumes prefix *abi-. Horn (1893: 1, 9) suggested a compound of āb + tāb with āb „Glanz“.
Probable loanword from local Arabic 'powder'.
Likely to be a loanword from Arabic
Schuster-Šewc
justificationDiscussion:
It can be related to PS *šip 'arrow, thorn, spine, quill'. However, the further etymology of PS *šip is obscure, cf. {ref Rejzek 2001}: 629, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}: 4: 45-46, {ref Boryś 2005}, {ref Vasmer 1986-1987}: 4: 440.
It has been linked to PIE *(s)kep-. However, this etymology needs additional phonetic assumptions.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, to chop' ({ref LIV²} 555, {ref Derksen 2008}:233, {ref ESSJa} 11:18-20).
Loan from local Arabic, cf. Arabic wād 'dry riverbed'.
Etymology uncertain, possibly an Arabic loanword.
Possibly an Arabic loanword.
Presumably a loanword from Arabic.
Etymology uncertain, maybe a loan from local Arabic.
Loanword from Arabic, cf. Standard Arabic  رقبة / raqaba 'neck'.
Loanword from Arabic.

notes: If these are compounds of māh 'moon', should they not be merged into /cognate/2232/?

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Arabic ركبة / rakba 'knee'.
Cf. Persian javān 'young' from PIE *h₂i̯éu̯-Hon- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:413-414).
'bright, yellow' > 'bitter' developed through the meaning 'bile, gall'.

The original meaning is probably 'damp forest, forest at a river'. The word has no certain further etymology. It can be an irregular variant of *lǫk- 'meadow' (it would be derived from PIE ?*lenk- then). However, the irregular voicing would be hard to explain reasonably. The relationship to PG *lingwa- 'heather' should be taken into account.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *velěti 'want, order', further derived from PIE *u̯elh₁- 'to choose' (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:514, {ref LIV²} 677-678).

While the Baltic cognates are certain, the further proposed cognates are more dubious (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:472). However, the connection to PIE ?*stei̯b- / ?*stei̯p- 'make stiff, make hard' (see the Baltic and other IE cognates listed, cf. below and {ref Smoczyński 2007}:603) is plausible and formally and semantically convincing.

notes: Related to *kʷr̥mi-. However, -v- is not phonetically explainable.

justificationDiscussion: The original meaning (almost directly attested in many Slavic dialects where its cognates mean 'vine, vine trunk') was 'creeping plant' (cf. {ref ESSJa} 16:119-120; for the root reconstruction, cf. {ref LIV²} 400).
Loan from Turkish bed, ultimately from Persian bad 'bad' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:39).
Generally considered to be of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-}:235-237).
Of onomatopoeic origin ({ref ESSJa} 8:146-147).
Loan from Modern Greek κόκκαλο(ν) 'bone' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 2:530-532)
No satisfactory etymology.

notes: The semantic development in Slavic is 'something that waves, nods' > 'plant, flower' (> 'bouquet (Czech)', 'ponytail (Polish)' etc).
justificationDiscussion: The etymology suggested by {ref ESSJa} points to PIE *keh₂u̯- but is less convincing semantically.
Loanword from Turkish yemiş 'fruit' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 1:496).
Loanword from Turkish χob 'beautiful', ultimately from Persian hūb 'beautiful' ({ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 4:284).

notes: 'stab'>'kill'.
justificationDiscussion: Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break', cf. OCS klati, 1.sg. koljǫ 'to stab' ({ref ESSJa} 10:154-156, {ref Derksen 2008}:230, {ref LIV²} 350).
Loanword from Turkish göl 'lake' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} I:306).
Of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} I:357).
Of onomatopoeic origin. No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref ESSJa} 8:18-19, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:202).
Although there are some possible formal issues, I find the comparison to PS *smykati, *smukati, derived from PIE *(s)meu̯k- 'glide, slide', very attractive.
Loan from Turkish çomak 'club'.
Loanword from Turkish kuyruk 'tail' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-}:82).
Loanword from Middle Low German gel, gele 'yellow' ({ref Polański 1962-1994} II:149).
Loan from Turkish meyva 'fruit', ultimately from Persian mäyva 'fruit' ({ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} 3:718-719).
As to the semantic development (relative) pronoun 'how, what kind' > 'strong, hard') cf. Latin 'qualitas' (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} I:218).
Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain, cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:507-508 for further discussion.

Very similar in form and meaning to Ancient Greek γλυκύς 'sweet', but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. Perhaps the Italic and Greek lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:186-187, {ref de Vaan 2008}:182). Cf. further discussion in /cognate/5055/.

As though continuing Sanskrit *saṁgōpayati 'hides' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:745 no. 12851). The verbal root, √gop- ~ √gup-, was backformed in Vedic from gopā́- (n.) 'cowherd', itself a nominal compound *gʷou̯-peh₂- 'cow-protector' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:499-500). Of the two elements, *peh₂- (cf. {ref LIV²} 460 *peh₂(i̯)- 'schützen, hüten, weiden') is arguably the original semantic head here (i.e. 'to protect (cattle)' > 'to hide') although I am hesitant to consider PIE *peh₂- as the root-reference form here because of the process of backformation that occurred to create the new root √gop- within Vedic.
Loanword from Sanskrit pudgala- 'beautiful; body; material object (including atoms); the ego, soul; individual'.

Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit vi-stara- 'spread-out', a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew' and ultimately to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:693 no. 11987, {ref EWAia} II:756-757, {ref LIV²} 599-600).

Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit ākāśá- 'sky' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:45 no. 1008), to be further connected with Vedic √kāś- 'to be visible, appear' and further to PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ({ref EWAia} I:344-345, {ref LIV²} 383-385).
Lexemes in this set coded for Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ 'black' < PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾r̥s-nó- (cf. {ref ESSJa} 4:155-157, {ref Derksen 2008}:92). For further etymological discussion, cf. /cognate/1111/ 'black'.

The cognacy in this class follows {ref LIV²} to PIE *(s)teup- after {ref Oettinger 1979}:417, 535, {ref Hajnal 1995}:127. Note however disagreement of {ref Melchert 1994}:242, {ref Neumann 2007}:384-385, comparing Gk. στυφελίζω suggesting a root-variant *(s)teubʰ- (after {ref IEW} 1034; not in {ref LIV²}). According to {ref Beekes 2010}:1418-1419, however, Gk. στυφελίζω has no secure connections outside of Greek.

notes: probably loans from New Persian (Tajik: garon)

justificationDiscussion: Derivatives from PIE 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' ({ref Derksen 2008}:234, {ref ESSJa} 11:44-45, cf. {ref LIV²} 556-7), PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (to pieces)' ({cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560) is often considered to be a dental-enlarged form of this root.

notes: cf. atirassa (adj.) (ati + rassa) 'too short' (opp. atidīgha) Vin iv.7; J vi.457; VvA 103
cf. cakkavāḷaŋ atisambādhaŋ Brahmaloko atinīcako 'the World is too narrow and Heaven too low' DhA i.310; iii.310 = VvA 68
justificationDiscussion: Cf. Sanskrit sambādha- 'contracted, narrow' ({ref Pali Text Society 1921–1925}:693), further to Vedic √bādh- 'to press, force', probably further to PIE *bʰeh₁dʰ- 'to press, oppress' ({ref LIV²} 68, however more sceptically {ref EWAia} II:222).
Loanword from French respirer ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Parallel loans from Latin or Old French in West Germanic and North Germanic.
Loan from Albanian shkrumb 'black ashes, anything burned to ashes' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:423-424).
loan_notes: Possibly borrowed into Albanian from the Latin root 'crem' (burn) with prefix 'ex-'. with vowel change in Albanian.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Sanskrit bī́ja- 'seed'.

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit śuṇḍā- 'elephant's trunk' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:725, no. 12516). Further etymology uncertain; probably a loanword from a non-Indo-European source (cf. {ref KEWA} III:354 for discussion of various proposals).

notes: Parallel loans from Old Indic

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi ḍag′ara.
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi büm 'earth'.
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi gulʹava

notes: Source unclear

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Kâta-vari.
Parallel loans from Saṇu-viri: Wâmâ ẓ′oːk
Loan from Middle High German wamp ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005}:279, {ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}, {ref Rejzek 2001}:587, cf. {ref Vasmer 1986-1987} 3:696).
Loanword from Middle High German spilen ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}).
Loanword from Italian cantare ({ref Snoj 1997-2016}).

The etymology and further cognacy is uncertain. For the discussion on the nativity of PS *melko 'milk' and its relationship to PIE *h₂melg̑- 'to milk' see {ref ESSJa}: 18: 87-88 (the authors claim that PS *melko 'milk' is not derived from / related to PIE *h₂melg̑- 'to milk').

Baltic and Nuristani lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ep- 'water, river' ({ref NIL} 311-317, {ref EWAia} I:81-82, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:19, {ref Strand 2011a}, no. 407, {ref ALEW} 1155-1156, {ref Derksen 2015}:483). Perhaps root-cognate with of Anatolian and Celtic lexemes meaning 'river', if the Celtic lexemes are to be analysed as from ?*h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. {ref NIL} 311-317 and further discussion in /cognate/1735/).
First attested in Middle English, further origins obscure, cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)} for further discussion.

notes: v. T. 8377.7 *puṇḍa- ‘lump’
Perhaps connected with PIE *dek̑s-.

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Kâta-vari pařʹas 'dust'

notes: Cf. {ref: Turner 1962-1966}: 38

loan_notes: Possibly from OIA pīvan- 'well-nourished', via some other language, due to retained p-.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Middle Indic bána- 'forest' (< Vedic vána- 'forest') (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:657 no. 11258).
Loan from Kâta-vati kk′ař.
Loanword from Kâta-vari.

Etymology outside of Brythonic uncertain. Traditionally connected to a PIE root 2. *lem- ({ref IEW} 675), but not in {ref LIV²} or {ref Schumacher 2004}. For probable cognates in Breton cf. {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Deshayes 2003}:459 (without comparing Welsh lexemes).
Generally considered a loan from Latin penna 'feather, wing, pinion' ({ref Orel 1998}:315, {ref Holm 2011}:62), but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:62 who attempts alternative etymologies.
Loan from Romanian.

Root etymology in this class follows the proposal of {ref Jokl 1911}:61-62 to an inner-Albanian connection with dhjes 'shit (on), ruin' to PIE *g̑ʰed- ({ref IEW 423; tentatively followed by {ref LIV²} 172, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:290-291); cf. alternatively {ref Orel 1998}:287 following {ref Meyer 1891}:301 assumes a connection to Albanian ndyj 'to make dirty, soil, to dip, immerse' connecting to Gk. δύω 'to sink, cause to sink, to plunge in' < *du̯eH- (cf. {ref LIV²} 129-130, without Albanian).

notes: variant of root *dʰreh₂gʰ-

justificationDiscussion: Root etymology follows {ref LIV²} 274, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:975-976, tentatively also {ref Huld 1984}:72. However, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:140-141 who proposes to PIE *h₁ed- 'eat', and {ref Holm 2011}:59-60 who rejects all previously proposed etymologies.
Root etymology disputed, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:388, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:994-995 for various proposals.
Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Persian برف / barf 'snow' (cf. /cognate/126/).

From Latin astrātum 'starred' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:59), a derivative of Latin aster 'star' < PIE *h₂ster- 'star', cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:585, {ref NIL} 348-354, and 'star' in /cognate/131/ for further etymological discussion.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:297 no. 5385.
Loan from French pousser 'to push'.
Loan from English
No certain etymology ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Loan from English round.

Probably from Proto-Celtic *grau̯ā (cf. Old Irish griän 'gravel', Welsh gro 'gravel, shingle'), postulated for Gaulish on the basis of loanwords attested in Romance ({ref Delamarre 2003}:183-184, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:328 no. 3851). Further etymology uncertain: {ref IEW} 460 suggests a root etymology *gʰreu- 'to crush, grind', {ref Campanile 1974}:131-138 argues for a pre-IE loanword.

notes: Cheung (2007: 368) assumes a root su(m)p/b "to make up, beautify" together with the prefix ni- "down"
PIE form tentatively suggested by Cheung (2007: 361)
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic ?*staHn- 'to take', which {ref Cheung 2007}:361 tentatively suggests may be a derived n-stem to Proto-Iranic *staH- < PIE *steh₂- 'to stand, place'.

notes: cf. Henning "Sogdica" (1940: 51): "Here, ʾʾywz is clearly "pond, fish-pond", or "lake" ("river", as the obvious etymology might suggest, is perhaps less likely)." Could this word be related to Sogdian ʾwzy "lake"? The Parthian reading may then be 'āywaz' or similar.

justificationDiscussion: Loan from English 'fight'.
Loanword from French foie 'liver' (not in {ref Deshayes 2003}).

notes: with prefix apa-

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from English sharp.
Loanword from Turkish sarı 'yellow' ({ref Meyer 1891}:379).
Brythonic lexemes continuing derivatives of a Proto-Celtic lexical root *su̯ek- (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:163, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).

Although the "Celtic" etymology of OBr. staer figures in the etymological dictionaries, there was never a real discussion of this isolated word, which shares with the Latin and Greek words only the root, not the suffix(es). Bernier, on the other hand, convincingly points out the extensive parallelism in the semantics of staer, ster and estoir, estier and of their use in onomastics.
It seems possible, that Old Breton, being exposes to intense linguistic contace, had several words for river. These were regional varieties or linked to different speaker groups respectively.
Loan from English river
Not in {ref Deshayes 2003}, but an obvious recent loan from French poitrine (< Late Latin *pectorīnus 'belonging to the breast', a derivative of Latin pectus, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:521).

Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ({ref Deshayes 2003}:361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in {ref Matasović 2009}; no etymology given in {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref Henry 1900}:50-51 for various older proposals.
Loan from Latin sonus 'a noise, sound' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:677).
Indic lexemes going back to phaṇati 'swells, rises, boils', presumably contaminated with phūṭ- 'blowing, puffing'. Details are unclear and both roots are probably onomatopoetic in origin.
Loan from English cloud.
Loanword from Dutch vlees 'meat'.
From Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'run', further to PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to float, eddy' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:413-414, {ref Seebold 1970}:375-377, {ref LIV²} 305-306).
Cognate with /cognate/8503/ via semantics 'cloud of (dust)'?
Continuing Latin lignum 'wood' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:408 no. 5034). Further root etymology disputed, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:340-341 for further discussion.

notes: Derivative of Lat. venter?
< Lat. bēstia 'wild animal'???

justificationDiscussion: Cf. Cornish colon 'heart'. Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ({ref Deshayes 2003}:361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in {ref Matasović 2009}; no etymology given in {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, cf. {ref Henry 1900}:50-51 for various older proposals.
Romance lexemes from Lat. fuscus 'dark-coloured, dusky' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:308), further derived from PIE *dʰeu̯s- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:263-264, {ref de Vaan 2008}:252).

notes: Via Lat. restāre?
Cf. Meyer-Lübke 1935 9355 viria 'Armband'?

justificationDiscussion: Continuing Latin hospitalis, -e 'hospitable' in a nominalised sense of 'accommodation; house' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:493-498). Latin hospitalis is further a derived adjective from Latin hospes, itis 'guest, visitor; host, entertainer', probably an old compound containing the roots of hostis 'foreigner; enemy' < PIE *gʰosti- and potis, -e 'having power' < PIE *poti- 'master, in control of' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:291, {ref Untermann 2000}:336, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:300-301).

Continuing a Latin verb bāiulāre 'to carry' with a later semantic evolution 'to bring (over)' > 'to give' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 1:206, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:71 no. 887). Latin bāiulāre is further a denominal verb to Lat. bāiulus 'porter', of obscure etymology ({ref de Vaan 2008}:68, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:64).

From Latin tostum, cf. It. tosto ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:731 no. 8814), originally the past passive participle of Latin torreō, -ere 'to scorch, roast' from PIE *ters- 'become dry' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:624-625, cf. {ref LIV²} 637-638).

As though from Latin iūstus 'lawful, just', a derived adjective from Latin iūs 'law'. Further etymology disputed (cf. {ref NIL} 283n17, {ref de Vaan 2008}:316-317 for various proposals and further discussion).
Loanword from Italian destra 'right'.

Romance lexemes continuing a secondary derivative from Latin vāstāre 'to make desolate, lay waste', itself a derivative verb from Lat. vāstus 'empty, desolate', as though continuing PIE *h₁u̯eh₂-sto- ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:765 no. 9168, {ref de Vaan 2008}:655-656, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:714-715, cf. {ref LIV²} 254).

As though from Latin *plantāre, a verbal derivative from Latin planta 'sole of the foot' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:546), further to PIE *pleh₂- 'be flat, even' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:470, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:512, {ref NIL} 562-564).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/4527/, 'mountain' in /cognate/2804/, 'hand' in /cognate/1712/, 'thin' in /cognate/1923/, 'wide' in /cognate/5264/, 'smooth' in /cognate/6801/, 'earth' in /cognate/5892/, 'tree' in /cognate/8103/.

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin fūstis 'stick, rod' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:308-309), no certain etymology outside of Italic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:264; cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:253 for discussion of some recent proposals).
Denominal verbs from Latin sāpō 'soap' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:628). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loanword from either Celtic or Germanic ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:596).
loan_notes: A loanword of uncertain origin, cf. Breton sebon, German Seife.

justificationDiscussion: Cf. Latin ex-cutere ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:263 no. 2998), further to PIE *(s)ku̯eh₁t- 'to shake thoroughly, to startle' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:504-505, {ref LIV²} 563-564, cf. also {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:552-553).
Continuing Latin aqua 'water' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:46 no. 570), cf. 'water' in /cognate/953/ and 'river' in /cognate/2649/ for further etymological discussion.
From Latin grossus 'fat, thick' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:330-331), further etymology unclear (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:273), formerly connected by {ref IEW} 485 with Celtic *brasso- in /cognate/4355/.

Continuing Latin colligere 'to gather, collect; read' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:194 no. 2048), in origin a compound con-legere, further to PIE *leg̑- 'to gather, pick up' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:332-333, {ref LIV²} 397).

Possibly related to TochB oko in /cognate/2653/, and Balto-Slavic and Celtic words in meanings variously 'fruit (of a tree), berry, acorn', but the exact etymological connection is uncertain because of problems in formal reconstruction. Cf. further discussion in {ref Kroonen 2013}:18-19, {ref ALEW} 1151-1152, {ref Derksen 2008}:27, {ref Lehmann 1986}:25.

Etymology uncertain. No connection to Lithuanian lãbas, etc., as suggested by {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 is accepted by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW} (cf. /cognate/678/). {ref Clackson 1994}:181-182 likewise finds Hübschmann's proposed connection to Gk. λωΐων doubtful. Arm. law seems to be etymologically isolated.
No certain etymology ({ref Sims-Williams 2007}:259).
Etymology uncertain. Cf. {ref HAB} I:553, {ref Olsen 1999}:198, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:497 for various proposals. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ɡei̯r-a-].
As though from *ā-prus-a- 'bubble up' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:84 no. 1832), further to PIE *preu̯s- 'to spray, spatter' ({ref EWAia} II:192-193, {ref LIV²} 493).

Perhaps root cognate with Western IE words for 'tear' (Gk. δάκρυ, OHG zahar, Arm. artaswr, etc.), if both are based on earlier *h₂k̑ru- 'bitter' as a derivative from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'be/make sharp' ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:391, cf. {ref Kortlandt 1985a}:59-61 and further discussion in /cognate/5111/).

notes: Either to LIV² *ten- or 1. *tend- (exact root etymology unclear).

justificationDiscussion: A derivative of Latin campus 'field', cf. Italian campare 'to live' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:145-146 no. 1563). Traditionally further to an Indo-European root *kamp- 'bend, curve' in the sense 'broad, curved (valley)' > 'field' (cf. {ref IEW} 525, {ref LIV²} 342n1 'fraglich'). The necessity of reconstructing PIE *a (a root structure *kh₂mp- appearing unusual) has renewed the hypothesis that Latin campus is in fact a European substratum word from agricultural terminology ({ref de Vaan 2008}:86, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:632-633).
Loan from Germanic.
A derivative of Latin mola(m) 'millstone' (Giovanni Abete, p.c.), further to PIE *melh₂- 'grind' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:386-387, cf. {ref LIV²} 432-433).
Of uncertain etymology (Giovanni Abete, p.c.).

Neapolitan avutà as though from Latin *voltāre 'to turn' (Giovanni Abete, p.c., cf. Meyer-Lübke 1935}:789), an unattested intensive/iterative formation to Latin voluō 'to turn' and further to PIE 2. u̯el- 'to turn, roll' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:752, {ref de Vaan 2008}:689-690, {ref LIV²} 675).

From Latin planta 'plant' (Giovanni Abete, p.c., cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:546), further to PIE *pleh₂- 'be flat, even' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:470, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:512, {ref NIL} 562-564).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'hunt' in /cognate/4527/, 'mountain' in /cognate/2804/, 'hand' in /cognate/1712/, 'thin' in /cognate/1923/, 'wide' in /cognate/5264/, 'smooth' in /cognate/6801/, 'earth' in /cognate/5892/, 'stand' in /cognate/8055/.

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes as though from Latin *mattea 'club' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:445 no. 5425), further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:366-367 for various proposals.
Apparently continuing a late Latin verb *pīliāre 'to take' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:537 no. 6503).
Of onomatopeic origin, first attested as Middle High German snūfen, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:819 s.v. New High German schnauben 'to sniff, snort' for further discussion.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Pace {ref Kluge 2011}:215, the etymologies of proposed Greek and Italic cognates are themselves quite uncertain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1052, {ref Beekes 2010}:1400).
Cognacy in this class for the verb is coded for NHG -legen (cf. NHG überlegen 'to consider, reflect, think'); cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:939 for the history of the formation.

In works on Germanic etymology, the etymology outside of Germanic is generally considered uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:417-418, {ref Kluge 2011}:804, {ref Kroonen 2013}:445), but cf., however, {ref LIV²} 560 connecting with PIE *(s)keu̯d- '(vor)antreiben'.

Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. {ref EWAia} I:154 and {ref Kroonen 2013}:97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion. For Middle and Modern Indic forms from Vedic áhar, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:44, no. 993.
Generally considered a loanword from Romance *pluverem < Latin *pulverem 'dust' ({ref Meyer 1891}:346, {ref Demiraj 1997}:323-324; but cf. {ref Orel 1998}:331-332, 335 for an alternative proposal.
No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 831-833).

notes: For the onset cf. Persian *ai̯u̯a-ka- > yak.
justificationDiscussion: Adjectival derivatives from Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ({ref ESIJa} I:140-143). Further connections disputed, cf. further discussion in /cognate/5932/.
Parallel loans from Persian.

{ref Morgenstierne 1938}: 538 reconstructs *fra-sid- for this word (comparing Pashto sl-eǧ- 'break (intr.)' and Ormuri syōk 'break (a rope)' for the root). Paxalina (apud {ref: Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 302) prefers a reconstruction *fra-sat-.

notes: see 3414 for the discussion of etymology
justificationDiscussion: {ref Cheung 2007}:151 suggests a derivation of this family of words from Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar-da- to Proto-Iranic 5. *hu̯ar- 'to paint, colour, stain', and further to PIE 2. *su̯er- 'to ache, fester'?.
the Sogdian form is a compound "bird-born", since Mazanderani has been put here as well, the "bird"-component will be given as root reference form

notes: Loanword from Persian.
Bailey (1979: 412 "ṣṣai") relates the Sogdian word to Yaghnobi čukēr-. Not in Cheung (2007).

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Arabic شر / šar 'evil, iniquity' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:297).
Continuing Proto-Iranic *čak/g 'to strike, hit', probably of onomatopoeic origin ({ref Cheung 2007}:31-32).
Parallel loans from Persian ماهى / māhī 'fish'.
Assumed to be Persian loans.

notes: ultimately *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur-

justificationDiscussion: Derived verb within Kurdish from a noun ǰamad, ultimately borrowed from Arabic ǰamad ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:486).
Loan from Arabic فاكهة / fākiha 'fruit' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:352).
Iranic lexemes continuing PIE *(H)reh₁- 'to give, present' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:293, {ref Cheung 2007}:186-187, cf. {ref LIV²} 499).
Loan from Persian خوب / xūb 'good'.

notes: Cf. Ossetic Digoron äxsidzgä "pleasant", Khotanese kṣiṃj- "to desire, long for".
Parallel loans from Persian
loan from Persian, because old *t would appear as t.
original meaning "snake"
Borrowing from Arabic?
Not related to bāzu-forms, because *b would appear as β. Cheung (2007: 430) puts the Sogdian word to the verbal root *waz- "to carry, drive".

justificationDiscussion: From Proto-Iranic *paiš 'to crush, grind', further connected to PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat' ({ref Cheung 2007}:292-293, {ref EWAia} II:169, {ref LIV²} 466-467).
Modern Iranic lexemes, possibly to be connected with Sanskrit karká- 'white' according to {ref KEWA} I:171 but etymology ultimately uncertain ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:222).
No certain etymological connection outside of Iranic. Mayrhofer (q.v.) asserts cognacy with Vedic kṣod-.
From Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh' + preverb *pati-; further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:141-143).

notes: Loan from Arabic via Persian.

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall; recount', further to PIE *(s)mer- 'to think about, remember' ({ref Cheung 2007}:137-138, {ref EWAia} II:78-79, {ref LIV²} 569-570).

notes: unclear why Cheung suggests k instead of k̑ despite his reference to LIV; ki̯ > čy and k̑i̯ > ϑy/sy would both result in Sogdian š

justificationDiscussion: Derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *i̯at- 'to take up a position', arguably further to a PIE root *i̯et- ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:432, {ref Cheung 2007}:214-215, {ref LIV²} 314-315, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:394-395 skeptical of connections outside of Indo-Iranic).
Parallel loans from Persian برگ / barg 'leaf'.
Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ni-pad- and further derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, to sink' ({ref Cheung 2007}:287-288, cf. {ref EWAia} II:76-77, {ref LIV²}:458).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'foot' in /cognate/225/, 'leg' in /cognate/2783/, 'stand' in /cognate/6813/, 'fall' in /cognate/1126/, 'sleep' in /cognate/9252/.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Persian بلند / buland 'long'.
Parallel loans from Sanskrit párvata- 'mountain'.
Etymology unclear, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1938}:543, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:349 for various uncertain suggestions.

Goidelic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *rēdi- 'simple, easy', further derived from PIE *(H)rei̯dʰ- 'to shake, wobble' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:16-17, {ref Matasović 2009}:306-307, cf. {ref LIV²} 502).

notes: Morgenstierne (1974: 72) only notes suγδ for Sarikoli, which could be a dialectal variant of sleʁ with metathesis and δ/l alternation.
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing *sāta(ka)- 'cut, smoothed, even', a p.p.p. to Proto-Iranic *saH- 'to whet, cut' and further to PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:424, {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:72, {ref Sims-Williams 2007}:262, {ref Cheung 2007}:325-326, {ref LIV²} 319-320).

The cognacy of the Hellenic, Germanic, Italic, Celtic, and Albanian lexemes in this set is generally agreed, but the precise root reconstruction is disputed, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1271, 1285, {ref Vine 1999}:5-30, {ref Demiraj 1997}:350-351, {ref Orel 1998}:384, {ref Holm 2011}:76, {ref Kroonen 2013}:601, {ref de Vaan 2008}:512, {ref Matasović 2009}:430).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:975, {ref Beekes 2010}:1287-1288; cf. {ref IEW} 1159 for unconvincing older proposals to Germanic lexemes via OHG rīban, etc.).

Generally compared to Lat. torqueō from a causative-iterative stem *torkʷ-éi̯e/o- 'twist' ({ref Aura Jorro 1993}:366-367); whether this is to be identical with Ancient Greek τρέπω, τροπέω (cf. /cognate/5106/) is less certain (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1132-1133, {ref Beekes 2010}:1503-1504).

notes: Considered by older etymological authorities to be cognate with Arm. očʻ 'not', but more recently called into question (cf. Clackson 1994:158, Martirosyan 2010:531). Cf. citations in cognate class for references to further literature.

justificationDiscussion: IE root etymology disputed. The Italic and Romance lexemes in this class might be connected with the lexemes from Proto-Germanic *dragan- in /cognate/2839/ via PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- but this would require the assumption of an irregular dissimilation of aspirates and devoicing in initial position. Alternatively some Celtic cognates are formally possible (cf. Old Irish tethraig* 'ran away, receded'), but note that the required reconstruction *tre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- violates Indo-European root structure constraints. Cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:626-627 and {ref LIV²} 154 for further discussion.

Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ({ref Derksen 2008}:238, {ref ESSJa} 11:133-135; cf. {ref LIV²} 357). Perhaps also connected to Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:220 and further discussion in /cognate/9647/).

Connected by {ref Matasović 2009}:427-428 to Slavic and Germanic words for 'wood' (cf. /cognate/3130/) following {ref IEW} 1138-9, but since this explanation this on postulating different root-extensions to a base root *u̯el-, *u̯elə- in {ref IEW} this remains somewhat tenuous.

Generally considered to be cognate with the Balto-Slavic word for 'head' (cf. Lith. galvà, etc.). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:43, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:220). Cf. further discussion regarding the Balto-Slavic lexemes in /cognate/1142/. Classes indexed at proposed-cognacy level 5/6: large majority view.
Romance lexemes from Latin sentīre 'to sense, feel' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:645-646), further to PIE *sent- ({ref de Vaan 2008}:554, {ref LIV²} 533).

The IE root etymology for this class is disputed. It seems equally plausible that the Italic forms from Lat. folium can go with either the Germanic and Greek words for 'leaf' from *bʰleh₃- in /cognate/252/, or with the Celtic words for 'leaf' from *dʰal(h₁)- in /cognate/1025/; cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:244; {ref de Vaan 2008}:230. For the Romance lexemes in this class cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:293-294.

The cognacy of these Germanic lexemes are difficult to assign. A majority view of scholars assign them with derivatives of one of the PIE *men- roots in /cognate/76/, alternatively a minority view of scholars places it with other Germanic, Italic, and Celtic words for 'human' < *dʰg̑ʰ-mon- *'earthling' /cognate/907/. The cognacy decision for these lexemes has therefore been to split these lexemes from the majority set into their own separate set, which has been appropriately indexed to the other existing sets. Cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:353-354, {ref Orel 2003}:260, {ref Lehmann 1986}:244.

The cognacy of these Germanic lexemes are difficult to assign. Cf. the cognacy decisions made for the same lexemes in the meaning set 'man': A majority view of scholars assign them with derivatives of one of the PIE *men- roots in /cognate/76/, alternatively a minority view of scholars places it with other Germanic, Italic, and Celtic words for 'human' < *dʰg̑ʰ-mon- *'earthling' /cognate/907/. The cognacy decision for these lexemes has therefore been to split these lexemes from the majority set into their own separate set, which has been appropriately indexed to the other existing sets.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic skandhá- 'shoulder, upper part of back', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:786 no. 13627, {ref EWAia} II:750).

The IE root etymology of the Balto-Slavic forms in this class is disputed: the two main candidates are either to PIE *h₃eh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'mouth' ({ref NIL} 387-390) or to ?*h₃óu̯st-o- 'mouth, lip' ({ref NIL} 390-391, {ref Derksen 2008}:509, {ref Derksen 2015}:481-482). The root reference form for this class tentatively follows the Balto-Slavic reconstruction of {ref Derksen 2008} and {ref Derksen 2015}.

Italic (and Baltic, in late parallel derivations) lexemes in the meaning 'red' are derived from IE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 14:288-291, {ref de Vaan 2008}:665, {ref Derksen 2015}:567), cf. also /cognate/1163/. See 'worm' in /cognate/348/ for further etymological discussion.
Two possibilities for a root etymology: Either to *ser- ({ref LIV²} 534) or to *u̯er- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1095-1097, cf. {ref LIV²} 3. *u̯er- 'to observe, perceive', {ref IEW} 1164).

Traditionally connected to IE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' (cf. {ref Orel 1998}:425-426, {ref LIV²} 525), but this etymology is unclear on phonological grounds; cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:996, {ref LIV²} 525-526.

Generally derived to PIE *k̑eHs- 'to instruct, advise' ({ref LIV²} 318, {ref Holm 2011}:77, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1001, pace {ref Orel 1998}:480 who assumes a connection with PIE *k̑eNs- ({ref LIV²} 326, cf. /cognate/464/).

Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Romance lexemes from Latin sabulum 'sand' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:619). Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.
Loanword from Luvian ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:980).

Germanic and Celtic lexemes continuing a root *s⁽k̑⁾eh₃-, probably lexically distinct from PIE *s⁽k̑⁾eH- on the basis of both forms having reflexes in Greek (cf. Ancient Greek σκηνή (West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́) 'tent' < *'cloth to provide shade' < *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂-néh₂ ({ref Beekes 2010}:1350-1351 versus Ancient Greek is σκότος 'darkness, gloom' which must formally continue *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-to- ({ref Beekes 2010}:1359-1360). It is probably best to separate these as distinct roots, although they may well have been (sandhi?) variants of one another in PIE. For further discussion cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1350-1351, {ref Kroonen 2013}:438, {ref Matasović 2009}:340).

{ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:151 assumes a connection to PIE *drep-, this etymology and other proposed connections outside of Iranic remains uncertain (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:78-79 for further discussion).

notes: Not sure whether the Middle Breton is actually supposed to be here.
justificationDiscussion: Celtic lexemes possibly to be connected with Latin scribō, -ere, although some points of phonological comparison make the identification formally difficult ({ref Matasović 2009}:344, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:55).

Of uncertain etymology ({ref Olsen 1999}:963, cf. {ref HAB} II:556-557), but cf. {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010} considering a possible Iranian loanword, following the suggestion of {ref Bailey 1979}:65. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ 'short', further derived from PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ({ref Derksen 2008}:236, {ref ESSJa} 11:99-104, cf. {ref LIV²} 559-560).

Often assumed to be a loanword from an unattested Lat. adj. excurtus (similarly cf. OHG kurz, kurt, etc. < non-prefixed Lat. curtus in /cognate/292/), alternatively inherited from Proto-Germanic *skurta- to Proto-Germanic *skertan- 'cut off' and perhaps further to be connected to PIE *skerd⁽ʰ⁾- and comparable to Lith. skérdėti, OIr. sceirtid (cf. {ref LIV²} 558 s.v. ?*skerdʰ- 'schneiden, stechen' (?), {ref Orel 2003}:346, {ref Kroonen 2013}:444.

Tocharian and Slavic lexemes from PIE *k̑leu̯s- 'to hear, to listen to' ({ref LIV²} 336, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:250-251, {ref Derksen 2008}:455-456). The root is probably a secondary verbal root abstracted from a desiderative formation from *k̑leu̯- 'hear' already in the protolanguage (cf. {ref LIV²} 336).
Lexemes continuing Latin cortāre 'to shorten' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:224 no. 2418, {ref DCECH} 2:216), further root etymology disputed (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:158 for further discussion).

Albanian lexemes generally connected with Germanic *tīdi- 'time', derived from PIE *deh₂(i̯)- 'to divide, split into parts' (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:51-52, {ref Orel 1998}:516 with references to further literature; {ref Orel 2003}:407, {ref Kroonen 2013}:516); for verbal derivatives to the same root, cf. {ref LIV²} 103-104.

Etymology here follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1000 and {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, but be aware some scholars {ref Orel 1998}:471, {ref Holm 2011}:58-59, following {ref Meyer 1891}:88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ({ref LIV²} 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in /cognate/7551/ (cf. the skepticism of {ref Demiraj 1997}:392).
