alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'burn' in /cognate/1461/, 'day' in /cognate/2234/, 'hard' in /cognate/8428/, 'sun' in /cognate/5455/, 'fog' in /cognate/6235/.

notes: Nursery word.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain. Three main possibilities: Either (1) connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so {ref Orel 1998}:269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- /cognate/42/), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so {ref Demiraj 1997}:271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by {ref Meyer 1891}:283-284, cf. /cognate/2150/). Either of these sources could also have been contaminated with one another (cf. the discussion of {ref Huld 1984}:93). Ultimately unclear.

Possibly to be connected with Anatolian, Baltic, Germanic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰerh₁- ({ref Meyer 1891}:486, {ref Jokl 1937}:139ff., {ref Orel 1998}:525-526), but details are not fully clear, cf. the discussion in {ref Demiraj 1997}:430-431.

IE root etymology uncertain. According to {ref Orel 1998}:145) to PIE *selk- (tentatively cf. {ref LIV²} 530-531); according to {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974-976) a straightforward derivation from PIE *selk- is impossible and may represent a contamination of *selk- (cf. /cognate/451/) and *h₂u̯elk- (cf. /cognate/5274/); alternatively Schumacher & Matzinger suggest possibly *sk̑ek- with contamination of -l- in the Old Tosk form of the root (see now {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
A loan from Old French jalne ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 4:26).
Etymology outside of Tocharian unclear, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:176 for a survey of various proposals.

IE root etymology disputed. Two main possibilities: Either to (1) PIE *h₂enh₁- ({ref LIV²} 297-298, so {ref Huld 1984}:63, {ref Orel 1998}:91, and others), or (2) to PIE *h₂ei̯d- ({ref LIV²} 258-259, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:256-257, {ref Demiraj 1997}:171-172).
Armenian lexemes continuing PIE *h₂r-nu-, derived to PIE *h₂er- 'to take, acquire' ({ref LIV²} 270-271, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:112-113).

Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:131).

Etymology uncertain. Attempts to relate to PIE *h₂ek̑-mōn in /cognate/7058/ are made with great difficulty (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:183-184, {ref Boutkan 1998}:113-115, {ref NIL} s.v. *h₂ek̑-), although this connection is still frequently assumed in secondary literature (cf. {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}).

notes: Considered by older etymological authorities to be cognate with Gk. οὐ(κ) 'not', but more recently called into question (cf. Clackson 1994:158, Martirosyan 2010:531). Cf. citations in cognate class for references to further literature.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:517-518, {ref Kroonen 2013}:456}). A connection has been proposed with Lat. malus 'bad', OCS malъ 'small', and Gk. μῆλον 'small cattle, sheep, goat' since {ref Solmsen 1904}:17-18, but the semantics and morphological structure are unclear.

For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form, we tentatively follow {ref Cheung 2007}:15-16 in distinguishing two separate Proto-Iranian roots, although the semantic shift *'to perceive, notice' > 'smell' is not entirely inconceivable and the lexemes could very well belong to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- ({ref LIV²} 83-84, {ref IEW} 150-2).

Lexemes continuing a derivative of Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'air', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Lehmann 1986}:237, {ref EWA 5}:1488-1491, {ref Kluge 2011}:586, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:328, 342).
Loanword from New Testament Greek θυμίαμα 'incense; incense offering' ({ref Lehmann 1986}:370).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Traditionally considered a labial-extension to the root *dʰu̯eh₂- 'make smoke' ({ref IEW} 247-248, {ref Orel 2003}:68, {ref Kluge 2011}:180; cf. {ref LIV²} 158). Alternatively {ref Kroonen 2013}:88 sets up a derived noun to PGmc. *dimpan ~ *dempan- 'to fog' < *dʰembʰ- (cf. MHG dimpfen 'to smoke, steam' Elfdalian dimba 'to smoke', Nw. demba 'to smoke'; but cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:180 who considers the MHG form a backformation to MHG dampf, not in {ref LIV²}.).

Possibly related to Germanic /cognate/647/ and Armenian /cognate/8305/ lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. {ref ALEW} 947 (Baltic material), {ref Beekes 2010}:1371 (Greek material), {ref Seebold 1970}:440-441, {ref Kroonen 2013}:458-459 (Germanic material), {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:69-70, {ref Matasović 2009}:281 (Celtic material), {ref Martirosyan 2010}:484 (Armenian material).

Possibly related Germanic /cognate/647/ and Celtic /cognate/8304/ lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. {ref ALEW} 947 (Baltic material), {ref Beekes 2010}:1371 (Greek material), {ref Seebold 1970}:440-441, {ref Kroonen 2013}:458-459 (Germanic material), {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:69-70, {ref Matasović 2009}:281 (Celtic material), {ref Martirosyan 2010}:484 (Armenian material).
Loanword from early Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic rót 'root' ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Parallel loans from Turkish toz 'dust'.

notes: the Arabic noun is used as a verbal stem in some languages

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Arabic حلو / ḥulw 'sweet, nice' (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:461).
Probably continuing a derivative of the Proto-Iranic root *paiš- 'to crush, grind', and further to PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat', although cf. the reservations of {ref Cheung 2007}:292.

Often considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ({ref LIV²} 488), however the *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. {ref ALEW} 789-790, {ref Derksen 2015}:363, {ref EWA 3}:385-388).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fly_N' in /cognate/5414/, 'wing' in /cognate/343/, 'bird' in /cognate/186/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/224/, 'hair' in /cognate/1902/, 'feather' in /cognate/2263/.

justificationDiscussion: The phonology of the form points to the etymology as a derived verb from a West Greek dialectal borrowing into Medieval Greek (cf. {ref Andriotis 1999}:1438), cf. Tsakonian φούκ̔α 'belly' in /cognate/5921/.
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'to prick, be pointed' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:330 no. 5806, {ref Bailey 1979}:129, {ref EWAia} I:668-669; cf. {ref LIV²} 592-593).

Goidelic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach' ({ref LIV² 282-284, cf. {ref Pedersen 1913}:557, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:151, {ref Schumacher 2004}:200-204, {ref Matasović 2009}:36-37).
Goidelic lexemes continuing PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'to rise, stride' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:57-60, {ref Matasović 2009}:376, {ref LIV²} 593-594).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:450, {ref Kroonen 2013}:415 for various proposals.

Iberian Romance lexemes, probably to be derived from Latin rāpum 'turnip' ({ref DCECH} IV:744). Further etymology uncertain, possibly an early non-Indo-European loanword (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:514, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:564, {ref ALEW} 875 for further discussion).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √har- 'to carry, bring' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:808 no. 13980). No certain etymology outside of Indic ({ref EWAia} II:803-804), {ref LIV²} mechanically ?2.*g̑ʰer- 'to take, get'.
Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ({ref LIV²} 175-176, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:213-216, {ref Kroonen 2013}:166-167).
Khwarazmian hwβ would appear to continue a present stem *hauba-, but there is no certain etymology (cf. {ref Samadi 1986}:92-93, {ref Cheung 2007}:299-301).
Of obscure origin, first attested in Middle English ME culle(n), kulle(n), kille(n), kylle, etc. ({ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}).
Root etymology uncertain, perhaps to Proto-Iranic *bauǰ- 'to release, free, open; save, deliver' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:18-19, {ref Samadi 1986}:43).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gaHz- 'to run, start', probably further to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- 'to enter (water), wade' ({ref Cheung 2007}:96, {ref LIV²} 183, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:111).
Usually explained as a blend of PIE *k̑erh₁- 'grow' with *sper- 'strew' (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:504, {ref Clackson 2017}:112).
Loanword from Calabrian Italian culírcia 'winged / reddish ant'.

notes: *(h₃)lig-o-
justificationDiscussion: Connected since {ref Meyer 1891}:245 to Greek ὀλίγος 'few, little', Lith. ligà 'illness', cf. {ref Huld 1984}:87, {ref Demiraj 1997}:243, {ref Orel 1998}:227.
Loan from Calabrian-Italian sco̧rza 'bark' ({ref Rohr 2000}:111-112).

Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic lexemes from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-) to PIE *steh₂- ({ref NIL} 639, cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:199, {ref EWAia} II:768-769, {ref ALEW} 979, {ref Derksen 2015}:430).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Italian lordo 'dirty, filthy'.
Loanword from Italian contare 'to count'.
Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'to swell' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:49, {ref Matasović 2009}:70, cf. {ref LIV²} 73-74).
Proto-Albanian loan (cf. Std. zgavër  'cavity, cave', also indicated by inflection) from Vulgar Latin *skavare (cf. Ital. scavare)
Identical to Standard Albanian trup 'body, trunk', a loanword from Slavic  *trupъ 'id.' (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:438-439, {ref Orel 1998}:467).

loan_notes: 'dusted, sprinkled with dust, dusty'; Latin form given for structural reasons, mre likely a late loan from an Italian dialect

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Italian volare 'to fly'.
Loanword from Italian, either directly from macinare 'to grind', or a denominal formation to a loan from macina 'mill, millstone, grinder'.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. {ref Adams 2013}:139-140 for various suggestions.
Light verb construction with Arbëresh kaça 'hunt' (n.) as the semantic head, a loanword from Italian caccia 'hunt'.
Loanword from Italian lago 'lake'.
Loanword from Italian destra 'right'.

Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *leh₃u̯-'to pour; to wash' ({ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} and {ref Melchert 2011}:127-132; cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:511-513, {ref Beekes 2010}:872-873, {ref Meyer 1891}:237, {ref Huld 1984}:85, {ref Demiraj 1997}:230-231, {ref Orel 1998}:210, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:980, {ref de Vaan 2008}:330-331).

Generally connected to Gk. κιχάνω < *gʰeh₁- ({ref LIV²} 196, {ref Kroonen 2013}174-175). Whether these forms are to be further connected on one hand to Arm. gam 'come' (so {ref LIV²}) or to Indo-Iranian lexemes (so {Kroonen 2013}) would decide whether to reconstruct initial *g̑ʰ or *gʰ.

Root etymology in this class follows {ref Schumacher 2004}:397-399 and {ref Matasović 2009}:200 to PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- ({ref LIV²} 555). Earlier literature assumed a connection to PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' and cognacy with Goth. gagg, OHG gang, etc. in /cognate/1334/, but this requires the assumption of an ad hoc initial voicing dissimilation (cf. {ref LIV²} 175-176, and earlier literature in {ref IEW} 439, {ref Pedersen 1909}:187, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:102-103)

Latin grāmen is very likely (but not absolutely certainly) cognate with Proto-Germanic *grasa- 'grass' in /cognate/230/; cf. note by Scarborough in citations for further discussion. For the appurtenance of Brazilian Portuguese grama to this class, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:327 no. 3835.
Loan from Calabrian Italian χatari 'to breathe'.
Loan from Persian cf. /cognate/1831/
Loans from Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit samudra- 'the sea, ocean' ({ref Adams 2013}:739).

notes: Sardinian forms formerly with Balto-Slavic lexemes in /cognate/1109/. ALEW doubts cognacy outside of Balto-Slavic. This needs to be double-checked. (-MJCS 19.10.2017).

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Calabrian ad(d)urare, -ari 'to smell' with apheresis, cf. Sandard Italian odorare < Lat. odōrāre.

Armenian, Albanian, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived to PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:286-287, {ref Meyer 1891}:413, {ref Huld 1984}:154, {ref Orel 1998}:315, 429, {ref de Vaan 2008}, {ref Schrijver 1991}:212, 495, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:516 no.6268, {ref DCECH} IV:342-343, {ref Matasović 2009}:126, 129).

Italic lexemes from Latin frīgere 'to be cold', a derivative of Latin frīgus 'cold, frost' (n.) < PIE *sriHg̑-e/os- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:254, {ref de Vaan 2008}:243, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:301 no. 3510; cf. {ref LIV²} 587)
Identical with Albanian madh 'big' < PIE *meg̑- in /cognate/360/.

Cf. Standard Albanian lesh 'wool; hair; fleece'; further etymology uncertain. A popular hypothesis considers a derivative to the same root as the Indo-European word for 'wool', *Hu̯l̥h₁neh₂-, if to be morphologically segmented *Hu̯l̥h₁-neh₂- via an alternative preform *Hu̯l̥h₁-so- (so {ref Demiraj 1997}:238-239, similarly {ref Huld 1984}:85-86). {ref Orel 1998}:219-220 considers a connection to the Balto-Slavic word for 'foliage'; against which cf. {ref Holm 2011}:65.

Etymology disputed. Either to PIE *k̑elH- (cf. 'cold' in /cognate/14/, 'freeze' in /cognate/1857/) or to PIE *g̑el- (cf. 'cold' in /cognate/196/, 'ice' in /cognate/6560/); cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:60.

Further etymology outside of Tocharian unclear. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:182-183, {ref Adams 2013}:236 attempt to connect Tocharian B krośce to the Greek forms, but this proposal is formally problematic (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:786).

Hellenic, Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deh₂u̯- ({ref Andriotis 1974}:200, {ref Beekes 2010}:298-299, {ref Cheung 2007}:67-68, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:111-112). The connection of Irish: Gaelic dóigh to this class assumes that it is cognate with OIr. dó- 'burn' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:111-112, {ref LIV²} 104-105). There remains the possibility that there may have been contamination in the Middle Irish period with OIr. daig 'flame, blaze' derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:8-9 s.v. daig, {ref Matasović 2009}:93).
Lexemes from Proto-Tocharian *m⁽’⁾æy-, further IE root etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:777-778 for further discussion.

Etymology uncertain. If {ref Kroonen 2013}:167 is correct, then the traditional etymology (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:165-166, {ref Lehmann 1986}:151) within Germanic to Proto-Germanic *gawēn- (and perhaps further to OCS gověti 'to revere and Latin faveō 'to be favorable' < *gʷʰou-eh₁-) is to be abandoned. {ref Kroonen 2013}:167 alternatively proposes cognacy to the Indo-Iranic root ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- (cf. {ref LIV²} 199), but this proposal has not yet met with widespread acceptance (not in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

For the provisional root ref. form, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:114-115, but this IE root reconstruction is uncertain; it is possible that we are dealing with a contamination of two separate roots (cf. {ref LIV²} 199, 358-359 s.v. ?*gʷʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen' and *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen').

Lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯j́ʰ- 'to hide', no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:502-503, {ref Cheung 2007}:117). {ref LIV²} 199 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen'.

{ref Rohlfs 1964}:288 considers the Italiot Greek words to be borrowings from Romance. Note, however, that AGk. λάκκος does exist, and might possibly be derived from *l̥ku̯o- (PIE *laku- or *loku-, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:827 s.v. λάκκος and further discussion in /cognate/8246/). It is difficult to exclude in principle the possibility of contamination or blending of inherited material with that of local Romance varieties. Similarly cf. Engl. lake in /cognate/5612/ which may well be a semantic calque from Romance.
Possibly of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:48).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around, roll' ({ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:351, {ref Georgiev et al. 1971-} I:181-182, 212-213, cf. {ref LIV²} 691-692).
Loan from Standard Italian fumata 'smoking, a smoke'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn', a root first attested in Middle Iranic without clear correspondences outside of Iranic. Possibly the same root as Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind' in /cognate/8719/ with a dental enlargement possibly under the influence of Proto-Iranic *u̯art- 'to turn', cf. YAv. varət- 'to turn' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:110-111).

Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂merd- 'to hurt, mistreat' ({ref LIV²} 280, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:414, {ref de Vaan 2008}:389, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:465 no. 5679, cf. {ref DCECH} III:143-145, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 6/3:126-129).

The basis of this Ossetic lexeme may go back to a root *men- (cf. {ref IEW} 728-729) if {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:122 and {ref EWAia} III:386 are correct in connecting the lexeme to the basis of Sanskrit manāk 'a little, slightly, in a small degree', but there are many unclear details of this etymology.

Hellenic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes traditionally reconciled to a basic root *lei̯- 'smooth', although the Celtic forms here may also require s-mobile (cf. ({ref IEW} 662-664, {ref Falileyev 2000}:103, {ref Matasović 2009}:346, {ref Beekes 2010}:844, {ref de Vaan 2008}:336-337). The Germanic forms derived from PIE *slei̯g̑- 'smear, make smooth' in /cognate/8680/ might be an extended form of this root. See further discussion in that cognate class.
Usually interpreted as based on PIE *pro- 'forward, to the front' with adverbial suffixes ({cf. {ref LIPP 2}:490, 643; {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:537-538, {ref de Vaan 2008}:491-492).

notes: could be derived from *fra-dmās- with fra- > ha-, assimilation fo dm > dn and subsequent loss of d

justificationDiscussion: Strand: from PIE stebʱ- 'post'; cf. OIA stambʱa-, T. 13682.

Rom. ud is from Lat. ūdus 'wet, moist' (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002} s.v. ud). The IE root etymology remains unclear. The traditional etymology of Lat. ūdus is to PIE *u̯egʷ- 'make damp (so {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:745-746, with references to earlier literature, tentatively also {ref de Vaan 2008}:648; cf. {ref LIV²} 662-663, {ref IEW} 1118), but {ref Weiss 1994}:141-143 makes a convincing case that a derivation to PIE *u̯eh₁- (cf. {ref NIL} 715-717 s.v. *u̯eh₁-r-. *uh₁-r- 'Wasser'; {ref IEW} 80f., {ref EIEC} 636) may also be a strong possibility. The prevailing majority opinion seems to judge the connection to *u̯egʷ- for Lat. ūdus to be more likely than *u̯eh₁- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:639-640 s.v. ūmeō and notes to /cognate/1578/), albeit still uncertain.

notes: 'kindle, burn'
justificationDiscussion: Secondary semantic shift from 'dry' > 'hard'. Etymology here follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1000 and {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, but be aware some scholars {ref Orel 1998}:471, {ref Holm 2011}:58-59, following {ref Meyer 1891}:88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ({ref LIV²} 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in /cognate/7551/ (cf. the skepticism of {ref Demiraj 1997}:392).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'burn' in /cognate/1461/, 'day' in /cognate/2234/, 'dry' in /cognate/8281/, 'sun' in /cognate/5455/, 'fog' in /cognate/6235/.

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:150-151 for discussion of various proposals. {ref Orel 1998}:79 wants a connection to PIE *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dru- on the basis of the dialectal variant drusk 'oak', but the priority of this form is uncertain and could well be a contamination with the word for 'tree' in /cognate/503/ (cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:151).
Loanword from Calabrian ficatu 'liver'.
Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:594 no. 10286, 10287, further to PIE *meld- 'to become soft' ({ref KEWA} II:675-677, {ref EWAia} II:386-387, cf. {ref LIV²} 431).
Etymology uncertain, either to be grouped with Vedic pāṁśu- 'crumbling soil, dust, sand' or púrīṣa- 'fullness(?)' ({ref Strand 1998}, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:452 no. 8019, 469 no. 8287).

A denominative verb formed to Danish skjul 'hide, cover', further to Old Norse skjól 'cover, shelter', probably to the same root as Danish sky 'cloud' ({ref Den Danske Ordbog}), but further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:495-496, {ref Orel 2003} 339, 347, {ref Kroonen 2013}:442, 452 for various hypotheses).
Denominal formations to Proto-Celtic *kowdo- 'hiding place' < PIE *k̑ou̯dʰo- ({ref Matasović 2009}:219, cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:442); for the root *keu̯dʰ- 'to hide' cf. {ref LIV²} 358-359.

Etymology disputed. Either to the Germanic word for 'hide, skin' in /cognate/820/ or to Celtic words for 'hide' from PIE *keu̯dʰ- in /cognate/8434/ (cf. {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}, {ref Orel 2003}:196). Not in {ref Kroonen 2013} or {ref Seebold 1970}.
Loan from Low German (cf. {ref Karulis 1992} II:258).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:511 no. 9092-9093). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps originally a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit √phal- 'to burst, split' with an irregular labial vowel -u- (cf. {ref KEWA} II:398).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhan- 'to speak' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:534 no. 9383), further IE root etymology disputed, cf. {ref EWAia} II:244, {ref LIV²} 69-70 for further discussion.

PIE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with North Germanic lexemes in the meaning 'dust; small bits' etc., which with Slavic cognates (cf. OCS měla 'lime', Ru. mel' 'sand-bank, shoal') one may reconstruct a common root *(s)melH-. This root might be identical with PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' with s-mobile (cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:414-415), or alternatively connected with Germanic words for 'small' ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:842-843, 846-847; but cf. discussion in /cognate/5112/, without Baltic lexemes connected).

Romance forms from Latin plōrāre 'to cry, weep' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:548-549, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 9:76-79, {ref DCECH} III:732-733), further etymology unclear (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:516, {ref de Vaan 2008}:473-474).
No generally accepted etymology, cf. {ref ALEW} 744-745, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:443 for further discussion.
Possibly derived from a putative PIE *stemH- 'to push', cf. {ref ALEW} 983-984, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:611 for further discussion.

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966
Not in Turner 1962–1966
Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: Continuing a derivative of Vedic cíti- 'layer', a derivative of the root √cay- 'to arrange in order, heap up, pile up' and ultimately to PIE 2. *kʷei̯- 'to collect, layer' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:260 no. 4798, {ref EWAia} I:541, I:532, cf. {ref LIV²} 378-379).
Continuing an Indic stem *ḍala- 'lump' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:311 no. 5536).
Continuing an adjective *pittaka- 'relating to bile', derived from Vedic pittá- 'bile' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:462 no. 8182). No further etymology ({ref EWAia} II:131).
Probably a loanword from Iranic, cf. Wakhi ṣ̌ʉw 'black' ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:669).

notes: Wiktionary gives (unreferenced) "From Early Assamese তেজ (tejo), from Sanskrit तेजोज (tejoja) or त्वग्ज (tvagja)."

justificationDiscussion: Same as 'fly_V' in /cognate/9512/?
From Vedic hŕ̥daya- 'heart' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:818 no. 14152), further to PIE *k̑erd- 'heart' ({ref EWAia} II:818, cf. {ref NIL} 417-423).
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Wakhi pʉz 'chest', Sarikoli puz 'id.', etc. ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:662).
Derived from Old Indic √oṣ- 'to burn' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:125), further to PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'to burn' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:281, {ref LIV²} 245).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1936}:666).

Continuing a derivative of Indic/Sanskrit √ḍhuk- 'to approach' with the semantic development 'to approach' > 'come to an end' > 'die' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:317 no. 5592). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loanword (cf. {ref KEWA} I:465).
Continuing a derivative in a large family of words grouped under {ref Turner 1962–1966}:641-642 no 11056 *litta- 'defective', with many variants.
More precise semantics uncertain, therefore etymology also uncertain (cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:125-126, {ref de Vaan 2008}:56 for further discussion).

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit kapā́la- 'cup, skull'. The Proto-Indic base *kap- is often considered to be cognate with Lat. caput, OEng. hēafod, etc., but there is some uncertainty over the etymology of the Modern Indic lexemes from Ved. kapā́la-, and of Ved. kapā́la- itself, cf. discussion in Mayrhofer {ref EWAia} I:300, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:137 no. 2744).

Traditionally Lithuanian burnà 'mouth' and Armenian beran 'mouth' have been connected etymologically (cf. {ref {Hübschmann 1897}:429, {ref Olsen 1999}:297, {ref ALEW} 152, {ref Derksen 2015}:106). Although this etymology is accepted, further morphological analysis and the isolation of an IE root remains unclear; further connections have been postulated to derive an n-stem noun from the same root underlying Lat. forō, -āre 'bore' OHG borōn 'bore', from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80), but these connections are not fully clear (cf. {ref ALEW}). However, if with {ref Derksen 2015}:106), who notes that if the Slovak perna 'lip' belongs with the Baltic forms, then the usually reconstruction to a root *bʰrH- is in doubt. As {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}, and {ref Olsen 1999} are in agreement about the cognacy, it has been accepted for this class, although the precise IE root etymology is in question. [NB: Arm. beran 'mouth' is not discussed in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.]

Continuing Latin brūma 'the shortest day of the year; mid-winter', a fossilised feminine form of the old superlative to PIE *mr̥g̑ʰ-ú- 'short' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:120 no. 1335, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:75-76, {ref de Vaan 2008}:75).
From Latin temperāre 'to temper' ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/1:168-177, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:713), further to PIE *temp- 'to span, stretch' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:611, cf. {ref LIV²} 626).

Cf. Lithuanian nókti 'to hunt, pursue; follow'. Etymology outside of Baltic disputed. According to {ref Kortlandt 1994} (followed by {ref Derksen 2015}:336) from PIE *h₂nek̑-, but this root etymology has not been met with widespread acceptance elsewhere (cf. {ref LIV²} 282-283; {ref ALEW} 708).
Etymology uncertain (cf. {ref ALEW} 1269 for further discussion). [Not in {ref Derksen 2015}. cf. also {ref Smoczyński 2007}:765].

notes: Only non-active forms in Alb. denote 'to swim'
justificationDiscussion: Albanian lexemes probably continuing PIE *leu̯h₃-e/o- with a present-stem n-suffix ({ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:980, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}; for the root reconstruction, cf. {ref Melchert 2011}). For older literature, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:237, {ref Huld 1984}:85, {ref Demiraj 1997}:230-231, {ref Orel 1998}:210.
Loanword from Italian grattare 'to scratch'.

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯es- 'to pant, breathe heavily'. In this class Pāli sasati continues the primary verb < Sanskrit śvasati 'breathe heavily' (cf. {ref EWAia} II:677, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:740 no. 12761), the modern Indic forms are light verb constructions with the nominal semantic-bearing morpheme deriving from Skt. śvāsá- 'breath' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:740, no. 12769). For Elfdalian, cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:266.

Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Often compared to Lith. mìlšti(s) and other Balto-Slavic forms with various degrees of confidence of the etymology (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:255, {ref Kroonen 2013}:403). {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:453 suggests possibly related ('eventuell'). No lemma for Lith. mìlšti(s) in {ref ALEW} or {ref Derksen 2015}.

notes: Parallel loans from Persian or Iranic

justificationDiscussion: Iranic loans from a cognate of Av. duma-. For the complicated argument see Turner ad rem. *d > l is regular in Vâsi-vari; Kâmviri and Kâta-vari (which have d-) continue a form other than duma-, giving us no reason to assume a loanword in Nuristani.

Perhaps continuing an original causative formation *dou̯h₂-éi̯e- to PIE *deu̯h₂- 'to join, fit together' but the details remain unclear (cf. {ref LIV²} 123, {ref Lehmann 1986}:342, {ref Kroonen 2013}:511). Cf. also Runic (Gallehus Horn) 1.sg.pret. tawido 'I made'.

Albanian and Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *trem- 'to tremble (in fear)'. The Romance lexemes apparently continue Latin tremere 'to tremble' contaminated with the Celtic root *krit-, cf. Old Irish crith 'trembling, shaking' ({ref LIV²} 648-649, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:388-389, {ref Orel 1998}:463, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:738 no. 8877, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 13/2:238-240, {ref de Vaan 2008}:628).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:207, {ref Lehmann 1986}:123, {ref Kroonen 2013}:152).

Baltic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *nem- 'to portion out'. Cognacy in this class follows {ref LIV²} s.v. 1. *nem-, {ref Lehmann 1986}:266-267), but {ref LIV²} 236 s.v. *h₁em-. It is possible that these two roots formed a rhyming pair in PIE (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:357-359); cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:387 for an attempt to reconcile the Germanic lexemes to *h₁em- by assuming a reanalysis of the compound verb *gan-eman- < *kom-h₁em-e- as containing the perfective prefix *ga-: *ga-neman-.

From Proto-Germanic *lūka- (with secondary lengthened grade), beside OHG liochan from Proto-Germanic *leu̯ke/a- based on PIE *leu̯g- 'lösen, brechen' (cf. {ref EWA 5} 1345-1347, {ref LIV²} 415-416. See {ref Seebold 1970}:337 for references to older literature.
Loanword from Calabrian Italian manca 'left-hand' (cf. also Greek: Italiot μανκούσο 'left' in /cognate/6082/).
Loanword from Calabrian mbuttare 'throw, push, introduce'

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed  {ref LIV²}. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated {ref Smoczyński 2007} and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek {ref Beekes 2010}.
Loanword from Latin saburra 'sand; ship's ballast' ({ref Meyer 1891}:420, {ref Orel 1998}:527).
Loanword from Calabrian Italian uχχare 'to blow up, swell'.

notes: Further connection unknown.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain. Three main possibilities: Either (1) connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so {ref Orel 1998}:269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- /cognate/42/), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so {ref Demiraj 1997}:271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by {ref Meyer 1891}:283-284, cf. /cognate/2150/). Either of these sources could also have been contaminated with one another (cf. the discussion of {ref Huld 1984}:93). Ultimately unclear.
Loanword from Italian foglietto 'slip, small piece of paper'.
Loanword from Latin sella 'seat, saddle' ({ref Orel 1998}:407).
Loanword from Latin sella 'seat, saddle' ({ref Orel 1998}:407).

Light verb construction with set coded for Albanian udhë 'way, road; journey'. Since {ref Meyer 1891}:445 generally considered based on a zero-grade *ug̑ʰ- to PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'drive, go' (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:120-121, {ref Demiraj 1997}:400-401 for further discussion; {ref Orel 1998}:482-483 alternatively considers to *u̯edʰ- 'strike, beat'). Further related within Albanian to vjedh 'steal, rob', for which cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1008.

Generally considered a loanword from South Slavic, possibly via the Ikavian dialect of Serbo-Croatian ({ref Jokl 1923}:177, 187-188, {ref Orel 1998}:229, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:247), but cf. {ref Huld 1984}:87 who proposes an IE etymology. (Not in {ref Demiraj 1997}).
Loan from Italian liscio 'smooth'.

loan_notes: 'never' [more likely from a late South Italian descendant of nunquam]

justificationDiscussion: The connection of the forms in this class to those from PIE *pstḗn in /cognate/2217/ is disputed, and rest on assuming that it is root-cognate with a gloss στήνιον from Hesychius's Lexicon. The word-formation within Greek is, however, unclear ({ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:795, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:1054-1055, {ref Beekes 2010}:1403-1404, cf. {ref IEW} 990).
Etymology in this class follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974 to PIE *seh₂⁽g̑⁾-, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).

notes: Morgenstierne (2003: 64) *para-azna-
via meaning "sort, kind"
Original meaning is "claw", which develops to "hand" and "arm" / "wing".

justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:331 no. 5812 *tinta- > Assamese titā 'wet'. Possibly with Palula síndu in /cognate/9901/, see further discussion there.

Light verb constructions coded for the equivalent of Modern Persian راه / rāh 'way, path' continuing Proto-Iranic *raθyā- 'road, path', derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *rátHa- 'wagon, chariot' and ultimately a derivative of PIE *ret- 'to run' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:44, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:203, cf. {ref EWAia} II:429-430, {ref NIL} 575-580).
Light verb constructions using the equivalent of Modern Persian بالا bālā 'top' as its semantic head.

notes: Probably an experiencer construction: "one's heart comes up/beats" with "heart" for the inner part of the body or the inner condition.
w-prothesis is regular in Wakhi.
original meaning is "strike"; Kurdish entries should be rechecked
awz- < *fra-wiz- < u̯idʰ-so- (if this is correct, then *fra-vēž- < *u̯ei̯dʰ-so- in 8314 cannot be correct)

justificationDiscussion: Occasionally considered a loanword from Ancient Greek δάκρῡμα (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:336). Elsewhere, in spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. {ref Hamp 1972}). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:322, {ref Beekes 2010}:299-300) generally follow the proposal of {ref Kortlandt 1985a}, assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'.
Light verb construction, literally 'to make wind' with semantic head bād 'wind' a loanword from from Persian (cf. /cognate/3436/).
A loanword from Dardic languages ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:47, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:637, no. 10991 *laṣṭi- 'stick').
loan_notes: A loanword from neighbouring Dardic languages, cf. Turner 1962–1966:637 s.v. 10991  *laṣṭi- 'stick'

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain. Connected by {ref KEWA} I:292 to Vedic kṣupa- 'shrub, bush', via an Iranic proto-form *xšupaka-, alternatively a derivative of an onomatopoeic verbal root *(x)ši/ap- 'to beat' (cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:337).
Parallel loans from Persian صاف / sāf 'smooth', ultimately from Arabic.

Connected with further East Iranic words, but of no clear etymology. Possibly related to Vedic śrath- 'become loose' (ślath- also attested in later Sanskrit), in which case it might be an early loan. Note the different meaning given in {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 332.

notes: check for an PIE etymology
In Avestan attested by darz- "to attach, fasten".

Original meaning "to find". Cheung (2007: 413) sorts Balochi under *u̯ai(H)n-, but does not explain the origin of -d-. Cognacy coding follows Korn (2005). Note that some Iranic forms of cognate set 1969 may actually belong here.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Arabic نَفَر / nafar 'individual, person'.
Parallel loans from Arabic قديم / qadim 'old'.
Parallel loans from Arabic قرمز / qirmiz 'kermes insect; red', ultimately a loan itself from Iranic (cf. /cognate/1163/).

notes: = {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:155 bāšar 'thinking, understanding'? If so maybe a loan from Arabic bāšara?

Apparently a denominal verb to NPers. nušin 'sweet, pleasant' continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *an-auša- 'immortal'. *auša- further to PIIr. √auš- 'to burn' (cf. Ved. √oṣ-) and ultimately to PIE *h₁eu̯s- (need to get the references in order for this – MJCS)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯ab/f- 'to call, utter (sing, speak, etc.)', without clear etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:401, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:94).

Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *xand- 'to laugh' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:442-443). In view of the Nuristani cognates to this root (cf. 'laugh' in /cognate/68/) we reconstruct Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰand-.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *skauH- 'to poke, touch, earmark', further to PIE *skeu̯h₂- 'to poke, hit' ({ref Cheung 2007}:347-348, cf. {ref LIV²} 561).
Connected to Proto-Iranic *kart- 'to cut' by some scholars, however this is difficult to justify semantically (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:243-244 for discussion and references to further literature).
Possibly to be connected with Khw. ʾdr 'fire' < Proto-Iranic *ātar- 'fire' (cf. {ref Henning 1971}:38).

notes: Attested in Avestan as paiti.xʷaŋh- with the meaning "to thresh".
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing different preverbal derivatives of the Proto-Iranic root *hu̯ah- 'to strike; to become tired', further etymology outside of Iranic uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:141-143).

notes: TJ: probably identical to set K "*men", cf. Wakhi "mak"
justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, perhaps related to Avestan maγa- 'cavity' + -k? (cf. {MacKenzie 1990}:115).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref MacKenzie 1990}:108 for suggestions and references to further literature.
Etymologically obscure (cf. {ref Henning 1971}:29).

Root etymology disputed. Either to *h₁es- 'throw' ({ref LIV²} 2. *h₁es-; cf. {ref Kimball 1987}; {ref Kimball 1999}:215, 391; {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:670-671 with references to earlier literature), alternatively others (cf. {ref Melchert 1994}:133) see a connection with the Hittite verb šii̯e/a- 'to shoot' and šai- 'to press' (cf. {ref LIV²} 1. *seh₁(i̯)-). Cf. also {ref HED PE, PI, PU} 27-37, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, pp.581-584.

Formerly connected to Gk. ἔρχομαι 'go' via *r̥gʰ- (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:15-16, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:285), now a separate root *h₁erg̑ʰ- (cf. {ref LIV²} 238-239, {ref Schumacher 2004}:548-550).

Cf. Old Irish dul 'going', further etymology obscure. Since {ref Pedersen 1913}:648 usually compared with Albanian dal 'to go out' from PIE *dʰalh₁- 'to bloom' in the sense 'to appear, come out' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:220, {ref Schumacher 2004}:257-259, cf. {ref Orel 1998}:54, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:968-969). {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:138) seems to imply that dul should be connected to the finite verb do·luid where ·luid continues PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- (cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:456-458). For the initial g- instead of d-, possibly from an allegro-pronunciation of ag dul 'at going' > /əgol/, or influenced by gabháil, the verbal noun of gaibid (David Stifter, p.c.).
Probably an onomatopoeic formation, but cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:522 for some proposed cognates outside of Armenian.

From Proto-Germanic *slihta-, an adjective derived to the strong verb *sleikan- 'to creep, sneak' ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:512-513, {ref Seebold 1970}:428-429), traditionally considered to be an extended form of the root *(s)lei̯- ({ref IEW} 663-664; cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:428-429, {ref Lehmann 1986}:314), cf. {ref LIV²} 566-567 for the revised reconstruction of a separate root *(s)lei̯g̑- 'smear, make smooth'.

A diminutive formation to Welsh a-bwyd 'bait, lure' with secondary semantic development 'earthworm', lit. a- (prep.) + bwyd 'food' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}). For the etymology of bwyd 'food', cf. Welsh bwyta 'eat' from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live' in /cognate/2144/.
As though from Proto-Iranic *kāra- 'people, army' via an intermediary sense 'social group, family' > 'house', cf. Old Persian kāra- 'people, army' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:39).
Etymology unlikely to be with Iranic *nā̆xa- as Persian nāxun ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:56).
Etymology unlikely to be with Iranic *nā̆xa- as Persian nāxun ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:56).
Probably a loan from Persian xandīdan 'laugh' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:95).
Parallel loans from Turkish pis 'filthy, dirty'.

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *u̯i-u̯ai̯d-, further to PIE *u̯oi̯d- 'to know', to perfect stem of PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:174, {ref Cheung 2007}:408-409, cf. {ref LIV²} 665-667).
Loanword from Arabic ǰamad 'ice, ice floe' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:486).

Continuing Proto-Iranic *stūnā-, cf. Young Avestan stūnā-, Old Persian stūnā- 'pillar', and probably further connected with Vedic sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick' < *stuh₂-ró-, a derivative to PIE *steh₂- 'to stand' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:282, {ref EWAia} II:768). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'big' in /cognate/7106/.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'hand' in /cognate/8753/.

justificationDiscussion: Modern Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *mr̥j́u- 'vertebra' (cf. YAv. mərəzu- 'vertebra', Old Persian *mr̥du- implied by Middle Persian mrdʾ 'throat' and other reflexes among modern West Iranic languages), further etymology unclear ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:656-657, {ref Bartholomae 1904}:1173-1174).
Loanword from Arabic رمل / raml 'sand' (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:190).
From Proto-Brythonic *oepr ({ref Deshayes 2003}:543) or *ẹ̄pl-V- or *ẹ̄pr-V- ({ref Schrijver 1995}:221) (the latter is preferable, BI).
A secondary formation to Welsh synnwyr 'sense, wisdom, sensibleness', borrowed from Latin sentīre 'to perceive' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}.

Generally assumed to be a compound based on Old Irish rét 'thing' ({ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:290, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:22-23). Old Irish rét is occasionally compared to Sanskrit rátna- 'possession', but this etymology remains doubtful ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:22-23, {ref Matasović 2009}:309-310, cf. {ref EWAia} II:428-429 s.v. rátna-).
derivation *u̯i-u̯āha-ka (cf. Nyberg 1974: 217 on Middle Persian), cf. Avestan vah- "weilen; to stay" (Bartholomae 1904: 1394)
Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *mau̯č- (1) 'to release, let loose/free', further to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, take off' ({ref Cheung 2007}:269-270, cf. {ref EWAia} II:382, {ref LIV²} 443-444).
Identical to Khwarazmian 'long' in /cognate/3381/, further to PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'be(come) tall, raise oneself' (cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:299, {ref EWAia} II:232, cf. {ref LIV²} 78-79, {ref NIL} 30).

notes: In Avestan, gaona- is also attested with the meaning "hair", probably "body hair" or "hairy meat" (probably animal meat with hair on it), cf. the Nerangistan 47.4/9 and the forms gaonauuaṇt- "hairy" and pouru.gaona- "having much hair".
justificationDiscussion: Cf. Avestan gaona- 'hair' ({ref Benzing 1983}:299), further etymology uncertain.

notes: cf. Avestan gah- and Sanskrit ghas-.
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to gorge, devour', further from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas-, cf. Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, devour, gnaw'. The Khwarezmian lexeme would contain the preverb *apa- ({ref MacKenzie 1975}:392, {ref Samadi 1986}:17, {ref Cheung 2007}:93), while the Sogdian form probably continues a form with preverb *uz- as though *uz-gahaya- vel sim. (Nicholas Sims-Williams, p.c.). No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. {ref LIV²} 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.
{ref Samadi 1986}:247 suggests *xšiwya-, {ref Cheung 2007}:452 connects with Avestan xšī- 'misery' and suggests a root *xšai-.

notes: cf. Vedic vadhū́-

justificationDiscussion: As though continuing Proto-Iranic *fra-garH-, to Proto-Iranic *garH-³ 'to steep, soak, moisten', and further to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾elH- 'to drip, well' ({ref Cheung 2007}:108-109, cf. also discussion of Skt. √gal-ⁱ 'to drip, drop' in {ref EWAia} I:476-477).

notes: Cheung tentatively connects this PIE root with an assumed Proto-Iranic root *tāp-, which is problematic. The connection to Khwarazmian ustamb-, however, is probable.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology disputed. {ref Cheung 2007}:389 tentatively connects to Proto-Iranic *tāp- 'to twist, wind' (with prefix *us-), while {ref Samadi 1986}:186 suggests a Proto-Iranic preform *us-stamba- but not without its own difficulties.

notes: The Avestan verb vaxš- means "to sprinkle" (not found in Cheung 2007). MacKenzie (1970: 553) "The Khwarezmian Glossary I" (BSOAS 33): derives the noun from *waxšu-.
original meaning "to praise"
justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *fraiH- 'to rejoice? to atone, [med.] please', further from PIE *prei̯H- 'to please, be pleased, enjoy' ({ref Cheung 2007}:87-88, {ref LIV²} 490, cf. {ref Samadi 1986}:69).

notes: via verbal meaning "to fit", however Bailey's link to the PIE root is not very convincing
justificationDiscussion: {ref Bailey 1979}:504 suggests an etymology to a verbal root *hu̯ar- 'be fit' further to a putative PIE *su̯er- referencing {ref IEW} 1049 although the semantics are not obvious. Cf. Canevascini in {ref Emmerick & Skjærvø 1997}:176-179 for extensive further discussion objecting to Bailey's etymology and tentatively proposing a connection to the Proto-Iranic root *hu̯ar- 'to eat, drink' invoking the common right-hand = good euphemism found widely throughout the Indo-European language family, suggesting a semantic development along the lines of the right hand being the 'eating hand' or the one that is suitable for eating with. For Khwarazmian, cf. {ref Benzing 1983}:685.

notes: Verbal meaning in Avestan "to press together", PP ϑraxta-, this is taken by Benzing (1983: 100) as the input of Khwarazmian ˀšxt "near", which is formally possible.

justificationDiscussion: Derived from the verb γyr- 'to turn' and further to Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind', without clear correspondences outside of Iranic ({ref Samadi 1986}:84, {ref Cheung 2007}:104). Probably further related to Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn' in /cognate/8398/.

notes: pǝrǝtu- means "passage" in Avestan, etymology follows Humbach (CLI, 1989: 195), derived from the verbal root PIE *per- "to transfer, come, bring across" (Cheung 2007: 294)

Suggested by Cheung (2007: 244) *ham-kr̩nta- "to twist, braid together". Samadi (1986: 128) suggested a "Gegenbildung" to *wi-kana- "to destroy" (i.e. *ham-kana- "to repaire" ?) of the root *kan- "to dig".

justificationDiscussion: Continuing Indic *giḍḍ- 'to fall' with metathesis > *ḍigg- ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:222 no. 4157). Further etymology uncertain.
Meaning of čhār- [sic] given as 'be lost' by LSI from 1919, but Khowar c̣horik 'fall' could imply original polysemy of the root.
As though from Sanskrit *jañjāla- 'worry, affairs' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:280, no. 5085).
As though from Sanskrit dhūli-, Indic *dhūḍi- 'dust, powder' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:391 no. 6835), further etymology uncertain ({ref KEWA} II:110).
Loanword from Waigali yū̆z, yoz 'cold' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:601 no. 10396).

Lexemes continuing Indic √śaṭ- 'disintegrates, is ill' (Dhātup.), whose semantics were contaminated by Vedic √śad- 'to fall off, out', and which it eventually replaced; no further etymology (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:711 no. 12269, {ref KEWA} III:291, 294).
From Sanskrit rājana- 'belonging to a royal family', with a shift in semantics to 'good' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:618, no. 10680), further to PIE *h₃reg̑- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:444-445).

Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit bhagín- 'prosperous, happy' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:531, no. 9348), further derived from Vedic √bhag- 'to apportion' from PIE *bʰag- ({ref EWAia} II:239-240; cf. {ref LIV²} 65).

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit sthávira- 'broad, thick, strong' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:793), a variant of Vedic sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick' ({ref KEWA} III:530-531). Further to be derived from PIE *stuh₂-ró- (cf. {ref EWAia} II:768-769, {ref NIL} 637-659 regarding the IE stem derivation).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'stand' in /cognate/309/, 'big' in /cognate/7106/, 'fall' in /cognate/6648/, 'egg' in /cognate/1803/, 'house' in /cognate/7136/, 'leg' in /cognate/3539/, 'old' in /cognate/1158/, 'true' in /cognate/806/, 'tree' in /cognate/2359/, 'left' in /cognate/6568/, 'thick' in /cognate/8343/, 'neck' in /cognate/8692/.

justificationDiscussion: Morgenstierne 1940 suggests a Dravidian loanword proposed by Edwin H. Tuttle (1926. Journal of the American Oriental Society 46. 177-178), but Fussman 1972 (probably on Morgenstierne's behest) no longer lists this.

Indo-Aryan lexemes derived from *vidharga- 'without movement', cf. Turner 11751 Bashkarik bilɔg 'ill, sick', implying polysemy; cf. also Morgenstierne 1940: 227.
Cognacy with Prakrit vilakkha- 'ashamed' from vi-lakṣayati 'be embarrassed' < 'be observed' from lakṣáyati 'mark, distinguish' is unlikely as -kṣ- should result in Gawri -c̣h- and borrowing from a Prakrit is not very likely.

puṭ 'hidden, concealed' (Morgenstierne 1973) might continue Turner 8253 puṭa- 'cavity, small receptacle, fold' which, in turn, could be either cognate with the root Indo-Aryan paṭ- or non-Aryan *poṭṭa-.
Cf. Vedic dvā́ra- 'door' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:381 no. 6663), further from PIE *dʰu̯er- with an irregular dissimilation of the initial aspirate (cf. {ref EWAia} I:764-765).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. Persian چپ / čap).
Continuing a derivative of Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick, club' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:350 no 6128). No certain further etymology ({ref EWAia} I:692, {ref KEWA} II:11-12).

loan_notes: Morgenstierne 1973: laγat 'kick', cf. Persian lakad, Pashto laγata

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic takrá- 'buttermilk with a third part of water' (n.), *'bitter' (adj.) with further semantic developments 'sour' > 'rotten' > 'old' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:319, no. 5617), further to Vedic √tañc- 'to coagulate' from PIE *tenk- ({ref EWAia} I:611-612, 614-165).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. Persian کهنه / kohne).
Probably cognate with Maiyā̃ nāṭh 'a dance, a game' < nr̥ttá- (Zoller q.v.).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic síndhu- 'river; the Indus', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:774 no. 13415, {ref EWAia} II:729-730).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic nāḍī́- 'tubular stalk of any plant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:404-405, no. 7047). Further etymology difficult, cf. {ref KEWA} II:127-129 for various possibilities.
Morgenstierne 1940 has ɬak 'rotten (of food)'.

A loan from Persian is probable due to the specific semantics of 'rotten' (as against 'smelling (good or bad)' in Indic). Indic gandhaka- would presumably result in gandak, as retention of voiced aspirates is haphazard and restricted to the onset in North-Western Pashai. Morgenstierne 1973: 69, followed by Turner, assumes contamination of the two lexemes.
Parallel loans from Arabic خراب / kharāb 'destruction, ruin' (via Persian?).

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell', cf. Vedic gandhá- 'smell', Young Avestan gaiṇti 'bad smell', further connections remain uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:461-462, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:368-369).

Lexemes from OIA avarati- 'ceasing [of activity]'. Turner (q.v.) has Khowar orói m. 'sleep' < avarati-, whence the verb oréik and Pashai ōráč m. 'sleep' < *avaratya-. Morgenstierne (q.v.) also supplies the forms areč and urač from other dialects. It stands to reason that the verb is formed from this noun (with č>š/_t), though it is not attested by Morgenstierne, who has only light verb constructions and the verb stem oreč-, urač-.

Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic √pat- 'to fall; fly' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:436, no. 7722), further from PIE *pet- 'to fall; fly' ({ref EWAia} II:71-72, {ref LIV²} 436, {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'fall' in /cognate/7561/, 'fly_V' in /cognate/1486/, 'feather' in /cognate/7563/, 'leaf' in /cognate/790/, 'narrow' in /cognate/4064/, 'river' in /cognate/1525/, 'run' in /cognate/5968/, 'wing' in /cognate/1567/

justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vaṇṭa- 'tailless' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:655, no. 11236), further etymology obscure (cf. {ref KEWA} III:131, {ref EWAia} II:206).

Most probably a loan from an unclear Iranic language, perhaps related to Wakhi sivand (cognate/9267, Cheung *xšaib-) or to Sogdian pšāyt- (Cheung *apa-čyaH-?). The sequence išpV- is otherwise only known in Gawri from išpō 'sister, husband's sister' < *svásr-.

As though from Sanskrit *upahanaka- 'striking', cf. Ved. √han- 'hit, strike; kill' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:107, no. 2280), further to PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref EWAia} II:800-801, {ref LIV²} 218-219).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'cut' in /cognate/6606/, 'hit' in /cognate/1998/, 'kill' in /cognate/3551/, 'hunt' in /cognate/1298/, 'tail' in /cognate/1935/, 'run' in /cognate/5193/.

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966.
Not in Turner 1962–1966.
Not in Turner 1962–1966.
Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: Khowar gaan 'wind' from Old Indic gandhá- 'smell, scent' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:221, no. 4131). To be separated from comparable lexemes in Iranic (cf. Av. gaiṇti- 'bad smell', Parthian gndʾg 'stinking' etc.), but no secure connections outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref EWAia} I:461-462).

Modern Indic lexemes as though from Vedic kumārikā́- 'girl', cf. Vedic kumārá- 'child, boy' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:170, no. 3303). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} I:368-369 for various uncertain proposals).

Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit dhamana- 'blowing with bellows' > *'storm' > 'rain' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:385 no. 6732). Further to Vedic √dham-ⁱ 'to blow' and ultimately PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ({ref EWAia} I:775, {ref LIV²} 153).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/2567/, 'breathe' in /cognate/3738/, 'neck' in /cognate/9538/, 'nose' in /cognate/9218/, 'swell' in /cognate/9032/, 'wind' in /cognate/3113/.

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Modern Iranic, cf. Persian شیرین / širin 'sweet'.
Loanword from Iranic (via Persian?), cf. /cognate/2456/, /cognate/9297/.
Turner (ad rem) and Morgenstierne 1973 have ūṣ 'long'
Etymology unknown (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Loan from Persian (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:53).

notes: Cheung (2007: 375) seems to prefer a derivation from *teh₂- "to flow, stream; to melt" partly "(certainly influenced by *tač)".
Pashto would simplify /xt/ > /t/. Kurdish: Vxt > v̄t.
loan_notes: The donor language surely is Persian, although this word is a loanword in Persian as well.

notes: The Avestan word sarǝda- means 'kind, species', cf. the Avestan derivation sarǝidiia- 'companion'. The derivation *sardaka- would give Pashto saṛay 'man', which is obviously used for 'person'. The differing auslaut is surely dialectal. Cf. Sanskrit śardha-.
Mayrhofer (EWAia I 415) mentions doubtful relation with an OInd. root kroḍ and Wurzelerweiterungstypus *°EU̯-s-d-. It may fit to Celtic *krou̯di- and Slavic *krǫt-?
Attested for Avestan, Middle Persian and Parthian, one possible attestation for Sanskrit vŕ̥ka-dvaras- "running like a wolf (?)". Uncertain etymology. Metathesis of PIE *dreu̯-?

Adams (1985, Die Sprache 31, p.12) “In pąsta- we have an exocentric derivative in *-to-, meaning ‘characterized by [base noun]’, regularly built on the oblique stem. For both the semantics and the morphology we might compare Latin arbor ‘tree’ and arbustum ‘vineyard planted with trees’.” He assumes a development of *poums → *pōms → *pōs, cf. EWAia II p.144 assuming a PIE *péu̯mōs.
The root means "to laugh". The semantic connotation to "prostitute" goes via "to flirt", i.e. "to smile at" someone.
Old Persian ham-arana- "zusammenwogend"
justificationDiscussion: Light verb construction with Old Persian ham-arana- 'fight' < *'coming together' as a the semantic head. The root etymology of the semantic-bearing element of the compound ºarana- is to the Indo-Iranic verbal root *ar- < PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ({ref Schmitt 2014}:187-188, {ref EWAia} II:702, I:105-106, cf. {ref LIV²} 299-301).

From Latin subtīlis 'fine in texture, precise' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:693), derived from *sub tēla as a technical term in weaving and further to PIE *tek- 'weave, plait' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:662, {ref de Vaan 2008}:619, cf. {ref LIV²} 619-620).

loan_notes: only attested in the compound asā dāru "stone wood i.e. ebony", as such a loanword with Central Iranic (aka. NWIr.) s, came probably together with the product

notes: The 's' in Lari and Balochi derives from the Old Iranic Genitive *brāϑrah with *ϑr > ç (as with Old Persian) > s. Either these are loanwords from Old Persian or both languages participated in the same change.
of the verb "to sacrifice" a derivation "what is to be sacrificed"

duuaraiti suggested to be derived from *dreu̯- with metathesis (also suggested by Cheung 2007: 84, or ϑu̯ar/tūr). However, since this root is also attested in its expected form drauu-/drūta- (daevic), this seems less likely. [but Schwartz JRAS 1966: 119ff. considers the latter to belong to dhreu̯- “deceive”]
justificationDiscussion: Continuing Proto-Iranic *du̯ar- 'to run', further etymology difficult (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:83-84 for discussion).

notes: cf. Turkish fena “bad” < Arabic faniya “vernichten” (fanāˀ) ?

justificationDiscussion: No etymology outside of Iranic (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:445-446).

notes: There is mrγ “pasture”, which is given in Sogdian for “forest”, formally *ati-margā- would work, but does it make sense?

justificationDiscussion: As though from Iranic *padakā- according to {ref Humbach 1989}:194, cf. {ref Henning 1955}:43, {ref Benzing 1983}:540), further etymology uncertain.
probably simply „what is to be eaten“

notes: lit. "cutting"
maybe a loanword?
cf. Avestan xšuuiptauuaṇt- "mit Melkmilch, gemolkener Milch versehen"
causative with prefix: *au̯a-rādaya-
via "swollen" > "thick", cf. Benzing (1983:256)
justificationDiscussion: Derivative adjective to Khw. (ʾ)δmʾs- 'to become thick', further to Proto-Iranic *damH- 'to blow, breathe, swell' and ultimately to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ({ref Benzing 1983}:256, {ref Cheung 2007}:55-56, cf. {ref EWAia} I:775-776, {ref LIV²} 153).

notes: The Pashto word could be a loanword from West Iranic because of probable *p > b, which is not expected for Pashto.

justificationDiscussion: Light verb constructions with nominal 'wild animals, quarry, hunting' as the semantic-bearing head. The etymology of Middle Persian naxčīr was originally interpreted by {ref Bailey 1946}:774n1 as though from Iranic *naxti-čiθra- 'originating in the night' (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:36-37). {ref Bailey 1958}:44 later revised his view in light of new Middle discoveries and alternatively considered as though from Middle Persian *naxa-čarya- 'moving about in the expanse, open spaces, the wilds'. If so, we could consider to either *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, arrive' → Iranic *naxa- 'expanse, wilderness', or to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to move, turn' > Proto-Iranic *carH- ({ref Cheung 2007}:33-34) depending on which morpheme is best considered the original semantic head of the nominal compound.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *rand-, further to PIE *lendʰ- 'to lower, go down' ({ref Cheung 2007}:312-313, cf. {ref LIV²} 412-413).

notes: This could be the name of a specific snake. If derived from garz- 'to lament', it might a kind of viper (similar to the puff adder, e.g. the Persian False Horned Viper).
, {re
justificationDiscussion: Continuing Proto-Iranic *nau- 'to move' and further to PIE *neu̯- 'to nod, tilt (the head)' ({ref Cheung 2007}:284, cf. {ref LIV²} 455-456). Not the same root as PIE *neu̯- 'new' ({ref NIL} 524-526).

notes: related to xvaēδa- 'sweat'? < PIE *su̯ei̯d? EWAia 799 (Vol. II)

justificationDiscussion: Lexemes continuing an Iranic root *Hrab/f-, further connections outside of Iranic uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:184-185).

Continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *i̯am- 'to hold; to stretch, reach out' ({ref Cheung 2007}:211, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:432). No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic; {ref LIV²} 312 provisionally reconstructs ?*i̯em- 'to stretch out'.
Loan from Wakhi diγ̌ə́r, digə́r 'fingernail' ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:662, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:146-147).
A probable loan from Wakhi ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:662, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:188).
Loan from Iranic *ā(w)yak ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:666).
Iranic lexemes continuing a derivative of PIE *keh₂- 'to desire' ({ref Cheung 2007}:227, cf. {ref EWAia} I:334, {ref LIV²} 343).

notes: Gharib (1995: 73, #1862) suggets < *vitarāk (cf. Avestan vītara)
original meaning "to smell badly, stink", note the MP term gannāg mēnōg "evil spirit" and note that the Zoroastrian hell is stinking badly.
Gharib (1995: 217 §5434) translates the Sogdian word mrγ by "wood, meadow" and relates it to mrγ- "straight, flat".
this is probably a transitive PP that came to be used as the PP of an intransitive verb (bring/brought > having been brought/come)

Bailey (1979: 478) relates the Saka word hāysiñä "fountain (?)" to the Sogdian word ʾwʾz, which he relates to Ossetic awazun etc. "to dam up". The latter is given by Cheung as a cognate of *waz-, which also means "to swim" in some Iranic languages.

Bailey (1979: 420) connects the Saka word samuvā "covering parts" with CS sʾpt 'left (< crooked) side' and derives both from PIE *k̑am- "bend over, cover" with reference to *kamp- (cf. LIV p.342, not in Cheung 2007). Bailey also puts NP čap here.
Gharib (1995: 454, #11143) derives the Sogdian word from *δrām.
Gharib (1995: 429 #10568) suggests a connection with Av. vǝrǝzra, which is not attested in Bartholomae (1904)
Bailey (1979: 440) < *an-āmara-ka- ‘not sour’, as the reverse, Khotan Saka āhvarai ‘sour’, is ‘not sweet’. Reference to Pokorny om- and Old Indic amlá-, amblá- 'sour; sorrel'.
justificationDiscussion: According to {ref Bailey 1979}:440, to be derived from *an-āmara-ka- 'not sour', and connected to Vedic amlá- 'sour', traditionally compared to Italic and Germanic lexemes, e.g. Latin amārus 'bitter', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, hard, cold', cf. {ref KEWA} I:46, {ref EIEC} 69).

To be connected with Avestan paitištāna- 'leg', further a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to stand', cf. Vedic stā́na- 'place for standing' ({ref Gharib 1995}:320, cf. {ref EWAia} II:764-766, cf. {ref LIV²} 590-592).

notes: maybe identical with 1584 *sem-; Nyberg "Manual" (1974: 93) derives this word from *hama-van- without indicating the meaning of the elements. (There is only van "tree" in his word list.)
Bailey (1979: 153) suggests a derivation from the verb dar- "to split"
justificationDiscussion: {ref Bailey 1979}:153 suggests a derivation from the verb *dar- 'to split' connecting to {ref IEW} 194-196 *del- (cf. {ref LIV²} 114 *delh₁-, without IIr. cognates listed; note that {ref LIV²} 119-121, {ref EWAia} I:701-703, {ref Cheung 2007}:59-60 assign Indo-Iranic *dar- to PIE *der-).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:79, {ref EWAia} I:756 for further discussion.

notes: Cheung (2007: 20) mentions a suggestion by Rastorgueva/Edel'man (2003: 159) to sort the Khotanese verb to *bād < PIE *bʰēdʰ-, viz. *pati-/api-bād-. They also suggest (not mentioned by Cheung) that this word could derive from api-šad- "oppress" < had "sit" (cf. Emmerick 1968: 85).

justificationDiscussion: Khotanese form with etymological meaning '(place to) run about, together' ({ref Bailey 1979}:454), root etymology further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *dram- and further to PIE 1. *drem- 'to run' ({ref Cheung 2007}:75-76, {ref EWAia} I:755, {ref LIV²} 128).
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:483 for discussion of various proposals.

notes: Bailey (1979: 410) connects this word with the verb fšar- "to press" just as Old Indic kṣudra- „small“ from kṣod- „press crush“. He explicitly excludes xšīra- "milk".
LW from OInd. bālaka-

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gaxša-, cf. Tumšuq Saka tsänakai and Zoroastrian Pahlavi *gašnak ({ref Bailey 1979}: 116).
Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain, the earlier proposal by {ref Bailey 1979}:168 to PIE *der- 'to run' via an extended form *dr-ep(h)- is no longer tenable (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:75).

notes: not found in Cheung (2007)

justificationDiscussion: Continuing Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to rejoice' and further to PIE *gʰer- 'to desire, be delighted' ({ref Cheung 2007}:104, {ref LIV²} 176-177 s.v. *g̑ʰer-, but *gʰer- in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}; cf. {ref Bailey 1979}:465).
Lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *xrau̯- 'to tear, break, scratch', further etymology uncertain ({ref Cheung 2007}:447-448, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:28, {ref Bailey 1979}:92).

notes: Not in Cabolov 2001–2010.
negation of baš "good", which Cabolov (2001: 155) explains as a Turkish loanword: baš 'head' > 'main' > 'good' (cf. German 'Kopf/Haupt' > 'haupt-' as with 'Hauptsache').
Not in Morgenstierne 2003
Same thing as t'ūk 'hair, wool, down' in sense of 'covering' > 'skin, hide' > 'bark'??? If so, Turkish loanword cf. Cabolov (2010: 418).
cf. MP kumīg "stomach"
< *nāf 'navel' ?
not found in Korn 2005, onset speaks in favour of a loanword

justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Arabic ﺣﺴﺐ / ḥasiba 'to reckon, count'.

A derivative from Proto-Iranic *gard- 'to call', from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound' ({ref Cheung 2007}:106); possibly originally an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ({ref ALEW} 331-332). Root reference form follows {ref LIV²} 210-211.

notes: Probably reflects the root Proto-Turkic *čöp 'dregs', reflected as čöp 'dregs, dirt, refuse' in Uyghur, Chaghatay, Middle Turkic, etc. Cf. the discussion for cognate/9742.
justificationDiscussion: Probably reflects a derivation from Turkic čöp 'dregs, dirt, refuse', cf. also cognate/9742

notes: identical with the Romanian word that was loaned from Turkish (6544)
justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Modern Persian مردار / mordār 'corpse'.

notes: Not in Morgenstierne (2003).

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Arabic ورد / warad 'rose'.
Iranic lexemes reflecting denominal formations to PIE *(s)por-no- 'wing, feather' ({ref Cheung 2007}:297, cf. {ref EWAia} II:97).
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- 'to look, seek after' ({ref LIV²} 668-669, cf. {ref EWAia} II:509-510, {ref Cheung 2007}:411).
Light verb constructions, whose semantic heads are loans from Persian parvāz 'flight'.

Traditionally compared with Avestan pāšna- 'heel', Sanskrit pā́rṣṇi- 'id.' via a (dual?) preform *pāršnā, but the proposal is not without formal and semantic difficulties, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:67.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *kau̯p- 'to pound, beat'; further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:249-250, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:570-571).

notes: maybe < *dreuH-so- ? cf. Cheung (2007: 79-80)
probably via New Persian غایب
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Arabic غایب 'absent, not present, concealed', probably via New Persian غایب 'hidden'.

notes: possibly "to do under", then čēr < *hača adari 'from down'

justificationDiscussion: Cf. Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike; thresh; [inch., intr.] to become tired' with no certain etymology outside of Iranic ({ref Cheung 2007}:141-143).
Etymology uncertain. {ref Morgenstierne 1938}:542 tentatively compared Armenian šand 'spark, red-hot iron', but this remains a conjecture (cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:344-345).
Cf. Proto-Iranic *kau̯š- 'to fight, struggle, kill', further derived from PIE *keh₂u̯- 'to beat; to split' ({ref Cheung 2007}:251-252, {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:525-526, cf. {ref LIV²} 345-346).
Cf. 'take' in /cognate/5227/.
Not documented by Morgenstierne or Steblin-Kamenskij. This is quite certainly a loan (and calque) from Khowar, as Wakhi -q- occurs exclusively in Arabic and Khowar borrowings.

Light verb constructions with Proto-Iranic *parθu- 'rib' (with later semantic development within Iranic to 'side') as the semantic-bearing head ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:98-99). Further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *párću- 'rib', with further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult to ascertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:100-101).
Cf. Gurani raq 'hard', Luri riiq 'wet-hardened in the cold', 'starched clothes', 'dried out in the cold', Shugni. rāx 'numb' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010}:192).
Further etymology not yet ascertained (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:596).

According to {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:306, as though from Proto-Iranic *dam-na- > *dav-n > *dafn, derived from Proto-Iranic *damH- 'to blow, breathe; to swell' and consequently ultimately to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:55-56, {ref EWAia} I:775, {ref LIV²} 153).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/2567/, 'breathe' in /cognate/3738/, 'neck' in /cognate/9538/, 'swell' in /cognate/9032/, 'rain' in /cognate/8821/, 'wind' in /cognate/3113/.

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Arabic (via Persian).
Uncertain, perhaps cognate with Ossetic xwyr, xwyra 'gravel, pebble' ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:476, cf. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:266).

notes: Not in Cabolov (2001–2010).

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:167).

notes: The Balochi word could be related to *čāt- via *čād- > *čūl (East Iranic) with -ak suffix or borrowed from a Persian form čāh > *čōh > ? *čūh + Turkish -lIK suffix (cf. Rastorgueva/Edelman 2003: 253), cf. Tadjik čalǝk.
*su̯elk̑s- cf. Middle Persian xwaš, Parthian wxaš
possibly a Turkish loan word: kol "arm", if it was used for all extremities

justificationDiscussion: A compound of Pre-Wakhi *dba-rūn(a)- where the members are dba- 'two' and rūna- 'thigh' < Proto-Iranic *rāna- 'thigh', cf. Avestan rāna-, Persian rān. The 'two' as a compound member apparently also occurs in Wakhi brət 'elbow' ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:102-103, {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:91).

notes: This could be related to zānū: zırānü < *zızānū < *zānū, maybe following the pattern dɨdan "tooth" (though this derives from dandān).
This word is most likely related to the armpit, cf. Av. kaša-, with suffix -ka- and a modern diminutive (?) suffix -ıḷa.
zāk could represent a nasalised zãk (?) < *zank- (?) < *zang-a-k, cf. Av. zaṇga- „ankle“, alternatively one would have to assume zāk < *zaγ-k < *zaγ-ak < *zaga- < *j́nͅgʰ-

Origin unclear, l can derive from *rd/rz if this verb had originally a prefix. It is also possible that there is a kind of r/l alternation. Then it could be related to cognate set 6659 *Hrab/f-: raw- > *rū- (?), though this is pretty wanted.
With prefix ni-, original meaning "to lie down", i.e. "to sleep".
justificationDiscussion: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *ni- 'down' + √*pad- 'to fall' via an intermediate sense 'to lie down', further to PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ({ref Cheung 2007}:287-288, cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} II:46, {ref EWAia} II:77-78, {ref LIV²} 458).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'foot' in /cognate/225/, 'leg' in /cognate/2783/, 'stand' in /cognate/6813/, 'fall' in /cognate/1126/, 'lie' in /cognate/8225/.

notes: could this be identical with Kumzari bidrit?

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Persian kōbal, gōpal 'cudgel' (cf. {ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:393).
Parallel loans from Arabic خلق / xalq 'people' (via Persian/Tajik?), cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:405.

notes: lit. "to stand up"
justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *Hrab/f- 'to go'. An etymology to a PIE root *rebʰ- 'to move oneself (boldly)' is tentatively considered by {ref LIV²} 496, but it is by no means assured (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:184).

notes: Morgenstierne considers the derivation of kˈāṇay < *karna-ka- possible and compares it with Lithuanian kálnas "hill". The Iranic form requires *klͅHn- or *kolHn- as input forms.

justificationDiscussion: {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:39 considers the derivation of kˈāṇay < *karna-ka- possible and compares it with Lithuanian kálnas. If so, this would suggest an input form *klͅHn- or *kolHn-, but cf. {ref ALEW} 441-442, {ref LIV²} 349, cf. /cognate/1866/.
Loanword from Lahnda laṇdā 'crop-tailed' ({ref Morgenstierne 2003}:44, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:645 no.11081).

notes: with prefix ham-
justificationDiscussion: Etymology here follows {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:27 suggesting Proto-Iranic *ham-gan-, cf. Skt. sam-han- 'put together, unite', ultimately from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:103, {ref LIV²} 218-219).

Cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:87 walˈāṛ 'standing' from *awa-darta/i- or *wi-darta/i-, further to Proto-Iranic *dar- 'to hold, keep; dwell', and ultimately PIE *dʰer- 'to stick, fix' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:57-59, {ref LIV²} 145-146).

notes: LIV suggests *h₂u̯i̯edʰ-
Khwarazmian with prefix upa-
justificationDiscussion: Following {ref Cheung 2007}:26} to PIE *kʷei̯- 'to pile up, heap, make'.

Etymology unclear. si- is not an attested prefix and it appears the nominal base refers to a physical object, so the proposal in {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 320 seems strongest, but the semantic gap between "stick/cudgel" and "throw away" is so great we might actually be dealing with homonyms.

notes: original meaning "ear" + verbaliser: k-oš-kēnīt
justificationDiscussion: Probably a light verb construction involving PIE *h₂us-i- 'ear' (cf. Young Avestan uši- 'ear') as the semantic head ({ref Korn 2005}:350). For the Indo-European comparanda cf. {ref NIL} 339-343.

Compared by {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:12 with Sanskrit ā-khid- 'seize', if so from Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰād- ~ *kʰid- which may formally reflect PIE ?*k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂d- 'to tear, squeeze', although further cognates outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain (cf. {ref LIV²} 344). [Not in {ref Cheung 2007}].

notes: probably related with Parthian wiδān "tent"
Regular development of *bazu(ra)- is bāzul and bāsk in Balochi. The word for heart "zird" shows that *rd/rz does not develop to l in Balochi.

justificationDiscussion: From Proto-Iranic *u̯ar(H)- 'to choose, convince; (med.) believe' + preverb *u̯i-; root etymology further to PIE *u̯elh₁- 'to choose, select' ({ref Cheung 2007}:420, {ref LIV²} 677-678).

notes: proposed relation to PIE *u̯ebʰ- "to weave" rejected by Cheung (2007)

justificationDiscussion: Lit. 'not-good', cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:106, cf. 'good' in /cognate/9287/ for further etymological discussion.

notes: The Persian develoment would have been *siš < *ϑiš < *k̑u̯is or *ϑiš < *siš < *k̑u̯is, cf. Klingenschmitt (2000: 202).
Wakhi šiš might belong here as well. The assimilation of siš > šiš is frequently attested (for Balochi examples cf. Korn 2005: 180).
the Elami form does not belong to 3666 *upā́kai̯, but to Kurdish geł "amount, group", cf. legeł 'with' and Gorani we gerd 'ibid.'

Emmerick/Skjærvø (1982: 55) follow Henning's suggestion to derive the Khotanese word from *drigu- (cf. Avestan drigu- "arm, bedürftig, schwach"). The Avestan word is considered an Iranian innovation by Mayrhofer (EWAia I: 68): "Konträrbildung zu dem ererbten indoiran. *ádhri-gu-, aus irriger Auffassung *a-dhrigu-".
justificationDiscussion: The etymology of Khotanese dīra- 'bad' given here follows the proposal of {ref Henning 1944}:141n7 proposing to connect the word to Avestan drigu- 'poor, weak' via metathesised *dirgu- (cf. {ref Emmerick & Skjærvø 1982}:55-56, and Maggi on the word again in {ref Emmerick & Skjærvø 1997}:77-78). Possibly further related to Vedic á-dhrigu-, an epithet of Indra, Agni, Soma, the Aśvins, and the Maruts, {ref EWAia} I: 67-68 for further discussion. Note, however, that {ref Bailey 1979}:159 preferred to see a connection instead to the PIE root *du̯ei̯- 'to fear'.

notes: Bailey (1979: 289) suggests a derivation from *u̯r̩dā- to *u̯ard- "soft"

justificationDiscussion: Historical phonology rules out any etymological relation to Persian saxt. The Wakhi sound <x> could imply a loanword from another Iranic language, as it is not usually found in the native vocabulary.

notes: Pashto zanāna, must be a loan if from *gʷen-, because *ǰ > ž
suggested meaning of the verbal root is "to be born, related", however, Cheung (2007: 251) states: "The root *kur- is probably nominal in origin."

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Italian mangiare 'to eat'.
Loanword from either Italian or Venetian mosca 'fly'.
Loanword from Italian pesante 'heavy'.
Loanword from Venetian casar 'to hunt'.
Loanword from Venetian rosso.
Loan from Venetian.
Loanword from Venetian.
Loan from Venetian.
Loan from Italian serpente 'snake'.
Loanword from Venetian dolze 'sweet'.
Loanword from Italian nuotare 'to swim'.
Loan from Italian penna 'pen, feather, quill, plume'.
Loanword from Venetian.
Loanword from Venetian caldo 'hot'.

As though from Latin *dē-ramāre 'to dismember' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:236), a derivative of Latin rāmus 'branch, twig' which is traditionally further connected to the root of Latin rādix 'root' if *rādmo- < *wrād-mo-, cf. Ancient Greek ῥάδιξ, -ικος 'branch, twig' (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:564, {ref de Vaan 2008}:513).

notes: How do we know Megleno-Romanian was not directly borrowed from Turkish?

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes from Latin ūstulāre (on the unexpected initial br-, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:757, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 14:75-82), a secondary form of Latin ūrō derived from PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, singe' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:755, {ref de Vaan 2008}:645, {ref LIV²} 245).
No certain etymology, perhaps to be connected in some way with the lexemes from Latin ūstulāre in /cognate/9342/, but this remains uncertain (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:757).
No certain correspondences outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:419, {ref Kluge 2011}:827; not in {ref Kroonen 2013}).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fahsa- 'hair of the head' as though from PIE *pok̑-s-o-, cf. Ancient Greek Gk. πέκος 'fleece' < *pek̑-es-, derived from PIE 1. *pek̑- 'to pluck (wool or hair)' ({ref Orel 2003}:89, {ref Kroonen 2013}:122, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1164, {ref LIV²} 467).

No clear etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Seebold 1970}:566-567, {ref Kroonen 2013}:596-597). Note that the Old High German form continues an intensive formation *writtōn- to the basic stem *wrītan-. 
The inclusion of Old Saxon hrîtan (Proto-Germanic *hrītan-) is not entirely straightforward, since the differing Anlaut is not phonologically reconcilable.
