Perhaps a secondary development from *wrītan- or the result of secondary contamination or blending with another root (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:272 for further discussion).
The likelihood of ultimately common root cognacy seems strikingly high, so Old Saxon hrîtan is included here, rather than in a separate cognate set as /cognate/9432/.
Connections outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:282-284, {ref Kroonen 2013}:265-266 for further discussion).

notes: *č > Sarikoli c (ts)
*č > Sarikoli c (ts)

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Turkic, cf. Uzbek, Kyrgyz ildiz 'root'.

notes: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 111)
not found in Morgenstierne (1974)
onomatopoetic? but cf. Turkish kuš "bird"
Sarikoli with prefix *awa-?
justificationDiscussion: Derivative of Proto-Iranic *dar- 'to hold, keep; dwell', and ultimately to PIE *dʰer- 'to stick, fix' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:57-59, {ref LIV²} 145-146).

notes: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 79)

justificationDiscussion: Derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *i̯at- 'to take up a position', arguably further to a PIE root *i̯et- ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:105, {ref Cheung 2007}:214-215, {ref LIV²} 314-315, but cf. {ref EWAia} II:394-395 skeptical of connections outside of Indo-Iranic).
From Proto-Iranic *nau(H)- 'to cry, wail', further to PIE *neu̯(H)- 'to cry out, shout' ({ref Cheung 2007}:284, {ref EWAia} II:23-24, cf. {ref LIV²} 456-457).

notes: original meaning "to wipe"
the Sarikoli development of PIE *skobʰ- > PIr. *kap/f- is čov-/čift- (see Cheung 2007: 235)

justificationDiscussion: No etymological information in {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:114.

no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 26)
not found in Morgenstierne (1974), cf. Kâta-vari: Eastern: kâk′ok puṇuk [?] which is however sorted under puṇuk < *puṇra-.

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Modern Persian γaš(š) 'stupor, deceiving'(?) ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:37).
Etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref Morgenstierne 1974}].

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain. [Not in {ref Morgenstierne 1974}].

notes: not found in Morgenstierne (1974)

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain; {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:101 suggests *fšatā- 'combed' (?); if so cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:92 for a further root etymology to Proto-Iranic *fšan- 'to drag, tear, split'? Further etymological connections uncertain.

notes: cf. Marathi ṭaṇaka (7579); Morgenstierne (1974: 82) quotes H. W. Bellew: Vocabulary of Sarigh Culi, etc., in Forsyth, Report on a mission to Yarkund 1873, Calcutta 1876 with "teyáng".
Morgenstierne (1974: 82) derives this word from the verb ϑāw- 'to burn', which derives from *tep-, while Cheung (2007: 68) from *deh₂u-.
justificationDiscussion: Root etymology disputed. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:82-83 derives from Proto-Iranic *tap/f- < PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' (cf. {ref LIV²} 629-630); {ref Cheung 2007}:67-68 derives from Proto-Iranic *dauH- 'to burn' < PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to kindle, catch on fire' (cf. {ref LIV²} 104-105).
Probably an early loanword from Persian/Tajik (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:108).

notes: cf. Morgenstierne (1974: 40): "kawg S[arikoli] (bur.) spring, well. - Lw. < W[akhi] kïk, kūk < *xāka-."
justificationDiscussion: Quite regularly development of older *kōl from Turkic köl < *kȫl 'lake', either Uzbek (standard ko'l) or Kyrgyz (standard köl). Cf. Shughni qůl 'lake' with a similar development.
{ref Morgenstierne 1974}:82 gives no etymology outside of the Shughni group.

Sarikoli derivative with adjectival suffix *-aina- from Proto-Iranic *kāra- 'people', cf. Old Persian kāra- 'people, army' ({ref Morgenstierne 1974:27). Further probably a vr̥ddhi-derivative on the basis of PIE *kor-o- 'war' (cf. {ref Schmitt 2014}:201-202).

notes: original meaning "to sting, stab"; Cheung (2007: 362) translates with "game; entertainment; joke" (probably: stab > kill while hunting > game > play) and considers the possibility of a loanword.

justificationDiscussion: From Proto-Iranic *tanč- 'to twist (together), become narrow, dense, constrict', further to PIE *temk- 'to become firm, coagulate' ({ref Cheung 2007}:377-378, {ref LIV²} 625, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:82).

notes: complex verb, no etymological information on Sarikoli 'kat' in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007); maybe metathesis < *tak ?

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from Persian rušt 'brightly coloured' ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:69).
Loanword from Tajik vayron 'destroyed, devestated', cf. Middle Persian awērān "devastated".
Possibly a loan from Indic? (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:62).
Etymology uncertain, doubtful suggestion as though from Proto-Iranic ?*xā(ha)xa- by {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:79.
Loanword (source?), well attested among Pamir languages; cf. Nuristani Vâsi-vari: Paṣki "li-" /cognate/7909/. Cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:42.

notes: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974); cf. Arabic beyt "verse (consisting of two half verses)"
*b would > Sarikoli v; Sarikoli b < *p/V_V; cf. Persian bū < Middle Persian bōy
no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974)
original meaning "to pour", Sarikoli with prefix *abi-
justificationDiscussion: Continuing Proto-Iranic *abi-haič- (*haič- 'to pour out') with further root etymology to PIE *sei̯kʷ- 'to pour (out)' ({ref Cheung 2007}:127, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:19, {ref LIV²} 523).

Probably continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *zai- 'to set in motion, impel' (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:109-110, {ref Cheung 2007}:461). Further connections outside of Indo-Iranic doubted by {ref EWAia} II:802-803, {ref LIV²} 174; cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:462 for proposed nominal cognates outside of Indo-Iranic. {ref LIV²} 174 mechanically reconstructs ?*g̑ʰei̯- 'to set in motion, drive'.

notes: a loan, because **k̑lou̯ni- > *sr° > Sarikoli x̌
not found in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007)
not found in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007), the latter noting Sarikoli pïrx- "to vomit" (p.298)

probably somehow derived from a proto-form of piyāde. If Horn's derivation of piyāde is correct (1893: 77 *padātaka-), pujuðo is a loanword of a West Iranic languages where *d/V_V > y and *t/V_V > d (d > ð could be secondary)

justificationDiscussion: Continuing Proto-Iranic *xšudrā̆- 'liquid' ({ref Morgenstierne 1974}:100), a derivative of a Proto-Indo-Iranic root *xšau̯d- 'to dissolve; to wash' without clear correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:455-456, {ref EWAia} I:439).

loan_notes: pl. of walad "child" < walada "to give birth", cf. Turkish evlat "child"

notes: not found in Morgenstierne (1974)
similarity to 5163 in using "night" for 'yesterday'
justificationDiscussion: Cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1974}:17, 100, and /cognate/5163/ for a semantic parallel for 'evening' > 'yesterday'.

notes: Sarikoli and Cappadocian Greek both loaned this word from a Turkic language, though obviously not the same

justificationDiscussion: From Proto-Germanic *grundu- 'floor' (Old Frisian grund); further etymological connections problematic, cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:161, {ref Orel 2003}:144, {ref Kluge 2011}:378, {ref Kroonen 2013}:192 for various proposals and further discussion.

notes: from root *k̑eh₃-, expected output would be hīne etc.
original meaning "dirt, dust"

justificationDiscussion: Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:426-427, {ref Orel 1998}:521, {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1009-1010 for various possibilities and further discussion.

notes: probably via Persian

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Germanic ({ref Seebold 1970}:162).

A European isogloss with proposed cognates also in Italic and Slavic; cf. {ref Schrijver 1991}:212-213 for further discussion. The Germanic forms in this class may go back to Proto-Germanic *salwo- as though from PIE *solH-u̯o- (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:466-467, {ref Kroonen 2013}:425), while the Celtic forms require a Proto-Celtic derived stem *salāko- (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:15-16, {ref Matasović 2009}:319).
A derivative to the same root as the Germanic strong verb *wend-a- ({ref Kluge 2011}:970), and further to PIE *u̯endʰ- (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:554-556, {ref Kroonen 2013}:587, {ref LIV²} 681-682).

Continuing Proto-Germanic *flaka- 'flat'. Traditionally considered to be a *-g- extended form of the root *pelh₂- (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:199), alternatively {ref Kroonen 2013}:143-144 proposes cognacy to Greek πλάξ, -ακός 'plane, plain; flat stone, board table' < *pl̥k-; Lithuanian plãkanas, Latvian plakans 'flat' < *plokono- (cf. also {ref ALEW} 785-786, reconstructing *pleh₂k- 'mit flacher Hand schlagen, klatschen').
Attestation restricted to West Germanic, without clear comparisons outside of Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:406, {ref Kluge 2011}:794).

From Proto-Germanic *kwēda- 'shit, excrement' (n.). 'bad' (adj.) ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:348-349), generally considered to continue a derivative from a PIE root *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'disgusting, gross' ({ref EWNl}, {ref Orel 2003}:229, cf. ALEW} 303-304, {ref Derksen 2008}:160-161 [not in {ref Kroonen 2013}]).

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:446, {ref Orel 2003}:334, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:485). The 'Schenkel' from Middle High German onwards are diminutive formations ({ref Kluge 2011}:800). For the root, cf. {ref LIV²} 555).

Generally considered derived to a Germanic expletive in the sense 'lewd, indecent' ({ref Heidermanns 1993}:102, {ref Faltings 2010}:106-108 following the etymological proposal of {ref Puhvel 1986}:154-155; cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:34). Root ref. form for this class follows {ref LIV²} 238-239 s.v. *h₁erg̑ʰ-. NB: The Leiden dictionaries reconstruct this root as *h₃erg̑ʰ- with initial *h₃- following the proposal of {ref Kloekhorst 2006} that reflexes of *h₃- merged with *h₁- before *-o-.
Derived to the comparative degree of Proto-Germanic *ferrai 'far', further from the PIE local adverb *per- 'through, beyond, over; very' ({ref LIPP 2}:607-614, {ref Kroonen 2013}:137).

Etymology uncertain. Appears to be fairly close to Proto-Germanic *wrītan- in /cognate/9348/ but the differing Anlaut is not phonologically reconcilable. Perhaps a secondary development from *wrītan- or the result of secondary contamination or blending with another root (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:272 for further discussion).

Based on a secondary derivative to Proto-Germanic *klīban- 'to stick' < PIE *glei̯bʰ-, a root exclusive to Balto-Slavic and Germanic (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:296-297, {ref de Vries 1977}:316-317, {ref Orel 2003}:216, {ref Kroonen 2013}:292-293, {ref LIV²} 189-190).

Celtic and Indic lexemes from a root *g̑ʰers-/*g̑ʰres- ({ref EWAia} II:823), traditionally considered to be derived from an s-extended form of the root *g̑ʰer- 'short, small, slight' (cf. {ref IEW} 443, {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1999}:68n57; not in {ref Matasović 2009}).
Indic lexemes derived from PIE *Herd- (cf. {ref LIV²} 223-224, {ref EWAia} I:117-118). For Modern Indic lexemes connected to this class, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:60, no. 1340.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Traditionally assumed to be a derivative in *-dʰro- to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' and connected with OCS vedro 'nice weather' ({ref IEW} 82; cf. {ref de Vries 1977}:649, {ref Derksen 2008}:513), but cf. the discussion of {ref Kroonen 2013}:583-584.

Traditionally conjectured to be a derivative to PIE *h₂ek̄- 'to be(come) sharp' ({ref de Vries 1977}:632, {ref IEW} 18), but this etymology is no longer continued by the more recent handbooks (cf. {ref NIL} 287-300; not in {ref Orel 2003}, {ref Kroonen 2013}).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:45 for various proposals). {ref Kroonen 2013}:39 considers a root etymology *h₂ed- for an old PIE word for a type of cereal grains.

Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives from PIE 1. *per- 'to cross, go through' ({ref LIV²} 472-473, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:186-188, {ref Lehmann 1986}:108-109, {ref Kroonen 2013}:128).

Indic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'to leave' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:492, no. 8743, {ref EWAia} II:457-458, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:451-452, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:161, {ref Matasović 2009}:240, cf. {ref LIV²} 406-408).

Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to hit, split' ({ref LIV²} 345-346, cf. {ref Hackstein 1995}:54-56, {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:115-116, {ref Malzahn 2010}:606-607, {ref Adams 2013}:222, {ref Cheung 2007}:251-252).
Loanword from West Germanic ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:624, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 17:12-15).

As though continuing Sanskrit *rāyaṇika- 'barking', a derivative of Vedic √rā- 'to bark, bark at' and further to PIE *leh₂- 'to bark, bark at' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:620 no. 10713, {ref EWAia} II:443, cf. {ref LIV²} 400-401).

notes: The form "Paš. cāla" in Turner (q.v.) is an error. Morgenstierne has č- and <c> /ts/ is not usually found in Pashai.

justificationDiscussion: Derivatives to Vedic ghaná- adj. 'thick, compact' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:828 no. 14468). Further etymology uncertain, cf. {ref EWAia} I:512, I:184-185 for further discussion.
Root etymology follows {ref LIV²} 562, cf. also {ref Seebold 1970}:425, {ref Orel 2003}:344, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Rejzek 2001}:631, {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 4:66-67.
The alternative < pīvas- "nourishment, milk, fodder" (Morgenstierne 1973: 137 "difficult") suggested by Turner is not convincing as -v- is not usually lost in Pashai except /a_a and /_i.

The alternative suggestion piśitá-, 'meat' in Prakrit and Pashai, is not convincing as we would expect -ita to result in Khowar -ir, e.g. Khowar bʌsir 'he-goat' < vāsita- (Turner q.v.), but kur 'where?' < kútaḥ (Turner q.v.). There is no reason to assume u~i fluctuation in Khowar – on the contrary, we would expect umlaut before -i-.

Continuing a derivative of Vedic √rap- 'to talk, chatter' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:614 no. 10620). Further etymology outside of Indic uncertain, possibly of onomatopoeic origin (cf. {ref EWAia} II:432-433, not in {ref LIV²}).

Italic lexemes derived from Latin rīpa 'riverbank' from PIE *h₁rei̯p- ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:605, {ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 10:415-417, {ref de Vaan 2008}:524; cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:574).

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966
Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: As though continuing Sanskrit *skambha- 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:786 no. 13640). Further etymology uncertain.

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966.
Not in Turner 1962–1966
Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: Morgenstierne (1950: A bundle of Pashai Etymologies), followed by Fussman, assumes a derivation from the stem kṣīrá-, thus 'white' < 'milky', but cannot explain irregular -l- < -r-. The same problem is posed by *kāśira-, whence the Nuristani words, where loss of the initial vowel would also be unprecedented.
Continuing the Vedic root √tvar- 'to hurry, make haste', further to PIE *tu̯er- 'to stir up, spur on' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:335 no. 5878, {ref EWAia} I:684-685, cf. {ref LIV²} 655).

Indic and Nuristani lexemes tentatively connected with Prakrit cikka- and Marathi cikkar 'small', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 259 and {ref Degener 1998}: 406. Coincidence and recent formation through sound symbolism are impossible to exclude.
Lexemes belonging to the complex field of **paṭ- 'membrane, covering, leaf', which seems to blend several original roots.
Denominal adjective from Classical Armenian ałt 'filth'. Further etymology outside of Armenian disputed, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:39-40 for various proposals.
Khowar kan < Old Indic kāṇḍa- 'single joint of plant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:154, no. 3023), further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:336-337).
As though from Sanskrit chadana- 'cover; leaf', a derivative of Vedic √chad- 'to cover', further etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:272 no. 4979, {ref EWAia} I:554-555).

As though from Sanskrit *gandhapūrikā-, an substantivised form of an adjective derived from gandhá- 'smell', and pūra- 'filling, making full' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:215, no. 4015. This class is coded for Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell', which appears to be the semantic bearing head of the original compound. Further etymology uncertain ({ref EWAia} I:461-462).
Apparently as though from Sanskrit aru- 'sun', only attested in lexicographical works ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:27, no. 612).
Continuing Vedic tr̥prá-, originally an epithet of soma of debated semantics. Further etymology obscure ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:338-339 no. 5934, {ref EWAia} I:666).
Loan from Iranic (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1936}:671).
NB: {ref Turner 1962–1966}:351 no. 6145 compares Iranic forms which {ref Cheung 2007}:48 assumes to be a separate root of onomatopoeic origin.
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'give' in /cognate/1010/, 'do' in /cognate/5125/, 'push' in /cognate/9832/, and 'say' in /cognate/7330/.

justificationDiscussion: Probably a loanword, cf. Saṇu-viri istˈã 'star' ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:666).
An early borrowing from Iranic ({ref Morgenstierne 1936}:669).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √vāś- 'to roar, resound' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:675 no. 11586), further to Proto-Indo-Iranic √*u̯āć-, cf. Proto-Iranic *u̯ās- 'to make a noise, roar, shout', but without clear correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} II:547-548, {ref Cheung 2007}:432).
Continuing a derivative of PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'to leave' via Indic udrēcayati 'causes to increase' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:96-97 no. 2061, cf. {ref EWAia} II:457-458, {ref LIV²} 406-408).
Etymology uncertain ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:163 no. 3193, {ref EWAia} I:355-356).
As though continuing Sanskrit *skambha- 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:786 no. 13640). Further etymology uncertain.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic meghá- 'cloud' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:595 no.10302), further generally derived from PIE *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- ({ref EWAia} II:374-375).

As though from Sanskrit sajya- 'strung (of bow); prepared, ready', a derivative of Vedic √sa(ñ)j- 'to adhere to' and further to PIE 1. *seg- 'to adhere, to cling to' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:758 no. 13095, {ref KEWA} III:419-420, {ref EWAia} II:688-689, {ref LIV²} 516).

notes: Not in Turner 1962–1966

justificationDiscussion: "< rahant-?" Turner (ad rem)

Derived from Vedic sr̥ṣṭá- 'released' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:783, no. 13578), further derived from Vedic √sarj- 'to let go or fly, discharge, throw, cast, hurl' and ultimately from PIE *selg̑- 'to release, throw' ({ref EWAia} II:709, {ref LIV²} 528-529).

Continuing Vedic dhamáni- 'vein, nerve; throat, neck', ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:385 no. 6733), further derived from Vedic √dham-ⁱ 'to blow' probably via an intermediate meaning 'pipe' and further to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ({ref KEWA} II:92-93, {ref EWAia} I:775, cf. {ref LIV²} 153).
alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'blow' in /cognate/2567/, 'breathe' in /cognate/3738/, 'nose' in /cognate/9218/, 'swell' in /cognate/9032/, 'rain' in /cognate/8821/, 'wind' in /cognate/3113/.

justificationDiscussion: Loan from Iranic.

notes: The retention of the intervocalic stop in this word is noted as being irregular by Morgenstierne 1940:214.
justificationDiscussion: Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit ākāśá- 'sky' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:45 no. 1008), to be further connected with Vedic √kāś- 'to be visible, appear' and further to PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ({ref EWAia} I:344-345, {ref LIV²} 383-385).
As though from Sanskrit *palva- 'grey' (({ref Turner 1962–1966}:450 no. 7974), cf. Ved. palitá- 'grey' < *pelh₂itó- ({ref EWAia} II:103-104).
Loanword from Old French flour, flur, flor 'flower' (via Middle English flour, flur 'flower'?).
loan_notes: Loanword presumably via English or French

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from English person.
Loan from Middle English smọ̄th(e) 'smooth'.
Loan from English serpent 'snake, serpent'.

From Proto-Brythonic *sacro-, an old borrowing from Latin sacer 'consecrated to a divinity, holy, sacred' in the later attested sense 'accursed, execrable, detestable, horrible' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Deshayes 2003}:319)
Related to Old Breton trinc 'sour', but no further etymology known outside of Brythonic (cf. {ref Deshayes 2003}:741).

notes: Connected with https://cobl.info/cognate/8436/?

justificationDiscussion: Romance lexemes as though continuing *passāre, a denominal verb to Latin passus 'a step, footstep', further a derivative to the same root of Latin pandō, -ere 'to spread out, extend' continuing a formation *pt-n-(é)h₂- to PIE *peth₂- 'to spread out' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:516 no. 6267, 6271, {ref de Vaan 2008}:442, {ref LIV²} 478-479).
From Latin boreās 'north wind; north' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:107), an old loanword from Greek βορέας 'north wind; north' ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:73-74).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian црн дроб, Bulgarian черен дроб 'liver'.
loan_notes: Cf. Macedonian црн дроб, Bulgarian черен дроб 'liver'.

justificationDiscussion: Continuing Latin vallis 'valley' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:762 no. 9134), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:712, {ref de Vaan 2008}:652).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. OCS лѣвъ 'left', Macedonian лев 'id.', etc.
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian блато 'marsh, swamp, bog' ({ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), see also Albanian baltë 'swamp, marsh'.
loan_notes: Cf. Macedonian блато 'marsh, swamp, bog', cf. also Albanian baltë

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian лови, Serbo-Croatian loviti 'to hunt'.
Loan ultimately from Turkish yemiş 'fruit' (via Macedonian imìš?).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian магла 'fog'.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin rīpa 'shore, riverbank' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:605 no. 7328), further from PIE *h₁reip-h₂ 'steep slope' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:524, cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:574).
From Latin follis 'bag, sack' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:294). Further connections outside of Italic not fully certain (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:230).

Eastern Romance lexemes from Latin *pullius 'young animal' (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:565 no. 6826), further to PIE *putslo- ({ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:544, {ref de Vaan 2008}:502-505; cf. Ved. putrá- < *put-lo-).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian дише, Bulgarian дишам 'breathe'.
East Romance lexemes continuing Latin matia 'guts' (only attested in lexical works), further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:444 no. 5412, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:390).

East Romance lexemes continuing Latin geusiae 'throat' (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}), a probable loanword from Continental Celtic (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:320 no. 3750, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:274).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian корен 'root'.
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian песок 'sand'.
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian мазен 'smooth'.
Borrowing from Slavic koža 'skin', compare Macedonian koža 'skin' in /cognate/1171/ (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002}).
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. /cognate/1171/.

notes: (< Lat. dūcere 'to lead'?)
Loan from Macedonian? /cognate/4966/

justificationDiscussion: Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian плива 'to swim'.

This cognate class codes Albanian hedh 'to throw' which may be regularly derived from PIE *skeu̯d- 'to propel (forth)' ({ref LIV²} 560); the Modern Albanian variant hjedh was semantically distinct in Old Albanian and is to be derived instead from *(s)kedh₂- 'to shatter, disperse' ({ref LIV²} 550, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} and {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:976 for further discussion. For older discussions connecting to PIE *(s)keu̯d-, cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:150, {ref Huld 1984} 72-73, {ref Demiraj 1997}:197-198, {ref Orel 1998}:143-144. For the Slavic forms attached to this class, cf. {ref ESSJa} 13:252-254, {ref Derksen 2008}:265 (not in {ref LIV²}). Regarding the proposed cognacy to Proto-Germanic *skeutan- 'to shoot, dash' ({ref LIV²} 560), cf. discussion in /cognate/8120/.

Germanic lexemes appearing to continuing derivatives of a PIE root *greng̑ʰ- 'to turn', although the evidence for this root is restricted to Baltic and Germanic ({ref de Vries 1977}:330, {ref Kroonen 2013}:305-306, cf. {ref LIV²} 191).

notes: This is the puϑra- word "son, boy", in Lari with *ϑr > ç (as with Old Persian) > s.

Although Common Iranic would continue *g̑ʰ as /z/ (as with Avestan), Klingenschmitt (2000: 200, fn. 30) emphasises that /d/-forms are not a sign of loans from Persian, but the result of an early dissimilation of *d͜zasta- > *dasta-: "Die Bedeutung des Wortes und die weite Verbreitung der Lautform *dasta- schließen aus, daß es sich um eine Entlehnung aus dem Persischen (ap. dasta-, mp. dast) handelt. Die Lautform *dasta- muß vielmehr durch Dissimilation entstanden sein (vgl. Morgenstierne, EVP, S. 39)."
SW Iranic would develop *k̑ > ϑ > h.

justificationDiscussion:
Root reference form for this class tentatively follows {ref LIV²} 563, but cf. {ref ALEW} 933-934 regarding the possibility that the lexeme goes back to a secondary neo-root *(s)krei̯-dʰ- and connected to Latvian skrìet 'fly_V' in /cognate/2273/.
'
Assumed to be cognate with PIE *pe⁽k̑⁾tu- in /cognate/4015/ by Klingenschmitt (1968: 67).

No certain etymology outside of Germanic. Earlier assumed to be from an IE root *b⁽ʰ⁾(e)ū̆- with an extension -g- (cf. {ref IEW} 100). For various other uncertain proposals, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:96, {ref EWNl} 1:395.

Etymology uncertain, the lexemes have been attempted to be related to PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall', however this is phonologically problematic since one expects PIE *pe- to develop to he- in Classical Armenian, however cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:293-294 attempting to maintain the traditional etymology. Perhaps a loanword from an Indo-European Anatolian language (cf. Hitt. pattar- 'wing, feather')? See also {ref HAB} IV:498.
For multiple explanations of initial pʿ from PIE *ped- and/or *peth₂- cf. {ref Kölligan 2019}: 273ff.
Brythonic lexemes generally assumed to be loanwords from Latin nūbilus 'cloudy, overcast' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref NIL} 502n15, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} N:8).
Possibly parallel loans from Dravidian, see {ref Turner 1962–1966}:206 no. 3894, cf. also 'knee' in /cognate/2792/, 'leg' in /cognate/9630/.
Possibly parallel loans from Dravidian, see {ref Turner 1962–1966}:206 no. 3894, cf. also 'knee' in /cognate/2792/, 'foot' in /cognate/9629/.
Loanword from Arabic اخسأ

notes: {Kashmiri form after pyonu dat. pĕnas ʻto drink' (cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3867)?, cf. Armenian kc(an)em "bite" (5942)}
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes likely to be continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰād-, further connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:445, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:203-204 no. 3865, 3867, {ref EWAia} I:451-452, {ref LIV²} 559-560).

Brythonic Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic preverb *tu- + *ag- 'to drive', ultimately cognate with PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' ({ref Schumacher 2004}:189-193, cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:27, {ref LIV²} 255-256).
Loan from Sanskrit pr̥thivī́- 'earth'.
Parallel loans from Hindi लड़ना / laṛnā ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:633 no. 10920, {ref Turner 1931}:548).
From PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'to overcome, conquer' ({ref LIV²} 670-671, cf. {ref Schumacher 2004}:683-688, {ref Matasović 2009}:421).
Loanword from Dardic, cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:37.
Loanword from Latin piscātus 'a catch of fish' ({ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).
Parallel loans from Persian گل / gol 'flower'.
Loanword from Catalan or Occitan bǫsc 'forest' ({ref DCECH} I:636-637).
Loan from Old French forest (cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:297, {ref DCECH} II:919).
Baltic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'to grow, become strong' ({ref ALEW} 67-69, {ref Seebold 1970}:532-533, {ref Kroonen 2013}:566).

For Khowar, cf. Vedic akṣa- 'blue vitriol' only attested in lexicographical works, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:2, no. 24; for Pashto from Proto-Iranic axšai̯na- 'dark coloured, dark blue', cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:79. For the probable cognate relationship between the two on the basis of Proto-Indo-Iranic *akša-, cf. {ref KEWA} I:543, {ref EWAia} III:3.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair'. Further etymology disputed, either (1)  with Lithuanian šerỹs 'bristle' < *k̑er(H)- ({ref Kluge 2011}:382, cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:443), or (2) from PIE *k̑es- 'to arrange in order; comb' ({ref Kroonen 2013}:220; if so, cf. lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *kosa 'hair, braided hair' in /cognate/8240/). A third option considered by {ref EWNl} II:360 is the possibility of a European substratum loanword.
Loanword from Persian (if inherited, expected Anlaut z-, cf. zangun 'knee' < *zānukāna- derived from PIE *g̑enu-).

Albanian and Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *gʷerh₃- 'to devour' (cf. {ref LIV²} 211-212). Albanian Arbëresh gríka 'mouth' is equivalent to Standard Albanian grýkë 'throat' ({ref Rohr 2000}:31; for the root etymology see {ref Demiraj 1997}:297-298; cf. {ref Orel 1998}:126). The Modern Indic lexemes are as though from Sanskrit gilana- 'swallowing', continuing a derivative of Vedic √gar-ⁱ (2) 'to devour' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:223 no. 4164, {ref EWAia} I:469-470).

This cognate class is based on the assumption that ModIr. scáil f. 'shadow' continues OIr. scál m. 'phantom', involving a semantic shift and a change of gender or MIr. scáile masc. and fem. 'shadow, reflexion, image, illusion'. 
If one rejects this connection, it would be possible to postulate *skeh₃-lā- vel sim. for Ir. scáil, Sc. sgàil and connect them with /cognate/8269/. However, this has not been suggested so far, probably because there does not seem to be any evidence for a feminine word denoting 'shadow' before Late Middle / Early Modern Irish.

Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit ākāśá- 'sky' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:45 no. 1008), to be further connected with Vedic √kāś- 'to be visible, appear' and further to PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ({ref EWAia} I:344-345, {ref LIV²} 383-385).

Modern Indic lexemes reflecting Sanskrit ākhyāti 'tells' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:47 no. 1041) and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kāzati, both probably to be derived from PIE *kʷek̑- ({ref LIV²} 383-385, cf. {ref EWAia} I:456-457, {ref Derksen 2008}:222, {ref ESSJa} 4:100-101, 9:168-170).
Loan from Arabic بحر / baḥr 'sea'.
Loanword from Turkic, cf. /cognate/3329/.
loan_notes: Cf. Turk. dengiz 'sea'. To judge from the distance between the Pamirs and the Caucasus, probably separate loan events from Ossetic lexemes in /cognate/3229/.

justificationDiscussion: Phonology excludes inheritance
Parallel loans from Sanskrit sū́rya- 'sun'.
Loanword from Arabic جلد 'skin, leather'.
Etymology uncertain, cf. {ref Emmerick & Skjærvø 1997}:146-150 with extensive discussion and rejecting the etymology of {ref Bailey 1979}:404 to Proto-Iranic *aiu̯a- 'one').
Loan from Persian ستاره / setāreh 'star'

Light verb constructions using verbal nouns of Latin regere 'to guide, direct, govern' as the semantic-bearing head. For Neapolitan all'erta cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:257 no. 2899 Lat. erigere, erēctus 'erheben, aufrichten', 2. *ergere, *erctus. Further to PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ({ref LIV²} 304-305, {ref de Vaan 2008}:517-518).  Parallel late derivation in Old Occitan drech, dreit cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:241 no. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade'.
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Persian راست / rāst, Tajik рост / rōst.

notes: Loan from Persian
justificationDiscussion: Parallel loans from Persian سگ / sag 'dog'.
Internal -h- and -b- can only be from Persian, we would expect zero or x for h and p for b in an inherited word
Internal -g- cannot be inherited

Nuristani lexemes in light verb constructions. Cognacy in this set is coded for 'water', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:19 no. 407 s.v. Vedic áp-, pl. ā́paḥ 'waters'. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'water' in /cognate/157/.
See discussion under https://cobl.info/cognate/5512/

See discussion under https://cobl.info/cognate/5697/.  And see also https://cobl.info/cognate/9689/.
The loan is so early that it is inconsistent to call it a parallel loan into both Middle and modern Dutch, rather than a loanword event type that at least Modern Dutch did inherit by transmission from Middle Dutch (or a closely related variety).

See discussion under https://cobl.info/cognate/5697/.  And see also https://cobl.info/cognate/9688/.
Inclusion of Luxembourgish here is questionable, as not directly derived from Middle *High* German, but it is not clear that this loanword appears so early that there was likely little real separation of the Luxembourgish lineage from those that led to the other languages included in this cognate set.

The West Germanic lexemes in this set are parallel loans from Old French. 
The same original Old French source was also loaned into other West Germanic languages. 
 Given the timing of the loans after the basic Dutch/German fragmentation is taken to have already begun, these define separate loan event cognate sets:   
https://cobl.info/cognate/9688/ in Dutch;  https://cobl.info/cognate/9689/ in Upper German. 

A later, follow-on loan-event from Middle Low German into North Germanic languages, is https://cobl.info/cognate/5697/.  

Cf. {ref Den Danske Ordbog}. {ref Kluge 2011}:777-778, {ref Oxford English Dictionary (OED)}, {ref Svenska Akademiens ordbok}).
Parallel loans from Old French.  See also https://cobl.info/cognate/6198/, a further cognate set with the same Old French loan source, but parallel loans into English and Frisian..
Old Frisian has berna while the Modern West Frisian variant is baarne, which is not a loanword
Frisian doesn't have open syllable lengthening - cannot be Frisian; OFri. liwere
comp. EFri. dialects säie, sii etc.
the archaic form is tsjok - rarely used nowadays
[frɔu] - likely from Middle Dutch; Also 'person'. AF: mins.

Although also the name of the internal organ 'stomach', in the variety of English targeted here, i.e. standard British English and following majority usage in England, the word 'stomach' has broadened to refer to the abdomen in general, and is has become the default, unmarked word for the target sense here.  The lexeme 'belly' is more marked in register, often with overtones of a protruding 'pot belly'..
See also the independent loan of the same ultimate Greek source lexeme into a variety of Macedonian, at https://cobl.info/cognate/7400.
loan_source: Ultimately Greek, but via Latin and then directly from Norman 'French'.

justificationDiscussion: No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:398-399, {ref Kroonen 2013}:434, 491 for further discussion.

Cognacy in this set follows {ref Cheung 2007}:93 to Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to devour', but cf. {ref Morgenstierne 2003}:33 suggesting instead to *gaz- 'to bite'. Outside of Iranic further cf. Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas-, cf. Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, devour, gnaw'. No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. {ref LIV²} 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.
Of uncertain origin, but generally considered a loanword from Basque txakur 'dog' (cf. {ref DCECH} I:728-729, {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:745 No. 8959a for further discussion).

loan_notes: No ṣ indicates loan from MIA
ẓ for r indicates via Saṇu-viri

justificationDiscussion: Cf. Torwali lāš, Chilis lačo 'bad', all of which require -tr-, as well as further Indic lexemes continuing *latta-, *lanta-, etc., 'defective'. No etymology outside of Indic.

Modern Indic lexemes meaning 'take, bring' derived from Indo-Iranian *naya- 'lead' and ultimately Proto-Indo-European *nei̯H- 'lead', cf. also Hittite nēanzi 'leads'. Cf. Ḍumāki nḗi-na 'to take away, carry off', Pashai nay-, nē- 'to lead, carry away', Assamese ni-ba 'to carry from one place to another', etc.

Etymology unknown; some relation, either divergent (derivation from a common source) or convergent (sound substitution through paradigmatic/syntagmatic analogy due to semantic proximity), with cognate/6095, cognate/6350, and/or cognate/3151 is plausible. Note that seemingly unmotivated retroflexes also appear, e.g., in lexeme/62214.
Cf. 7300 Kalaṣa-alâ: Nišeigrâm: čâpṭa?

notes: Probably reflects the root Proto-Turkic *čöp 'dregs', reflected as čöp 'dregs, dirt, refuse' in Uyghur, Chaghatay, Middle Turkic, etc. Note also the vocalism of Chagatay derivative čäp-räk 'dregs, dirt' (cf. Räsänen, Clauson ad rem) as well as the forms Uzbek čụp, Middle Turkic ču/üp (Dybo 2006–).
justificationDiscussion: Initial ts- indicates a loan, perhaps from one of the neighboring Indo-Aryan or Nuristani languages that dentalize č>c. Cf. also cognate/9142.

Indo-Aryan lexemes meaning 'ground, earth', originally a Classical Sanskrit epithet dháraṇī (bhū́mi) 'supporting (earth)' from Sanskrit dhár- 'hold, keep', ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *dher- 'fasten'.

notes: Morgenstierne 1940:251 attests the noun in the meaning 'bird', which may be an error, cf. also (ibidem) an attestation of the lexeme in an unclear meaning.
justificationDiscussion: Light verb construction with the same noun as the light verb construction lexeme/62224.
Retained intervocalic stops indicate a loan.

notes: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11348 s.v. *varta- 'round stone', *'rolled / rolling stone', from PIE *uert- 'roll, rolled; turn, spin', cf. Skrt. vartula- 'round, circular', Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 156
justificationDiscussion: Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indo-Iranic *varta- *'turning around, circular object' → 'round stone', further to be derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to revolve' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:661 no. 11348, {ref KEWA} II:154-156, cf. {ref LIV²} 691-692).

notes: Attested as nāŋg by Morgenstierne 1940:245, who states that secondary nasalization preserved the intervocalic plosive and thus assumes the word is inherited (cf. also Nepali, Lahnda nā̃g with nasal vowel (ibid.) and the Nuristani theonym noŋ (Turner 7039)). The nasalization could simply have since been lost in Gawri. However, the forms indicating ŋ(g) could also conceivably be loaned from Persian nahaŋ, as suggested by Turner 7039.
justificationDiscussion: Retention of intervocalic plosive suggests a Sanskrit loanword.
Modern Indo-Iranian lexemes continue Sanskrit magha- '*fragrance', 'kind of flower', also reflected in Prakrit, Nepali, Oriya, Hindi, Gujarati.

Derived from the verb γyr- 'to turn' and further to Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind', without clear correspondences outside of Iranic (Samadi 1986:84, Cheung 2007:104). Probably further related to Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn' in cognate set 8398.

Presumably not a compound, so retained intervocalic stop indicates loanword. Source unclear; Burushaski abáš 'Schwierigkeit, Unglück; (Adverb:) schwierig' is connected by Berger with Shina abáš (no meaning given) and tentatively with the Shina and Khowar necessitative particle baš, which goes back to Indic váśya- 'be subjected, obedient' (T 11433).
Morgenstierne 1973: 172 "to crush with the teeth"
Light verb construction using a noun denoting 'mill' (originally, 'controlling device'), itself a nomen agentis of an Indo-Iranic root meaning 'control' with no secure parallels outside Indo-Iranian.
Light verb construction with a noun denoting 'water'
Continuing a derivative of Vedic káṇa- 'a grain of corn' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:113 no. 2661). Further etymology uncertain (cf. {ref {EWAia} I:291).

Assamese jui 'fire', continuing Vedic jyótis- 'light, brightness' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:292, no. 5300), a derivative of Vedic √jyot- 'to shine', a phonetic variant of Vedic √dyot- 'to shine', and a neo-root further to the same root as Vedic dyáv- 'sky', itself a derivative of PIE *dei̯- 'shine' via *di̯-éu̯- (cf. {ref EWAia} I:604-605, II:750-754, {ref NIL} 69-81).
Cf. Persian maš-am 'smell' (n.)
Etymology for ǰu(ā) 'tomorrow, morning' in Morgenstierne 1973:; cf. also West Pahari ǰiši 'at dawn'. Ultimately a prefixation of PIE *h2eu̯s- 'daybreak'.
Name of a specific species of snake, literally 'cow-nose', cf. English names such as 'hognose snake' and 'cownose ray'.
Enigmatic form with -VdV- and -VsV- speaking against inherited status; might plausibly contain cognate/5015 Vedic hiá- and/or (reduplicated?) cognate/375 *dei̯-.

Lexemes in the meaning 'red' derived from IE *kʷr̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye. For Sogdian kyrm- 'snake, worm' > qyrmyr, cf. {ref EWAia} I:394-395. Probable late parallel replacement/shift with Slavic /cognate/1163/.  See 'worm' in /cognate/172/ for further etymological discussion.

Baltic (and Italic, in late parallel derivations) lexemes in the meaning 'red' are derived from IE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye ({ref von Wartburg 1922–2002} 14:288-291, {ref de Vaan 2008}:665, {ref Derksen 2015}:567), cf. also /cognate/1163/. See 'worm' in /cognate/348/ for further etymological discussion.

Light verb constructions using verbal nouns of Latin regere 'to guide, direct, govern' as the semantic-bearing head. For Old Occitan drech, dreit cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:241 no. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade'. Further to PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ({ref LIV²} 304-305, {ref de Vaan 2008}:517-518).  Parallel late derivation in Neapolitan all'erta cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:257 no. 2899 Lat. erigere, erēctus 'erheben, aufrichten', 2. *ergere, *erctus;

Late parallel derivations in Brythonic Celtic and Raji: Barzoki.  Lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. {ref Kortlandt 2003}:77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in /cognate/6370/ which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. {ref EWAia} I:693-694, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:352 no. 6152, {ref Deshayes 2003}:170, {ref Matasović 2009}:90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in /cognate/328/.

Late parallel derivations in Brythonic Celtic and Gawarbati.  Lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. {ref Kortlandt 2003}:77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in /cognate/6370/ which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. {ref EWAia} I:693-694, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:352 no. 6152, {ref Deshayes 2003}:170, {ref Matasović 2009}:90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in /cognate/328/.

Indic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *(s)kend- 'to shine' ({ref EWAia} I:528-529, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:252 no. 4661, {ref Demiraj 1997}:199-200, {ref Orel 1998}:146-147, {ref Holm 2011}:70-71; cf. {ref LIV²} 554).

The further IE cognacy and the PIE root are not entirely clear (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:323, {ref Boryś 2005}:579, {ref Rejzek 2001}:604-605, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1362-1363. Probable late parallel replacement/shift found in other Slavic languages. For further citations see /cognate/1128/.

The further IE cognacy and the PIE root are not entirely clear (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:323, {ref Boryś 2005}:579, {ref Rejzek 2001}:604-605, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1362-1363. Probable late parallel replacement/shift found in other Slavic languages.  For further citations see /cognate/1128/.

The further IE cognacy and the PIE root are not entirely clear (cf. {ref Bezlaj 1977-2005} 3:323, {ref Boryś 2005}:579, {ref Rejzek 2001}:604-605, {ref Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}:1362-1363. Probable late parallel replacement/shift found in other Slavic languages.  For further citations see /cognate/1128/.

Celtic (and Iranic) lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' (cf. {ref Cheung 2007}:6-10, {ref Bailey 1979}:499, {ref MacKenzie 1990}:112, {ref Matasović 2009}:62). Late parallel replacement/shift in Iranic, /cognate/9784/.

Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing different derivatives and light-verb constructions derived from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to carry, drive' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:494 no. 8792, p.677 no. 11612, {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref Cheung 2007}:429-432).  For further citations see /cognate/7464/.

Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing different derivatives and light-verb constructions derived from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to carry, drive' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:494 no. 8792, p.677 no. 11612, {ref EWAia} II:535-537, {ref Cheung 2007}:429-432).  For further citations see /cognate/7464/.

Loanword from Persian داغ / dāġ ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010} I:293).
Parallel loans from Persian خراب / xarāb (< Arabic 'destruction')
Loan from Persian پوزه / pōz(e) 'muzzle, snout'
Parallel loans from Persian daryāb; cf. 'lake' in /cognate/2771/ and 'sea' in /cognate/2011/.
According to {ref Turner 1962–1966}:463 no. 8201, Assamese paruwā < *pawarā < *papaḍa-?
"In meaning 'ice' (< 'solid' : but cf. Wkh. sǖr) phonet. doubtful: Dm. sōr 'ice', Phal. sōr, swōr, Sh.jij. sōr." (Turner ad rem)
From Latin crusta 'crust, shell', probably from PIE *krus-to- from a root *kreu̯s- 'to thrust, pound' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:147 for further discussion).
Turner (based on Morgenstierne 1940) has Bashkarik [sic] čhār- (c̣h-?) 'be lost', but the existence of Khowar c̣horik 'fall' (ibid.) might imply polysemy that Morgenstierne did not record.

Most closely resembles OIA [phup]phusa- m. 'lungs', as Gawri -s- can only go back to -s(y)-, and thus certainly a derivation of the root *phūṭ- 'blowing, puffing', probably onomatopoetic in origin and perhaps related to *phaṇati 'swells, rises, boils', though details are unclear.

The nominal base seems related to the widespread word for 'steam, smoke', which is also found in Hindi (dax, dux), Persian (duxān) , and possibly Arabic daxana (cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 361) and is etymologically unclear, seemingly belonging to the large group of Arabo-Persian vocabulary.

Previously unrecorded. Almost certainly related to the other Iranic lexemes in cognate class /7164/, but perhaps a loan, as the retroflex in Wakhi would require a sequence *či̯- according to current knowledge.

Etymology not fully clear. A protoform *darš(a)ya-, perhaps related to Vedic dar- 'crush, split' and/or dṛṣad- '(mill)stone' (also in Khowar and Waigali), would be phonologically and semantically plausible ({ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 168, {ref EWAia}: I: 741). An early loan from Indic cannot be excluded.
Tentatively connected with Persian, Sogdian and Yidgha verbs but with no etymology outside Iranic.

notes: Several Eastern Iranic languages have d > l (Bactrian, Yidgha-Munji, Pashto). Yidgha-Munji has būi 'smell' (from Persian bū, Morgenstierne 1938 q.v.), so the origin of the Wakhi word must be a different one. There are several other basic words with d > l in Wakhi ('demon', 'hand', 'tooth', 'middle', 'sweat', cf. Morgenstierne 1938: 455), which probably do not all derive from Yidgha-Munji.
loan_source: Ultimately Persian, via an unclear Eastern Iranic language

justificationDiscussion: Presumably derived from Proto-Iranic *zgar- 'flow', in turn from Proto-Indo-European *gʷĝʰer- 'id.' (cf. Vedic kṣarati 'flow away'), with a semantic shift from 'flow' via 'amble, walk along'. -γ- would be expected for -g-, cf. {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 436, but here are multiple cases of stop~fricative oscillation. See {ref Cheung 2007}: 474 for parallel semantic shifts.
Previously unrecorded and with no etymology.
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. {ref Horn 1893}: 97 and {ref ESIJa}: II: 226.

notes: Attribution to the PIE root *trenk(ʷ)- (cognate class 8718) is ruled out on phonological grounds. The Wakhi reflex of this root is tranǰ-, etc., cf. {ref Cheung 2007}: 395.
justificationDiscussion: Etymology not entirely clear. Morgenstierne's ad-hoc proposition of *srišna-, tentatively accepted by Steblin-Kamenskij, does not seem to have any contenders (cf. {ref Morgenstierne 1938}: 544, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}: 344). Similar formations reflecting the root *sra- are found in neighboring Iranic languages.

alsoUsedInOtherMeanings: Cf. 'give' in /cognate/1010/, 'do' in /cognate/5125/, 'hit' in /cognate/9507/, and 'say' in /cognate/7330/.

justificationDiscussion: Traditionally derived from PIE *h₂onh₁-mo- 'breath' > 'wind' as in Greek, cf. /cognate/1556/, although this requires the assumption of an ad hoc dissimilation of *-nm- > Arm. -łm- (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:27, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:416). {ref Kölligan 2017} more recently proposes an etymology with Armenian hołm continuing an original epithet 'shaking (wind)', cognate with Greek πόλεμος 'war' which he analyses as an original epithet 'shaking (of spears)', both from *polh₁-mo- which would be phonologically fully regular. The etymology of the proposed Greek comparandum πόλεμος 'war' < *'shaking, trembling' is not universally agreed upon, however (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:875-876, {ref Beekes 2010}:1218-1219).

Danish traeffe (not target meaning for HIT in any case) appears to be a loan from German (perhaps Low German), not a cognate with 2708.  
https://ordnet.dk/ddo/ordbog?query=træffe&set_language=da

loan_notes: 'a body part'; loan because of ǰ instead of z; cf. also cognate/8475/

justificationDiscussion: Nuristani lexemes possibly deriving from PIE *pro-kʷi̯eu̯-.
Loaned from Vedic *āpula- 'abundant' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:55, no. 1211), cf. Vedic vipula- 'extended, wide'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. {ref EWAia} II:557-558).

loan_notes: PIE *h₂ost-; loss of s implies < MIA

justificationDiscussion: PIE *kerk̑- via OIA kr̥ś-, with r̥ś > r̥ṣ in Nur.

notes: Strand: Khowar tseq (/ognate/9488/) is probably a loan from Kalaṣa-alâ ćik-.
loan_notes: *č > ć [ts] indicates < a later MIA dialect
loss of *s indicates loan < IA < PIE *h₂ster-

justificationDiscussion: According to {ref Deshayes 2003}:426, a loan from French pincer 'to pinch' (denasalised) + the verbal prefix kra-.
A derived verb based on Latin fūr 'thief' ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}:306), which continues PIE *bʰōr, a derivative of PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ({ref de Vaan 2008}:251, cf. {ref LIV²} 76-77).
An inherited word would have nn instead of r, and indeed pan(n) still exists in the meaning 'blade of a watermill'
{ref Turner 1962–1966}:789 no. 13693 considers from *stinta- 'wet', with some reservations about the diachronic phonology.

notes: The Lari form may contain an inchoative suffix. Not noted in Cheung (2007).
justificationDiscussion: No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic ({ref EWAia} I:451-452, cf. {ref LIV²} 359-360), cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:203, no. 3865. The Kumzari and Lari forms are not in {ref Cheung 2007}, but the PIr. root *xād- < PIIr. *kʰād- seems the best candidate here.

notes: {Extended root *h₁ei̯- (of the "facere" type), attested in Albanian only., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7955 s.v. Vedic pálāyate ʻfleesʼ (TS); cf. Vedic párā + i (áyate?), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 233}
justificationDiscussion: Albanian and Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ({ref Turner 1962–1966}:448 no 7955, {ref KEWA} II:233, {ref EWAia} I:102, {ref Orel 1998}:154, cf. {ref LIV²} 232-233).

Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:95 no. 2029, {ref EWAia} I:775, {ref Cheung 2007}:55, {ref Steblin-Kamenskij 1999}:273-274, {ref Derksen 2008}:114-115, {ref ESSJa} 5:99-100, {ref LIV²} 153).

notes: Gharib suggests *yaunikā- for Sogdian

The Tregâmî form, omitted in {ref Turner 1962–1966}:367 no. 6438, is practically identical to that of closely related Waigali given ibidem and {ref Morgenstierne 1952}:130. Both forms might be Indic loans.
justificationDiscussion: Indo-Iranic lexemes for 'woman' continuing a reflex of Vedic durbala- 'weak, impotent; slender', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:367 no. 6438.
Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic lañja- m. 'tail', probably from a non-Aryan root, cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:632 no. 10915.

Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic raṅga- 'dye, colour', from a root raj- 'be colored, be red, redden' of uncertain further etymology. Cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:611 no. 10560 and {ref EWAia}II: 424.
Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic samá- 'equal, alike, level', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:762 no. 13173.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic praguṇa- 'proper, suitable; straightforward', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 481 no. 8473.

loan_notes: Loan because of j (for inherited z)

justificationDiscussion: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic viśālá- 'spacious, broad', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:691 no. 11936.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic saru- 'fine', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 766 no. 13264, {ref Kakati 1941}: 96.
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-European *ml̥h₃dʰ-, cf. Vedic mūrdhán- 'forehead, head, top part', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:591 no. 10247, {ref EWAia} II:368, {ref Bailey 1979}:52.

notes: Composed of a Tajik prefix bē- and an unclear root, cf. {ref Novák 2010}:14.

justificationDiscussion: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-European *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew', cf. {ref LIV²}: 168, {ref Cheung 2007}: 226

Iranic lexemes continuing *kamā- 'neck', cf. Sogdian qmʾ 'neck, throat', perhaps also Wakhi kâmī́, Sanglechi kamák 'back'. Connections to either /cognate/2293/ or the root *kamp- 'bend' (cf. {ref ESIJa}:IV 197) are phonologically doubtful as loss of the labial/liquid is unexplained (Kümmel, p.c.).
Modern Indic lexemes as if from Sanskrit saṁtāra 'crossing over', ultimately PIE *terh₂- 'cross', cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 747
Modern Indic lexemes as if from Vedic prátirati and *praturati 'cross, go to sea', both variants of prátarati 'cross', ultimately PIE *terh₂- 'cross' cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}: 483, 485, 487.
See OED entry 25440

Loan from Latin aēr 'air, atmosphere, sky' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} A:20-21, {ref Broaderick 1984b}:4, {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:24, {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}).  The same Latin form was also loaned in parallel into Brythonic, see /cognate/1096/
Loanword from Middle Low German ({ref Den Danske Ordbog}).
Loanword from Low German bange 'afraid' ({ref Den Danske Ordbog}).

No certain etymology outside of Hittite ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}: 573-575), cf. also {ref HED M}: 126-140 and Tischler (1990), Hethitisches etymologisches Glossar L–M, pp.186-191 for further discussion of older literature.
